title: Nikon Says He Preserved Tapes As Protection Against His Aides; Nixon Says Tapes Were Protection From Aides; Suspicious of Prosecutor; Oval Office Conversations; Dissuaded by Family
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon says in his memoirs that he did not destroy the taperecorded conversations that led to his resignation from office because he suspected that some of his aides might turn against him and the tapes would give me at least some protection.

title: STOCK RALLY IN U.S. CONTINUES TO DRAW FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: Ever since it began two weeks ago, the spectacular stock market rally has ben attracting an influx of foreign, investment, notably from Britain. West Germany and Switzerland.

title: Pop: Masekela And Alpett
description: HERB ALPERT. and Hugh Masekela.are not the world's most accomplished trumpeters. When they improvise they tend to work in broad strokes, without much sublety or detail, and their work can be quite ragged when they aren't playing strict parts together. But Mr. Alpert, who used to lead the Tijuana Brass and is a founder and executive with A.&M. records, and Mr. Masekela, the South African expatriate trumpet player and bandleader, have come together to turn their limitations into advantages.

title: Seattle Slew Returns to Big A
description: Seattle Slew, last year's king of the turf, made his return to Aqueduct yesterday. but only in the role of a mati.pee idol, not as a horse to bet on.

title: A Rhodesian Wallace? Tsktsk.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, in attempting to solve the problems of Southern Africa, has unwisely made a villain of Robert Mugabe. Press accounts of his trip last month indicated that Mr. Vance wanted to edge Mr. Mugabe out of a new Rhodesian settlement. Earlier, a Vance aide wrongly likened Mr. Mtigabe's electoral possibilities to those of George C. Wallace.

title: 25 Are Arrested at May Day Event Near North Carolina State Campus
description: RALEIGH, N.C., April 30 (UPI)Twentyfive people were arrested late last night when the police broke up May Day celebration near the North Carolina State University campus.

description: In a recent protest; it was stated with some vehemence that people who help out with:the dishes after dinner in my home are nothing if not a menace and, what with breakage,and so on,, a costly one at that.

description: A young employee of a carting company surrendered to the Nassau County police last night, a day after he allegedly shot a 49-year-old neighbor and wounded her 54-year-old husband in a busy Brooklyn intersection.

title: Bullets Top 76ers In Overtime,122-117
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 30  Elvin. Hayes, often maligned for his lackadasical play during the playoffs, scored of his 28 points in a fiveminute overtime today and the Washington Bullets defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 122117, at the Spectrum.

title: Teng, Challenging Mao Ideology, Says Students Role Is to Study
description: HONG KONG, April 30In a major 4.Veech on education that seems to challenge some of Mao Tsetung's most fundamental ideals for a new society, Deputy Prime Minister Tang Hsiaoping has aAserted that the main task of students is to study. and that examinations are as necessary to schools as quality control is to faciories.

title: Hospital Group Gets New Head
description: David A. Reed, president of Lenox Hill Hospital since May 1969, has been elected chairman of the Greater New York Hospital Association, the coordinating body for the city's major voluntary and municipal hospitals. He succeeds Msgr. James P. Cassidy. director of the health and hospitals.division of the Catholic Charities of the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese.

title: Paris Police Chief During 68 Revolt Ponders His Role:
description: PARIS, April 30 Ten years ago Maurice Grimaud reluctantly led the police against the barricades of a student revolt that profoundly shook French society. Today the former Paris police chief is still trying to portray himself as a man caught in the middle

title: Anderson Apparently Weathering Storm Over Medicaid Abortions
description: ALBANY, April 28The battle over Medicaidfinanced abortions rocked the State Legislature early this month, shaking the leadership of Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, who was dramatically rebuffed by his fellow Republicans in a the eve of the passage of the state budget. Although tempestuous showdown on Mr. Anderson eventually persuaded his colleagues to stop holding the budget hostage over the issue, many legislators questioned whether the episode would shatter his ability to lead for the rest of the year. That was a few weeks ago, of course, and it now appears that time really does heal many wounds in Albany.

title: Convening on 34th Street
description: New York City's selection of the 34th Street site for the new convention centeris welcome news after years of seesawing uptown and downtown in search of the perfect location. Yes, we have seesawed with the best of them. There is no perfect location; each proposal has been a study in compromise. But the underused land of the Pennsylvania railyards adjacent to the Hudson River has many advantages in flexibility, cost and speed that the original platform site in the river at 44th Street lacked.

title: Marjorie Marks Is Bride of Allen Carney
description: Marjorie Carol Marks, daughter of Mr: and Mrs. Stanley H. Marks of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Allen Patrick Carney of Cambridge. Mass. Rabbi Barton Shallat performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meaddw Country Club in Great Neck. L. I.

title: Native Dancer and the Derby
description: ABOUT midafternoon on Derby Day, Bill. Winfrey left the barn on the back side of Churchill Downs walk his wife, Elaine, and two visitors around the grandstand side. Before departing, he peered into Native Dancer's stall. The gray colt was snoozing.

title: Bostock Market
description: WELL, Lyman Bostock, that greatly talented and remunerated young Angel outfielder, has announced that he will donate his salary for, the month of April to charity. A week or so ago, he was so disappointed with his batting averageit hovered considerably closer to the last three figures, 000, of his annual salary than to the first three, 450that he announced he would return his April pay to the club if his hitting didn't improve significantly. Gene Autry, the Angel owner, said no, no, he wouldn't think of accepting the Money, so newhis bat not heated upBostock said he would parcel out his pay to deserving parties.

title: Lancers 1, Tea Men 0
description: FOXBORO, Mass., April 30 (AP) The Rochester Lancers defeated the New England Tea Men, 10, today by winning a shootout, in a North American Soccer League game.

title: Islanders Analyze Why They Are Outb of Playoffs
description: The Islanders promising season has ended long before they hoped it would. When the Toronto. Maple Leafs beat them, 21, on Lanny McDonald's goal in overtime Saturday night and cap tured the National Hockey League quarterfinal .playoff series, the Islanders became just another New York winter sports team asking these questions: Why? How?

description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 30  An esI pionage trial, scheduled to begin here tomorrow, carries an implied threat that could reduce the leaks of Government information that in recent years hive frequently disturbed the Nixon, Ford and Carter Administrations.

description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)Thc Government has begun secret exploratory research on .a. new nuclear blast bomb for the military that would produce increased heat and blast but reduced radioactive fallout.

title: Dolls That Are Character Studies, Not Toys
description: From potter to dress designer to dollmaker  an unlikely progression, but that's the saga of an unlikely young woman named Diana Deiss. She has long crinkly hair, light blue eyes rimmed in kohl and a star tattooed on her forehead. And her dolls are rather unlikely,too: Salammbo, Virginia Woolf and Harriet Tubman are among the characters she's chosen to depict. The dolls are not for children to play with but for adults to collect, to contemplate, to take inspiration from.

description: TORONTO, April 30 Prosecution of Toronto newspaper and its top executives for publishing details of a secret report on Soviet spies in Canada has caused a backlash against Government secrecy among publishers and editors across the country.

title: U.S. Is Offering Greater Yields
description: The Trelsury will sell $4 billion of notes and bonds this week. and the yields on the two issues will be the highest available to investors since August 1975.

title: Johnny Harris, Soviet Hero
description: The other day, a Soviet journalist was refused permission to interview an inmate of a maximumsecurity prison in Alabama. The warden was concerned that the Russians would make propaganda out of it. Doubtless so. Still, we think he should have said yes to the visitor.

title: ISRAELI WITHDRAWAL IN LEBANON RESUMED

title: Sporting Gear
description: Women who wear pretty tennis outfits usually have an ugly problem: what to do with the extra tennis ball while serving. While Chris Evert has a ballperson at her disposal, pocketless females are forced to tuck a ball under a panty leg or place it on the court, which is a dangerous practice. Geoffrey Beene, the designer, has a solutiona tennis skirt with a buttonon apron in front that holds two tennis balls. The stylish skirt, made of white, doublestitched cotton, can also be worn without the apron. As Bonwit Teller for $32.

title: Chorale Sings Bach Mass
description: THE Collegiate Chorale's presentation of Bach's Mass in minor Saturday night at Carnegie Hall was marked by superior choral singing, perfectly fine orchestral playing and solo singing that was always competent If never outstanding. But avobe all the performance benefited from the cohesive, highly sympathetic conception of the conductor, Richard Westenburgwhb naturally can also be credited for much of the excellence of the ensemble playing and singing.

title: Ratings Fight Is a Rerun
description: THESE days it is more accurate to speak of a network ratings campaign than of a television season. The classic season .had a beginning, middle and end, and the end of what should have been .the current season would have occurred about three weeks ago. Instead, the networks frenzied ratings competition continues, building up to new climaxes. Moreover, it shows no sign of abating even during the summer.

title: Catholic Missionaries in Rhodesia, Caught in the Middle, Fare Badly
description: SALISBURY,- Rhodesia, April 29  For eight weeks there has been an unusual lull in one of the ugliest ,aspects of Rhodesia's worsening guerrilla war. A glance in a chronicle maintained by the Roman. Catholic Church here in the capital shows that there have been no attacks on isolated missions since Feb. 25, when a crowd of blacks sacked what once had been one of the most successful outposts.

title: 2 Stamford Buildings Burn
description: STAMFORD,Conn., April 30 (AP)Firemen battled a blaze tonight that spread to two buildings in downtown Stamford, including one containing a furniture store, the police said. No serious injuries were reported  in the fire that spread quickly because of high winds. Bath tihe furniture store and an adjoining drug rehabilitation center called Liberation House were ablaze, the police said.

title: AUTO DEALERS ARE HIT BY BOMBINGS IN ITALY
description: ROME, April 30 Bombs believed to have been set off by ultraleftists caused serious damage to dealerships of the stateowned Alfa Romeo auto company in Rome and other Italian cities this morning. No one was hurt.

title: Just Ask for Fricassee
description: Did you know that the longest word ever to appear in print has to do with food? I didn't until someone pointed it out recently in the Guinness Book of World Records. The word describes what is called a fricassee containing 17 ingredients, both sour and sweet, and including vegetable marrow, brains, pickles, honey, vinegar, the fish called mullet, plus a dash of ouzo,. the powerful, aniseflavored drink frequently offered with Greek foods. The word contains 170 letters in Greek, transliterates into English in 182 letters and appears in a comedy by Aristophanes (448330 B.C.) titled The Ecclesiazusae. The word is: lopadotemachoselachogaleokranioleipsanodrimhypotrimmatosilphioparaomelitokatakechymenokichlepikossyphophattoperisteralektryonoptekephalliokigklopeleiolagoiosi raiobaphetraganopterygon.

title: Instead, 640 'Electors
description: NEWARK, Del.Every four years, political observers devote some time to grumbling about our Electoral College systemlargely because it does not assure victory to the Presidential candidate with a majority of the popular vote.

description: Dave Johnson of the Philadelphia Phillies and Willie McCovey of the San Franeisco Giants, two former National League comeback players of the year, continued to prove yesterday that a lot of hits could he left in a ballplayer after the age of 35.

title: The Ballet: Pas de Deux For Quintet
description: IN DANCE it's often true that two's company, the pas de deux being a vehicle for emotional expression and personal display. But Saturday's matinee by 5 by 2 Plus at the American Place Theater demonstrated that five can also be good choreographic company, whereas at American Ballet Theater's Saturday evening program at the Metropolitan Opera House two dancers became bad company indeed.

title: Munson Object Of Fan Complaint

It resulted from an incident at Metropolitan Stadium on Friday night in which Stewart Thornley, a 22-year-old sophomore at the University of Minnesota, alleged that the Yankee catcher had tried to choke him.

title: Hired Hands, Not Inmates, Till Jail's Soil
description: YAPHANK, L. I.Plowing and planting began last week on a farm here that is much like a lot of other farms in Suffolk County, except that it. is part of the county jail. And unlike at other jailfarms across the country, the farming here is done by hired hands instead of prisoners.

title: Topics:
description: The people who run the Postal Service have printed a new stamp without numbers on it'nondenominational as they (and some universities) say. They propose to issue it as soon as the Postal Rate Commission formally decrees what it haS already announced: that the price of firstclass postage will rise from 13 to 15 cents an ounce. The stamps were printed, some time ago when the service was still uncertain of how much the corn.; mission would allow. Once the new rate becomes definite, the service will put the number on the new stamp. Meanwhile, however, it will meet the public bare.

title: The GiveAway Pay Plan
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 30 (UPI)Lyman Bostock, who signed as a free agent with the California Angels for a reported $950,000 a year after hitting .336 last season for the Minnesota Twins, said today that he was in such a hitting slump he was going to give his salary to charity.

title: Bucks. Win, Tie Playoff Series

title: Merrill Lynch Merger With White Weld Causes Talk, Often Critical
description: Since Merrill Lynch & Company bought White Weld Holdings Inc. two weeks ago for $50 million, Wall Street has been buzzing with rumors and inside stories, many of them critical of the two securities firms and skeptical of the outcome of the merger.

title: Afghans,ReportingSovietBacking, Proclaim Revolutionary Council

description: Seville, Spain.

description: The taxexempt bond market last week shouldered its heaviest volume so far this year, but the muscles that made it the champion of Hie securities market last year seemed to have become flabby. Interest rates climbed to their highest levels in a year or more, and new issues sold slowly.

title: Fukuda, Off to U.S., Promises to Battle Big Trade Surplus
description: TOKYO, April 30 Japan will do its best to meet its international economic responsibilities and will try hard to reduce its $8.9 billion trade surplus with the United States, according to Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda, who left for the United States today.

title: Music: The Prospective Encounter
description: IF THERE WAS a unifying theme to the New York Philharmonic's Prospective Encounter Saturday night at the Cooper Union, it was the fact that contemporary music has. no unifying theme. All six recently written works on the program demontrated the kind of diversity in styles, techniques and esthetics that composers practice today.

She chose William. Bernbach, Jerry Della Femina and Edward McCabe. And this weekend, as this 60th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies wound down at the Camelback Inn, she talked about her selection.

In life, in law and in politics, he believes that the long view is what counts, and that is the perspective he offers on the current problems of his close friend, client and confidant, Jimmy Carter.

description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 23British Columbia has decided to make treatment for heroin use compulsory in the hope of ending Canada's worst drug problem.

title: A Nuclear Gamble on India
description: President Carter has taken a calculated risk in approving another shipment of nuclear fuel to India after the Nuclear Regulatory Commission refused to issue an export license. India is the only nation that has exploded a nuclear device built with materials diverted from a civilian prograin, and it has adamantly refused to allow international inspection of all its nuclear facilities. But Mr. Carter had little choice. He promised the fuel on his visit:to India in January. And he clings to the hope that the Indians can be. brought to accept international safeguards against the misuse or nuclear materials. It is gamble worth taking.

In between the two, across the breadth of the country, thousands of Americans are expected to observe or participate in events extolling the benefits that can be derived from sunlight.

title: Newport Jazz Lists Schedule

The festival, which originated in Newport, R.I., in 1954 and moved to New York in 1972, will take place primarily in New York City with adjunct weekend concerts in Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N. J., and at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in Saratoga Springs.

description: NEW ORLEANS, May 1Ernest N. Morial, the first black ever elected Mayor of this Deep South river city, took office today, asserting, A new era has begun; the requiem has sounded for the old political order.

description: WASHINGTON, May 1President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin muted their differences today as they joined in a White House celebration of Israel's 30th anniversary attended by several hundred rabbis and other Jewish leaders that turned into a reaffirmation of IsraeliAmerican ties.

title: $11.2 Billion Payments Deficit Reported for the First Quarter
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The United States recorded an. $11.2 billion balance of payments deficit in the first quarter of 1978, compared with a $9.9 billion deficit in the last quarter of 1977, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

She received a tremendous standing ovation from the delighted 2,000-member audience at Avery Fisher Hall..

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A team of students from Martin Luther King High School in Manhattan celebrated Law Day by winning a mock trial contest in the United States Court House at Foley Square. The students played the roles of lawyers and witnesses in the trial of a fictitious civil case conducted by Chief Judge David N. Edelstein of the Federal District Court.

title: Chief Says Paterson Fire Was Set
description: PATERSON, May 1Officials here said today that the multimilliondollar fire that destroyed four industrial buildings and five residential structures in the Riverside section of the city late Saturday and early Sunday had been deliberately set.

title: Prices of Precious Metals Drop
description: Prices of precious metals declined yesterday on some carryover selling from last Friday in the absence of any significant market news.

title: 300,000 Leftists March in Madrid to Mark May Day
description: MADRID, May 1Hundreds of thousands of Spaniards took to the streets today in the first freely celebrated May Day since Francisco Franco came to power four decades ago.

title: COURT BLOCKS MOVE BY CURTISSWRIGHT AGAINST KENNECOTT
description: On the eve of a stockholder meeting to determine the future of the nation's largest copper producer, a judge interceded yesterday to block the insurgents in one of the most spectacular corporate takeover battles in many years.

title: Screen: Blacks and Mardi Gras
description: The black Mardi Gras organizations of New Orleans are the principal subject of the two films that will be shown from today through Sunday as part of the New American Filmmakers series at the Whitney Museum.The longer and more ambitious is "Always for Pleasure," by Les Blank, a Berkeley filmmaker who has previously chronicled the lives of Cajuns in rural Louisiana blacks in Texas and Chicanos in Chicago.Because Mr. Blank appears to have no point of view beyond the rubric, "Life Is for the Living," his 58-minute film tends to be structureless and finally tedious. There are endless shots of happy blacks, less footage of happy whites on St. Patrick's Day in the crescent city, the obligatory interview with an old jazz-man at Preservation Hall, where the lifeless, out-of-tune playing is an embarrassment, a fellow explaining how he cooks crawfish, towboats puffing on the Mississippi, and of course, a long look at the carnival organizations themselves.The 33-minute "The Black Indians of New Orleans" is by Maurice M. Martinez, a member of the faculty at Hunter College, and its approach is more disciplined than coherent. It focuses on two organizations, the Yellow Pocahontas and the White Eagles, their leaders, and their preparations for their parades. Unlike "Life Is for the Living," it also provides a brief historical context in a narration.Why these black equivalents of the white "krewes" have all adopted Indian names and feathered and beaded costumes is, by the way, a matter of conjecture. One is that long in the past there was a certain intermarriage between the blacks and the Indian tribes of the hinterland.

title: Banks Get Right To Keep Checks From Bouncing
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Federal Reserve Board voted today to permit member commercial banks, beginning Nov. 1, to transfer money automatically from their customers savings accounts into overdrawn checking accounts if customers request the service.

description: Selfhelp Community Services was founded in 1936 to help victims of Nazi persecution begin a new life in America. The organization's annual benefit concert Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall enlisted 45 members of the New York Philharmonic, with both featured performers German musicians.

title: Peng Shaohui, Chinese Army Aide, Served as Deputy Chief of Staff
description: TOKYO, May 1 (AP)Peng Shaohui, deputy chief of staff of China's armed forces, died in Peking, the Hsinhua press agency reported today. He was 72.

title: Unusual Clusters of Cancer Place Medical Spotlight on Rutherford
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J.Michael Arecco, a technician with New Jersey's Division of Environmental Cancer, turned the knob on a drinking fountain in the Pierrepont School, the largest elementary school in this pleasant, middleclass town eight miles west of Manhattan. He let the water run awhile before carefully filling four sterilized bottles.

Sales (including $183.1 million, at Carborundum) rose to $427.8 million from the yearearlier $232.5 million.

title: City Opera: Turn of the Screw
description: As most coloraturas yearn to sing Bellini's Mama, boy sopranos must dream of taking on the role of Miles inBritten's The Turn of the Screw, probably the juiciest role in a treble's operatic repertory. This plum fell to Robert Sapolsky Sunday nIght at the City Opera, a performance that rang down the curtain on the company's spring season.

title: Rev. Phebe Lewald Is Bride of Cameron Coe
description: The Rev. Phebe Dillingham Lewald. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lewaid of Sherwood Forest, Md., was married yesterday in Annapolis, Md., to Cameron Coe, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Chalmers Coe of Columbus, Ohio. Bishop David K. Leighton of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland performed the ceremony in St. Anne's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the bridegroom's father, pastor of the First Congregational Church in Columbus. and by the Rev. Richard V. Landis, rector of St. Anne's.

title: M'GUIRE IS SHIPTING UNIT ON CORRUPTION
description: The first major administrative reorganization of the New York City Police Department in several years was announced yesterday by Robert J. McGuire, the Police Commissioner.

title: Two CliffHangers for New York City
description: On June 30, New York City's present loan agreement with the United States Treasury expires. The next day, the city's new fiscal year begins, and Mayor Koch has now submitted his proposed budget for it. Without sound budget, Congress will not enact the new loan agreement necessary to avert default. Mr. Koch's budget would be sound were it not missing two elements. First, the city's labor coststhe largest single factor in the expense budgethave not yet been established. Second, the document remains subject to a new, complex- ratification procedure by the City Council and the Board Estimate, which could result in substantial disagreements, changes and delays. These delays could kill the city's hopes.

title: Lone Sledcler Reaches North Pole; 54Day Trek Is First of Its Kind
description: A Japanese explorer has become the first person to reach the North Pole alone by dog sled after having struggled across 600 miles of frozen Arctic Ocean and survived attacks by a marauding polar bear.

title: The Marketing of a Marxist
description: We have too many of those kind of people from up New York down here now. So said Samuel Hoover, member of the University of Maryland Board of Regents, when asked why he opposed the appointment of Prof. Bertell Oilman of New York University as chairman of Maryland University's Department of Government. Mr. Hoover objects to Professor Oilman's Marxist approaches to the study of politics. As it happens, the professor also a firstrate scholar; the Maryland University search committee chose him from among 100 candidates for the position.

Adapted by Suzanne Clauser from Grandpa and Frank, a novel by Janet Majerus, the script is drenched in the homely ingredients of what is commonly called family entertainment.

Unofficial tallies gave Mr. LaChance 1,328 votes to 1,057 votes for his opponent, Morton Malls. The official returns are to be disclosed later by the Honest Ballot Association.

title: Guards Against MeterSkimming Pressed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1A recent parking meter skimming scandal has led to an audit of Sa' Francisco's tax collection system and recommendations for stronger safeguards.

title: `RN : The Memoirs of Richard Nixon
description: Copyright 1978 by Richard Nixon

title: Jersey's Poorer School Districts Still Lag
description: New Jedsey's two-year-old school aid program, financed by an income tax, has failed to stem the growing disparity between the perpupil expenditures of rich and poor school districts, a Ford Foundationfinanced study has found.

title: New Afghan Leader Begins Selecting His Top Aides
description: NEW DELHI, May lNoor Mohammad Taraki, the new head of the Afghanistan Government, began selecting his top aides today amid signs that the country was quickly returning to normal after last Thursday's violent coup.

title: ARAFAT HINTS EASING OF R L. 0.'S ATTITUDE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1Yasir Arafat said today that the only possible solution to the Middle East problem was for the United States and the Soviet Union to provide guarantees for Israel and a Palestinian state.

title: S.E.C. CHARGES LAWYER ON POLITICAL PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a Miami lawyer with improper professional conduct as a result of her alleged involvement in a plan to make secret, unrecorded political contributions to political candidates in the Bahamas.

title: Steel Makers Expect Profit Rebound in 2d Quarter
description: Steel industry executives expect the second quarter of the year to show dramatic improvement over the first quarter, when earnings were severely depressed by the national coal strike, adverse weather and a high level of imports all of which masked a strong recovery in the demand for steel.

title: Connecticut Senate Approves Bill To Reinstate Sunday Blue Laws
description: HARTFORD, May 1After some parliamentary maneuvering, the State Senate right turns on red lights under legislation reinstating Connecticut's blue laws restricting many stares from opening on Sundays. The bill, which passed 21 to 14, now goes to Gov. Ella T. Grasso, and a spokesman said the Governor would have to study the final version before deciding whether to sign it.

title: Cambodians Settled in Thailand Join Refugee Camps
description: KHLONG YAI, April 30Thailand has begun admitting Cambodians who have long been effectively resettled in this country into the refugee camp near this fishing port.

title: Designers Discover a New Route to IndiaVia Seventh Avenue
description: First it was the Beatles. Now it's Seventh Avenue. India keeps getting discovered. While the Beatles and their followers were interested in Eastern philosophies, the gauze shirts and em- broidered peasant tops they were wearing in the 60's started a fashion trend among the young. Soon there was proliferation of little shops selling inexpensive Indianmade gauzes which became a uniform topping for jeans.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, May 1 (AP)Two teamsters today sued six current and six former trustees of the union's health and welfare fund for $7 million in damages, alleging fraudulent use of money.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, Bronx. 8 P.M. (RadioWINS, 8 P.M.)

title: Remark on West Side Clarified by Goodman
description: ALBANY, May 1Senator Roy M. Goodman, an East Side Republican who was quoted yesterday as describing, Manhattan's West Side as the quintessential disgrace of the planet, said today that he had been referring only to the part of the West Side below 42d'Street next to the piers on the Hudson River.

title: COURT BLOCKS MOVE BY CURTISSWRIGHT AGAINST KENNECOTT
description: On the eve of a stockholder meeting to determine the future of the nation's largest copper producer, a judge interceded yesterday to block the insurgents in one of the most spectacular corporate takeover battles in many years.

title: Organized Labor in Israel Holds May Day Parade, First Since 1967 War
description: TEL AVIV, May 1For the first time since before the 1967 Middle East war, organized labor in Israel held a May Day parade today.

title: Bridge
description: Two major team championships were decided Sunday, night at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I., where the Long Island Regionals were concluded.

title: Unusual Clusters of Cancer Place Medical Spotlight on Rutherford
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J.Michael Arecco, a technician with New Jersey's Division of Environmental Cancer, turned the knob on a drinking fountain in the Pierrepont School, the largest elementary school in this pleasant, middleclass. town eight miles west of Manhattan. He let. the water run awhile before carefully filling four sterilized bottles.

title: Arms Deal Delay Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged the Administration today a temporarily withdraw its proposed sale of advanced aircraft to Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

title: A Test for the Bishop
description: Whether the three black members of Rhodesia's transitional Executive Council actually agreed to the firing of Justice Minister Byron Hove is still a matter of dispute. But the fact that he was fired only underlines the extent to which the internal agreement of last March between the three and Prime Minister Ian Smith leaves whites in power. And it makes even less credible the new Government's bid for international recognition as the legitimate voice of Rhodesia's 97 percent black majority.

title: A Palestinian Office Opens in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 1A Palestine Information Office, financed by the Palestine Liberation Organization with the stated objective of informing Americans about the Palestinian people as a whole, opened in Washington today.

title: New York Labor Dispute Hints at a Jurisdictional War
description: A charge of union raiding in New York State has brought into focus the changing shape of organized labor and has set the stage for a jurisdictional war.

title: TrueGOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIVES ON PAPER Cardboard, scraps whatever was availableserve as canvases for 77 paintings and drawings done by 37 Jewish artists during internment under the Nazis, to be shown in a display starting tomorrow: The art exhibition, on loan from the Ghetto Fighters Kibbutz in Israel for a tour of American cities, is on view through Nov. 12 at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue at 92d Street. The images are titled Spiritual Resistance: Art From Concentration Camps, 19401945. Its sponsor is the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

title: Poorer Districts Still Lag Under Education Reforms

description: HACKENSACK, May 1  A former operatingroom technician at Riverdell Hospital testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he had overheard a dispute between Dr. Jascalevich and another doctor as they tried to stop the bleeding in a patient on the operating table.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: SUPPORT FOR ISRAEL AFFIRMED BY CARTER ON 30TH ANNIVERSARY
description: WASHINGTON, May 1President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin muted their differences today as they joined in a White House celebration of Israel's 30th anniversary attended by several hundred rabbis and other Jewish leaders that turned into a reaffirmation of IsraeliAmerican ties.

title: N. Carolina Deniocrats Seek Rival to Helms. Today
description: WINSTONSALEM, April 30The dominant questiobs'in Tuesday's Democratic senatorial primary are which of eight candidates has the best chance of ousting the incumbent Republican, Jesse Helms, and whether that candidate can be chosen without a runoff election.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A $10 million lawsuit filed in Federal court in Newark charged that an unarmed Newark man was shot to death by a security guard at a downtown movie theater two years ago.

title: World News Briefs
description: BONN, May 1 (AP)Robert H. Reid, an American reporter for The Associated Press, was expelled from Czechoslovakia today, apparently for interviewing member of the Charter 77 movement that has been campaigning for observance of the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accords.

Jascalevich that he had overheard a dispute between Dr. Jascalevich and another doctor as they tried to stop the bleeding in a patient on the operating table.

title: Court to Consider If Ruling by  S.E.C.  Decides Civil Suit
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Supreme Court today agreed to consider whether a ruling by the Securities and Exchange Commission should decide a subsequent civil damage suit between two private parties involving the same factual situation.

title: More Banks Raise Prime Rate to 81/4%
description: Several banks raised their basic lending rate to businesses, or prime rate, yesterday. to 8% percent from percentthe highest level since March 1975. Many of the nation's biggest banks, however, including the Bank of America and Citibank, have not changed the level of their rate.

title: U.N. Soldiers Killed in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1Within hours of the thirdstage withdrawal yesterday by Israeli troops, the United Nations peacekeeping force was involved in two violent incidents in a newly evacuated area. Two guerrillas and three United Nations soldiers were killed, and today the peacekeeping force was on alert throughout the zone.

title: Carter. TaxCut Package
description: President Carter is holding firmly to his $25 billion taxcut package, despite efforts by friendly critics and Congressmen to trim it, because he is determined to keep the economy moving on a growth path toward full employment throughout his first term. Page 51.

title: Mrs. Kin4 Defeats Miss Evert as Apples Rout Strings, 3118
description: It was a match Billie Jean King had to win. There was a World Team Tennis record crowd of 15,132, and she had taken only 19 games in her previous six singles matches against Chris Evert.

East Germans Free American in Prisoner Exchange

title: Chiefs in Good Position
description: The Kansas City Chiefs, who need all the help they can get, are in an enviable position for the National Football League draft, which starts at 10 A,M. today. Details on page 42.

title: DefIvition of Executive Vague
description: WASHINGTON, May 1After returning to Washington, Mr. Bosworth said in a ,telephone interview that he was a little vague on how he would define who was an executive. In general, he added, he had in mind top corporate officers, possibly those with the rank of vice president or higher.

title: Rodgers Sets Up Musicals Fund
description: To celebrate what his wife, Dorothy, calls two of his lifelong lovesNew York City and the musical theater, Richard Rodgers has established a $1million endowment to finance productions of new musicals in New York.

title: Midtown  Developer Gets Variance Allowing Additional Office Space
description: A controversial zoning change allowing the developer of a new midtown office building to build additional office space if it also provides a 60-foot-high groundfloor ,'galleria was approved yesterday by a divided City Planning Commission.

title: Speer Links a Rise In Price of Steel To Output Gains

description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states may not impose criminal sanctions of newspapers that print accurate reports of confidential disciplinary proceedings against judges.

description: CLIFTON PARK, N.Y.There were no sounds or signs of celebration, but In an 8-by-10 room on the second floor of the twostory wooden dwelling called 35 Kensington Avenue, in Northhampton, Mass., my grandmother had just turned 100, had entered her second century.

description: Richard M. Nixon says that during his historic trip to China in 1972 Mao Tsetung told him that he was comparatively happy when rightwing governments took power in Western countries.

title: More Citicorp Work Earned by SSC&B

description: TRENTON, April 1 (UPI)New Jersey's Civil Service workers generally do not have a favorable image, according to a Rutgers University poll.

title: Banks Get Right To Keep Checks From Bouncing
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Federal Reserve Board voted today to permit member commercial banks, beginning Nov. 1, to transfer money automatically. from their customers savings accounts into overdrawn checking accounts if customers request the service.

title: Moderate Quake Off Coast
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 1 (UPI) A rolling earthquake, termed moderate, shook sections of the coast early today and knocked the sheriff's department radio off the air. Seismologists at Cal Tech in Pasadena said the 1:03 A.M. ternblor, centered offshore in the Santa Bar- bara Channel, registered 3.7 on the Richter scale. The sheriff's department in Coleta. just west of Santa Barbara, said its radio equipment was out of commisSion for two-and-a-half hours following the quake.

title: New Coach of Pistons: Vitale, a Super Salesman
description: Amid a fanfare of bugles, drums and cannon fire, the Detroit Pistons touched off a new era of basketball salesmanship yesterday in the Silverdome. Actually they hired a coach who is his best publicrelations director.

Hove, the black Justice Minister, will have played a significant part in its undoing. At a meeting today, Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and the three black leaders who signed the accord failed to resolve the

title: Technologies Extends Bid
description: HARTFORD, May 1 (AP)The United Technologies Corporation said today that it had extended for 72 hours, or until Thursday at 5 P.M., its offer to purchase up to two million common shares outstanding of Ambac Industries of New York at $48 a share. The company said that, during the extension, it would purchase all shares on a firstcome, firstserved basis and would pay for all shares immediately after they have been tendered.

title: Dollar Is, Steady Abroad As Trading Is Curtailed Because of Many Holidays
description: The United States dollar held steady in very quiet foreign exchange trading yesterday because of widespread holidays in Europe and a scarcity of news developments, The Associated Press reported..

title: U.S. Agreed With Soviet to Limit Cooperation With Allies on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Carter Administration, during Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's visit to Moscow last month to advance a new strategic arms accord, agreed to a vaguely worded provision that would limit future American cooperation on nuclear weapons with allied governments in Western Europe, officials said today.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DOWN 0.1% IN MARCH; 2D DROP IN 3 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)--A Government barometer of future economic trends declined in March for the second time in three months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Topics
description: In the course of New York City's yearlong drive against welfare fraud, many needy people apparently lost the help they deserve. Prior to the crackdown, about 18 percent of those receiving welfare checks should not have been getting them; another 35 percent were receiving excessive benefits. The city instituted rigorous screening and checking procedures. The results were impressive  on paper. By January, city welfare rolls had dittoed to 927,000, the lowest figure in eight years. The rejection rate for new applications nearly doubled, reaching 48 percent.

title: News Summary
description: IsraeliAmerican ties were reaffirmed at a White House observance of Israel's 30th anniversary. Several, hundred rabbis and other Jewish leaders participated in the celebration with President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin, whose differences over Middle East peace issues were muted. description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1Yasir Arafat said, today that the only possible solution to the Middle East problem was for the United States and the Soviet Union to provide guarantees. for Israel and a Palestinian state.

title: Two Rookies With a Royal Look
description: If free agents symbolize the finance of baseball, rookies symbolize its romance. Rookies are the children of the game, its future and its fascination. Every baseball fan worth a bag of peanuts has, on seeing a rookie for the first time, predicted that this kid is going to make it big. Rookies also are a reminaer that once upon a time all the teams had scout and develop most of their best players instead purchasing them at auction. But the Kansas City Royals still operate that way. Instead of signing expensive free agents, they depend on their farm system. As the Royals arrived at Yankee Stadium last night for a threegame series, they had two of baseball's most stimulating rookiesClint Hurdle and Willie Wilson, each making about only $25,000 this season, one a 20-year-oldithome-run hitter, the other a 22-year-old base stealer; one a cannon, the other a bullet. Neither tearing the American League apart now, but be patient; the Royals are. They think so much of Clint Hurdle as their first baseman that they traded John Mayberry to the Toronto Blue Jays; they think so much of Willie Wilson as an outfielder that they might trade Amos Otis.

title: Market Place
description: While New York City argues for Federal bond guarantees in Washington, speculators may, wish to review the prospects of a limited number of the city's general. obligation bonds with aboveaverage safety features.

title: Brooklyn Man Arraigned in Killing
description: Charged with murder and attempted murder, 22-year-old John Cracchiolo was arraigned in Criminal Court in Brooklyn yesterday following the fatal shooting Saturday of 49-year-old Lorraine DiOrio, his neighbor in the borough's Carroll Gardens section. He was sent to the Brooklyn House of Detention pending hearing Thursday.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Union Pacific Corportion, parent of the Union Pacific Railroad, said that directore of the Shenandoah Oil Corporation, have agreed in principle to the merger of Shenandoah into the Champlin Petroleum Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Union Pacific Corporation.

title: Two by Two, the Pets Came to Be Blessed
description: Blessed are the beasts of Greenwich Villafte. But not Lucifer the Cat, who pulled a swift one. Lucifer was not among the other beasts of the earth and the fowl of the air and the things that managed to creepeth into St. John's Episcopal Church in the Village this week to get themselves properly blessed.

title: ABC's Fall TV Schedule to Retain 84% of Present PrimeTime Shows
description: ABC, which apparently knows a good thing when the nation sees it, is retaining, almost but not quite untouched, for its next season the schedule that was successful in the one just ended.

title: Briton Hopes His Gift of Big Bells Can Find a Home in America
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  For about three years an Englishman named David Wills has been trying to give the United States a little presentnothing gaudy, only a peal of great bells just like the ones in Westminster Abbeybut it hasn't been easy.

title: Notes on People
description: . Patricia Hearst's attorneys, F. Lee Bailey and his partner, Albert Johnson, withdrew from her case yesterday. They said that since the Supreme Court had rejected her appeal on a bank robbery conviction, there was little more they could do for Miss Hearst, and that, besides, they had other pressing business. In San Francisco, Mr. Johnson said, My partner and I came into this case to represent Miss Hearst both here and in Los Angeles more than three years ago. He noted that the Los Angeles case had been disposed of and that Miss Hearst, free on $1 million bail, was awaiting a judge's order to begin serving her sevenyear . prison sentence, expected to begin after the end of this month, when the judge returns from vacation. On the advice of Mr. Bailey and Mr. Johnson, the Hearst family has retained George Orrick, a San Francisco lawyer, who will represent Miss Hearst in future court appearances.

title: Jazz: Don Pullen Quartet at Axis
description: Don Pullen, who was at Axis in Soho on Sunday leading a quartet, used to be something of an anomaly in contemporary jazz. While most other pianists either took a lyrical, NeoRomantic approach or thundered and roared in the manner of Cecil Taylor, Mr. Pullen did both. Up until a few years ago, this refusal to take sides seemed, to some people at least, to indicate the lack of a personal style. But Mr. Pullen's playing has always been personal, and now the better young pianistsAnthony Davis comes to mindhave begun to make it their business to learn broad stylistic gamut.

title: ELLIOTT W. EAVES JR.
description: Elliott W. Eaves Jr., a retired corporate lawyer who was an authority on publicutility financing, died yesterday in North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a lingering illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 4619 241st Street, Douglaston, Queens.

title: RN: The Memoirs of Richard Nixon
description: N July 15, 1971, I talked on television for only 31/2 minutes, but my words produced one of the greatest diplomatic surprises the century. I read an announcement that was being made that very moment in Peking:

title: ExHead of Singer Company Slain In Jersey
description: Donald P. Kircher, the former president and chairman of the board of the Singer Company, was shot to death at his summer estate in Kingwood Township, N.J., and his brother-in-law has been charged with murder.

title: Ennui Under the Elms
description: Ladies and gentlemen, we interrupt this program to take you to Washington where something may have happened. Standing by in our Washington studio is Winston Jakes. Can you tell us, Winston, whether something really has happened in Washington and, so, what?

title: Garland Out for Season
description: CLEVELAND, May 1 (UPI)Wayne Garland, the Cleveland Indians pitcher who has been troubled for more than a year with shoulder stiffness, will undergo surgery and miss the rest of the season, the club announced today.

title: Lone Sledder Reaches North Pole; 54Day Trek Is First of Its Kind
description: A Japanese explorer has become the first person to reach the North Pole alone by dog sled after having struggled across 600 miles of frozen Arctic Ocean and survived attacks by a marauding polar bear.

title: 10Year. U.S. Notes Likely to Yield More Than 8.25%, a Postwar High
description: The Treasury's 10year notes scheduled for sale early this afternoon will likely yield more than 8.25 percent, the highest rate of return on intermediatematurity securities sold by the Federal Government since August 1975. Indeed, for the specifiC 10year maturity, the yield will reach a postwar high.

title: Charges Against Munson May Not Be Filed
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 1 (AP) Charges in an alleged choking incident involving Thurman Munson of the Yankees will probably not be filed, the Bloomingdale City Attorney said today. Stew Thornley, 22 years old, said Munson tried to choke him when he sought the catcher's autograph on fraternity paddle last Friday night after the YankeesTwins game.

title: Nationalists in South West Africa Is Acquitted of Assassination
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, May 1 (Reuters)A member of the nationalist SouthWest Africa People's Organization, Victor Nkandi, was acquitted today of charges of assassination of a moderate black leader, Chief Filemon Elifas.

title: G.M .Dividend Down 35c, to $ 1 .50 a Share
description: The General Motors Corporation, which last week reported lower earnings, yesterday declared secondquarter regular and special dividends totaling $1.50 on its common stock. The total was 35 cents less than General Motors paid in last year's quarter.

title: Afghan Coup Was Surprise to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The coup that has installed what appears to be a proSoviet party in power in Afghanistan came as a surprise to the United States Government, officials said today.

title: Terry Miller Banking On a Career in N.F.L.
description: As a child growing up in Colorado Springs, Terry Miller always was a leg man. While everyone around him was chairlifting up the mountain sides with two good legs and being carried down again with a break here or a fracture there, Miller kept his legs on the ground and his head out of the clouds.

title: White House Ready to Subpoena Business Data in Inflation Fight
description: ATLANTA, May 1As part of President Carter's plan for voluntary', control of inflation, the Administration is prevared to subpoena corporate records and publicly criticize companies that do not hold down prices, the director of the Council on Wage and Price Stability said here today.

title: NuclearPlant Ban on Coast Called Unconstitutional
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1'California's chief legal officer renewed a dispute last week over the constitutionality of three state laws that are hampering the development of atomic power. In a formalWASHINGTON,May 1 (AP)  The House Government Operations Committee recommended in a report released today that further Federal licensing of nuclear power plants be suspended until legal opinion, Attorney General Evelle Younger asserted that three statutes, enacted in 1976, transgressed both the Federal and state Constitutions.

title: Boeing Profits Rose 60.2% in Quarter
description: Increased sales, mounting production of commercial jets and higher income from other activities were mainly respcnsible for a 60.2 percent rise in first-quarter earnings of the Boeing Company, T. A. Wilson chairman, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Seattle.

title: Why Carter Holds Firm on TaxCut Package
description: Why is President Carter holding so ,firmly to his proposed $25 billion tax. .cut package despite efforts of such friendly critics as G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and many Congressmen to trim it?

title: Deputy Inspector Cleared of Lying When He Denied Sharing in Bribes
description: Deputy Police Inspector Daniel F. McMahon was acquitted by a State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan yesterday of charge that he lied to a grand jury when he denied having regularly shared in bribe money from Harlem gambling interests in 1970 and 1971.

title: C.I.A. Agent Tells Trial She Gave Data From Truong to Vietnamese
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 1A paid agent of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that she delivered books, envelopes and messages from a Vietnamese graduate student in Washington to officials of the Vietnamese Communist Government in Paris.

title: Defense Officials Angered by Move ToBan. Carrier for Cruise Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Defense Department officials are angry and dismayed over decisions by the House Armed Services Committee to delete funds for an aircraft to carry cruise missiles and increase spending for a luxury plane to carry admirals and Marine generals.

title: A Too White Academy Worries Coast Guard
description: NEW LONDON, Conn.Across the neatly trimmed grounds of the Coast Guard Academy, the cadets march crisply from one wellmaintained building to the next, on their way to classes in everything from ship design to human behavior.

title: Chamber Trio Ends Season On Beethoven
description: For its final program of the season, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center tied together a peculiar assortment of works, but as so often happens with this group the performances held to so high a level that interest was easily sustained. This listener, for. in. stance, did not expect much from the first piece, Beethoven's Variations in E flat for piano, violin and cello (Op., 44), which can sound like just one more extended exercise in variation form.

title: Hodges Leads in North Carolina Democratic Primary
description: RALEIGH, N.C., May 2Luther H. Hodges Jr., a banker who has never held elective office, led the Democratic senato rial primary voting over seven other candidates today, but he failed to achieve the majority needed to avoid a runoff with his closest challenger, State Insur ance Commissioner John R. Ingram.

title: U.S. Hockey Team Routed by Czechoslovakia, 83
description: PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 2 (AP)Pavel Richter, Jan Zajicek and Jaroslav Pouzar scored two goals apiece today and led Czechoslovakia to an 83 victory over the United States in the world ice hockey championship.

title: Scars and Flowers in Kabul Coup
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 2Five days after the military coup that brought Afghanistan a Communistdominated Government, dozens of tanks are still parked at Kabul's main intersections. But these are now carpeted with pink flowers and decorated with bright crepe paper steamers .

title: Gretchen Hood, Capital Hostess, 91
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)Gretchen Hood, a Washington singer who danced with Presidents and kings and went out with H L. Mencken, led today at the age of 91.

title: Private Lives
description: INSIDE the house, they were, dieting. So I went out to the garden to count theulips. We planted tulips last October. To my astonishment, they are coming up, one by one, as if they knew exactly how to do it. I am astonished because I am regarded by my many enemies as a Black Thumb; have merely to enter a room and the vegetable kingdom perishes. Somehow, the tulips hadn't gotten the word.

title: Carter Will Veto Arts and Humanities Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 2President Carter has found a way to save the Federal Government $3 million, Congressional sources said today, by deciding to veto a bill to hold White House conferences on the arts and the humanities next year. ,

title: Nixon Calls Order to Bomb Hanoi His Most Difficult Decision of War
description: Richard M. Nixon says that the decision to bomb the Hanoi area in Christmas week of 1972 was his most difficult of the whole war, but it was also one of the most clear cut and necessary ones.

title: Q & A
description: Q Sometime ago you mentioned a re cipe that consists of spaghetti that is cooked and served with fresh caviar. On rare (very rare) occasions I find myself with a few spoons left in a tin which my guests are too polite to demolish. What about tossing this with pasta?

title: Precious Metals Gain in Late Rally
description: A late rally raised prices of precious metals futures yesterday as traders cast aside their usual caution on the eve of an auction of gold bullion by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Derby Day: A Winner
description: SO FAR as horseracing fans are concerned, the main event that will take place in Louisville this coming Saturday at 5 p.m. is the 104th running of the Kentucky Derby. But to serious eaters and drinkers, that two-and-a-half-minute event represents merely a brief interlude in what is really a two-and-a-half-day continuous feast. Derby time in Louisville and environs is party time, and, in keeping with the best traditions of Southern hospitality, that means food and drink. From Friday evening to late Sunday afternoon, the whole city of Louisville (if not the entire state of Kentucky) is given over to a series of buffet cocktail parties and dinners, brunches, lunches and suppers, and lots of nibbling in between.

title: Casino Unit Rejects Month Delay on Resorts Hearing

title: Mayor Gibson's Record
description: When Kenneth Gibson became Mayor of Newark 1970, the city was a symbol of urban decay. Today, Mr. Gibson can point to a record of modest but important improvements, such as reducing street crime, expanding the healthcare system and building more than 2,000 Units of new housing. In addition, thanks to his mod- crate approach, whites and blacks have abandoned the brinkmanship that once kept the city at the edge violence. So it is only right that he should be a heavy favorite for reelection next Tuesday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fair Chance for Homosexuals
description: If God had meant for men to go with men, or women with women, He would have made us all alike. So declared one of the residents of St. Paul, Minn., where voters last week repealed a provision of the city code that prohibited discrimination on the basis of affectional or sexual preference. This month residents of Wichita, Kan., and Eugene, Ore., will vote on repealing similar ordinances in their cities, and another such effort is under way in Seattle.

title: Intercity Bus Industry Is Pressing For $500 Million U.S. Aid Package
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The intercity bus industry, which failed last year in an attempt to gain a $200 million Federal subsidy, is making a bid this week to obtain a $500 million package of Federal assistance over the next four years.

title: STATE SENATE UPHOLDS DEATHPENALTY VETO BY A ONEVOTE MARGIN
description: ALBANY, May 2The State Senate failed tonightby one voteto override Gov'rnor Carey's veto of a bill to restore the death penalty.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SOME of the most preposterous of all utterances are those made upon occasion by parents children in an effort to transform happenstance into propaganda in behalf of some pet theory. It is highly probable that children see right through such idiocy but are too innately polite to point it out. So the practice continues.

title: Remark Stirs Row in Britain
description: LONDON, May 2Sir Niel Cameron, Britain's highest military officer, touched off a row at home and abroad by his remark in Peking that the Soviet Union was the common enemy of Britain and China.

title: Yearly Automobile Emissions Test Voted in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, May 2Every car in Connecticut manufactured after Jan. 1, 1968, would have to pass an annual emissions test costing not mare than $5, under bill given final approval in the Senate today.

title: svat Replaces a General Over West Bank Violence In anArab High School
description: TEL AVIV, May 2 (Reuters)Brig. Gen. David Hagoel, commander of the Israeli military government in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan, has been dismissed from his post over an incident in which Israeli soldiers threw teargas grenades into a classroom of an Arab secondary school, the Defense Ministry announced tonight.

title: China Plans Labor Parley
description: HONG KONG, May 2 (Reuters)China will held its first national trade Union congress in nearly two decades this October, the official press agency said yesterday. China's trade union movement has been inactive since the Cultural Revolu. tion of the 1960's, when it was accused, of overemphasizing improvements in the welfare of its members.

title: Advertising
description: When Peter G. Diamandis of Conde Nast Publications first read about Vital magazine in midApril he felt a nervous twinge. It sounded like Self, the maaazine on physical and emotional fitness, that he is planning. 1 nen ne read that Vital was to be a dual audience publication and he was relieved. He is aimed at women, just as all the company's publications areVogue, House & Garden, Glamour, Mademoiselle and Bride's.

title: What Is This Thing Called Tofu?;
description: IN THE early 1970's the Hashizume Bean Cake Corporation came to life as a minor cottage industry, tucked away in the basement of a giant red brick factory in Long Island City. Each day it churned out a few hundred pressed soybean cakes, or tofu, and supplie ! the handful of Japanese restaurants and Oriental speciality stores in business at the time in the NeW York area.

title: Letter &
description: To the Editor:

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Did you ever think I'd tell you about something for which even I'm hard put to find use? Of course you did. The something, or somethings, from China, are truly exquisite handpainted cutouts of classical opera masks and fantasy goblins. There's a pig eating a watermelon (something you've always wanted), and an old man with a long beard, and on and on  20 different selections in all. What do you do with it, or them, when you've handed over your $2.50 or multiples of the sum? You put them on the wall you can just keep them as is, to touch and enjoy. Or if you have a friend you like a lot, send one off for a nice surprise. You'll find them at Noto, 245 West 72d Street (off Broadway), any day, including Sunday.

title: The No. 1 and the Draftniks
description: In the moments before the National Football League draft was about to begin yesterday, Earl Campbell, the Heisman Trophy running back from Texas, was walking into the Hotel Roosevelt's grand ballroom when a sportswriter introduced himself. Earl Campbell, bulky and prosperous in threepiece tan pinstriped suit, smiled and shook hands, then turned to Mike Trope and Bruce Marke. his agents, Everybody in this town, Earl Campbell whispered, must be a sportswriter. Everybody he meets anyway. He was sur- rounded by sportswriters when He was here to receive the Heisman Trophy and he was surrounded by them again yesterday even before Commissioner Pete Rozetle announced him to be the Houston Oilers choice as the No. 1 player in the N.F.L.'s annual livestock show. His selection was a foregone conclusion when the Oilers arranged a trade with the. Tampa Bay Bucs last week and it was confirmed by a prop near the microphone yesterdaya light blue Oilers jersey with Campbell') and 34 sewn on the back.

title: Teachers in Toledo End Strike That Shut Schools for 23 Days

title: Screen: 'Meet in Paradise':Fun and Philandering
description: "WE WILL ALL Meet in Paradise," the director Yves Robert's follow-up to "Pardon Mon Affaire," has the unmistakable air of a sequelnot because it seems like the continuation of a story, but because it doesn't seem like a story at all. Four fun-loving philanderers are up to a variety of boyish tricks, and the film apportions equal time to each of them, with no predominant plot thread or guiding principle. The characters are entertaining, and so are many of their adventures, but the film has all the structural solidarity of a dandelion in seed stage: it's pretty, airy, and just on the verge of blowing away.The terribly solemn Etienne, played by Jean Rochefort just as Peter Sellers would have played him, does a "Pink Panther" ineffectual-snoop routine, trying to figure out whether his wife (Daniele Delorme) really is "a faithful, happy example of the French woman, who is the envy of tourists the world over." Loutish, lustful Bouly (Victor Lanoux) keeps busy supporting his wife, his mistress, and a lot of interchangeable-looking children.Daniel (Claude Brasseur) may be on the verge of entering into a marriage of convenience with a wealthy older woman, but when he looks out a window and whistles "Not bad!" the object of his attention ismuch to his hetero-sexual cronies' disappointment  a handsome young soldier. And Simon (Guy Bedos), a doctor who is the ultimate mama's boy, makes love to his female patients behind the X-ray machine.The film's funniest sequences involve this foursome's ill-advised purchase of a country home, a fist-fight they conduct wearing earmuffs on a tennis court, and a bully's single-handedly demolishing an entire car, whch happens to have Mr. Rochefort inside it at the time. Mr. Bedos's dealings with his mother are also most amusing. Mr. Robert has a dry wit, a sure hand and, figuratively speaking, an old hat: His is a lightly likable, essentially familiar brand of comedy, designed to elicit a few mild chuckles and an occasional ooh-la-la.Mr. Robert also attempts good-humored social satire at times, but his work is a good deal more tepid in this department. Mr. Robert's notion that the foibles of the French bourgeoisie are silly but lovable is a profoundly uninteresting one.It should be noted that "We Will All Meet in Paradise" bears a distinct resemblance to "My Friends," an Italian film released two years ago, also about the adventures of four fun-loving philanderers. "My Friends" was uproariously funny, and deftly satirical and "We Will All Meet in Paradise" doesn't hold a candle to it."We Will All Meet In Paradise," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), alludes obliquely to its characters' sexual escapades, but it treats this material in a harmless, genial manner.

A prison spokesman at Alderson said that prisoners who do not cause trouble are sent to facilities near their homes so they can try to maintain as close a relationship as possible for. relatives and friends.
