description: PRAGUE"I've lived in this city for 20 years, said a foreign resident of Prague not unsympathetic to the regime. And I've never heard anyone in all that time defend the existing governmentnor heard anyone oppose the concept of a socialist society, eititer. Nowadays, the ordinary run of people just aren't interested in politics or in the liberty that they've learned to live without. If you mind your own business and don't worry about such ideals as freedom and such realities as the Russians, you can get along.

title: Screen: 'Melting Man':Saturnine Pellagra
description: THERE'S a powerful temptation to say that you never thaw a movie as foolish as "The Incredible Melting Man," but the fact is that each spring brings similar releases to fill the need of drive-in operators for something cheap to put on the screen for the kids in the cars to ignore or laugh at.This one, which opened yesterday at several theaters, is about an astronaut who contracts a disease during a trip to Saturn that causes his flesh to melt like wax unless he gets an all-meat diet. The problem is that prime steak or the whitest veal won't do. Only human flesh has the nutrients necessary to control this interplanetary pellagra.Alex Rebar in the title role heads the cast of unknowns. William Sachs, writing and directing his first feature film, shows no aptitude in either department. The real puzzle is not how the movie got made but why, on a brilliantly sunny day, a dozen adults including a dignified man in a white turban, presumably spent $3.50 to see it at the Victoria, a shabby house with uncomfortable seats, still filthy with the debris left by the previous day's audiences.

title: DANIEL SCANLON
description: Daniel Scanlon, a retired Civil Court judge for the City of New York died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 74 years old and lived at 4250 Van Cortlandt Park.Edward Lee Martin, a lawyer at Gulf & Western Industries specializing in labor relations, died Tuesday at his home on Sky View Farms Road in Lebanor N.J. at the age of 55.

title: Cleaning Tips From Those in the Know
description: MODERN technology and the chemical industry have made springcleaning less backbreaking, and yet there are certain oldfashioned recipes that consistently prove their worth. Here are a few that were passed on to us.

title: Some Relief for L.I. Road TieUps Seen in Plan Pushed in Congress
description: A House of Representatives subcommittee on surface transportation approved a $30 million computerbased program yesterday that is intended to save Queens and Long Island motorists millions of dollars and unmeasurable frustration and anger.

title: Notes on People
description: PRIME Minister Constantine Caramanlis flew from Greece to Bonn yesterday for a twoday visit in which he will receive the Charlemagne Prize for services to European unity. Set up in 1949 by the West German city of Aachen, the prize has gone in previous years to Winston Churchill and Konrad Adenauer. It consists of an illuminated citation and a stipend of $1,400. Mr. Caramanlis.met with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in Bonn yesterday before going to Aachen. He is to receive the prize today.

title: A Belfast Tradition Falls in Mayoral Vote
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 3  Belfast's city councilors have elected the first Lord Mayor not to be a member of the exclusively Protestant Unionist Party.

title: Authorities Release Georgia Youth Accused in His Half Sister's Death
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., May 3 (AP)  A teenager arrested last week in the drowning death of his 7yearold half sister was released by the authorities today after a grand jury failed to take any actionagainst him.

title: House Rejects Bid to Trim Nondefense Spending.
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The House today narrowly rejected a Republican move that would have trimmed nondefense spending to provide a larger tax cut and a smaller budget deficit.

title: Dance: Quixote By Baryshnikov
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV has produced a Don Quixote for our busy time. In his staging of a famous 19thcentury Russian comedy ballet classic, the pace turns to pizzazz and a winding narrative path becomes a shortcut.

title: SpringCleaning: A Bustling Tradition
description: WE ARE dealing with a very timely and ticklish subject this week: springcleaning. Springcleaning an old and honorable ritual in which the home, nest. cave or whatever was turned inside out and cleansed and renewed through an intensive scrubbing, polishing and purification that provided a seasonal, psychic and physical rebirth. Springcleaning is an ancient urge that comes with soft breezes and clear skies. It is a traditional time of upheaval and renewal.

title: MONDALE, IN MANILA, SEES MARCOS CRITIC
description: MANILA, May 3  Vice President Mondale conferred today with President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, then met with several of Mr. Marcos's leading critics in an effort to emphasize the Carter Administration's concern over human rights violations in the recent elections here.

title: KerrMcGee's Profit for Quarter Declined by 30% to $17.7 Million
description: The KerrMcGee Corpti, the don's largest supplier of uranium for commercial electric power generation, continued its profit slide in the first quarter with an earnings drop of 30 percent on a sales dip of 2.1 percent.

title: Home Beat
description: It all began in the Meadow Club in Southampton. The man who never cared terribly for printed fabrics and the lady from bloomcraft for whom prints are everything got to chatting. John saladino and Lyn }lamer put their heads together .and six months later the world is offered a brand new collection of reasonably priced ($9.00 a yard) 54inch mattefinished satin cotton prints called John Salodino Designs.

title: Begin Tours America, Talking ofBetter Ties
description: CHICAGO, May 3  Relaxing aboard his Israeli Air Force transport, Menachem Begin removes his suit jacket for a cardigan that is a little worn but much like those of President Carter. The touch of informality by the Israeli leader is rare and the similarity to Mr. Carter is only coincidental.

title: POLICE SAY TWO HOMICIDES MAY SOLVE HILLSIDE DEATHS
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3Police officials here said tonight that they belieyed a double homicide Monday night could lead to a solution of many, if not all, the 13 socalled hillside strangler murders.

title: Vast Iceberg Drifting In the South Atlantic
description: LONDON, May 3 (AP)  An iceberg with an area 36 times that of Bermuda and inhabited by penguins was reported today to be drifting slowly in the South Atlantic from the Antarctic in the direction of Africa.

title: Gold and Silver Rally on Expectation of Jump in Wholesale Price Index
description: Expectations that the latest Wholesale Price Index figures, due today, would show a rise of almost a percentage point caused another late rally yesterday in prices of precious metals.

title: Elderly at Rally Boo StandIn for Mayor
description: Deputy Mayor Ronay Menschel arrived as Mayor Koch's standin at a rally for the. elderly in Central Park yesterday, but was booed off the speaker's platform by the disappointed audience of 4,000.

title: Carter to Visit Oak Ridge May 22
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)  President Carter will visit the nuclear research and development facilities at Oak Ridge, Tenn., on May 22, a White House spokesman announced today. Although the President is pressing ahead with plans to phase out the $2.5 billion Clinch River nuclear breeder reactor project at Oak Ridge, Senator James R. Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, said plans for the trip did not call for Mr. Carter to visit the Clinch River project.

title: VESCO LEAVES COSTA RICA AFTER HE POSTS A BOND
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 3 (AP)  Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, has quietly left Costa Rica, flying with an aide in a private plane to Panama, immigration officials at San Jose airport said today.

title: First Atlantic City Casino Hotel Booked Solid Through Labor Day
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 3 (AP)  Resorts International Hotel is booked solid trough Labor Day weekend as operators prepare to open the first legal gambling caSino here late this month.

title: Aspens and Volares Recalled by Chrysler
description: DETROIT, May 3  The Chrysler Corporation today announced the recall of 1.2 million of its Aspen and Volare cars built for the 1976 through 1978 model years for the precautionary repair of the front suspension pivot bar nracket that could cause the loss of control of the vehicle should the bracket fail.

title: Ivey McCray's Run'ers Is Staged
description: IVEY McCRAY'S Run'ers, a production of Henry Street Settlenient's New Federal Theater, apparently draws its impulse from the career of Wilma Rudolph, who won three gold medals in the 1960 Olympics. In the play, racing becomes a metaphor for the black woman's search for consciousness.

title: Arson Is Suspected In Nine Forest Fires In Bear Mt. Region
description: STONY POINT, N.Y., May 3  Suspidons that arsonists have beenresponsibie for many fires in Bear Mountain and Harriman State Parks were voiced by officials today as 300 National Guardsmen from the Bronx joined in the firefighting.

title: Robert Abelow, at 75,, Who Edited Employee Relations Law Journal
description: Robert Abelow, a labor lawyer and editor of The Employee Relations Law Journal, died Monday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: ROBERT FUHRING
description: Robert Fuhring, a technical writer for Carl Byoir & Associates Inc., the publicrelations concern, in New York, and picture editor of Pageant Magazine from 1945 to 1947, died of a heart attack on a train in Grand Central Terminal Tuesday en route to his home in Montrose, N.Y. His age was 63.

title: A Device for Ignoring the Poor
description: Of all the sins of urban renewal, the worst was demolishing, and not replacing, poor people's housing. This in the name of eliminating slums and blight. When urban renewal was succeeded by communitydevelopment block grants, Congress stipulated that low and moderateincome people were to be the primary beneficiaries of the new program. But now the House Subcommittee on Housing and Community Development has endorsed an amendment to the blockgrant legislation that could make poor people the victims once again.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by cornbined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially.fastselling record.

title: $200,000 Is Needed for Repair Of Bankrupt Rail Line in Jersey
description: NEWARK, May 3 (AP)  The State Department of Transportation says at least S20P,000 is needed to repair portions of a bankrupt 52mile rail freight line that is below Federal safety standards.

title: Electricians Union Reaches Tentative Pact to End Strike
description: A tentative agreement was reachea yesterday in the eightweekold strike byconstruction electricians that has delayeabuild:ng projects throughout New Yorfr City at a cost of millions of dollars.

title: CARTER AND FUKUDA AGREE TO BOLSTER MONETARY PROCESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  President Carter talked about trade surpluses. the dollar and general world economic and political conditions with Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda of Japan today and heard about Japan's plans to accelerate purchases from thd United States.

title: Dollar Climbs in Trading Abroad; Gold Price Advances to $170.875
description: The dollar moved higher against most European currencies overseas, but lost :grOund yesterday in foreign exchange trading in New York, the Associated Press reported.

title: Nkomo Rejects Rhodesian Offer. Of Amnesty and Vows to Fight On
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, May 3 (AP)  One of Rhodesia's principal guerrilla leaders, Joshua Nkomo, today formally rejected the Rhodesian Government's offer of unconditional amnesty for his men and pledged to keen fiehtine.

title: The Willow: Aggressive and Beautiful
description: DARE I admit that I just returned from mauling a willow tree out by the front drive? Actually it wasn't entirely my fault; the voracious beavers that settled in by the bridge a quarter of a mile downstream about two years ago are really to blame.

title: Adults Only Housing Policies Appear to Be Spreading
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3  A shingle is going up outside more and more of the nation's apartment buildings these days. It reads: No Kids.

title: Farewell to Will Geer to Feature Singing at the King Center May 12
description: A memorial service will be held May 12 at 6 P.M. for Will Geer at the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Center at 310 West 43d Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Arlo Guthrie, Mrs. Woody Guthrie, Pete Seeger and representatives of actors unions will he among the friends and performers attending.

title: Backgammon:
description: The annual spring Clermont Club Tournament began in London last weekend. This year the event, which always attracts a strong field, was limited to exactly 100 players competing for $100,000 in prize money. As is common, even in the most important tournaments, many of the best players were eliminated in the prelhninary rounds. One of these unfortunates was the Irish champion, John Garratt, whose first round loss illustrates the sooftenfrustrating nature of the game.

title: Jazz: George Benson
description: SUBURBAN performance centers and indoor sports arenas may be bigger, but Broadway remains the mecca for many popmusic performers, the symbol of class and urban approbation. George Benson, whose latest single not exactly unfortuitously is entitled On Broadway, reached Broadway last night, opening a twoweek run at the Belasco Theatpr

title: SALES OF NEW CARS INCREASED BY 7.6% FOR 10 DAYS IN APRIL
description: DETROIT, May 3  Sales of American. made new cars in the final 10day selling period of April clinked 7.6 percent abovesales in the comparable period of last year, based on the daily selling rate measurement, according to reports today from the four major automobile makes.

title: Exhibition Honors Josiah Wedgwood, Scientist and Artist
description: LONDON

title: Factory Orders Up 2.5% in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)  Factories reported a 2.5 percent increase in order: for new products in March as they con. Untied to recover the losses suffered the first part of the winter, the Corn. merce Department said today.

title: Uprooted Greek Cypriots Yearn for Word of Missing Kin
description: LARNACA, Cyprus  The last time Yiannoula David saw her husband was on Aug. 21, 1974, when Turkish soldiers rounded up all the men and boys in her village of Asha in northern Cyprus' and took them away. Alone with her hus band, Frangopoulos, her sins David and Haralambos, who were then 14 and 15 years old, were also taken. Mrs. David and her two smallest children were herded with the other village women to a seeluded part of the village.

title: Retail Sales Show Lag for April; Slow Pace Tied to Early Easter
description: Consumer buying of clothes, home furnishings and related items slowed last month in New York City and the metropolitan area, to the point where even the largest sales gains of retailers only matched the inflation level.

title: Boe 2 Years Behind In N.H.L. Payments
description: Roy Boe, president of both the Nets and Islanders, is two years overdue in payments to 14 National Hockey League teams for the original cost of the Islanders entry into the league, was disclosed yesterday.

title: Fewer Die on French Roads
description: PARIS (Reuters)Highway accidents killed 13,104 . people in France in 1977, 5 percent fewer than in the preceding year, according to official figures. The number of injured was 354,905, about 1 percent fewer than in 1976.

title: 15 Restaurant Violators Listed By New York City Health Dept.
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday listed 15 restaurants with healthcode violations and two that had corrected earlier violations The restaurants were listed as follows:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday misstated the route of a hiking and cycling trail proposed for an abandoned Penn Central rail spur in New Jersey. The correct route of the 8.2mile trail would be from the Battle Monument in Trenton to the Delaware River near Washington Crossing State Park.

title: Leonard Silk
description: WASHINGTON  If President Carter is to get his $25 billion package of tax cuts and tax reforms through Congress, he will need the full support of Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and the most important member of Congress when it comes to taxes. But Senator Long thinks that the President's tax bill, in its existing form, does not have a prayer, even if it comes from Jimmy Carter.

title: CARTER ORDERS A RISE FOR SOLAR RESEARCH
description: GOLDEN, Colo, May 3President Carter journeyed to a rainswept mountaintop here today to celebrate Sun Day by announcing that he was directing the expenditure of an additional $100 million for solar. research projects.

title: Pineda Is Killed in Spill At Pimlico Three Years After Brother's Death
description: BALTIMORE, May 3  A 25yearold jockey died and two other riders were injured today in a fourhorse spill at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Favoritism Denied On Alcoholism Aid By Acting Director
description: ALBANY, May 3  John R. DeLuca; the acting director of the New York State Division of Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse, today denied that he had shown favoritism in approving grants of state money or that he had brought political pressure against persons who opposed him.

title: U.S. SAID TO ACCEPT SOVIET PLAN LIMITING MISSILES AND PLANES
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The United States, in a compromise on one of the last few obstacles to a new strategic arms accord, has tentatively decided to accept a Soviet proposal that would limit each side to 2,250 longrange missiles and bombers through I985, according to Administration officials.

title: Mets Rained Out
description: The New York Mets game with the Braves at Atlanta Stadium was rained out last night.

title: ABCTV Offers a Glimpse of Its 20/20 Magazine
description: The cadre that will bring 20/20, the new ABC newsmagazine program to television next month, assembled at the Hotel Plaza yesterday to unveil, finally, a longawaited glimpse of. the program's shape.

title: 3 Seized at a Brooklyn College Rally
description: Six pclice officers were injured and three persons arrested yesterday when a demonstration by black and Hispanic students at Brooklyn College erupted into a scuffic.

title: Worker Dies in Fall
description: HOBOKEN, May 3 (UPI)  A sheetmetal worker was killed yesterday, When he fell 48 feet from an office building under construction at Grogan Marine View Plaza. The worker, Albert Balk Jr., 31 years old, of Clifton, N. J., lost his balance when he was struck by a loose piece of metal, authorities said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Shcharansky Trial in Soviet Is Expected This Month
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of New York said today that he had learned that Anatoly Shcharansky, the Soviet dissident, might be brought to trial in Moscow later this month.

title: FRANCE JAILS RAPISTS AFTER PIVOTAL CASE
description: AIXENPROVENCE, France, May 3  A precedentsetting rape case that has dragged through a series of courts for nearly four years to become a cause clbre in France concluded here today with sentences ranging from four to six years in prison for three local men.

title: Fuel Tax on Barges Approved by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The Senate approved legislation today imposing for the first time a fuel tax on commercial barge lines using the inland waterwavc

title: Industrial Parks Proposed in Port
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Koch, Governor Byrne and two New Jersey Mayors gave their blessing yesterday to a plan by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to reverse the flow of manufacturing jobs away from the New York metropolitan area.

title: INDUSTRY LOSES PLEA ON STRIPMINE RULES
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  A Federal district judge today rejected a legal attack by mining interests on Government stripmine regulations that had been scheduled to take effect tomorrow. But Judge Thomas A. Flannery postponed until 6 P.M. Friday the effect of his ruling so that the complaining coal companies cbuld decide whether to take his decision tci, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Market Place
description: The plan announced Tuesday under which Globe Union Inc. would merge with the Square D Company may face a strong chailenge from U. V. Industries, owner of 20.5 percent of Globe Union's shares.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: BILL DOWNS, NEWSMAN FOR ABC IN WASHINGTON
description: Bill Downs, a Washington correspondent for ABC News whose 40year career took him through newspapers, radio and television, died of cancer yesterday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 63 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Nixon Says Watergate Damaged Ability to Repulse Foes of Detente
description: Richard M. Nixon says that the Watergate scandal badly damaged his ability to counter the .mounting opposition in the United States to his policy of fostering detente with the Soviet Union.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GRAND CANYON Those musical revivals by the St. Bart's Players this time of year mean a spring bonus. Their Off Off Broadway showcase, the annex of St. Bartholomew's Church on Park .Avenue. at 50th Street, has a front terrace affording one of New York's most striking views for intermissionstroller. ContrasTing the panoramic ring of skyscrapers is the church's sidewalk garden, now alive with tulips.

title: Topics
description: New York expects delivery of two new Staten Island ferryboats, complete but for names. Suggestions have been called for.

title: Braths
description: ABELOWRobert. On May 2, 1978. Beloved husband of Miriam Steinbrink. Loving father of William and Judith Abelow, and grandfather of Janie and Debbie. Dear brother of Jeannette Jarnow, Memorial service Thursday, May 4, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell. Madison Ave at 81 St. Please omit flowers.

title: Scapegoating Our High Schools
description: So much has.been written and said about New York City's public education system in general, and the high school diploma in particular, that is critical for all of us to take a more careful look at our city's secondary schools.

title: HEAD OF F.B.I. GIVES DATA ON INFORMERS, DEFENDING THEIR USE
description: ATLANTA, May 3  William H. Webster, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, strongly defended in a speech here today the bureau's continuing use of undercover informers and for the first time disclosed the number of informers employed by the agency.

title: Kent State to Mark 8th Anniversary of Killings Today
description: KENT, Ohio, May 3  What has become a seasonal wariness has settled over Kent State University in the last few days as students, faculty and others prepared to commemorate the eighth anniversary tomorrow of the killing of four students and the wounding of nine others by Ohio National Guardsmen called out to quell a campus demonstration against the invasion of Cambodia by American forces in 1970.

title: For Cable TV Industry, Picture Is Bright
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 2  The persistent Dixieland beat lends an ebullience to most proceedings in this city, but that rhythm is not the main reason delegates to the National Cable Television Association convention seem so happy. They are cheerful because of widespread industry agreement that the future looks brieht indeed.

title: Country Music: Festival in Brooklyn
description: THE Brooklyn Aaademy of Music began a sixday Old Time Country Music Festival Tuesday night. This is a potentially valuable addition to the city's musical life in several ways, and one hopes it will continue and expand. But the actual opening show left something to be desired.

title: Fire Kills 6 in Toronto Family
description: TORONTO, May 3 (Reutes)A mother trying to save her 11 children died with 5 of them in a fire at their home in a Toronto suburb early today. Mrs. Barbara McCann, about 45 years old, died along with her daughters Melanie, IS, Patricia, 17, Margaret, 12, Elizabeth, 10, and a son, Danny, 9. The father, Paul McCann. a stockbroker, escaped with six other children.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 250 Bus Shelters Will Be Built for Newark
description: NEWARK, May 3  Two prototypes Of 250 to 400 bus shelters that will soon be erected in Newark were opened today near City Hall and Military Park.

title: Port Agency Seeks Authority to Invest In Industrial Parks
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Koch, Governor Byrne and two New Jersey Mayors gave their blessing yesterday to a plan by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to reverse the flow of manufacturing jobs away from the New York metropolitan area.

title: CURARE CASE IS TOLD OF STAFF PROBLEMS
description: HACKENSACK, May 3  A doctor who is a part owner of Riverdell Hospital testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that the surgeon had resisted adding Surgeons to the hospital staff, had questioned their ability when they had joined the staff and had finally asserted that the lack of ability of the new surgeons was causing the death of patients.

title: Horatio Alger of Crime and 22 Seized in Narcotics Inquiry, in the Bronx
description: Twentythree persons, including a 32yearold former New York City welfare inspector once described as a Horatio Alger of crime, have been arrested as a result of a twoyear investigation into the multimilliondollar drug traffic in the BrOnx

title: 2 Queens Men Accused of a Plot to Kidnap And Kill 2 Officers Because of Drug Raid
description: Two Queens men were arrested yesterday and charged with attempting to kidnap and kill two police officers who had arrested one of them in a raid last October.

title: A 57YearOld Jockey Is Set to Ride in Derby.
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3  Deep furrows give his face the look of a plowed field, and the green eyes peer out from between thickets of crow's feet.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT TO READ instead of the Nixon memoirs? Three old hands are back this month with new pots off the mysteryfiction wheel. There is, of course a horse in Dick Francis's Risk. Mr. Francis, the British exjockey who turned into a thriller writer 18 books and 18 years ago, always has horses in his novels. This horse, Tapestry, jumps over hurdles with a minimum of help from an amateur jockey, Roland Britten, who in real life is a certified public accountant. The damnedest thing happens to Britten after almost every race: He is abducted and stashed in some dark place for several days, such as the hold of a boat on its way to Minorca, or the back of a van in a warehouse in Newbury.

title: French in U.N. Lebanon Force Call Off Patrols After Clashes
description: TYRE, Lebanon, May 3  The French command of the United Nations peacekeeping force here called off all patrols temporarily today in an attempt to reduce the tension created by clashes yesterday in which three United Nations soldiers were killed.

title: John Dickinson: own to Bare Bones
description: ONE OF this country's more innovative design talents, John Dickinson, has put together a . .set of rooms for Macy's  alas, in Sail Francisco Through May, Macy's in the Bay Area is offering the display as a tribute to the designer: A drawing room, studio apartment and bedroom filled with the arresting furniture conceptions that have won Mr. Dickinson wide attention  ranging from noisy plaudits to raised eyebrows.

title: CURARE CASE IS TOLD OF STAFF PROBLEMS
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 3A doctor who is a part owner of Riverdell Hospital testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that the surgeon had resisted adding surgeons to the hospital staff, had questioned their ability when they had joined the staff and had finally pointed out that the lack of ability of the new surgeons was causing the death of patients.

title: Lance, in Chicago to Give Speech, Sidesteps Questions on Activities
description: CHICAGO, May 3  Bert Lance, in his first public appearance since he accepted a consent decree after charges of civil fraud, Met affably and confidently with reporters here today but deftly sidestepped most questions about his activities.

title: BUDGET CUTS TERMED PERIL TO HOSPITALS
description: TRENTON, May 3  The accreditation of at least one state psychiatric hospital will be in serious jeopardy because of cuts in the 197879 budget to be voted on in the Legislature tomorrow, according to the state's Human Services Commissioner, Ann Klein.

title: Tremors Shake Eastern Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 3 (AP)  Mild earth tremors today shook the eastern Turkish town of Pulumur, 300 miles east here, but caused no casualties. The Anatolia press agency, quoting the local governor. said 15 school buildings and 270 houses had been damaged.

title: No More MEGO's
description: EASTON, Md.A MEGO, in newsmagazine lingo, is a topic to be avoided at all costs: the acronym stands for My Eyes Glaze Over. Typical MEGO's are petrodollars, foreign aid, government reorganization; your lids are growing heavy even as you read these words.

title: Sound
description: APE DECKS, I am told, are currently the hottest ticket in audio. Once considered an optional extra, they are now regarded as virtually indispensable as more and more listeners discover the pleasures of.having their own recording facilities. Those who had originally set up their sound systems without tape decks now seem to be rushing out to remedy that lack. And except for a small minority intent on quasiprofessional recording on reels, most listeners opt for cassettes, beguiled by their compactness, convenience, and ease of handling.

title: PINHAS ROSEN DIES; EXISRAELI MINISTER
description: TEL AVIV, May 3Pinhas Rosen, Minister of Justice during Israel's first 13 years, died in a home for the aged in Kfar Saba yesterday, two days after his 91st birthday.

title: New York City to Open Hearings on Budgets
description: The City Council and Board of Estimate will begin a series of public hearings on the proposed 1979 expense and capital budgets at 10:30 A.M. today at Borough Hall in Brooklyn.

title: Sleepers Sought in Late Rounds
description: The National Football League's annual draft of college players concluded yesterday with the selection of the last 168 of 334 athletes aspiring for jobs in one of sport's more affluent organizations.

title: Philadelphia Radical Group Agrees to Surrender
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 3  A knot of radicals that has vexed this city since 1975 are scheduled to surrender to the authorities here tomorrow, 51 days after police officers barricaded the block in which they were quartered.

title: Critic's Notebook. There's Many a Slip...
description: THOSE who buy socks can generally expect to keep their feet warm, and those who buy $1.98 watches can generally expect to miss appointments. But those who buy the raw material from which movies are made seldom know what to expect, since a novel or outline or firstdraft screenplay often undergoes drastic alterations before it reaches the screen. In the cases of two current hits, Coma and Coming Home, a great many nips, tucks, twists and revisions went into the customtailoring process that turned the initial idea for each film into the finished product.

title: VANCE JOINS LOBBYING ON CIVIL SERVICE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Representative Stephen J. Solar; a Brooklyn Democrat, was at a meeting of the House International Relations Committee when the call came from Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: Roy Boe and the Public Trust
description: It's as if Roy L. M. Boe were twins  one the friendly, peanutmunching rooter for the New York Islanders and the New Jersey Nets, the other a wheelerdealer who projects more suspicion than credibility. The wheelerdealer is being sued for $10 million for allegedly diverting $3.5 million surreptitiously from the relatively prosperous Islanders the virtually insolvent Nets or himself. In the litigation brought by Thomas J. Thornton, one of the Islanders many limited partners, Roy Boe also was accused of having concealed financial data from his Islander partners and of having called on them for additional financing to cover up his cash drain. Roy Boe yesterday denied the charges. But now the whispers that have circulated around Roy Boe for several years are in the public domain, where the owner of a sports franchise belongs.

title: Hodges in Party Runoff to Decide Rival for Helms in North Carolina
description: RALEIGH, N.C., May 3  Luther H. Hodges Jr., a Charlotte banker who led the North Carolina Democratic senatorial primary yesterday, will face the state's Insurance Commissioner, John R. Ingram, in a May 30 runoff that party regulars fear will be divisive.

title: Films by Maya Deren:Intense Shorts
description: THE FEW FILMS directed by the late Maya Deren are extremely shortranging from 4 to 15 minutesand they cannot be watched with anything less than the utmost concentration. Miss Deren, a pioneer avant-garce figure who did most of her work in the late 1940's, invested every last object and gesture in her films with strong symbolic meaning, and her work requires the same kind of painstaking scrutiny one might ordinarily bring to a painting. The Film Forum's Deren retrospective, which will be shown tonight through Sunday and again from May 11 to May 14, lasts only an hour and a half, but the relentless intensity of the program makes it exhausting.Aside from the draining effect Miss Deren's films have when snown together, there are other good reasons for taking her efforts in small doses. She tended to repeat herself somewhat, in both her extreme attentiveness to the voluptuous possibilities of the human body and in her predilection for shifting characters back and forth between natural, primitive-looking locales and abstract, "socialized" settings. Typically, "At Land" begins alternating an image of Miss Deren crawling along a beach with one of her wriggling across the table at a dinner party.Miss Deren figured as physically and seductively as she could in most of her films, but "A Study in Choreography for Camera" concentrates entirely on the dancer Talley Beatty, who leaped through a forest, a living room and a museum. The completed film runs only four minutes, and it is followed on the program by 15 minutes of out-takes, extra footage of Mr. Beatty that Miss Deren shot and stored away.This unused material would be illuminating if one had the time or the inclination to study it closely, and it would certainly cast more light upon Miss Deren's decision processes if the finished film were shown again, afterward. Scheduled as they are, though, the out-takes merely overwhelm the film itself, and they serve to limit the potential audience for this program to only the most serious students of the avant-garde cinema.

title: Hers
description: ANYONE who has bought nine cars in three years is a prime target for people who have something to sell. I will explain the cars another time. The house problem is fresher In my mind. The pursuit of something to acquire is a fine way for a writer to avoid writing, which, as Fran Lebowitz has explained, is one of the things we do best. I like looking for houses very much. You ride around with someone who shares the househuntine addiction (which, I suspect, is how a lot of brokers get into the business) and you get to nose through other people's liv,es. Like everything else we do when Not Writing 111 lScan be NotWritten off as Research. Without putting one toe in the house you can guess what is in the linen closet and imagine the contents of that drawer the kitchen where one throws everything which has no category. Sharpens the instinct for character.

title: NEW &
description: There have been Roman shades and Venetian blinds, Austrian shades and Riviera blinds, and now there are Capri shades. The special feature of the Capri shades is that they can be used in a variety of positions: to cover a window completely, to expose just the bottom or just the top, or let light in from both bottom and top at the same time. All this versatility ig because the shades come with three rods, which go through the top, center and bottom of the shade, and two sets of triplenotch brackets (for the top and center of the window) so the placement of the rods can be changed at will. The shades may be installed either inside or outside the window frame. The advantage of inside installation is that the shades will fit snugly and keep out all the light. Set on the outside;they take the place of curtains or draperies. Altman's has the shades, which are made by Finetre, in natural Haitian cotton, navy denim trimmed with natural burlap, corduroy in brown, blue or red trimmed with burlap, and a natural casement cloth. Stock sizes are 30, 36 and 48 inches wide and 60 inches long. Prices range from $46 to $66. Altman's custom department will also take Special orders for other sizes and fabrics.

title: Pop: Echoes of Savoy
description: FORTY YEARS AGO, the Savoy Sultans, the house band at the Savoy Ballroom, the home of happy feet, was the prototypical Harlem lump band. It had the light, insistent, riffing drive that kept feet happy at the Savoy. The band is long gone, but echoes. of it can still be heard at the West End Cafe, Broadway and 113th Street, when a group led by George Kelly, a saxophonist with he Sultans, is playing there and, somewhat surprisingly, at Onde's a restaurant at 160 East 48th Street, where Art Syms, a pianist, leads a quartet Mondays through Saturdays.

title: Disks: Perahia Plays Mozart
description: THIS DISK copfounds three oftenrepeated musical maxims: that young virtuosos like flashy Romantic display pieces, that it takes seasoned maturity to play Mozart well and that soloists who try to conduct  especially when they perform at the same time  are sacrificing musical integrity on the altar of ego. All three maxims have a basis in fact. We have indeed been deluged in recent years with young pianists who play loud, notefilled music very strikingly, but who sometimes break down in simpler, more profound idioms. In the old days, virtuosos played Romantic music with Romantic rhetoric, and often their Mozart  no matter how old they were  sounded anachronistic in terms of style.

title: Levitt, N ot Running for ReElection, Says He Will Back Best Qualified
description: Arthur Levitt, who has decided no to run for a seventh term as State Comptroller this year, said yesterday that he would support as his successor someone best qualified in terms of character and trustworthiness.

description: Leaders of the negotiating comunittee of the municipal labor coalition are scheduled to meet this morning to review the, bargaining situation with the city before several of them leave on extended trips.

title: Members of House Disclose Data On Outside Income and Liabilities
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Members of the House of Representatives made public today the most extensive disclosure yet of their personal finances, but the disclosure statements seemed unlikely to cause many Congressmen political embarrassment.

title: Charge Is Dismissed Against Richmond
description: A misdemeanor morals charge against Representative Frederick W. Richmond has been dismissed by a District of Columbia court because the 54yearold Brooklyn Democrat has been receiving professional treatment as required under a firstoffender law, a spokesman for Mr. Richmond said yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Carter's Speech to the Bar Association
description: LOS ANGELES, May 4 (AP)Following are excerpts from President Carter's speech today to the 100th anniversary luncheon of the Los Angeles Bar Association:

title: Eartha Kitt, in Concert, Doing Her Own Thing
description: After a fouryear absence, Earth& Kitt ireturns to the local concert stage, doing her Eartha Kitt thing at the 92d Street Y at 8:30 P.M. Sunday, for the scholarship fund of the Y School of Music.

title: Two New York Unbeatables
description: The announcement by New York State's Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, that at 77 he will not run for a seventh term in Albany, completes the changing of the guard that started with a similar withdrawal by Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz some months ago. Mr. Lefkowitz is a Republican and Mr. Levitt a Democrat, but the voters have returned them to office for 20 and 24 years, respectively, no matter which party gained the governorship.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A judge in Newark heard motions yesterday to dismiss a lawsuit that accuses psychologists, doctors and administrators of the MaplewoodSouth Orange school system with educational malpractice.

title: VANCE ARRIVES IN MEXICO FOR TALKS WITH LEADERS
description: MEXICO CITY. May 4Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance met with senior Mexican officials today for talks that seemed largely aimed at reassuring Mexico that the Carter Administration has not forgotten it.

title: Companies Report Earnings

title: Carter Hopes for a Strategic Arms Accord This Year
description: WASHINGTON, May 4President Carter said tonight that he hoped to achieve a new agreement on limiting strategic arms this year and added that any compromises by the United States would have to be met by equivalent concessions from the Soviet Union.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, May 4The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is to begin here tomorrow a threeday conference of leaders of black organizations to discuss a list of 14 social issues the organization says is of crucial importance to the nation's 20 million blacks.

description: Morning

description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (Reuters)The Senate voted 63 to 29.today to authorize a feasibility study of a sealevel canal in Central America.

The buildings theresome of them industrial and some of those abandonedturn their backs on a shoreline that was once a watery playground for some of New York's first suburbanites: families of means who followed the introduction of ferry service to the island in the early 19th century.

description: An 110 spurt midway. through thc. first half paced the Soviet Union jun!or national basketball team to an 8562 victory over the Riverside Church team last night at Columbia University's Levien Gym.

description: WHITE PLAINS, May 4After months of bitter infighting over proposals to merge Westchester's two overlapping police agencies, the county's Democratic Executive and Republican Sheriff today struck a classic political compromise.

description: Confessing to a feeling of ambivalence, Patrick J. Cunningham presided last night at his last dinner as Democratic leader of the Bronx.

Jeffers, 31 years old, of Springfield, Ill., a paraplegic who was recently named director of the Illinois Division of Vocational Rehabilitation.

title: A Wide Range of Income for Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Last year Representative Harold S. Sawyer drew $100,000 from his law firm in Grand Rapids, Mich. The 58yearold Republican, who took former President Gerald R. Ford's old seat in Congress, owns enough stock and real estate to qualify as a millionaire.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4 (Reuters) A delegation of Yugoslav war veterans left today for a visit to the United States at the invitatin of the Council of Associations of American War. Veterans. The delegation, the first of its kind 1 to visit the Uhited States, was led by Andreja.Milanovic, vice president of the Yugoslav War Veterans Organization.

description: Spring weather brings the flea markets and antiques shows out all over the metropolitan area.

title: Pupils Boycott to Protest Principal's Tenure Loss
description: In an effort to retain the present principal of Public School 9 on the Upper West Side, parents and students staged a oneday boycott of classes yesterday. 0nly 181 of the 600 students came to school.

title: Dance: Lar Lubovitch
description: L ARLUBOVITCH'S choreography resembles daydreaming. All three works presented by the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company Wednesday night at the Roundabout Theater were like the idle fancies that might occur to someone sitting back in a chair, listening to records.

title: Piano: Miss de Bottazzi
description: A NA Maria Trench de Bottazzl is the Argentinian pianist who confounded medical opinion by resuming her career following a nearfatal automobile accident in 1962. She made a successful New York debut in 1974, and subsequently gave a Fisher Hall recital in which the audience was asked to choose from a list of 100 works that she had memorized.

title: Art. The Way Museums Work
description: THERE are collectors who acquire art with passion, knowledge, deeply developed tastes. And then there arewell, buyers of art who simply put themselves in the hands of dealers.

description: A group of foreign investors yesterday made a cash offer of $50 million to buy three of Manhattan's major midtown hotels from the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: BEGIN IS IN NE IN YORK, HEARTENED BY TOUR
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin returned to New York yesterday to pick up moral and financial support for Israel, the second honorary degree of his trip, and further opportunities to explain his policies.

title: W.H.O. SEES A HEALTH GAIN IN ISRAELIOCCUPIED LANDS
description: GENEVA, May 4A special committee of the World Health Organization reported today that there had been some improvement in medical care in Arab territories occupied by Israel since 1967. But the committee added that health services in the occupied lands have not attained the technical level they should have reached after so long a period.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MAY 5, 1978

title: Major Retail Chains Report Strong Gains in April
description: Strong sales gains were recorded in alpril by the nation's largest retail chains over the 1977 month, but some of the LS companies reporting yesterday had small advances or declines, indicating some erosion in consumer buying last month.

title: Carter May Compromise on Planes, Possibly Increasing Sales to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Carter Administration Indicated today that it was willing to compromise on its controversial plan for a package sale of military jets to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel. Congressional sources said part of the compromise might involve an increase in the number of advanced planes to be sold to Israel.

title: New P.S.C. Chairman
description: Will the Consolidated Edison Company get to raise its rates 10 percent next year? Will the Telephone Company be allowed to charge phoneusers for future executive pay bonuses? Will other New York State utility rates go up and service improve or deteriorate? The answers will depend significantly on the new leadership of a reflective, methodical and occasionally outraged 33yearota lawyer rrom Bunato.

title: Discover New York
description: The Municipal Art Society has plans, starting Sunday, for you to walk your feet off for weeks to come in pursuit of New Yorks that you may have seen but never really knew.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP 1.3 PERCENT IN APRIL, THE MOST IN 3 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  wholesale prices, the harbinger of what consumers will pay in shops, rose 1.3 percent last month, the largest gain in three and a half years, the Government reported today.

title: Better Drug for Hypertension Successfully Tested
description: BOSTON, May 4 (AP)Boston doctors have successfully tested a new drug that lowers high blood pressure without the unpleasant side effects of the medicines now prescribed for this common illness.

title: Restaurants
description: SOME nine years have passed since Le Madrigal first opened the doors on its sunny, stylish Parisian interior with pastel murals of the Directoire period by Jean Pages, deep apricot velvet banquettes and a small greenhouse of a garden dining room. During that time it has consistently enjoyed a following among the famous and the fashionable and, through the years., it seems that the service has become friendlier, More concerned and far less overbearing than it was during this restaurant's first burst of success.

title: PRIVATEPENSION PLANS SCORED IN F.T.C. REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)Private retirement investments through insurance companies and lending institutions sometimes pay less than the investor expects, according to a Federal Trade Commission report released today.

title: Dresser Loses Round On Federal Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Dresser in dustries Inc. has had a setback in fighting requests by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission for i nformation about payments the company has made abroad.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 5.6%
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week was an estimated 18.3 billion tonmiles, up 5.6 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 495,181 cars, up eighttenths of 1 percent from last year.

title: Passaic's Sheriff Sues State on Jail
description: NEWARK, May 4 (UPI)The sheriff of Passaic County filed suit today in Federal District Court here, blaming the state for inadequate conditions at the county jail.

title: Pirate Day Tomorrow At South St. Seaport
description: Pirates aplenty will be on hand at the South Street Seaport tomorrow from I to 5 P.M., when the Seaport's annual Children's Day celebration gets under way. The theme this year is pirates Children of all ages are invited to wear seafaring regalia: prizes will be awarded for the best costumes.

title: The Anatomy of Glitter, Bottom to Top
description: Give away a couple of honorary awards, make certain a heavy sprinkling of glittering creatures are glittering, hire Donald Bruce White, who serves hot food on hot plates, transform a roof garden into a tent, and presto, voila, abracadabra  a successful party. You see, it doesn't take much, if you're Joseph E. Brooks.

title: Trouble
description: WEST HAVEN, Conn.As long as they need me! And that's exactly what I mean. That's the only reason I take the, nonsense that the public and the Welfare Department hand out. If it weren't for the children,and may I remind the taxpaying public that the A.F.D.C. [Aid to Families with Dependent Children] grant is for themwelfare wouldn't be necessary.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The top sales executive of Nissan, U.S.A., the American distributor for the Japanesemade Datsun cars and trucks, said in Memphis yesterday that his company was just short of declaring a moratorium on its planned expansion of the Datsun dealer network in the United States.

description: State Senator Bernard G. Gordon, a Republican from Peekskill, N. Y., died of cancer last night at his home. He was 62 years old.

title: $ 15 Billion Transit and Road Bill Cleared by House Subcommittee
description: WASHINGTON, May 4A House subcommittee today cleared a $15 billion transit and highway bill that was nearly 50 percent more expensive than the pro. gram that the Carter Administration had recommended and ignored reforms advocated by the White House.

description: WASHINGTON, May 4For the first time in memory, the Republican members of the Senateall 38 of themhave been unanimous on something, and probably on the wrong thing.

description: To the Editor:

title: Improving Farmers Incorne At the Consumer's Expense
description: WASHINGTONSome recent developments have changed the depressed mood of the 4.5 million Americans engaged in the production of food and fibers and in related industries. One source of high tension for the Carter Administration has thereby been eased, but, economists say, at substantial cost to the rest of the population who buy the output of the nation's farms ana rancnes.

title: ETHICSCODE CHANGES URGED IN LEGISLATURE
description: TRENTON, May 4The chairman of the State Legislature's Joint Committee on Ethical Standards today suggested a revision of the code of ethics, including a prohibition on legislators sitting on committees that write laws affecting their professions or businesses.

description: Residents of the Canarsie section of Brooklyn asked yesterday that money for new park in their neighborhood be eliminated from the proposed city budget.

description: THE Franz Liszt Chamber Orchestra of Budapest is a conductorless ensemble of 16 string players, which made its debut here in 1974. Last night in Carnegie Hall, it made its first appearance in New York since then.

description: PHILADELPHIA, May 4Members of a group of radicals who had barricaded themselves in a house here and defied the police began surrendering one by one today.

description: ALBANY, May 4They come together most Monday mornings during the lawmaking season, bearinab the banners of Schoharie, Chemung, Tioga and Oswego, among others. Their discussions bear an air of legislative savvy, but spiked with references to fertilizer, grain, soybean and agribusiness.

description: A century ago, the traveler crossed the East River to Brooklyn by ferry arrived in a separate city of half a million people. Today he crosses the East River through subway and auto tunnels and over bridges, and Brooklyn is no longer a city separate from New Yorkthough if it were, its population of nearly 2.5 million would make it the fourth largest city in the United States.

description: How will the chief executive officer of the 1980's differ fr6m today's corporate chief?

description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L.L, May 4 Dr. Jerry Sacks, who narrowly missed winning the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament last year when he lost to Bob Housen, 1 up, in the final, made sure he would take home at least one prize from this year's invitation amateur event.

description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI)Paul Logan Martin, who retired late last year as political editor of U.S. News & World Report, died today of cancer at Arlington County Hospital. He was 65 Years old.

title: 2 Octogenarians Loo o Derby for a Ninth Hurrah
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4The 104th Kentucky Derby, to be run here Saturday, has two sentimental favorites going for it: Admiral Gene Markey, and his wife, Lucille, the octogenarian master and mistress of Calumet Farm, whose colt, Alydar, offers the best hope in a decade of adding a ninth Derby cup to the unprecedented eight that already grace their dazzling trophy case.

title: The Barn Where It All Began
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., .May 4Rain drenched the green acres of Calumet Farm and, as night, came on, lightning blazed as Beaverboy lazed in the moonless sky. It Was dark outside by the time Sweet Tooth was led into the foaling stall to bear Raise a Native's baby. She was already three . times a mother and although nobody could foresee it then, her third foal would be a smasher. This was a yearling filly by Herbager that was destined to start Calumet back toward the glories the fain had known a quartercentury earlier. From 1941 to 1961 Calumet horses earned close to $16 million and the stable was either first or second on the national moneywinning list 16 times in 21 years. Now it was March 23, 1975. Purses that year would total only $212,000 and there wouldn't be another stakes winner until 1977 when Herbager's daughter, Our Mims, would be the best 3yearold filly in America.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Good evening, everybody. First of all, let me say that it's a great place to be back to in Portland. I've come West on this trip to talk about the most pressing issues that we face: energy and environment, urban policy, agriculture, jobs, inflation, criminal justice, tax reform, and also to listen to what Wettemers have to say.

title: DOLLAR SHOWS DROP IN NEVI YORK TRADING
description: The dollar declined against major world currencies in light foreign exchange trading in New York yesterday and turned in a mixed performance abroad, where most European markets were closed for the Ascension Day holiday, The Associated Press reported.

description: The Borough of Queens is a large swatch of land on the sunrise side of the East River, a place from which you can get matchless views of highspired Manhattan, but which is itself often shrugged off by downtown Manhattan except as a terminal for airplanes.

title: Bruins Halt Flyers, 75, For 20 Edge
description: BOSTON, May 4 Some people have called Rick Middleton, Jean RateIle and Brad Park the Boston Rangers since they came to the Bruins in a trade with New, York several years ago. Tonight the three former Rangers tallied three goals and four assists to lead Boston to a 75 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers, giving the Bruins a 20 lead in their National Hockey League semifinal series.

description: CHICAGO, May 4The National Conference of Catholic Bishops today adopted two plans that attempt to follow up on the intense needs expressed by clergy and lay Roman Catholics at the 1976 Call to Action conference in Detroit.

description: Piano pieces learned in childhood tend to star forever fixed in the mind's ear of the adult as they were played thenfalteringly, on an outoftune upright, Beethoven's Far Elise, for instance. or Schumann's Traumerei.

description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., May 4The opening of the third Women's International, an invitation gclf tournament comparable to the men's Masters, was postponed today as the result of a tornado watch. Although the sun came out immediately after the postponement had been an nounced, the forecast was for continued strong winds, with gusts UD to 65 miles an hour.

title: Referrals to Dr. Jascalevich Cited
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.. May 4 Even after other doctors at Riverdell Hospital discovered what they suspected was the drug curare in the locker of Dr. Mario, E. Jascalevich. they continued to refer patients to him because they felt that was the safest thing to do, a doctor testified today.

title: Bridge:
description: Teenage playeis with the ability to play against ranking experts on equal terms have long been common in chess, and are becoming more common in bridgeespecially in the New York metropolitan area.

title: AFGHANISTAN VOWS ACTIVE NEUTRALITY
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 4The new Prime Minister of Afghanistan has declared that with the military coup of last week the nation had acquired a policy of active positive neutrality and free judgment.

title: E.P.A. Cites Cost Moves
description: Douglas Costle, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, has told the White House that his agency was considering ways to make cleaning up dirty air and water less costly to industry. Page D2.

title: At the Movies

A dozen arc light moons, mounted on towers up to 40 feet tall, winked on, one after the other, and glittered on the brick paving, which had been wetted to simulate rain.

title: Center Seeks Permit to Demolish Radio City if Rescue Plans Fail
description: Rockefeller Center has notified the Landmarks Preservation Commission that it had filed an application with the City Department of Buildings to demolish Radio City Music Hall, saying the request was within the rules governing the landmark etatus of the 45yearold showplace.

description: JOHANNESBURG, May 4The South African Government announced tonight that its forces had crossed from SouthWest Africa into neighboring Angola in what it described as a limited military operation against guerrillas of the SouthWest African People's Organization.

description: Martin Scorsese, who directed such films as Mean Streets and Taxi Driver, and Herschel Bernardi, whose credits include Tevye in Rroadway's Fiddler on the Roof, will not exactly meet on public television, but they are ingredients of a package, a new nonfiction series about America's many ethnic groups.

title: Dow Falls Early on Inflation Fear; Recovers Partly to Close at 824.41
description: The stock market absorbed sharp losses early yesterday after the Government's report of an April surge in wholesale prices but staged an afternoon comeback to finish with a modest decline.

title: Art People
