New Life for Old Objects represents about eight years of toil by 11 conservators, funded by grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Can Music in May Beat the Rug?
description: One of Pierre Boulez's most success?? innovations when he was music director of the New York Philharmonic Aras to present a series of Rug Concerts in Avery Fisher Hall. The orchestra was brought down from the platform onto the main floor, while the audience sat in front and back of It on rugcovered tiers.

title: Broadway
description: TERRENCE McNALLY has a new play, and Edgar Bronfman Jr. Will produce it. It is called Bye, Bye Broadway, James Coco will star in it, and Robert Drivas will direct it. It is supposed to arrive here in October after trying out in Falmouth, Mass., Candlewood Lake, Conn., and Boston, and it is about, obviously, Broadway and the theater. The show is a valentine to the theater, but it has Terrence's edge, Mr. Bronfman says. It's a comedyfarce, but mostly it's a comedy.

title: Books of The Times
description: SUPERFICIALLY at least, Martin L. Gross seems to make a case in his latest book, The Psychological Society: A Critical Analysis of Psychiatry, Psychotherapy, Psychoanalysis and the Psychological Revolution. Yes, things may have gotten out of hand when socalled psychohistorians begin drawing absolute conclusions about the unconscious drives of people they have never even met, let alone psychoanalyzed. Yes, psychotherapy has not been as successful as pharmacology in treating such severe mental disturbances as schizophrenia arid,the manicdepressive diseases. Yes, Sigmund Freud did err in believing his hysteriastricken patients when they said they had been seduced by their put its in childhood, and his theories of infantile sexuality were in part hypothesized to redeem that error.

title: Jazz Concert Tomorrow at Hudson Museum
description: The last concert of the Living History of Jazz series sponsored by the Hudson River Museum and the State University at Purchase, N.Y., will feature Harold Ousley, tenor saxophonist. and Slide Hampton, trombonist, at 8

title: GUILD SUBMITS CONTRACT TO ITS MEMBERS AT U.P.I
description: Negotiators for the Wire Service Guild agreed yesterday to submit new contract terms proposed by United Press International to a vote of the membership, but said they were strongly recommending rejection.

title: Tear Gas Fired at Kent State
description: KENT, Ohio, May 4Portage County Sheriff's deputies fired a volley of tear gas to break up an attempt late this afternoon to storm a 10foot high wire fence around a controversial gymnasium annex near the site where four students were killed by National Guardsmen at Kent State University eight years ago today.

title: MONDALE,IN BANGKOK, OFFERS REFUGEE PLAN
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 4Vice President Mondale informed Thai leaders today that the United States was willing to lead a group of developed nations in financing the resettlement of some 100,000 Indochinese refugees now in camps in this country.

title: Notes on People
description: It was all supposed to be hushhush for the present, but yesterday it. leaked out that Nelson A. Rockefeller had put up for sale his summer home, The Anchorage, located at the end of his own 4.6acre peninsula at Seal Harbor, Me. The former Governor of New York and Vice President and his wife, Happy, were traveling in the Far East in their private jet and could not be reached for comment on why they are getting rid of the property, at an asking price of $1 million. The estate, which has been in the family since the original John D. Rockefeller made his fortune, includes a house that rambles around rocks and pine trees, a spectacular deck cantilevered over the water, two observation towers with glass tops, a heated swimming pool sunken into the rocky coast, and views of the Maine coastline said to be breathtaking. Sotheby Parke Bernet International Realty is handling the sale, which does not include the Coal Shed at the entrance to the estate, in which Mr. Rockefeller's art collection, offices and dock facilities are located.

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Fell To 225 From 225.5 a Week Ago
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell slightly to 225 from 225.5 last week.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP 1.3 PERCENT IN APRIL, THE MOST IN 3 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Wholesale prices, the harbinger of what consumers will pay in shops, rose 1.3 percent last month, the largest gain M three and a half years, the Government reported today.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Concert: Music in May Opener
description: MUSIC in May k the pleasantly Springy name of the New York Philharmonic's new postseason series, replacing the Rugs Concerts that were such a great public relations success during Pierre Boulez's tenure as music director.

title: DR. A. YESELSON, 57; RUTGERS PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Abraham Yeselson, an authority on international affairs and chairman of the political science department of Rutgers University College, the evening division for adults, died Wednesday in Middlesex General Hospital in New Brunswick, RI, after a long illness, He was 57 years old and lived at 226 Grant Avenue in Highland Park, N.J.

title: P.L. O. Pledges to Shield U.N.Force
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 4An official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said todaythat it was using maximum political and military pressure to prevent further attacks on United Nations peacekeeping forces in southern Lebanon.

title: ALCOA TO LIFT COST OF ALUMINUM USED FOR BEVERAGE CANS
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the industry giant, said yesterday that it would raise by 3.4 percent the prices of aluminum used in beer and soft drink .cans. The new price, effective on May 29, was set at 72.5 cents a pound.

title: Film: 'The Last Supper,' A Parable From Cuba:Politics and Religion
description: THE time is the late 18th century Holy Weekand the placea huge, isolated Cuban sugar plantation owned by a Spanish count from Havana who appears to represent the best of the ruling aristocracy. The Count is middle-aged and has the gaunt look of someone who suffers spiritually, as well as from intestinal disorders. He does not take lightly the responsibilities of power. He is as much concerned for the souls of his slaves as he is for their physical fitness.When his overseer, a brutishly practical man named Manuel, punishes a returned runaway by slicing off the slave's ear, the Count feels the victim's pain. The Count doesn't question the system, of course. Instead, he devotes himself to making it work. To this end he invites 12 slaves, picked at random, to join him for dinner on Maundy Thursday, in effect to re-enact the Last Supper that Jesus shared with his disciples the night before his crucifixion."The Last Supper," a new Cuban film by Tomas Gutierrez Alea, the director whose "Memories of Underdevelopment" was one of the critical hits of 1973, is a fine, cool, almost detached political parable told entirely in religious terms. In this way it recalls the kind of contradictions that made "Memories of Underdevelopment" so fascinating, and that are, for Mr. Alea, virtually a stylistic method.Though "Memories" looks at the Cuban revolution through the eyes of a middle-class intellectual who can't bring himself to participate, the film itself is passionately committed. "The Last Supper" is about death resurrection, not only about the death and resurrection of freedom, but also of repression.Like the earlier film, it seems to say more than one ever expects to hear in popular revolutionary literature, where ideas and feelings are supposed to be recognized and accommodated by even the dimmest minds."The Last Supper," which opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, is not an easy film. It has something of the haunted, guilt-ridden manner of the Count, the character who dominates the film and who remains forever mysterious. It's not, I think, that the director or Nelson Villagra, who plays the Count, withhold information. It is, rather, that the truth of human behavior can never be more than action observed. The rest is speculation.The film's centerpiece is the extraor-dinary last supper presided over by the Count, who begins by washing and kissing the feet of the 12 slaves while each, in turn, giggles and panics at the lunatic behavior of the master. In the course of the meal, as the wine flows, the Count attempts to instruct the slaves in Christian mythology and dogma."Sorrow," he says, "is the only thing we can give God with joy"everything else belongs to God anyway. The slaves find this concept confusing, while all, except one former cannibal, are amused at the thought of consuming the body and blood of Jesus in the form of bread and wine.Before the supper has ended, the Count, now thoroughly drunk and in a mood to be pals with the help, has freed one slave and promised no work the next day, Good Friday. When those promises are not honored, the rebellion that breaks out results in the crucifixion of a most unlikely son-of-God and in his resurrection in the person of the Count himself. His wrath is not that of a disappointed God, but of a property owner.My program notes, unfortunately, identify only the actor who plays the Count, but the film has several other memorable performances. There is the man who plays the priest at the sugar mill, a boyish-looking fellow who attempts to meet the needs of the Count and the slaves and fails everyone. There are also the actor who plays the runaway slave, a man who becomes a symbol for eventual revolutionary victory, and the old, old black man who plays the briefly freed slave.Except for the occasional use of the hand-held camera, which is so intrustive as to seem self-congratulatory, "The Last Supper" has been beautifully photographed in color by Mario Garcia Joya, who also shot the black-and-white "Memories of Underdevelopment." The colors are mostly the colors of depressed rural areaslots of tobacco browns and the yellows of feeble candlelight. The skies are blue, but they are oppressive, and the greens suggest a landscape of weeds.

title: Board Orders Rehearing on Its Approval of Building Nuclear Power Plant on the Shore of Lake Ontario
description: ALBANY, May 4Only five months after it approved construction of a $1.1 billion nuclear plant at Sterling on the shore of Lake Ontario, the State Siting Board today suddenly ordered a rehearing of the case, questioning whether the added electricity was needed.

title: The Pop Life
description: OF all the British punk pub newwave rockers, Elvis Costellowho will headline two shows tomorrow night at the Palladiumhas been about the most successful. Graham Parker and the Sex Pistols have won as much critical praise, but Mr. Costello (who was born 23 years ago as Declan Patrick McManus) has sold better than they have and has received his lavishly fair share of critical approval too. As well he should.

title: Witness Against N.C.A.A. Disputed by House Staff
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) In a confidential memorandum released today, the staff members of the House Oversight and Investigations subcommittee said that the recorded testimony of J. Brent Clark, a .former N.C.A.A. inVestigator, was deficient and should he corrected.

title: House Passes Tuition Tax Credits
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Overriding the advice of its own Budget Committee, the House voted today to allow a tax writeoff for parents of students in colleges and also in private elementary and secondary schools.

title: American Express and most major credit cards honored
description: Telephone PL 94805  Fifth Ave. at 43rd  Madison Ave. at 54th  Third Ave. at 70th NEW JERSEY, Riverside Square. Hackensack  Paramus Fashion Canter A Paramus Park Mall  Livingston Mall  CONNECTICUT: Lafayette Plaza, Bridgeport DUNES FLORSHEIM NEW YORK: Midsland Plaza Hicksville  Green Acres Shopping Center, Valley Stream  Cross County Shopping Center, Yonkers  Upper Name Mall, Nanuet Orange Plaza, Middletown  NEW JERSEY: Menlo Park Shopping Center, Edison

title: $11.4 Billion Approved for CETA
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)  The House Education and Labor Committee yesterday approved $11.4 billion to finance the Comprehensive Education and Training Act for three more years. The bill would keep the current level of 725,000 public service jobs and expand training programs for the unemployed with no skills.

title: Angolan Leader Meets Rumanian
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 4 (Agence FrancePresse)  President Agostinho Neto met yesterday with the Rumenian Deputy Agriculture Minister, Jon Ceaucescu, who is leading an economic and trade delegation to Angola.

title: STATE DRAFTS BILL TO FREE INSURERS ON BIG CONTRACTS
description: In a novel effort to recapture a lost share of the commercial insurance market for New York State companies, the State Insurance Department is drafting a bill to set up a free zone that exempts. large contracts from regulation.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, May 4Henri Curiel a cofounder of the Egyptian Communist Party who was once suspected of a key role in international leftwing terrorism, was killed here today by unknown assailants.

title: REFERRALS ARE CITED IN JASCALEVICH CASE
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 4Even after other doctors at Riverdell Hospital discovered what they suspected was the drug curare .in the locker of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, they continued to refer patients to him because they felt that was the safest thing to do, a doctor testified today.

title: A Communist Coup in Afghanistan
description: The Carter Administration is so far rightly unruffled by last week's coup in Afghanistan, where the leaders of A small Communist Party seized power in Kabul. But there are three potential areas of concern for Americans. One is simply that a genuinely nonaligned Government has fallen to an avowedly Communist one that is likely to tilt toward Moscow. A second is the possibility of trouble with neighboring Pakistan and Iran. And the third is the real possibility of widespread bloodshed as the new crowd attempts to impose its authority on Afghanistan's independentminded tribesmen.

title: Energy Research Chief Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)The Senate today confirmed President Carter's nomination of Robert D. Thorne to run the nation's energy research program. By voice vote and without debate, the Senate went along with a recommendation by its Energy Committee that Mr. Thorne get the job, which means he becomes Assistant Secretary for energy techonology. He has held the position on a temporary basis since last October. The job pays $46,500 a year.

title: Show Time at the Apollo
description: The curtain goes up again at Harlem's Apollo Theater tonight. Once the capital of the black entertainment world, the, theater closed three years ago, a casualty of its deteriorated neighborhood. The new Apollo may become part of the resurgence of the entire 125th Street corridor, the commercial hub of Harlem.

title: H. J. Heinz to Buy Weight Watchers For $71 Million
description: Weight Watchers International founded 15 years ago by a 214pound woman from Queenstentatively agreed yesterday to sell its operations to the H. J. Heinz Company for more than $71 million in cash.

title: Banks Stepping Up Loan Demand at Fed
description: Commercial banks stepped up their borrowing from the Federal Reserve substantially in the week ended Wednesday, raising the likelihood that the central bank will increase the rate it charges on such loans possibly as soon as today.

title: Emil Benoit, Professor at Columbia
description: Emil Benoit, professor emeritus of international business at Columbia University and a writer on arms control, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City at the age of 69. He lived at 39 Claremont Avenue in Manhattan and maintained a second home in Greene County, N.Y.

title: CABLES IN SPY TRIAL CALLED NONSENSITIVE
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 4A State Department expert on Southeast Asia. found last year that there was little of a sensitive nature in the documents allegedly transmitted to Vietnam by two alleged spies.

title: U.S. PLANS TO STUDY G.M. EMISSION AUDIT
description: DETROIT, May 4The Justice Department announced here today that it would begin an investigation of possible criminal violations of Federal air pollution control laws by the General Motors Corporation.

title: Bikeathon on Sunday Aids Cerebral Palsy
description: Bicyclists will be pedaling for money for Cerebral Palsy in Central Park and in the Midland Beach section of Staten Island on Sunday. Every mile complet ed by riders, who will he sponsored by individuals or corporations, will result in contributions for the organization.

title: Juveniles in Jersey Can Be Tried As Adults for Violence, Court Says
description: TRENTON, May 4 (AP)State appeals ?? panels have ruled that juveniles charged with both violent and nonviolent crimes can be tried as adults on all counts and that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey cannot build a New Jersey Turnpike interchange in Elizabeth.

title: Hughes Urges Tighter Procedures For Setting Bail in Violent Crimes
description: TRENTON, May 4Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the New Jersey Supreme Court said today that bail procedures in the state might be too lenient and were posing a threat of violence, and he asked assignment judges and prosecutors for suggestions on how to tighten them.

title: Canadiens Triumph, 32
description: MONTREAL, May 4 Two goals by Guy Lafleur and keen thirdperiod goaltending by Ken Dryden enabled the Montreal Canadlens to survive an improved effort by the Toronto Maple Leafs and win tonIght, 32. The victory gave the Canadiens a 20 lead in their lourofsevengame semifinal Stanley Cup playoff series. Games three and four will be Saturday and Tuesday in Toronto.

title: For Children
description: Spring Fair

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Dismissal of Suit Over C.I.A. Book Sought on Issue of Secrecy Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Attorneys for Frank W. Snepp 3d today asked a Federal judge to dismiss the Government's civil suit against him on the ground that the Government itself had conceded that he did not disclose any classified information in his book Decent Interval, which described the end of the Vietnam War and the collapse of Saigon.

title: Pimlico Somber Following Jockey's Death
description: BALTIMORE, May 4In an atmosphere of gloom following yesterday's death of Robert Pineda, the jockey who was killed in the second race at Pimlico in a fourhorse pileup, another jockey escaped serious injury in today's second race at approximately the same place where Pineda and three other jockeys fell.

title: Publishing: Exploring the Human Body
description: JONATHAN MILLER, who first came to public attention as coauthor and performer in that zany revue, Beyond the Fringe, is not a name unknown to American audiences. His directorial talents have been seen on stage here in work froni Robert Lowell to William Shakespeare. On television he was the guiding hand in the dramatization of Socrates, taken from the writings of Plato and Alice in Wonderland, which many critics and viewers maintained was not taken from the writings of Lewis Caroll.

title: Stage: Dead End, 40 Years Later
description: DEAD END by Sidney Kingsley. Directed by Will Lieberson; setting by Sarah Pryor Oliphant; lighting by Daniel Charles Abrahamsen; sound by George Jacobav costumes by Don Warshaw; production coordinator, Ted Mornel; production stage manager, George Zagoren. Presented by the Quaigh Theater. At the Hotel Diplomat, 103 West 43d Street.

title: London Opening of Annie Given Rave Reception
description: LONDON, May 3 (Reuters)London gave a triumphant reception tonight to Martin Charnin's British production of Annie, starring New York's original heroine, Andrea McArdle, at the Victoria Palace Theater.

title: School ChancellorDesignate Announces Three Appointments
description: Dr. Frank J. Macchiarola, the New York City School Chancellordesignate, yesterday. announced three appointments to his transition staff.

title: 93YearOld Vessel Undergoing Restoration in Hoboken Yard
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., May 4Barnacles and a thick layer of salt and dirt were sandblasted today from the heavy iron hull of a 93yearold fullrigged sailing vessel.

title: Music: High Baroque Masterpieces
description: LTITLE by little, musicians are learning that Baroque composers were not really primitive artists whose works must be inflated and given a modern gloss to sound right. It is as if connoisseurs of painting, say, were suddenly to confess that Georges de la Tour's use of candlelight was indeed effective and that he might not have done any better If he had photo floodlights at his disposal.

title: Affirmed Gets Post On Inside for Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 Laz Barrera's jaws, working slowly on a piece of gum, never lost their rhythm today even when Affirmed drew an unwanted inside post position for Saturday's 104th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Purolator to Plead No Contest
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)  The Purolator Security Company, of Piscataway, N.J., agreed to plead no contest today to charges of rigging bids with another company in Detroit to provide armored car service, the Justice Department said.

title: A Correction: Dulles, Va., Not Md.
description: We described Dulles International Airport yesterday as overlooking the Maryland countryside. Its tower is high as well as graceful, but it is not so farsighted. The airport is located in Chantilly, Va., with its own very agreeable countryside.

title: Carter May Compromise on Planes, Possibly Increasing Sales to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 The Carter Administration indicated today that it was willing to compromise on its controversial plan for a package sale of military jets to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel. Congressional sources said part of the compromise might involve an increase in the number of advanced planes to be sold to Israel.

title: CONFERENCE DELAYS VOTE ON GAS PRICING
description: WASHINGTON, May 4After a sixweek hiatus, the HouseSenate energy conference held an open session today to allow committee leaders to discuss a tentative settlement on natural gas pricing reached during intensive private meetings..

title: Tornado Kills 2 and Injures 96 in Florida School
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., May 4A tornado dropped out of a charcoal sky today and struck an elementary school like a car wreck, killing two children and injuring 96.

title: Stones Disk Due in June
description: Some news about two of the most eagerly awaited rock record releases and tours, those of Bruce Springsteen and the Rolling Stones. Mr. Springsteen's first album since Born to Run of 1975 should be out around the beginning of his summerlong tow; which will get under way May 23 in Buffalo. He will appear at the Nassau Coliseum on June 3, and no Manhattan dates have yet been set. All concerts in the first two weeks of the tour in the Northeast are sold out.

title: Dance: Ailey Ailey Opens With 2 Premieres
description: You might say the dancing was better than the choreography at Wednesday night's opening of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the City Center55th Street Dance Theater.

title: Advertising
description: The Glendinning Companies, which gave a grateful nation the first gas station game in 1964, has something new to offerCash Rebate, a supermarket promotion that will go into testing in about a week.

title: Fukuda Proposes Joint Financing on Fusion
description: Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda of Japan said yesterday that he had proposed to President Carter that the United States and Japan set up a jcint fund of Up to $1 billion to develop nuclear fusion as a source of energy.

title: Dr. Austin M. Pattner Marries Reina Safro in New Jersey
description: Reina Safro, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Safra of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Austin M. Pattner, son'of Mr. and Mrs. Abbe Pattner Of Floral Park, Queens. Rabbi Solomon Rothstein performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Problems in HomeCare Program Partly State's Fault, Albany Says
description: New York State conceded yesterday that it had to take the rap for some of the troubles of New York City's pioneering but widely criticized homeattendant program. The program, serving the sick and disabled poor, costs 5100 million a year in Medicaid funds,

title: The Right Not to Smoke
description: The effort to reduce smoking.in public places has been stalled in New York State by the Assembly's refusal greatly to expand the nosmoking areas. New Jersey legislators, too, are threatening to override tough antismoking regulations approved by the state's Public Health Council. Both Legislatures are succumbing to false arguments.

title: New York Representatives List Finances
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brboklyn, had outside income of $136,760 in addition to his Congressional salary in the last quarter of 1977, according to: Congressional financialdisclosure statements released today by the House ethics Committee.

title: Derby a Reunion for the Cauthen Clan
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4Up the highway from here in his old Kentucky borne, 18yearold Steve Cauthen was the richest citizen, the most successful dropoat and the favorite son tonight as he flew south from New York to ride Affirmed in the 104th Kentucky Derby.

title: 2 Octogenarians Look to Derby for a Ninth Hurrah
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 The 104th Kentucky Derby, to be run here Saturday, has two sentimental favorites going for it: Admiral Gene Markey, and his wife, Lucille, the octogenarian master and mistress of Calumet Farm, whose colt, Alydar, offers the best hope in a decade of adding a ninth Derby cup to the unprecedented eight that already grace their dazzling trophy case.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: CARTER AIDES ASSERT OUSTER IS DIFFICULT
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)When the Carter Administration took office last year, Federal managers discovered some people on the payroll making up to $50,000 annually who hadn't been seen for years, officials told a Senate committee today.

title: Auctions
description: YESTERDAYS are very much in the spotlight these days as can be seen in the sales of 19thcentury paintings that go on view in three New York galleries tomorrow, and under the hammer Thursday through Saturday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Young women from around the country who have been practicing Olga Korbut's kind of superhuman stunts all year are gathering on Long Island this weekend. They're competing in the United States gymnastics championships, at the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale. Optional exercises will be judged tonight, starting at 8, and the finals begin tomorrow afternoon at 2. The top 10 winners will become members of the United States national team; and the top 20 will be eligible to compete next fall in the world championship trials, a step toward the 1980 Olympics. Tickets, $5.50 to $7.50, are available through Ticketron (9779020) and at the box office. From New York, take the Northern State Parkway to the Meadowbrook Parkway and continue to the Coliseum exit.

title: E.P.A. Tells White House It Seeks To Cut Industry Antipollution Costs
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Douglas Costle, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has told the White House that his agency was considering several measures intended to make cleaning up dirty air and water less costly to industry.

title: Article 3  No Title
Jackson Pollock Exhibit to Be Checked
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 4 (AP)An exhibition of nine paintings attributed to the late American artist Jackson Pollock will be dismantled and sent to the United States for a check of their authenticity, the exhibitor said yesterday.

title: Books: Boswell to the AvantGarde
description: SIDNEY BERNARDBronxborn, a Washington Avenue kid with remembrances of hot mickies on his tongue, a World War II GI., a Brooklyn police reporter for the defunct Standard News Association and now roving editor of The Smith and The Newsletter on the State of the Culturereports on the avantgarde cultural scene about town with a loving attention to detail and personal involvement that is unmatched. The pieces in this collection cover a geographic and cultural topography running from the Old Village to the East Village, from the Upper West Side to the United Nations demonstration front, from Sheep Meadow beins to South Street Seaport singins Each is a finely embroidered sampler of objective observation intermingled with personal journalism.

title: Pressures for Change in Brazil
description: In the early 1960's Leonel Brizola may have been Brazil's most dynamic populist figurea onetime shoeshine boy who rose to phenomenal popularity through fiery rhetoric and such nationalist action as the expropriation of the I.T.T.owned telephone system in the State of Rio Grande do Sul, while he was its governor.

title: GOV. BRISCOE FACES TOUGH RACE IN TEXAS
description: HOUSTON, May 4Judging by the Democratic primary election fight between Gov. Dolph Briscoe of Texas and State Attorney General John Hill, it almost seems as if this is 1928 instead of 1978.

title: U.S. Granting $38 MitIlion Credit to Chilean Farmers
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Agriculture Department has approved $38 million in credits to Chilean farmers and ranchers despite the Administration's avowed policy of denying aid to Chile because of its human rights record.

title: An Architectural Tour of SoHo's CastIron Heritage
description: On Sunday afternoon the Friends of CastIron Architecture will lead a tour through SoHo, an area many New Yorkers associate with crumbling factories and wellappointed artists lofts. But the tour will demonstrate that SoHo is more than that. It represents the world's highest concentration of iron architecture dating from the 1860's through the 1880's. And to know the architectural history of its streets is to get a vivid glimpse of the city's past.

title: BREZHNEV IS IN BONN FOR FOURDAY VISIT
description: BONN, May 4 President Leonid I. Brezhnev came to West Germany today for four days of talks on disarmament, dtente and trade.

title: Are Mormons Against Feminism? Not Exactly
description: Barbara B. Smith, the topranking Mormon woman, tends to wince these days whenever she hears feminists complain that the Mormon Church has become the newest enemy of the women's movement.

title: Article 2  No Title
Members of House Disclose Data On Outside Income and Liabilities
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Members of the House of Representatives made public today the most extensive disclosure yet of their personal finances, but the disclosure statements seemed unlikely to cause many Congressmen political embarrassment.

title: Dividends.
description: OMITTED

title: Styles for Royally Proportioned Men
description: Fat is one word we'd never, never dream of using. Nor are we fond of portly, oversized or heavyset. When referring to our customers, we much prefer to say kingsized.

title: New Face: Penelope Milford
description: ONE of the main reasons Penelope Milford stands out in the film Coming. Home is her going crazy scene, as she calls it. She plays Jane Fonda's hip friend, Vi, who breaks down after her brother, a disturbed Vietnam veteran, commits suicide in a veteran's hospital by injecting an air bubble into his arm.

title: MOHAMED ALHABIB ESSOUSSI
description: TUNIS, May 4 (Agence FrancePresse) One of the founders of the Tunisian Army, Gen. Mohamed alHabib Essoussi, died here today. He was 64 years old. He fought for the French Army in France, Italy and Indochina and was chief of staff of the Tunisian Army from 1967 to 1976.

title: Sailing Vessel, 93 Years Old, Being Restored
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., May 4 Barnacles, and a thick layer or salt and dirt were sandblasted today from the heavy ironhull of a 93yearold fullrigged sailing, veisel.

title: About Real Estate
description: WHITE PLAINSThe building was called Executive Tower and it had a look that was distinctively Bahamian. Robert Lord, the builder, had even flown the architect, Anthony M. Pucillo, down to the Bahamas to get a firsthand look at the style he wanted to capture.

title: RN: The Memoirs Of Richard Nixon
description: The solidarity of the Nixon family never wavered even in the dark days of the Watergate scandal. The last of seven daily excerpts appears on page 8.

title: Bridge:
description: The expert bridge community, like Gaul, is divided into three parts. There are some who restrict themselves to tournaments, because they lack the time or the inclination for games played for a money stake. There are some who like the comfort of a rubberbridge chair, and have no liking for the hurlyburly of duplicate play in which the rewards, in this country at any rate, are masterpoints and prestige rather than cash. And there are those who play both roles with equal facility.

title: Eric M. Simon, Artist, at 86; Designed Variety of Products
description: Eric M. Simon an artist whose career of several decades included work as a painter, illustrator and packager, died Wednesday at the CaroIton Nursing Home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 86 years old and lived most recently in Stamford, Conn.

title: Pomare Work In a Premiere By Alvin Ailey
description: Eleo Pomare's BloodBurning Moon, which the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater offered in the work's New York premiere Thursday night at the City Center, is a dancedrama that never quite becomes dramatic enough.

title: Installment Debt Up By Record in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)Consumers increased their installment debts by the largest amount in history during March as they resumed shopping when warmer weather returned, the Government said today. Rising consumer credit is regarded as important because it indicates that shoppers have enough confidence in the economy to risk increasing their debts.

title: U.S. Six Ends Loss String, Beating East Germany, 73
description: PRAGUE, May 5 (AP)The United States ice hockey team won a battle of tailenders today, outplaying East Germany, 73, in the world championships. The victory increased the Americans hopes of avoiding relegation to Group B. The United States had lost in previous five games in Group A.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON, May 5For the last 35 years, a New Jersey businessman has spent his spare time studying how to make sea waves produce electricity. Charles A. Peterson Jr. of Scotch Plains believes that with the method and apparatus for which he got a patent this week, he has succeeded.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: KHACHATURIAN HONORED IN MOSCOW: The body of Aram Khachaturlan, the Soviet composer who died on Monday at the age of 74, lying in state at the Conservatory in Moscow yesterday. Among dignitaries who. paid respect to the composer were Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin. Burial will be in Armenia today.

title: Terrorist Abductors of Moro Say They Are Carrying Out Death Plan
description: ROME, May 5:The Red Brigades terrorist organization declared today that it was carrying out its death sentence against former Prime Minister Aldo Moro because the Italian Government had failed to give a positive response to its demand for an exchange of prisoners. But the message fell short of saying that Mr. Moro had actually been killed.

title: Weight Watchers, Noted Successful Loser
description: Potatoes and pasta. Lobster. Margarine. Camembert cheese. Grapes, cherries and bananas.

title: LOBBYING STEPPED UP ON AUSTRALIAN PLANE

title: POLICEMAN AND BYSTANDER SHOT NEAR TIMES SQUARE
description: A fleeing gunman shot and wounded a police officer and a bystander during a chase through large, lateafternoon crowds at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue yesterday. title: Bryant Park Is Denied to Group As Site for the Big Apple Circus

description: ROME, May 5The Red Brigades terrorist organization declared today that it was carrying out its death sentence against former Prime Minister Aldo Moro because the Italian Government had failed to give a positive response to its demand for an exchange of prisOners. But the message fell short of saying that Mr. Moro had actually been killed.

title: JOBLESS RATE AT 6%, LOWEST IN 31 YEARS; EMPLOYMENT GROWS

title: Treasury to Lift Trigger Prices On Steel Imports
description: The Treasury Department announced yesterday that it was revising the trigger prices on imported steel upward in a move to make domestic steel products more competitive.

title: American Ship Building Elects
description: The American Ship Building Company announced yesterday the election of Edward C. Forbes as its president and chief executive officer. Mr. Forbes had been chairman of the executive committee. He replaces Francis W. Theis, who is leaving the company but will continue as a director.

title: Sports Auction to Open

The auction coincides with the opening of an art exhibit devoted exclusively, to paintings and sculptures with a sports theme.

title: Conoco, Drilling Offshore, Plays Down Rumor on Rig But Its Stock Holds Gain
description: ABOARD THE NEW ERA, off New Jersey, May 5The Continental Oil Company's stock jumped 2 points this morning after a report circulated that this drilling vessel 77 miles offshore had found promissing rock formations. But the report was based on remarks by a Conoco employee and apparently was unwarranted.

title: W. Germans Top Sounders. 10
description: SEATTLE, May 5 (AP)  Stuttgart of West Germany scored a penalty kick in the second half to beat the Seattle Sounders, 10, in North American Soccer League exhibition play last night. Markus Elmer scored from 20 yards out on a direct free kick that hit the left post then bounced off the Sounder goalie, Cliff Brown, and into the net.

title: Big Board Will Extend Its Hours To Help Clear Questioned Trades
description: In its continuing effort to clear,up the number of questioned trades arising from the heavy trading volume of recent weeks, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it will be open next Tuesday from 4 to 6 P.M.

title: Reno Area Pins Its Hopes on a New Casino
description: RENO, May 5 In an attempt to regain some of the economic and political power they have lost to that gambling phenomenon Las Vegas, the once great silvermining and ranching communities around Virginia City, Carson City, Reno and Lake Tahoe have begun an allout public relations campaign, built around the opening this week of the world's largest casino, the MGM Grand Hotel Reno.

title: Lyric Arts Trio in Chamber Works

This is to sav it is made up of a pianist (Gena Raps), a violinist (Mary Freeman Blankstein) and a cellist (Marion Feldman).

title: Art of Patronage Still Thrives In Albany

title: Corporation Affairs
description: DETROIT, May 5The Chrysler Corporation today announced an acrosstheboard price increase averaging $90 each on its new 1978model cars. The move by the No. 3 automobile maker comes on the heels of price increase by its two larger competitorsthe General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Companyas will as by the smaller American Motors Corporation. Most leading foreign car makers have also announced price increases in recent weeks, but by substantially larger amounts than those announced by the American manufacturers.

title: Who Shall Live and Who Shall Die?

title: Running Scared On Abortion

Like a naive fool, I suppose, I had believed that the 1973 United States Supreme Court. decision guaranteeing women the right to choose whether to bear children or end unwanted pregnancies through abortion was such a reasonable decision that it would not be tampered with. After all, who knew better whether a child would benefit from being born, to be loved, cherished, supported and given every advantage that could be mustered up than the woman who would become, forever, its mother?

Perhaps no one there has noticed that New York City's expectation of a $600 million bank balance on June 30 is based on the belief that the trustees of its union pension funds will lend it a further $683 million this month. Labor's pensionfund representatives have begun to emphasize how difficult it will be for them to do so. This accounts for several developments that are particularly unfit for the eyes of New York's presumed benefactors in the Federal city.

title: Eudora Welty in Type and Person
description: IN this invigorating selection of her reviews and essays, Eudora Welty constantly touches the painful place where literary critic and creative writer meet. They are, she seems to suggest, essentially at crossputposes. CFriucat analysis, she writes in Writing and Analyzing a Story, has to travel backward toward a vanishing point beyond which only influences lie. The writer is bound in the opposite direction and works into the open"; to write fiction is to make a journey without maps. She pursues this theme in Words Into Fiction": The writer does not seek to solve the mystery of language but rather to take advantage of it. Criticism tries to solve the mystery, by translating fiction into another language. It offers us close analysis, like a headphone we can clamp on at the U.N. when they are speaking the Arabian tongue. The critical phrase in other words is, she says, one to destroy, rather than make for a real  that is, imaginative  understanding of the author.

title: Design
description: On a hill above Florence stands a Renaissance villa that, from the outside, looks much like its contemporaries, with stuccoed walls, warmtiled roofs, columns and iron gates. But inside, it's pure Italian modern. The contrast works because designers Carla Venosta and Guido Zimmerman, who restored the exterior of the villa to its original architecture, used many of the same centuriesold materials indoors  stucco for walls, terracotta tiles in some rooms and, in others, the gray serena stone used in Tuscan farmhouses for hundreds of years. But they are used in a modern manner. Furnishings are kept to a minimum, but the rooms are not stark because the softness of the surrounding hills, seen through plateglass windows, is brought into every room.

title: TV VIEW
description: Afew weeks ago, NBC's Tom Snyder opened his latenight Tomorrow show in characteristically irate fashion. Having just watched on public TV a twopart discussion about television in general, he was exasperated with professional detractors of the medium, and he promised to wage a sustained counterassault against some of the grosser absurdities of the holierthanthou print press. One cheer, then, for Mr. Snyder. As the obvious faults of the electronic medium have now been compiled to the point of acute stupefaction, many of the fervent naysayers have evolved into pointless bores, huckstering for their own egos and vested interests as shamelessly as any broadcaster.

title: Topics
description: It was Hippocrates who, around 400 B.C., observed that life is short, art long, opportunity fleeting, experience treacherous and judgment difficult. His words were called to mind last week by a little performance in Washington.

title: MUSIC
description: WHAT proved to be a harrowing drive to Stamford in the January ice and snow (and a useless one, too, because atter all that the concert was called off), turned out to be a lovely spring excursion last Sunday when the Stamford Symphony Orchestra closed out its season with the missing program. In fact, it is such a short trip that many.Westchesterites would do well to acquaint themselves with this shipshape orchestra and its interesting music selections.

title: Dudley Williams  You Can Only Go by Feeling
description: Ask most dancegoers who they would include in a short list of top modern dancers and the name of Dudley Williams is sure to spring up. But the man whom critics have called the type of dancer every choreographer dreams about having at his disposal, both elegant and passionate, and among the best male dancers to be found today has long been something of an unsung hero, dancing with quiet force as he is these days at the City Center 55th Street Theater, where the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is appearing through May 21.

title: DEFENDANT IS UPHELD ON A FAULTY VERDICT
description: Strict standards for jury deliberations have been eadorsed by a Federal appeals court ruling that stressed a defendant's right to a verdict based solely on evidence presented in open court.

description: Now that the snow tires have been put away and the clocks put forward, the thoughts of many motorists are turning to not just a summer driving tour but to a coasttocoast trip. To a few the pros. pect means completing the more than 3,000mile haul in the shortest time possible, but, in fact, most will take it much more easily, treating it as part of their lessthanstrenuous vacation.

title: The Violence of Extremism Grips Turkish Politics
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey  For the Turkish people, outbursts of political violence have come to be a part of daily life: bombs go off in coffee shops, .university classrooms become battlefields and passing cars spray machinegun fire on crowds waiting at bus stops. So when last week's May Day celebration passed without a single political death, the reaction was as much one of disbelief as of relief. The previous May Day, terrorists opened fire on demonstrators gathered in Istambul's Taksim Square. Thirtysix people died, eight by gunfire and the rest trampled to death by the panicked crowd.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 A car, approaching the entrance to Churchill Downs, slowed for a red light, and a small boy hopped on a fender.

The coat of arms originally sculpturec by Gilroy Roberts will still be there, but there will be an added inscription sayinE Republica de Panama . . . 75o aniversario which will be seen on only the 1978 coinage.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THIS is the time of year when most homeowners will soon be spending at least part of each weekend cutting the lawn and very often the grass is thick and green and partly damp. This causes clippings to mat and cake on the underside of rotary power mowers and to stick On the sides of the blades and housings. One easy way to prevent this is to spray the underside of the mower with a light film of lubricant before starting.

title: Tracey L. Lloyd Fiancee Of Stuart Richard Young
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Richard Lloyd Jr. of Arlington, Va., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Tracey Lee Lloyd, to Stuart Richard Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Youn2 of New Canaan. Conn.

title: READING SKILL PLAN TROUBLES TEACHERS
description: HOUSTON, May 5June Webb teaches reading to fifthgraders in Pearland, Tex., a suburb of Houston, and under a new school policy she must indicate each year whether each of her students has achieved 80 percent mastery of each item on a list of 80 educational skills.

title: Tenants Decry State of 7YearOld Housing Project
description: The rat peered from a hole in the corner wall, then darted toward a mound of garbage that had been stuffed into the fourthfloor incinerator shaft of 615 East 141st Street in the South Bronx.

title: What's Doing Around WILKESBARRE
description: COAL AND WATERThe story goes that when an underwear company decided to introduce the colored Tshirt to the world, it came up with the slogan that Undershirts used to be as exciting as a weekend. in WilkesBarre. Good for laughs, perhaps, but still an unfortunate reflection of the common view of this city as a moribund town of floods and coal mines. Coal and water have certainly been the dominant themes in the city's history but, contrary to what the company's copywriters might think, the two have left a rich heritage of architecture, and a fascinating blend of ethnic groups, making the city a rewarding hunting ground for those who like to explore on foot or by car.

title: U.S. POLICE PROGRAM IS CALLED C.I.A. COVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The United States is accused in a book to be published next month of using a program for training foreign policemen as a cover for Central Intelligence Agency activities and for encouraging the torture of political prisoners in Brazil and Uruguay.

title: Progress of Students Gives Heart To Demoralized Harlem Teacher
description: In 1976, Mary Stevens vowed to leave the public school system. She said then that she would make the class she has had now for two years her last. She had become demoralized after years of teaching problem children under trying conditions, some the result of budget cuts and teacher layoffs.

title: Susan Brien Meek Is Married to James Dickison
description: The Episcopal Chapel of Our Saviour in Broadmoor, Colorado Springs, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan Brien Meek to James Edwin Dickison. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harvard L. Wilbur.

title: Cauthen's Hundred Years
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 The way Laz Barrera planned. it, Steve Cauthen would take Affirmed out of the gate briskly and then tuck him back behind the pace. There could be no loitering at the start because Affirmed was in the second stall with Raymond Earl, a speed horse, at his left and if he didn't get out of there in a DUrry me whole Kentucky Derby field would be running over him.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6About a month ago, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. puzzled people in political circles here with the start of an intense and expensive campaign for a primary election in which he has no meaningful opposition.

As with Jack Kerouac's romans a clef, you get the feeling that only the names have been changed.

title: Council Unit Votes to Extend Apartment Upgrading
description: A New York City Council committee has voted to extend for up to three years a program that provides major tax benefits to landlords who upgrade their apartment buildings and to owners and developers who convert industrial and commercial buildings to apartments.

Its continents have been delineated and traversed, photo.. graphed and mapped. Its seas have been crossed and islands fixed by latitude and longitude. The world, so they say, has been made known to those who live thereon.

description: BUDAPEST, May 6 (AP)Four managers of the Gyor foundry have been given prison terms after a court found theni guilty of carelessness in a furnace explosion that killed nine workers on Jan. 4, The plant's manager, Albert ?? was sentenced to three years and eight months in prison and sentences for three assistants ranged from one and a half years to two and a half years.

Not only have the ledges themselves been of interest to preservationists but also the wooded lands atop them that slope to the west.

description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)American news. organizations are suspected in many countries of being involved in United States intelligence gathering. But testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee indicates that American journalists and news executives do not agree on a need for a law to curb the Central Intelligence Agency and other agencies in maintaining contacts with the media.

title: Tuscan Hilltop Summer
description: We had planned our summer in Italy for over a year, but it was only after months of answering ads in journals and newspapers and placing transAtlantic calls to obscure towns that we received a promising nibble. A cable from a town called Buggiano Castello arrived; stating cryptically: House available, letter follows. We located the town on a detailed map of Tuscany; it was midway between Florence and Lucca, about two miles from Montecatini Terme, a fashionable Italian watering spa.

title: MRS. GOULD'S SUNBIRD
description: I would not classify myself as even a thirdstring ornithologist. Rather, I'm more a birder of the fieldidentification type than a proper scientific sort. 1 rank myself without hesitation, though, as a worldclass name enthusiast. Easily and unpredictably, I succumb to the almost chantlike allure of certain names of people, places and, in this instance, birds.

title: Sudanese Leader in Damascus To Improve SyriaEgypt Ties
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 5, (UPI) President Gaafar alNitneiry of the Sudan arrived here today. in an effort to improve strained relations between Syria and Egypt.

description: They had lost their way. Not that Martin Paris and his wife, Lois Gordon, had never traveled to Brooklyn before, but on this chilly, day Dr. Paris had taken some wrong turns just east of Flatbush Avenue and found himself driving into unfamiliar territory.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: HAVE you ever been a twin? I haven't, but I do know it can be as trying at times as being fat, bald or exceedingly handsome. People tend to ask you the same questions all the time. After a while, it is easy to develop the routine patter that goes with being a guide at the Pyramids or the Louvre.

title: GARDENING
description: INDOOR plants are used as much for their contribution to the decor of home and office as for their interest as growing, living things. We often insist on using them in dark corners where light is inadequate for their growth and survival. Winter, with its short days and cloudy weather, often compounds this problem, so that they may be scarcely alive by spring.

title: Russia's Backfire Bomber; Red Threat or a Red Herring?
description: WASHINGTON  The Soviet Union's Backfire bomber is a flexible airplane, capable of carrying two large airtosurface missiles, or about 20,000 pounds of bombs. It is a controversial plane, still shrouded in some mystery, and a focus of intense dispute over its range and capabilities. Within the Carter Administration, the Joint Chiefs of Staff have taken a more ominous view of the plane's potential than the Pentagon's civilian leadership or other agencies.

title: Why Conductors Are Treated Like Gods
description: Are conductors the most popular, glamorous and esteemed celebrities in the music world today? Ask Sir Georg Solti, who arrives in town this week to lead four allBrahms concerts with the Chicago Symphony in Carnegie Hall, and he would probably answer in the affirmative. The city should erect a statue to me, Sir Georg recently told the Chicago Tribune. Eight years ago when I came, the orchestra was virtually unknown, nationally and internationally. We accomplished a small miracle.

title: Alleged ExNazi Fights Deportation
description: WATERBURY, Conn., May 5 (UPI)Government efforts to strip Feodore Fedorenko, an accused war criminal, of his citizenship and deport him to West Germany move to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., later this month.

description: It happens now and then. A miscalculation causes a check to bounce, producing anxiety over one's financial management  and a nenaltv of $5 to $7.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1ROBERT GROSSMAN

title: GARDENING
description: THOSE who have plenty of sunny garden space and who like to reap surprise harvests can have a lot of fun growing gourds. You never know exactly what you'll find from a packet of seed. Usually, it's a mixture of assorted shapes, colors and sizes.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: TALKING TO MYSELF, by Studs Terkel. (Pocket, $2.50.) Studs Terkel, who caught the spirit of Chicago by chatting with all manner of people and then publishing his tape recordings in several volumes, turns the microphone on himself. The result is an agreeably higgledypiggledy conversation  one memory reminding him of another, from boyhood service as a hotel desk clerk, to Daleyesque dirty politics, to the SelmaMontgomery civilrights march.

title: All in The Family
description: THE family, where all our troubles begin, is a tricky subject for the novelist. The Jewish family saga may be the trickiest of all  most difficult to control and subdue within the measurable limits of storytelling  because of the extraordinary social horrors that have disrupted its narrow confines. There are also monumental masters to move beyond Sholom Aleichem being only one of the first. Samuel Astrachan gives the subject a serious try in a saga of three generations of the intermarrying families Katz and Cohen and their fruitful issue; and it is apparent from the opening pages of KatzCohen that Mr. Astrachan is as familiar with the complexities of Jewish life in the East Bronx of the early 1940's (where the story begins) as he is with the circumstances of the family's rise to affluence, power and the concomitant dilution of their passionate blood and sittell ties  (where the novel ends).

title: Fighting World Hunger From Mineola
description: EACH evening about midnight, when the parkinglot lights have been turned off, the stale fruits and vegetables thrown into the huge black Dumpster and the store closed, the manager of a Huntington supermarket receives a visit from a peculiar shopper.

title: Thomas J. Me gear Marries Sally Hill; 7 Attend the Bride
description: Sally Ann Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Hill of Ridgewood, N..J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Jefferson Megear, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard H. Meeear of Brookville, L. I. The Rev. John W. Finn performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

title: STUDY ASSERTS TAX BREAKS WILL COST $136 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI)Business tax breaks provided by Congress will cost the Government $136 billion in the next fiscal year as part of an entrenched, growing and nearly uncontrolled tax privileged system, according to a report issued today by Common Cause.

title: Ambassadorial Wives: Some Are More Than Simply Helpmates
description: WASHINGTON  In a funny kind of way, it's a little like the tortoise and the hare  we took our lead from you, but we have overtaken you in a sense, said Margaret Jay, wife of the young British Ambassador, Peter Jay. She was referring to some of the questions that are raised about the proposed equal rights amendment and its British equivalent. as she tours the United States..

title: Hardy the Obscure
description: HIS words ring on  as live words will: so wrote Thomas Hardy in an elegy for George Meredith. The line holds more strongly still for Hardy himself. Serious readers and critics in recent years have found in his poetry values that make it attractive at a time when the great figures of literary modernism may have come to seem a bit questionable. Biographers and scholars, too, have kept a steady glare of attention on Hardy, as if to light up those recesses in his life that he meant to keep darkened.

title: Health Analysts Ask if Nation Can Afford More Physicians
description: In the battle against rising medical costs, some health system analysts are beginning to ask themselves not whether the country needs more doctors but whether it can afford many more.

title: Moscow and Bonn Sign an Accord On Economic Ties for 25 Years
description: BONN, May 6Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt linked the Soviet Union and West Germany. today in a 25year economic cooperation agreement.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: GOVERNOR GRASSO'S decisive defeat of Lieut. Gov. Robert K. Killian in a. primary fight over state nominating convention delegates in New Britain may have gotten pie most .attention . from the public last week, but state legislators spent more time talking about. another Democratic primary contest.

title: Immigrants Court a New Life
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: A Plan for College Football and a
description: The recent playoffs to determine a National Collegiate basketball champion formed, as always, a highlight of the sporting year. Teams like Duke and CaliforniaFullerton surged out of nowhere to excite the nation, while a manytime champion like Kentucky showed how to hold off the renegades.

title: Fashion
description: It Is going to be a tactile summer. Influential designers across the country have discovered the special feel and eye appeal of fabrics that say touch me  materials with nubby textures; open, airy weaves; tissue weignts; ana liguidlike smoothness. The newest of these summer fabrics go from luxuriously slithery silks to earthy, pebblytextured woven fabrics with a handloomed look. What makes these materials so new and so noticeable is the way they are used. A sheer, crisp, cotton broadcloth, for example, looks terrific when it ends up as a big, blousy top teamed with a sturdier cotton skirt. Or a silken knit with the look of Portuguese fishnet is enticing when worked up into a slouchy, sexy sweater worn with nothing more than tanned bare skin. And, this summer, the designers stay down to earth with their color choices  wheat, cream, mushroom, slate, sage, deep olive, violet and pewter.

title: Iran Arrests Student Protesters
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 6 (AP)Security policemen arrested 23 university students today when an antiGovernment demonstration by several hundred people in the northern town of Babol turned violent, officials said. Two policemen were reported injured after protesters smashed bank windows and attacked parked cars in the town's main square.

title: RareBreed Westminster Set May 28
description: American fanciers who have never seen a Tibetan mastiff, Xoloitzcuintli (pronounced sholoeatsquintlee) or Finnish spitz will have the opportunty on May 28 when the Associated Rare Breeds Club of New England presents its sixth annual show at Banner Lodge in Moodus, Conn.

description: Virginia Townsend Cross and Joseph Wesley Shaw 4th were married yesterday at the First Unitarian Church in Worcester, Mass., by the Rev. Wallace Robbins

description: SIEEGALKate, On May 5,1978 at age 94. Devoted wife of the late Max. ?? loved mother of Rose Shulman, Dr. Manaheim Siegal and Edith Ratnotf. Cherished grandmother of .4 and greatgrandmother of 10.

description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 6 (AP)Maya Kyla, a pioneer modern dancer who studied under Martha Graham and Agnes DeMille, died yesterday in Santa Monica Hospital of a tumor of the colon. She wag 68 years old

title: Mary Jane Hipp to Be Wed on June 17 To Charles Lawrence Brock. Publisher
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Hipp of New York, Greenville, S.C., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., of the engagement of Mr. Hipp's daughter. Mary Jane. Hinn to Charles Lawrence Brock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Brock of St. Louis.

title: HEALTH, EXERCISE, BEAUTY, DIET
description: It would seem that the Amen. can woman can never be too rich, too thin or too well read about being either. Each year, publishers lists heave and swell with newly mined theories of thinning, compendiums of fatteners, exhortations to embrace the pleasant pain of exercise, the sybaritic excesses of the California hot tub. One hardly knows where to turn. Told in one book that it's a feminine necessity to create mandarinlike, Cherlength fingernails, one is warned in the next book to forgo such nails when lifting weights, only to be reassured by a third book that pumping iron, with or without Chernails, will never deplete one's store of femininity: Confusion reigns.

title: Flow of 5 Largest Rivers in U.S. Was Well Above Normal for April
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)The upward trend in the nation's water supplies continued in April. with the flow of the five largest rivers well above normal, according to the Geological Survey.

title: Cynthia Gregory: We've Earned Our Stardom
description: The turbulent relationship between Cynthia Gregory and American Ballet Theater has kept ballet cognoscenti and Miss Gregory's many fans in a state of fairly continuous suspense. Within the past three years, the 31yearold ballerina, acclaimed by dance critics as one of the world's outstanding dancers, has retired from dancing in 1975, returned to dancing in 1976, resigned from ABT in 1977 and returned to the fold in 1978.

title: How Workfare Will Help the State
description: TRENTON

title: Soaring Price of Medical Care Puts a Serious Strain on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The cost of health care in the United States, rising quickly and inexorably, is putting serious strains on the economy and posing sharp policy dilemmas for the Carter Administration.

title: THEATER
description: MAMA RONECK, N.Y.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Remember 15 years ago, when the musical brain trust of America was announcing the death of the symphony orchestra? The symphony orchestra (so ran the argument) had sclerosis. It was nothing but a museum, a repository of works of the past. It had no place any longer in the scheme of things. It refused to play contemporary music, ana tnus naa lost the respect of any tightthinking person. It was bogged down in a sterile repertory, contentedly so, and those in charge were not even making an attempt to spin the wheels.

description: GREAT NECK  Sumre by Stasia ; watercolors by Bert Bronheim; 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays; Gallery Soho 7 Ltd., 6 Bond St. Reception today 4 to 8 P.M.

description: ANOTHER May, and the beginning of another season for striped bass. But is it the beginning of the end?

title: Charismatics Plan
description: NEWARK

title: IN BRIEF
description: Wholesale prices, considered a key barometer of the future price of consumer goods, rose 1.3 percent in April, their steepest rise since November 1974. The increase was paced by rising food costs. ... The Aluminum Company of America announced a 3.4 percent price increase in the aluminum used in beer and softdrink cans and an 11 percent rise in the price of automobile bumper and body stock. It was the fifth increase in aluminum prices in a year though the action by the nation's largest smelter of the metal did not draw fire from the Carter Administration, which has emphasized a program of voluntary restraint in combating inflation.... Unemployment fell 1o6 percent in April, the lowest level since the start of the mid1970's recession. Government analysts cautioned not to expect similar improvement during the remainder of the year, however.

title: Experts Testing 3,500 in Michigan for PBB Effects
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 6State officials, with the help of a research team from New York, began testing 3,500 people here this week to determine how the chemical PBB has affected them.

title: IDEAS &
description: Many of the most celebrated recent First Amendment decisions of Ihe United Slates Supreme Court have involved the claim that some ot her cons notional right should outweigh the right of freedom of expression. In the Pentagon Papers case. the Government argued that publication of documents about the war in vietnam let ii am would significantly interfere with the foreign policy of the nation and with decisions entrusted by the Constitution to the President ; in a series of cases involving the effort of many trial judges Io restrict what the press may print about the courts, the claim was made that such restrictions were necessary to enforce the Sixth Amendment (fair trial) rights of defendants in criminal trials. Both arguments were rejected  but in other cases, including those involving the right of journalists to protect their confidential sources, the press has fared less well.

title: Yoko Ichino Dances Kitri, In Quixote
description: The young woman who took over the ballerina role of Kitri Friday night in Mikhail Baryshnikov's production of Don Quixote at the Metropolitan Opera House may have looked familiar.

title: BONES OF MASTODON HINT A HUNTING LINK
description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y.Robin Ward, a 26yearold science student, was taking an afternoon stroll near her home here the other day when she spotted a huge white bone lying against a stone wall. Curious, she stooped down to examine it further, and her attention was caught by a sharp white object protruding from the soil. Using her hands as a shovel, Miss Ward pulled out an eightinch tooth.

title: Coping With Scandal cyclesx2019;
description: A newspaper exposes specific abuses. The public becomes indignant. A blueribbon commission is named and substantiates the charges. Then a special prosecutor is appointed, arrests are made, some convictions obtained: Public interest eventually fades. The temporary prosecutor stays on for a while, then becomes a permanent fixture in the bureaucracy or fades into oblivion. Within a decade or two, another expos is written....

title: Beauty
description: Most women buy cosmetics at a local drugstore counter or on the main floor of large department stores. But there are a multitude of places that are off the beaten drug and departmentstore track. Many women wonder if these interesting little cosmetic boutiques tney see tucked away on side streets really offer products or services that are different from anyone else's. Yes, it is possible to find some products and beauty ideas that are unique and fascinating in many of these places, but it's also a good idea to keep in mind that some of the socalled exclusive makeup and treatment items may be similar to or exactly the same as those found in the next little shop down the street.

title: Carolyn Leigh Fiancee of W. C. Patterson

title: Headliners
description: They won't have Arthur Levitt to kick them around any more: The 77yearold Comptroller of New York State last week decided, after 24 years in office, not to seek reelection. For the last three years, Mr. Levitt has chiefly striven, always successfully, with critics in and out of government who t onsidered him retrograde for refusing to commit more of the $9:3 billion in state employee pension funds, of which he is sole trustee, to investment in bonds to rescue New York City from bankruptcy. Mr. Levitt has not said whom he will support as his successor, but presumably it will not be New York City's Comptroller, Harrison M. Goldin, an undeclared candidate for the job and a vigorous advocate of buying city bonds with state pension funds. Also running or thought to be on the Democratic starting blocks are Stephen Berger, former executive director of the city's Emergency Financial Control Board; Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo; and Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive.

title: BuiltIn Fumes Plague Homes
description: A few hours after their house in upstate New York was insulated with ureaformaldehyde foam, the young couple developed headaches and a burning sensation in their eves. The baby cried all night. Within days the pet rabbit died. After a week with the heavy, strongsmelling fumes, the family moved out. An appeal to the foam installer resulted in a gift of air fresheners. Calls to the foam manufacturer brought no action at all. Now, five months later and still making payments on the house, thetouple plan to sue both, but the case could lake years to settle.

title: CRIME
description: Unlike the twoayear wonders, Tony Hillerman seems to spend time writing his books and it shows. About six years ago he started a series about a collegeeducated Indian policeman in New Mexico. There have not been many books since then, but each has been a model of its kind: well plotted, full of Indian lore and the feeling of the desert, never condescending, beautifully written. Now Lieut. Joe Leaphorn is back, in THE LISTENING WOMAN (Harper and Row, $7.95).

Nothing In art was alien to aim; our English ancestral collections at that time were still intact ; he came, he saw, and he marveled.

Population increases, coupled with decreases in available land in colonial times, pushed those in search of homes up to the edge of the Mountains.

description: Custer State Park in the Black Hills of South Dakota is an amazing example of the oftrepeated observation that the Black Hills offer'more variety than any area of comparable size in the world. Sharp ecological contrasts appear throughout the 72,000acre park, a blend of grass and pine and mountain, and the largest state park in the contiguous United States. It is also a game preserve that is home on the range to the country's largest buffalo herd (1,300).

title: Kings Point Wins Rowing

The Kings Point oarsmen won six races to three for Manhattan College,. which finished second with 93 points. Fordham was third with 70 points, scoring victories in the women's four with coxswain and the women's eight. New York State Maritime College also scored 70 points and was placed fourth because of fewer victories. Iona was fifth with 54, St. John's sixth with 34.

title: New Figures Show That Every Second Adult Woman Will Soon Have a Job
