The fund will be used, the union said, to initiate a studies program on the relationship betwen labor and society, the effect of changes in industries. and technologies and the history and current activities of the American labor movement.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: President Carter has made the fight against inflation the prime objective of his economic policy. His April speech was constructive as far as it went but it did not eo far enough. Two inffedients were conspicuously absent: a substantial reduction in the budget deficit and substantial incentive for private capital formation. Without these two ingredients we are in imminent danger of catching the English disease of going from inflation to recession to inflation at an everincreasing pace.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Auto Racing

title: Brazilian Declines Carter Invitation
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 6President Ernesto Geisel of Brazil has turned down an invitation to visit the United States extended to him by President Carter during his state visit here in March.

title: Sara Milstein Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Milstein of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Irene Milstein, to Steven Carl Eisner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Eisner of Baltimore.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: It is clear io me that the whole world's coming apart, cluding the hooks I try to read. But until I'd seen Lanford Wilson's The 5th of July, I had hoped the stage would hold out a Bule longer.

title: Elizabeth Villard Is Engaged
description: Elizabeth St. John Villard, an assistant professor of drama at Vassar College, and David Porter Howe, a lawyer with the Admiralty and Shipping Section of the Department of Justice in New York, plan to be married on June 26

title: Dispute Over National SecurityEmerges in Bitter Suit on Role of Dead Laboratory Worker
description: A dispute over a Government claim of national security interests has emerged in a bitterly contested civil suit filed by the estate of Karen G. SilkWood, a technician who was killed in late 1974 shortly after protesting safety conditions in the commercial plutonium plant where she worked.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ANNA MILLER, nee Craig through her Scottish forebears, plays the piano, and Jimmy McQuilkin plays the bagpipes. You'd have thought that never the twain would meet, but meet it did in the Argyle, a Scottish crafts shop in Kearny, a short time aeo.

title: Robin Rosenthal to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester Rosenthal of New Providence, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Rosenthal, to Anthony D. Mazurek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony S. Mazurek of Jersey City. A November wedding is planned.

title: Drought Losses Severe in Brazil's Breadbasket
description: IGUASSU FALLS, BrazilThe larger part of the majestic Iguassu Falls, an enormous horseshoe of hundreds of individual falls and cascades that cover 2.5 miles on the BrazilianArgentine border, has gone dry for the first time in memory.

title: Italy Clings to Hope  but the Odds Are Slim
description: The end of the melancholy drama in Italy seemed very near. A message bearing the by now familiar imprint Of the Red Brigades, released to newspapers in four cities, declared: We... conclude the battle which began March 16 by carrying out the sentence to which Aldo Moro has been condemned. Sonic tried hard to read cruel hoax into the message; a few saw it as a calculated effort by the terrorists to prolong and increase tensions. Others grasped at the inexact language. of the message, desperately finding hope in the vague verb used (eseguendo, a form of carrying out that could mean present or future action). All the attention is now concentrated on the gerund, one politician said.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Elephant Crushes Its Trainer At Quebec Circus Performance
description: ROCK FOREST, Quebec, May 6 (AP)6,000pound elephant trampled its. trained to death during a circus performance an a sharpshooter killed the animal. aftci efforts to tranquilize it failed, thepoliciii said. Another, elephant fled the ring hub was cornerecktoday in woods near here.

title: Giants Believe After a Miracle Draft
description: As jokes about Giant draft choices grow stale, the team that tried to bring RocV Thompson, Eldridge Small and Richie Glover to the National Football League can start grinning.

title: The Vanderbilt Collection Now Includes Controversy
description: CENTER PORT

title: Geraldine Ortner Is Married
description: Geraldine Lombardo Ortner, widow of Bennett Ortner, was married yesterday to Robert M. Hanlon Jr., a lawyer and assistant dean of the Fordham Law School. The ceremony was Derformed in St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx by Msgr. John L. Guido, the pastor, assisted by the Rev. Donald Magnetti and the Rev. John Oldfield. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Philip T. Lombardo of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Lombardo. Mr. Hanlon's parents are the late Mr. and Mrs. Hanlon of Point Lookout, L.I.

title: Editors Choice
description: AIRSHIPS, by Barry Hannah. (Knopf, $8.95.) Collection of striking short stories, set mostly in the New South.

title: U.S. Task Force Makes Plans to Upgrade Health Care in Harlem
description: One hundred percent immunization of schoolchildren in Harlem before schools close for the summer and evening hours for Harlem clinics are among the immediate goals of a task force appointed by Joseph A. Califano Jr. the United States Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Westfield 440Yard Team Wins Again at N.Y. Relays
description: Westfield High's outstanding sprintrelay team made a 60mile round trip for fewer than 43 seconds of running yesterday, but the New Jersey foursome returned home with watches for the second straight week. It won the 440yard event in the 13th annual New York Relays at St. John's University. Queens.

title: Cherry Hill After the Fire
description: THE burnedout remains of Garden State Race Track in Cherry Hill have now been acquired by the state's Sports and Exposition Authority, which will reconstruct it.

title: World News Briefs
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 6 (AP)Vice President Mondale met with President Suharto today and said recent Indonesian actions on human rights had received a very favorable reaction in the United States.

title: JeriLynn Orange Fiance of Lawyer
description: JeriLynn Orange, a violinist who expects to receive. a Bachelor of Music degree this month from the Mannes College of Music, and Ronald Lewis Cohen, an associate with the New York law firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Irvine, plan to be married next autumn.

title: INTERVIEW
description: I'M not comfortable with hoopla regarding me, said Harold E. Yuker. But he had to put up with some  in the form of a reception and celebratory dinner for campus oldtimers the other day  because Harold E. (for Elwood) Yuker is rounding out 30 years at Hofstra.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Last Monday afternoon about 250 of this city's most influential business lobbyists gathered in a private room at the Capital Hilton Hotel. a few blocks from the White House. Their purpose: to coordinate their efforts against legislation that would require lobbyists to reveal many details of their activities and finances.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Walter J. Turnbull, who appeared in recital last Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall, is a tenor who is bestknown locally as the founder and director of the Boys Choir of Harlem. He comes from Mississippi, has appeared frequently with local opera groups and other organizations, and is a D.M.A. candidate at the Manhattan School of Music.

title: Nancy Lopez, 21, Taking Pro Golf Tour in Stride
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., May 7 For Nancy Lopez, the transition from being one of the country's best amateur female golfers to the country's leading professional has been about as easy as sixinch uphill putt.

title: Palestinians Planning Show Trial of Israeli
description: BEIRUT, May 6 (Reuters)An Israeli soldier captured in southern Lebanon last month will be a given a show trial, officials of a Palestinian guerrilla group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of PalestineGeneral Command, said today.

title: G. O. jones Weds Gay Votaht
description: The chantry of St. Thomas Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Gay Vought, daughter of Mrs. Chance M. Vought Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Vought, to Graham Oscar Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Henry Jones of Norwood, N. J.

title: PROCEDURE ON JUDGES IS FACING A CHANGE
description: ALBANY, May 5A bill changing the way New York's judges are selected and disciplined is expected to be passed by the Assembly and Senate early next week.

title: The Lively World of ClubCircuit Rock
description: THE YOUNG men on stage are working the crowd. One on the end, with a white fedora and big, sleepy brown eyes A la Paul McCartney, flashes curledlip smiles at the audience even as he sings.

title: He Was the Clown Prince of Jazz
description: More than anyone else, Fats Waller captured the spirit of the Golden Age of Harlem, the 20's and 30's. He was there, part of the scene, playing the rent parties, playing at Connie's Inn or the Apollo, writing for Connie's or the black revues at Daly's 63d Street Theater. That's what we hear in his music today, the glory of Harlem. Fats was  Harlem, and now, 35 years after his death, he is being rediscovered. Ain't Misbehaving, a revue that is also a tribute, opens on Tuesday at the Longacre Theater.

title: Virginia Darling Is Married
description: The marriage of Virginia Kusterer Darling of Delray Beach, Fla., and West Hartford, Conn., widow of Robert E. Darling, to Rear Adm. William H

title: State Dept. Checks on Harriman As Representative at U. N. Parley
description: WASHINGTON, May 6W. Averell Harriman, who represented the United States at Yalta, led the American delegation at the Vietnam peace talks and has served as confidant of five Presidents. has undergone a security check to see it he is loyal enough to represent the United States for a few weeks at a United Nations disarmament conference.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MALVERNE

title: Commodity Expert
description: ENGLE WOOD

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: In the City And Country
description: TWO interesting new writers, John Gould and Robert Roper, testify boldly to the vitality of Life in provinces beyond the Hudson; and each, despite rural settings, is in his own way more universal in appeal than the savvy Stephen Dixon (see below). Mr. Gould's landscape is Downcast, the aus

title: Begonias Are Easy for Color All Summer
description: In Grandmother's time almost everyone knew about wax begonias. There was always a pot of these charming little plants on a window sill or on the sun porch overflowing with colorful blooms.

title: The Apollo Theater Reopens With Ralph Mac Donald
description: Harlem's Apollo Theater reopened Friday night after a threeyear hiatus, for the first time under black ownership. It was a gala occasion. and despite some annoying delays and problems with the sound system, the opening show was mightily effective.

title: Music: Two Country Bands Perform in Brooklyn
description: People who enjoy old time country music often forget that it has long been played by professionals on stages as well as by ordinary people in their homes. Scott Nickrenz, the music director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Old Time Country Music Festival, hasn't forgotten.

title: Skippers Told to Pack A Good FirstAid Kit
description: One of the most important items of equipment on any pleasure craft, sail or power, is the firstaid kit. It is also usually one of the most inadequate.

title: KLAN PATROLS TUPELO AS 400 BLACKS MARCH
description: TUPELO, Miss., May 6two Justice Department observers arrived here today as more than 400 black members of a militant civil rights group marched on he Lee County Courthouse and Ku Klux pansmen, threatening to make citizens arrests, patrolled the city in automobiles..

title: Hidden Rites Is Revived by Ailey
description: Two very different works by Alvin Ailey made their seasonal bow Friday, at the City Center55th Street Theater, where the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has opened a threeweek run.

title: Black Actor Held Briefly in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 6 (AP)A black actor from South Africa said today that he had been detained at Nairobi's airport for nine hours because he had no acceptable currency to pay his visa fee. Winston Ntshona, the actor, said he had arrived here Thursday night to play a feature role in an Americanproduced movie.

title: Taking a Risky New Tack
description: Nobody can say that Raymond P. Kurshan, chairman of Management Assistance Inc., doesn't like his risks big. Fresh from a Hairbreadth Harry turnaround I hat took the computer manufacturer from the brink of bankruptcy to some very solid looking profit ratios, the mildmannered accountant is looking for fresh markets to capture.

title: A Foreign Gloss on the Big Apple
description: Foreign capital is no stranger to New York, as a stroll down virtually any street in Manhattan's East 50's or 60's will show. Israeli banks, Italian retailers and Japanese trading firms are all part of the city scene. But just how great is the Impact of foreignowned companies in New York?

title: Sue Warren Whitley Wed To Phillip Strange Norton
description: Sue Warren Whitley, daughter of retired Judge George Franklin Whitley Jr. of the Virginia State Circuit Court and Mrs. Whitley of Smithfield, Va., was married yesterday to Phillip Strange Norton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Norton of New York.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Artistically, Mikhail Baryshnikov's departure from American Ballet Theater to join the New York City Ballet this summer is a bigger leap than his move in 1979 from Leningrad's Kirov Ballet to American Ballet Theater. The impact will be upon him rather than upon the City Ballet, which has always absorbed change without detriment to its artistic profile. In other words, Mikhail Baryshnikov will have to dance the kind of ballets he has never danced before and in a way in which he has not been taught until now. It will be a stylistic shift toward a different philosophy, one that emphasizes choreography over the individual dancer.

title: Apollo Triumphs in Soccer
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., May 6 (AP) Mike Mancini's goal with 17 minutes 46 seconds left in. the game today gave the New York Apollo a 10 vitctory over the New Jersey Americans in an American Soccer League Contest. The Americans had sold 6,153 tickets for the game at Rutgers Stadium, but the weather limited the crowd to 1,864.

title: William L. Standard, 78, A Lawyer for Seafarers And Writer on War, Dies
description: William L. Standard, a lawyer who specialized in the welfare of merchant seamen, died yesterday at the Cabrini Health Care C:nter in Manhattan. He Was 78 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street.

title: A Group Founded on L.I. Seeks to Rectify Injustice of the Hungry
description: Each evening about midnight, when the parkinglot lights have been turned off, the stale fruits and vegetables thrown into the huge black Dumpster and the store Closed, the manager or a mintington, L.I.,supermarket receives a visit from a peculiar shopper.,

title: Giving the Gift Of Fresh Air
description: WHEN you ask Lysa Mercado what she likes best about the summer, she responds in her 7yearold, nononsense manner that she likes swimming ("even though sometimes it gets cold") and the Pullises ("even though Emily cries sometimes cause she's just a baby and we have to tell her she can't do thin2s").

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information was received too late to appear in Section 2:

title: Secret Kissinger Travels to Paris Depicted in a Book
description: Some details of how Henry A. Kissinger managed to travel without publicity to negotiate with the Chinese and North Vietnamese in the early 1970's emerge in a new book. Silent Missions. by Gen. Vernon A. Walters, who retired in 1976 as deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Article 5  No Title
Cornell Foils Penn's Bid For 8th Heptagonal Title
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 6 Neal Hall and Carl Francis led Cornell to victory this afternoon as the Big Red foiled Pennsylvania's bid for an eighth consecutive Heptagonal outdoor track and field championship. Amassing a majority of its points in the sprints and relays; Cornell outscored the Quakers 7263

title: Ideas &
description: No one is against sunshine, but some are more for it than others. Last Wedneiday, an unknown number of solar enthusiasts estimated by one organ. Izei at 30 to 35 million  gathered accoss the nation to watch the sun come. up, look at demonstrations of solar technology, and otherwise celebrate Sun Day, an occasion conceived to draw attention to the potential of solar energy and encourage greater Federal commitment to its development. The movement's objects include legislation for a solar energy &Ink to provide low. interest loans for solar heating installa. tions and right to sunlight laws to ensur4 that no one casts a shadow on his neikhbor's solar collector.

title: A Band of Musicals for
DINING OUT
description: SITAR is an Indian adventure. Inside the new, stark white building on Route 110 in Melville a restaurant that is lavish in its appointments and exquisite in its detail. (For a complete description of Sitar, see Page 8.)

title: The Music Festivals of Europe 1978
description: Celebrations, anniversaries, special events and an unusually broad selection of performers make 1978 a vintage festival year. La Scala, Milan, for example, is observing its bicentennial with a yearlong series of operas, ballets and concerts that began last December and continues through Dec. 31, with the house dark only in August. Lucerne is celebrating its 800th birthday with programs of a historical and musical nature, and Vienna, as well as all of Austria, is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the death of Franz Schubert.

title: 3 Forces in Growth Of Somers Displayed
description: Materialism, diversity and change three forces that affected the growth and development of Somers from its beginnings to the present day  are the themes of a special exhibition running through May 20 at the Somers Historical Society Museum at the Elephant Hotel on Route 100.

title: Monetary Fund Changes Chiefs
description: PARIS  Jacques de Larosiere, who will take Over next month as head of the International Monetary Fund, has chosen a good moment to become the world's chief currency policeman.

title: The Best Little Sheriff From Tenafly
description: AN hour before curtain at the Entermedia Theater in Manhattan, Henderson Forsythe relaxed in a corner of the downstairs lobby. He slipped easily in and out of his serious train of thought to greet arriving cast members and their children, who seemed to adore the gentle man who stars as the gregarious sheriff in The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.

title: Auto(matic)biography
description: MORE than a year ago, Michael Korda, an editor at Simon and Schuster, took the bold if somewhat naive initiative of sending a letter to Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev proposing that he write his autobiography. Whatever visions there might have been of a publishing coup vanished when the reply from Moscow, according to Mr. Korda, was, in effect: Sorry, Leonid Ilyich is too busy these days to do a book for you, but why not let the Academy of Sciences write a biography instead?

title: Big Oil Rig Launched in Scotland
description: KISHORN, Scotland, May 6 (AP)A 600,000ton rig believed to be the world's largest oil platform was launched yesterday on its 430mile journey from Scotland's west coast to the Ninian oil fields. It is being towed by eight tugs and officials said it should arrive at its destination, 105 miles northeast of the Shetland Islands, in about 14 days.

title: $5 Million Damage Award Is Urged By Jury in Airplane Collision Case
description: MIAMI, May 6 (AP)A Federal court jury recommended yesterday that the estates and families of four men killed in the collision of their light plane with an Air Force jet get a 65 million damage award.

title: A PLEA FOR ACTION . . .
description: Unless we take urgent measures at once to reverse current trends, the Russians in a few years time will have the capability to fight a nuclear war  and to win such a war in the military sense of ending up in undisputed command of the battlefield and being in a position to dictate the peace.

title: GARDENING
description: TWO perennial vegetables that have been known and used for ages past are rhubarb and asparagus. Rhubarb, which was originally used as medicine, cart be traced back to China more than 4,000 years ago. It was introduced into Europe in the 1600's, probably from somewhere along the Volga River, and brought to New Jersey by early settlers.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: MARY GORDON'S novel Final Payments has received unusually good notices (a remarkably fine first novel, Maureen Howard wrote in the Book Review) and the author said over the telephone recently that what surprised her most was that a novel about sacrifice and old age has had such widespread appeal.

title: Board Rules on Cause of Sinking
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)The National Transportation Safety Board has ruled that damaged hatch covers caused the sinking in 1975 of the ore boat Edmund Fitzgerald, in which 29 people died. The 729foot vessel sank in a storm on Lake Superior.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The adage what goes up must come down held true for the stock market last week.

title: John Zamboni, Miss Connally Plan Wedding
description: Nancy Townsend Connally, who graduated last year from Yale University, and John VerPlanck Zamboni, Yale, 76, plan to married June 3 in Yale's Dwight Chanel.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Aaron W. Godfrey's answer to the question Do Schools Give Taxpayers a Fair Return?"[Opinion Page, April 16] is both inadequate and frustrating. What I got out of it was his mystifying contempt for publicschool teachers, school boards that try to get budgets passed and parents who would rather see teachers in the classroom than on strike. Coupled with this is a rather dreary arrogance suggesting that Mr. Godfrey knows all the answers to whatever ails the public schools. He wants discipline, lots of homework and an emphasis on grammar, spelling and sentence structure. The result will be that students will think critically.

title: Cautiously, Gains Claimed on SALT
description: Circumspection pays, the Carter Administration has learned, when the issues involved are as complex, crucial and politically contentious as those surrounding a new treaty limiting strategic nuclear arms.

title: FILM VIEW
description: On transcontinental flights, certain airlines now train closedcircuit cameras on the cockpit during takeoff and landing, broadcasting the pilot's every maneuver to a truly captive audience. The idea behind this innovation is presumably to reassure the passengers, but it is selfdefeating.

title: PENTECOSTALS TAKE RISKS IN SOVIET UNION
description: RUSSIAN Pentecostals are taking risks to express their religious feelings, according to a Swedish Bible courier who recently spent five months in captivity.

title: Confrontational News Fair or Foul?
description: Afilm crew for a local TV station bursts unannounced into an expensive Manhattan restaurant to look for alleged healthcode violations. The station is later sued by the restaurant for trespassing.

title: Princeton Choir Is Charleston Bound
description: PRINCETON

title: Suffolk Girl Scouts Now Stress.
description: COMMACK

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, May 6 (UPI) Ipswich, dominating every phase of the match, upset favored Arsenal by 10 Saturday to win the F.A. Cup for the first time in the club's history.

title: Symphony Conductor Wears Many Hats
description: ONE year after becoming music director of the New Jersey Symphony, Thomas Michalak is still having trouble remembering which city he is in when he wakes up.

title: The Region
description: Remember Sherlock Holmes and The ,Hound of the Baskervilles? The key to the mystery was that the dog didn't bark. In the contract talks between New York City and the municipal employee unions no one is barking either, and that's a clue that could mean trouble.

title: Retiring Servant Commits Suicide. In Her Room at Buckingham Palace
description: LONDON, May 6 (AP)A servant at Buckingham Palace who took an overdose of drugs in her room there committed suicide, evidently because she was depressed about having to retire at the end of the month, a coroner ruled this week.

title: Surreal And Absurd
description: THE title of this book immediately raises two queries in the reviewer's mind. Why has John Biguenet chosen in his title to avoid the term short story, when in fact the works he is presenting belong to a particular branch of that genre? And why has he restricted his choice to foreign examples  that is, to South American, Canadian and European prose pieces  when he could surely have also included works by United States authors, so as to demonstrate the important point that this kind of literature, far from being peculiar to a few countries, corresponds to a now universal metaphysical and esthetic attitude? What he is basically concerned with is Absurdist Surrealism, either as a halfconscious intuition or as a more elaborated philosophy, and this is present in North America, as elsewhere.

title: Bank Reform Goes Slowly
description: WASHINGTON  William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, could not find a silver lining, but he managed to detect a .gray one in the controyersy over banking practices that finally forced Bert Lance to resign last September as President Carter's budget director.

title: Slice of Americana
description: PURCHASE

title: Carter, Elated Over Western Tour, Plans More Trips
description: WASHINGTON, May 6President Carter, jubilant over the public reaction to .his threeday Western swing, plans more frequent trips in which he will stress the same populist themes of his Presidential campaign, White House aides said today.

title: ANTIQUES
description: He was known to all as A.M. Cassandre, mastermaker of such Art Deco posters as those that celebrated a French liner and a French liquorthe Normandie and Dubonnet. And his career probably seemed as glamorous as was Paris between World War I and World War II, the period that he documented in arresting advertising designs that translated Cubism and Surrealism with extraordinary skill so that they appealed to all.

title: DINING OUT
description: HARTSDALE

title: The World
description: BUENOS AIRES  After eight years and thousands of deaths, political violence seems to burning itself out in Argentina, but political reconciliation remains an elusive goal.

title: The World
description: When it comes to denouncing the United States for using (however fitfully) the human rights issue as a weapon of diplomacy, strongmen of the right or left sound alike. If there are violations of human rights in the United States, you should not expect the Philippines to bp totally free, President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines declared last week. A proGovernment newspaper added its own attack on such incidents as the shootings at Kent State University: For lack of space, only a few out of the infinite number of American abuses can be included in this enumeration. Mr. Mondale himself, without doubt, can add to the list.

title: Columbia Senate Supports Selling South African Stocks Selectively
description: Columbia University's governing body, the University Senate, has recommended selectively selling stocks in corporations with South African holdings if the corporations showed indifference to the country's apartheid policies.

title: In Soviet, Widespread Practice of Bribery Helps One Get a Car, Get an Apartment and Get Ahead
description: MOSCOW, May 6The Soviet Union is a society of pervasive governmental control, where the state runs everything and the police have almost unlimited power.,

title: New School for Social Research May Lose Three Doctoral Programs
description: Three of six doctoral programs at the New School for Social Research in Manhattan may be'closed by the New York State ,Board of Regents because senior faCulty positions have gone unfilled and the narrow focus of the faculty has come under attack.

title: Prosecutor's Test of Rights in Stamford
description: STAMFORD

title: BRIDGE
description: FROM a purely Westchester standpoint, the result of the district final of the Grand National Team Championship April 16 between two groups of contractbridge experts was of no great importance. One way or another. three Westchester players were sure to advance to the zonal final scheduled in King of Prussia, Pa., for June 10 and 11.

title: POLITICS
description: I'M a very sensitive guy at this point, said Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes of Great Neck as he pledged to pay his own expenses for an ostensibly official trip that ended with his suffering a torn Achilles tendon in a ski accident. He meant sensitive politically, not physically.

title: New England Fishermen Told To Reduce Catches of 3 Fish
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 6 (AP)New England fishermen have been told they must reduce their weekly catches of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder by 30 to 50 percent, starting tomorrow.

title: Anne Smith Engaged, To Kenneth J. Tucker
description: Anne Harrison Smith, a student affairs consultant with the American Field Service, and Kenneth Joseph Tucker, a proofreader with Ogilvy & Mather, the New York advertising agency, plan to be married June 10.

title: Dr. R. L. Segal Weds Francoise Fielding
description: The marriage of Francoise Evelyne Fielding, a'lawyer, to Dr. Robert Lloyd Segal, an endocrinologist, took place at the Carlyle yesterday. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: Article 2  No Title
Spy Trial Raises Again the Question of How Many Big Brothers Are Listening?; 20thCentury Technology vs. 18thCentury Constitution
description: WASHINGTON Last year, President Carter personally. authorized the installation of a secret video television camera and recording apparatus somewhere in the Government office of Ronald L. Humphrey, a United States Information Agency employee suspected of passing secrets to an agent of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. Mr. Carter is by no means the first President to approve electronic surveillance in a national security case, and no one suggests that his action has made the United States a police state.

title: Corporate Speech and Media Inc.
description: Fortunately, the Chief Justice of the United States, Warren Burger, is not always judicious. He let fly a vigorous essay in the guise of a concurring opinion last week which reminded us of important quarrels on the high bench concerning freedom of the press and served notice that the First Amendment rights of, say, The New York Times may one day be judged legally no greater than those of General Motors. That raises some fascinating and troubling freespeech questions and we are grateful to the Chief Justice for bringing them the surface. Unlike him, we think they are still safely academic and we hope he will not press them toward resolution too quickly.

title: The Inside Story
description: Connecticut Yankees, known for their, reserve, are also known for nosiness. Nothing fulfills our sense of discreet curiosity better than the house tour, which flourishes in Connecticut in the spring and allows us to peek into other people's lives without invading their privacy.

title: PHYSICIANS CONTINUE TO LEAVE STATE PLAN
description: Since., Feb. 1, the number of doctors throughout the state who have resigned their authorizations to treat workmen's compensation patients rose from 154 to 228 as of May 1, a spokesman for the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board said last week.

title: A Correction
description: Peter Rowan, singer, and Tex Logan, fiddler, highlighted a Soloist Spotlight show at the Englishtown Music Hall last Sunday afternoon. A listing on this page said incorrectly that Bill Monroe and his Bluegrass Boys would appear.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: Peking Presses Campaign Against Official Corruption and High Living
description: HONG KONG, May 6In an effort to restore, discipline and respect for the leadership of the Communist Party after a decade of turmoil, Peking has started a campaign to expose official corruption, high living, extralegal deals and the persecution of innocent people.

title: DINING OUT
description: VILLA CAPRI, a Jersey City restaurant that is surrounded by warehouses and factories, looks like a cement fortress from the outside. But don't be deterred. Inside, a theatrical stage set awaits. Busboys in red jackets and waiters in black tuxedos perform their rituals against a backdrop of sailboats, palm trees and a simulated arcade.

title: A Rose by Any Other Name
description: He works now at Riverfront Stadium, which is perched above the traffic rumbling along the interstate between the downtown Cincinnati office buildings and the Ohio River bridges. But about two miles away, in an old neighborhood of old warehouses, Pete Rose was returning to his baseball roots. He was driving down ow streets toward where Crosley Field once was. Growing up in Cincinnati, he often saw the Reds play in Crosley Field and he played there himself for half his career. Here's where it was, he announced now to the visitor he was taking on a guided tour. What a great little ball park it was. But there was no evidence that a ball park had been there. No ruins, no commemorative stone. Merely a vast empty lot with small rocks and other debris all over it.

title: Nancy DiFederico And Timothy joyce, Lawyer, Are Married
description: Nancy Ann DiFederico, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mario A. DiFederico of Akron, Ohio, and Timothy J. Joyce, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Joyce of Newt Rochelle. N.Y.. were married yesterday. The Rev. John F. Baldovin performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: The AirConditioned Tractor
description: THIS spring, Louis Demarest kept the airconditioning on in his tractor while he planted potatoes on his 900acre farm in Orient. title: He Could Be the King of Curmudgeons
description: Acouple of seasons back, Fred Gwynne was winning applause with a commanding performance as Big Daddy, the profane and hardbitten patriarch of an unraveling Southern Clan, in a successful revival of Tennessee Williams's Cat on a Hot Tin Roof. Last season, Mr. Gwynne was one of the bright spots in the shortlived Broadway run of Preston Jones's A Texas Trilogy, in which his portrait of a crustily stubborn old war veteran was generally regarded as brilliant. On Wednesday night at the Minsk. off, Mr. Gwynne will have a leading role in Angel, a new musical based on Thomas Wolfe's Look Homeward, Angel. This time around, he will play W. 0. Gant, the drunken irascible stonecutter whose scandalous misbehavior makes him a largelthanlife figure in a small Southern town. In short, he seems to have cornered the Broadway market in colorful curmudgeons, but where other actors might worry about being typed in this way, the towering Mr. Gwynne embraces the idea with enthusiasm.

title: Literary Ids and Egos
description: ONLY the title goes against the grain. It's touchy, defiant. New York Jew would seem to be the invention of a man who descends on a room full of strangers not anticipating delight but personal insults, whereas Alfred Kazin, a lifelong partisan of literary excellence, should look forward to argument, yes, but argument informed by honest appreciation. Even gratitude, that rarest of virtues in the literary world. A world wherein, as Thurber once put it, nobody sits at anybody else's feet unless he's been knocked there. Mr. Kazin's views are not only deeply felt, they matter.

title: Quake Shakes Mexico Border Area

title: A FATAL ROMANCE AT YALE
description: At 17, Richard James Herrin was riding the crest. The son of a Mexican mother and an Irish father who abandoned the family when Richard was 3, he was graduating first in his class of 415 at Abraham Lincoln High School in Los Angeles. He had played football and baseball there. He had been a leader in the student government. He was the class valedictorian. No one had ever seen him angry. He had never had a fight. During the summer and on weekends, he helped out in his stepfather's swap shop. He went with his mother to 7 A.M. mass every Sunday.

title: Screen: Lelouch's 'Cat and Mouse; Murder Intrigue
description: The title of Claude Lelouch's pretty and personable new murder mystery, "Cat and Mouse," is a play on the name of the story's main character, a police inspector called Lechat. It also refers to the brand of gamesmanship Mr. Lelouch usesthis time to unusually good effectto keep an audience on its toes. "Cat and Mouse" is populated by characters with fertile imaginations, so the film depicts quite a few incidents that prove, on close inspection, not to have taken place. In this same spirit, Mr. Lelouch keeps his camera continually pacing and peering, until it begins finding clues that aren't really clues at all.An unseen man, a minor figure in the story, always directs his visitors to a drawerful of identical-looking cigars in his humidor, ominously reciting the same line: "Take any one, they're quite correct." A peculiar jewel theft turns out to have been part of another movie someone was watching at the time of the actual crime. A married woman is seen visiting her lover, whose back is toward the camera; it turns out that Mr. Lelouch has shot the scene this way not out of any particular discretion, but because the whole episode is being described by a gossip-mongening, unreliable witness. The film reeks of that staple ingredient of any good-humored tale of intrigue, the red herring.In the past, Mr. Lelouch has often applied his full powers of obfuscation to more dramatic or romantic material, fudging the fine line between fantasy and reality at moments when it needs to be drawn most clearly. Here, though, these same stylistic idiosyncrasies are so appropriately applied that they take on a whole new dimension of wit."Cat and Mouse" isn't primarily a comedy, but it continually sends up the conventions of mystery fiction, and also parodies a great many movie-making gimmicks. The jewel-robbery scene, the one that is actually part of another film, is shot exactly as if it were part of this one. Mr. Lelouch takes great pains to trick his audience, and an even greater delight in the camera's power to deceive.The plot revolves around the death of a wealthy businessman (Jean-Pierre Aumont), the questionable innocence of his bereaved wife (Michele Morgan) and the genial snooping of Detective Lechat (Serge Reggiani). Its dnouement is complicated in the extreme, rich with the unflagging niceness that is so formidable a part of Mr. Lelouch's mystique. Even the lesser characters, such as the couple's sneaky-looking servants or the dead man's pornographic-star mistress, are so likable that it's hard to imagine any of them as cold-blooded killers.The solution to the mystery isn't clever enough to rank Mr. Lelouch's script with the work of Conan Doyle, but it does manage to satisfy the demands of logic without compromising the film's essentially benign view of human nature. For a murder mystery, that's a great deal more difficult and impressive than it may sound.Mr. Lelouch always uses handsome, friendly-looking actors to reinforce his films' feeling of warmth, but this time he has really outdone himself in the realm of clever casting. In 1975, when "Cat and Mouse" was made, Miss Morgan hadn't been in a film in years, and was perhaps still identified in most viewers' minds with her earlier, more glamorous roles. Mr. Lelouch cast her as a serene, implacably elegant matron of about 50, and chose the rumpled, redoubtable Mr. Reggiania wonderful character actor who had also been out of view for a whileto play the detective who both suspects and admires her.The teaming of Miss Morgan and Mr. Reggiani gives the film an ironic recogniton of class boundaries and a delight at the ease with which they can sometimes be crossed; in addition, it provides great deal of romantic spark. Their performances are top-notch, and they make a fine couple.However, they don't spend a great deal of time ogether Miss Morgan is most often seen at home, on one of the most spectacular estates suburban Paris has to offer. Mr. Reggiani is usually seen with his assistant, an equally rumpled, younger fellow played by the estimable Phlippe Leotard. Together with two women friends and one of the worst-trained police dogs in movie history, they are often shown eating, drinking and emphatically illustrating that a policeman's lot need not be an unhappy one. The unlikely domestic troubles revolving around Mr. Reggiani produce some of the film's most amusing and memorable vignettes.Occasionally, Mr. Lelouch's methods backfire. A brief flashback to the death of a young man in an auto accident, prettily shot and scored by Francis Lai, has the ill-chosen rosiness that mars some of Mr. Lelouch's other films. And an episode showing the two detectives racing through traffic, meant to be dizzying, goes on so long that it has the desired effect and then some.Luckily, lapses like these are infrequent. Besides, in a backhanded way, they're useful: They recall the preciousness that has been so tiresome in some of the director's other films, and that is so commendably absent this time. In addition to being one of his best and most ingenious films, "Cat and Mouse" is the closest Mr. Lelouch has come to producing his patented glow with enough discipline and economy to attract moviegoers of all persuasions, not just the romantics in the crowd. Those who are not charter members of Mr. Lelouch's fan club ought to find "Cat and Mouse" a specially nice surprise."Cat and Mouse," which is rated PG (Parental Guidance Suggested"), features one very innocuous-looking shooting and a plot involving a young prostitute, a pornographic-movie star and a few extramarital love affairs.

title: Higher Learnings
description: THE reforms and experiments in higher education of the 1960's are now being reformed. Popular reaction to radical politics, economic austerity leading to legislative demands for accountability, disappointment on all sides with the apparent decline in students quality are making it difficult to believe that anything of educational value can have come out of those wastefully experimental though selfrighteously political times. Remarkably, however, David Riesman  an author of The Lonely Crowd and Henry Ford II Professor of Social Sciences at Harvard  and Gerald Grant, a professor of sociology and education at Syracuse, in this study of recent educational experiments, have achieved the kind of detached yet compassionate vision necessary if the newest reforms are to be anything but ignorant backlash.

title: Food
description: One of the byproducts of the socalled gastronomic revolution in this country is a willingness of many home cooks to attempt dishes that were, a short while ago, too intricate for home preparation. But now, with modern kitchen technology, the most complicated dishes can be successfully made by the talented amateur. Still, there comes a time when the palate demands food as undetailed and uncomplicated as a basic, simple roast of meat. If we were asked to nominate the least complicated kinds of roast meats  and the best

title: First French Romantic
description: FRANCOISRENE DE CHATEAUBRIAND (17681848) holds a commanding position in French cultural history. Astride two centuries, witness of a rapid succession of political regimes, he was in turn traveler, soldier, diplomat, religious writer, statesman, political pamphleteer and the most prodigious prose artist of his age. Descendant of noble Breton family (his ancestors fought in the Crusades), he was torn between allegiance to the past and to new political ideas, suffering and expressing the contradictions of his turbulent times.

title: Deaths
description: EPSTEINBernard, M.D., The Administration and staff of Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center express deep sorrow at the passing of Dr. Bernard Epstein who guided the radiology department for more than 2 decades. Distinguished researcher, extraordinary teacher and superb clinician that he was, scores of L.I.J. staff members will remember him, too, as a concerned and wonderfully warm human being who always showed that he cared. He was a man of great wit & wisdom with tremendous talent in art as well as science and stores of energy that accommodated all his interests. We will miss him a great deal. To his loving family we offer our heartfelt sympathy.

title: Prostitution Ring Broken Up
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 6 (AP)The authorities say that they have broken up an interstate ring in which runaway teenage girls were used as prostitutes in a West Virginia truck stop. He said that as many as 300 prostitutes, many of them minors, may have worked the area around Triadelphia, W. Va. The girls apparently come from several Ohio cities, he said.

title: CANAL IS A MIRACLE SAYS INDIAN FARMER
description: BIKANER, IndiaJust a few years ago the soil of Pratap Singh's threeacre millet farm north of here was gray and gritty and his crop was scrawny at the best of times. Now, irrigated by the waters of the Rajasthan Canal, which being cut for 400 miles across northwestern India, the little plot is fertile, almost lush, and its yield has more than doubled.

title: Effort by Policemen's Union to Sell Ads To New York Merchants Fought in Court
description: New York City's Police Department is fighting in court to prevent the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association from asking thousands of businesses to make a small investment by purchasing advertising space in a. souvenir journal to be distributed at a policeman's ball.

title: Depailler Takes Monaco Race
description: MONTE CARLO, May 7 (AP)Patrick Depailler of France, driving a TyrrellFord, won the 36th Monaco Grand Prix today and took the lead for the world driver championship.

description: WASHINGTON., May 7Some high Federal officials had a novel idea the otherday. They concluded that the National Visitors Center here should be turned into a railroad terminal. title: David Jerome Taylor Weds Bette Ackerman

title: Landmark. Ho!

One, which the Justices have under advisement, concerns the designation Grand .Central Station as a historic site to be saved from destruction by order of New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission. We await that decision eagerly. no matter its name.

title: Television
Bouncing A Phrase

Now he is president of the Amvideo Corporation, a company that owns several small cable systems that are prospering by bringing television signals into homes that do not have access to sufficient stations over the air or are bothered by poor reception.

title: US. CALLS FARM PROGRAM OF SOVIET TOO AMBITIOUS

During the studies, a colorful cloud of barium gas several miles wide is expected to be visible in Nevada, California, Arizona and Utah.

title: 4 Today Programs To Honor Berlin at 90
description: Irving Berlin will be 90 years old this week and NBC's Today show is turning the occasion into something of a fourday festival honoring the Prolific composer. This morning the program reviews the Berlin career. Tomorrow, Arthur Schwartz, Alan Jay Lernes and Sammy Cahn, all fellow composers, will appear. Wednesday, Ethel Merman will sing Berlin songs and on Thursday, Mr. Berlin's birthday, Kelly Garrett will do the honors.

title: The Jews and Carter
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's visit to the United States has taken place in an atmosphere marredif one reads the newspapers regularlyby roiling dissension in the American Jewish community, and by a deep rift between that community and the carter Administration. That image is distortion, damaging to all, a dangerous diversion from the more serious, substantive issues that need to be faced in the Middle East.

title: Rochester's New City Hall a Blend of Past and Present
description: ROCHESTERThey are calling it the New City Hall, and technically that is right, since it is about a decade newer than the old City Hall. But the new Rochester City Hall is not a building of glass and metal and low ceilings and fluorescent light. It is a sumptuous, brooding mass of brown sandstone, with an immense tower and fortrsslike turret and a skylighted central atrium. The building was completed in 1891 as a Federal office and courthouse, and abandoned by the Federal Government in 1973 for a new and bland office building. The building Tay vacant and deteriorating for years as Rochesterites, city officials and the Federal Government argued over what should be done with it. Preservationists won, and the city government, emboldened by the Federal Government's offer of the building for $1, began in 1971 to turn the old structure into its own new home.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the late editions of Saturday's Times it was incorrectly. stated in a headline that two former Salomon officers had been .sentenced to jail. The men involved are.former officers of S..J. Salmon & Company, a, nOw defunct brokerage house.

description: PARIS, May 7French businessmen have often complained that the academic, community is long on theory and short on practice, that few professors know the realities of meeting payrolls and running factories, and that consequently they impart a warped, hostile view of the economic world to their students.

description: The Coast Guard and the Suffolk County police rescued scores of boaters who were stranded last night in fog off Long Island's South Shore.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: LIONEL SOLOMON, a 38yearold novelist living and teaching in Cambridge, Mass., writes a letter to his old friend, a teacher too, and a wellknown critic, Sidney: . . . the best of the modern novels are a literature of the self, not of society, which was your forte; a literature of egohonesty and truth and stripping down of the self in ways that went deeper than 19thcentury literature . . . a literature of personal life that included the impact of 20thcentury psychiatry and personal breakdown, without recourse to a philosophy of hope or a religion of salvationall this was a long way from the old ideas of the novel which you helped design and develop; and a long way from the sorts of categories and imprisonments that you yourself, and perhaps many others of your generation, were at home with.

title: Mondale Trip: Reassurance for Asian Allies
description: CANBERRA, Australia, May 7The irony was unintended, but Vice President Mandate's arrival in Manila last week on the first stop of his current fivenation tour of Southeast Asia and the Pacific coincided exactly with the third anniversary of the fall of Saigon. Mr. Mondale made no public mention of the anniversary, but nonetheless it served to underline the central purpose of this 28,00mile, 12day journey.

title: TWO MAJOR SOURCES OF TREASURY FUNDS EXPECTED TO SHRINK
description: The United States Treasury has been borrowing heavily not only from foreign nations but also from states and cities in this country. It is becoming clear, however, that these two bountiful sources of ready cash will not make loans to Uncle Sam so freely in the months ahead. In which case, interest rates are likely to rise.

title: Study Finds Wage Gap Between Races Narrowing
description: LOS ANGELES, May 7The wage gap between white workers and black workers in the United States has narrowed substantially in recent years, and between black and white women the gap has almost disappeared, the RAND Corporation said in a study made public today.

title: Dog Show: Cocker Tops Stellar Field at Trenton
description: WEST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 7Ted Young Jr. said he knew it was a stellar lineup of contenders for best in show tonight at the Trenton Kennel Club's 49th show, but it didn't faze Ch. Tabaka's Tidbit of Wynden C.D.X. The black cocker spaniel bitch on the other end of the black lead held by Young swept past five other illustrious rivals and took her 16th bestinshow trophy. There were 3,116 dogs in competition today at Mercer County Park, but it was Tidbit's show all the way.

title: $2 Permit RequiredWhere to Get It
description: In addition to a smallgame hunting license, New York State hunters must also buy a $2 permit to hunt turkeys. Applications for the permit may be obtained from any licenseissuing agency or regional office of the State Department of Environmental Conservation. The completed applications then should be mailed to Turkey Permit, Box 5415, Albany 12205. It is possible, with opening day only a week away, that permits applied for early this week will not get back to'the applicant before May 15. The D.E.C. regional office in New York City is at 2 World Trade Center, 61st floor, 4882770.

The show will remain on view until June 11 in the north gallery of the museum's Costume Institute.

title: Aspiring Comedians Find the Going Grim
description: Restlessly he prowls the empty apartment, tossing a baseball into the air over and over again, his forehead furrowed with gloom. The rooms are silent except for the thwack of ball against mitt; in one corner the cat lurks, tail twitching. Outside the dim apartment, the streets are full of sunshine and people. But Barry Diamond is all alone at home, with only his tape recorder, whirring on the table, waiting for him to say something hilarious.

It's a vessel in the strictest sensea fully bouyant craft that can propel itself across the open sea at speeds of up to seven knots, then nestle down into the water and twist almost six miles of pipe into the earth below.

title: Glacier Threat to Oil Ships Assessed
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (Reuters)The continued breakup of an Alaskan glacier could pose a threat to shipping lanes at Port Valdez, the southern terminus of the Alaska pipeline, the United States Geological Survey warned today. The agency monitors the 425squaremile glacier to assess its potential for rapid movement backward, creating icebergs like those than broke off last August. Should the glacier begin a rapid ?? it could throw off large icebergs very rapidly, a survey spokesman said.

title: Sporting Gear
description: In the old days, you called them water wings, and they provided a sense of security for kids flopping around in the water while learning how to stay afloat. Today, they're Schwimmflugels (swim wings) and can be used as swimming aids for children and adults. The inflated triangular wings are attached around the upper arms, and an uninflated flat side is worn against the body. This not only helps eliminate chafing and other discomforts, but also permits unrestricted natural arm movements. A safety feature includes twin air chambers, so if one is punctured, the other can still support the wearer. They are not meant to be life preservers, however. Schwimmflugels are priced at $4 a pair from Bema U.S.A., 2015 Weaver Park Drive, Clearwater, Fla. 33515.

description: Nine doctors and businessmen who invested in an upstate nursing home 11 years ago made profits of nearly $3 million from Medicaid reimbursements for exorbitant construction costs and a sweetheart lease. title: Penney Settlement In Suit With Lazar Totals $2.5 Million
description: The J. C. Penney Company has obtained an agreement from H. L. Lazar, Inc., a general contractor, its affiliates and certain of its subcontractors to pay Periney $2.5 million in settlement of a suit brought against them to recover alleged bribes and overcharges.

title: Some Earnings Climb Under Rule On ForeignExchange Accounting
description: In many of the financial statements pouring out of corporate headquarters these days. there is a hidden positive factorthe flip side of the much maligned Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 8.

title: Mime: Amarantov In New York Debut
description: BRIS AMARANTOV, a boyishlooking 37yearold mime who recently left the Soviet Union, made his New York debut yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Argentine Issue: Who Will Rule?; RightWing Terrorism at Issue
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 7The Argentine military junta's decision to keep President Jorge Rafael Videla in office until early 1981 leaves unresolved the question of the apportionment of political power between the junta and General Videla.

title: Dance: Trio by the Ailey
description: Theater presented three works for the first time this season Saturday night at the City Cen ??e was dead serious. One was frivolous. And one was merely silly.

description: After Reggie Jackson struck out against Len Barker of the Texas Rangers in the 12th inning yesterday at Yankee Stadium, he had a piece of advice for Chris Chambliss, the next batter.

title: Aid for Battered Women Called Lax
description: NEWARK, May 7Despite increased public awareness of the problems of battered women, there has been little institutional response to the problems confronted by women who are victims of violence in their homes.

title: U.S. Reported Planning to Seek Cuts in Amtrak Service
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Federal Department of Transportation will recommend significant cutbacks in Amtrak service tomorrow in a new nationwide plan to save Federal subsidization costs, railroad and Government sources said.

title: FRANCES JOSEPHINE VOGES
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 7 (UPI)Frances Josephine Voges, an 800pound woman known in sideshows and carnivals as Baby Frances, died at University Community Hospital yesterday of pneumonia and heart disease. She was 57 years old.

title: Phyllis Newman In a Solo Show
description: WITH her crystalline singing voice, her wholesome good looks, her self  mocking humor and her forthright, effusive manner, Phyllis Newman is a natural musical comedy leading lady. She can light up a theaterand she has a personality that is transportable to other media, which is why she is such a popular and convivial guest on television talk shows.

title: Chess:
description: The principle behind the Louis D. Statham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., is to pit some of the world's top players against players who hold at least a United States Chess Federational national master's rank.

title: InterestBearing Checking Accounts the Ban Is Eroding
description: Two Federal agencies chipped away last week at a 45yearold prohibition on paying interest on checking accounts.

title: Former Mayor Beame Is Counting On Carter's Help to Pay His Debts
description: With a little help from his offandon friend in the White House, former Mayor Abraham D. Beame hopes to pay off in one swoop the substantial debt from his unsuccessful reelection campaign.

title: Alabama Town Fears Moon Sect Plans Takeover
description: BAYOU LA BATRE, Ala., May 7 (UPI)When members of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church paid $6 million for land and a boatbuilding company here, people in this small fishing town worried over the social and religious impact of the cult's entry.

title: Bleacher Bums Take to the Stage
description: THE CHICAGO CUBS learned they couldn't take the bums out of the bleachers and move them to Atlanta in 1969, but the Organic Theater Company has successfully taken the bums out of the bleachers and transferred them to a New York stage in 1978.

title: `Absurd Person Staged on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Alan Ayck bourn's Absurb Person Singular is a comic vessel that, fills steadily with pain. It is a comedy of war, and although its savageries touch upon the private wars of husbands and wives, its main concern is public.

title: 2 TIMES CORRESPONDENTS RECEIVE WEINTAL AWARDS
description: Flora Lewis and C. L. Sulzberger of The New York Times; Keyes Beech of The Chicago Daily News, and Eric Sevareid have been awarded the 1978 Edward Weintal Prize and Awards for distinguished reporting on American foreign policy and diplomacy.

title: Caputo Proposes New York City Borrow From Federal Reserve
description: A Republian member of Congress from New York State proposed yesterday tha New York City borrow from the Federal Reserve Bank to avert potential bankruptcy if legislation to aid city financing gets bottled up in the Senate

title: Few Democrats in Massachusetts W illingto Oppose Senator Brooke
description: BOSTON, May 7Senator Edward W. Brooke. the only Republican to carry Massachusetts since 1970, does not have a united party behind him: Polls show new areas of vulnerability on personal and political issues, and among some important population groups.

title: Financial Reports of 407 in House Show They Are Cautious Investors
description: A computerized study of the personal financial disclosures filed last week by 407 members of the House of Representatives disproves some myths but provides some interesting insights into the way members handle their private finances and their public responsibilities. .

title: Advertising
description: We've got a pair of winners this morning, Ted Bates & Company and Advertising to Women. Bates got the Breck Shampoo and Creme Rinse accounts from American Cynamid. For A.T.W. it is Chung King Chinese Foods (frozen and canned) and Patio brands Mexican foods from R.J.R. Foods, a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds Industries. The billings on the former are put at $7 million and the latter at $4 million.

title: Business Spending Plans Rise 8.5%, Survey Says
description: United States businesses plan to spend a record $159.3 billion on plant expansion and modernization thin year, an increase of 8.5 percent over 1977, the McGrawHill Publications Company stated yesterday.

title: Chinese Combating Drought
description: HONG KONG, May 7 (Reuters)Almost six million Chinese farmers are fighting a drought in the eastern Chinese provinces of Anhwei and Kiangsu, the Peking radio, monitored here, reported today. More than 3.2 million farmers nave been mobilized in the northern Huai River region to combat the drought, the radio said. In Kiangsu Province, about 2.5 million farmers were digging wells, the broadcast added.

title: Big Apple Directory Printed for London
description: Every Tuesday since November The Times of London has been running the same full page with the headline The Times Reader Services Directory and the subhead, The who's of what's where.

title: A Couple That Live in a Nursery School  By Choice
description: We used to change 30 diapers a day. It was like running a farm, said Dominique Hiigli with a laugh. She looked speculatively at the padded, pearshaped form of a 20monthold youngster who happened to be tottering past. Seeing no telltale signs of wetness, she continued, It all came, really, out of the excitement of having our own daughter.

title: How to Take the Limp (and Wince) Out of Jogging; Flexibility Muscle Balance Training Schedule Terrain Proper Footwear
description: WHEN everybody else is jogging to get in shape, how do you get in shape for jogging.

title: Quazza of F.D.U. Leads in Decathlon
description: Jeff Quazza of Fairleigh Dickinson University registered 3,512 points yesterday afternoon to take the lead at the halfway mark of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association decathlon championship at St, John's University.

title: Horowitz Plays Chopin
description: IT WAS a classic case of the mountain's coming to Mohammed yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. With the gesture of a true grand seigneur, a gesture that among musicians today probably only Vladimir Horowitz could have made and carried off triumphantly, the pianist gave an all Chopin recital specifically for his overseas admirers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The first of eight public hearings on the Department of Transportation's proposed commuter rail and bus fare increases is to begin today at the Bayonne Municipal Building at 8 P.M.

title: Stage: E.L.T. Presents Sondheim's Company
description: THERE Is an Infectious joy that infuses the young, professional performers who play in the revivals presented by the Equity Library Theater, uptown on West 103d Street, and the newest production, Company, is a case in point.

title: Beatification Rites Held for Italian Nun
description: ROME, May 7 (AP)Sister Maria Enrichetta Cominici, an Italian nun who pioneered settlements for her religious order in India during the 19th century, was beatified today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If a football team tries a field goal earlier than fourth down and It is blocked but recovered by the offensive team, is it the same series of downs or is t firstand10? What if t's a fake feld goal?

title: Mexico Legalizes Communists and 2 Other Parties
description: MEXICO CITY, May 7The Mexican Government has legalized the Communist Party for the first time in 40 years, enabling it to compete openly for congressional seats in the July 1979 elections.

title: Toronto's SelfMade Tiger
description: IT is a face only a mother could love, It resembles a clenched fistthe skin is pulled tight over high cheekbones, and a nose, perhaps once classic, now has unseemly bends and a certain pugness to it. His face is so flat, someone once said, he could kiss a wall. It is hard to imagine Dave (Tiger) Williams kissing anything.

title: 6 Are Injured in Houston Violence
description: HOUSTON, May 7 (UPI)  Violence erupted at a city park tonight, leaving two television newsmen and four police officers injured and city police force on standby alert.

title: A Power Combine for New York State
description: The cost of building electricity generating plants has soared in recent years. In part this inflation is unavoidable, even desirable, because it reflects additional expenditures for antipollution equipment and nuclear safety. But there is still considerable room for saving money in siting, financing and constructing power plants. And that is why a proposal by New York's seven power companies for a joint construction and operation effort merits government approval.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TONIGHT

title: Begin Ends U.S. Trip With Plea for New Peace Talks
description: Prime Mininster Menachem Begin wound up his eightday coasttocoast United States visit with an emotional appeal before an audience of several thou. sand gathered yesterday in New York City's Central Park 'to, our Arab neighbors, to give up their hostile designs on Israel, and let us sit down and negotiate peace.

title: Cosmos 20 Victors, Tie League Mark
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 7Though they played below, their capability, the Cosmos posted their sixth consecutive victory this season by defeating the Detroit Express, 2.0, before 45,321 fans this afternoon at. Giants Stadium.

title: Sinking the Waterways Bill
description: The nation's barge operators flexed their muscles last week, persuading the Senate to drop legislation that would have required them to pay part of the cost improving rivers and canals. Now it is up to the President to make good on his promise to veto new lock and dam construction until a costsharing formula is found.

title: The View from Damascus
description: DAMASCUSWe are not rejectionists. With those words a respected Syrian official began explaining that his Government is committed to the idea of real peace in the Middle East.

title: El Salvador's Dissidents Disappointed at U.S. Silence
description: SAN SALVADORReligious and opposition leaders in El Salvador have expressed dismay at the silence of the Carter Administration in face of a new wave of repression by this country's rightwing military Government.

title: From Theater to Chapel
description: A Roman Catholic chapel is being moved around the corner from Park Avenue to a building on East 58th Street that, during World War II, housed the Cafe Society Uptown nightclub and later the Fine Arts Theater, one of New York's earliest artfilm houses on the East Side.

title: No Easy Riders In Bike Marathon
description: Only joggers and Pigeons watched the city's longest and most important bicycle race yesterday, 50 miles that started at 7:10 A.M. in the drizzle and gloom and eerie quiet of Central Park.

title: Soviet Immigrants Stage a Happening in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, May 7  Two barechested Russian immigrants wearing butcher's aprons and the look of slightly debauched seraphim darted madly across a trafficfilled road running along Jerusalem's Valley of Hinnon, which in Jewish lore is regarded as hell.

title: Flyers Top Bruins, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7The Philadelphia Flyers dug into their resources tonight, including their lucky Kate Smith recording of God Bless America for the first time this season, and turned back the Boston Bruins, 31, at the Spectrum.

title: Nancy C. Juster Married to Marshall S. Schiff

description: President Carter's recent criticism of lawyers echoes not only his famous 1974 Georgia Law Day speech, but also the observations of a range of other students of the legal profession.

description: THE Oslo Philharmonic's concert in Carnegie Hall Saturday night could be viewed in two ways, one of which would have to take into consideration the depressingly conventional nature of the program.

title: F.T.C. OPPOSES SHIFT FOR OIL ACCOUNTING
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Federal Trade Commission has urged the Securi ties and Exchange Commission not to adopt a controversial change in the way oil and gas producers are required to account for exploration costs.

title: Aspiring Comedians Find the Going Grim
description: Restlessly he prowls the empty apartment, tossing a baseball into the air over and over again, his forehead furroived with gloom. The rooms are silent except for the thwack of ball against Mitt; .in one corner the ,cat lurks. tail twitching. Outside the dimapartment; the streets are full of sunShine and; people.. But Barry Dianiond is all alone at home, with only his tape recorder, whirring on the table, waiting for him to say something hilarious.

title: KEY RHODESIA BLACK RAISES NEW THREAT OF QUITTING REGIME
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 7Bishop Abel Muzorewa's political faction today again raised the prospect of abandoning the shaky biracial ruling coalition here unless the Government reversed itself on its dismissal of a black serving as cominister of justice.

title: Music in May: Marriner
description: NEVILLE MARRINER continues h,s efforts to broaden his repertory and his image beyond he Baroque and Classical periods, and the conductor's second program on the New York Philharmonic's Music in May series. Saturday night at Avery Fisher Hall contained only one. piece of the sort usually associated with him.

title: Lois Portnoy and Stephen Houze, Lawyers, Wed
description: Lois Jonnie Portnoy, daughter of Dr. Samuel and Theodora Portnoy of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Amagansett, L. I., was married yesterday morning to Ste phen A. Houze, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Houze of Rolling Hills Estates, Calif.

title: CITIES SEEKING ROLE IN U.S. WATER POLICY
description: DENVER. May 7The National League of Cities held a twoday water policy conference here in a belated attempt to get its oar into President Carter's proposed national water policy.

title: Ontario Plan Uses Old Lottery Tickets To Help Literature
description: TORONTO, May 6What good is a lottery ticket when the draw is over and you've lost? In Ontario, the normally worthless bit of paper can introduce the holder to Canadian literature and help a struggling publishing industry that complains of being swamped by the flow of popular books and magazines from the United States.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the late editions of Saturday's Times it was incorrectly, stated in a headline that two former Salomon officers had been sentenced to jail. The men involved are former officers of S.J. Salmon & Company, a now defunct brokerage house.

title: Market Place
description: Edward E. Laufer offers this advice to those seeking profits in the stock market: Read annual reports of companies reporting losses, because better times may be in the offing.

title: U.S, SUES TO RECOVER STUDENT LOAN FUNDS
description: NEWARK, May 8The United States Attorney's office in New Jersey opened today what was called the first program of its kind to recover $5.5 million from 7,000 former' college students in the state who have failed to repay educational loans guaranteed by the Federal Government.

title: ELLSBERG AND 19 OTHERS ARRESTED AT PROTEST SITE

title: Mount Etna Continues Eruption
description: CATANIA, Sicily, May 8 (AP)Mount Etna continued to pour lava from its main crater for the ninth day today. The stream of lava was flowing into a natural basin and experts said it was not threatening arable land or inhabited villages on the slopes of the mountain.

title: Debate on Nepotism Rules Grows With a Rise in Working Couples
description: WASHINGTON, May 8When Charles and Lee Tidball began loolchig for their first jobs 20 years ago, they dreamed of a glorious future collaborating in medical research.

description: WASHINGTON, May 8The Carter Administration has begun an intensive campaign to get the New York City fiscal aid bill through Congress, Admintion officials said today.

description: New York City's Health Department yesterday listed 12 restaurants with healthcode violations and five that had corrected earlier violations. The restaurants were listed as follows:

title: Ali's New Drink: Mr. Champs Soda
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8 Muhammad Ali sipped a bottle of Mr. Champ's grape soda today and announced that he had formed a business partnership with an Arabbacked company that would sell his image in endorsement on soft drinks, paint and other merchandise in underdeveloped nations of the world.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: EDITH SOMBORN ISAACS

title: AMIN DESCRIBES CARTER AS A VERY GOOD MAN
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 8 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda, apparently trying to patch up relations with Washington, praised President Carter today as a very good man and renewed his offer to Mr. Carter and to members of Congress to visit Uganda.

title: Magistrate Sets Bail at $250,000 For Suspect in Killing of Letelier
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)A federal magistrate set bond at $250,000 today for a Cuban exile accused of plotting the death of Orlando LetoHer, a former Chilean diplomat who was killed here when a bomb exploded in his car in 1976.

title: MCA Earnings Up 33% in Quarter, Led by Universal Pictures Unit;
description: MCA Inc., a leader in television film production, reported yesterday a 33 percent increase in earnings in the initial three months this year on a 19 percent gain in revenues.

description: BASEBALL

title: Farm Union Agrees to Contracts With 7 TableGrape Growers
description: FRESNO, Calif., May 8 (AP)The United Farm Workers announced today that it had reached contract agreements with seven tablegrape growers at Delano, Calif., where Cesar Chavez began his long battle to represent field hands 33 years ago.

title: Ethiopia Rebels Report Killing 42
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, May 8 (AP)Somali guerrillas fighting in Ethiopia killed 42 Ethiopian soldiers in an ambush in the southern province of Sidamo, rebel news bulletin here said today. The report said the Somali Abo Liberation Front staged the attack but gave no date for the incident. The report could not be confirmed independently.

title: Deputy Mayor for Economics
description: Because his appearance at City Hall yesterday was to be a special occasion, Peter Jay Solomon prepared himself by doing two things he normally balks athe got his hair trimmed, and he stayed away from the 200,000 bees he raises in the garden of his weekend home in Connecticut.

title: DOCTOR PLEADS GUILTY IN MEDICAIDFRAUD CASE
description: One of eight doctors indicted last month for allegedly defrauding Medicaid of more than $131,000 by falsifying patient records has pleaded guilty to a reduced charge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: 108 Welfare Charges Added
description: CHICAGO, May 8 (AP)A grand jury issued 108 more theft counts today against a South Side woman who was indicted earlier on 505 counts of illegally receiving welfare funds. Arlene Otis, 30 years old, now stands accused on 613 counts of illegally receiving $150,839 in welfare funds from July 1972 to February 1978.

title: For Cities: Reform a Reform
description: The Carter Administration's urban policy is on a collision course with part of its tax reform legislation, and someone should flag down the bill in the House Ways and Means Committee. If it isn't changed, it could derail a major effort to revive industry in the older cities. through taxexempt bond financing.

title: U.S. Rejects a Bid to Sell China Device With Possible Military Use
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The United States has rejected on security grounds an application for the export to Peking of advanced airborne equipment for geological exploration even while a Chinese team was in this country taking a training course in its use.

title: City U. Proposes Large Cutbacks In Building Plans
description: The City University administration, projecting a 9 to 15 percent enrollment decline by the year 1990, has proposed master plan that calls for dropping at least half a dozen of its largest construction projects and says that a $140 million campus for York College is no longer educationally justifiable.

title: Dessoff Choirs in Bruckner Mass
description: Of Bruckner's three bestknown masses, the one in E minor is probably the most admired. Drawing inspiration from 16thcentury church music, it combines Romantic harmonies and polyphony of Palestrina. Unlike the D minor and F minor Masses, which use a full orchestra, it sparingly complements the chorus with winds alone. Unlike the nine symphonies, its vision is purely and exclusively otherworldly.

title: C.I.A. AIMS TO IMPROVE IMAGE AND PRODUCT
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  In various ways the Central Intelligence Agency is going public, partly to improve its image in the United States and partly to improve its product, highranking agency officers said in interviews last week.

title: C.A.B. APPROVES CUTS IN FIRSTCLASS FARES
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board granted the domestic airlines permission yesterday to cut firstclass fares throughout the country to 130 percent of normal coach fares.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PATIO PARADE With the public flocking to the free entertainment at the Market atrium of the Citicorp Center, new programs have been added. There is now something for everybody in tne skyscraper courtyard, entered on 53d or 54th Street midblock east of Lexington Avenue. It's also wise to arrive early for a table seat, bringing your own snacks and beverages for these informal interludes.

description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 8Speaking at the Democrats annual JeffersonJackson Day dinner in Omaha the other night, Gov. J. J. Exon said that Nebraska had finally become a viable twoparty state.
