title: Planned 40Mile Queens Subway, Cut to 15, Is Costly and Behind Time
description: What started out a few years ago as 40 miles of new subway routes to serve the longsuffering residents of Queens has been whittled down to 15 miles, is years behind schedule, and will cost more than twice as much as originally estimated.

title: U.S. Plans Inquiry Into Pension Funds Of Teamster Union
description: A special United States Labor Department task force is being created to investigate New York and northern New Jersey teamster union pension and welfare funds.

title: $30,000 FINE LEVIED ON POLICE INSPECTOR
description: The New York City Police Department has imposed a fine of $30,000 on an inspector who, while a lieutenant, allegedly failed to take proper police action against illegal gambling activities in Harlem in 1963.

title: Proposition Improvisers Open at Actors' Play house
description: Improvisation is the art of the moment. The improvisational actor must be quickwitted, surefooted and perhaps a trifle addled. Why else would he put his art on the line in an instant? The great American improvisers are few, and most of them were trained in Chicago.

title: KISSINGER SUPPORTS INCREASE IN NUMBER OF JETS FOR ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger urged the Carter Administration today to increase the number of jet fighters it proposes to, sell to Israel while the Administration gave further signs that it was seeking a compromise on the $4.8 billion warplane package for the Middle East.

title: Bridge
description: The proliferation of tournaments in the last decade may be a boon, for players can compete somewhere in the metropolitan area almost every weekend, but it is also a headache to organizers who are involved in scheduling dates.

title: Preliminary Tests Offer No Clues To Causes of Rutherford Cancers:
description: PARAMUS, May 8Analysis of the initial water and radiation samples undertaken in Rutherford has not yielded any clue on the causes of the community's clusters of leukemia and Hodgkin's disease, a state environmental official said today.

title: Ethnic Hungarians in Rumania Charge Regime Seeks Assimilation
description: BUCHAREST, RumaniaThis nation's leaders are putting pressure on the Hungarian ethnic minority to drop its cultural traditions and become part of a unified, Rumaniandominated state.

title: STRATEGY IS SHIFTED ON DEATH PENALTY
description: ALBANY, May 8Senate Republicans abruptly shifted their strategy on capital punishment today by dropping the attempt to enact the deathpenalty into law this year and, instead, pressing for a referendum permitting voters to advise the Legislature on the subject in November.

title: Chileans Turn Out Homespun Children's Clothes
description: The women who shop with their little girls on the second floor of Saks Fifth Avenue may never have heard of Conchali, but the women of Conchali are very aware of them. In that little corner of Santiago, Chile, is a cottage Industry turning out handembroidered and handsmocked children's dresses that are now being sold at Saks. If the dresses appeal to New York women, the cottage industry can grow to include more than the 100 women now involved.

title: Doctor Disputes Autopsy Report On One Victim in Curare Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.. May 8A doctor at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich challenged today an autopsy finding that one of the five patients Dr. Jascalevich is charged with killing might have died of a distended bladder.

title: VORSTER PLANS INQUIRY ON USE OF SECRET FUNDS
description: CAPE TOWN, May 8Prime Minister John Vorster announced tonight that he had appointed a special investigator to review the secret funds used by his Government to try to create a favorable image of South Africa abroad. He pledged that if any diversion of the funds to personal gain was uncovered the person or persons involved would be prosecuted.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, MAY 8, 1978

title: Article 4  No Title
The Loneliness of a Top Hammer Thrower
description: Almost every weekday morning at about 9 o'clock, one of America's finest track and field competitors practices his event in a nearlyempty parking lot at Marine Park in Brooklyn. His audience, he says, is a bunch of drunks.

title: West Virginia Primaries
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 8 (UPI)A Democratic showdown between freshman House member and the maverick politician whose seat he inherited in 1976 is the big event in tomorrow's West Virginia primary. The contestants are Representatives Nick Joe Rahall and Ken Hechler& who formerly served in the House for 18 years.

title: U.N. LEBANON FORCES MOVE HEADQUARTERS
description: TYRE, Lebanon, May 8The United Nations peacekeeping force moved its headquarters today from a site north of this Palestiniancontrolled port to a village south of here in the strip of Lebanon still held by the Israelis.

title: Books of The Times
description: Has anyone who lived through it forgotten the McCarthy era? Probably not, but there are those who, in the aftermath of the leftwing political resurgence of the 1960's, have argued that regardless of his tactics what the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy accomplished may not have been such a bad thing, if only because he dramatized on the doMestic scene the dire threat of Communism on the international scene. With this argument in mind, it is instructive to read David Caute's The Great Fear, a history Of The AntiCommunist Purge Under Truman and Eisenhower, by an English historian, novelist, and critic who has taught on both sides of the Atlantic, and whose previous political studies include Communism and the French Intellectuals, 191460, The Left in Europe Since 1789, Frantz Fanon, and The FellowTravellers: A Postscript to the Enlightenment.

title: The Return of the Returnable
description: Should consumers be required to leave a deposit on all soda and beer containers to encourage their return? Or should they continue to enjoy the convenience of throwaway containers that litter the landscape and waste materials and energy? That seemingly simple issue has been causing controversy for years across the nation; it arises again today when the New York State Senate Conservation Committee votes on the latest version of a deposit bill. It would require, a minimum 5cent deposit on bottles, cans or other containers for carbonated soft drinks, beer and other malt beverages. It is similar to laws passed by six other states (Oregon, Vermont, Maine, Michigan, Connecticut and Iowa) and to Federal legislation long pending in Congress.

title: BERKOWITZ'S GUILTY COULD BE CONTESTED
description: The guilty pleas entered yesterday by David R. Berkowitz, the 44caliber killer, do not mean that his days in court are over.

title: Topics
description: A few weeks ago, the adjoining columns carried a letter from a representative of the Television Information Office, an arm of the TV broadcasters, which took exception to this lead from an Editorial Notebook: On weekend mornings, while parents sleep, the kids watch television. The point is relevant to judging the propriety of advertisements directed at the very young. The man from the Television Information Office charged that our premise was far from accurate; many parents are not only up but watching, and he alluded to data supporting his rebuttal. We asked him to supply those data.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday, incorrectly identified as Eleanor Mor. genthau a Democratic aspirant for the Senate in Massachusetts. She is Ruth S, Morgenthau.

title: Public Health Panel Agrees Plan To Curb Smoking May Be Faulty
description: TRENTON, May 8New Jersey's Public Health Council agreed informally today that its tough new restrictions on smoking in public places might be faulty, but gave no sign of being willing to modify them.

title: CONVICTION REVERSED IN MIGRANTS MURDER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8A new trial for Juan Corona was ordered today by a California District Court of Appeal, which reversed his conviction in the murders of 25 farm workers bn the ground, that his lawyer had failed to represent him competently.

title: FIX GARBAGE TRUCKS, NEW YORK IS WARNED
description: The head of the sanitationmen's union warned yesterday of a growing garbagecollection problem in New York City and said that unless immediate steps were taken to speed the repair of garbage trucks, serious health hazards would develop.

title: Combined Communications Agrees To  a $370 Million Gannett Merger
description: The Gannett Company, the newspaper chain with the largest number of papers in the nation, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Combined Communications Corporation, one of the country's biggest broadcast chains.

title: Senator Talmadge's ExWife Expected to Run for Congress
description: ATLANTA, May 8 (AP)Betty Talmadge, former wife of Georgia's senior Sanator, Herman Talmadge, will announce her candidacy for Congress this week, The Atlanta Constitution said today.

title: About New york
description: Another effort to save another odd piece of the city gets under way May 19, but mercifully that tiresome claque of Beautiful People has not been invited to rue and to pose. Instead, the Ugly Duckling people have been invited a cross section of the nation's unknowns, perhaps the most uncelebrated hasbeens of two and three decades ago, the anonymous toilers of the nearly extinct Liberty Ships of World War II.

title: Taxes &
description: Ever since the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. was enacted in 1974, small business has complained the law imposed such costly and onerous reporting requirements that it worked against the interests of the very workers it was designed to protect

title: Dutch School Uses WorkingClass Speech to Help Pupils
description: AMSTERDAMTon Bax balanced himself on the edge of the table above the third graders sprawled out on pillows below and asked how they had spent the evening before. The answers tumbled forth in the staccato language of north Amsterdam's bluecollar district, flashing quick sketches of workingclass home life:. a family quarrel, the same noodleandmeatball dish three nights in a row, a father who had not yet found a job.

title: Mall Plan Splits Two Vermont Communities
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.A skirmish in the battle to revitalize the nation's ailing cities is being fought in this bustling and prosperous college town in the mountains near the Canadian border.

title: Carol Bellamy's Struggle To Play a Star Role
description: Just about everyone hailed Carol Bellamy as the brightest new face in New York politics when she was elected City Council President last November. Just about everyone agreed that her brief speech was the hit of the inauguration on Jan. 1.

title: Irish Arts, Making a Comeback, Sparkle in Galway
description: GALWAY, IrelandIreland's national Gaelic theater here, an early showplace for such luminaries as Siobhan McKenna and Micheal Mac Liammoir, is celebrating its 50th anniversary. The anniversary coincides with a revival of the arts in Galway, a place once considered a cultural oasis of western Ireland.

title: Brown Increases Funds For Women's Athletics
description: PROVIDENCE, R.J., May 8 (UPI)Brown Univers.ity Made. a commitment today to increase funding for its women's athletic program 50 percent next year.

title: Advertising
description: Advertising agencies and advertisers spent more money during the last year to develop new TV programming than they did altogether in the three precedine ones.

title: Film Industry Fears an Inquiry By U.S., but None Is Seen Soon
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8Four months after Hollywood was shaken by its most embarrassing scandal in decades, leaders in the motion picture industry are still fearful of a Congressional investigation of their practices, but none appears imminent.

title: Publisher Says Recipe May Cause Explosion
description: Random House yesterday recalled 3,000 unsold copies of a cookbook published last fall, and issued a warning to the 15,000 purchasers of the book, saying a recipe in it could cause a serious explosion.

title: Surveys Shows Job Openings For Graduates of High School
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)Most of the permanentjob openings available to highschool graduates are for secretaries, typists and clerks, according to a Government survey.

title: Plane Carrying 60 Crash Lands In Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS. Tuesday, May 9A National Airlines Boeing 727 carrying 53 passengers and seven crew members dropped out of an overcast sky and crash landed in a swampy area east of Pensacola, Fla.. last night, remaining afloat while a cluster of private boats and a barge rescued passengers.

title: Eartha Kitt Sings a Benefit for the 92d St. Y
description: Eartha Kitt began the first set of her benefit concert at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Sunday evening singing with the Barry Levitt Sextet, progressed to a foursong interlude with piano accompaniment and finished with four Israeli songs, backed by members of the Y Studio Orchestra and the Y Symphonic Workshop. On paper it looked like a varied program, but in fact it was all Eartha Kitt, and very much of a piece.

title: CARTER OPENS DRIVE FOR PASSAGE OF BILL ON AID TO NEW YORK
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The Carter Administration has begun an intensive campaign to get the New York City fiscal aid bill through Congress, Admintion officials said today.

title: Westchester's Plan On Waste Disposal Encounters a Delay
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 8A bipartisan attempt by the Westchester County Board of Legislators to come compromise that wold solve the cowl. ty's longstanding and politically sensitive solidwaste disposal problem, temporarily collapsed tonight under the pressure of objections from the County Executive, who termed the resolution unworkable.

title: Phone Rate Rise Sought
description: The New York Telephone Company has filed a petition with the state Public Service Commissio,n seeking $80 million a year in rate increases, all to be borne by business. Page 57.

title: Bills Implementing Court Amendments Approved in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 8Despite efforts by some rankand?? members in the Senate to tear apart a series of agreements reached by Democratic and Republican leaders, the State Senate and Assembly voted tonight in favor of changes in the way judges are selected and disciplined.

title: In Defense Of TV
description: ATLANTABroadcasting and print journalism are more complementary than competitive, but they are different. Many TV critics cannot seem to grasp or accept this. They constantly judge exercises in broadcast news and documentaries by newspaper measurements; they see it through their own prism. They tell us we should have left out this or included that; there are usually compelling reasons Why we do what we do, dictated by the special imperatives of the medium.

title: Say It Ain't So, California
description: David Eisenhower, grandson to one President, soninlaw to another, deserves to be listened to when he talks politics, This is why it is surprising to read that he believes hostile feelings toward former President Nixon reflected a broad. American dislike of California, Mr. Nixon's native state.

title: City Ballet: New Dancers in the Old Roles
description: Two evenings with the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater are not necessarily the two evenings one originally had in mind.

title: 1968 and 1980
description: Gov. Jerry Brown of California said this week that he is beginning a maximum effort from early morning until late at night, costing $800,000 to $1 million, to win a Democratic primary in which he has no serious opposition. That leaves little doubt that he wants to go on to smashing reelection next November, then enter the primaries against President Carter in 1980.

title: Doubts About Bilingual Education Raised in a Study Released by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)A $1.5 million study of bilingual education raises doubts about whether the federally backed projects improve student achievement and even about whether the students need to be taught in their native language.

title: Biofeedback: From Counterculture Fad to Accepted Medical Tool
description: Hippies practiced it. Fastbuck artists promoted it. And in the beginning biofeedback had a dubious image inflated by hype and was lumped together by the media with everything from meditation and yoga to est and biorhythms. It was viewed askance by the general public, and with particular suspicion by the medical profession.

title: PHILIP MORRIS HOLDS TO SEVENUP OFFER
description: Philip Morris Inc. said yesterday that it planned no immediate change in its offer of $41 a share, or up to $440 million, for all of the outstanding shares of the SevenUp Comnany.

title: Music: The Chicago Symphony
description: This is the week that Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony are zeroing in on Brahms. Last night in Carnegie Hall, Sir Georg started the Brahms minifestival with the D minor Piano Concerto and the Symphony No. 4. Alfred Brendel was the pianist.

title: Ethelda Bleibtrey, 76, Won 3 Medals For Swimming in 1920 Olympic Games
description: Ethelda Bleibtrey, who took up swimming as therapy for curvature of the spine and won three Olympic gold medals in 1920. died last Saturday in West Palm Beach. Fla. She was 76 years old.

title: Laborites Defeated in a Tax Vote
description: LONDON, May 8 (Reuters)Britain's Labor Party Government suffered an embarrassing parliamentary defeat tonight over its taxation program but vowed to carry on In office.

title: Fosse to Undergo Surgery
description: MILAUKEE, May 9 (AP)Roy Fosse, the catcher obtained by the Milwaukee Brewers last November as a free agent but injured during spring training, has been scheduled to undergo surgery Wednesday in Los Angeles. The American League club said today that the surgery to repair a torn cartilage in Fosse's right knee Would sideline him for two or three more months.

title: U.S. Plans Inquiry on Teamsters
description: A special United States Labor Department task force is being created to investigate New York and northern New Jersey teamster union pension and welfare, funds.

title: National Health Is Staged on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCOThere are two orders of humanity in Peter Nichols's The National Health: the patients and the practitioners.

title: Koch Establishes Steering Group To'Monitor Development Funds
description: Noting the enormous effect Federal measures have on regional and local economies; Mayor Koch announced yesterday the creation of a special steering group of New York City aides to coordinate the .application and use of Federal dollars for economic development.

title: The U.N. Today
U.S, PHYSICISTS DOUBT A RUSSIAN DISCOVERY
description: Leading American physics laboratories were anxiously consulting each other this week about an assertion by Soviet scienfists that, if true. would revolutionize the transmission of electric power throughout the world.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: JOSEPH HANLON

title: Notes on People
description: A family spat has erupted in Plains, Ga., over memoirs of Hugh Carter, an uncle of the President. Mr. Carter, a Georgia State Senator and antiques dealer, says in his book, Cousin Beedie and Cousin Hot, that Lillian Carter, the President's mother, has always been domineering in her relations with her daughter  in  law, Rosalynn. When Jimmy Carter told her of his intention to marry Rosalynn, Mr. Carter said, Lillian Carter commented with her characteristic bluntness that Rosalynn was not good enough for her son and not good enough to join the Carter family. Lillian said openly that Jimmy was marrying a girl from the wrong side of the tracks.'  Of the future President, Hugh Carter quoted Lillian Carter as having said, There's nothing special about Jimmy. Because of these and other references to her in the book, Mr. Carter said yesterday on. NBC's Today program, Lillian Carter confronted him and said, You're the scum of the earth for what you said about me. As for the President's reaction, Hugh Carter said, He understands.

title: ALFRED S.MILLS, 68, EXSAVINGS BANKER
description: Alfred S. Mills, the former chairman and chief executive officer of The New York Bank for Savings, the country's fourthlargest savings bank, died Sunday at his North Salem, N.Y., home. He was 68 years old.

title: NEW AFGHAN RULERS START PURGE OF CIVIL SERVICE
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 8 (Reuters) Afghanistan's new leftwing government has started a purge of civil servants and of members of the dynasty that ruled the country for more than a century, wellinformed sources said today.

title: Rebound of Canadian Dollar. Buoys Trudeau Government
description: OTTAWA, May 9Canada's dollar has been rebounding after a winter of weakness that caused profound distress within the Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and sent Canadians scurrying to deposit money in the United States.

title: Delaney's Retirement Buoys G.O.P.
description: That comparative rarity in New York Citya Congressional election that the Republicans can winwas set up, Queens politicians said yesterday, by the planned retirement of James J. Delaney, the state's senior member of Congress.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: WILLIAM E. OSBORNE

title: Council Seeks Option on Pensions
description: Over the objections of Mayor Koch, the City Council yesterday unanimously approved a homerule message to the Legislature reopening a pensionplan option to as many as 2,000 city employees.

title: F.T.C. Chief Assails Califano' s Drug Reform Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission has charged that a revision of the Federal drug laws proposed by Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, could significantly weaken criminal enforcement efforts against executives whose companies sold adulterated or misbranded drugs.

title: Surgeon Testifying in Curare Trial Says Man Recovered and Then Died Suddenly
description: HACKENSACK, May 9A surgeon testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that in the first operation he performed after he had been granted increased surgical privileges at Riverdell Hospital his patient recovered normally and then died suddenly five days after the operation.

title: U.S.Investigates Reported Bribe By Ford Motors
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The Ford Motor Company is under Federal grand jury investigation of whether it paid a bribe to obtain a $30 million contract with an agency of the Indonesian Government in 1975 to build ground stations for that country's domestic satellite communications systems, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Music: Rudiakov, Cellist
description: ANY program of American music drawn from works written over the last 30 years is bound to yield a crazy quilt of diverse styles and idioms. This certainly characterized the contemporary compositions for cello and piano that Michael Rudiakov played in Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night.

title: American Found Dead in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9 (Reuters)A 22yearold American student was found dead today at Araiya, in the mountains southeast of Beirut, police sources said. He was identified as Paul Kerry Wilson, a student at the University of Georgia. According to the sources, he had been shot through the head and stabbed.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Princeton Issues Mild Warnings To 205 in SitIn on South Africa
description: PRINCETON, May 9Princeton University officials voted late last night to issue disciplinary warnings to 205 students who participated in a sitin last month at Nassau Hall, the campus administration building, to protest the school's holdings in corporations that do business in South Africa.

title: Tax Defeat Points Up British Labor's Election Woes
description: LONDON, May 9Last night's defeat in the House of Commons on an income tax cut was embarrassing but not fatal to Prime Minister James Callaghan's Labor Government. He apparently has no intention of calling a general election, in spite of. loud demands from the Conservative opposition, but the vote underscored his anxiety as he looks toward the next election, which could come this fall. He needs to increase Labor's seats sharply if he hopes to get anything done in the next Parliament.

title: An Embittered Family Excludes Leaders of Italy From Funeral
description: ROME, May 9The family of Aldo Moro told Italian political leaders and members of the slain leader's Christian Democratic Party today that they would not be welcome at his funeral.

title: 60  Minute Gourmet; Cotes de Veau mix Endives (Veal chops with braised endives); Endives Braisees (Braised endives); Mixed Green Salad
description: IN A MENU outlined recently for a hastily prepared meal??it was noted that Belgian endive is, to my taste, one of the, finest of cooked vegetables when braised. It was stated that it does require an extended cooking time, time which the other ingredients for a meal can be assembled, chopped, heated and so on.

title: Bruins Top Flyers, 42, Fora1 Lead in Playoff
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 9  Gerry Cheevers, the Boston Bruins goalie, returned to the lineup tonight, and to Coach Don Cherry that was the key factor in the Bruins 42 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in their National Hockey League semifinal playoff.

title: Harry Howell Tames, Pretties Team Canada
description: PRAGUE, May 9Team Ugly, as Canada was called at last year's world hockey championships because of itn violent and illegal play, has had its face lifted.

title: Foes Are Sought to Race Seattle Slew on Sunday
description: Depending on how trainers respond to a promotional help wanted appeal, Seattle Slew will make his longawaited return to the races next Sunday at Aqueduct.

title: Carter Calls the Killing Cowardly
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  President Carter called the murder of Mr. Moro a contemptible and cowardly act. In a statement released by the White House, he said: My sympathies and the sympathies of all Americans go out to Aldo Moro's bereaved family and nation.

title: FED MOVES TO CURB. SHORTTERM RATES
description: Shortterm interest rates again tended to push upward yesterday, and the Federal Reservefor the second straight daycame into the market three different times to inject reserves into the banking system in an apparent effort to keep them from moving still higher.

title: GIBBON EASILY WINS 3D TERM IN NEWARK
description: Mayors, Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark and Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson scored onesided reelection victories yesterday, but Mayor Arthur Holland of Trenton was forced into. a runoff on June 13 against City Council President John Cipriano because he failed to capture more than 50 percent of the vote.

title: Car Injures 6 L.I. Schoolchildren After Allegedly Running Red Light
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I., May 9A car driven by a 17yearold girl allegedly ran through a red light near an elementary school here today, plowing into six children who had just been waved off a curb by a crossing guard.

title: The Spices of India  in New York City
description: Spices are the life of Indian food, but one needn't cross the ocean to find them. They are readily available here in New York.

title: The BigE'  Making Big Leap for Title
description: There was a time when Elvin Hayes couldn't cross the midcourt line without hearing some catcalls from the stands imploring him to Shoot, Elvin, shoot. For a long time it appeared these were the only occasions when Hayes would follow orders on the basketball court.

title: Japan Recognizes Afghan Regime
description: TOKYO, May 9 (Reuters)The Japanese Government recognized the new Government in Afghanistan today, the Foreign Ministry said. The Japanese Embassy in the Afghan capital of Kabul, it said, will express to the new Government Tokyo's hope for the maintenance of friendly relations.

title: Lettuce: Wet Winter, High Prices
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9As two women stood frowning before a mound of 99cent lettuce in a suburban supermarket here the other day, one turned to the other and said, Unbelievable, isn't it?

title: Chickens Roosting in the Bronx
description: It would be hard to find a more severe example of the New York disease than the threatened departure from the city of Gourmet Poultry Specialties, a thriving new South Bronx firm, to Nanticoke, Maryland. Founded a year ago with 28 employees, Gourmet now employs 380. To take new, bigger contracts, it must enlarge further, but the city government will not say yes or no to its proposal to lease a vacant city building nearby.

title: TV: David Mercer's Shooting the Chandelier
description: OF the three plays offered in a human rights package on public television's Great Performances, two share the curious distinction of being set in Czechoslovakia, not exactly the most common locale for Englishspeaking drama these days. Sandwiching the American staging of The Trial of the Moke, both Professional Foul, presented two weeks ago, and Shooting the Chandelier, tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, also happen to be BBC productions.

title: LIMIT ON ABORTIONS ADVANCES IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, May 9The Republicancontrolled State Senate tonight passed a measure that generally requires notification of the parents of a teenage girl before the girl can have an abortion.

title: 50c Fare Proiection Linked to Guesses and Good Intentions
description: According to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's top budget officer, Governor Carey's plan to save the 50cent fare and get more Federal funds to upgrade subways is based on good intentions, guesses and speculation.

title: Article 1  No Title
Vance Offering To Sell Israel 20 More F1 5's
description: WASHINGTON. May 9Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance offered Congress an informal compromise today in an effort to ease opposition to the Administration plan to sell advanced military jets in a package to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel. Mr. Vance proposed that Israel be offered the opportunity to purchase additional planes beyond the package and that assurances be obtained from Saudi Arabia that its planes would be used solely for defense.

title: Canadiens in Final On Sweep of Leafs
description: TORONTO, May 9The Montreal Canadiens marched into the Stanley Cup final by brushing aside the Toronto Maple Leafs in four straight games, ending with tonight's 20 victory in Maple Leaf Gardens. Ken Dryden recorded his 10th career playoff shutout, his second of this postseason, and faced just 23 shots, Jacques Lemaire scored in the first period and Steve Shutt had a secondperiod powerplay goal.

title: Inflation in Prices Put At 62% Since 1970
description: Because both inflation and rising taxes have been squeezing the household budget so much, the average family has had to raise its pretax income by at least twothirds to maintain a 1970 standard of living, according to the Conference Board's latest economic road maps, released yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times of April 23 incorrectly identified Kwame Nkrumah and Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe as graduates of Lincoln University in Missouri. They were graduated from Lincoln University in Chester, Pa.

title: Carter and Arms Sales
description: There are probably two more weeks In which President Carter can save his policy of ending the boom in world arms sales. One chance will come in arms sales negotiations with the Russians, and another at the United Nations.

title: Public. Gets Bigger Voice in New State Energy Plan
description: ALBANY, May 9Bowing to pressure from Assembly Democrats and environmental groups, the Carey administration has revised its energy plan to include representatives of the Legislature on the panel that would be charged with defining the state's energy needs and to broaden public participation in the planning process.

title: Government Wants Travel Industry to Straighten Up and Fly Right
description: An elderly man from Alabama signs aboard a vacation cruise to San Juan, P.R., and St. Thomas, V.I., and finds himself shanghaied to Cozumel, Mexico, a place he's never heard of. A New York charter operator gives a Massachusetts travel agent 50 airplane seats to sell to Hawaii and announces on departure day that there is only room for 30. A New Jersey couple pay for a deluxe hotel in London and wind up in Brighton. A Florida woman books for Istanbul, Turkey, and lands in Alexandria, Egypt.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Careers
description: I'll bet it will be a record summer for students, said Edward Wilsmann, president of the Olsten Corporation. He was talking about the availability of summer jobs for college and high school students.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An administrative law Judge in Albany recommended that the Consolidated Edison Company be directed to Lase its charges to 200 of its largest customers more closely,, on the cost of providing electricity to them.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: REAL NOURISHMENT A Little Light Music is the label of the free noontime and evening concerts now being presented in midweek as a community service by All Saints Church, 230 East 60th Street, between Second and Third Avenues. But these Wednesday lunchtime programs at 12:30 P.M., which are repeated on Thursdays at 6 P.M. for homebound workers, happen to include some fine, serious music.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times of April 23 incorrectly identified Kwame Nkrumah and Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe as graduates of. Lincoln University in Missouri. They were graduated from Lincoln University in Chester, Pa.

title: LAW ALLOWING CITIES TO EXCEED TAX LIMIT UPSET IN NEW YORK
description: ALBANY, May 9The State Court of Appeals today struck down a twoyearold law that allowed localities to collect property taxes above state constitutional ceilings to pay for pensions, Social Security and other costs.

title: Fur Season Starts Off Big
description: Revillon led off this year's fur showings with a smash hit that had the audience at the Pierre Hotel on its feet and cheering the other night.

title: Six Challenging In America's Cup
description: NEWPORT, R.I., May 9 (AP)six foreign yacht clubs, including one representing England's return to competition, have challenged the New York Yacht Club for the America's Cup.

title: Officers Back on Beat and People Get to Know Them
description: The youngster strolled out of the grocery on Knickerbocker Avenue eating a footlong hamandcheese sandwich when he spied Police Officers Alan Stegmuller and Michael Sneed walking their heat.

title: LEGISLATORS' RAISE IS CALLED UNLIKELY
description: ALBANY, May 9Apparent resistance from Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly minority leader, and legislators reluctance to vote raises for themselves just before they run for reelection are likely to doom a nascent effort to increase lawmakers salaries, legislative leaders said today.

title: Man Killed in Subway Station Identified as a Postal Employee
description: A man slain Monday night in the Hunts Point Avenue subway station in the Bronx was identified yesterday as Edward J. Jaenchen, 58 years old, of 2051 Haviland Avenue. the Bronx.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Bridge:
description: Redoubled contracts are very rare indeed in headtohead matches between strong teams. But one occurred Sunday in the final of the Westchester County knockout team championship, and the result was influenced by an unusual accident.

title: Sadat's Removal of Finance Expert Stirs Apprehension on the Economy
description: CAIRO, May 8  The removal of Egypt's top economic strategist in a Cabinet shuffle has caused some concern here about the effect on the Government's ability to attract foreign aid and to. retain international business confidence.

title: MORO SLAIN, BODY FOUND IN ROME
description: ROME, May 9The bulletriddled body of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro was abandoned by his kidnappers today in a parked car in the historic center of Rome, a short distance from the headquarters of both the Communist and Christian Democratic parties, whose Salliance the terrorist Red Brigades are fighting to destroy.

title: Rail Mishap Ruins Rocket Motors
description: HAMLET, N.C., May 7 (UPI)A Seaboard Coastline Railroad flatcar carrying two motors for Navy Poseidon rockets overturned in a railroad yard Monday, the authorities said. A Navy spokesman said that there were no warheads with the motors and that there was no danger of explosion. The motors, each costing $400,000 and weighing about 39,000 pounds, were damaged beyond repair.

title: Modern Design Gets Approval For Historic Site in Brooklyn
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday approved a design for a modern fourstory house on a disputed site in Brooklyn Heights, an area that the city has declared a historic district because of its distinctive 19thcentury architecture.

title: How to Make the Legendary Chocolate Mousse Cake
description: 1. To prepare the mousse for a chocolata mosse,cake, select a not too heavy metal bowl. To the bowl add one pound of sweet chocolate. Add one cup of milk and half a cup of sugar. Add six egg yolks.

title: Fire Kills Five in Virginia
description: MOUNT VERNON, Va., May 9 (AP)Five persons, including a 27yearold woman and her two small children, were killed this morning when fire raged through the Brooks Motor Lodge in this suburb of Washington. Six others were hospitalized. The dead were identified as Helen Thornton; her daughter, Kimberly, 4, and son, Richard Eli, 19 months, and two 40yearold men, Leroy Gregg and Morris Carroll Pettit. Officials said that faulty wiring in a television set might have started the fire.

title: The Chronology of the Moro Case
description: March 11Italian Government crisis ends on the basis of an understanding with the Communists worked out by former Prime Minister Aldo Moro, president of the governing Christian Democratic Party. A new Christian Democratic Government is agreed upon, with the Communists as part of the governing majority but not represented in the Cabinet.

title: Reds Top Mets on Homer in 10th
description: CINCINNATI, May 9The New York Mets needed only two outs tonight to beat the Cincinnati Reds for the second straight time and escape again from their own mistakes. But one of the men they had to get out was George Foster, and they did not escape.

title: Indians 5, Mariners 4
description: CLEVELAND, May 9 (AP)Mike Vail; the former Met, lined a twoout single in the bottom of the ninth inning, driving in Larvell Blanks with the winninob run, as the Cleveland Indians nipped the Seattle Mariners, 54, tonight.

title: What Italy Has Lost  and Kept
description: Aldo Moro's life ended in the back of a car found only yards from the headquarters in Rome of the Christian Democratic Party, which he had served since the end of World War II. If the kidnapping of the former prime minister proved the ability of the Red Brigades to carry their campaign to the highest reaches of Italian politics, his bloodied corpse symbolized the terrorists goal for the Italian state.

title: Theater: Ain't Misbehavin
description: WHAT whistles, hoots, throws off sparks and moves at about 180 miles an hour, even though it is continually stopped?

title: LORIS NET DECLINED 12.6% IN 1ST QUARTER
description: Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of the Loews Corporation, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting here that net income declined 12.6 percent in the first quarter, despite record operating results.

title: For Berlin at 90, Exuberance Is Song
description: ON MAY 8, 1907, just before his 19th birthday, Irving Berlin officially became a songwriter. That is the date of the copyright of his first song, Marie From Sunny Italy, written in collaboration with Nick Nicholson. Mr, Berlin's contribution was the lyric, and his share of the rovalties was 37 cents

title: CARTER AND POWELL SEEK ADDITIONAL PRESS AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, May 9In an effort to bolster his public image, President Carter is seeking a new press aide to function as a rough equal to Jody Powell, the White House Dress secretary and to do longterm public relations planning, Ar. Powell said today.

title: Rescue Work by Tugboat Captain Keeps Toll in Airliner Crash to 3
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., May 9 (AP)A National Airlines jet carrying 58 persons crashed into Escambia Bay, while coming in for a landing last night. Three passengers were killed, and stunned survivors were forced to scramble out emergency doors into fog and a sea slicked with jet fuel.

title: Chicagoan's Brahms
description: ACONCERT that consists of two Brahms symphonies might not, be everyone's idea of a blithe evening. So much Germanic sobriety and stern rejection of life's giddier aspects, placed back to back, could make certain weakMinded listeners come away feeling that they had spent a couple of hours lifting heavy weights.

title: Ethiopia Expels a West German And a Briton as Arms Traffickers
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 9 (Agence FrancePresse)Ethiopia has expelled a West German diplomat and a Briton for illegal arms trafficking, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said here yesterday.

title: Nick Lowe's Hard Rock
description: NICK LOWE'S late set at the Bottom Line Monday night was one of the most energetically amusing, clever yet viscerally appealing 45 minutes of hard rock that this writer has heard in a long time. Mr. Lowe is more than lust a hardrocker. He's been around on the English pubrock and newwave scenes for more than a decade, has produced many of the finest names of the new British rock (Graham Parker, Elvis Costello, et al.) and has now released an LP of his own that is win ning a lot of friendly attention.

title: Piano: Webster at 70
description: BEVERIDGE WEBSTER, that valuable member of the musical community, celebrated his 70th birthday last night with a piano recital in the JuillBard Theater (he was born in Pittsburgh on May 13, 1908).

title: MORO SLAIN, BODY FOUND IN ROME
description: ROME, May 9The bulletriddled body of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro was abandoned by his kidnappers today in a parked car in the historic center of Rome, a short distance from the headquarters of both the Communist and Christian Democratic parties, whose alliance the terrorist Red Brigades are fighting to destroy.

title: Inflation in Prices Put At 62% Since 1970
description: Because both inflation and rising taxes. have been squeezing the household budget so much, the average family has had to raise its pretax income by at least twothirds to maintain a 1970 standard of living, according to the Conference Board's latest economic road maps, released yesterday.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, MAY 9, 1978

title: Frisco Stockholders Vote Merger
description: Shareholders of the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway Company at the annual meeting in St. Loius approved the previously announced merger of the Fr??sco into Burlington Uorthern Inc. BurlIington shareholders will vote on the merger on Thursday. Terms call for the exchange of each Frisco common share for 0.95 share of Burlington Northern common and 0.5 share of a newly created $2.125 preferred stosk with a redemption value of $25.

title: Court Nullifies AboveCeiling Tax
description: ALBANY, May 9The State Court of Appeals today struck down a twoyearold law that allowed localities to collect property taxes above state constitutional ceilings to pay for pensions, Social Security and other costs.

title: Louisiana Declared Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)President Carter declared Louisiana a major disaster area today, clearing the way for use of Federal aid toward recovery from severe storms and flooding in parts of that state last week.

title: ENDANGERED STATUS BID FOR ELEPHANTS REJECTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)The Interior Department decided today that African elephants are not endangered, a move that some animal protectionists say spells doom for the world's largest land mammal.

title: Rice's Horne Run Helps. Red Sox Defeat Royals
description: BOSTON, Nay. 9 (AP)Jim Rice of Boston gave KansasCity's Jim Colbom a verbal warning after being hit with a pitch in the fifth inning, then belted a tworun homer inthe seventh tonight as the Red Sox extended their winning streak to seven games with a 43 victory over the Royals.

title: FORD RAISES ITS CAR PRICES ACROSS BOARD 1.3 PERCENT
description: DETROIT, May 9 (AP)The Ford Motor Company increased prices of its cars across the board today by an average of $91, or 1.3 percent, which is about the same as those announced during the last two weeks by the other major manufacturers.

title: Grown Child, Aging Parent: Help Arrives
description: THEY have been called the sandwich generaHon. Some are in their 30's or 40's, caught between the needs of their growing children and the needs of their aging parents.

title: Surgeon Testifies in Curare Trial on a Sudden Death
description: HACKENSACK, May 9A surgeon testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that in the first operation he performed after he had been granted increased surgi:al privileges at Riverdell Hospital his patient recovered normally and then died suddenly five days after the operation.

title: Red Brigades: A Trail of Violence
description: The Red Brigades, the extreme leftwing terrorist group that killed former Prime Minister Aldo Moro, is Italy's largest and most wellknown terrorist organization. Linked to bombings, bank raids, assassinations and other politically motivated acts of violence, the urban guerrilla group contends that the only language imperialists can understand is that of arms.

title: APPEAL ON BERKOWITZ PLANNED BY LAWYERS
description: Defense lawyers for David R. Berkowitz plan to appeal the competency ruling that allowed him to plead guilty to all six murder charges stemming from the Son of Sam case.

title: Corporation Affairs Alcan Holds Aluminum Price Line
description: The Alcan Aluminum Corporation, a unit of Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said that it would not increase the price of its primary aluminum ingot at this time. A company spokesman said we don't believe an increase is justified by market conditions.

title: Waldheim Denounces Brutal Act
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 9Secretary General Kurt Waldheim in a statement today called the murder of Mr. Moro a brutal and inhuman act. Mr. Waldheim, who had made four appeals to the captors of the former Italian Prime Minister, eulogized Mr, Moro as a distinguished public servant.

title: Advertising
description: Having discovered that there is nothing quite like advertising for keeping an idea alive, the Churches of Scientology in 21 markets will begin on Monday a TV ad campaign for Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health, a 28yearold book written by the church's founder, L. Ron Hubbard.

title: Israeli Sirens Honor Dead in Nation's Wars
description: TEL AVIV, May 9 (Reuters)Airraid sirens wailed throughout Israel tonight to mark the opening of a memorial day for the dead in Israel's wars.

title: Puerto Ricans Accelerating Return to Crowded Homeland
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto RicoThe return of Puerto Ricans from New York, Chicago and other mainland cities has accelerated greatly in the last few years, raising questions about the social and political implications the movement will have on this overpopulated island.

title: Options Fraud Is Laid to Bache
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission alleged today that one of the nation's largest brokerage firms allowed unsupervised salesmen to defraud small investors in options. The S.E.C. ordered the strongest corrective measures since approving listed options trading.

title: Federal Aid Is Pledged to Assist In Cleanup of Industrial Pollution
description: TRENTON, May 9The regional administrator for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said today that the agency recognized that New Jersey's 14,000 cancer deaths each year might be connected to the state's concentration of industry, and added that the agency would help in planning and enforcing a cleanup of industrial pollution.

title: Market Place
description: The PRF Corporation, whose stock has soared in overthecounter trading in response to expanded earnings, may not be quite so undervalued as some appear to believe.

title: Investigator Is Named to Study U.S. Services Unit
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The head of the General Services Administration, the Government's big scandalridden construction and housekeeping agency, announced today that a major portion of the agency's $4.5 billion yearly expenditure was being placed under the scrutiny of a newly appointed special counsel.

title: BLASTS CALLED PERIL IN TRASH PROCESSING
description: CHICAGO, May 9Explosions from discarded ammunition, gasoline cans and other items pose a serious danger at plants that grind up the nation's refuse, which is an increasing source of fuel and salvaged raw materials.

title: About Real Estate Union Chelsea Bank Coming to 5th Avenue
description: Say Fifth Avenue, and a Venezuelan knows what you're talking about, said Felix M. Ginorio Jr.

title: FOODS AND LIVESTOCK LEAD COMMODITY GAIN
description: Strong demand for futures contracts in basic foodstuffs and livestock products dominated the commodity markets yesterday.

title: Sporting Goods Makers on the, Offensive
description: A rather strange thing happened in Key Biscayne, Ha., a week ago. .An American industry troubled by a heavy volume of foreign competition agreed that the best defense for that problem was a strong offensebut not the typeof protectionist initiatives that some other similarly afflicted businesses have often take in recent years. At their annual meeting, about 350 members of theSporting Goods Manufacturers Association were told by Howard J. Bruns, their young president, that the most effective way to counteract growing import competition was to sell more aggressively abroad, rather than seeking increased tariffs, mere stringent quotas, financial aid or other assistance from Washington.

title: House Might Sacrifice Tax to Pass Energy Package
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The House leadership signaled today that it was ready to risk losing President Carter's energy taxes in conference in order to get the four other elements of his energy program passed.

title: GULF SUIT CHARGES URANIUM MONOPOLY BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation retaliated yesterday against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation by charging in a Chicago court that its Pittsburgh neighbor had conspired to monopolize the uranium, nuclear fuel and power reactor businesses.

title: GIBSON EASILY WINS 3D TERM IN NEWARK
description: Mayors Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark and Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson scored onesided reelection victories yesterday, but Mayor Arthur Holland of Trenton was forced into a runoff on June 13 against City Council President John Cipriano because he failed to capture more than 50 percent of the vote.

title: Music From Marlboro
description: NO sane person goes exploring in the wilds without taking an experienced guide along, and the musicmaking the Marlboro Festival has long been kept on the right path by adherence to a similarly sensible principle. Young musicians there are seldom sent out to explore the most fearsome terrain without having a veteran or two in their ranks, which steadies performance and often gives it an irresistible mixture of impulsiveness and long perspective.

title: Theater: Three Solo Pieces. by Winston Tong
description: WINSTON TONG'S Three Solo Pieces at La Mama is a oneman show only in the strictest definition of the term. Using dolls as puppets, voices on tape, slides and illuminations, the most exact words, settings and costumesand himself as actor, puppeteer and presenceMr. Tong creates a multidimensional world. Mr. Tong's pieces are related to Bunraku puppetry, mime and environmental theater, but they coalesce into a startlingly original art. Performed before an enraptured audience, Three Solo Pieces is a fantastical evening of theater.

title: Officers Back on Beat and People Get to Know Them
description: The youngster strolled out of the grocery on Knickerbocker Avenue eating a footlong hamandcheese sandwich when he spied Police Officers Alan Stegmuller and Michael Sneed walking their beat.

title: Where to Turn
description: The following is a list of workshops, lectures, classes and counseling services offered in the metropolitan area for relatives of the aging.

title: Government Wants Travel Industry to Straighten Up and Fly Right
description: An elderly man from Alabama signs aboard a vacation cruise to San Juan, P.R., and St. Thomas, V.I., and finds himself shanghaied to Cozumel, Mexico, a place he's never heard. of A New York charter operator gives a Massachusetts travel agent 50 airplane seats to sell to Hawaii and announces on departure day that there is only room for 30.

title: Where to Find Indian Spices
description: MANHATTAN

title: Hungary Loudly Pledges Loyalty to Soviet, Yet Quietly Goes Own Way
description: BUDAPESTEach spring, atop Gellert Hill, where the 49foot bronze woman bearing a palm of victory stares mutely across the Danube, thousands of Young Pioneers and members of the Young Communist. League pay boisterous tribute to the anniversary of the Soviet liberation of our country from the yoke of fascism.

title: Witchita Repeals Homosexual Law
description: WICHITA, Kan., May 9 (AP)A city ordinance prohibiting discrimination against homosexuals was repealed overwhelmingly today, following a pattern of similar referendums in St. Paul, Minn., and in Miami.

title: PROXMIRE IS READY FOR LOAN HEARINGS
description: Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said yesterday in a reversal of position, that he would be willing to hold hearings on the New York City loan legislation before contracts have been negotiated with the municipal labor unions.

title: Pop: David Bowie
description: DAVID BOWIE may no longer sell as many records as he once did (or may well one day do again). But he still gives a superb live show, and the enthusiasm at the end of Monday night's concert at Madison Square Gardenthe first of two therewas a genuine attestation to excellence.

title: Europeans Pay Homage to Moro, Call for Defense of Democracy
description: PARIS, May 9Throughout Western Europe today, leaders paid homage to Aldo Moro, expressing horror at his death, which several considered an attack on the institutions of democracy itself. Several leaders called for a common front to fight terrorism and defend democratic regimes.

title: Family Matters, of the Heart
description: I think it's time we broke our children's hearts. They've had their tonsils out, their teeth straightened and all their shots. Their hearts are the only things we haven't done.

title: An Embittered Family Excludes Leaders of Italy From Funeral
description: ROME, May 9The family of Aldo Moro told Italian political leaders and members of the slain leader's Christian Democratic Party today that they would not be welcome at his funeral.

title: Linden Mayor Gets Gunman to Give Up
description: LINDEN, May 9A 27yearold man, armed with a pistol, reportedly chosed his family from the:r home tonight and kept a dozen policemen at bay for more than an hour until Mayor John T. Gregorie entered the house unarmed and talked him into handing over his gun.

title: Begin, Back Home, Says the Cabinet Will Discuss U.S. Peace Proposals
description: TEL AVIV, May 9 (ReutersPrime Minister Menachem Begin said on his return to Israel today from the United States that his Cabinet would soon discuss American suggestions about the future of the occupied West Bank.

title: American League Blue Jays 4, A's 0
description: TORONTO, May 9 (UPI)Toronto's Tom Underwood, a lefthander, notched his first American League victory tonight and extended Oakland's streak withosut a run to 29 innings with a fivehit 40 triumph. Rick Bosetti singled in .one run and scored two for the Blue Jays.

title: PROXMIRE IS READY FOE LOAN HEARINGS
description: Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said yesterday in a reversal of position, that he would he willing to hold hearings on the New York City loan legislation before contracts have been negotiated with the municipal labor unions.

title: BERGEN TAKES OVER HEAD START IN UNION
description: HACKENSACK, May 9The Bergen County Community Action Program became the administrator of the Union County Head Start program yesterday, marking the second time in four months that the federally financed antipoverty agency has been called to the rescue of a program in another county.

title: Ellsberg Free on Bond in Protest
description: DENVER, May 9 (AP)Daniel Ellsberg and eight other demonstrators were released on $200 personal recognizance bonds today, a spokesman for the Jefferson County Sheriff's Department said.

title: Publication for Disabled Seeks Aid
description: One of the largest newspapers serving the physically disabled community is struggling to resume publication four months after it shut its doors because of a lack of funds. Achievement, a monthly newspaper written by, for and about the handicapped, published its last issue in December 1977 after a nineyear history. The paper claimed a circulation of 16,000 at its peak.

title: Radical Group Gives 7 Weapons To Philadelphia Police in Truce
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP)Members of Move, a radical group, surrendered a shotgun, two rifles and four pistols to the police today in a final phase of negotiated truce ending an 11month seige at the group's ramshackle house in West Philadelphia.

title: City Approves Subsidized HighRent Harlem Project
description: A proposed $15 million housing development for 201 families in Central Harlem was given conditional approval by the New York City Board of Estimate yesterday. Ordinarly, onebedroom apartments would rent for $650 a month, but Federal subsidies will lower the cost for most tenants to about $200 a month.

title: Radio
description: 67:30 A.M., WNYCFM. Celebralion, Bennett ; Ozark Set, Sieg meister, Serenade for Violin Solo, and Strings and Percussion, Bernstein.

title: Hunter Posts Anniversary Victory Against Twins, 31
description: Unlike during his flawless effort against Minnesota 10 years and one day ago, Catfish Hunter did not pitch a perfect game against the Twins last night. He lost his bid for a 10thanniversary repeat on the eighth pitch of the game, but the single that Willie Norwood punched on that pitch , was the only bit ??unter allowed in six innings as the Yankees trimmed the Twins, 31.

title: Rhodesians Obey Boycott, Cancel So. Africa Match
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 9 (AP)A Rhodesian soccer team said today it had abided by the black African ban on sports competition with South Africa and canceled a twomatch series in Johannesburg on Saturday and Cape Town on Monday.

title: CARTER SEES LONG FIGHT IN SENATE ON LABOR BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI)President Carter told A.F.L.C.I.O. leaders today to expect a long and bitter battle in the Senate over labor law revisions designed to speed up the process of organizing nonmembers into unions.

title: Moro, Long  at Top in Politics,Was in Line for Presidency
description: Former Prime Minister Aldo Moro, whose death at the hands of extreme leftist terrorists was confirmed in Rome yesterday, had been regarded as the leading candidate for the office of head of state, although he had never forMally announced that he was seeking to become the successor to President Giovanni leone when Mr. Leone's sevenyear term expired in December.

title: St. John's Golfers Take Met Intercollegiate Title
description: SPARKILL, N.Y., May 9  Jack Gimmler, the St. John's golf coach, was forced to diyide his nineman varsity squad into two units today so the Redmen could compete in two major tournaments in the area. St. John's No. 1 team of five golfers went to the Catskills to compete for a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, to be held next month in Oregon.

title: Vance Offering To Sell Israel 20 More F15' s
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance offered Congress an informal compromise today on the Administration's plan to sell advanced military jets in a package to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel, proposing to increase the number of planes. for Israel and to obtain assurances that Saudi Arabia would use its planes solely for defense.

title: Competency to Stand Trial Is Held Key Issue in Corona Murder Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9The central issue in the case of Juan Corona is his competency to stand trial, which was not questioned in the trial that led to his conviction on 25 counts of firstdegree murder.

title: RHODESIA REAFFIRMS DISMISSAL OF BLACK
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 9The Executive Committee heading this country's interim Government announced today that after reconsidering, it was standing by its controversial dismissal of Byron R. Hove from his post as black Minister of Justice.

description: NEW DELHI, May 9Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party has won a crucial election in Uttar Pradesh, her home state. Her party's nominee, Moshina Kidwai, received a majority in a byelection Sunday fdr a seat in the lower house of Parliament. The seat became vacant with the resignation of a Janata Party member. Ram Naresh Yadav, after he was named Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh.

In proxy statements received by the stockholders yesterday, Western Pacific said that it considered itself a likely takeover target. A holding company that is trying to sell its railroad to employees, Western Pacific recently has made sizable purchases of the Houghton Mifflin Company and the Hazeltine Corporation.

description: THERE has been a major change in this, the third edition of The Times's vintage chart. Instead of being based on a system of 10, it is based on 20, which allows for a few more gradations and nuances. (To be sure, a rating or u.a would be identical to a rating of 19, but 19 is cleaner, less complicated.) Frank Schoonmaker always used 20, occasionally even splitting it further to come up with ratings such as 13.5.

He divided the estate among his four children, a former wife and her daughter. Mr. Geer died April 22 at the age of 76.

The Chauveron closed its door in 1971 when the owner, Roger Chauveron, decided restaurant life could be more palmy in Miami Beach.

title: Pop: Diana Ross Sings Something for Everyone
description: DIANA ROSS. gave a performance last year at the Forest HIlls Tennis Stadium that impressed this reviewer as just about the most assured and artful evening of pop music imaginable. She is at the Westbury Music Fair this week, and at her opening on Monday night she did not seem quite as fresh because large parts of the Forest Hills show had been incorporated into her new presentation; it was a subjective reaction. The quality remained the same, and it was very high indeed.

title: 2 Die in Swiss Avalanche
description: SION, Switzerland, May 9 (Reuters)Two people were killed when an avalanche buried 10 skiers yesterday at an elevation of 9,850 feet in the Valais Alps south of here, the police said today. Eight of the skiers freed themselves.

title: About a Seized Kenyan Writer. And Fiction by Him.
description: On the day Robert F. Kennedy was shot 10 years ago, I was getting ready to teach my afternoon English class at a Nairobi high school. We were about halfway through a study of Animal Farm, one of the required books on the syllabus. I arrived about 10 minutes late. On the blackboard, one of my thirdyear students had written: Today's LessonCompare the U.S. with Animal Farm.

Mr. Vance rarely appears at such ceremones and his presence at this ono was scen as a show of support for Mr. Sayre, whose nomination survived a strong challenge from conservatives in the Senate.

title: Window Candy Was Dandier
description: ANYBODY around here remember window candy? Chances are you don't even know what it is, though a moment's reflection would prob. ably clear everything up. I'm not at all certain that window candy was ever a purchasable commodity in very many places at any time, and I'm.sure as sure can be that no one anywhere can lay hands on it now.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Seems to me that some time ago I went into the business of kids and cleanliness  and encouraging the mating of the two. What better attraction to lure the little ones to water than the soapburger. Three slim bars of soap are intersected by one and onequarter face cloths, and. the whole really does look like a hamburger. Why one and onequarter face cloths? The answer is simple. One to wash the face and onequarter to wash one ear, which is only half of what you'd like done but twice as good as two dirty ears. The soapburger will be at a lot of stores in the not too distant future, but if you can't wait, try Bloomingdale's stationery department on the main floor, and ours not to reason why a soapburger is in stationery. Also Shenanigans at 384 Bleecker Street. Oh, almost forgot the price. How does $6 strike you? Well, don't forget you're paying for the idea, too.

description: Supporters of York College and at least one school facing contruction cuts or elimination demanded public hearings yesterday on those plans.

description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI)A group of Senators who met with President Carter today said that changes in the veterans preference rules were the biggest barrier to Civil Service reform legislation.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE late W. H. Auden said of M. F. K. Fisher, I do not know of anyone in the United States today who writes better prose. While I find that statement a bit extravagant. I think that in A Considerable Town, Mrs. Fisher brings a highly developed sensibiliy to bear on a city that is both fabled and infamous. She has been in love, she tells us, with Marseilles for almost 50 years. Such enduring faithfulness certainly implies one sort of response, but perhaps, in these cynical times, another as well. To some readers, such longevity may smack of uncritical complacency.

title: FOREIGNIMAGE FUND ISSUE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: CAPE TOWN, May 9For weeks South Africa has been occupied with disclosures that senior Government officials circumvented Parliament to finance a secret influencebuying campaign abroad and by allegations that some of the money was siphoned off for personal use.

title: Personal Health
description: DESPITE centuries of depiction in cartoons and caricatures of nobility, gout is no laughing matter. As one young victim put it, It hurts like hell, and I didn't do anything to deserve it. Nor is it a disease limited exclusively, or even primarily, to the upper classes, although certain excesses among the nobility of yore could have precipitated its occurrence in those already susceptible.

title: Guerrillas Raid Hotel in Rhodesia, Killing 2 and Wounding American
description: JULIASDALE, Rhodesia, May 9 (AP) Two black guerrillas attacked the dining room of a luxury hotel here last night with grenades and automatic rifles, killing two white Rhodesian women and wounding three persons, including an American visitor.

title: A Gala Blooms at the Botanical Garden
description: Sundown finally came to the Bronx at 8 P.M. last night. It was just about 30 minutes later than Carlton B. Lees would have ordered it, if he had had anything to say in the matter. He didn't.

description: OSCARS are awarded once year, but there may have been some years that you've missed during the halfcentury of their presentation. In that case, there is always ABCTV's Oscar special on May 23, at 10 P.M.

title: E.P.A. Orders American Motors to Recall Most of Its 1976 Model Cars
description: WASHINGTON, May 9In a sweeping move, the Environmental Protection Agency is ordering the American Motors Corporation to recall virtually all of its production of 1976 model cars, plus a substantial number of 1975 and 1976 model Jeeps, to repair pollutioncontrol systems that are found faulty.

title: Chess:
description: In the instructive book How to Open a Chess Game, by Evans, Gligoric, Hort, Petrosian, Portisch, Xeres and Larsen, the basic injunction laid down by Lajos Portisch is, Your only task in the opening is to reach a playable middle game. Besides being objectively playablethat is, without serious, uncompensated weaknesses or a stultifying sterilitythe middle game aimed for in the opening should suit a player's style.

title: IstanbulTruck Stop To Mideast
description: ISTANBUL, TurkeyKurt Vestergaard, a 35yearold Dane with slickedback 1950'sstyle hair, and the sleeves of his red Tshirt rolled up to show off his tattoos; steered his 40ton, fiveaxle truck through the honeycomb of streets on the Asian side of Istanbul and onto the milelong suspension bridge that hangs over the Bosporus, linkine Asia to Europe.

title: Movie: 'The End' With Burt Reynolds:Director and Star
description: "THE END," which was directed by Burt Reynolds, who also stars in it, is like being with good friends at a party where nothing goes right. The food doesn't arrive. The ice runs out. A couch catches fire and, outside in the street, the Department of Water Supply is making a noisy, after-hours dig to locate a broken main. Instead of calling the whole thing off, the host tries to cope.This is pretty much what Mr. Reynolds tries to do in "The End," a comedy about a cheerful, completely unreliable Los Angeles real-estate promoter who learns he has a fatal blood disease and takes the news badly. Mr. Reynolds tries to cope but the party seldom results in much more than physical and emotional exhaustion.The beginning of "The End," which opens today at the Baronet, more or less defines everything that's wrong with the movie that follows. Wendell Sonny Lawson (Mr. Reynolds), who has a measure of fame for having been his own television huckster, is in his doctor's office receiving the fatal news.The camera doesn't show us the two men in the same shot. Mostly we get close-ups of Wendell, who overacts so broadly that we know the film's mood is comic even though neither he nor the doctor (Norman Fell) are funny. Wendell becomes enraged. He cries. The doctor, who has a cold, doses himself with nasal spray and offers feeble hope ("Perhaps some doctor, somewhere, in some little lab will find a cure. . . .")The scene wants to be funny. It tells us it's trying to be funny, but you sense mounting desperation, which is suddenly made manifest when, for no apparent reason, the director begins to photograph the star through the tropical fish tank that tones up the doctor's office. There's no logic to this shot. It's another way of shooting a scene that is not going anywhere anyway.Thereafter Wendell Sonny Lawson undertakes a frantic search for sympathy and a practical, painless way out. He visits his elderly parents (Myrna Loy and Pat O'Brien), who are nice but too self-absorbed to notice that he has absconded with all their sleeping pills. His ex-wife (Joanne Woodward) loathes him for good reason, though she would seem to be as bad a bargain as Wendell in any marriage.His best friend (David Steinberg) simply agrees that suicide is the wisest course, while his girlfriend (Sally Field), a sweet slob who lives in a clutter of cats and unwashed dishes, cries a lot and, after they've made love, admits that she didn't have an orgasmbut then she never does.It is difficult to believe that Jerry Belson, who wrote the screenplay for "The End" (as he did for the successfully satiric "Smile"), didn't have more in mind about the barren lives of these people than what we see on the screen. This is half-heartedly satiric material that's been directed by Mr. Reynolds as if it were broad, knock-about comedy sometimes and, at other times, as if it were meant to evoke pathos, which it never does.With the right direction, Mr. Reynolds has shown himself to be an accomplished comedian as in "Semi-Tough," but the actor here is betrayed by the director who doesn't appear to know which way the camera should be pointed.The movie isn't totally unfunny. Wendell has an amusing encounter early on with Bobby Benson, who plays a Catholic priest so young and nave that all he can say is "wow" when Wendell attempts to confess. Carl Reiner has a nice, very brief bit as a "death therapist," But the film's only sustained comedy is supplied by the incomparable Dom DeLuise as a schizophrenic murderer who befriends the desperate Wendell. Mr. DeLuise's characterization amounts to a solo nightclub performance and, like many a nightclub performance, it doesn't really go anywhere, it just runs out of material.The film's most serious shortcoming is Mr. Reynolds's apparent inability to direct himself in relation to the other actors. He's not rude to them. He doesn't upstage them. He has an excellent supporting cast and he obviously relishes their talents, but he has no concept of where he, as actor as well as director, stands as boss. He's simply overwhelmed.

title: REP.THONE IS VICTOR IN NEBRASKA ELECTION
description: LINCOLN, Neb., WedneSday, May 10United States Representative Charles Thone won? the Republican gubernatorial nomination in a fiveman primary election race yesterday.

title: People and Business Colussy Formally Takes Over As President of Pan American
description: Dan A. Colussy, 46 years old, once vice president of an advertising agency, was formally named president of Pan American Airways, the country's largest international air carrier yesterday. Mr. Colussy, whose appointment had been disclosed earlier, succeeds Forwood C. Wiser Jr., 57, who resigned after two years in the post, William Waltrop, 40, executive vice president for operations, will succeed Mr. Colussy as vice president for marketing.

title: SINGAPORE AIRLINES AGREES TO PURCHASE UP T0 19 BOEING JETS
description: SINGAPORE, May 9In one the largest contracts ever placed for civilian aircraft, Singapore Airlines has agreed to buy up to 19 Boeing 747's and 727's in a deal estimated to be worth almost $900 million, the governmentowned airline announced here.

title: Koch Pressing Restructuring of Education Board
description: Having forced the current sevenmember Board of Education to select the Chancellor of his choice, Mayor Koch is now concentrating on the other part of the school plan he promised as a candidateto change the structure. tenure and salary of the Board of Education so that he can control its educational policies. But this requires a change in state law, and so far the Legislature is proving less amenable to the Mayor's demands than the Board of Education was.

title: Youngstown Municipal Strike Ends
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 9 (UPI) A 17hour strike by 1,250 city workers ended late last night when negotiators reached a tentative agreement on a oneyear contract. The workers, including firefighters and police officers, returned to work shortly after Mayor J. Phillip: Richley announced the agreement. The new contract would give workers a 6.4 percent pay increase and cost the City $1.12 million. The workers had sought an 8 percent raise a,nd the city had offered 6 percent. The workers and expected to vote on the pact in the next few days.

title: The Spring Offensive
description: For weeks, people had been wondering when Jimmy Carter would start being his own best friend. Private mutterings in Washington grew into public complaints of ineptitude. As the criticism mounted, the polls dropped; one last week showed him with a positive rating of only 29 percent. From Austin to Boston, the question was heard: How could a man with the political brilliance Mr. Carter demonstrated in winning the White House now respond so passively, so much like a nonpolitician?

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: HANS OSTERMANN

title: From Petals of Blood
description: 1. They came for him that Sunday. He had just returned from a night's vigil on the mountain. He was resting on his bed, Bible open at the Book of Revelation, when two police constables, one tall, the other short, knocked at the door.

title: Joan Little Extradition Ordered by Court of Appeals
description: Joan Little was ordered returned to North Carolina yesterday by New York's highest court.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: JUDGING by all accounts, to own a car in New York is to commit oneself to a lifetime of conniving for parking spaces, staying tuned for the latest bulletins on alternatesideofthestreet parking rules, and letting nothing stand in one's way in the eternal quest for room at the curb.

title: U.S. AGENCIES CALLED TAX ON BIAS LAW ENFORCEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)Although two dozen agencies outside the Department of Health, Education and Welfare spend nearly $10 billion on education, none have taken steps to enforce a 1972 law that prohibits discrimination,against women in education, a Presidential advisory counciI charged today.

title: Berger to Head a New Seagram's Sales Group
description: Frank S. Berger has been named president of the House of Seagram, new marketing and sales affiliate of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. for the United States and Canada. He also was named vice president for marketingNorth America of the parent company, the Seagram Company of Canada, the world's largest marketer of spirits and wines.

title: Sylvia Townsend Warner Is Dead
description: Sylvia Townsend Warner, novelist, shortstory writer and poet noted for her graceful style and ironic wit,died on May 1 at the age of 85 in the village of Maiden Newton in Dorset, England.

title: Priest Admits Diverting $2 Million
description: BALTIMORE, May 9The Very Rev. Guido John Carcich, former chief fundraiser of the Pallottine Fathers, today pleaded guilty to misappropriating $2.2 million of charitable contributions made to the Roman Catholic order.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Cholera Kills 105 in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 9 (Reuters)  A cholera epidemic has killed 105 people since it began in October, public health officials said today. They said about 3,000 cases had been reported.

title: U.S. and Soviet Each Plan to Launch Two Missions to Venus This Year
description: Four missions to Venus, two by the United States and two by the Soviet Union, are planned this year in the most comprehensive scientific investigation thus far of the Earth's nearest but still mysterious planetary neighbor.

title: Defendant in Spy Trial Tells Jury He Was a Proud, Loyal American
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 9A former Government official accused of being an espionage agent for Vietnam told a Federal jury here today that he was a proud, loyal American, not a spy.

title: National League Astros 5, Phillies 1
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP)J.R. Richard pitched a fourhitter and struck out 11 batters as the Houston Astros scored four times in the seventh inning and defeated Philadelphia, 51, tonight.
