description: When Byron R. Hove, a black Justice Minister for the interim Government of Rhodesia, was dismissed for criticizing the whitedominated police and judiciary, then refusing to retract his statements, Prime Minister Ian D. Smith told an interviewer: He has been put in his place.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
New York Sees Record Tourism
description: New York City is heading toward record year for tourism, officials of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau reported at their annual meeting yesterday.

title: Church and State
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The 88 tie in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on sending military airplanes to Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia is a perfect example of the balanced senatorial mind. Whenever senators have to choose between politics and foreign policy, on secondary issues, they tend to come out dead even

title: Ballet Theater: Other Dances in Old Slavonic
description: AFTER a round of the fulllength Don Quixote, which will resume next month, the American Ballet Theater returned to its mixedbill programming Wednesday nieht.

title: U.S. LEFTIST EDITOR SAYS CAMBODIANS ARE THRIVING
description: The editor of a Chicagobased Marxist weekly who led a delegation of Western reporters on a visit to Cambodia said yesterday that the Communist Government there had indicated to him that it would soon open the borders to similar visits by unsympathetic American reporters.

title: SENATE PANEL IN TIE ON VOTE TO THWART MIDEAST JET SALES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Senate Foreign Relations Committee blocked move today to thwart President Carter's proposed sale of military planes in a package to Saudi Arabia and Egypt as well as to Israel.

title: Time for Compromise on Cyprus
description: some three weeks have passed since the Turkish Cypriot community submitted new proposals for resolving the Cyprus problem. But the Greek Cypriots refuse even to come to the table to discuss them. The impression spreads that the Greeks are counting on the partial embargo on American arms shipments to Turkey induce a still better offer. They should be dissuaded from any such calculation.

description: TRENTON, May 11 (UPI)State Senator Brian T. Kennedy, Republican of sea Girt, challenged Assemblyman Peter thapiro, Democrat of South Orange, oday to a twomile race to prove that State Senators are not as old as many vconle think they are.

It was a seedy strip filled with massage parlors, pornographicmovie theaters, sleeping derelicts and hawkers shouting, Check it out!

This was underlined by the hurried trip here of Secretary of the Treasury Blumenthal whose intervention was needed simply to get New York's leaders to reach an accord on a deadline for accomplishing what Congress requires before it votes new aid for the city.

title: Japanese Predict Gains for Yen As Trade Surplus Hits New Highs

description: O ne of the week's more provocative attve offerings is being presented on an independent station, WOR Channel 9, tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. It is a 90minute documentary called The Assassination of President. Kennedy: What Do We Know Now That We Didn't Know

description: BELGRADE; YugoSlavia, May 11 (AP) Melvin Paul of the United States advanced into the quarterfinals of the world amateur boxing championships tonight, outpointing Andras Botos of Hungary in a bruising fight.

title: Healy Doffs Mask for a Mike
description: Fran Healy, a littleused catcher but oftused diplomat, retired from playing baseball yesterday to begin broadcasting baseball.

description: Following are excerpts from an address given by Jean Stapleton, who plays Edith Bunker in the television program, All in the Family, upon receiving a doctor of humane letters degree at Emerson College, in Boston.

title: FRANK ARMOUR JR.
description: PITTSBURGH, May 11Frank Armour Jr., who joined the H.J. Heinz Company as a plant tour guide and retired 41 years later as vice chairman of the board, died yesterday at PresbyterianUniversity Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Movie: 'Greek Tycoon,' Rotogravure Style:Two Jacquelines
description: "THE GREEK TYCOON" recalls a sort of newspaper journalism you don't see much anymorethe Sunday supplement recapitulation of a famous murder, divorce or other scandal, put together, from morgue clips, and filled out by the writer with breathless speculation about what really might have happened and what really might have been said, always with more exclamation points than are absolutely necessary. It's the literature of vultures who have no interest in tearing into something of the first freshness.In case you haven't seen the ads, which tell all, the film is the something-less-than-passionate love story of the beautiful young widow of an assassinated United States President and an aging Greek promoter who owns oil tankers, airlines and islands and dreams of becoming President of Greece, which would be decidedly odd since his real-life model traveled on an Argentine passport.Cast in the leading roles are Jacqueline Bisset, who bears a striking resemblance to Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, but, at this date, is younger and more beautiful, and Anthony Quinn, who sort of looks like the late Aristotle Onassis, though he's a much bigger man and according to all reports about Mr. Onassis, possesses much less charm.Some of the other characters who pop up like animated mannequins are a former British prime minister, who looks as if he'd like to look like a bulldog; the Greek tycoon's noisy, publicity-loving mistress; his first wife, who commits suicide under what may or may not be mysterious circumstances; the late President of the United States himself, played by James Franciscus, and his brother (the Attorney General) and sister-in-law.The movie wastes no time attempting to create a fictional equivalent to the Camelot that was the Kennedy era, giving us only a fast montage that includes a reference to a glittering White House dinner party where Neil Diamond entertained and "Greg and Vronique Peck" headed the guest list. If Mort Fine, who wrote the original screenplay, had shown any point of view elsewhere in the script, you might think this was meant to be funny. However, the film is as witless as it is gutless.Most of it is devoted to the courtship and marriage of Liz Cassidy (Miss Bisset) and Theo Tomasis (Mr. Quinn), about whom the writer and J. Lee Thompson, the director, would like to have it both ways. They portray Liz as being deeply in love with both her husbands (in succession) but having a teeny tiny weakness for shopping, and Theo as a brilliant international pirate with a heart of gold, a fellow who loves Liz but loves what she represents even more.Though at 106 minutes the film seems as lone as "The Other Side of Midnight," which ran 160 minutes, "The Greek Tycoon" is only truly intolerable when it attempts to be serious, as when Mr. Quinn talks with supposed feeling about his humble peasant origins or deals lovingly with his son and heir, played by Edward Albert. But then it's not even fun when it's wrestling with its gossipy subject at a skin-deep level, perhaps because our fantasies outrun those of the moviemakers. Played straight, though the laughs are built-in, is the sequence about the notorious wedding contract, which guarantees the bride $10 million for every year she remains married to the Greek. This prompts Liz to recoil in disgust ("It's horriblewriting it all down!), while Theo explains patiently that it's simply an old Greek custom.The performances are uniformly awful, which is a record not easily matched by any movie not made by Larry ("It Lives Again") Cohen. Miss Bisset is great to look at, but "The Greek Tycoon" is the sort of movie in which a fine-looking woman can be upstaged by a boat. This is the magnificent yacht, owned in real life by William Levitt, which doubles as Theo Tomasis's La Belle Simone."The Greek Tycoon," which opens today at Loews State II and other theaters, is fiction divided against itself. It would make no sense if we hadn't read the headlines and gossip columns, to titillate us.

description: City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday charged that economic development ranked quite low on the Mayor's list of priorities and that the city had no strategy for economic recovery.

title: Feminist Group Assails Coal Industry
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 11  A complaint charging the coal industry witn being one of the most blatantly discriminatory employers in the country was filed today by a Tennesseebased group representing a coalition of women's organizations in Appalachia.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, May IIHenry Brammar and Emil Oberg are both 90 years old and live in retirement, makdng model ships.

title: Israelis Take to Parks for Independence Day Cookotzt
description: JERUSALEM May 11Israel celebrated its 30th anniversary today in the form of a giant national picnic that left city streets deserted and the country's green enclaves filled with seekers of respite from the country's ordinary hectic pace.

title: Reserve Report
description: Business Loans:

title: Champion Texas Chili Cook Is Home on the Range
description: HOUSTON, May 11By day, Ed Paetzel is a mildmannered personnel director calmly guiding a staff of hun&ads through the traumas of running a bigcity hotel. But nights and week- ends, when he dons his battered cowboy hat and blue shirt with jackrabbit on the back, Mr. Paetzel becomes Chill Lee, pretender to the throne once occupied by the late Wick Fowler, creator of the legendary TwoAlarm Chili that has long been synonymous with Texas cuisine.

title: Vesco, in Bahamas, Plans Return To Costa Rica Despite Entry Ban
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas; May 11Robert L. Vesco,.the fugitive American financier, said today that he had come to the Bahamas to assist the liquidators of various companies that he once controlled and that he intended to return to Costa Rica despite a ban on his entry there.

title: Women's Caucus Hails 10 Democrats in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI)Ten Democratic Congressmen were given perfect voting scores this year by the National Women's Political Caucus.

title: Diana Kissel Barnard Wed To Alan T. Schumacher
description: Diana Kissel Barnard of Stonington, Conn., and Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas, widow of J. Lawrence Barnard, was married in New York last evening to Alan T. Schumacher, a widower, of Newport. R.I. The Rev. Alanson B. Houghton performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. A reception followed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Meredith M. Brown, son-in-law and daughter of the bride.

title: Bridge:
description: A string of three victories is not uncommon in major team events, but is very rare in pair contests. Trying this weekend for a remarkable triple in one of the world's strongest events will be Alan Sontag and Peter Weichsel of New York. Opposing them in the fourth Cavendish Invitational Pairs event, which they won in 1976 and 1977, will be many of America's top stars and a handful of experts from foreign parts.

title: SENATE PANEL IN TIE ON VOTE TO THWART MIDEAST JET SALES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Senate Foreign Relations Committee blocked move today to thwart President Carter's proposed sale of military planes in a package to Saudi Arabia and Egypt as well as to. Israel.

title: CARTER CALLED VEXED BY LABOR REJECTION OF WAGE GUIDELINES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  President Carter is deeply disappointed by organized labor's rejection of voluntary wageprice guidelines, his top inflation adviser said today, and another top aide said that that characterization of Mr. Carter's reaction was mild.

title: Lincoln Square Council Supports Tucker Statue
description: Support for the controversial statue of Richard Tucker, the opera singer, which is proposed for a West 66th Street park, was affirmed yesterday by the Lincoln Square Community Council, which includes representatives of Lincoln Center, Roosevelt Hospital and neighborhood groups.

title: Italians Throng Into Cemetery To Bury Their Grief in Flowers
description: TORRITA TIBERINA, Italy, May 11This hillside town north of Rome was crowded today with visitors, many of them crying and nearly all heading straight for the little cemetery where the funeral of Aldo Moro was held yesterday.

title: Reasoner to Leave AB C in July and Return to CBS
description: Harry Reasoner will leave ABC in July, he announced yesterday in a statement that was released by the network. It brought to a conclusion a long period of uncertainty about the outcome of his attempt to leave ABC and go to work at CBS.

title: Million in Art Taken From Italian Shrine
description: LA VERNA, Italy, May 11 (UPI)Burglars stole antiques worth more than $1 million today from the shrine on the site where tradition has it St. Francis of Assisi received the stigmata.

title: RICHARD L. WILCOX, 59, EXECUTIVE AND AUTHOR
description: Richard L. Wilcox, a publicrelations executive, combat correspondent in World War II, author and a former member of the staff of Life magazine, died Monday in Bellevue Hospital following a heart attack. He was 59 years old and lived at 176 East 77th Street.

title: Jascalevich Associate Tells of a Mysterious Death
description: HACKENSACK, May 11A doctor testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he remembered vividly his first operation at Riverdell Hospital because his patient had died mysteriously and suddenly the next morning while recovering from a routine abdominal exploratory oneration.

description: ALTER !NIRobert. On May 10, 1978. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Bortlik). Loving father o Barbara Roepe and Virginia Boucher. Dear brother of Phyllis Aspromonte, Mary King, Frances Egan and Edith Catal. Also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral from the Thomas M. Quinn & Sons Funeral Home, Inc, 35.20 Broadway, LI. City, NY, on Saturday at 1 PM. Cremation Fresh Pond Crematory. Visiting hours 710, PM

title: Environmentalist DisputesPriorities
description: TUXEDO, N.Y.After four decades of scholarship and research on the troubled relationship between people and their environment, a leading environmental scientist is convinced that American society now has its ecological and health priorities confused.

title: Art: Staring Down The Camera's Eve
description: WE are obviously at the point in photography where some younger practitioners are using the medium to question its own premisesin other words, making photographs that test suppositions about photography.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: A concert by the Cleveland Quartet, a talk by the author Toni Morrison and a show of Alan Gussow's paintings. No wonder that the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack, N.Y., calls this weekend the busiest of the year. The Cleveland Quartet will play works by Mozart, Rachmaninoff and Mendelssohn tonight at 8:30. Tickets are $3.50: reservations: (914) 3580877. Tomorrow afternoon at 1:30, Toni Morrison will talk about her Song of Solomon and other works. No admission charge. Before and after both programs, there will be time to see the retrospective of Alan Gussow's landscape paintings. From New York City, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to Exit 12: eoritinue to Route 303 south and then to Route 59 east. The Rockland Center, at 27 Old Greenbush Road, is just off the intersection

title: Vietnamese Accused of Espionage Denies Passing Crucial Documents
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 11A Vietnamese graduate student who is accused of espionage denied today that he had ever provided Vietnamese officials in Paris and New York with any material other than such items as a Senator's speech, the Congressional Record or technical books dealing with the reconstruction of Vietnam.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MAY 12, 1978

title: Use of Autos for Assault Increasing in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, May 11A man driving a pickup truck went for a 30mile ride on the Los Angeles Freeway system the other day, and by the time his cdyssey was over, the police said, he had rammed into 32 cars.

title: Books of The Times
description: SIR ISAIAH BERLIN is a fox (a pluralist), and not a hedgehog (a monist). Other foxes we have known include Pushkin and Goethe and Joyce, Aristotle and Balzac and Turgenev. Among the hedgehogs

title: Westchester Fun Days
description: Everyone's in on it this weekend, as hosts as well as guests, when Westchester County opens its corporate and collegiate campuses, highways and waterways, parks and trails, and many other facilities lust for fun.

title: F.A.A. Wants Air Passengers to Stay Buckled Up on Flights
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Federal Aviation Administration proposed today that, as a safety precaution, airline passengers be required to remain buckled in their seats throughout flights. Excepted would be trips to the rest room or periods when the crew explicitly authorized passengers to unfasten the belts, the agency said.

title: SECURITIES DEALERS URGE NEW YORK AID
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 11The Public Securities Association, in a departure from its long-standing position of opposition to Federal credit aid to cities, came out strongly today for such assistance to New York City to avoid the possibility of bankruptr.v_

title: New York Aid Bill Is Moving Rapidly To Floor of House
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Carter Administrationsupported bill to give New York City nearly $2 billion in loan guarantees, approved last week by the House Banking Committee, is now expected to move more rapidly to the House floor than originally thought.

title: MACY, PENNEY JOIN IN SHOPPING CENTER SET FOR STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 11Mayor Louis A. Clapes announced today that stores operated by Macy's and J. C. Penney will be the anchors of a one-million-square-foot downtown shopping center.

title: BUSINESSMEN IN HARLEM OFFER TO SUPPORT DURYEA
description: Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea, seeking support from the black community in his campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor, was warmly received yesterday by a group of Harlem businessman

title: Ginsberg Wins by Shot in Long Island Open
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 11Roger Ginsberg has worked long and hard on his backswing, his takeaway and his grip, changing most of these parts of his golf swing during the last 12 months. Apparently Ginsberg has also learned patience.

title: Art: Young Americans at the Guggenheim
description: YOUNG American Artists at the Guggenheim Museum is a curious, intelligent and provocative display that is well worth an hour of anyone's time. Chosen by Linda Shearer, assistant curator at the museum, and funded by the Exxon Corporation, it offers an an-

title: Dow Up 12.04; Investor Faith In Miller Cited
description: Stock prices surged higher yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced more than a dozen points.

title: A Spring Fling of Outdoor Festivals in City and Suburb
description: For food, there will be such dishes as Tibetan momos, Korean chapchai and Indonesian tofu isi. For entertainment, there will be troupes of Mongolian folk dancers, Japanese koto musicians and aikido demonstrators.

description: HAVING played Columbo on television for seven years, Peter Falk is not finding easy to transform himself, in Brink's, which began shooting in Boston last Monday, into, the leader of the gang that pulled the biggest robbery in American history.

title: Lillian Hellman Fails to Bar Her Toy From Ooenine.
description: An Off Off Broadway production of Lillian Hellman's play Toys in the Attic, about which Miss Hellman has complained, is to begin as scheduled tonight at the WPA Theater, Gerald Haston, the producer, said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court in Albany voided as discriminatory a rate schedule under which customers of the Long Island Lighting Company paid less for electricity if they used it when demand was low.

title: Management
description: When a chief executive officer retires and turns over the reins of active management, he should not stay- on the board of directors. The break should be swift, clean and unequivocal.

title: Carter Rejects Plan For Low El Al Fares
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)President Carter today rejected a proposal by El Al Israel Airlines for a lowcost standby fare between New York and Tel Aviv. Mr. Carter acted on a recommendation of the Civil Aeronautics Board. The President makes the final decision on routes involving international travel to this country.

title: OPEC Finance Ministers Talks Set for Next Tuesday Postponed
description: VIENNA, May 11(AP)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said here today that a session of its finance ministers, scheduled to open next Tuesday, has been postponed until May 23 due to unforeseen circumstances

title: Outlook for U.S. Rate Rise Bolsters Price of Dollar; Gold Is Up to $175.375
description: The dollar rose against nearly all major world currencies in international foreign exchange trading yesterday, The Associated Press reported. Dealers said trading was active in New York but fairly quiet in European markets.

title: What, Besides Mere Money, Makes a Jewel a Gem?; Bagful of Gems; Trickery and Intrigue
description: Behind the bulletproof doors, all is plush carpeting, antique wood tables and soft lights reflected in floor-to-ceiling mirrors, muted shades, of beige and gray, quiet opulence.

description: TORRITA TIBERINA, Italy, May 11This hillside town north of Rome was crowded today with visitors, many of them crying and nearly all heading straight for the little cemetery where the funeral of Aldo Moro was held yesterday.

title: Caribous Stop Fury, 42
description: DENVER, May 11 (AP)Sead Susic scored his first two goals of the season to lead the Colorado Caribous to a 42 victory over the Philadelphia Fury in a North American Soccer League game last night. After Susic's first goal at 13 minutes 47 seconds, Louie Nanchoff scored his first N.A.S.L. goal for Colorado.

title: Velasquez, MapleCleared
description: Jorge Velasquez and Eddie Maple were held blameless yesterday for disqualifications Wednesday at Aqueduct that could have prevented them from riding in the Preakness a week from tomorrow.

title: Bob Hope Partner Dies,
description: OMAHA, May 11 (AP) Gail Hood, an early vaudeville partner of comedian Bob Hope, the comedian, died today of cancer. Mr. Hood, who was 81 years old, worked with Mr. Hope on the Sun time musical comedy circuit in 192527. He once told a reporter that Mr. Hope was a mediocre dancer, but showed signs of being a natural comedian.

title: 76ers vs. Bullets: A. Tale of Two Locker Rooms
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11In most professional sports arenas, the basketball locker room is a large mousetrap where the player does his attitude dancing before and after a game. If

description: To get to the Seventh Heaven street fair in Park Slope, by public transportation on the IND line take th'e F train to Ninth Street or the D train to Seventh Avenue. On the IRT line take the No. 2 or No. 3 Seventh Avenue Express trains to Grand Army Plaza:BY car, take the Brooklyn or Manhattan Bridge and follow Flatbush Avethie until Seventh Avenue.

description: On stage, Patrick Bissell looks every inch a ballet prince. Tall, with squared jaw and a neatly trimmed mop of brown hair, he has impeccable partnering manners. Critics have begun to take notice of the 20-year-old dancer who joined the corps de ballet of American Ballet Theater less than a

title: Chicago Schools To Bar Advance Of Poor Readers
description: CHICAGO, May 11 (AP)About 15,000 of Chicago's 40,000 eighthgraders will be required to attend remedial reading classes this summer if they want to go on to high school.

title: JOHN R. TALLEY, 66
description: ATLANTA, May 11 (AP)John R. Talley, a director of the CocaCola Company and past chairman of the board of the CocaCola Export Corporation, is dead at the age of 66.

title: Ford, Under Fire, Defends Sell at Annual Meeting
description: Mr. Ford opened today's annual meeting by, again presenting a lengthy statement defending himself and other directors against the charges. The allegations ara so blatantly untrue and so .completely unwarranted by the facts that I felt had no other course but to speak out immediately, he said. His original denial of the charges was made last week.

title: House Energy Conferees Delay Meeting on Gas Pricing Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Because they found they did not have the votes, House energy conferees put off a meeting and a vote on the latest natural gas pricing proposal that had been scheduled for today.

title: Guild Charged Bad Faith
description: U.S. Labor Board Charges Guild With Coercion at The Daily News

title: Needed: A New Tax Strategy
description: As the economic topography of 1978 and beyond comes into sharper view, the President's plan for cutting taxes, drawn up in the fog of last winter, seems less and less appropriate. Inflation is getting worse than the President and his advisers had anticipated but the economy turning out to be considerably stronger. The unemployment rate dropped to 6 percent in Aprila level that the Administration had not hoped to reach for another year. Many economists believe the outlook for the rest of 1978 and early 1979 is for continued growth of employment and some further drop in unemploymentwithout the stimulus of any tax cut.

title: Wire Service Guild Approves New U.P.I. Contract, 337 to 305
description: The Wire Service Guild voted last night to accept a proposed 25month nationwide contract with United Press International. The approval, by a vote of 337 to 305. was aeainst the recommendation of the guild negotiating committee. which had described the management proposal as an extraordinary insult. The guild represents 900 U.P.I. employees in the United States.

title: HUEY NEWTON SEIZED ON INTENT TO MURDER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther Party chairman, and two associates were arrestea and charged with assault with intent to commit murder early this morning after a barroom brawl.

title: Runaway Medical Costs Forcing Hospitals to Reconsider Methods
description: BOSTON  Two men, their laws slack, their faces a parchment yellow, lay cranked to a reclining position in their hospital beds, Oxygen nozzles were fixed to their nostrils and intravenous solutions dripped through tubes into their arms. Wires attached to their arms and chests ?n to sleek, stainless steel ma- chines that monitored their vital functions. A nurse sat between the two beds, glancing frequently at the monitors to make sure no crisis was at hand.

title: Suzy Chaffee  Somersaults and SeriousThoughts
description: She first gained fame as a madcap downhill racer on the 1968 United States Olympic ski team. She later became a celebrity when she switched to freestyle. or hot dog. skiing and won three world championships. Then came her Suzy Chapstick television commercial, followed by her recent much-publicized schusses down the slopes with Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: LOUIS SHERWIN, 95, PROCLAMATIONS AIDE
description: ALBANY, May 11Louis Sherwin, former newspaper reporter and drama critic who served as the state proclamations officer for. 28 years, died today at Albany Medical Center Hospital of aspiration pneumonia. He was 95 years nip

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 11 (AP)The Shah of Iran postponed a trip to Easterr Europe today and took command troops acting to break up demonstrations by thousands of Moslem extremists, de. manding the ouster of the Shah and return to strict Islamic principles of rule.

title: A Voice From Harlem's Past
description: You'd scarcely recognize Claudia .McNeil this weekend at Michael's Pub, where she is singing songs associated with Ethel Waters. When she starred in dramatic, nonsinging roles on Broadway in Raisin in the Sun and in the television production of Member of the Wedding, she was a big, ample woman welching nearly 300 nounds.

title: t LeadPoisoning Cases, Attributed to Old Paint, Found at State Hospital
description: TRENTON, May 11Four patients at the State Neuropsychiatric Institute at Skillman have been found to have lead poisoning, apparently caused by old, leadbated paint, used at the hospital 25 years ago

title: Soviet Notes Israel's 30th Year With Denunciation of Zionism
description: MOSCOW, May 11 (UPI)The Soviet press marked the 30th anniversary of the founding of Israel today with a bitter denunciation of Zionism as expansionist, racist and warlike.

title: A SelfHelp Neighborhood Fights Against Urban Blight
description: The view north and west from the corner of Rogers Avenue and Lincoln Road in Brooklyn provides a powerful and graphic symbol of the frustrations and the pride of the active members of the Pr ospectLefferts Gardens Neighborhood Asso- ciation and, to some extent, other groups in similar neighborhoods throughout the city.

title: Dividends

title: Philip Morris Bids Bring- Suit by 7Up
description: The SevenUp company announced yesterday that it had filed suit to block the latest tender,,offer and merger bid by Philip Morris Inc. because the diversified tobacco company failed to publish com plete details of the offers as required by securities law. Philip Morris immediately agreed to comply with the, requirements..

title: Market Place
description: The wise investor who examines prosaic company is likely to look at the dividend record before calling his broker. And well he might, because the surest way to benefit from share ownershin is to obtain an income.

title: Phils Send Seaver to 4th Loss, 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (UPI)Steve Carlton pitched a sixhitter in outdueling Torn Seaver, and Richie Hebner drove in two runs with a triple and scored a run tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Cincinnati Reds. 41.

title: Euripides Gets a Cathedral Setting
description: The cavernous nave of the Cathedral of Saint John The Divine will be filled for the next three weekends with the rounds of Greek tragedy. Tonight at 8:30 a new production of The Bacchae of Euripides opens at the cathedral, on Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 8.5%
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 18 billion tonmiles. un 8.5 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 487,932 cars, up 3.1 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose threetenths of 1 percent from a year ago.

description: MAY 12, 197R

title: Amara Accuses Met Of Bias Against Age

title: Ford Endorses Limits On WagePrice Rises
description: DETROIT, May 11Henry Ford 2d, the chairman of the Ford Motor Cornpany, told shareholders today that he agreed with President Carter that inflation was the most serious problem confronting the nation, and he endorsed th' President's appeal for cooperation in limitine wage and price increases.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on May 2 said incorrectly that 15,000 refugees were housed at a camp at Khlong Yai, Thailand. That camp houses 400 refugees; about 15,000 are housed in several camps.

title: Hua Accepts a French Invitation
description: PARIS, May 11 (AP)Hua Kuofeng, the Chinese leader, has accepted an invitation to visit France, a visiting Chinese Deputy Prime Minister, Ku Mu, anrounced today. Mr. Ku made the announcment after a 75minute meeting with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. No date has been set.

title: Halpern, Former Convict, Spars for Bikers Inmates

title: ExLobbyist in Agreement
description: Gulf Oil's former chief lobbyist has agreed to a consent arrangement regarding alleged Federal securities violations in connection with illegal political payments. Page D7.

title: Agencies Adopt Uniform System For Rating of Commercial Banks
description: The three Federal banking regulatory agencies said yesterday they had adopted a uniform system for rating the condition and soundness of the nation's commercial banks. Until now, the three agencies, Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and Comptroller of the Currency, used differing systems that made comoarison difficult.

title: Peking Accuses Soviet Forces Of a Raid on Manchurian Border
description: HONG KONG, May 11Peking charged today that Soviet soldiers using a helicopter and military boats crossed the border on Tuesday, shooting and wounding some Chinese.

title: MITSUBISHI INTERNATIONAL TERMS CHARGES AN ERROR
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., May 11 (UPI)The Mitsubishi International Corporation believes it was mistakenly indicted by Federal grand jury in South Carolina on charges of conspiring to .steal polyester film trade secrets from the Celanese Corporation, according to the concern's general counsel in New York.

title: BROADWAY CONCERN LOSES LIGHT PACT
description: The Broadway Maintenance Corporation, the frequently criticized holder of a 25year monopoly on Manhattan and Bronx streetlight maintenance failed yes= terdaY to submit the low bid for the new cntract.

title: BUDGET CONFEREES STALLED ON 2 ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Senate and House budget conferees agreed on the easy ones today but got bogged down on national defense and education as they sought to set tentative goals for the fiscal year starting in October.

title: Brooklyn's 7th Heaven
description: If John Denver has developed almost heaven in West Virginia, the people of Park Slope in Brooklyn have found seventh heaven on a local thoroughfare.

description: By The Associated Press

title: Students Sample Tombs Time
description: Cries of Let me outplease let me out and the sound of rattling cell bars filled Tier 5 of the Tombs yesterday afternoon. Eventually, the cells were opened and the people in them wound un at trials in Criminal Court.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An agreement has been reached to sell Garden State Park race track in Cherry Hill, which was destoyed in fire in April last year, officials said yesterday.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11Henry Brammar and Emil Oberg are both 90 years old and live in retirement, making model ships.

title: Notes on People
description: When Tom Tipton marries Earnestine Collins in Minneapolis on May 20, they will be supported by an allstar cast. Mr. Tipton, founder of the city's first blackowned advertising agency, will have Vice President Mondale as his best man, standing in for the late Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who had always said he wanted the bestman honors. A groomsman will be Joe Black, former pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, and among Mr. Tipton's ushers will be three proftssional football players, Alan Page, Carl.Eller, and Jim Marshall. To top it all off, Roberta Flack, a high school classmate of Mr. Tipton, promised to sing at his wedding.

title: Bruins Beat Flyers And Gain Cup Final
description: BOSTON, May 11For the second year in a row, the National Hockey League championship will pit the Montreal Canadiens against the Boston Bruins. By beating the Philadelphia Flyers, 63, tonight at Boston Garden, the Bruins captured the semifinal series, four games to one.

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Rose To 226 From 225 a Week Ago
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 226 from 225 last week.

title: U.S. Seeking New King of QuarterMile
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 11After a decade of dominance, led by such figures as Lee Evans, Larry James, Vince Matthews, Tommie Smith, JOhn Smith and Wayne Collett, the United States is searching for a new king of the auartermile.

title: Brooklyn Rabbi Admits He Gave Bribes to Flood
description: A Brooklyn rabbi pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of bribing Representative Daniel J. Flood with at least $5,000 in return for the Congressman's intervention with Federal agencies on behalf of the rabbi's B'nai Torah Institute.

title: Precious Metals Futures Decline As the Dollar Rebounds Smartly
description: The dollar rebounded smartly yesterday in response to the halfpoint rise in the Federal Reserve's discount rate and provoked a sharp selloff the precious metals and foreign currency futures markets late in the session.

title: New Report of Cancer in Bergen
description: PALISADES PARK, May 11An environmentally oriented group of residents opposed to industrial growth in this small Bergen County community has notified town officials that at least 14 residents in fiveblock radius have died of cancer in recent years and that another five are ill with malignancies.

title: Nigerians Hold Key Posts at Gulf Oil Unit
description: ESCRAVOS RIVER DELTA, NigeriaThis is the way people who have not been to Africa often think it looks, though it seldom does. Muddy waters stream past clusters of reed huts built on stilts. Crocodiles lie in ominous renose. Dugout canoes cut through marshes. In one channel an old dredge forces an opening in the swamp. Tied to it is a motorboat called The African Queen.

title: Yoyo Ma Wins Fisher
description: YO-YO MA, a 22-year-old cellist who was born In Paris of Chinese parents and who has been living in this country for the last 15 years, has been awarded the Avery Fisher Prize for 1978. It is the first time since the Fisher Prize Program was established in 1975 that only one artist was named for an award.

title: Montessori Indian Night
description: An evening of Indian music and dance and exotic food is planned tonight from 6:30 to 10:30 at the Montessori Family School, 323 East 47th street. Proceeds from the evening,

title: French Troops Keeping Chad From Falling to Rebels
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, May 10With rebel forces 250 miles from the capital, the Government of Chad is being saved from collapse only by a substantial and growing commitment of French troops and fighterbombers.

title: Former Teamster Official Indicted in Getting $60 ,000 From Concerns
description: NEWARK, May 11A former New Jersey teamsters official was indicted today by .a Federal grand jury on charges that he demanded and received illegal payments of more than $60,000 from executives of four companies with which the union had contracts.

title: President Says States Will Share Cost of New U.S. Water Projects
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  President Carter. told leaders of environmental groups today that his longawaited national water policy would include provisions for state sharing in the costs of new Federal water projects, as well as Federal money to aid states in conserving the water they get from them.

title: Melnyk's 65 on Stellar Putting Leads Colonial by Shot
description: FART WORTH, May 11 (AP)Steve Melnyk took only one putt on each of last 12 holes, including a sevenfooter for a, birdie on the 18th, to post a five-under-par 65 today and lead in the first round of the Colonial National Invitatinn polf tournament.

title: SENATE PANEL KEEPS ARMS BAN ON TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Carter Administration's effort to end the threeyearold arms embargo against Turkey suffered a major setback today when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 8 to 4 to maintain the ban, that was instituted in 1975 becauSe of Turkey's invasion of Cyprus.

title: Senator Haskell of Colorado Seen In Deep Trouble in Reelection Bid
description: DENVER, May 11Floyd K. Haskell of Colorado is the only Senate Democrat in the West up for reejection this year, and political followers say that he is in deep trouble. The Republicans have three, strong contenders in their primary election Sept. 12, and the party is prepared to put a potful of money into beating Mr. Haskell.

title: Two Campus Police Officers Cited for Heroism
description: NEWARK, May 11Patrolling the neighborhood in bitter cold at 2 A.M. last Feb. 18, Maurice G. Montemurro, a 24-year-old member of the RutgersNewark Police Department, saw flames shooting from an apartment building at 8G University Avenue.

title: BOND PRICES TUMBLE IN FEAR OF RATE RISE
description: Bond prices tumbled sharply late yesterday afternoon after the Federal Reserve reported a surprisingly large jump in the  nation's money supply. The in- Crease raiSeci rears tnat tne central bank might well decide to raise its Federal funds target to 7 percent after its policysetting open market committee meets in Washington next Tuesday.

title: Books: Images of South Africa
description: THE DICTIONARY definition of apartheid a policy of segrega tion and political and economic discrimination against nonEuropean groups in the Republic of South Africa (Webster's New Collegiate Dictionary) pales into inadequacy when faced with the reality of Peter Magubane's photographs of this policy in action.

title: Brooklyn Rabbi Admits He Gave Bribes to Flood
description: A Brooklyn rabbi pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of bribing Representative Daniel J. Flood with at least $5,000 in return for the Congressman's. intervention with Federdl agencies on behalf of the rabbi's B'nai Torah Institute.

title: The Age Of Diaghilev Through Artists Eyes; (Page C18); The Age of Diaghilev in Artists Eyes

By encouraging collaborations between innovative choreographers, composers and painters, Diaghilev made classical ballet a modern art

title: Around the Nation
description: NORMAL, Ill., May 11 (AP)Tne 4.4day jail term of Normal's striking firemen ended early today when all 22 were released, but little progress was reported toward settlement of their dispute.

title: Califano to Attend Services
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, will head the United States delegation to the memorial services for Aldo Moro, the State Department announced today.

title: Southeast: Activity Seems To Outpace Rest of theU.S.
description: ATLANTAThe pace of economic activity in the Southeastern states appears to be headed along a somewhat faster track than the one being followed by the nation as a whole. Even

title: Restaurants
description: WITH warm weather and long twilights just ahead, one of the delights of. New York in summer is an early fish dinner at Sloppy Louie's, the 43-year-old restaurant that is a landmark on South Street near the Fulton Fish Market. Not only is it pleasant to have the simple, moderately priced fish main courses that are preparea mere, out arterwara there rs tne bonus of being able to sit on the pier of the South Street Seaport Museum, or to walk among the enticing alleyways of the financial district and to marvel at the lobbies of some of the more interesting buildings such as the Cocoa Exchange.

title: Britain Acts to Reduce High Taxes
description: LONDON, May 11Amid farce and confusion, the House of Commons took a small step last night toward reducing the nation's heavy taxes on middle- and upperincome people.

title: Publishing: The Making of Na Big Book
description: WHEN they get around to doing Ken Follett's This Is Your Life, the week of April 23 will occupy a big place in it. For that was the week Mr. Follett became half a millionaire.

title: BillWould Hold All Parents Liable For Vandalism by Their Children
description: ALBANY, May 11  The Assembly today approved a bill that would make parents liable for vandalism committed by their children even if the parents could prove that they had been diligent.

title: Advertising; Sending New Fans Off to the Races; Product Idea Survey; What Else Is New?; PoliceCommunity Links; Accounts; Addenda
description: The New York Racing Association, whose yearold marketing program appears to have halted an eightyear downward trend in attendance, is breaking a new ad campaign next Wednesday that is intended to create a whole new clan of fans. And if research can make a campaign work, this one should work.

title: Levittown Will Drop 70 Teachers, Pointing to Decline in Enrollment
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I., May 11The LeVit town School Board voted last night to cut out 70 teachers, most of them from kindergarten through the sixth grade and some with as much as 15 years of experience.

title: CARTER CALLED VEXED BY LABOR REJECTION OF WAGE GUIDELINES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  President Carter is deeply disappointed by organized labor's rejection of voluntary wageprice guidelines, his top inflation adviser said today, and another top aide said that that characterization of Mr. Carter's reaction was mild.

title: Fed Raises Discount Rate For Loans to 7% From 6 /2%
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday raised the interest rate it charges on the loans it makes to banks, one of the most significant interest rates of the economy.

title: Shift in Ambulance COntrol Urged
description: New York City's designated top health official said last night that he would ask Mayor Koch today to remove the city's emergency ambulance service that responds to the 911 telephone number from the control of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation and set up a new Emergency Medical Service Board to run it.

title: U.S. and Soviet Agree to Hold Regular Talks to Curb Arms Trade
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that they had agreed that the problem of limiting arms sales was urgent and needed to be resolved to promote international peace and security and strengthen dtente.

title: Sale of Small News Service in Capital to Have a Big Effect
description: WASHINGTONOn the week that the Gannett Company, the newspaper chain with the largest number of papers in the nation, announced that it would acquire the Combined Communications Corporation, one of the country's biggest broadcast chains, in a $370 million transaction, the following may not exactly qualify as major media news:

title: Auctions
description: WHEN Christie, Manson & Woods came to New York frcm London a year ago, it chose to challenge its archcompetitor, Sotheby Parke Bernet, by scheduling as its premiere sale here Impressionist and modern art, the fields Sotheby's has long dominated.

title: Dispute on Anticrirne Bill Pits Caiey Against Allies
description: ALBANY, May 11An unusual dispute has arisen between Governor Carey and his Democratic allies in the Assembly over,whether either side had been aware that a key anticrime bill contained sleeper provision to wipe the state's existing deathpenalty statute off the books.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MAY 12, 1978

title: Pressure Differs For 6th Game
description: The Washington Bullets, with WeS. Unseld back in the starting lineup, and the Philadelphia 76ers face contrasting pressures tonight in the sixth game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference championship at the Capital Centre in-Landover Md.

title: CASINO UNIT OFFICIAL DOUBTS HOTEL'S DATA
description: TRENTON, May 11A member of the Casino Control Commission said today that an environmental impact study submitted by Resorts International underestimated the extent of overcrowding and the effect on traffic that the opening of Atlantic City's first casino would bring.

title: Lebanon Moslem Prayer Leaders Told to Denounce Afghan Regime
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 11 (UPI)The office of the leader of Lebanon's Sunni Moslems has ordered speakers at mosques to condemn alleged atrocities committed against Moslem scholars by the new Government in Afghanistan, the independent daily An Nahar said today.

title: L.I. Folklore at C.W. Post
description: They'll be telling Long Island folklore all day tomorrow at Long Island University's C.W. Post Center in Greenvale. L.I. This 14th annual Storytelling Institute, sponsored by the school and the Nassau and Suffolk county library systems, will begin at 9:30 A.M. in Room 208 of Humanities Hall and end at about 4 P.M.; participants must register in the same building ??A M The symposium costs $8.50, including lunch. Information: (516) 2992333.

title: 18 Arrested in Raids On Wide Betting Ring
description: Eighteen persons were arrested last night here and upstate In what the police said was a $50 million-a-year gambling operation controlled by the Vito Genovese crime family.

title: For the Tuition Credit
description: YONKERSSome friends of the public schools have worked up strong case against the Tuition Tax Credit Bill sponsored by Senators Daniel P. Moynihan, New York Democrat, and Bob Packwood, Republican of Ore gon. They argue that any tax credit for partial tuition to nonpublic schools will lead to the death of the public school. The House Ways and Means Committee removed that provision of the bill on April 11, but the full House has the opportunity to reinstate it with a floor amendment.

title: Art: Al Held Puts Op In a Hall of Mirrors
description: POST-PAINTERLY Abstraction,' like all the other posts, has a millennial ring to it, as though the present in which it was coined had no hope of becoming more than a footnote to the past. True as this might

title: Jersey Casino Aide Doubts Hotel's Data On Traffic Problems
description: TRENTON, May 11A member of the Casino Control Commission said today that an environmental impact study submitted by Resorts International underestimated the extent of overcrowding and the effect on traffic that the opening of Atlantic City's first casino would bring.

title: Suspect Ties Klein to Kidnapping
description: Paule Ransay, one of three persons accused of kidnapping Calvin Klein's daughter last February, testified yesterday that the fashion designer had been her lover and had arranged the abduction himself, promising to give her $100,000 in addition to the $100,000 in ransom money.

title: Toasts to Clearwater Planned for Sunday
description: The Clearwater, the Hudson River sloop that set sail nine years ago to publicize and initiate environmental projects, will be toasted at a birthday celebration Sunday at the Casa Galicia Restaurant, 119 East 11th Street, (between Third and Fourth Avenue).

title: Convergence After All?
description: We heard heated debate some years ago about something called the convergence of Soviet and American societies. American scholars argued that both were moving together and would some day be indistinguishable. Needless to say, the Kremlin's pundits labeled all such speculation as bourgeois fantasy.

title: Italian Guerrillas in Milan Shoot Chemical Bank Manager in the Legs
description: ROME, May 11A man and woman, both wearing masks, fired four shots into the legs of the Italian manager of the Chemical Bank of New York in a street ambush in Milan today.

title: $100 MILLION OVERCHARGE BY UTILITIES ESTIMATED
description: WASHINGTON, May 11(AP)Consumers in areas affected by last winter's 110. day coal strike may have been overcharged $100 million for emergency electricity purchases by utilities, a Federal energy official said today.

title: Town Hall Faces 1978 79 Shutdown
description: New York University will decide within the next two weeks whether Town Hall, for decades one of New York's best concert facilities, will be open for business next season according to William von Raab, N.Y.U.'s vice president for administration.

title: Trudeau, Hoping for an Upturn, Puts Off Election, Perhaps to 79
description: OTTAWA, May 11Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced today that the next elections, which had been expected for this summer, would be postponed, possibly until next spring.

title: ExGulf Lobbyist Consents to Pact With U.S. on Political Payments
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)The former chief lobbyist of the Gulf Oil Corporation entered into a consent agreement today regarding alleged Federal securities violations in connection with $5 million in illegal contributions to Presidential, Congressional and state political candidates.

title: 3 DIE IN BEIRUT FIGHTING BETWEEN RIGHTIST UNITS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 (Reuters)Three persons were killed and several wounded in fighting between rightwing Lebanese militia units in a Christian suburb of Beirut. nonce sources said today.

title: Television
New Communications Satellite
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 12 (AP) experimental communications satellite owned by the European Space Agency has been fired into space with a Delta rocket eight months after the first attempt failed. The 1,845pound satellite, called Orbital Test Satellite, is the forerunner to test concepts for an operational satellite network planned for the 1980's. The satellite can handle two television channels and 5,000 phone calls simultaneously.

title: Bus Strike in St. Louis Ends
description: ST. LOUIS, May 12 (UPI)Bus drivers and mechanics returned to their jobs todny, ending a oneday walkout that had affected about 250,000 riders, but the contract dispute that led to the wildcat strike remained unresolved. The 1.400

title: Crazy Rhythm
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif.In my early years I whistled a lot of tunes without knowing the words. Who needed the words? The blitheness of spirit, the buoyant optimism, the great expectations were all in the tunes. I still remember the time and place I first heard . I was in Chicago. Music was the way Chicago got into me. They had a band on the stage before the movie, and during the intermission we sang along with the organ. I loved to sing .with a lot of people, if the song was right.

title: Plans for River Project Upset Florida Oystermen
description: APALACHICOLA, Fla., May 11Gene McLeod talks about the oyster in personal, en6earing terms, as one might speak of a friend or a relative.

title: Sale of Bonds Urged for Building and Flood Control,
description: TRENTON, May 12The state's Commission on Capital Budgeting and Planning recommended today that bond referendums totaling $248 million be put before the voters on the Nov. 7 ballot.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COME ON DOWN This is a big day along Bedford, Barrow and Commerce Streets, as the Greenwich Village blockassociation festively holds its annual fleamarket and fair, selling crafts, antiques, knickknacks, plants and foods.

title: LyricTroupe Stages'CradleWill Rock
description: Marc Blizstein's The Cradle Will Rock has been a legend in the American theater ever since its first production in 1937, when it was barred from the theater it was scheduled to play in, and a performance was improvised elsewhere by the composer and the cast. It achieved considerable status as the first successful American attempt to adapt locally the sardonic style of the BrechtWeill theater pieces. The Cradle Will Rock is, in fact, dedicated to Brecht.

title: Provincetown Postal Staff Arrested
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., May 12 (AP) The postmaster of this Cape Cod resort town and his entire clerical staff have been arrested and charged in connection with embezzlement of nost office funds.

title: Moses Wins 400 Hurdles In Fast 48.62
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 12Proving he had lost nothing since last season, Edwin Moses won the 400meter intermediate hurdles tonight with the fastest time in the world this year, 48.62 seconds.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, MAY 12, 1976

title: Royals BeatYanks,43, On InsidePark Homer
description: KANSAS CITY, May 12A lastplay collision between Paul Blair and Reggie Jackson turned what appeared to be a 3.2 Yankee victory into a 43 loss to the Kansas City Rcyals tonight, giving Amos Otis an ins:de-the-park tworun homer instead of the final out of the ninth inning.

title: Mother of Senator Laxalt Dies
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 12 (UPI)Theresa Laxalt, mother of United States Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, died Wednesday at O'Connor Hospital. She was 87 years old. In addition to the Senator, Mrs. Laxalt is survived by four other childrenMary Dint of Santa Clara, Calif.; Peter Laxalt, of Reno; Robert Laxalt, of Reno, and John Laxalt, Washington, D.C.

title: Bruins May Be Prepared This Time
description: Things will be different this time, vowed virtually all the Boston Bruin players as they prepared for the start of their championship series for the Stanley Cup tonight against the Canadiens at Montreal's Forum.

title: Diplomats, Carey and Koch at a Mass for Moro
description: A memorial mass for Aldo Moro, attended by members of the United Nations diplomatic corps, leaders of the ItalianAmerican community and high officials of New York City and the state, was celebrated yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Another Sexist Bastion Falls: Hurricanes Renamed
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The Commerce Department announced today that a bast,on of sexism as renowned as the men's bar at the Biltmore had fallen to the changing times: Hurricane will no longer be named exclusively for women.

title: Trial Begins for Doctor Accused Of InjectionMurder of His Wife
description: A former resident in surgery at Harlem Hospital went on trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, charged with murdering his wife with a. hard-todetect drug injected last year while she was a patient at the hospital.

title: Moscow Sets Trial for a Dissident
description: MOSCOW, May 12 (ReuterS)Yuri Orley, a Soviet human rights activist, will go on trial Monday, his Triends said today.

description: Battery Park Housing Plans Win Tentative Backing of Washington

title: Con Edison Seeks a 9 .6% Increase InElectric Rates, Starting May 79
description: The Consolidated Edison Company asked the New York State Public Service commission yesterday to let it raise its electricity rates next year by 9.6 percent, or nearly $230 million a year. It cited increased costs and anticipated lower profits for this year as its chief reasons.

title: SevereWeather Strikes Midwest
description: Violent weather hit areas of the Midwest yesterday. In Oklahoma, above, a tornado swept across northern part of the state. In Kansas City, lightning accompanying a hail-andrain storm hit a transformer, causing a blackout in part of the city.

description: ROME, May 12 (Reuters)The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI would attend a state memorial service tomorrow for his friend Aldo Moro.

title: Israelis Renew Pledge to Curb Cluster Bombs
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Israel has signed a secret agreement with the United States renewing a pledgeviolated during its March incursion into Lebanon not to use Americansupplied cluster bombs except under special wartime coilditions.

title: Wheat Futures Rise 10c On News of Smaller Crop; Corn Prices Up Slightly
description: CHICAGO, May 12 (AP)Wheat futures climbed higher this week, lifted by a variety of developments that could signal the beginning of the end of burdensome supplies that have depressed prices for more than two years.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, May 12 (AP)The Chicago Bulls named Rod Thorn, assistant coach of the New Jersey Nets, as general manager today. The move sets the stage for the Bulls to hire a coach to replace Ed Badger, who resigned. A former Bull's star, Jerry Sloan, is considered the leading candidate.

title: Corporation Affairs Labatt, Canadian Brewer, Agrees To Acquire Winery in California
description: John Labatt Ltd., the large Canadian brewer, said that it had agreed in principle to acquire substantially all of the assets of Bear Mountain Winery of Bakersfield, Calif., a grower cooperative and winery, in exchange for Labatt's assuming substantially all of Bear Mountain's liabilities, which were not disclosed. Bear Mountain sells its product under a private label and under the M. Lamont and Mountain Gold brands.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: RON NESSEN WRITES BOOK. ON WORK IN WHITE HOUSE
description: Ron Nessen, who gave up a job as White House correspondent for NBC News to become a press secretary to President Ford, has written a book that focuses on the differences between reporting on the White House and working for it.

title: Emergency Meeting Set on Palisades Cancer Deaths
description: PALISADES PARK, May 12Local health and environmental officials began gearing up today for an investigation into a reported concentration of 15 cancer deaths within a fiveblock radius in recent years. The State Health Department had turned down an appeal for immediate assistance in the investigation.

description: Looking for. Mr. President, a pursuit that is making waves in the nation's giant apparel and retailing industries, might easily be viewed as new adult game.

title: Additional Aid for Minority Arts Is Sought at State University
description: The voicing of complaints in Harlem is not new, but yesterday at a State Senate hearing in Harlem on how the New York State Council on the Arts is affecting minorities, complaints were voiced on behalf of American Indians, Greeks, Balkan peoples, Asians and Hispanics as well as blacks.

title: Sonics Take 31 Lead
description: SEATTLE, May 12 (AP)Dennis Johnson scored 11 of his 31 points in the fourth period, and Fred Brown scored all 11 of his points in the final period to lead the Seattle SuperSonics to a 10094 victory tonight over the Denver Nuggets. The triumph game Seattle a 31 lead in the four-of-sevengame series for the N.B.A. Western Conference championship.

title: DAVE KERR,68,DIES; GOALIE FOR RANGERS
description: Dave Kerr, the goalie who appeared in every game of the last New York Rangers championship season, in 193940, died Thursday in a Belleville, Ontario, hospital after a long illness. He was 68 Years old.

title: CARTER NOW SEEKS A SMALLER TAX CUT AND 3MONTH DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  President Carter abandoned his plan for a tax cut on Oct. 1 today, saying that the cut should be delayed to Jan. 1, 1979, and should be smaller than the $25 billion he has been insisting on.

title: Scaffolding Falls on Two
description: Two men who had allegedly been removing wood from the protective scalfolding around an abandoned building in the Bronx were injured yesterday when the scaffolding collapsed on top of them, the police said. The men, identified as Leonard Taylor, 23 years old, of 1115 Clay Ayenue and Sonny James, 29, of 595 East 170th Street, both of the Bronx, were not serioz, injured in the accident. at 166th Sire:: and Findlay Aver.ue, ac, cording to Police Sgt. Thomas Sullivan. He said the two might be arrested on charges of criminal mischief when they were ceased- from Lincoln Vospitol::

title: Blumenthal Sees Lower Budget Deficit Than Forecast
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said here today that he expects the Federal budget deficit for fiscal 1979 to be lower than the $59 billion most recently forecast by the Carter Administration.

title: Peter Sparling. Dancers Appear
description: Peter Sparling is an intelligent dancer and choreographer. The program of modern dance presented by Peter Sparling and Dancers on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church was wellbalanced, with a sendup of gangster flicks, a dramatic solo based on Greek mythology, a dark abstract group work and a Chinese folkloric theaterdance pieceall choreographed within the last two years.

title: Deaths
description: ARONOWITZIda, The Board of Di- rectors and members of the Jack Martin Fund record with deep sor row the passing ot Ida Aronowitz sis- ter of our esteemed member of the Board, Lou Strombero. We extenc our heartfelt condolences to all members of the family.

title: Pentagon Bars Data on Plane Crash
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 12 (UPI)The Pentagon concedes that a plane crashel, but is not saying anything else.

title: Bullets Win, 10199, Eliminate 76ers
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 12Wes Unseld, the massive Washington Bullets center, tapped in his missed shot with 12 seconds remaining tonight, and the basket provided his team with a 10199 victory over the Philadelphia fifers and the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference championship.

title: News Summary
description: Israel renewed its pledge to the United States not to use Americansupplied cluster bombs except under special wartime conditions. The pledge was violated during the Israeli drive into Lebanon in March. The renewal of the pledge was made in an agreement, the terms of which are secret, in the form of notes dated April 10 and 11. The agreement has been transmitted to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the House International Relations Committee. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: U.S. SAYS SAUDIS STAND BY VOW ON BASING U.S. JETS
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)The Administration said tonight that Saudi Arabia stood by its pledge not to base sophisticated Americansupplied fighters within striking distance of Israel despite statements to the contray by the Saudi Arabian Foreign:Minister.

title: WMCA Rejects Union
description: Clerical and editorial employees at radio station WMCA rejected, by a vote of 17 to 4, any union representation in an election held Thursday night by the National Labor Relations Board. The election. which offered a choice between no union and the National Association of Broadcast. Employees and Technicians, was the latest action in what has been long and bitter fight between station management and the union.

title: GIMBELS REPORTS $3.6 MILLION LOSS
description: Gimbel Brothers Inc. reported a loss of $3.6 million yesterday for its second fiscal quarter ended April I, compared with a $5.7 million loss reported in the same period in 1977. Sales for the period increased 3.9 percent to $210.5 million from $202.7 million.

title: DR. HERBERT C. FETT SR., AN ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON
description: Dr. Herbert C. Fett Sr., an orthopedic surgeon who had practiced. tin Brooklyn for nearly 60 years, died yesterday morning at the Oznam Nursing Home in Bayside, Queens. He was 86 years old.

title: Winds Cause Delay of Test Blast
description: TONOPAH, Nev., May. 12 (UPI)High winds today forced scientists to cancel planned explosion of bariummetal vapor, which had been expected to create green cloud visible from parts of Utah, Nevada, Arizona and California. The test. in which a rocket was to carry a bomb to an altitude of about 120 miles, had been designed to show how ionospheric disturbances, including the explosion of a nuclear weapon in space, affect communications.

title: Deborah Syma Fletcher Wed To Douglas Parker, Lawyer
description: Deborah Syma Fletcher, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Fletcher of Brooklyn, was married at noon yesterday to Douglas Alan Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Parker of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Ann Karen Winters Bride Of Paul Gerard Maguire
description: Ann Karen Winters, daughter of Mrs. John Carroll Everett of Atlanta and the late Dr. Daniel McCoy Winters, was married in New York yesterday to Paul Gerard Maguire of Alexandria, Va., son of Mrs. Frank E. Maguire of Short Hills and Monmouth Beach, N.J., and the late Mr. Maguire. The Rev. John Herrington performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Catechetical Center.

title: Can We Afford a Volunteer Army?
description: Five years after the end of the draft, the allvolunteer armed forces remain a source of concern. No nation has ever before tried to maintain a mass army by voluntary recruitment. The experiment has brought sharply higher costs, a cut in the forces from 2.7 to 2.1 million men, lags in recruiting for active and reserve units, and a decline in the quality of the nation's fighting men. It is now an Army with substandard education, heavy racial imbalance and a dropout rate double that of the draft era (40 percent of recruits are discharged before completing their first term of service). These issues have been evaded by the military, the Congress and successive Administrations because revival of the draft has been deemed politically impossible. But the luxury of evasion may not last long.

title: Nat West, Founded in 1658, A Patriarch of British Banking
description: Four years ago the National Westminster Bank Ltd. let it be known that it was interested in a major investment in the United States. The bank disclosed it had made tentative inquiries into the possibility of acquiring the then financially troubled Franklin National Bank. That interest never materialized.

title: 'Jennifer,' Sister Film To 'Carrie'
description: Say, have you heard the one about the shy, strange-looking high school girl who lives with her religious-nut parent and is tormented by her wealthier class-mates, until she uses her telekinetic powers to knock 'em dead? "Jennifer" is a hand-me-down version of "Carrie," from which it borrows all of the above, plus a shower scene, final scare and a couple of costumes that look just like Sissy Spacek's. If it doesn't copy the precise ending of "Carrie," the reasons appear to have been financial rather than esthetic ones. Instead of marshaling an entire special-effects department to help Jennifer (Lisa Pelikan) trash her hometown, the film merely shows her summoning up "the vengeance of the viper." After that, giant snakes appear. They bite all the right people.B-movie knock-offs ordinarily tend toward campiness, but "Carrie" is a hard act to follow in that department, So "Jennifer" is every bit as sane and solemn as "Carrie" was outlandish. The class consciousness "Carrie" hinted at is more pronounced here: Jennifer's vicious archenemy (Amy Johnston) is the daughter of a senator played by John Gavin, with her own Mercedes for joy riding and assorted B's, G's and YSL's placed prominently on her clothing. Lest anyone miss the point, she also knows Warren Beatty, has dated John Travolta and smokes her cigarettes from a holder.All things considered, "Jennifer" could be a whole lot worse. The cast, which includes Nina Foch, Jeff Corey, Florida Friebus and Bert Convy, is more reputable than the material might warrant, and while Miss Pelikan is not Sissy Spacek by a long shot, she does have a suitably spooky look in her eye."Jennifer," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains the aforementioned snakes, fleeting nudity and a rape that takes place mostly off camera.
