title: Music of Band Era Swings at Norman's
description: Norman Silver, who owns Gregory's, the minuscule jazz bar on First Avenue at 63d Street, has opened a second, much larger room called Norman's, on Second Avenue near 64th Street, where he is making an effort to travel back to the 1930's and early 40's.

title: Marriage Announcement 20 -- No Title
description: Abigail Jacob to Be Wed In August to Cary Miller

title: More Seek Divorce in France
description: PARIS (Reuters)Divorce cases France rose by a record 15 percent last year to an annual total of 93,000, the Justice Ministry says. The ministry said the figure, representing the number of divorce proceedings started, compared with a growth rate of 5 to 6 percent a year between 1970 and 1976.

title: The Rush for Vacation Homes
description: The Northeast's seashore, can expect another tidal wave of vacationers this summer.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Ballet is in the air. American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet are playing opposite each other. The Joffrey Ballet and the Eliot Feld Ballet have recently finished their own seasons. The Pennsylvania Ballet opens Tuesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. With such major American ballet companies in the spotlight, it is easy to forget that springtime is moderndance time as well. This year, things have been better, but in another sense worse, than ever. With lemminglike regularity, the New Yorkbased modern dancer has continued to schedule his or her annual allimportant season or concert at the same time as nearly everyone else.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The changing church. Last week John J. Delaney, editor, writer, retired publisher, returned home from Rosemary College in Lake Forest, Ill., with an honorary doctorate. Awards of this kind are an old story for the man who headed Doubleday's Catholic Book Department for more than 20 years. In 1955 he won the Thomas More Association Medal for the year's most distinguished contribution to Catholic publishine. and since then there's been a series of similar honors.

title: Despite the Risk of Jail, the ExLeader of Nepal Is Determined to. Return
description: Despite opposition from friends, family members and wellwishers in the United States, former Prime Minister B. P. Koirala of Nepal, who was recently released from prison in order to get medical care in New York, plans to return to his country again to face a trial that could result in life imprisonment.

title: The Open Range Closing
description: READERS unable to suppress an unfashionable yearning for a good story will be delighted with The Bad Lands. Oakley Hall's books have all been simply written, with a strong narrative pull and one or two vivid characters in each novel. In Warlock (1958) he made skillful use of both history and legend and produced one of the better novels about the

title: Koch Will Seek 20Year Extension of Control Board to Obtain Federal Loan Guarantees
description: The Koch administration is expected to propose to Albany tomorrow that the Emergency Financial Control Board be extended for 20 years as New York City presses its efforts to meet a deadline nex Saturday for resolving its financial situation.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WE are people of the streets. Our mobility is at the expense of stationary layers of highway that hide the earth. Asphalt suppresses and constricts, squeezing the earth tightly (like string wound tightly round and round a balloon).

title: Lorraine Johnsen Fiancee
description: The engagement of Lorraine Gail Johnsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Johnsen of Brooklyn, to Kurt Gerard Steinhauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin V. Steinhauer of Kew Gardens, Queens, has been announced by the future bride's parents. An autumn wedd;ng is planned.

title: Discussion Is Out, Only Experience
description: The legendary village atheist, who once symbolized the toughminded tradition of dissent from religion, is fading from American folklore as the result changing cultural patterns which have reduced public debate on such issues as the existence of God.

title: Federal Job. Program Aids Cities, But Fraud Reports Mar Success
description: CINCINNATI, May 13The Federal Government's newly expanded jobs program has begun to have a substantial impact on communities around the nation, but it is under attack because of widespread reports of fraud and because it has not brought into productive work as many of the longterm unemployed poor as intended.

title: Computer Error Said to Hurt Hunt for Welfare Fraud
description: A Brooklyn Assemblyman has charged that tremendous confusion and errors in computer checks by the City Human Resources Administration and the Federal Social Security Administration have  madri ths two detection systems an uttet failure at present for catching welfare fraud.

title: Births
description: Krantz

title: The Beach: Owning vs. Renting
description: IN the afternoon mail was a card from the Beckers, who were in Spain; they had chosen the Costa del Sol, not the Jersey Shore. The and me earlier that we would not see them this summer. They were going to the Galapagos Islands.

title: The Housing Squeeze: Oyster Bay's Answers
description: She's one of the lucky ones, said Jesse H. Harmon, chairman of the town's Housing Authority, noting that there was a waiting list of more than 2,000 applicants for all eight projects, with an average waiting time of five years.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was erroneously reported in an article about reading problems that appeared in The Times Spring Survey of Education on April 30 that Thomas He Stokes, a Staten Island politician, had a reading disability. The severe reading difficulties attributed to Mr. Stokes in the article occurred during his childhood and have been largely overt. come. A recent test taken by Mr: Stokes at the Education Institute for Learning and Research showed him to read in the 99th percentile, at a masters degree level.

title: DEFENSE INCREASES URGED BY JAPANESE
description: TOKYO, May 13A major defense de bate has begun in Japan, inspired in part by President Carter's plans for Withdrawing American combat units from South Korea, but more fundamentally by a drastic reduction in United States forces In the Far East and a rapid Soviet military buildup in the region.

title: A Black Photojournalist Depicts Apartheid Life
description: When Peter Magubane finished describing his oftenharrowing experiences as a photojournalist in South Africa, in a recent lecture at the International Center of Photography, the first query in the question-and-answer period was: How did you keep your sanity?

title: THE MARKETS
description: Stock prices surged higher late last week - amid tidings that, in years past, would have been bad news for Wall Street. On Thursday, for example, the Federal Reserve raised its discount rate to 7 percent, from 61/2 percent, but the Dow Jones industrials barreled ahead a dozen points.

title: LONG ISLAND JOUR1VAL
description: IT WAS a grand day for the State University Center, with the news that a new dental school had been approved, and photographers took many pictures of the Governor of New York conveying the good news to the president of the Stony Brook campus and the Brookhaven Town Supervisor.

title: TV VIEW
description: The BBC's production of Our Mutual Friend, which reaches the fifth of seven episodes on public television tonight at 9 (Channel 13 in New York), almost begs for an accompanying cantata of nagging qualifications. Like the Charles Dickens novel, the dramatization by Julia Jones and Donald Churchill is not quite all of a cohesive piece. Yet, the over- an effort, produced by Martin Lisemore and directed Peter Hammond, is imaginative and adventurous enough warrant attention and, not infrequently, applause.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Many New Jerseyans are frightened by reports that the state, while it ranks very low in its per capita contribution to education and the arts, is among the leaders in cancer deaths.

title: REQUIEM FOR MORO CELEBRATED BYPOPE; TOP LEADERS ATTEND
description: ROME, May 13Pope Paul VI, President Giovanni Leone, the entire Italian Cabinet, the diplomatic corps and special envoys from many countries attended solemn state memorial service today for Aldo Moro, the former Prime Minister slain by the Red Brigades:

title: Use of Computer Terminals by Pupils in Freeport Helps to Improve Math and Reading Levels Markedly
description: FREEPORT, L.I.The poster outside the activities room at the Archer School acclaimed a couple of celebrities. It read: Congratulations/ Computer WizardsCathy EsopaOlentha Von ReddenVni Ova TOPPRO OUT in Math at 8.0. What It meant was that the two had ivastered the mathematics curriculum at a level considered standard for the eighth grade, and were working to finish ninthgrade math. Olentha volunteered that he needed nine more points to top out of junior highnine more 1011's on tests. Cathy said she needed 10 more.

title: V.A. Chief Asks for Entrances Designed for the Handicapped
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)The Veterans Administration Administrator, Max Cleland, who is a triple amputee, appealed today for more buildings to provide entrances designed for handicapped oeoole.

title: City Ballet Salutes One of Its OwnJerome Robbins
description: Twentyfive years ago todayon May 14, 1953the New. York City Ballet gave the first performance of a little work for two dancers. No one, not even its choreographer, expected it to stay in the repertory for more than a season or two. Instead, Jerome Robbins's Afternoon of Faun has survived to become perhaps the most famous miniature in contemporary ballet.

title: Mindy Ann Lipson, Paul Stephen Aisen Set December Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lipson of St. Paul have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mindy Ann Lipson. to Paul Stephen Aisen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Aisen of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for December.

title: Welsh Poachers Using Crossbows
description: GWENT, Wales (AP)Sheep poachers in Wales are using a modern version of the ancient crossbow, the local farmers union reports. The modern crossbow extremely accurate at long range and many are fitted with .telescopic sights, said Brian Edwards, the union's secretary. The union warns crossbows licensed.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: In your Union Carbide article [April 23], Mr. Axtmann and Mr. Schulz have either been seriously misinformed or are under grave illusions about the price Of housing available to their employees in the Danbury region, especially their clerical employees, which they seem so concerned about. Their offer to minority employees of appropriate legal services in cases of discrimination is unrealisaic. In my 15 years of assuring equal opportunities to minorities in home ownership or apartment rentals, I've encountered out of thousands only four families willing to go all the way to court and seven willing to file a complaint for what they were entitled to by right.

title: How to Make pro Basketball Exicting And Hair Raising
description: Today's professional basketball players are bionic, but the game has become a bore.

title: Encounter: We Were Sisters, Helping Each Other Fold the Wash
description: The people of Pau, a historyrich city in southern France, take modern technology in their stride. Not so the beautiful young foreigner who stopped short at the entrance of the shop to peer in at the oneeyed machines. I looked up, saw the panic in her dark eyes, and smiled en couragement. I'm frightened by strange laundries myself.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: When Senators Jacob K. JavIts and Harrison A. Williams, authors of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, or ERISA, introduced a new bill recently to amend the act, the cries of pain and anguish were almost as great from some quarters as they had been when the law was first passed.

title: Way Clear for the Yacht Sequoia To Be Used in Tourist Business
description: NORTH MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., May 13A decision last week by the House Interior Committee to keep the Government from buying the former Presidential yacht Sequoia has cleared the way for the vessel's owners to proceed with their plans to open the yacht as a tourist attraction next month.

title: Kostelanetz Leads Philharmonic
description: Andre Kostelanetz's second promenade concert with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall Friday nightto be repeated Tuesday nighthardly posed any radical challenges to one's musical imagination. But as an unpretentious pops program it had its charms.

title: Habitat Is Critical For Whooping Cranes
description: WHEATLAND, Wyo., May 13 (AP)The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has decided to protect the Big Bend area of the Platte River in central Nebraska by designating it a habitat critical to the survival of the endangered whoonine crane.

title: Man of Many Jobs
description: 0 N Seventh Avenue they call it the schmooze, the lunchtime gabfest in Yiddish, Spanish, Italian and even English that gives the lonely crowd of garment cutters, pressers, sewingmachine operators and cart pushers the courage to go on toiling in New York's feverish rag jungle day after wearying

title: Crime A Code for Winning Votes
description: ALBANYThe State Assembly's raucous consideration of Governor Carey's tough new anticrime package last week was filled with the usual partisan recriminations, but they led to one unusual result: The bill passed with not a single dissent from either side the aisle.

title: Elderly, Along With the Poor and Young Couples, Are Caught in Housing Squeeze on Long Island

Her bluegray eyes swept across the daffodils and ;dowering crab anle tree* along a stream at the Beech Brook Residence for the Elderly, one of eight such projects in the Town of Oyster Bay. The federally subsidized projects are serving .several hundred of the town's more than 40,000 elderly residents.

title: Alcoholic Pitcher's Last Game (And Almost Last Day of Life)
description: My name is Rinold George Duren Jr. Everybody called me Ryne. I was a relief pitcher for the New York Yankees in the late 1950's and early 1960s, and then went on to play for a clutch of other teams through the middle 1960's.

title: FISHING
description: THE bill of fare for New Jersey anglers is varied this week, as winter flounder are leaving the bays and rivers for deep water and the cast of summer fish is arrivine.

title: Union Seminary Names Dean
description: Dr. Milton McCormick Gatch Jr., head of the English department at the University of Missouri, will become academic dean and professor of church history at Union Theological Seminary on Morning- side Heights in the fall. Dr. Gatch, an Episcopal priest, will replace Dean Robert T. Handy, who will return to teaching church history fulltime, Dr. Gatch, who is 45 years old, will begin his new duties Sept. 1.

title: FISHING
description: THE bill of fare is varied for Long Island anglers, although swarms of mackerel still dominate the action this week in the Atlantic Ocean and the Sound. Weakfish, which commercial fishermen have been netting by the boxful along the South Shore, should begin to take a hook and line now after spawnina. The feast of flounders along the North Shore beaches continues .unabated, while cod and pollack are the best bets off Montauk.

description: WASHINGTON, May 13The biggest thing in Washington these days, or at least the tallest, is Washington's professional basketball team which has just won the Eastern championship of the National Basketball Association.

description: philip Johnson is riding up Madison Avenue in a taxi. and his gaze is focused steadily out the window. Look at that, the way that arch is done, he says. pointing to the stone entranceway of building in the mid60's. What a fantastic play of shadow.

description: THE CHESS PLAYERS'=Sanjeev Kumar and Saeed Jaffrey play fatuous nobles in Satyajit Ray's film set in Lucknow, India, in the 1850's. It opens Wednesday at the Little Carnegie.

title: Sadat Remains Loyal Son of a Nile Village
description: MIT ABUL KOM, Egypt, May 10At first serenity ruled the drowsy spring day. A woman swathed in peasant black effortlessly balanced a slender water jug on her head as she guided a docile gray water buffalo along the worn path of the muddy canal. Down the asphalt road past the banana trees, other women squatted on the canal bank, massaging their laundry in shiny metal washtubs. A man went by on a donkey, leading several camels that had all but disappeared under enormous loads of fragrant alfalfa.

title: Champions Plan Catamaran Races
description: They seem straight out of Star Wars. But it's no illusion. Combine exotic materials, such as a new carbon fiber and a new type of foam, and shape them into something that resembles a cross between a jet plane and the Kon Tiki and you have a CClass catamaran, the swiftest shin under sail.

title: John Alderman Fiance Of Nancy Carol Sisitzky
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Sisitzky of Windsor, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Carol Sisitzky,, to John Wyatt Alderman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Alderman of New Providence, N.J. The wedding is planned for September.

title: Dream and Nightmare
description: IN a preface to his latest novel, Romain Gary disarmingly confesses to failure. But then, he adds, I have always preferred to fail rather than not to attempt. I have even come to think that civilizations are something failures are slowly Building in their wake.

Fire ants have been known to kill squirrels, pigs, chickens, calves and even humans who happen to be allergic to their sting.

title: The Railroad Renaissance Runs Out of Steam
description: The blossoming of the environmental and energy conser vation movements in the early 1970's brought visions of a renaissance to the United States railroad industry. Company executives, Government officials and train buffs talked excitedly about restoring the romantic era of the rails  an energyefficient, nonpolluting method of handling most intercity passenger and freight traffic.

title: YONKERS PROJECTING $12.8 MILLION DEFICIT
description: YONKERS, May 13When this city's Manager presents his proposed 197879 budget Monday, it is expected to call for a 13 percent increase in property taxes and layoffs of 300 to 600 city employees and still project a $12.8 million deficit.

But when Eugene Kinkead poses it near the end of a long discursion on this maligned and misnamed bird, we are glad asked it. By that time we have happily learned more about passer domesticus than we ever thought we would want to know.

description: MILWAUKEE, May 13 (AP)Thirty crewmen were evacuated by Coast Guird helicopter from the British cargo ship Photinia today after the 450foot vessel ran aground in shallow Lake Michigan water off the shore of Milwaukee.

title: ART
description: THE Holocaust, the systematic extermination by Nazi Germany of six million European Jews before and during World War II. was an unspeakable horror. But much of the art done by Jews in concentration camps did not record the torment, torture and death they faced, but reflects a serenity, a vitality and a sense of hope.

title: Ethiopian Leader Warns Somalia About Ogaden For the Last Time
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, Ethiopia's head of state, has warned Somalia for the last time that Ethiopia might push the fighting between the two countries beyond its frontiers if what he called Somali provocations continued in Ethiopia's Ogaden reeion.

title: 150 Chinese Leave Vietnam
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, May 13 (API-Morethan 150 ethnic Chinese who have been allowed to leave Vietnam flew from Saigon to Taiwan today aboard a chartered airliner. airline officials in Bangkok said. The officials said the passenqers all carried Taiwan passnorts or had links with the Government on Taiwan, which agreed to accent them.

title: Carter Sharply Attacks Cuba, Saying Use of Troops Hurts Peace Moves
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  President Carter, in one of his sharpest attacks on Cuba, said in an interview released today that President Fidel Castro was under Soviet domination, was sending troops into the Middle East as well as Africa and was trying to prevent peaceful settlement of international disputes.

description: TOKYO, May 13 (Reuters)President Kim 11 Sung of North Korea said today that the Japanese radical leftists who hijacked a Japan Air Lines jetliner to North Korea eight years ago had been reedu cated, Kyodo News Agency reported today

description: HONG KONG, May 13In the sharpest departure yet from the egalitarian policies of Mao Tsetung, China has begun to institute a new program of dividing school children into classes of fast, normal and slow learners.

description: SYDNEY, Australia. May 13 (AP)A 66-year-old New Zealander missing since his yacht ran aground nearly a month ago was rescued today from a rubber raft by a freighter off eastern Australia.

title: Where It Is Shady, Fern Fronds Are Fancy
description: hose who have problem spots might try ferns. Places that are too damp or too shady, often suit them perfectly. Ferns are also excellent for softening severe structural lines around foundations or walls or for filling in awkwardly leggy shrubs.

title: Hudson River Study Charts The Return Of the Sturgeon
description: THE sturgeon, prized for its flesh, and its eggs, which are made into caviar, is flourishing in the Hudson. Few people know or care about the sturgeon in the Hudson because they believe the river is dangerously polluted and unable to support life, said  William Dovel, a marine biologist. But that's just not true. The Hudson has been terribly maligned and misunderstood. In reality, it is one the most productive nursery habitats for fish along the entire Atlantic Coast.

description: LONDON, May 12Britain's racist National Front has taken a thrashing in local elections. A close look at the voting results last week in numerous cities and towns shows the front in sharp decline from its position after elections last year.

title: Topics
description: Kim Dung Jo, South Korea's Ambassador to the United States during the Nixon Administration, was more than a diplomat. One of his employees has testified that he once saw the Ambassador stuffing thick wads of cash into some 24 white envelopes. A Congress- man's secretary says the Ambassador gave such an envelope, containing thousands of dollars, to her boss. The House Ethics Committee, investigating the Korean bribery scandal, describes Mr. Kim as a major figure. The committee has now explored the involvement of Tongsun Park in Korean gifts and contributions. But as to the raw meat, the cash payments (the white snow, their code name), the committee has been stymied, even sneered at. South Korea refuses to make Kim Dung Jo available for questioning in any fashion.

Voros of Buck Hill, Pa., became the bride, of Andrew Osmun Fort, son of Mr. and Mrs. Osmun Fort of Plainfield, N. J., and North Hatley. Quebec. The ceremony was performed by the Rev Ralnh Moore.

The fanfare of local festivals has vanished; the traffic jam on Pasadena Avenue, carrying tourists to the beach, has eased. As surely as the robins, most tourists have flown north, hoping that the climate there is more agreeable than when they left. Late spring in this Florida city is time of quiet. It will stay that way until July, when the second season brings families back. Until then, local residents and visitors can relax.

title: Stage: Ageless

That figures: The two main characters_ the mercurial and funloving Sally Bowles and the earnest, introspective writer Chris, are sharply and convincingly drawn.

title: Film: 'The Teacher,' From Cuba:The Program
description: Six years and two months late, the first New York festival of Cuban Films starts tonight at the Beacon Theater, with the local premiere of "The Teacher," an example of the kind of determinedly upbeat movie making that is as common in a revolutionary society today as it once was in pre-World War II Hollywood.During the festival, which begins continuous performances at the Beacon on Tuesday, eight new Cuban films, including "The Teacher," will be shown three times each before the event ends next Sunday.Tricontinental Film Center is the sponsor of the event, as it was in March 1972 when attempts to hold a Cuban film festival in this country were aborted by agents of the United States Treasury Department, who seized the prints of the films for possible violation of the Trading With the Enemy Act. Two films that had been scheduled to be shown in that festival"Memories of Underdevelopment" and "Lucia"were successfully released in this country later."The Teacher," made last year, is the first narrative feature by Octavio Cortazar. 'It's set in early 1961 and isabout the adventures of a 15-year-old Havana boy, Mario, who goes as a student-teacher into the remote Zapata swamps as a member of President Fidel Castro's Conrado Benitez Brigade, whose mission was to eliminate illiteracy. In the course of his mission, Mario not only teaches the peasants to read but also learns to overcome his own various fears (of spiders, rats, death), participates in the successful repulsion of the Bay of Pigs invaders and learns how to chop down trees, make charcoal, shoot wild boars and catch alligators.Part political parable, part discreet love story, part melodrama, part nature movie, "The Teacher" has something for everyone in its home market. For us, it makes Cuba look like a gigantic camp. No scene passes without someone's heartily clapping someone else on the back. It is nicely acted and set but is much less interesting as cinema than as a interim report on what the Cuban Government and Cuban film makers think they can contribute to the revolution's success.For a glimpse of much more provocative kind of Cuban film making today, one should see "The Last Supper," now at the 68th Street Playhouse. It's the work of Tomas Gutierrez Alea, whose "Memories of Underdevelopment" is one of the best films to come from any country in the last 10 years.

title: Beyond Terrorism
description: One hardly need be Italian for the ordeal of Aldo Moro to leave a lasting impression on the heart; nor be paranoid to wonder about its impression on the mindabout terror spreading to other free societies. To Americans, that is, in a sense, an ingenuous concern. We forget how checkered our own history is with terrorismthe Molly Maguires, Haymarket, Ku Klux Klan, let alone such recent manifestations as the Weather Underground, the Symbionese Liberation Army and the F.A.L.N. Puerto Rico. That we have experienced and survived terror in our past offers no consolation to anyone, but history does offer a lesson: We need to guard against terror; but we need to guard, with equal diligence, against overreacting to it.

Noticing the draft, and the demand for seats, its five performers have now tapped, slithered and swivelhipped their way from the East 70's to the West 40's (they really must have danced down the 30 blocks because those proud storklike kneelifts and the rippling fingers that keep them giddy company obviously didn't begin 8 o'clock on the night I saw the show but had been going nonstop since the dawn of time). title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: WE took it for granted as schoolchildren memorizing Tennyson: Come my friends/ Tis not too late to seek a newer world./ Push off, and sitting well in order smite/ The sounding furrows  From Ulysses to Captain Ahab and the protagonist of Joseph Heller's Something Happened, many of our favorite literary heroes suffer midlife a spiritual crisis that can assail humans blessed with all material trappings. They leave prosperous homes and loving families in search of some mysterious deeper fulfillment. And this archetypal leavetaking has been labeled by reams of critical literature as a search for transcendence, a quest for deepened identity and even a search for secular salvation.

title: A Race To Death
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.This year physicists are commemorating the discovery of fission 40 years agothe splitting of the atomic nucleus. Nuclear reactions are extraterrestrial processes; they occur in the sun and In the stars but very rarely on earth. The fission chainreaction that brought nuclear energy within human reach is the first major technical application of a cosmic process. It is 20 million times inore powerful than ordinary chemical reactions. The arm of technology grew by a factor of many millions with the lifetime of one generation. No wonder that even the nonmilitary applications are considered by many with some misgivings.

title: 'Nunzio' Film Portrays Man Who's a Child:The Cast
description: Like "Rocky," "Nunzio" is a movie that tells you what to feel and then twists your arm anyway, just to make sure you're still paying attention. The resemblance ends there, since "Rocky" was miraculously able to pull off a ploy that, in "Nunzio," is merely ex-asperating. It's not for nothing that the ads for the film show its title apparently scrawled in crayon; this is a blunt manipulative movie full of strong-arm tactics, with a central point that is made, then reiterated, and then endlessly underscored. There aren't any fine points to "Nunzio," nor are there any true background details. If the director, Paul Williams, wants something to be noticed, he simply shoots it in close-up.The title character is a 31-year-old man with the mindand the innocence, and the goodness of heart and so onof a child. As played by David Proval, the excellent actor who appeared as the bartender in "Mean Streets," Nunzio is part Rocky, part Superman and part David Berkowitz, a wide-eyed, unnervingly uncommunicative eccentric. On those few occasions when the film allows the character to mesh with his surroundings or behave comfortably, Mr. Proval brings an eerie accuracy to the character's lumbering movements, his strange habit of repeating phrases over and over, his fierce concentration on tasks that would strike anyone else as easy, and his childish eye for unusual details.However, neither Nunzio nor the audience is ever allowed much room to breath. When the character is alone, he is almost always seen doing something attention-getting, like dressing up in a cape and sweat-shirt with a great big "N" across the chest. When he is with the others, Mr. Williams never focuses the scene sharply enough to suggest either how Nunzio accommodates himself to others or how his friends and family feel when they aren't humoring him.None of the film's supporting characters seem to have lives that extend beyond the confines of the screenplay. The gang of Brooklyn toughs who pick on Nunzio are occasionally seen talking among themselves, but their conversation invariably looks and sounds as if it is being conducted for the camera's benefit. It becomes impossible to believe that soft-spoken, ineffectual Nunzio figures as influentially in the lives of half the population of Brooklyn as the screenplay insists he does.James Andronica, who wrote the script and appears in the large role of Nunzio's brother, overwrites in the same way that he overacts. Mr. Andronica, a muscular actor who combines a toughness strongly reminiscent of Harvey Keitel's with extreme effusiveness, alternates fits of weeping or hugging with elaborate shows of forcefulness. Either way, the hey-ma-look-at-me aspects of his performance are distracting and, even worse, commonplace.Some of the other players, particularly Mr. Proval, work hard to elevate "Nunzio" from the ranks of run-of-the-mill Italian family melodramas. But Mr. Andronica's mannerisms are so stereo-typically attached to that genre, and his script is so much a case of a situation's masquerading as an actual story, that they overwhelm the film's few half-hearted bids for originality."Nunzio" is either for audiences who've never seen an Italian family on screen before, or for viewers who need to be convinced that the retarded are somtimes capable of doing wonderful things, and that they therefore ought to be treated with respect."Nunzio" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") because of a sex scene that has been trimmed, presumably to avoid an R ratine. As a result, the scene no longer makes sense.

First elected in 1944, Mr. Delaney dropped out for term, then ran successfully again in 1945 and every two years since, piling up bigger and bigger majorities; last time, spare themselves the embarassment of losing, the Republicans and Conservatives endorsed him. Often described as a right-ofcenter Democrat, Mr. Delaney recently drifted leftwards, winning an SO percent rating in a 1977 tabulation by Americans for Democratic Action, But the Ninth District is a fortress of Delaneyism, not liberalism, and sends a number of Republicans Albany; the election of Mr. Delaney's successor is therefore considered up for grabs to all parties.

There are also panel cartoons mocking the pieties, hypocrisies and power abuses of our times. The satire is caustic, antiauthority and thoughtprovoking; it is also, miraculously, verbally and graphically funny.

title: A Welcome Boost for Chamber Music

One plot began about two years ago, when people in the chambermusic field began thinking about a national organization to promote their art. By last September, Chamber Music America was incorporated, and it was able to hold its first annual meeting here in December. It hired an executive director, Benjamin S. Dunham, and established an office at 1372 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10018, block away from the site of the old Metropolitan Opera House.

title: CARTER'S FARM
description: The motel's cramped meeting room was overflowing with Montana farmers and ranchers. Most of them had driven through a January blizzard to reach Great Falls and let Vice President Walter F. Mondale know just how unhappy they were over what the Carter Administration was doingor not doing  to help them. Mr. Mondale had prepared himself to meet them about as well as a nonfarmer could. But he had brought some additional insurance with him  he had brought along Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland to bail him out if he got into trouble. He very quickly did. A grizzled farmer arose and declared he had just read that President Carter said he wasn't going to help the farmers until they got their act together and agreed on what they wanted. description: The difficult, continuing negotiations over New York City's muchcriticized 1969 direct leases of daycare centers have so far reduced rents and resulted in repairs in eight centers, with four more pending. The benefits to the city are estimated at 51.25 million.

title: On the Mountains Surpassing Dreams
description: Nearly 50 years ago I came across book by the Swedish explorer Sven Hedin'From Pole to Pole'and for the first time read about the forbidden land Tibet, the Himalayas and a country called Nepal. Ever since I have harbored a passion for that part of the world, and have often traveled in spirit up and down those mountains. Finally, at the the age of 63, I decided I had to see them before I died.

title: Rain and Foil Bring Good News to Mets
description: The New York Mets and their walking wounded won a reprieve yesterday when the heavy rain swept away their doubleheader against the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium. They also won a bonus, perhaps a small medical miracle, when Tim Foli reported that his torn left knee had healed and that he would return as the fulltime shortstop next week instead of next year.

title: Doctors, With Fees Rising, Say Costs Cut Into Incomes
description: We never talked about it in medical school. But I used to think that someone who made $100,000 a year would be on easy street, with a dream house on top of the hill, recalled the young doctor.

title: William Powell Lear, 75, Is Dead; Pioneered Small Jet and Autopilot; The SteamPowered Auto; Blueprint for My Future; An Eclectic Career; 'Retire? What For?; William P. Lear
description: William Powell Lear, the industrialist who pioneered the small corporate jet plane and who invented, among other things, the car radio, the automatic pilot for aircraft and the eighttrack stereo cartridge, died yesterday of leukemia in Reno. He was 75 years old.

title: Alice Geller is Married to Scott Levine
description: Alice Geller, an associate of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates law firm, was married yesterday morning to Scott Levine, a lawyer with Davis Polk & Wardwell.

title: Mueller, 42, Victor in Marathon
description: YONKERS, May 14Four years after collapsing in his first race, at the age of 38, Fritz Mueller captured one of America's toughest distance races today by winning the Yonkers Marathon in a driving, cold rain.

title: Market Place; Stock Discord at Bun ? Burner
description: Dissident shareholders of Bun & Burger International Inc., operator of a chain of fastfood shops, hope to frustrate a management plan to take the company private. Their strategy is to sell shares to their children and grandchildren and thus keep the number of shareholders above 300the level that makes a company subject to filing requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Israeli Officer's Remarks Debated
description: JERUSALEM, May 14The Israeli Cabinet today discussed charges that the new Chief of Staff had meddled in political matters and then, in what appeared to be an attempt to end the controversy, voted to cut off its debate. The vote was 14 to 3.

title: Sadat Schedules Quick Referendum To Quell Criticism
description: CAIRO, May 14President Anwar clSadat, stung by growing criticism of his domestic policies, called tonight for a national referendum next week that would give him a vote of confidence and have the effect of purging his most troublesome critics from political life.

title: Hungary Looks Beyond Soviet for Its Oil
description: SZAZHALMOMBATTA, Hungary Twice in the last 15 years, oil changed the face of this Danube River town. But now, as in much of Eastern Europe, the boom fueled by increasingly scarce Soviet oil is ending, and Hungary is having to look longer and harder at just where its future growth is going to originate.

title: Water Resources Conference
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., May 14 (UPI)Tho Water Resources Association of the Delaware River BaSin began its 19th spring conference today, this year devoting the threeday forum to water crises and conservation. The association, a citizens watchdog group, representing resments of New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Delaware, is continuing its emphasis on the need for wise management of water and related land resources.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Curare Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N. J.The seven womenyoung, middleaged and older bore a suggestion of family resemblance, perhaps because they all had blonde or blondestreaked hair. They sat in the same row at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, former chief surgeon at Riverdell Hospital, who is accused of killing five persons by giving them lethal doses of the drug curare.

title: U.S: Bows in Tennis
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, May 14 (AP)Spain's team of Manuel Orantes and Jose Higueras defeated the United States, 21, toJav and advanced to the final of the first S250,000 Nation's Cup tennis tournament.

title: A Symbol of Change
description: OXFORD, Miss., May 14Senator James O. Eastland, for more than three decades the symbol of racial resistance in this once intransigent state, warmly welcomed Senator Edward M. Kennedy today, praising the New Englander as member of a distinguished American family and one of the outstanding young leaders of our country.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, May 14 (Reuters)The Chinese Communist Party says that war with the Soviet Union is inevitable and as called on its army to intensify training in modern warfare, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, said today.

title: Kelley Doubts a Terrorist Outbreak
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 14 (UPI)The former Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Clarence Kelley. said he doubts that recent outbreaks of terrorist activities will spill over into the United States. This is not good hunting ground for terrorists, Mr. Kelley said at a workshop on terrorism yesterday at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. The strength and sophistication of the bureau and local law enforcement agencies will continue to deter it, he said.

title: Zaire Reports an Attack in South By CommunistBacked Katangans; Mobutu Asks for Aid, Asserts 4,000 Rebels Came From Angola; Kolwezi Called Target; Says Cubans Take Part; France Aided Zaire; Morocco Studying Request; France Receives Appeal; PARIS, May 14 (AgenceFrance Presse); Mobutu Foe Denies Role
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 14Zaire said today that its southern province of Shaba, formerly known as Katanga, was being attacked by Communistbacked Katangan rebels from Angola who had entered the country through Zambia.

title: The Federal BlueCollar Bonanza
description: President Carter's resolve to start the antiinflation fight within Government is bad news for most Federal employees, who will receive smaller raises next year. But for the 450,000 Federal workers whose collars are blue, tough talk from the White House will have no effect. Unless Congress amends the law, they will continue to receive up to 12 percent more than private workers doing the same job, and Federal blue collar wage policies will continue to feed inflation.

title: 56TH ST. BLAST DAMAGES RUSSIANLANGUAGE PAPER
description: An explosion and fire heavily damaged linotype machines and mailing equipment yesterday at Novoye Russkoye Slovo (New Russian Word), the 68-year-old Russianlanguage daily newspaper at 243 West 56th Street.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The question of whether those who work for New York City should be compelled to live in the city has once again been raised, pitting the Koch administration and residencylaw advocates against most of the municipal employee unions and others who feel that city workers should be able to live where they choose, including the suburbs.

title: Rowing: Yale Is Victor
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 14Yale's varsity crew, the heart of which is made up of four 19-year-old sophomore oarsmen who have little regard for history, won the Eastern rowing championships here today with a certain ease foreign to recent Eli crews. The Yale eight finished the 2,000meter course under control and half a boatlength ahead of Harvard after holding the lead 90 percent of the way.

title: Television
Easing Spain Into NATO
description: For more than a generation, during Gen. Francisco Franco's dictatorship, the nations of Western Europe ostracized Spain from their councils. Yet they winked at the defense agreement between Madrid and Washington, signed in 1953, which gave the United States the use of four strategic bases and made Spain, defacto, part of the Western alliance. Now a democratic Spain is deeply engaged in negotiations to join the Common Market, and would probably be welcome in NATO if applied. But NATO is a divisive issue in Spain's newly open politics, anddesirable though Spanish membership would bethe Western governments should wary of making their blandishments too strong.

title: Jets Win, Lead W.H.A. Final, 20
description: SPRINGFIELD. Mass, May 14 (UM The Winnipeg Jets, with goals scored by five players. beat the New England Whalers. 52. tonight and took 7, 2.0 lead in the four-of-seven-gang World Hockey Association final playoff series.

title: 'Almost in Despair; AT HOME ABROAD; Is Israel willing to withdraw for peace? The answer has always been negative.
description: AMMAN, May 14The consequence of Israel's refusal to give up occupied territory in return for peace are nowhere plainer, or sadder, than in Jordan. Many people here, Jordan- lans and Palestinians, watched on Israeli television when President Sadat went to Jerusalem. Some say they wept with joy in anticipation of peace. Now there is a bitter feeling of hope abandoned.

title: Linley Pennebaker Wed To Kevin E. Callahan
description: Linley Elizabeth Pennehaker, daughter of Sylvia Bell Pennebaker of New York and Sag Harbor, L. I., and D. A. Pennehaker, was married yesterday afternoon to Kevin Edward Callahan. He is the son of Lavina M. Callahan of Brooklyn and the late John P. Callahan.

title: U.N. PEACEKEEPERS RESUME PATROLS IN LEBANON TOWN
description: TYRE, Lebanon, May 14 (UPI)United Nations peacekeeping forces resumed patrols today in this southwestern port town, while the Palestine Liberation Organization said it objected to such move. The patrols were halted 12 days ago after a battle in which guerrillas killed three United Nations soldiers.

title: Schumer Says Corps of Engineers Shortchanges New York City
description: Assemblyman Charles E. Schumer charged yesterday that the Army Corps of Engineers discriminates against New York City.

title: Miami Bar Mitzvah Has Love and Family and Joy and Cheerleaders
description: MIAMI. May 14  Nearly 60 years ago, Robert Cohen's bar mitzvah party was held in a noisy and crowded tenement flat on Manhattan's Lower East Side.

title: The Day Slew Came Back
description: SEATTLE Slew's day started at 4 a.m., before anyone could guess what the weather would be. It was still dark but no stars showed, and a blustery wind out of the southeast rattled the trees in Beimont's stable area while the colt munched his breakfast of dry oats.

title: France's Aid in Chad's Civil War Highlights Its Touchy Police Role
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, May 12 France's deepening involvement in a civil war in Chad has highlighted its role as a potential gendarme among former African colonies and once again raised the thorny issue of foreign intervention in Africa.

title: Yields Stabilize For Municipals
description: The taxexempt bond market tomorrow will complete the sales of more than $1.5 billion of refunding issues, and then will begin to head into a period of lighter financing activity. Consequently, some underwriters have become confident that yields will remain stable over the very near future.

title: Cosmos Tested but Defeat Caribous for 7th Straight
description: DENVER, May 14 (UPI)Vladislav Bogicevic booted two goals today and led the unbeaten Cosmos to a 43 victory over the Colorado Caribous in the North American Soccer League. Goals by Bogicevic and Franz Beckenhauer in the second half provided the winning margin.

title: H. U.D. Chief Gaining Power And Urban Leaders Respect
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Of all the mementos in the rambling Northwest Washington home of Patricia Roberts Harris, probably hone carries more sweet irony than the engraved silver picture frame awarded her last month by the United States Conference of Mayors for her responsive, effective service to the cities of America.

title: Tee, Green or Rough, a Rule for Every Occasion
description: GOLF is perhaps the most ruleridden of games. There are rules for playing a ball that comes to rest on a wooden bridge, on a patch of snow or on bubblegum wrapper. Whatever the circumstances, one can always expect a rule to govern it; one must not, however, expect always to like the ruling.

title: Union Members Rally in Illinois To Support Strike By Firefighters
description: NORMAL, Ill., May 13 (UPI)  More than 150 members of about a dozen unions staged a rally Saturday to support and give nearly $1,200 to this town's striking firefighters.

title: Kayak Expert Dies
description: GARDEN VALLEY. Idaho, May 14 (AP)A kayaking expert, Dr. Walter L. Blackadar, drowned yesterday in kayak accident in the Payette River near here. The victim was the subject of a national magazine article several years ago detailing his kayaking experiences in an Alaskan river.

title: WORLD CHURCH GROUP IRKS GREEK ORTHODOX
description: ATHENS, May 14The leaders of the Orthodox Church of Greece are considering suspending their membership in the World Council of Churches because, they say, it is being run by a Protestant elite that has reduced Orthodox membership to secondclasc status.

description: The Metropolitan Golf Association tests its tournament officials every spring by presenting them with situations or problems that can occur during a game. title: Breakaway Episcopalians Meet To Set Up New England Group
description: SALEM, Mass., May 14 (AP)Conservative Episcopalians upset by the ordination of women and homosexuals as priests have begun laying the groundwork in New England for a formal breakaway.

description: It rained on the tubas and the drums, the floats and the jeeps, the Boy Scouts and the honorary hostesses, the Governor and the Mayor, the police and the passersby. In sum, it rained on their parade.

description: ANDREW BOLOTOWSKY came up with an imaginative idea for his flute recital in Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon. All the music was contemporary and each piece involved a varied assortment of instrumental and accompanimental groupings.

description: LUTHERVILLE, Md., May 14 (AP)Nancy Lopez held off a hid by Donna Caponi Young and won the $65,000 Greater Baltimore golf classic by three strokes today.

description: DETROIT, May 14Car thieves and people who lose their keys may soon find it harder to get inside or under the hood of a locked car or to start it without using the ignition.

description: Early in January, Dr. Blanche Bernstein, the newly appointed Human Resources Administrator, received a letter from James Sams, president of the Chama Society, an organization of black workers at her agency.

title: Make Way for a Black AutoRacing Star
description: IN. the white world of auto racing, it has long been dream of proMoters to attract black customers. The best way, probably the only way, is to discover a black racing driver. Doing so has not been easy. Few blacks can get started in racing because far fewer blacks than whites can afford what'usually starts out as a very expensive hobby.

description: John Schumacher, the former Bonwit Teller chairman who recently became the head of M. Ferrari Diffusione, Inc., New York, has resigned from that job to return to retailing.

title: EXC.I.A. CHIEF ANSWERS CRITICISM OF ANGOLA ROLE
description: William Colby, former Director of Central Intelligence Agency maintained in television interview yesterday that allegations made by a former C.I.A. official about the agency's operations in the 197576 Angola civil war were not necessarily false but based on different characterizations of the events.

description: IN THE few moments when the voices of Studs Terkel's working Americans rise from perceptive selfdescription to dramatic selfrevelation, the musical Working comes excitingly alive.

title: MAJOR BLACK FACTION DECIDES NOT TO QUIT RHODESIAN COALITION
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 14The followers of Bishop Abel Muzorewa today decided to remain in the ruling coalition rather than withdraw over the controversial dismissal of a minister belonging to their group.

title: Patching Up Amtrak
description: Amtrak is drowning in red ink. The huge passenger rail system dumped on Washington by the private railroads spends almost three dollars for every dollar earns. As Congress searches for politically acceptable ways to trim its $600 million annual operating deficit, the Transportation Department's very modest proposals for route reforms deserve a sympathetic hearing.

title: TV: Buyline With Betty Furness
description: IN THE BEGNNING, in those television days or gracious, elegantly turnedout women swirling about in the Loretta Young manner, Betty Furness, joined the celebrity game by opening refrigerator doors in commercials. In more recent years, she has crossed to the other side of the consumer line, going from sales pitches to warnings about defective products or questionable practices. On WNBC's NewsCenter 4, she has established herself as one of a handful of firstrate watchdogs In television consumerism (WCBS's John Stossel is another).

title: Claude Bel!anger of Paris; Publisher Was Prominent In Resistance During War
description: PARIS, May 14Claude Bellanger, prominent French newspaper publisher, ice president of Agence FrancePresse, the news agency, and the longtime president of the International Federation of Newspaper Publishers, died yesterday at his home here after a short illness, was announced today. Mr. BeBanger, who published Le Parisien Libere, a popular daily, was 68 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: The dates and movie theater that will he showing a program of Yugoslav films this week were incorrectly listed Friday in the Weekend section. The films will he shown today through Wednesday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, 887 Seventh Avenue,

title: Indian Dances Help Explain Myths of East to Students
description: Until about three months ago, Barbara Mateer, Deborah Lessen and Claude Assante had never seen a performance of Bharata Natvam, the Indian classical dance, nor did they know what a telana was or what the mythologies of Lord Krishna were. Now they can tell you that a telana is a dance number, that the legends of Krishna, a Hindu god, are chiefly about his exploits as a great warrior and lover, and that these are often the basis for Indian dances.

title: Advertising
description: The escalation of the tempest in the chicken pot continues today as Showell (Md.) Farms, processors of Cookin Good broilers, adds television to its advertising arsenal.

title: Country Music: Ernest Tubb In Rare Visit
description: THE stylistic polarities of presentday commercial country music are between Tennessee and Texas, Nashville and the Austin outlaws. But an earlier country singer, Ernest Tubb, spanned those polarities all by himself. Born in Texas in 1914 and always a self-confessed lootator or Jimmie Rodgers, Mr. Tubb has been a member of Nashville's Grand Old Opry since 1943. Although his country hits don't come quite as frequently and inevitably as they used to in the 1940's, 50's and 60's, he still tours regularly and counts as one of the honored veterans of the genre.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Any boat owner would be grateful for an automatic way to seal the drain hole, keeping unwanted water out and allowing bilge water to escape. Gator's Boat Float is designed to do just that. A rubber ball, mounted outside the transom and hanging loosely on two stainless steel chains, rides over the drain hole. If someone forgets to put the plug in, or if it falls out, the ball seals the open hole by means of suction. For $4 from the maker, J & L Tool, Box 367, Shelbyville, Ind. 46176.

title: H.E.W. Experts Due in New York To Help With HomeCare Program
description: The Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare will send computes specialists this week to try to help overcome problems in New York City's homeattendant program, which now spends $100 million a year in Medicaid funds to avoid institutionalizing disabled poor people, most of them elderly.

title: Checkout Scanners: The Critics Insist They're No Bargain
description: Supermarket price-scannerscheckout-counter computers the t are triggered by those strange parallel black lines on cans and boxes and almost everything else in the storeare prolifecating in the metropolitan area these days amid controversy over what the trend means for consumers.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MAY 15, 1978

title: Events Today
description: COSMOPOLITAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, Avery Fisher Hali, Lincoln Center, 8.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: MINNESOTA OFFICIAL SPURS RETURN OF DORMANT FUNDS
description: ST. PAUL (UPI)Jim Lord, the Minnesota Treasurer, is not charging hanky panky, but he says it is strange Northwestern Bell cannot find two of the state's biggest companies in the telephone book.

title: Route 18 Work Expected to Delay Turnpike Traffic at Interchange
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 14 (UPI)The New Jersey Turnpike Authority says that eastbound traffic on Route IS at the approach to Interchange 9 in East Brunswick may experience some travel delays this week because of deck repairs on the Route IS overpass.

title: A Designer for Just Three Years, He Has the Look of a Winner
description: In the less than two years that he's been designing the Portfolio line. Perry Ellis has gone from obscurity to the hottest contender for this year's Coty Award in women's fashion.

title: Lullaby for a Clone; (A Novelty Song for Our Age)
description: How alone

title: Come Back, Joltin Joe
description: RECENTLY Pete Rose, while giving his autograph to a kid, mentioned to the kid how much he used to covet Joe DiMaggio's autograph when he was kid. The kid looked blank.

title: A U.S. Sale of F15's in Mideast Might Spur Market for the Jets
description: If Congress allows the Carter Administration.to go ahead with its plans to sell F15 jet fighters to Saudi. Arabia and Israel, it will be the first sale of the sophisticated plane in the developing world. And defense analysts say, the precedent would almost certainly encourage other thirdworld countries to seek similar equipment.

title: East Germany Curbs Dissidents
description: EAST BERLINEast Germany's writers have been in the forefront of the humanrights battles between hardliners and intellectuals that have troubled this country for the past few years. In a harsh reaction to the recurrent conflict, the Communist Party moved recently to exclude most of the country's prominent independently minded authors from the national writers congress at the end of May, evidently to prevent the dissenters from speaking ou.

title: Adaptive Reuse of Historic Sites Stressed at Upstate Conference
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., May 14 - In Rochester, the old Federal Building has been turned into City Hall. In Oswego, an empty middle school has been converted into 31 units of housing for the elderly. In Albany, the vacant Delaware and Hudson Railroad building has been refurbished as the headquarters of the State University.

title: Around the Nation
description: NACOGDOCHES, Tex., May 14 (UP1)A Southern Pacific freight train carrying gas and chemicals derailed on a bridge today and several of the cars exploded in flames, releasing a cloud of fumes that drove residents from this east Texas city.

title: 7 Die in English School Bus Crash
description: LONDON, May 14 (Reuters)Six children and an adult were killed today when a school bus collided with a truck near Chelmsford, east of here. Eight other oungsters and the bus driver were inured. They were returning from a school unction.

title: U. S. Army in Germany Confident It Is in Fighting Form
description: FULDA, West Germany, May 10The sirens sounded at 4 A.M. over the barracks, tha sleeping city and the mist-covered green hills of Hesse. Lights appeared. A tank motor coughed, caught and then throbbed steadily. A soldier running toward the motor pool shouted, This what they mean by the dawn's early light, Sarge?

title: Sports World Specials
description: The four walls that serve as Olympic housing: Will they a prison make?

title: J: O. Tobin Prevails in Californian
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 14 (AP)J.0. Tobin, the heavy favorite, scored an easy victory, posting his sixth straight triumph at Hollywood Park. in the $214,550 Californian Stakes today. His rival from the East, Cox's Ridge. finished third.

title: Israel Says Sending U.S. Jets to Arabs Would Endanger Its Security
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The Israeli Government, on the eve of a Senate vote on the Carter Administration's package proposal to sell warplanes to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel, said today that sending the aircraft to the Arab nations would constitute a serious danger to Israel's security.

title: Budget for Handicapped Children Faces New Legislative Controls
description: TRENTON, May 13Four committees of thp New Jersey Legislature are preparing legislation to tighten controls on from $25 million to $30 million spent by the state each year to educate 5,000 seriously handicannerl children About 4.000 of these children attend 150 special private schools in the state, 25 of which are boarding schools. The remaining 1,000 have been attending 100 boarding schools in other states, but many of these children are being returned to New Jersey because of legislative pressure.

title: Yanks Lose in Ninth, 109
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 14A long, complicated game finally got away from the New York Yankees today when Amos Otis hit a double over Reggie Jackson's head with nobody out in the ninth inning to give the Kansas City Royals a 109 triumph and victory in the threegame series, two games to one in ninthinning decisions.

title: Commodities
description: As any shopper who visited a supermarket In recent days knows, the cost of prime beef is the highest ever, much more expensive than the prices that provoked consumer boycotts of red meat in the spring of 1973. Today, however, the record prices for topgrade beef cuts have not raised protest for several reasons.

title: STUDY WARNS OF SPREAD OF DISEASE ON AIRCRAFT
description: ATLANTA, May 14 (AP)The risk of a spread of Lassa fever, a rare disease that now appears confined to Africa, could he increased by the transportation of patients on commercial airline flights, the Center for Disease Control has warned.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonia
description: LUKAS FOSS and the Brooklyn Philharmonia tried to make a grand effort over the weekend, with three fullscale performances of the Verdi Requiem in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House. To judge from the performance o nSaturday evening, it wasn't a very successful seriesan honorable try, perhaps, but too flawed for real satisfaction.

title: PANEL TO CONSIDER ELECTION CHANGES
description: ALBANY, May 14A legislative committee will consider proposals this week that critics say will make it harder for candidates for public office to get on the ballot.

title: 'I Love New York
description: On a raw, wet morning the other day, halfway up the block to the candy store for the newspapers, we tried for, oh, the hundredthousandth time to come to grips with the fact of New York City. No dice it couldn't be done. And then, in the dirty rain under the awful o'clock sky, no breakfast yet, the raincoat leaking, the shoes soaked through, revelation struck us cock-a-hoop and left us feeling lightheaded.

title: Radio
description: 74 AM, WNCN. Symphony for Strings in A, Sammartini; Song of the Flea, Mussorgsky; Etude, Scriabin; Piano Sonata No. 24, Beethoven; The Enchanted Lake, Liadov; SchottischeChoro, VillaLobos; Liebesfreud, Kreisler.

title: BEGIN REJECTS SADAT BID ON OCCUPIED TERRITORIES
description: JERUSALEM, May 14 (AP)--Prime Minister Menachem Begin has rebuffed an Egyptian suggestion that Israel turn over control of the occupied West Bank to Jordan and return the Gaza Strip to Egypt as interim steps toward a Mideast peace.

title: More Villagers Flee Volcano
description: MANILA, May 14 (UPI)More refugees fled today from villages threatened by Mount Mayon, a volcano spewing ash. lava and rocks. Reporters at the scene, 200 miles southeast of Manila, said about 15,000 people had fled their homes to more than a dozen evacuation centrs. No casualties have been reported from the eruptions, which began May 3.

title: Casino Operators in Nevada Viewing Jersey Competitors With Unease
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.The shrewd, calculating businessmen and state officials who dominate Nevada's casino industry say they are worried that legalized casino gambling in Atlantic City may become infiltrated by organizedcrime figures.

title: CORRECTION
description: The dates and movie theater that will be showing a program of Yugoslav films this week were incorrectly listed Friday in the Weekend section. The films will be shown today through Wednesday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, 887 Seventh Avenue,

title: Reporter's Notebook: Curare Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N. J.The seven womenyoung, middleaged and older bore a suggestion of family resemblance, perhaps because they all had blonde or blondestreaked hair. They sat in the same row at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, former chief surgeon at Riverdell Hospital, who is accused of killing five persons by giving them lethal doses of the drug curare.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIS OWN THING Many New Yorkers heard Calvin Hampton for the first time last December, when the music director and organist of the downtown Calvary Church gave a series of free seasonal concerts at the midtown Citicorp Center. Since he also happens to be a composer of acclaim, Mr. Hampton's church performance tonight, at Park Avenue South and 21st Street, will be something altogether different.

title: QUEBEC SEEKS TRADE WITH U.S, AS A FACET OF SOVEREIGNTY AIM
description: MONTREAL, May 14Quebec is seeking to expand relations with the United States in trade and investment as an important part of its drive for political sovereignty.

title: Ballet: Lavery, Tomasson in New Roles
description: APAIR of new faces in old roles made the New York City Ballet's Saturday even ing program at the New York State Theater intriguing enough for the most jaded of balletomanes.

title: Local Congregations Challenge Policies of National Church Bodies
description: SAN DIEGO, May 14A visitor in the Presbyterian church of Van Nuys, Calif., on a Sunday in January recalled that an audible gasp arose among worshipers when the minister announced that a special report by the parent denomination had advocated the ordination of avowed, practicing homosexuals.

title: SLOW RECORDING OF DATA ON HISPANICS CRITICIZED
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)The United States Commission on Civil Rights accused the Labor Department today of inadequate efforts to meet Congress's directive that it produce more information about unemployment among SpanishAmericans and urged President Carter to order increased efforts.

title: Lisa Lystad Married To Mark Jay Warren
description: Lisa Douglass Lystad, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lystad of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark Jay Warren, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Warren of Moreland Hills, Ohio. The Rev. Chester Wickwire, chaplain of Johns Hopkins University, performed the nondenominational ceremony in the garden of the Lvstad home.

title: Turkey Arms Vote Alarms NATO
description: BRUSSELS May 14Senior officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization expressed alarm today over the possible consequences to the alliance of the vote by the Senate Foreign Relations Commit. tee to maintain the three-year-old arms embargo against Turkey.

title: Auto Racing: Rain Frustrates Andretti
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 14Mario Andretti opened the door to Garage 75 On Gasoline Alley, peered outside and cursed.

title: REPORT SEES DANGER TO SOURCES OF FOOD
description: WASHINGTON  Fisheries, forests, grasslands and croplands, the systems that support life on the planet, have come under mounting and unsustainable pressures and have become a source of increasing economic stress, a new study has found.

title: Italians Voting in Local Elections
description: ROME, May 14Nearly four million Italians, a tenth of the electorate, voted today in partial local elections that are considered to he the first test of the political impact made by the kidnapping and slaying of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro.

title: Piano: Beethoven By Nunez
description: IVAN NUNEZ'S recital in Alice Tully Hall Saturday night consist ed of two Beethoven sonatas (the Moonlight and Appassionata) and Schumann's Carnaval. No awards for adventurous programming here. These are three of the most frequently encountered standards in the entire piano literature, but they are undisputed masterpieces and it always interesting to hear some fresh thoughts on their content.

title: Saving of State Jobs Linked to U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Special antirecession assistance by the Federal Government in the last six quarters to the State of New Jersey, Essex County and the City of Newark has saved or created nearly 1,300 jobs, according to a new analysis prepared for Congress.

title: CHARLES H. WALKER
description: Charles H. Walker, a retired patent lawyer and senior partner in the Manhattan firm of Fish & Neave, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home at Old Black Point in Niantic, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: Kingman Clouts 3 Home Runs, Bats In
description: The San Andreas fault didn't crack and split Los Angeles from the rest of the country yesterday. That loud noise was a result of three home runs by Dave Kingman in the Chicago Cubs 15inning 107 victory over the Dodgers. In San Francisco, Terry Whitfield's heroics in the Giants 54, 43 doubleheader sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals and Philadelphia's 74 defeat of Cincinnati back East helped widen the gap between the firstplace Giants and the rest of the National League West.

title: PESSIMISM GROWING FOR CREDIT MARKETS AS RATE RISE LOOMS
description: The credit markets are turning decidedly pessimistic, with many moneymarket economists warning that interest rates are headed sharply higher in the near future.

title: Doctors, With Fees Rising, Say Costs Cut Into Incomes
description: We never talked about it in medical school. But I used to think that someone who made $100.000 a year would be on easy street, with a dream house on top of the hill, recalled the young doctor.

title: Letters
description: The vote of the Federal Reserve Board to authorize automatic transfats from savings accounts into checking accounts is another long step toward destroying the usefulness of monetary policy for opposing inflation. Anybody who has a savings account (and this kind of account is no longer limited to individuals but begins to be generally available for business firms) will find it best to deposit every paycheck or other item of receipts in his savings account, not bothering to replenish his checking account. Whenever a check is drawn, absence of funds to cover it in the checking account will be made good by automatic transfer. This system is fully equivalent (except for some bookkeeping fuss at the bank) to merging the customer's checking and savings accounts and letting the merged account both yield interest and serve

title: Supplementary Over-the-Counter Listings
description: Week Ended, May 12, 1978

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Article 2 -- No Title

title: `Runaways Moves Up to Broadway
description: RUNAWAYS, written, composed and directed by Elizabeth Swados. Settings by Douglas W. Schmidt and Woods Mackintosh; costumes by Hilary Rosenfeld; sound by Bill Dreisbach; lighting be Jennifer Tinton; production stage manager, Gregory Moen. Presented by Joseph Papp; Bernard Gersten. assodate producer. At the Plymouth Theater, Z36 West 45th Street.

title: Carter Back From Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)President Carter returned to Washington late this afternoon by helicopter after a rainy weekend at Camp David. He attended private religious services earlier at the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin mountains of Maryland.

title: Oxford Pendaflex Is Offering $24 For Shares of Dvmo Industries
description: The Oxford Pendaflex Development Corporation, a subsidiary of Esselte AB, a Swedish company, said In advertisements published today that it was offering to purchase any and all shares of Dymo Industries Inc. for $24. Based on the 2.6 million Dymo shares outstanding, the transaction has a value of $62.4 million.

title: A Pornographer's Saga: Wealth, Disrepute, Jail and Now Escape
description: ATLANTA, May 12Even though Andrew Young, the chief Unitrd States dolegate to the United Nations, tried to help Michael G. Thevis, this city's millionaire pornographer, Mr. Thevis could never find a Federal prison that suited him.

title: A Mini Home Hydroelectric Plant Is Marketed in France at $7,800
description: PARIS. May 14A French company has begun marketing a miniature hydroelectric power plant priced as low as 57,800 that can heat a country house indefinitely provided there is small waterfall in the garden.

title: Virginia Leonard Is Bride of James Ewing
description: Virginia Waugh Leonard and James Madison Ewing were married yesterday in the First United Presbyterian Church in Macomb, III., by the Rev. Kenneth Mortonson.

title: Chess:
description: The quicker it goes, the better Walter Browne likes it. The United States champion captured first prize in the Reykjavik International Tournament. playing under a time control of 30 moves in an hour and a half, with 20 moves an hour for adjournment sessions, the fastest ever for a oremier event.

title: Seattle Slew Wins by 8
description: On a dismal day of rain, wind and mud, Seattle Slew provided a magic moment at Aqueduct yesterday with a triumphant return to the winner's circle.

title: New York Acts To Rehabilitate Its War Zones
description: Not long ago, Julius C. C. Edelstein, the dean for urban policy and programs at the Graduate School or City University and former secretary to Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr., was asked whether he was optimistic about New York City's future. Of course I am. Dean Edelstein replied. Its strength lies in its people, and I believe in the strength and the ingenuity of the people of New York.

title: Thomas P. O'Neill 3d Again Rejects Senate Race
description: BOSTON, May 14Lieut. Gov. Thomas P. O'Neill 3d announced here today that he would not, after all, seek the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

title: If Media Were King
description: WASHINGTONMartin Tolchin, who covers the White House for The New York Times, poked his head in my office a little while ago to wonder aloud: What if the press were really running the country? Could we do any better?

title: Rise Seen in PollutionControl Cost
description: Pollution control expenditures this year by businesses are expected to climb 21 percent to a record $10.92 billion, 4 percent more than the projected gain for total capital investment. These were the findings of the 11 th annual survey of pollution control costs by McGrawHill Publications.

title: Checkout Scanners: The Critics Insist They're No Bargain
description: Supermarket price-scannerscheckout-counter computers that are triggered by those strange parallel black lines on cans and boxes and almost everything else in the storeare proliferating in the metropolitan area these days amid controversy over what the trend means for consumers.

title: Tennis: Gerulaitis Wins W.C.T. Title
description: DALLAS, May 14 (AP)Vitas Gerulaitis, who hadn't played since Wednesday night, overwhelmed Eddie Dibbs today with his deadly volleys and newlystrengthened serve and posted 63, 62; 61 victory in the World Championship Tennis final.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: I see many tag plays baseball where the ball never touches the runner, especially at home plate, where only the back or the edge of the catcher's mitt makes contact. Why do umpires permit this?

title: Rebels Said to Capture Key Zairian Mining Center
description: WASHINGTON, May 14State Department officials said tonight that it appeared that most of Kolwezi, a key town in Zaire's southern copper belt, was in rebel hands.

title: Court Conduct: Classiness Is All
description: IN a sport where love means nothing, it's not surprising that etiquette means everything. I remember being taught as a 10yearold novice never to walk behind someone else's court while the ball was in play, never to throw my racquet in disgust, never to argue over my opponent's line calls and never to serve until my opponent was ready.

title: Liberal Party Still Feeling Wrath Of Koch Over a Lack of Support
description: Although he exudes bonhomie, Mayor Koch is a man who carries political grudges, and he carries them long time. The Liberal Party is still feeling his wrath for its failure to support him in the mayorat race last year, even though he had received Liberal endorsement for Congress for years.

title: France's Aid in Chad's Civil War Highlights Its Touchy Police Role
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, May 12 France's deepening involvement in a civil war in Chad has highlighted its rolo as a potential gendarme among former African colonies and once again raised the thorny issue of foreign intervention in Africa.

title: 4 Die in Fire at Halfway House
description: ATHENS, Tex., May 14 (UPI)A fire last night at a rural halfway house for the mentally disturbed killed four persons. The fire destroyed a frame dormitory near the community of Carroll Springs. Nine residents escaped uninjured.

title: Sirica Says Watergate Scandal Was Unfortunate but Instructive
description: EMMITSBURG, Md., May 14 (UPI)Federal District Court Judge John J. Sirical said today that the Watergate scandal, like others of American history, was an unfortunate episode but one that provided a lesson.

title: Deaths
description: AMBROSEA. Rommel, age 60, of Irvington. Va. died Saturday, May 13, survived by wife Barbara Melick Ambrose, father of Arthur Tennent Ambrose of Taston, Pa. and the late Geraldine A. Williamson, two grandchildren, brother William G. Ambrose and son-In-law Robert P. Williamson. Mr Ambrose was a pension consultant for Peat, Marwick, Mitchell, Inc. of New York City from which he retired in 1973. He was graduate of Blair Academy and Rutgers University. Funeral services 11AM, Tuesday at Grace Church, Kilmarnock, Virginia. Memorial contributions to Grace Church Memorial Fund.

title: Staten Island Woman, 19, Found To Be a Victim of Strangulation
description: A 19-year-old Staten Island woman found dead Saturday in the Annadale section was strangled, according to an autopsy report issued yesterday. The victim was identified as Kathleen Foy of Copley Street in the borough's Huguenot section.

title: Harold Arlen's Songs Basis of Cabaret Show
description: LIGHTNING has not struck twice at the Manhattan Theater Club. After launching Ain't Misbehavin', the dazzling melange of Fats Waller's songs that has moved on to Broadway to an enthusiastics response, the Theater Club's cabaret has now turned to the songs of Haroia Arlen in a production called Happy With the Blues (the title of Edward Jablonski's biography of Mr. Arlen). But the vitality and imagination that kept the Waller songs shooting off like a gala display of fireworks are missing from the Arlen presentation.

title: Jones Captures CanAm Opener
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga., May 14 (ANAlan Jones of Britain drove to an easy victory today in the first race of the 1978 CanAm series, winning by more than 30 seconds from Al Hothert of Warren, Pa.

title: Nevada Casinos Uneasy About Jersey Competitors
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.The shrewd, calculating businessmen and state officials who dominate Nevada's casino industry say they are worried that legalized casino gambling in Atlantic City may become infiltrated by organizedcrime figures.

title: Electric Rates Up 1 9% for Industry,  12 .8% for Homes
description: From December 1976 to last March, the nation's electric utilities raised their rates for industrial and large commercial users by 19.1 percent, on average, while residential rates rose only 12.8 percent, according to National Utility Service Inc., a large utility consulting service based in New York and San Francisco.
