description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week folloWSI

title: Italians Voting in Local Elections
description: ROME, May 14Nearly four million Italians, a tenth of the electorate, voted today in partial local elections that are considered to he the first test of the political impact made by the kidnapping and slaying of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro.

title: Guy Lafleur Is
description: Canada's gentle hero is a willing prisoner of his nationwide fame

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: For week ended May 12, 1978

title: Rep. Edgar: Democrat Trying to Hold His Republican District
description: UPPER DARBY, Pa., May 13When volunteers go out and canvass voters for Representative Robert W. Edgar, they receive an outline of what they are supposed to say.

title: Black Aides at Odds With Human Resources Chief
description: Early in January, Dr. Blanche Bernstein, the newly appointed Human Resources Administrator, received a letter from James Sams, president of the Chama Society, an organization of black workers at her agency.

title: Ballet: Baryshnikov and Kirkland in Nutcracker
description: ONE of the worthiest aspects of Mikhail Baryshnikov's staging of the classics for American Ballet Theater is that they were not produced as vehicles for himself.

title: Tanzania Reports Cholera Deaths
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 14 (Reuters)Eleven more people died of cholera in the Kigoma region yesterday, raising to 48 the number of deaths from the disease there since the beginning of this month, the Tanzanian press agency reported.

title: Anthracite Region Declines, Atop 15 Billion Tons of Coal
description: NANTICOKE, Pa., May 11There was a time when the first word of a contract settlement and the raise it called for would whip through this community of hardcoal miners and echo off the mountains. On such days, no matter how meager the promised pay, the beer tasted better and the future shooed out of mind.

title: Cheating Is the Object Of a Game on Taxes
description: DALLAS (UPI)Two local Internal Revenue Service employees created a board game to allow taxpayers to cheat the Government in the comfort and, the safety of their homes. It costs $11.98 and is not tax deductible.

title: Commuters Seek to Block Fare Rise
description: LITTLE SILVER, May 14A group of commuters meeting here today s:iid would seek an injunction barring a 10 percent fare increase proposed by the Department of Transportation to take effect on all commuter railroads in the state by July 1.

title: Mayor's Neighborhood Meetings Yield Mixed Results on Complaints
description: A month ago, when Mayor Koch and his top aides held one of their constituent hours, listening to complaints from residents in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, Josephine Giliberti told Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo of flooding during rainstorms underneath the elevated Btrain tracks on New Utrecht Avenue, few blocks from her home.

title: $62 MILLION DAMAGES PAID IN TURKISH PLANE CRASH
description: LOS ANGELES, May 14 (UPI)More than $62 million has been paid in damages to more than 1,100 persons as result of the 1974 crash of a Turkish Airlines DC10 near Paris in which 346 persons were killed, it was reported Sunday.

title: Piano: Frager Performs
description: MALCOLM FRAGER, who in years past won both the Queen Elisabeth and Leventritt competitions, hasn't appeared on the New York concert or recital stages in recent years as often as one might have expected. So his recital Saturday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall constituted something of an event by its very existence. The performance was a benefit for the Daycroft School, a Christian Science institution in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Bridge:
description: Two young Scotsmen built up a massive lead in the first day's play of the Cavendish Club's invitation pair championship in New York City on Saturday. Michael Rosenberg and Barnett Shenkin, who have been a powerful force in British bridge in recent years, were so far ahead of their nearest rivals at the halfway point in the event that they were likely to win with an average game on the second day.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: Caracas Train Job Awarded to French
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 14A French Government consortium headed by the Societe Generale de Techniques has been awarded a contract for rolling stock for the Caracas Metro worth about $249 million.

title: MAJOR BLACK FACTION DECIDES NOT TO QUIT RHODESIAN COALITION
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 14The followers of Bishop Abel Muzorewa today decided to remain in the ruling coalition rather than withdraw over the controversial dismissal of a minister belonging to their group.

title: Plan to Convert Olympic Buildings Into Prison Assailed
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y.The complex for the 1980 Winter Olympics, much of it in the steelwork-frame stage, looks like a college campus. In fact, the buildings now rising on a cleared site in Ray Brook, a village five miles west of here, will be used after the Olympicsbut not for a college.

title: Ken Holtzman Sits, Waits and Wonders
description: DOCK ELLIS, once a teammate, says Ken Holtzman has died. In baseball, when a player is sent to the minor leagues or is released or is not uses, other players say he has died.

title: Golf: Trevino Posts First 78 Triumph
description: FORT WORTH, Tex. May 14 (AP)Lee Trevino, gesturing and joking under the hot Texas sun he loves so well, carded a four-under-par 66 today that gave him a fourstroke victory in the Colonial National invitation golf tournament.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Article 3 -- No Title

title: Nuggets Conquer Sonics by 123114
description: DENVER, May 14The Denver Nuggets, employing a couple of subtle defensive changes and a notably unsubtle offense, remained alive in the Western Conference final of the National Basketball Association playoffs, defeating the Seattle SuperSonics this afternoon; 123114.

title: Hayes Leads by 5
description: L.A BAULE, France, May 14 (AP)Dale Hayes of South Africa, seeking his second consecutive European victory, took a fivestroke lead over Severiano Ballesteros of Spain in the third round of the French open golf tournament today.

title: Holyoke, Its Paper Industry Goa; Provides for Elderly Who Stay
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., May 13 (AP)Like any boom town, HolyokeIts business, its people and its buildingsgot old all of a sudden.

title: Hockey:Soviet Union Takes World Title
description: PRAGUE, May 14The Soviet Union won the world hockey championship tonight by beating Czechoslovakia, 31. Each team finished with nine victories and one defeat, but Czechoslovakia also heat the Russians by two goals, 64, a week ago, so the championship was decided on the difference in goals scored for and against .

title: DR. E. F. LINDQUIST
description: IOWA CITY May 15 (UPI)Dr. E. F. Lindquist, author of the National Merit Scholarship tests and several books on intelligence testing and measurement, died Saturday at University Hospitals, where he had been treated for a heart ailment. He was 77 years old.

title: BLOOD TO IDENTIFY DONOR AS PAID OR VOLUNTEER
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)  In a move to battle viral hepatitis, the Food and Drug Administration formally ordered today that all future shipments of blood for transfusions be labeled paid donor or volunteer donor.

title: DOLLAR SHOWS RISE; GOLD UP $1 AN OUNCE
description: The dollar rose against the yen in Tokyo and the lira in Milan but fell marginally against the pound in London in quiet foreign exchange trading around ale world yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Cornell Out to Defy Critics In Lacrosse Title Tourney
description: Cornell, the topranked lacrosse team in the country,is preparing for its sternest test, the National Collegiate postseason tournament for Division I teams. The top eight in the final coaches nail are in the tournament.

title: Commissioner Tells Policemen to Meet People on the Beat
description: In a reversal of previous police practice, officers on foot or motor patrol in New York City were instructed yesterday to introduce themselves and get to know the residents and business people in their patrol sectors.

title: Oil Lobbyist Boasts of Early Access to Federal Data
description: WASHINGTON, May I5A lobbyist for the oil inclust y has contended that he received advance notice of many actions by the Department of Energy and managed on one occasion to review a department letter to a Senator before the letter was mailed.

title: Maine A.H.L. Champion
description: PORTLAND, Maine (AP)Tom Gorence deflected a shot over the head of the goalie, Doug Soetaert tonight to give Maine a 54 victory over New Haven and earn the yearold Mariners the American Hockey League championship and the Calder Cup.

title: United Press international
description: READY FOR REMATCH: Alydar, who came in second to Affirmed in Kentucky Derby, munching alfalfa after early morning workout In Baltimore.

title: Blue Jays 10, Angels 6
description: AT TORONTOHeld to four hits over the first four innings, the Blue Jays, sent 14 men to the plate in the seventh inning, and brought nine of them home in a rally keyed by Sam Ewing's tworun single. They touched three Angels pitchers for seven hits and four walks in the inning to register the biggest inning since the expansion club joined the American League last year. Dave McKay started the scoring with a basesloaded walk. Then Ewing got a pinch. hit single. Singles by Rick Bosetti, Roy Howell and Rick Cerone and a doubla by Bob Bailor followed. John Mayberry's grounder scored the eighth run and the ninth scored on a throwing error by Ken Landreau, the right fielder. Balor Moore, third of four Toronto pitchers was the winner.

title: Halpern's Brief Return to Garden: Stopped in 3
description: John Garfield would have lost at Madison Square Garden last night. There were no Bmovie happy endings to a ClassD boxing card in which two former convicts were beaten in what was billed as comain events.

title: On Treating Alcoholism as a Handicap
description: At the end of this term, if Brooklyn College has its way, Dr. Cleophus Whitaker, a professor of Africana studies, will be out of a job. He has been denied reappointment for academic reasons. According to Dr. Whitaker, who is suing the City University, the reasons are not all that academic. He says they relate to alcoholism; he has been an alcoholic, he concedes, but being treated and is on his way to recovery.

title: Market Place
description: A major investor in the Beker Industries Corporation grew disenchanted a while back after the company indicated that it might not be able to meet revolvingcredit and termloan payments due this year.

title: NBCTV Dropping Nearly a Third of Shows in Fall
description: NBCTV, the third network in ratings, will replace nearly onethird of its primetime evening hours with new programming, according to the schedule announced yesterday.

title: GOVERNMOT PARTY IN ITALY MAKES GAIN IN LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: ROME, May 15  The governing Christian Democratic Party made substantial gains in local elections held. in scattered areas throughout Italy yesterday and today. The party appeared to benefited from voter reaction to the killing by terrorists last week of the party's president, Aldo Moro.

title: Carter Signs Farm Legislation And Raises Wheat Target Price
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)President Carter signed into law emergency farm legislation today and announced that he is raising the target price on 1978 wheat to $3.40 a bushel, an increase of 40 cents, as authorized in the bill.

title: CITIBANK SETS CERTIFICATE TIED TO RATE ON U.S. BILLS
description: Citibank announced yesterday that, beginning June 1, it would issue new sixmonth savings certificates that would pay interest at the United States Treasury bill rate, which is considerably higher than rates currently available at banks or savings institutions. Government agencies approved such certificates last week.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Indians cannot use the Federal court system to sue their own tribes for alleged violations of their civil rights, the Supreme Court concluded today.

title: New York City Repays Loans
description: New York City repaid $450 million in seasonal loans to the Federal Government yesterdayfive days before maturity. Interest on the loans was $22,937,493. The city saved $50,349 by repaying five days early. It still owes $675 million in loans during the final year of the threeyear Federal seasonalloan Program, which experes June 30.

title: Dr. Henry Newson, 68
description: DURHAM, N.C., May 15 (AP)Dr. Henry W. Newson, a nuclear physicist at Duke University who was instrumental in the deve.lopment of atomic energy, died last night at Duke Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Fireman Hurt in 5Story Fall
description: A fireman was injured yesterday falling from a fifthfloor scaffolding to the street, while fighting a onealarm blaze in a commercial building under renovation at 9 East 57th Street, according to fire officials. The fireman, whose nnme was not released, suffered a broken leg and fractured shoulder. He was admitted to S. Clare's Hospital, where his condition Wa reported as fair.

title: Court Bars a Subpoena by Goldin Of Records on School Program
description: New York City's Comptroller cannot subpoena records of the Board of Education to investigate how the board's vocationaleducation program is working, a justice in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

title: A Watershed on Mideast
description: News Analysis

title: BUDGET COMPROMISE APPROVED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  The Senate approved compromise budget goals tonight, setting a spending level of $498.8 billion for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1.

title: Topics
description: Some 600,000 New Yorkers live in developments owned and operated by the city's Housing Authority. For all the social changes since 1937, when the first project was opened, the authority has flourished. No project has been abandoned; a long waiting list for apartments remains. It is an outstanding record, attributable to the fact that the authority attracted outstanding public servants. Its current chairman, Joseph Christian, started in city government in the 1930's as an $840ayear clerk. He climbed the career Civil Service ladder without polishing brass doorknobs or shining in politics. An effective administrator, a believer in the value of decent housing for lowincome working families, and a dogged searcher for Federal money, Mr. Christian has proved that the New York Civil Service system can offer careers that match unusual talent.

title: New York Asks Extension on Life Of Fiscal Control Board to 1997
description: New York City officially proposed to the State Legislature yesterday an extension of the Emergency Financial Control Board's life with undiminished powers over the city's finances probably until

title: Garbage Into Energy: Now a Seller's Market
description: In idle moment, when he gazes down upon New York from his office on the 67th floor at World Trade Center. Peter Goidroark's thoughts often turn to garbage.

title: Ambassador Bunker, 84, Retiring (Again) but Not From Trips to Asia
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Ellsworth Bunker retired in 19?9 at the age of 35 because of an arthritic back. He has retired six times since then: once from the sugar business and five times from Government or United Nations service.

title: Tribe Found in Philippine Crater
description: MANILA. May 15 (AP)  A tribe of primitive cave dwellers wearing loincloths made of hammered bark has been discovered living in the crater of an extinct volcano in the jungle 130 southwest of Manila, the Philippine Government announced today.

title: Tigers Defeat Mariners, 42, for Slaton's Fourth
description: Thanks to Milt May, his batterymate, Jim Slaton pitched his first complete game as a Detroit Tiger last night and won his fourth straight game, 42, from Seattle on a fivehitter.

title: Sewer Project In Suffolk Poses A Fiscal Burden
description: St. Mary's parish in East Islip, LI., runs three bingo games a week to help support its 650. student elementary school. The profits from the bingo, bolstered by tuition and what the pastor describes as the very generous contributions from the parish's 5,000 families, keen the school in the black.

title: Rangers 8, Brewers 6
description: AT ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ferguson Jenkins was backed by a 13hit Texas assault in picking up his fourth straight victory. Jim Sundberg, stretching his hitting streak to 14 games. singled twice, doubled once and scored two runs. Juan Beniquez and Toby Harrah each knocked in a pair of runs, The Rangers battered Bill Travers, making his first appearance of the season following elbow surgery last December, for six hits and five runs in the first two innings.

title: MAY 110 CAR SALES 2D BEST IN HISTORY; DAILY RATE UP 9.6%
description: DETROIT, May 15The nation's automobile manufacturers today reported their secondbest sales performance on record for the first 10 days of May, following a record sales month in April.

title: Soviet Bars Defense Witnesses as Well as U.S. Government Observer at Dissident Trial
description: MOSCOW, May 15  A Soviet judge refused today to allow Yuri F. Orlov, a dissident, to call any witnesses for the defense in his trial, which opened in a small courthouse sealed by the police.

title: PETER POLLACK, WRITER AND A LECTURER ON ARTS
description: Peter Pollack, former director of the American Federation of the Arts, a nonprofit organization designed to foster the production and appreciation of the arts in America, and curator of photography at the Art Institute of Chicago from 1945 to 1957, died last Saturday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 67 years old.

title: Gambling Board Gives a GoAhead To Open First Atlantic City Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 15Resorts International was granted a temporary license today to operate the first legitimate gambling casino in the country outside Nevada, and it appeared likely that the casino would open on the Boardwalk here May 26.

title: A Gloom Full of Spies
description: Notes on the espionage business, jotted while recuperating from an overdose of spy novels. Spies are old and tired and sick of It all.

title: Article 8 -- No Title
The N.A.A.C.P. Enters the Marketplace
description: After 70 remarkable years of fighting to advance the rights of black Americans through the courts, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is shifting to economic issues. Recent policy statements have focused on economic growth, energy policy and minority business development, and at this month's conference in Chicago of civil rights leaders, the N.A.A.C.P. representatives concentrated on the chronic problem of black unemployment.

title: West Germany's View of Economic World
description: On both sides of the Atlantic, there is a sense of deadlock and frustration over economic policy. European leaders, tortured with selfdoubts, look to the United States for leadership, but express disappointment and confusion

title: Yankees Defeat White Sox, 41; Rivers Is Benched by Martin
description: CHICAGO, May 15Mickey Rivers was sitting on the benchand hating itas the Yankees tried to put their previous day's escapades out of mind with a 41 victory over the White Sox tonight at Comiskey Park. Jim Beattie earned his second major league victory without a loss with strong relief assistance from Sparky Lyle.

title: RALPH LOWELL AT 87; BANKER AND SCHOLAR
description: Ralph Lowell, a banker, philanthropist and patriarch of Boston society who helped found the nation's first educational television station 25 years ago, died yesterday at Faulkner Hospital in Boston. He was 87 years old and lived in the Boston suburb of Westwood.

title: Navratilova Case: Mother Still Waits
description: REVNICE, Czechoslovakia, May 13Jana Navratitova is losing hope that she will soon see her daughter, Martina, for the first time since she defected to the United States nearly three years ago.

title: Preserving Alaska's Crown Jewels
description: The House Rules Committee votes today on the Alaska lands billin the opinion of Interior Secretary Andrus the most sweeping and important conservation legislation that any of us will see in our lifetime. The bill seeks to preserve extensive tracts as national parks, forests, wildlife refuges and scenic riversprotected against mining, oil and gas exploration, logging, and other exploitation. The bill has precipitated a classic confrontation between conservationists and developers. The conservationists want to preserve areas of spectacular scenery and an unparalleled array of wildlife. Developers fear they will be denied access to vast resources simply because a few. effete rich backpackers want to set aside millions of acres for their own occasional enjoyment.

title: Criticized Assemblyman Charges Others Might Have Casino Ties
description: TRENTON. May 15  Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, who is under criticism for having sold slot machines to Resorts International Inc., charged today that two other legislators had possible gambling casino connections and that there was at least the appearance of confblict of interest.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: About New York
description: On Jan. 17, 1949, Arthur Shapiro was browsing in the Eighth Street Bookstore as a student and heard strange gutteral sounds in the next aisle.

title: MISS HEARST IS BACK IN A FEDERAL PRISON
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 15Patricia Hearst returned to Federal prison today to serve the rest of her sevenyear sentence for bank robbery.

title: ARTHUR WHITFIELD HUGULEY JR.
description: Arthur Whitfield Huguley Jr., chairman of the board of the Westway Trading Corporation, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., wholesale dealers in sugar and molasses, died Sunday in a hospital in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 68 years old and had homes in Bedford, N.Y., and Mountain Lake, Fla.

title: Various Corporations Disclose Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Latest Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: GOVERNMENT PARTY IN ITALY MAKES GAIN IN LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: ROME, May 15The governing Christian Democratic Party made substantial gains in local elections held in scattered areas throughout Italy yesterday and today. The party appeared to have benefited from voter reaction to the killing by terrorists last week of the party's president, Aldo Moro.

title: Defense Suggests Dr. Jascalevich Tried to Stop Unneeded Surgery
description: HACKENSACK May 15The defunse in the murder trial u Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich sought today to portray the Surgeon as having tried unsuccessfully to halt an operation on a woman who then died after what turned out to be unnecessary surgery.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, May 15 (Reuters)  President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania flew to Peking today for one of the more elaborate welcomes to be given a visitor. More than 100,000 people were assembled in the capital's center to cheer and entertain the President and Mrs. Ceausescu. The most senior Chinese leaders had greeted them at the airport.

title: Bookmen Meet in Shadow of Conglomerates
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 15The Association of American Publishers has comvened here for its annual meeting in deductible splendor with a kind, prearranged word from President Carter All who cherish learning and education owe a debt of gratitude to your industryand with reason to crow about the prosperity of book publishing in the United States.

title: 80 Palestinians in South Lebanon Agree to Withdraw
description: MAARAKE, Lebanon, May 15  Eighty heavily armed Palestinian guerrillas, surrounded near here since Saturday by 200 United Nations peacekeeping troops, agreed today to withdraw peacefully.

title: The Pressures and the Counterpressures
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  In an Atlanta synagogue last night, guests at a dinner celebrating Israeli independence found notes at their tables telling them to call their Congressmen to protest the proposed package sale of jet fighters to the Middle East. In Milwaukee a wealthy businessman named Elmer Winter received a call from the

title: Eberhard Upsets Milton
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 15 (UPI)Klaus Eberhard of West Germ :ny stored a mild upset on the first day of ne $175.000 German open tenchampirmships today xvhen he elimirated Bernie Mitton of South Africa in srihsc,q, 61, 62.

title: WilkesBarre Newspapers Sold To Capital Cities Communications
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., May 15 (AP)Contracts were signed today for the sale of the WilkesBarre Publishing Company, publisher of the Times Leader, the Evening News and WilkesBarre Record, to Capital Cities Communications Corporation of New York City.

title: Traffic Flows to Busy Theaters In California, Land of the Auto
description: SAN FRANCISCOCalifornia, which did not invent the automobile but was the first to perceive its natural talent for governing society, furnishes the automobile with, among other things, theaters.

title: U.S. STUDIES PLAN TO BURY NUCLEAR WASTES IN OCEAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  Sedlments that have apparently rested undisturbed on the ocean floor for 50 million years or more are being studied as possible burial grounds for nuclear waste, Congress was told today.

title: A New Postal Stamp Lacks Denomination
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)The Postal Service said today that it was distributing a nondenominational stamp to be used until the Postal Rate Commission decided the new rate for firstclass postage,

title: STATE'S SUIT STARTS ON MERCURY WASTES
description: HACKENSACK, May 15A state,campaign to force removal of heavy concentrations of mercury contamination from the Hackensack Meadowlands got underway here today with the start of a trial against six alleged polluters accused of dumping up to 300 tons of the hazardous metal in the soil and water of the district.

title: ECONOMY BRIGHTENS SUMMER JOB OUTLOOK
description: The summer job outlook seems better than it has been in years, but the number of jobhunting youths is soaring, too.

title: President of Upper Volta Faces Runoff Vote in Bid for New Term
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, May 15 (AgenceFrance Presse)  President Sangoule Lamizana faces a runoff on May 28 in the presidential elections, after polling 41.32 percent of votes cast in yesterday's voting.

title: Yugoslav Boxer Wins; American Eliminated
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 15 (AP)Mehmet Bobujevci of Yugoslavia outpointed Simion Cutov of Rumania, an Olympic silvermedal winner, to night, and Lemuel Steeples of St. Louis, a light welterweight, was eliminated by Heinz Kruger of East Germany at the second World amateur boxing championships.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Dolphins and Whales Learning to Need People
Streicher Dances Circus Tabu
description: These days, the Truck and Warehouse Theater is the site of an arts festival bearing the fanciful name of Electric Spaghetti. It is to be hoped that other programs in the series will prove more festive than Saturday night's dance concert, which was something of a limp noodle.

title: Spain Victor in Final Of Nations Cup Tennis
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, May 15 (AP)Jose Higueras and Manuel Orantes of Spain triumphed over Australian rivals today in singles matches. clinching the $60,000 first prize of the Nations Cup tennis tournament.

title: Boe Ordered to Pay Cable Company
description: MINEOLA, L.I. May 15Roy L. M. Boe, president of the New York Islanders and the New Jersey Nets, found himself in more financial trouble today when he was ordered to pay $4,139,750 to the Long Island Cable Communications Development Company.

title: Progress Reported in CommuterBus Strike Talks
description: NEWARK, May 15Federal and state mediators reported some progress today in their efforts to end a sixweekold strike against the Manhattan Transit Company that has forced more than 20,000 interstate commuters from Bergen, Bassaic and Hodson Counties to find other means of transportation.

title: Elizabeth Swados Up for 4 Tonys
description: Elizabeth Swados, the young creator of the musical Runaways, whcih opened on Broadway last week, has won four nominations for the American Theater Wing's 1978 Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards.

title: Ford Asking Court To Throw Out Suit
description: The Ford Motor Company filed a motion yesterday to dismiss a suit that charges Henry Ford 2d, its ,chairman, with conspiracy to misuse company funds. The company asserted in the motion that the case was a lawyers lawsuit masquerading as a shareholder derivative action.

title: Article 7  No Title
Alexander Kipnes, Met Singer; Called One of Greatest Basses
description: Alexander Ripnis, the Russianborn singer who was regarded as one of the great basses of this century, died Sunday at a convalescent home in Westport, Conn., the town where he lived. He was 57 vears old.

title: MRS, GANDHI ASSAILED IN REPORT ON INQUIRY
description: NEW DELHI, May 15  The judicial commission that has been Investigating former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government has concluded that it was characterized by illegality, widespread repression and persistent subversion of human rights.

title: CREDIT MARKETS GAIN ON TAXCUT PULLBACK
description: The credit markets moved moderately higher in price and lower in rate yesterday in a mild response to President Carter's decision to trim his taxcut proposal and delay its implementation by three months. The Federal Reserve chairman, G. William Miller, applauded the decision as very constructive, and his comment also helped the market for fixedincome securities.

title: Market, in Surge Of Buying, Hits A7Month High
description: A surge of buying in the final hour sent the stock market ahead yesterday to its highest level in seven months. Wail Street analysts said there was no specific news development to account for the late strength, which came on the heels of impressive advances last Thursday and Friday.

title: Sewer Project In Suffolk Poses AFiscal Burden
description: St. Mary's parish in East Islip, 1..1., n:; three bingo games a week to help support its 650 student elementary school. The profits from the bingo, boihy tuition and what the pastor (:escribes as the very generous contributions from the parish's 5,000 families, keep the school in the black.

title: CORRECTION
description: An 18thcentury Hogarth engraving thaT appeared in The Times April 24, identified as a meeting of undertakers. in fact depicted physicians. It satirical title, shown under the engraving, is Company of Undertakers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Blumenthal Assails Bill Designed to Cut CapitalGains Tax
description: WASHINGTON, May 15A bill to reduce capitalgains taxes, which is supported by Republicans and a growing number of Democrats, was attacked today by the Ar'ministration.

title: BITTER DEBATE IS DUE ON LABORLAW BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Senate, in what is likely to be a long and bitter war of words, is scheduled to begin debate tomorrow on legislation to amend the national labor law.

title: Sir Robert Gordon Menzies, 83, Dies
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 15Sir Robert Gordon Menzies, Australia's most successful politician and its greatest conservative leader, died while reading in his study in Melbourne yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: Y Cancels Violin Program
description: The program called Romantic Violin Tradition, scheduled for Thursday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., has been canceled. One of the performers in the program, which was to feature Yuval Waldman, was injured. Ticket holders may obtain a refund by mailing their tickets to the box office at the Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10028.

title: U.A.W. BIDS TO REPRESENT VOLKSWAGEN PLANT IN U.S.
description: PITTSBURGH, May 15 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers filed a petition today seeking a union representation election at the new Volkswagen Rabbit assembly plant in New Stanton, Pa.

title: Fashionconsdous Crowd Turns Out for Gala at Gracie
description: The fashion industry descended on Gracie Mansion last night for what was billed as a Gala at Gracie, the first big charity bash to be held at the mansion since Edward I. Koch was elected Mayor.

title: Sears Net Off 1.9%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's target retailer, yesterday told its annual meeting in Chicago that net income for the first quarter, ended April 30 had dipped 1.9 percent. At the same time, the country's thirdlargest retail chain, the J. C. Penney Company, announced at its meeting in Kansas City that its net for the period topped the previous year's by 14.3 percent.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Koch Rebuts Reports Budget Is Artificially Inflated
description: Mayor Koch yesterday rebutted a report that the city budget had been artificially inflated.

title: JOIE RAY, 84, DEAD; STARRED AS RUNNER
description: Joie Ray, a former world indoor recordholder in the mile run and a member of the National Track and Field Hall of Fame, died in Benton Harbor, Mich., on Saturday night after a short illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Conflict Comes as Surprise
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 15  Shaba Province has not been quiet since an insurrection there was quelled a year ago, but the latest outbreak of fighting has apparently caught the Government and Western observers by surprise.

title: Report on Lance:Financial PowerBuilt on Borrowed Money
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Senate investigation of Bert Lance, President Carter's close friend and former budget director, quietly came to a close today with the official publication of the record of Senate committee hearings last fall that explored Mr. Lance's record as Georgia banker.

title: Twins 9, Orioles 6
description: AT BLOOMINGTON, MinnMike Marshall, the rightranded relief pitcher, was added to the Minnesota roster early yesterday, after Rod Carew talked of a clubhouse revolt it Marshall was not signed. Marshall was the beneficiary last night of a threerun 10th inning horne run by Willie Norwood in the Minnesota victory. Marshall pitched 1 2/3 innings of hitless ball, striking out two and walking one.

title: Zaire at a Glance
description: The Land The former Belgian Congo was called the Republic of the Congo when it became independent in 1960. and later the Democratic Republic of the Congo, but was renamed Zaire in 1971 after the traditional African name of what Europeans called the Congo River. From a 25mile Atlantic coastline at the river's mouth, the country balloons inland, and extends more than half way across Africa toward the Indian Ocean. Its size (nearly 900.000 square miles) is more than three times that of Texas. Much of the area is tropical rain forest, with fertile plains and nearly treeless grasslands in the south.

title: Around the Nation
description: NORMAL, Ill., May 15 (UPDFirefighters ratified a new contract by a 22to0 vote and returned to work tonight, ending an eightweek strike in which firemen were sentenced to jail for refusing to return to work.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Justices Let Stand Order to Reporters To Reveal Sources
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Supreme Court let stand today two state court orders requiring reporters to identify sources of information that they had attempted to keep confidential.

title: Business Records
Wornen in TV Ads: The Old Image Lingers
description: Everyone knows her. Her clothes are clean, her shoes sensible, her floors shiny, her Formica spotless. She has two children, one helpful friend, one nosy neighbor and a dog who occasionally tracks dirt into her kitchen. Unfortunately, her husband's shirts are not as white as they should be and she does not realize that he would choose stuffing over potatoes. With the exception of these two things, her life is relatively worryfree. She can see her own face in her dishes.

title: Resorts Casino Is Inspected Amid Predictions of Success
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 15  Potential winners seemed to outnumber eager losers at the Resorts International Hotel here today, perhaps for one of the last times before the hotel casino's expected opening for legal gambling on May 26.

title: The Verandah, a Staging of Life on Island of Jamaica
description: Out of the contrasts and conflicts of Jamaican society just before World War 11, Clifford Mason has fashioned a rich, multilayered play full of psychological turns. emotional nuances and surprising insights. The Verandah, playing weekends at the Gene Frankel Theater, reveals the complexity that lies behind the seeming simplicity of Jamaican life. That life is neither quaint nor exotic. Real people inhabit Mr. Mason's world and they suffer as they try to work out questions not limited to the islands of the West Indies: What am I? To what do I owe allegiance?

title: Cherry Mixes Wit, Coaching Wisdom
description: Don Cherry, the ebullient coach of the Boston Bruins, not only produces one of the National Hockey League's toughest and most disciplined teams, but he also charms the snarls off the toughest interrogators. He is not what one has come to expect from the average wewererobbed, bigtime coach.

title: Dolphins and Whales Learning to Need People
description: Within three weeks after Southern California's Marineland closed for remodeling last November, the dolphins were sulking, the sea lions were getting fat and the killer whales were depressed. By the end of the first week, Tom Otten, head curator, said, the animals were looking around for the people. Looking at empty bleachers is pretty tiresome.

title: U.S. MUST PREPARE INDEX OF TAPES IN CRIME INQUIRY
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 15 (AP)The Justice Department was ordered today to draft an index of conversations monitored by the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the office of Raymond L. S. Patriarca, a reputed leader of organized crime in New England.

title: Books of The Times An Articulate Noise
description: H. L. Mencken once wrote of Arnold Bennett that he carries skepticism so far that it often takes on the appearance of a mere peasantlike suspicion of ideas, bellicose and unintelligent. Even Mencken's newest biographerhagiographer is perhaps a better word

title: Indian Woman, in SexBias Case, Challenged Tribal Law for the Sake of Her Children
description: SANTA CLAFtA PUEBLO, N.M.Julia Martinez is a tiny, softspoken, elderly Santa Clara Indian whose English is flawed, whose manner is shy and who is at the center of a lawsuit that touches the sovereignty of every Indian tribe in the United States. She is not politically active and. could be considered militant only by a long stretch of the imagination. Her stubborn, decadeslong effort has one motivation.

title: Green feld Sells Noah for Film
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15A Place for Noah, Josh Greenfeld's recently published biography of his 11yearold braindamaged son, has been purchased by an independent film and television company for $125,000.

title: $12.7 MILLION LOSS REPORTED BY CORCO
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, which is operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, reported yesterday a consolidated net loss of $12.7 million for the first quarter of this year. This was more than double the $6.3 million lost in the initial three months of last year, after an extraordinary credit of $800.000.

title: Britain Assails Dissident Trials
description: LONDON, May 15  As Yuri Orlov's trial opened, the Foreign Office issued the following statement:

title: SAVINGS GROUPS REPORT POOR APRIL DEPOSIT FLOWS
description: Thu nation's mutual savings banks reported yesterday a net deposit outflow of S550 million in April, the industry's secondworst April on record. Meanwhile, savings and loan associations in New York State said there was a slowdown in the inflow of net savings in April and that mortgage money was getting harder to get.

title: Judges Censured in TicketFixing
description: ALBANY, May 15 (AP)The State Commission on Judicial Conduct took action today against 13 more local justices for alleged ticketfixing, but limited its sanction to censure rather than seeking their ouster from office.

title: Pakistan Gets Plea on Bhutto
description: LONDON, May 15 (Reuters)  Amnesty International asked Pakistan's military Government today to permit observers to attend the appeal hearing of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who is under sentence of death for the alleged murder of a political opponent.

title: Ouster of Schools Head in Hartford Reflects Growing National Problem
description: HARTFORDThree year ago, with a reputation as one Of the country's op urban school experts, Edythe J. Gaines, arrived in Hartford to become Superintendent of Schools amid high hopes that she Would he able to revitalize Connecticut's largest school district.

title: Luce Sees Con Ed Rate Relief Unlikely but Payout Safe
description: Charles F. Luce, chairman and chief executive of the Consolidated Edison Company, told shareholders at the utility's annual meeting yesterday that he could see little hope for moderating electricrate increases over the next dozen years unless the Government changes the fuel policy and tax policy which imposes on Con Ed and its customers.

title: Prices of Precious Metals Futures Rise
description: Prices of precious metals moved up throughout the session yesterday for a variety of reasons. For one, there were persistent rumors that the International Monetary Fund would reduce the amount of gold bullion it auctions each month by 50,000 ounces, to 475,000 ounces.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Are Mixed
description: Yields were mixed on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in the 91dos and 182day maturities.

title: Pennsylvania Candidates in Final Plea in the Primary
description: PHILADELPHIA. May 15  A wide army of Democratic and Republican candidates employed every medium of public expression today in a last effort to gain votes in tomorrow's Pennsylvania gubernatorial primary.

title: Basque Separatist Group Bombs TV Tower and Kidnaps Motorisi
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, May 15 (AP)  The Basque separatist group E.T.A. bombed a television relay tower in an Shastian and ahducted a motorist near Bilbao during the weekend, the police reported today. The motorist later vrl found gagged and tied but unhurt. The erorsts kept his car.

title: BattingPractice Millionaire
description: To the New York Yankees, he was not worth more than $1.5 million over five years even after two World Series victories. To the Boston Red Sox, he was worth $2.5 million. But no matter what the future shows Mike Torrez to be worth, the big righthander already has a 51 wonlost record for the American League East leaders. To be honest, he said, I usually don't get going until later in the season, but lately I've been keeping my pitches down. Throwing batting Practice has helped him do that. In baseball's era of prima

title: Mrs. Nixon Enters Hospital
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 15 (AP)Pat Nixon, the former First Lady, was admitted to Long Beach Memorial Hospital today for treatment of a lung infection, a hospital spokesman said. Mrs. Nixon will probably remain in the hospital until the end Of the week, her physician, Dr. John Lundgren, said. Susan Pescar, a hospital spokesman, described Mrs. Nixon's condition as good and said that she was resting comfortably.

title: U.S. Expresses Misgivings
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  The State Department expressed its misgivings today over dissident trials that begain in Moscow and Tbilisi despite United States warnings that the trials could imperil SovietAmerican relations.

title: Soviet Junior Five Wins
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 15AleKsandr Lyndin scored 5 points in the final 33 seconds, 3 from the foul line, to give the Soviet national junior basketball team a 7977 victory over the long Island scholastic allstars tonight at Long Island Lutheran High School in the finale of an eightgame tour of the United States. Aleksandr Belosteni paced the Soviet, team, which wound up with a 62 wonlost record, with 19 points. Richie D'Antonio of Lynbrook High was the game's high scorer with 20 points,

title: Insurgents in Zaire Report Seizing Key Towns, but Claim Is Disputed
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 15  Insurgents trying to seize the southern copperproducing province of Shaba said today that they had captured two key towns, but their statement was disputed by Zaire's army.

title: DEBATE IS INTENSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Senate tonight upheld President Carter's controversial decision to sell fighter planes in a package deal to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel.

title: PHILIP J. LAWSON
description: Philip J. Lawson, former director of special projects of the Cushing & Neve!! Technical Design Corporation and later a freelance consulting engineer, died early yesterday at his home at 119 Washington Place in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.

title: Gambling Board Gives a GoAhead To Open First Atlantic City Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 15  Resorts International was granted a temporary Iicense today to operate the first legitimate gambling casino in the country outside Nevada, and it appeared likely that the casino would open on the Boardwalk here May 26.

title: City Ballet Salutes Robbins With Evening of His Dances
description: Remembering that Jerome Robbins created his Afternoon of a Faun just 25 years ago, the New York City Ballet was moved to mark that occasion Sunday night at the New York State Theater with an allRobbins program. Naturally, Faun was among the ballets. Yet any excuse to salute Mr. Robbins needs no justification and the evening provided its own raison d'etre. It opened with Fanfare and The Cage, continued with Afternoon of a Faun and ended with The Concert. The choreographer himself came out for a bow with Suzanne Farrell and Peter Martins after Faun. An additional curtain call sent Robbinsomanes to their feet.

title: Oerter and Wilkins: Not a Confidence Game
description: Now that Al Oerter and Mac Wilkins have met and agreed not to disagree on the road to the 1980 Moscow Olympics, the next logical question is: Can the 41yearold Oerter catch the worldrecord holder in the discus throw?

title: Deaths
description: BARONMollye. Beloved wife of William Baron. Loving mother of Gladys Ostfeld and Myron (Mike) Baron. Devoted grandmother of Michael and Barry Levy, Debi and Marty Baron. Cherished sister of Henry and Herbert Caplan and Julia Goldfish. Funeral services are Tuesday May 16, Westminster Chapel, Coney Island Ave & Ave H at 2:30PAA.

title: Yugoslav Amateurs Win
description: ATHENS, May 15 (UPI)Yugoslavia defeated Greece, 21, in overtime today and won the European Cup for national amateur soccer teams. The wining goal was scored after 20 minutes of extra time.

title: East and West Meet on Stage
description: Margaret Fisher and Beth Anderson are working at different ends of the country, Miss Fisher in the San Francisco Bay area and Miss Anderson in New York, but both of them are performing artists whose pieces include elements of music, dance, poetry and theater. They shared a program at the Experimental Intermedia Founaation on Sunday night, and the contrasts were as interesting as the similarities.

title: House Commerce Group Approves Bill to Delay Amtrak Reduction
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee approved today a bill that would delay any reduction in Amtrak passenger trains until Oct. 11979.

title: PHILIP MORRIS OFFER IS ACCEPTED BY 7UP; BID UP TO $48 A SHARE
description: Philip Morris Inc. and the SevenUp Corporation jointly announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement to combine the two companies under the control of Philip Morris.

title: Nitrate Reduction Ordered in Bacon
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Agriculture Department today ordered that within a year, meat packers all but eliminate the potentially cancercausing chemicals now used to preserve and to redden bacon. The result, a department spokesman said, would be bacon that tastes and looks almost like what is eaten today.

description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 15Insurgents trying to seize the southern copperproducing province of Shaba said today that they had captured two key towns, but their statement was disputed by Zaire's army.

title: The Chicago Symphony Displays A Lot of Brass in Brahms Break
description: The Chicago Symphony literally displayed a lot of brass Thursday night in Alice Tully Hall. While the rest of the orchestra took a free evening in the midst of its fourconcert Brahms series in Carnegie Hall this week, 14 members of the brass section appeared on their own in a tangy collection of brassy tidbits culled from the Renaissance to the present day.

Joie Ray Dies at 84
description: Joie Ray, former holder of the world indoor record for the mile and a noted marathon runner, died yesterday at the age of 84. Story on page 69.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: The Internal Revenue Service is not known for its inclination to shirk a fight, and yesterday it took on the Church of Scientology, a religious sect already embroiled in controversy with other Federal agencies. The score for the first round in the tax arena was the Government 3, the church 0.

title: RENT STRIKERS PROTEST BLOCKS BRONX HIGHWAY
description: About 250 people halted morning ruH: hour traffic on the Major Deegan D.pressway yesterday to publicize an 11monthold rent strike at the fouryearold River Park Towers housing project in the Bronx.

title: Mugged Once, but Victimized Twice
description: A stranger in a woolen cap is racing down the hall toward me with a raised hunting knife that seems to grow longer and sharper by the second. I am carrying two supermarket bags stuffed with groceries and a heavy Sunday newspaper, about to fish out my keys and open the door to my home.

title: Justices Back Reasonable Listening by Wiretap
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Supreme Court concluded today that law enforcement agents do not need to make an effort to minimize interception of private conversations when conducting a courtordered wiretap as long as circumstances of the case make it reasonable to listen to everything.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GREENER GRASS Warm weather means new activities by one of the city's bestorganized and most rewarding independent tour units operating the year round. Seeing is only part of the busandfoot explorations provided by Lou Singer's safaris throughout Brooklyn. Much of the enlightenment and fun comes from the narration of Mr. Singer, a proud resident of the borough who is eager to share encyclopedic knowledge and enthusiasm. Only Mr. Singer, perhaps, could have been the leader of a recent, successful tour called Japan in Brooklyn.

title: Garbage Into Energy: Now a Seller's Market
description: In idle moments, when he gazes down upon New York from his office on the 67th floor at 1 World Trade Center, Peter Goldmark's thoughts often turn to garbage.

title: Cecil J. Lurie, 77, Civic Leader Founder of Steel Products Concren
description: Cecil J. Lurie, a civic leader and the founder and retired president of the Atlas Steel Products Company, distributors of building products, of Jersey City, died yesterday at the Newark Beth Israel Medical Center after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 9 North Cobane Terrace in West Orange, N.J.

title: Notes on People
description: Neville Marriner was named yesterday to succeed Stanislaw Skrowac; zewski As music director of the Minne; sota Orchestra in Minneapolis. He to take over at the start of the 197980; season. Klaus Tennstedt, the German maestro, will be pr;ncipal guest conductor in 197980, and Leonard Slatkin, now principal guest conductor, will be artistic director for the summer season. The Minnesota Orchestra, previously known as the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, was organized in 1903. Mr. Marriner, who is English, is 53 years old. Ile began his career as a violinist and formed a chamber ensemble called St. Martininthe Fields, whose recordings under his leadership number about 200. In 1969 he formed the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, which he still conducts.

title: F.D.A. Still Seeking Specific Health Hazard in Liquid Protein Products
description: One was a 33yearold, laboratory technician who worked for a doctor; another a recent college graduate in her early 20's; a third was a housewife with two children, and a fourth an operating room nurse who had one child. Each was at least 100 pounds overweight and absolutely intent on doing something about it.

title: Plans by Lilco for 2 Nuclear Plants Win Approval of Washington Panel
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 15The Federal Atomic Safety and Licensing Board has approved virtually all aspects of two nuclear generating plants in Jamesport, L.I., and, in doing so, has severely criticized Suffolk County's opposition as containing misrepresentations and misstatements.

title: House Committee Approves Bill To Reduce Regulation of Airlines.
description: The House Public Works Committee, by a 36to4 vote, approved yesterday bill that would markedly reduce regulation of the nation's airlines.

title: Ford Strikers Stay Off Job
description: ROMEO, Mich., May 15 (UPI)  Striking employees of the Ford Motor Company's Romeo tractor plant stayed off their jobs today despite the urgings by union and company officials to end their fourdayold walkout. The workers at the tractor facility walked off their jobs after an argument between a welder and a general supervisor.

title: Ouster of Schools Head in Hartford Reflects Growing National Problem
description: HARTFORDThree years ago, with a reputation as one or the country's top urban school experts, Edythe J. Gaines, arrived in Hartford to become Superintendent of Schools amid high hopes that she would be able to revitalize Connecticut's largest school district.

title: Panel Urges More State Control Over Connecticut School System
description: HARTFORD, May 15A panel of state and local education officials today proposed a greatly increased role for the State Department of Education in the traditionally autonomous local school districts.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Health Department refused to conduct a special investigation into reports that at least 14 residents in a fiveblock area of Palisades Park have died of cancer in recent yea rs.

title: American League A's 3, Indians 2
description: AT CLEVELANDDwayne Murphy, a rookie batting .059 before the game, capped a tworun rally in the sixth inning with a sacrifice fly that scored Mike Edwards, a pinchrunner. The victory went to Joe Coleman (30) on three innings of hitless relief. Elias home the first Tiger run in the first, scoring Lou Whitaker. Sosa pitched the ninth and picked up his sixth save. The A's still leading the West, chased Rick Wise, the Cleveland starter. in the sixth when Wayne Gross led off with a double and Gary Alexander singled him to third. Alexander moved to second on the throw to the plate. After Wise retired the next hatter, Dennis Kinney came on in relief. Gary Thomasson greeted the leftbander with a runscoring single that. tied the game at 22 and sent Edwards to third. Andre Thornton hit a home run for Cleveland, his fifth of the season.

title: U.S. TO GIVE NICARAGUA SOME HUMANITARIAN AID
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  Nicaragua is scheduled to receive some United States aid of a basic human needs nature, a State Department official said tonight.

title: Student Accused of Aiding Vietnam Admits Sending Secret Document
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 15  A parttime graduate student charged with espionage and other crimes acknowledged today that one of the documents that the Government has accused him of sending to Vietnamese officials in France was marked secret.

title: SURGEON CHALLENGED AT JASCALEVICH TRIAL
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 15  The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Marlo E. Jascalevich sought today to portray the surgeon as having tried unsuccessfully to halt an operation on a woman Who then died after what turned out to be unnecessary surgery.

description: EL PASO, Tex., May 15 (AP)Renee Richards defeated Billie Jean King, 6.2, last night as the the Sun Belt Nets posted a 2826 victory over the New York Apples in a World Team Tennis match.

title: Budget Hearings Offer Residents a Forum on City Ills
description: Pleas for sewer repairs, new schools and street paving were enlivened yesterday by a Chinese dragon dance as the City Council's Finance Committee and the Board of Estimate finished their borough hearings on the proposed new city budget.

title: StockTrading Halts Limited
description: The Supreme Court deprived the Se curities and Exchange Commission of one of its major weapons against fraud the power to halt trading in a stock indefinitely through a series of 10day suspensions. Page 49.

title: New Dates Set If Sonics Win
description: Should the Seattle. SuperSonics reach the National Basketball Association championship round against the Washington Bullets, the fourth game of the fourofsevengame series would be played May 30 at the Kingdome in Seattle.The Sonics were not scheduled to move to the Kingdome until next season.

title: Indy Idleness Reaches 3 Days
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 (UPI) inactivity continued at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway for the third consecutive day today, depriving many crews of practice time for next weekend's time trials for the 500mile race May 28.

title: Iranian Soldiers Patrol Uneasy Capital
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 15 (AP)Troops and antiriot policemen patrolled the streets of Teheran today after opponents of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi ordered stores to close and motorists and pedestrians to stay off the streets.

title: Kennecott Changes Meeting Date Of Stockholder Session to May 30
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation said yesterday that its stockholders meeting. originally scheduled to he reconvened today, would be held instead on May 30.

title: CABINET OF TECHNICIANS REINSTATED IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 15  President Elias Sarkis reinstated a Cabinet of technicians today after efforts to form a government of national union had failed.

title: ANTICRIME PACKAGE ADVANCES IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, lvlay 15The Democraticdominated Assembly today overwhelmingly passed five parts of Governor Carey's anticrime package, stiffening penalties for youthful offenders and for persons who jumped bail.

title: Bridge:
description: Most experts would be happy to finish second in a prestigious pair championship, but for two young Scots this result. in the Cavendish invitational in New York during the weekend was a dubious pleasure. The two, Michael Rosenberg and Barnett Shenkin, had led from start to finish, and had seemed certain winners, until a stumble on the very last deal deprived them of victory.

title: FRIED HAMBURGER CALLED POSSIBLE CANCER SOURCE
description: Hamburger neat cooked too long at temperatures above. 300 degrees Farenheit may produce cancercausing substances, hut the extent of the tisk not yet known, a biologist said yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Jordan's King Plans To Wed an American
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 15 (Reuters)King Hussein of Jordan intends to marry Elizabeth Halaby, an American employed as an architect and designer by Royal Jordanian Airlines, officials said here tonight.

title: Carey to Seek a State Limit on All Hospital Rates
description: ALBANY, May 15A bill that would for the first time impose direct state limits on all hospital rates, including those paid by individuals and private health insurers, is expected to be proposed this week by the Carey administration.

title: Allen Investment Firms Drop Suit; Times Agrees to Print Correction
description: Two Wall Strcet firms, Allen & Company and Allen & Company Inc., said yesterday that they had instructed their lawyers not to proceed with libel suits they had been preparing against The New York Times because the paper had agreed to print a correction and statement of regret. The suits had been threatened because of an article that appesred in The Times Magazine on Feb. 26. The companies said in a statement yesterday that the suits would not be pursutd.

description: Give Peace a Chance! proclaimed the headline in a fullpage advertisement urging United States senators to vote against a Mideast arms package that includcd the sale of advanced F15 fighter planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: WALTER IL SIMSON, 72, ELECTRICAL PIONEER
description: Walter H. Simson, a pioneer in developing, manufacturing and selling longlasting heavyduty lamps and electric lights, died Saturday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 72 years old and also had a home at 224 Highland Avenue in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Deaths
description: HUGULEYArthur W., Jr. May 15, 1978. of Lake Wales, Fla. and Bedford, N.Y. Husband of Constance Creighton Hugulev, father of Arthur Hugulev, Ill, Tenafly, N.J., Margaret Law of Portola Valley, Calif., and Hester Smith of Darien, Conn. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Memorial Services at St. Matthews Episcopal Church, Bedford, to be announced later.

title: MISS HEARST IS BACK IN A FEDERAL PRISON
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 15  Patricia Hearst returned to Federal prison today to serve the rest of her sevenyear sentence for bank robbery.

description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 16 (AP)Despite losing his original ride, Willy T. Ribbs will have a car for World 600 qualifying at Charlotte Motor Speedway next week.

description: WASHINGTON, May 16The Defense Department placed the 82d Airborne Division and the Military Airlift Command on alert today for possible evacuation of American citizens from the combat area of Zaire.

description: V IDEO CITY, a new weekly series beginning tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock on WNYCTV, Channel 31. is tile hype of project that is doubtlessly significant beyond its tiny budget and obvious flaws. The core of the content consists of videotapes and films made by independent producers who, as group, never have had easy access to television, particularly to the commercial stations and networks.

title: Roy Cohn Strides Into Limelight, Again
description: I still live flamboyantly but I do it a little more quietly, said Roy Marcus Cohn, the wunderkind of the 1950's, corporate wheelerdealer of the 1960's, and playboy for all seasons His emerg`ence in characteristic style at the Ford Motor Company annual meeting last week raised the question of what he has been up to recently. Or at least, what he was doing before he took on the current stockholder suit against Ford and its chairman. Henry Ford 2d.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 16With Resorts International planning to open the nation's first gambling casino outside Nevada in 10 days, the problem of coping with expected monumental traffic jams Is one of the most pressing concerns in this resort city of 43,000.

description: Robert Strauss, President Carter's inflation adviser, made another pitch yesterday for his boss's antiinflation campaign. There is in this country today a psychology of I'll grab mine and run,' he said. That is what we have to stop if we are going to turn back the [inflationary] curve.

title: Carter Leads a Drive to Mollify Jewish Opponents of Arms Deal
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  President Carter and top figures of his Administration made scores of phone calls last night and today to key senators and leaders of the American Jewish community in an effort to reduce any negative political impact of the bruising struggle over the Middle East arms package.

Ross, a lawyer and social activist, who served as the first chairman of the New York City Rent Commission, made an unsuccessful race for Mayor as the American Labor Party candidate in 1950 and led the successful fight to integrate the Stuyvesant Town apartment complex, died Monday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 76 years old.

General Manager Dick Berg said it was done because the feeling was the Stompers were not headed in a positive direction. They have a 44 wonlost record.

title: Red Brigades Intimidates Italians But Fails in Effort to Start Civil War
description: ROME, May 16The Red Brigades terrorist organization has within a few months established itself as an effective military and political power in Italy, transfixing and intimidating the country and paralyzing its political leadership in an attempt to create a climate of civil war. The effect of the terrorists has been far beyond anyone's predictions, but there is no civil war today in Italy.

title: Financing Is No Problem For the Red Brigades
description: Money is no problem for the Red Brigades, according to police officials in Italy. Several kidnappings that netted high ransoms over the past years are now believed to have been the work of tevorists and not of common criminals, as was assumed at the time.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP)The Pentagon set in motion today the largest American arms sale to Japan in history, formally notifying Congress of plans to sell Japan 100 F15 fighters and 45 P3C antisubmarine planes for $2.2 billion.

title: ROBIN CRAVEN, ACTOR, 71; PLAYED ON STAGE AND TV
description: Robin Craven, an actor, died Monday in Roosevelt Hospital of a stroke and heart failure. He was 71 years old and lived in New York.

description: New York rateS  (AP)

title: What the Planes Buy
description: In refusing to block President Carter's package of jet fighter sales to Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the Senate has in effect ratified the contentions of Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford and now Jimmy Carter that the United States can uphold its commitment to Israel and at the same time enter into partnership with its moderate Arab neighbors. That partnership extends even to becoming, in the case of the Saudis, a main supplier of modern weaponsinterceptor aircraft as sophisticated as any in America's own Air Force. It is a sign of just how far the Middle East debate in this country has changed that virtually all the Senate's attention was focused on the 60 F15's promised to the Saudis; the sale of 50 less capable but nonetheless potent F5E's for Egypt sailed through without a mutter.

title: FITZSIMMONS AVOIDS PANEL ON CORRUPTION CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP)Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who has been accused of union corruption, avoided a meeting of his union's disciplinary panel today.

title: Zaire Sends in Paratroops
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 15 (Reuters)Zaire said today that it had dropped paratroops into the embattled coppermining area of Kolwezi to bolster its forces fighting for control of the town. The town's airport is reported held by insurgents, who are making their second attack in 14 months on the mineralrich southern province of Shaba.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Can you tell me the difference between baking soda and baking powder? Are all baking powders double acting? And are baking powder and baking soda interchangeable?

title: Training Grant for Conductors
description: A $3 million grant has been made by Lila Acheson Wallace to the Juilliard School to establish a longrange program for the development of young American conductors. The grant was announced yesterday by Peter Mennin, the school's president, who said in an interview that it would endow a permanent program that in its scope and ambition was probably unprecedented in the United States.

title: Minister in Texas Is Elected Presbyterian Moderator
description: SAN DIEGO, May 16The Rev. William P. Lytle. a pastor from San Antonio, today was elected moderator of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. by the 190th General Assembly of the church.

title: POPULAR WESTERN NOVELS MADE AVAILABLE IN CHINA
description: PEKING, May 16Love Story and The Catcher in the Rye, two American novels that treat sex in a candid way and were bestsellers in the West, have been available in translation to selected Chinese for several months, it has been learned.

title: Two Quakes Jolt Northern Japan
description: TOKYO, May 16 (Reuters)  Two moderate earthquakes jolted the Aomori area at the northern tip of the main Japanese island of Honshu today, injuring two persons, the police said.

title: 50 Black Civilians Killed in Crossfire In Rhodesian War
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 16The Rhodesian military command disclosed tonight that 50 black civilians were killed Sunday in a crossfire between guerrillas and Government troops. It was the highest civilian death toll in a single encounterin the fiveandahalfyearlong war.

title: Big Ten Sets Minimum VisitingTeam Share
description: EVANSTON, Ill., May 16 (AP)Big Ten athletic directors and faculty representatives today approved an agreement that assures visiting Big Ten football teams of receiving at least $100,000 from each conference game.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Going Out Guide
description: LADY OF MILWAUKEE In 1961, Eleanor Roosevelt proclaimed that henceforth and forevermore, HiIdegarde would retain the title, First Lady of the Supper Clubs, an accolade based on the singer's longtime residency at the Plaza Hotel's Persian Room, her recordings and her subsequent international tours. With her undaunted cheer and smart songstyling at the keyboard now spanning a 50year career, Hildegarde is today's Interlude star in the weekly, lateafternoon series at Town Hall, 113 West 43d Street, between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas.

title: Carter Names T.V.A. Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP)President Carter designated S. David Freeman today to be chairman of the board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority. Mr. Freeman has been a T.V.A. board member since last August.

title: Nixon Plans a Visit To Town in Kentucky
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., May 16 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon plans to visit a tiny eastern Kentucky town on July 2 to dedicate a recreational complex named for him, Representative Tim Lee Carter, Republican of Kentucky, said today.

title: Dane Rudhyar Receives $2,500 Composer's Award
description: Dane Rudhyar, 83yearold composer, has received the $2,500 Marjorie Peabody Waite award given every three years by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Leters to a composer for continuing integrity and achievement in his art. The Frenchborn musician, who came to the United States in 1916, not only composed but has written about music theory, philosophy and the occult and published books of poetry.

title: Koch Is Pressed on Queens Campus
description: The Queens delegations to the State Legislature and the City Council united in protest yesterday to put pressure on Mayor Koch for approval of a York College campus in the Jamaica section.

title: Jersey Energy Body Urges Increased Use Of Buses and Trains
description: NEWARK, May 16The State Department of Energy recommended today basic public transportation network that calls for a greater emphasis on rail and bus transportation and steps to limit the use of automobiles.

title: Chess:
description: You would expect the strongest player in town to have the inside track by knowing better than his foreign colleagues how to beat the local competition, but that is not how the script went in the Reykjavik International Tournament.

title: Ongais Hurt in Crash as Indy Reopens
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 16 (UPI).Danny Ongais, who hit 201.974 miles an hour in practice before rain closed the Indianapolis Motor Speedway tor three days, hit the wall in his backup car today after the track reopened. He suffered minor injuries.

title: Bill to Widen M.A.C. Power Gains, But Control Board May Face Delay
description: ALBANY, May 16Legislative negotiators were reported today to have ironed out some, but not all, of the difficulties involving a critical bill to expand the authority of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. Several aides said they were hopeful the legislation could be approved before the end of this week.

title: Schwenk Not Guilty On Charge of Theft From Suffolk G.O.P.
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 16 (UPI)A former Suffolk County Republican chairman, Edwin M. Schwenk, was found not guilty today of charges that he stole $245,000 in party funds during the nine years he headed the local political organization.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN IS REPORTED HEALTHY
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI)Tax increases that Congress passed last December have .restored the financial soundness of the nation's Social Security system until the year 2030, the Government said today.

title: Princeton Will Retain Policy on South Africa
description: PRINCETON, May 16Princeton University has decided not to sell the stock it holds in corporations that do business in South Africa, university officials announced today,

title: Harned Resigns Two Cessna Posts
description: Malcolm S. Harned, 57, resigned as president and chief operating officer of the Cessna Aircraft Company yesterday, to take the new position of senior vice president of technology. He also was dropped from the board.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Stock Exchange elected Terence J. Fox presideqnt and chief executive officer of Iroquois Brands Ltd. to a twoyear term as a public governor of the exchange.

title: Schwenk Not Guilty On Charges of Theft From Suffolk G.O.P.
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 16A former Republican leader of Suffolk County, Edwin M. Schwenk was found not guilty today of charges that he stole $245,000 from the County Republican Committee in the 10 years of his chairmanship.

title: Egypt Says Jet Decision Reopens Way to Peace Talks
description: CAIRO, May 16Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel said today that Cairo felt encouraged to continue its Middle East peace efforts because the Carter Administration's plan to sell jet fighters to Egypt and Saudi Arabia as well as to Israel had been approved.

title: Notes on People
description: AHUSBANDANDWIFE team of biochemists, Dr. James Miller and Dr. Elizabeth Miller, yesterday received the first annual $25,000 BristolMyers Award for Distinguished Achievement in Cancer Research. The Millers, who received their award in ceremonies at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, work at the University of Wisconsin's McArdle Laboratory for Cancer Research. They were honored for their discovery that most chemicals must first be activated within the body before they can cause cancer,. and cited as major contributors in the study of the causes of cancer.

title: Mayor Announces Plan to Merge 2 Hospitals in the South Bronx
description: Officials at two hospitals in the South Central Bronx yesterday announced they planned to merge the hospitals, but acknowledged that approval of the State Department of Health was required and that merging could take at least several months.

title: Blast Damages Ontario Hotel
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, May 16 (AP)An explosion damaged the Klondike Hotel and nearby buildings in downtown Niagara Falls early today. Fire officials said the blast was caused by a bomb but the police said they did not know yet what type of explosive device was used.

title: N.Y.U. Professor, Marxist Game Inventor, Finds Art Imitates Life
description: In Class Struggle, a new game that is a sort of Marxist version of Monopoly, man's fate in capitalist society is approximated by a roll of the dice that leads a player to instructions printed on a Chance Card. Rather, the card describes the reallife situation of the game's inventor, Bertell Oilman, a New York Unive.rsity associate professor whose appointment to head the politinal science department at the University of Maryland has become a major issue in Maryland's gubernatorial campaign.

description: The Eastman Kodak Company said In a court filing yesterday that its share of unit sales in the amateur market for conventional cameras declined sharply last year.

title: SOVIET JUDGE CURBS DISSIDENT'S DEFENSE
description: MOSCOW, May 16Fifteen witnesses for the prosecution were called today in the trial of Yuri F. Orlov, a dissident, but he was given only scant opportunity to question them, his wife said, and was Irefused permission to look at documents referred to in their testimony.

title: Yankees Win, 83; Holtzman Is Victor
description: CHICAGO, May, 16Ken Holtzman, who may have been making his last appearance in a Yankee uniform, picked up his first victory of the season tonight with the help of superb relief from Rich Gossage and a 14hit New York attack that produced an 83 triumph over the White Sox before a crowd of 21,837 at Comiskey Park.

title: William Steinberg, Orchestral Conductor, Dies at 78
description: William Steinberg, former music director of the Pittsburgh and Boston Symphony Orchestras, died in Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday morning. He had conducted the New York Philharmonic in a private concert in Avery Fisher Hall on May 1, and entered the hospital the following day. He had been ill off and on in recent years. He was 78 years old.

title: Pakistan Extends Bhutto Curb
description: KARACHI. Pakistan, May 16 (Reuters) The Pakistan military Government has extended for another month the period of house arrest imposed on Benazir Bhutto. the 24yearold daughter of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, an official spokesman said. Mr. Bhutto has been condemned to death on charges of having ordered a political killing three and a half years ago.

title: Personal Health

But most of all, snakes have been the objects of fear and disgust. Many think of snakes, especially poisonous snakes, as aggressive enemies that will attack man with little or no provocation.

title: Private Lives
description: SHAKESPEARE asked in Henry IV: What is honour? A word. What is that word honour? Air. A trim reckoning! Who hath it? He that died a Wednesday. Doth he feel it? No. Doth he hear it? No. Tis insensible then? Yea, to the dead. But will it not live with the living? No. Why? Detraction will not suffer it. Therefore I'll none of it. Honour is mere scutcheon  and so ends my catechism.

title: Books of The Times
description: NOT EVERYONE in Los Angeles is happy, according to Benjamin Stein's Dreemz, a diary of the author's first year June 1976 to August 1977working as a television scrptwriter for Norman Lear. The woman with bluegreen eyes who wants to live with Mr. Stein is probably not happy, because she can't seem to decide. whether to do something productive or let her soul nurture itself alone. Neither, one suspects, is Sybil, Mr. Stein's rich and glamourous Gentile friend, who tells him she will no longer go into Bloomingdale's in New York because Of the pushy, short, buxom women in the elevator with their New York accents. Definitely not happy are Mike the wheelerdealer and his girlfriend, Rhonda, who once planned to start a sort of babysitting service in which she would actually have the clients babies at $10,000 per. Mike and Rhonda are dead of drowning, after Mike had finally hit it big with a device that makes guitar riffs sound like they are being played on your spine. And as Ben Stein, who respects money, observes, Money is no good when you're dead.
