description: DETROIT. May 17  Hefty price tags still scare away the average buyer, but Cadillac, car maker for the carriage trade, says its buyers are getting younger, nearly 10 years younger. In good part, it has Congress and Mercedes Benz, a fcrmidable competitor, to thank for that.

title: Study Shows That CityRaised Crops Are Not Harmful to Health
description: IS URBAN vegetable gardening hazardous to your health? Not in New York City, suggests a recent study by Cornell University's Cooperative Extension, which directs the New York City urban gardening program.

title: A Correction
description: In an article in The Home Section last week about Conran's, the retail store, Pauline Dora was incorrectly identified. She is the vice president in charge of buying for Conran's.

title: Bias Suit May Cost University $1 Million
description: PROVIDENCE, May 17 (AP)  A Brown University official said today that a major sex discrimination suit that was settled out of court last fall would probably cost the Ivy League school as much as $1 million.

title: Lord SelwynLloyd Dies at 73, A Key Briton During Suez Crises
description: LONDON, May 17  Lord SelwynLloyd, who as Foreign Secretary in 1956 was a key figure in the attack on the Suez Canal by British, French and Israeli forces, died today at his home in Oxfordshire. He was 73 years old.

title: Advertising
description: Ally & Gargano will be losing the domestic advertising account of Pan American World Airways and the J. Walter Thompson Company may be losing Pan Am's international business, the airline said yesterday.

title: CARTER'S WATER PLAN BACKEDBYGOVERNORS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Six Western Governors today told President Carter that they agreed in principle with his suggestion that states share in the cost of building large Federal water projects in their areas.

title: DOMINICAN SOLDIERS HALT THE COUNTING INPRESIDENTIAL VOTE
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 17  The Dominican Army today interrupted the counting of votes in an election that appeared to he going against President Joaquin Balaguer. The opposition candidate, Antonio Guzimn of theleftist Dominican Revolutionary Party, was reported to be far ahead when troops and policemen took control of the election center shortly after 4 A.M.

title: Money Rates
description: New York rates(AP)

title: G.0 P. TRIED TO STOP JET DEAL TO WIN JEWS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Before the Senate voted Monday to uphold President Carter's decision to sell jet fighters to Egypt and Saudi Arkbia, as well as to Israel, the Republican national chairman and the head of the party's Senate campaign committee urged Senate Reblicans to oppose the plan, arguing that opposition could dislodge Jews from the Democratic Party.

title: Jersey to Use Computer to Reduce Traffic TieUps in 8 Counties by 81
description: TRENTON, May 17  By 1981, automobiles in eight northeastern New Jersey counties will be guided around traffic jams and congested areas by a $17.4 million computer system now under design, the State Department of Transportation said today.

title: Disclosure Delay Asked by Curtiss
description: The Curtiss Wright Corporation asked the Federal Appeals Court in New York yesterday to bar disclosure of the winner in the proxy fight for control of the Kennecott Copper Corporation.

title: House Panel Reverses Itself, Bars a Social Security Tax Cut This Year
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The prospect of a cut in Social Security taxes this year all but evaporated today as the House Ways and Means Committee reversed itself and reiected such a move.

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION:

title: A SECOND pia UNIT IN SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17For the second time In a week, a band of guerrillas moved into southern Lebanese territory held by United Nations peacekeeping troops today and refused to leave.

title: DR. WALTER R. MILES, 93; A PIONEER IN PSYCHOLOGY
description: Dr. Walter Richard Miles, a pioneer in psychology, died Monday at the Friend's House Nursing Home in Sandy Spring, Md. He was 93 years old.

title: Calendar of Events for the Home
description: The Craftsman's Gallery, 16 Chase Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Bronx Violence Creates Special Problem for Hospital
description: About half of the 500 brain and spinal injuries treated at the Bronx Municipal hospital Center in the last six months were caused by violence, A ratio that hospital officials described as exceedingly high.

title: Incomes Up 1.4% in April In Big Rise
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  The combined personal income of all Americans increased 1.4 percent in April at an annual rate, a further sign of strong economic growth, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Helping New York City to Master Itself
description: No exsinner likes to be told he can't be trusted out without a chaperone. The more angrily he resists, the more others are likely to believe he has not yet earned his freedom. The continuing opposition, by New York's union chiefs and some state and municipal officials, to extending the life of the Emergency Financial Control Board arouses suspicions that the city still needs this guardianship. Unquestionably it does, but the controls

title: Sonics Down Nuggets and Gain Final
description: SEATTLE, May 17  Ahead by 21 points going into the fourth quarter, the Seattle SuperSonics tonight went on to a 123.108 victory over the Denver Nuggets that put them in the final round of the National Basketball Association playoffs for the first time in their 11year existence. They eliminated the Nuggets, four games to two, just as they had eliminated the defending champion, Portland, by the same margin in the preceding round,

title: F.C.C. Acts On Minority Broadcasting
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The Federal Communications Commission today adopted two policies designed to give preference to members of minority groups who want to buy radio and television stations.

title: DOMINICAN SOLDIERS HALT THE COUNTING IN PRESIDENTIAL VOTE
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 17  The Dominican Army today interrupted the counting of votes in an election that appeared to be going against President Joaquin Balaguer. The opposilien candidate, Antonio Guzman of the leftist Dominican Revolutionary Party, was reported to be far ahead when troops and policemen took control of the election center shortly after 4 AM.

title: Dr. J. Stauffer Lehman, 37, Expert On Diseases Occurring in Tropics
description: Dr. Stauffer Lehman, who headed a tropicaldiseases research program for the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation, died Monday at his home at 11 Riverside Drive. He was 37 years old.

title: COMPANY ROUNDUP
description: The Folger Coffee Company, a unit of the Procter & Gamble Company, said yesterday that it would suspend at once all purchases of coffee from Uganda. The Nestle Company and the Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation, meanwhile, said that they had already discontinued purchase of coffee from the East African nation in light of requests made by members of Congress.

title: Rebels Said to Gain
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 17 (AP)  Rebel tribesmen were reported gaining ground today in southern Zaire. stranding 2,500 foreigners behind their lines.

title: Q &
description: Q. Our new house has lovely builtin walnut bookcases in the library. The shelves, however, are sticky in the corners and along the sides, and books along the ends of each shelf are difficult to pry loose. Can you tell me what I can do to prevent the books from sticking? Mrs. L.A.S., Allentown, Pa.

title: Another Austrian Climbs Everest
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 17 (AP)  A ninth member of an Austrian expedition has climbed Mount Everest, the Ministry of Tourism said today. The Austrian Frank Oppurge, reached the summit on Sunday.

title: Bridge:
description: Some of the 40 stars in the Cavendish Invitation Individual here Tuesday night proceeded at a snail's pace, which had a double impact on the scoring process.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar continued to hold its ground yesterday against such major currencies as the West German mark, the Swiss franc and the yen, but currency watchers warned again that its strength was resting more on faith than facts.

title: Piano: Bolcom Concerto
description: THE GRAND synthesis of the popular and serious music traditions in America, which once seemed not only possible but desirable and necessary, does not have many audible champions these days. A kind of Berlin wall, built up as a result of generations of failure and disappointment, now appears to divide the two traditions. Only a few worrywart Hegelians even raise the old question of rapprochement.

title: Music: Cosmopolitan Closes Its Season
description: THE Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra closed its 14th season Monday night with an annual scholarship benefit concert in Avery Fisher Hall. Although principally designed to give young musicians experience in orchestral performance, the Cosmopolitan almost always gives good musical value. And this concert, under the direction of Yuri Krasnapolsky, was no exception.

title: Four From Bar Harbor Airlines Die as Plane Splits Over Maine
description: TRENTON, Me., May 17 (AP)  Two top officials of Bar Harbor Airlines and two of the airline's pilots perished in a fiery 11 crash when their plane split apart and burst into flames, the state police said.

title: Close Encounter of `Cannibalizing Kind
description: Los ANGELES

title: North to Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17 (AP)  The Dodgers and the A's swapped center fielders who weren't playing regularly in a trade that sent Bill North to Los Angeles and Glenn Burke to Oakland late last ight.

title: Home Beat
description: IF YOU went to a lawyer  feeling as people claim they do about lawyers these days  you'd hardly expect to end up liking him so much that you went into business together, would you?

title: The Jackson High School Decision: Patterns of Segregation and the Unanswered Question
description: The Federal Court decision on Tuesday ordering the integration of Andrew Jackson High School in Queens was clearly a victory for civilrights advocates, but in the opinion of legal experts the decision fell short of setting a significant precedent for future school desegregation cases in New York City and the country.

title: Danish Beer Brewing A Task for Academicians
description: COPENHAGEN  Carlsberg and Tuborg, Denmark's two internationally known beers, are produced by a brewery with an unusual board of directors.

title: Insider Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Excha nges yesterday released their latest reports of trading in listed shares by major stockholders. directors and officers. The lists include the following:

title: Gasoline Output Rises in Week
description: Gasoline production and stocks of distillate rose in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute renorted yesterday.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON  The Amtrak office here is not the happiest place these days. Last week, Transportation Secretary Brock Adams outlined a plan for virtually dismembering the rail system, and Amtrak executives learned of the Administration proposal only two hours before it was publicly announced.

title: Puerto Rican Youth, 16, Who Collapsed on Street Has OpenHeart Surgery
description: Jose Bonilla, a penniless 16yearold youth who collapsed on a Brooklyn street two weeks after he arrived from Puerto Rico to make a new life in New York, underwent openheart surgery yesterday at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Design Notebook
description: THE old Horn & Hardart Automats may never have been the Four Seasons, but they were nonetheless palaces in their own way. Most of them squatted selfconfidently in the midtown Manhattan streetscape, rounded masses of pinkish stone with a distinct air of monumentality to them  an air enhanced by the twostoryhigh dining spaces, complete with balconies, which most of them sported.

title: City Is Reported To Offer Unions A Raise of 8%
description: With a Saturday deadline for a contract sett!ement looming, New York City was reported to have increased its wage offer yesterday to a coalition of municipal unions to 8 percent over two years.

title: Stein Cites Con Ed for Conflicts
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan has charged the Consolidated Edison Company with serious conflicts of interest in charitable contributions, legal payments and directors fees, which he said had been made at reate payer's expense, a number of its directors denied that th

title: Sidney G. Roth, 65, N.Y.U. Official On Leave With Energy Department
description: Sidney G. Roth, on leave recently from New York University as vice chancellor for Federal relations, died Tuesday in his home in Washington. He was 65 years old and had a home in Manhattan at 29 Washington Square West.

title: 700 Practice Betting at Atlantic City Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 17  Gambling at the green tables of the Resorts International Hotel began tonight, but neither genuine highrollers nor born losers were present. Fake money was used, and winning and losing were only states of mind.

title: Two Cities in Italy, Worlds Apart, Both Feel Impact of Social Crisis
description: PALERMO, Sicily  Socially, politically, economically and temperamentally, Palermo and Bologna are at opposite ends of the intricate Italian tapestry.

title: Publishers Groups Make Plea for Orlov
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va.  The Association of American Publishers and the international Publishers Association, in.,the first such coordinated action this year, have sent a message to the head of the Soviet Union calling for a fair and open trial for ,Yuri Orlov, who has been brought to court after 15 months in prison because of his socalled antiSoviet agitation.

title: Buying a Corporate Toehold
description: Over the last few years, the American Financial Corporation, a relatively unkrown Ohio insurance holding company. has invested some $30 million in the Combined Communications Corporation.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Books of The Times
description: VIOLET CLAY, in Gail Godwin's new novel, is an orphan and a Southern girl who leaves home and husband for New York at age 24 to become a great painter. Nine years later, after the usual assortment Of not very interesting men  a hairdresser, a Hungarian and an oboist  all that she paints are covers on Gothic romances for a paperback publishing house. One lousy day, the oboist having run off to Norway, she loses her job and is told by telephone that Uncle Ambrose, the failed novelist, has committed suicide in a cabin in the Adirondacks. First Violet goes to Brooklyn Heights, and then she goes to the Adirondacks.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Markets

title: NEW &
description: It's just about time for people with summer homes to think about getting them ready for the season. Those lucky folks  and anyone who's moving into a new apartment should take a look at some new zipon furniture created by the Danish designer Neils Bendtsen for Design Research.

title: Russian Scientist Forecasts Vast Colonies in Space
description: MOSCOW, May 17 (AP)  A leading Soviet astrophysicist has forecast that within 250 years it will be possible to construct a vast artificial biosphere in outer space capable of supporting 10 billion people, more than twice the world's present population.

title: Westport Appro ves Building Of First Apartment Houses
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Nay 17  This welltodo community of onefamily homes, practically the prototype of suburban affluence, decided today to permit the construction of its first apartment houses.

title: SHAH OF IRAN FACING GROWING OPPOSITION
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 16  After four days of bloody riots in major Iranian cities last week, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is facing the strongest opposition to his rule in 15 years.

title: What's Shut on Which Memorial Day
description: Some call it Memorial Day, others call it Decoration Day. Some will be off Monday, May 29, this year to celebrate it, others Tuesday, May 30. A tiny, lucky few will be off both days, and there are also those who do not know yet which day they will get.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BANK DEPOSITS The public is invited to a threeweek display of works by more than 40 artists, writers and composers who were honored yesterday at the annual ceremony of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, 633 West 155th Street, near Riverside Drive. Free viewing hours are 1 to 4 P.M., excluding Tuesdays. Among the artists represented are Robert Rauschenberg, Clyfford Still and Marisol, in painting and sculpture; and Cesar Pelli, architect. On view will be manuscripts from Joyce Carol Oates, Donald Barthelme, Renata Adler and Barbara Tuchman, among those cited for literature; and Jacob Druckman and George Perle, in music.

title: Cosmos Suffer First Loss
description: The Cosmos suffered their first defeat of the season last night, bowing to the Portland Timbers, a shootout, The loss ended the Cosmos winning streak at seven, Details, Page D23,

title: House Bars Bid to Kill Neutron Weapon Fund
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  The House today rejected, 306 to 90, an attempt to kill funds for producing neutron warheads.

title: Boe Is Sued Again for Nets Money
description: Roy L. M. Boe, whose Islander hockey team and Nets basketball team have been threatened by lawsuits and debts, was the subject of another multimilliondollar actinn yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: ACKERMANBessie. Devoted mother of Irving Krifchmar, Rochelle Rothpearl, and Toni Kirschenbaum. Adored grandmother and greatgrandmother. May IS, 1978. Services Thursday. May 18, 1 PM, at Garlick's Funeral Home, 1496 Unionport Road, Bronx.

title: Stocks Up As Dollar Holds Firm
description: Stock prices climbed to another eightmonth high on extremely heavy volume yesterday amid encouraging signs in the credit markets and steady dollar in foreign exchange dealings.

title: Stalingrad Heroism in the Bronx
description: Recently, while arranging a seminar, I was told by the information officer of an embassy that I shall not name here that, although they would like to be represented, they could not find anyone from their office to go to the Bronx.

title: Los Angeles Solution: Insurance
description: ATHENS, May 17  After meeting with the International Olympic Committee for more than two hours here today, Mayor Tom Wadley of Los Angeles repeated his conviction that his city would stage the Summer Olympic Games of 1984. The award is expected to be made tomorrow.

title: Tongsun Park Leaves, for U.S.
description: Seoul, South Korea, May 17 (Reuters)  Tongsun Park left here today to resumf, his testimony in the United States on alleged Korean influence buying in. Con. gress. The South Korean businessman re turned here last month after an eight. week visit on which he testified beforc the ethics committees of both the Senaaw and House of Representatives.

title: Madrid Seems Disenchanted By Year of PreDemocracy
description: MADRID, May 17  A year ago, Madrid tingled with excitement. Walls and buildings were papered with the sp. peals and promises of newly legalized political parties. Rallies were heavily attended as politicians and organizations strained to cross from repression or obscurity, or both, to legitimacy via the historic parliamentary elections of June 15. 1977.

title: S.E.C. Assails Bill on Customer Bank Record Confidentiality
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The Securities and Exchange Commission warned a Senate subcommittee today that legislation designed to protect the confidentiality of customers bank records would cripple the agency's enforcement program.

title: Giants Win 7th in Row As Blue Halts Cubs, 95
description: Although Vida Blue was not exactly overpowering, the San Francisco Giants gained their seventh successive victory yesterday, beating the Chicago Cubs, 95. Blue posted his sixth triumph in seven decisions.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Malverne Voters Again Reject Plan to Pay for Busing of Blacks
description: MALVERNE, L.I., May 17  For the 10th time in seven years, residents last night turned down a proposal to provide funds to bus 400 black students to two predominantly while elementary schools. The vote, on an $8.6 million school budget, was 1,404 to 1.209.

title: Eritreans in Rome Report Rebels Still Block Ethiopians in Asmara
description: ROME, May 17 (Reuters)  Eritrean rebel representatives here said today that heavy fighting continued for a third day in the disputed Ethiopian province, with the insurgents. blocking Government troops from breaking out of the provincial capital.

title: Home Improvement
description: AHOME driveway or walk that is paved with asphalt  usually referred to as blacktop should last almost indefinitely  if it installed properly over a solid base of gravel and compacted soil, and if it gets the needed maintenance. If minor cracks and similar defects are neglected, particularly in cold climates where the ground is subjected to frequent freezeandthaw cycles, the condition of the blacktop will worsen and large sections may eventually need replacement.

title: U.S. Preparing Moves To Increase Exports
description: HOT SPRINGS. .Va., May 17  The United States, trying to overcome the mertia of a huge domestic market that absorbs most of its factor,,  output. is lively mobilizing a national effort to spur exports and thereby narrow the gap between what it buys abroad a d what it sells.

title: Mets Bow, 21
description: A winning sixhit pitching performance by Nino Espinosa following a losing but impressive one by Jerry Koosman gave the New York Mets a split in a doubleheader with the Atlanta Braves last. night at chilly Shea Stadium.

title: EDWARD R. HITZ
description: Edward R. Hitz. who retired n 1961 as a vice president and general sales p7ecutive of NTtCTV, died .'aturdey at his home in Tequesta, Fla., of a heart atack. he was 77 years old and formerly lived in Bronxville, N.Y., and Westport, Conn.

title: Most Americans Said to Leave Zaire War Zone
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The State Department said today that 77 of the 88 Americans caught up in the invasion of Zaire by Katangan exiles had been moved out of the combat area, practically eliminating the possibility of a rescue operation by American paratroopers.

title: Intercity Bus Midwestern Utility Wins Losing Out, $15 Million Judgment
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The Interstate Commerce Commission reported today that weakness in the intercity bus industry and diminishing profits must be viewed with concern by the industry and the Government.

title: Shortages Said to Weaken British Army of Rhine
description: BRUSSELS, May 17  Low standards of equipment, restricted training resulting in a decrease in readiness, a shortage of transport for reserve units and the continuing drain imposed by operations in Northern Ireland have combined to reduce the quality of the British Army of the Rhine.

title: Screening of Workers Proposed For Detection of Possible Cancer
description: PATERSON, May 17  A state health official said today that New Jersey was seeking Federal support for a widespread screening of worIrs in the rubber, chemical and petrochemical industries for early detection of possible bladder cancer.

title: Raid Nets 5 Tons of Marijuana
description: MIAMI, May 17 (UPI)  Agents for the Florida Department of Criminal Law Enforcement confiscated an estimated 51/2 tons of marijuana in a raid on a southwestern Miami residence early today, the department said. Maria Sanchez, 29 years old, and Bruno Carlos Garcia, 33, were arrested and charged with possession of more than 100 pounds of marijuana with intent to sell. They were later released on bond.

title: ORLOV'S WIFE SAYS POLICE STRIPPED HER
description: MOSCOW, May 17  Irina Orlov said today that she had been stripped in front of three men and forcibly searched as she left the courthouse where her husband, Yuri, is being tried for publicizing Soviet violations of human rights.

title: 700 Bet Fake Money as Atlantic City's Casino Warms Up
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 17  Gambling at the green tables of the Resorts International Hotel began tonight, but neither genuine highrollers nor born losers were present. Fake money was used, and winning and losing were only states of mind.

title: Houston Man Says Saudis Held Him for 6 Months
description: HOUSTON, May 17  A Houston businessman who said he escaped from Saudi Arabia inside a packing crate aboard an airliner several days ago has charged that the Saudis had detained him against his will since November.

title: An American in Paris: The Eclectic Spirit
description: PARIS

title: Disks: Obscure Mozart
description: OF MOZART'S 19 completed stage works, only five or six can be said to hold places in international repertory. The reason usually adduced for this neglect is that the genre known as opera seria, with its stylized formality and emphasis on vocal pyrotechnics, went out or fashion in Mozart's later years, taking into near oblivion most of his operatic output.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  As one of President Carter's principal advisers on economic matters and their political implications, Vice President Mondale regularly speaks for the Administration before business groups. He will do so tomorrow before the Economic Club of New York, and he often serves as the Administration's link to individual businessmen. He was interviewed here on some of the key questions he has faced.

title: Gardening: A Sampling of Sources for the Spring Planter
description: THE gardener's shopping season is on and neophytes might benefit from a few pointers on how to carry it off with aplomb.

title: The State Troopers and the Gamble
description: In 1971, New Jersey's state troopers gambled  and lost. The Internal Revenue Service warned them that considered their $15aday meal allowances to be taxable income. But the troopers, confident that the I.R.S. interpretation would be upset in court, continued to treat the allowances as reimbursement of business expenses and paid no income tax on it. The troopers position prevailed

title: About New York
description: In a way, Mayor Koch has found a perfect mirrorimage audience in Queens  sharp, cocky, selfcentered and blunt to the point of insult  and we should be happy for him as he thrusts and parries, one against one thousand, the Douglas Fairbanks of urban dialectic.

title: Jury Gets Case of ExU.S. Official And Student Accused of Espionage
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 17  The espionage case of a former United States Information Agency official and a parttime graduate student accused of spying for Vietnam went to a Federal jury toI night.

title: Around the Nation
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 17 (UPI)  The Texas Supreme Court ruled today that the children of illegal aliens living in Texas do not have a constitutional right to free public education.

title: Bruins Bet on Cheevers, Gambling Man
description: BOSTON. May 17  They call Gerry Cheerers a money player because the 37yearold Boston Bruins goalie seems to be at his best when the stakes are the highest.

title: Judge Roberts's Conduct at Trial Is Criticized by Appellate Court
description: Judge Burton B. Roberts was sharply criticized yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court for clearly improper behavior that might have eiudiced the jury in the trial of a man convicted of manslaughter.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets became somewhat more convinced yesterday that the Federal Reserve was not about to raise shortterm interest rates another notch right away, and fixedincome prices rose fairly sharply although trading activity remained generally confined to bond dealers themselves.

title: Notes on People
description: WHILE announcing yesterday that he would run for a third term, Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate minority leader, left the door open to run for the Presidency in two years. He made the annucement in the backyard of his ranchstyle home in the small town of Huntsville, in East Tennessee. Mr. Baker, mentioned recently by Bill Brock, the Republican national chairman, as one of three prime Republican contenders for the Presidency, said, I am not laying the groundwork to run for President, but aded, If I am elected to the Senate and if there is opportunity to run for President later, I would consider it then, but not until then.

title: U.S. Aides Favor Sale by Allies of Arms to China
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  High officials in the Carter Administration are now inclined to favor the sale of certain defensive weapons to China by West European countries.

title: HOBART G. WEEKES, 77, A NEW YORKER EDITOR
description: Hobart Godfrey Weekes, the arbiter of style in word usage at The New Yorker during most of its history, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: A Black Is Confirmed As U.S. Judge in South
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)  The Senate confirmed the nomination of Robert F. Collins as a Federal District judge today. He is the first black to be named to the Federal bench in the South.

title: First Women Join the White House Honor Guard
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  A few military curmudgeons probably grumbled about nothing being sacred anymore, but the White House honor guard went coed today.

title: The Answer Is Not in Africa
description: Hardly a day passes without some new violent episode among the tribes of Africa as they struggle to preserve or to alter the boundaries inherited from their old colonial masters. Ethiopians are on the march against their longrebellious province_ of Eritrea. Rebellious Xatangans, now called Shabas, are reviving the battle break free of Zaire, the former Belgian Congo, or least to topple its central Government, led by President Mobutu.

title: France: New Step on Path to Austerity
description: PARIS, May 17  France's recently reelected conservative Government took a step today toward carrying out a new policy of encouraging French industry to become more profitable and Competitive, despite mounting evidence that it could bring on more unemployment.

title: But There Is No Peace
description: JERUSALEM, May 17  It is six months since Anwar Sadat came Lo Jerusalem. Trying to find traces of last November's euphoria is already political archeology: dusty work. The blunt truth is that, in Israel, the Sadat initiative looks iust about dead.

title: 11 STATES SET TO APPEAL THE 15CENT POSTAGE RATE
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 17 (UPI)  The Deputy Attorney General of Maine, Donald G. Alexander, said today that he would represent 10 states in appealing final approval of the proposed increase from 13 cents to 15 cents in postage for a firstclass letter.

title: Wiz Film Premiere Oct. 24 to Aid Astoria Studio
description: To stimulate motionpicture making at the Astoria Motion picture and Television Production Center, proceeds from the world premiere of the movie The Wiz will be donated to the center for its maintenance and improvement.

title: Assembly Votes Stiffer Penalties for Youth Violence
description: ALBANY, May 17  The Democraticcontrolled Assembly today approved package of bills designed to toughen penalties against juveniles who commit violent crimes, and Governor Carey announced a proposal for $52 million in additicnal spending this year on the state's criminaljustice system.

title: Table of Proposals on Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Following is a table showing President Carter's budget proposals for the fiscal year 1979, starting .Oct. 1. and the ceiling figures proposed by Congress for the same items. The numbers are in billions.

title: 24% Rise Noted in Complaints of Police Corruption
description: A substantial increase in the number of complaints of corruption against police officers in the first three months of rais year was disclosed yesterday by the New York City Police Department. But officials emphasized that they did not Believe that the increase necessarily indicated an emerging corruption problem within the department.

title: City Is Reported To Offer Unions A Raise of 8%
description: With a Saturday deadline for a contract settlement looming, New York City was reported to have increased its wage offer yesterday to a coalition of municipal unions from 6 to 8 percent over two years.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: 9 Restaurants Termed Violators Of the New York City Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday cited nine restaurants that have violated the health code, and three restaurants that have corrected earlier violations. The restaurants were listed as follows:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Energy Department recommended yesterday that energy facilities not he located in the Fine Barrens or barrier islands.

title: Running Against Hoover
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The illconsidered decision of the Carter Administration to prosecute former F.B.I. officials, and to discipline present F.B.I. agents, for using questionable but longtolerated investigative techniques in order to stop the terrorist bombers of the Weather Underground, has begun to backfire.

title: White House Denies Israeli Lobby Insult By Hamilton Jordan
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The White House denied today that Hamilton Jordan, a Presidential aide, or any other official had threatened to break the back of the Israeli lobby as the sale of warplanes to the Middle East was being debated.

title: New Mroderator Of the United Presbyterian Church
description: SAN DIEGO, MayAs the Rev. William P. Lytle today began his first news conference as the newly elected moderator of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., a blaring recording of a song from the show Godspell arose from an adjoining room to drown his words.

title: Haitnik's Beethoven
description: WE have had them before, we shall have them again. Last night, the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam started a sixconcert series in Carnegie Hall that will take in the nine Beethoven symphonies and the five piano concertos. Bernard Haitink is the conductor, Vl&dimir Ashkenazy the pianist.

title: State Purchasing Plan Said to Cost Millions in Excess Vendor Charges
description: TRENTON, May 17  An independent jobber told the State Divisionof Purchasing and Property today that its buying procedures  designed to save money  were actually c sting government ageniies millions of dollars a year in exiess charges.

title: Blacksmiths Make Art Out of Metal
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.

title: Classes at Boys Club Compliments of a Chef
description: Bcrdros Jivekian's tatooed arms and genial ship cook's manner put off thoughts of mutiny by his newest recruits, despite their misgivings about the Armenian dishes he had asked them to taste.

title: Music: Peter Zummo
description: PETER ZUMMO, a composer and trombonist, presented the last concert in the Dance Theater Workshop's initial contemporary music series Tuesday night. His ensemble, Zummo Labs  three percussionists, a marimba, trumpet and trombone  has been together for some time now, and the music, although it still has some loose ends dangling, is beginning to sound interesting.

title: 3Year Financing Likely for Public TV
description: The public  broadcasting industry, which had hoped for legislation that would repeat the present fiveyear Federal financing authorization, will instead receive a threeyear authorization under House and Senate bills thought to be likely to be enacted late next month.

title: Ohio Court Orders New Trial For Man Charged in 11 Killings
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 17 (UPI)  The Ohio Supreme Court today ordered a new trial for James U. Ruppert. 43 years old, who was convicted of murdering 11 members of his family on Easter in 1975.

title: Indians Beat Yanks In 10 Innings, 5 to 4
description: CLEVELAND, May 17  The Yankees, whose bats had sprayed 55 hits in five games in Kansas City and Chicago, ran into an unlikely stopper tonight at Municipal Stadium, Sid Monge, a seldomused lefthander who throws sidearmed, held them scoreless with one hit in 6 13 innings of relief as the Indians topped the Yankees, 54, in 10 innings.

title: Business People
description: The Milstein brothers, Seymour and Paul, ,Ito ncved into positions of power in the troubled United Brands Comnany after the suicide of Eli M. Black, then president of the company, in 1975, moved into the two top jobs in the company yesterday.

title: Stage: Vilodiglianf Depicts Torment
description: NEGLECTED in his lifetime, abusing himself with drugs and drinking, Amedeo Modigliani was a classic case of the tormented, tempestuous artist. Three years younger than Picasso, he died al tuberculosis in 1920 at the age of 36. Posthumously, he was recognized for his greatness.

title: Most Americans Said to Leave Zaire War Zone
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The State Department said today that 77 of the 88 Americans caught up in the invasion of Zaire by Katangan exiles had been moved out of the combat area, practically eliminating the possibility of a rescue operation by American paratroopers.

title: Cash Prices
Poor Congressmen
description: What does poor now mean in America? Washington's officially defined poverty level was raised recently; for an urban family of four it is now $6,200. Meanwhile, some members of the House of Representatives would have us believe that for them, the poverty level is $66,125 and they are entitled to more. Can they serious?

title: Westport Votes for Zoning Change To Permit Building of Apartments
description: WESTPORT, Conn., May 17  This welltodo community of onefamily homes, practically the prototype of suburban affluence, decided today to permit the construction of its first apartment houses.

title: Wallace's Withdrawal Sets Off Power Struggle in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 17  After 16 years in the shadow of George C. Wallace, state politicians today began the battle for a share of the dominance that the Alabama Governor has held alone since he took office in 1962 with the promise to preserve segregation forever.

title: INDOCHINA FIGHTING BREAKS OUT AGAIN
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 17  Heavy; fighting has once more broken out along; a broad front on the VietnameseCambo; dian border, according to wellinformed. Western sources.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (UPI)  Danny Ongais, who crashed into a wail 24 hours earlier, led the speed parade today in practice for this weekend's raindelayed time trials for the Indianapolis 500.

title: Ballet: De la Pena, Nutcracker Prince
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV provides American Ballet Theater's younger, newer dancers with a chance to shine, in the second act divertissements of his The Nutcracker. The twoact ballet is full of amusing and acutely observed dramatic moments as well. And so the choice of George de la Pena for the lead male role of the Nutcracker Prince seems appropriate. From his first moments in the company's corps de ballet three and a half years ago, Mr. de la Pena distinguished himself as a firstTate young dramatic dancer.

title: Hers
description: FOR many years I had little difficulty, indeed I took a certain exhibitionistic thrill, saying, in the jazziest way I could, that I got drunk all the time and used speed. To admit, even to myself, that I was an alcoholic was quite different, such a charged connotation of shame and hopelessness that word carried. Now alcoholism is mostly accepted as a disease, something on the order of asthma, a chronic thing like diabetes. One has it and one learns how to deal with it.

title: Guitar: Manuel Barrueco
description: MANUEL BARRUECO, a 25yearold Cuban guitarist who teaches at the Manhattan School of Music, has been praised in previous recitals for his technical finesse, but he has also been accused of not exploiting satisfactorily the coloristic possibilities of his instrument. On Tuesday night in Alice Tully Hall, he seemed to be making up for this deficiency in the second part of the program, where he played works by Granados and Albeniz that would test his tonal range.

title: Park Slope Will Host a Brownstone Tour
description: Underneath all those coats of paint, promised a member of the Park Slope Civic Council, is bird'seye maple from the turn of the century.

title: Two Pittsburgh Politicians to Vie For Pennsylvania's Governorship
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 17  Pennsylvania voters chose two Pittsburgh politicians yesterday to oppose each other in the gubernatorial race this fall, ousted a 10term Congressman and picked an obscure biology teacher to run for Lieutenant Governor.

title: COMMODITIES
description: All platinum futures advanced the daily permissible limit of $10 an ounce or $500 for a contract of 50 ounces on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Brokers attributed the strength, which had been building gradually since November, to tight supplies.

title: Backgammon:
description: Two of England's tofrrated players, Lewis Deyong and Alan Lorenz, met in the finals of last month's international tournament in St. Tropez, France. Rarely do the same two players ever meet in the finals more than once: remarkably, this was the third such encounter between Deyong and Lorenz in major competitions in less than a year. In this yearlong rivalry, the record was tied until Deyong took first place in St.. Tropez with a narrow 1312 victory.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Mike Douglas Show Moving Closer to the Stars
description: The Mike Douglas Show, one of television's longestrunning talk series, will be leaving Philadelphia for Hollywood in pursuit of greater proximity to stars, it was announced yesterday by the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company.

title: Dividends
CORRECTION
description: A company that said earlier this week that it had received permission from the Japanese Finance Ministry to acquire interests in two American insurance companies was incorrectly identified in The Times Tuesday as the Tokyo Fire and Marine Insurance Companyi, In fact it was the DalTokyo Fire and Marine Insurance Company, .

title: EARNINGS
description: The International Harvester Company, a leading producer of farm equipment, trucks and construction and industrial equipment, reported yesterday a 23 percent jump in earnings for the April quarter on a 9 percent sales gain.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Wednesday, May 17, 1978

title: Scouts Refuse to Ease Rules For Youngsters With Handicaps
description: PHOENIX, May 17 (UPI)  The Boy Scouts of America, holding its annual convention in Phoenix, says it will not lower its merit badge requirements for handicapped youngters.

title: Dance:Solosby the Ailey
description: SOLOS are risky. While good solo dances can be revelations of a performer's technique, temperament and stage presence, the indifferently choreographed solo is trap. No matter how talented a performer may be, it is always difficult to transcend choreographic limitations.

title: MITCHELLLAMA AID PROPOSED BY CAREY CALLS FOR RENT RISES
description: ALBANY, May 17  Governor Carey will propose that the financially troubled MitchellLama housing program be bailed out by raising the rents of residents who earn more than the state median income  $17,200 a year. At the same time, Mr. Carey will propose that the state subsidize residents who earn less than that so that their rents will be no more than onequarter of their incomes.

title: Rhodesia Challenged by Witnesses On How Blacks Died in Shooting
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 17  Accounts by witnesses today sharply disputed yesterday's official Rhodesian account of the deaths of 50 civilians who the Government said had been caught in crossfire Sunday between security forces and guerrillas holding a political meeting. The witnesses, blacks who said they had been at the meeting, reported there had been only a single armed guerrilla at the gathering, that there had been no firing by anyone other than Government soldiers and that 94 rather than 50 civilians had been killed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A group of 12 fire marshals and 12 police officers has been set up to combat arson in the Bronx. The group, known as the Bronx Coordinated Arson Project, will work out of District Attorney Mario Merola's office to provide aroundtheclock coverage of suspicious fires, Mr. Merola said.

title: Market Place
description: THE CONAIR CORPORATION reported earlier this week that its firstquarter earnings had dropped dramatically to 2 cents a share from the 29 cents reported a year earlier, and some analysts wondered whether another company with fortunes closely tied to a single consumer product was about to fade.

title: Energy Talks Called Of f
description: WASHINGTON. May 17 (AP)  Despite intensive lobbying efforts, Congressional energy leaders found themselves today still a few votes short on a proposed natural gas compromise and canceled a showdown session on the measure.

title: SHAH OF IRAN FACING GROWING OPPOSITION
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 16  After four days of bloody riots in major Iranian cities last week, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is facing the strongest opposition to his rule in 15 years.

title: Peking Disputes the Soviet Version of Border Incident
description: HONG KONG, May 17  Peking disputed today the Soviet version of a border incident last week and said it had bullets and cartridge cases to prove that several Chinese had been wounded in the incursion.

title: Rhodesia Challenged by Witnesses On How Blacks Died in Shooting
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May I7  Accounts by witnesses today sharply disputed yesterday's official Rhodesian account of the deaths of 50 civilians who the Government said had been caught in a crossfire Sunday between security forces and guerrillas holding a political meeting.

title: Merrill, No. 2 Jet Pick, Avoiding Rookie Camp
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 17  To the amazement of Coach Walt Michaels, the No. 2 draft pick he hopes will anchor the defense did not show up at the Jets informal working camp today.

title: Cosmos Bow To Timbers in Shootout, 21
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 17 (AP)  The Portland goalie, Mick Poole, blocked shots by Steve Hunt and Giorgio Chinaglia in the shootcut as the Timbers handed the New York Cosmos their frst North American Soccer League loss of the season tonight, 21.Thie Cosmos had won seven in a row

title: 90 WOMEN FAIL TEST TO BE FIREFIGHTERS
description: The women who applied for positions as New York City firefighters this year  the first female applicants in the city's history permitted to compete with mien  all failed the physical test administered to Fire Department applicants;

title: SENATORS SEEK EXTENSION OF EQUAL RIGHTS DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Four United States Senators announced today that they and 19 other Senators would introduce a joint resolution to extend for seven years the deadline for ratification of the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Believing that much of the antipathy to hunting in this nation is directed against the conduct of those engaged in it rather than the actual killing of birds or animals, the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources has received legislative backing in establishing an adult hunter education program. During the last two winters, pilot adult hunter education courses were warmly received by sportsmen, says the department, which adds that it believes such courses must be voluntary if they are to be effective.

title: Freud Library, Victim of War, Gets New Home In New York
description: In the summer of 1939, Dr. Jacob Schatzky, librarian of the New York State Psychiatric Institute, was intrigued by a small ad in the catalogue of Heinrich Hinterberger, a bookseller with a shoo at Hegelgasse 17, Vienna.

title: Cancer Director Warns of Job Exposure to Chemicals
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)  The director of the National Cancer Institute said today that there was a scientific basis to justify immediate action to reduce the exposure of cancercausing chemicals to humans.

title: Begelman's Theft Plea: No Contest
description: David Begelman, former studio chief of Columbia Pictures Industries movie and television units, pleaded no contest yesterday to charges that he stole $40,000 in company funds.

title: What's Shut on Which Memorial Day
description: Some call it Memorial Day, others call it Decoration Day. Some will be off Monday, May 29, this year to celebrate it, others Tuesday, May 30. A tiny, lucky few will be off both days, and there are also those who do not know vet which day they will get.

title: MITCHELLLAMA AID PROPOSED BY CAREY CALLS FOR RENT RISES
description: ALBANY, May 17  Governor Carey will propose that the financially troubled MitchellLama housing program be bailed out by raising the rents of residents who earn more than the state median income  $17,200 a year. At the same time, Mr. Carey will propose that the state subsidize residents who earn less than that so that their rents will be no more than one quarter of their incomes.

title: Dominican Republic at a Glance
description: Political History  The Dominican Republic, which occupies the eastern twothirds of the island of Hispaniola in the Caribbean, 125 miles off Florida, has had a turbulent existence. For more than 30 years it lived under the dictatorial rule of Gen. Rafael Trujillo Molina, who was assassinated in 1961, reportedly with material support from thc? Central Intelligence Agency.

title: American Airlines Gains
description: Albert V. Casey, chairman and president of American Airlines Inc. told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting here that traffic was strong in April and early May and we believe American's traffic increase will exceed the industry's. He forecast a 48state industry growth of about 9.6 percent for the year as a whole, compared with 7.6 percent for 1977. However, he added that American's financial results for 1978 are not likely to be as impressive as those of the last two record years.

title: Jersey Clinic to Expand
description: BELLE MEAD, N.J., May 17 (AP)  The Carrier Clinic, largest privately operated psychiatric hospital in the state, has announced plans for a $3.2 million expansion program. Dr. Robert S. Gerber, president of the 250bed facility, said the project had received necessary state approval and would significantly improve the enic's alcoholism and special treatment programs.

title: Witness Tells of His Discovering Curare in Dr. Jascalevich's Locker
description: HACKENSACK. N.J., May 17  A Riverdell Hospital doctor testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he felt compelled to break into Dr. Jscalevich's locker after he discerned a pattern late in 1966 to the sudden deaths that were occurring at the hospital.

title: Ground Rules for Terrace Gardeners
description: IN AN OLD but respectable apartment building on West 56th Street lawyer slowly opens the French doors to a terrace where tenderheaded flowers murmur and potted lime trees release their last perfume in moonlight. At the Park Avenue palazzo or a society matron, an intimate dinner party unfolds on the terrace, white tablecloths contrasting with redmouthed azaleas, women in voile almost invisible against the andromeda. In an East 28th Street highrise redolent of years of cooking, the tiny terrace of a freelance editor fairly chokes with Sophora japonica, Acanthopanax grandiflora and the sixinchhigh Chionodoxa gigantea.

title: From Functional to Elegant,a Plethora of Pottery Table Settings
description: YOU don't need to be a June bride or out shopping for a summer wedding gift to enjoy the display of handmade tableware on view at the Elements Gallery through June. Anyone with an eye for the unusual and the handcrafted will find something to love in this assortment of table settings from 10 different craftsmen, featuring everything from functional everyday stoneware to elegant porcelain.

title: British Get Plea On 3d Air Route
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  President Carter is urging the British Government to accept airpassenger service between London and three cities. not two as previously agreed, the White House said today.

title: Bond Tables Explained
description: Bonds, Interestbearing debt certificates, are quoted In percentage of the par or face value of the bond, which is represented as 100. The name of the Issuing company is followed by the original coupon or interest rate and the last two digits of the year of maturity.

title: Shipping/Mails
T.V.A. Cuts Rate Rise After AntiInflation Plea
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  The board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority, perhaps heeding an antiinflation plea from the White House, today approved a general 8.5 percent increase in power rates instead of a 12 percent increase it had considered.

title: World News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 17  The Australian Government, reacting to growing domestic alarm about the increasing number of boat people arriving in small craft off the north coast, and to pressure from the United States and other nations, announced today that it would accept 9,000 more Indochinese refugees from camps in Thailand and Malaysia during the year starting in July.

title: Terrorists Wound Turin Policeman
description: ROME, May 17  Terrorists seriously wounded a policeMan in Turin this morn ing as he left his home to go to work. The two gunmen escaped.

title: Do Somet about the weather.
description: Do this. Save money!

title: Boy Arrested in Teacher's Killing
description: AUSTIN, Tex, May 18 (UPI)A junior high school student who is the son of a former Presidential press secretary wags accused today of shooting to death a teacher who had given him a failing grade.

title: Campbell and Vlasic Agree to F.T.C. Plan
description: The Campbell Soup Company said it and Vlasic Foods Inc. had agreed to a Federal Trade Commission proposal affecting the proposed merger of the two. Last month Campbell agreed to acquire Vlasic, a maker of pickles, relishes, peppers and related items, for stock then valued at about $33 million.

title: Sonics Owe Success To Wilkens's Coaching
description: SEATTLE, May 18The neatlylettered sign read simply: Lenny for King.

title: People of Atlantic City Wonder What the Wheel's Turn Will Bring
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 18  On the Boardwalk of this onceprosperous, nowshabby resort city by the sea, merchants of practically everything, from the usual tourist items to women's expensive handbags, are sprucing up their shops and sometimes renaming them (for example,'Gamblers Gifts').

title: For Children
description: SHEEP TO SHAWL DAY, an annual demonstration, showing how sheen are sheared, and how wool Is utilized on shown be members of the Spinning croon of the New Canaan Ilistorlral Society, who will demonstrate hypes of wool culture and spin wool and flay, from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M, on Sanday, at the Stamford Museum P. Nature Center, Inc., 39 Syotleld town Road, three.quartms of e mile north ct Fait 35 on the Merrill Parkway. All cf the museum facilities will be open, Entrance fn: $2 per car. Call (100) 3221646.

title: Dividends
Cornfeld Has A Losing Day In Swiss Court
description: Bernie Cornfeld is back in the news. The flamboyant founder of the nowbankrupt Investors Overseas Services mutual funds complex stood in a Geneva. Switzerland, court yesterday as it denied his appeal against a court order

title: Economy, Buffeted on All Sides, Is Showing Faint Signs of Hope
description: MILAN, Italy  Carlo de Benedetti draws a simple lesson from the wave of leftist terrorism that has engulfed Italy in recent months. The time has come for our industrialists to stand up and fight, he says.

title: Solvent Is Found In Students Blood In Massachusetts
description: AMHERST, Mass., May IS (AP)University of Massachusetts officials closed the schcol's 17stor yGraduate Research Tower tonight after tests showed the preence of a laboratory solvent in students blood.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Joyce Lashof, secondranking official in the Federal health bureaucracy, said yesterday that she had resigned in a continuing dispute with Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Dr. Lashof had the title of Deputy Assistant Secretary for Health Administration, an area in which she is a specialist, and was paid $47,000 a year. She was said to have been angered and frustrated because she thought Mr. Califano was bypassing her and dealing directly with agencies under her jurisdiction. It's obviously a series of complex issues over a period of time, Dr. Lashof said yesterday. There were differences in administrative policy. The job is just not what I thought it would be when I took it. Dr. Lashof went to Washington from Illinois, where she had served as state Director of Public Health for four years.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Concert: Speculum Musicae
description: THERE were two premieres on the Speculum Musicae program last night in Alice Tully Hall, and one of them had to wait about 60 years. Henry Cciwell finished his Quartet Romantic in 1917, but no musical group could then play it, and it has remained for Speculum Musicae to attempt its complexities.

title: 9th Ave. Is Cooking Up A MileLong Party
description: THE midtown length of Ninth Avenue used to be called Paddy's Market when it was the exclusive home of New York's Irish immigrant merchants and their sidewalk pushcarts. Today it is perhaps the city's most varied ethnic enclave, a mile of Italians, Greeks, Hispanics, Filipinos, Poles and Asians, stretching from 37th to 57th Street.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Traders in pork bellies futures sensed that consumers have been balking at the retail price of bacon the last month or so, and they were proved right.

title: Rocket Gives Nevadans a Show
description: TONOPAH, Nev., May 18 (UPI)A rocket spread a bright green cloud of barium ions 120 miles over southern Nevada early today as scientists completed a twopart test of how highaltitude disturbances affect radio communications. The rocket, whose launching had been postponed four times by had weather, produced a glow that was clearly visible in Las Vegas. The first launching. May 8, resulted in a cloud that was seen over parts of Nevada, California, Arizona and Utah.

title: Israel's Defense Chief Proposes Expansion of 6 West Bank Sites
description: TEL AVIV, May 18Israel's Defense Minister, Ezer Weizman, has proposed the expansion of six controversial Israeli settlements on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan into urban centers, and then a halt to any more new colonies in the territory.

title: Cheevers Gives Bruin Fans Something to Cheer About
description: BOSTON, MaY 18With 1 minute 41 seconds remaining in the game and a white oval on the scoreboard showing that Montreal had not scored goal against the Boston Bruins, Bob Gainey of the Canadins took a shot that deflected off a stick.

title: Bruins Triumph, 40, Cut Canadiens Lead;
description: BOSTON, May 1SA superhuman performance by the Boston Bruins tonight proved the Montreal Canadiens mere mortals after all. With a convinc ing 40 defeat of the defending Stanley Cup champions at raucous Boston Garden, Boston cut Montreal's lead to two games to one in their Nat:onal Hockey League final as well as ended an eightgame losing streak at the hands of the Canadiens in playoff competition.

title: About Real Estate
description: The intersection of Fulton Street and Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn is one of the world's great urban hubs, affording vistas of the Manhattan Bridge to the north, Prospect Park to the south and, past the retailing concentration on Fulton Street, the Brooklyn Civic Center to the west.

title: Art People
description: VICTOR VASARELY was in town this week for the opening of the Vasarely Center at 1015 Madison Avenue at 77th Street. At 70, the initiator of op art looked enviably trim and lean in a threepiece suit of pearlgray flannel with the ribbon of the Legion of Honor to add a grace note of scarlet.

title: Events and Openings
description: THANK GOD ITS FRIDAY, dire.:ted by Robet Ktane; at the Criterion, Orbbeurn aha neighborhood !beaters.

title: JASCALEVICH LAWYER CITES A MISDIAGNOSIS
description: HACKENSACK, May 18 The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich sought to prove today that it was the mistakes of Dr. Stanley Harris and other doctors at Riverdell Hospital that caused the sudden deaths at the hospital rather than the curare that Dr. Harris discovered in Dr. Jascalevich's locker.

title: Moon Church Sues Times for Libel Over Alleged Links to Korea C.I.A.
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church has sued The New York Times for libel, charging that the paper published articles alleging ties between the church and the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Alydar's Fast Drills Bolster Supporters
description: BALTIMORE, May IRIf morning workouts lead to afternoon success on the race track, then Calumet Farm's Alydar will be the horse to watch in Saturday's 103d running of the Preakness. This was the consensus today at Pimlico Race Course, where seven 3yearold colts were entered for the second part of thoroughbred racing's annual triple crown series. Once again, as they did before the recent Kentucky Dorby, the Alydar fans were beginning to make a new case for that colt in his continuing battle with Harbor View Farm's Affirmed.

title: Friedman Resigns His Patronage Job On CityWater Unit
description: Elected last week as leader of the Democratic party in the Bronx, Stanley M. Friedman quit his $25,000ayear patronage post as president of the Board of Water Supply yesterday.

title: Seaboard Ends Talks
description: Seaboard Coastline Industries said it had terminated discussions on a possible affiliation with the Southern Pacific Company. No reason for the termination was given. In December. the companies announced their intention to enter into exploratory discussions on such a possibility.

title: Art: Angelo Savelli, Uptown and Down
description: IT seems that artists, once they have abandonedor lost their foothold inthe New York gallery circuit should engineer comebacks with care. Like actors, they must regroup old supporters while also attracting new ones, unless they wish to come on as oldtimers or vehicles for nostalgia. And free spirits though they supposedly are, artists are nevertheless expected to have resumes as seamless as those of corporate executives, or at least colorful explanations for the gaps.

title: 4 BLIND COLLEGE SENIORS ARE HONORED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, May 18I'm very excited, but a little scared, said Merilyn Carol Rosenthal, 22 years old, of Highland Park, N. J., who is the first blind woman to be accepted as a student at Harvard Law School.

title: WhistleBlowing on Toxics
description: The letter from Thornton F. Bradshaw, president of Atlantic Richfield, was mailed to Arco's 50,000 employees. Its message: Whenever an Arco worker, from executive vice president to janitor, becomes aware of a chemical substance manufactured by the company that might involve a substantial risk to health or the environment, it must be reported to the Government.

title: BELGIAN AND FRENCH TROOPS FLY TO ZAIRE TO SAVE 2,500 FOREIGNERS; U.S. SENDS PLANES AND SPEEDS AID;Associated Press;Belgian paratroopers preparing to leave for Zaire from airport near Brussels;NO AMERICAN FORCES Operation Organized After Reported Fall of Kolwezi in Copper Mine Area
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Belgian and French troops were flown to Zaire today in an Americansupported operation to rescue more than 2,500 foreigners, mostly Europeans, trapped by fighting in the coppermining area of the African country.

title: Restaurants
description: A bridge to Japan in the heart of town.

title: Mets Top Braves, 87, In 10 Innings
description: The New York Mets demonstrated last night that while they may nct be opportunists they can he persistent as they defeated the Atlanta Braves, 87, in a 3hour40minute, 10inning marathon at Shea Stadium.

title: Jersey Woman Is Guilty in Death Of Her Adopted Thai Orphan, 2
description: NEWTON. N.J. May 18 (AP)  Nancy G. Myers. 31 years old, of Ogdensburg, who was convicted of second degree murder and child abuse, faces up to 37 years in prison when she is sentenced June 30.

title: City Ballet: Tricolore Preniiere
description: THE champagne fizzled last night at the official premiere of Tricolore by the New York City Ballet at the State Theater. Conceived as the French counterpart to George Balanchine's other flag ballets, Stars and Stripes and Union Jack, the latest entry was a work in progress when Mr. Balanchine fell momentarily ill. Although he has been supervising the production in recent weeks, the choreography of the ballet's three sections was turned over to Peter Martins, JeanPierre Bonnefous and Jerome Robbins.

title: ExNevadan Is First to Be Indicted Under Jersey's New Gambling Act
description: TRENTON, May 18State officials today announced the first indictment under the New Jersey gambling casino law. It involved a former Nevada man seeking a state license to be a gambling school instructor.

title: Economy, Buffeted on All Sides, Is Showing Faint Signs of Hope
description: MILAN, Italy  Carlo de Benedetti draws a simple lesson from the wave of leftist terrorism that has engulfed Italy in recent months. The time has come for our industrialists to stand up and fight, he says.

title: Rainess Accounting Firm Undergoing a ShakeUp
description: The public accounting firm of Clarence Rainess & Company, which is about the 15th largest in the nation, is quietly charting a major reorganization.

title: EARNINGS
description: The K Mart Corporation, the nation's secondlargest retail chain and leading operator of discount department stores, yesterday reported its first quarterly Profit decline in several years,

title: 3 CARTER AIDES WARN OF HIGHWAYBILL COST
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Carter Administration sharpened its attack today on a House transportation bill, alleging that the measure's spending levels were too high and warning that it could bankrupt the highway trust fund.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Recalls 110,000 78 Cars
description: DETROIT, May 18 (Reuters)The Ford Motor Company said today that it was recalling 110,000 1978 model cars for inspection of front seat belt assemblies. The recall is for Ford LTD, LTD II, Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar passenger cam. The company said that some shoulderharness retractors may not lock upon sudden deceleration and that some shoulder belts may not be able to be unlocked.

title: Quandary In Africa
description: Swiftly moving events in Africa will probably produce strong new pres sures on President Carter to take more forceful action to counter the SovietCuban presence on that continent. But what he should do is not so clear, except to those who always advocate military intervention.

title: Criticized Company Gets City Monopoly On Lighting Repairs
description: The Welsbach Electric Corporation yesterday established a monopoly over all New York City streetlight maintenance for the next three years, underbidding the Broadway Maintenance Corporation for the contract to maintain lights in Queens.

title: What Counts in Santo Domingo
description: It's been 13 years since American troops rushed to the capital of the Dominican Republic to save it from a dubious Communist threat. The hysteria of those days has fortunately faded in Washington. but our responsibility for the frail democracy the troops left behind cannot be evaded. Having intervened so often and so foolishly in Santo Domingo. the United States is now obliged to exert all possible diplomatic pressure to assure that a threatened election is allowed fairly to run its course.

title: Profits Show A 2% Drop
description: WASHINGTON, May IS (AP)The Government reported today that aftertax corporate profits fell 2 percent in the first quarter of the year, and that the performance of the economy in the period, while better than originally estimated. was sell fairly dismal.

title: Ballet: Pennsylvanians
description: ANY way one looked at it, Wednesday evening's program by the Pennsylvania Ballet at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was splendidly danced. But one could look at the double bill of George Balanchine's Divertimento No. 15 and John Butler's Carmina Burana in several ways.

title: Topics
description: For the confession of the year, perhaps of the era, we are indebted to the indefatigable John Osborne of The New Republic. He drew it easily, it seems, from Jody Powell at the White House, where it will long hover in the air to mark and to mock the Presidencies of our day.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Screen: 'Thank God It's Friday':At the Zoo
description: "THANK GOD It's Friday" has the form of a disco movie, but it's really a record album with live-action liner notes featuring a dozen young actors, most of whom are quite nice and, as yet, unknown, and a few who are better known but not as impressive as the new people.The setting is the Zoo, a Los Angeles discotheque, and everything in the movie happens either in or around the Zoo in the space of a few hours on a Friday night.A young couple, married five years, rediscovers their love. Miss Plain-Jane finds romance. The womanizing owner meets his comeuppance. A dance-crazy Mexican-American wins the big contest, and an unknown singer, played by Donna Summer, in her film debut, begins her climb to stardom. Miss Summer, whose wigs are as elaborate as Diana Ross's, is competition for the superb Miss Ross in no department other than hair.The film, which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, was directed by Robert Klane (who wrote the novel on which "Where's Poppa?" was based) and written by Barry Armyan Bernstein in the breathless, multinarrative manner of "Car Wash," which gives one the impression that a good deal is happening even when the movie is standing still.Among the actors who fare best are Chick Vennera, as the Mexican-American fellow who has the film's only good number, an exuberant disco dance on the tops of the cars in the Zoo's parking lot; Ray Vitte, who was in "Car Wash." as the Zoo's manic disk jockey; Valerie Landsburg and Terri Nunn, as two extremely underage patrons, and Jeff Goldblum, who played the rock critic in "Between the Lines," as the Zoo's pushy manager.The Commodores come on to play themselves in the finale, which is not much different from any other part of the movie. The dcor of the Zoo is suitably garish and looks dangerously flammable. I would have felt easier while watching the movie if I'd known where the exits were.There is nothing in the way of explicit sex or nudity in "Thank God It's Friday," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), though the language is sometimes vulgar and there is one sequence involving the use of various kinds of drugs, uppers and downers, that is supposed to be funny but isn't.

title: Vitas and Those Three Guys
description: Some people look at Vitas Gerulaitis and believe they are looking at Bjorn Borg, which is understandable. Each has long blond hair. Each has the flatbellied slimness of a tennis payer. Each has a European style about him, at least until Yitas Gerulaitis speaks in a voice with the streetcorner ??raarla of New York in it, the opposite of Bjorn Borg's tedious English in a muffled Swedish accent. But some people still believe what they want to believe, that they are looking Bjorn Borg no matter what that New York voice tells them. That's all right, Mr. Borg, a stranger once said to Vitas Gerulaitis on a jetliner. I know you've got a great sense of humor. And when Vitas Gerulaitis politely insisted that he was not Mr. Borg, the stranger walked off in a huff, snorting. All right, Mr. Borg, if you're going to be like that. Vita's Gerulaitis shrugged, as if there was nothing he could do. But to solve his identity problem, he knows what he has dowin Wimbledon or the United States Open so that when some people see a slim tennis player with long blond hair, they will think of Vitas Gerulaitis instead of Bjorn Borg.

description: BRUSSELS, May 18Secretary of Defense Harold Brown promised the defense ministers of other Atlantic alliance countries today that in the event of any crisis in Europe the United States would double its army there in two weeks and triple aircraft strength in a week.

Employees with 30 years of service get a discount of 100 percentworth $7.71 a month in New York Cityand free message units and longdistance tolls of up to about $35 a month.

title: Art: Stie glitz Collection at Met

Even the formidable Allred stiegiitzhimself a master photographer and a pioneer dealer, editor, propagandist and collector in the fieldhad to wage a vigorous campaign extending over a period of many decades to win a place for this then unappreciated art in our greatest art museum.

description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Belgian and French troops were flown to Zaire today in an Americansupported operation to rescue more than 2,500 Europeans trapped by fighting in the coppermining area of the African country.

title: Art: Moral Sculptures
description: IT is now a little more than 20 years since H.C. Westermann began to leave his mark on the American art scene. He was known from the outset as a demon carpenter: a man whose skills might in more settled times have won him the kind of fame that surrounds the name of Duncan Phyfe in the history of American cabinet making.

description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)Robert C. Byrd, the Senate Democratic leader said today that no attempt would be made to end the filibuster on a bill revising the Federal labor law until the Memorial Day recess was over.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: THE weekend schedule's flashiest bauble is Ziegfeld: The Man and His Women, a threehour television movie Sunday on NBC. But sober types seeking something less gaudy can turn, as ever, to public television for at least a couple of more substantial excursions. One is new; another is returning.

title: Mercury Is Polluting the Meadowlands And Scientists Are Uncertain on Impact
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., May 18Pervasive mercury pollution has been found in the Hackensack Meadowlands and state scientists are uncertain about the longterm impact the contamination will have on the health of people in the area.

title: Music: John Herald
description: OF the folk musicians associated with the area around Woodstock, N.Y., Tohn Herald and Artie Traum have been about the most active recently, at least insofar as the New York club scene is concerned. Wednesday night, they opened at the Other End, 147 Bleecker Street, for a fournight run. Mr. Herald and the five players who make up his band are the headliners, and Mr. Traumpartnered by Pat Alger, who has appeared with Mr. Traum and Mr. Herald on a number of collaborative Woodstock disksis the opening act.

description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 18King Hussein will formally present his American fiance to the press next Tuesday, and until then there is to be a blackout on news of the wedding preparations, including even the date of the ceremony, according to a palace spokesman.

title: Sneva Clocks 203.1 M.P.H.
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 (AP)  Tom Sneva, who won the pole position here last year, had the second, fastest speed ever at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, going 203.1 miles per hour shortly before the close of today's practic, for the Indianapolis 500.

title: People of Atlantic City Wonder What the Wheel's Turn Will Bring
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 18  On the Boardwalk of this onceprosperous, nowshabby resort city by the sea, merchants of practically everything, from the usual tourist items to women's expensive handbags, are sprucing up their shops and sometimes renaming them (for example.'Gamblers Gifts').

title: Music: Philharmonic's Americana
description: THE program of Americana offered by the New York Philharmonic in its Wednesday night Promenade in Avery Fisher Hall was compiled and conducted by Gunther Schuller, who in his comments spoke of rummaging around search of material. The quoted phrase suggested digging in old dusty attics, looking for antiques, whether of artistic worth or not, to put on display.

description: NEWARK, May 18State and Federal mediators said today that they would meet tomorrow with members of Local 225 of the Transport Workers Union following the union's rejection late last night of a compromise that sought to end the 48day old strike against the Manhattan Transit Bus Company.

title: America's Other Internment
description: PHILADELPHIAThe news that the Federal Bureau of Investigation, with the consent of the National Archives, is planning to destroy criminal files of cases that have been closed for five years made me wonder what will happen to about 800 boxes of unassorted documents in the Federal Records Center at Suitland, Md. The boxes contain the story of the Justice Department's quasisecret internment program during World War II for men and women of enemy nationality who were not criminals.

title: Britons Pay Premium to Buy U.S. Stocks
description: LONDON, May 18  When stock prices began to soar on Wall Street last month, most investors playing the market were picking such companies as American Telephone and Telegraph at $62 a share, Exxon at $48 and International Business Machines at $250.

Cathy Doerner of the United States, lost to Renata Tomanova of Czechoslovakia, 61, 61, and Kathy May of the United States beat Glynis Coles of Britain, 64, 64. In men's singles, Wladimir Zednik of Czechoslovakia defeated Paul McNamee of Australia, 62, 64, and Hans Giklemeister of Chile beat Kim Warwick of Australia, 26, 64, 61.

description: HOWARD NEWMAN, chief executive officer of Western Pacific Industries, who is stalking both the Hazeltine Corporation, a designer of electronic military equipment, and Houghton Mifflin, the venerable publishing house, hopes to slam the door on any ambitious entrepreneur who might want to do the same to him.

title: Japanese Landslide Kills Two
description: TOKYO, May 18 (UPI)  A mountainside soaked by melting snow gave way today in a landslide that buried 16 buildings in a mountain town 130 miles northwest of Tokyo. The police said that two bodies had been recovered and that 10 people were missing.
