title: Athletes as Artists: A Good Mix
description: They are up against the wall, and for most of them that isn't a new position. They're athletes and they're artists, and if that wasn't a common mix 25 years ago, now it flows like  watercolor on rice paper. Some of their names are Rocky, Killer  and Rosey, not exactly Degas, Lautrec and Picasso, but the medium is the message. The paintings, sketches, sculpture, needlepoint, cartoons and photographs of 14 professional athletes will be on display at the Spectrum Gallery on West 57th Street through June 30, and some of the proceeds from the show will go to the Gaucho Basketball Fund to benefit Harlem youngsters. Many of the contributing artists were at. the gallery yesterday, and they spoke about their art as well as their craft.

title: DURYEA NOMINATION REPORTED CLINCHED

Duryea's campaign manager declared yesterday that the Montauk, LI., Republican had captured enough support on the party's state committee not only to clinch the party's designation for Governor, but also to deny an automatic place on the primary ballot to any Republican opponent.

The rate on the notes is 8.15 percent, and that compares favorably for the company with the 8.13 percent yield on United States Treasury notes also coming due May 15. 1983.

title: Broadway
description: LESTER OSTERMAN and Richard Horner will produce The Crucifer of Blood, and inasmuch as there is a Broadway season, what with shows corning in now all year round, Crucifer of Blood probably will be the first show of next season. It should be at the Helen Hayes for previews by Sept. 12. Crucifer. written and directed by Paul G. Giovanni, is based on Arthur Conan Doyle's The Sign of Four, and in it Sherlock Holmes is young. Paxton Whitehead, who played Holmes in the Crucifer production at the Studio Arena Theater in Buffalo last winter, will play Holmes on Broadway. Crucifer (the word means someone who carries a cross) has a cast of 16 and five sets that will be designed by John Wulp, the man who first thought of reviving Dracula. The five sets are India, Holmes's rooms on Baker Street, an opium den in Limehouse, the harbor of London and a seedily elegant flat in London. There is also boat chase on the Thames.

This year, as part of his tax initiative, the President had hoped to coax Congress a step further down the road toward equal tax treatment for all forms of income.

Tiernan, a former Democratic Representative from Rhode Island, was named vice chairman. Ms. Aikens succeeds Thomas E. Harris, a Democrat. The chairmanship of the sixmember commission, which monitors compliance with Federal election laws, is rotated annually between Democratic and Republican members.

title: Island's Phones Are Restored
description: MONHEGAN ISLAND, Me., May ID (AP)Telephone service was restored to this ocean island today, more than three months after the worst storm of the winter damaged the cable linking Monhegan to the mainland. The line serving the island's 13 phones, all ot tnem pay stations, hummed with chatter as Monhegan's residents enjoyed their first phone conversations since Feb. 8. New England Telephone said service was restored after a Coast Guard cable tender repaired the 17mile cable.

title: New York State's (Groan) Taxes

Unfortunately, political leadership in New York has refused to recognize the deleterious consequences of taxation and its direct relationship to the continuing loss of industry and jobs from our state.

At the U.N., a Very Little Night Music

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AT LONG LAST DESSERT The longawaited reprise of George Gershwin's Let Em Eat Cake is due tonight at 8 in a concert version by the Gregg Smith Singers at Alice Tully Hall. This will be the first performance of the composer's nexttolast show, before Porgy and Bess, in the 44 years since its closing on Broadway. A sardonic work, angrily depicting an American dictatorship, Let Em Eat Cake was less successful than its cheerfully satirical predecessor, Of Thee I Sing, the first musical to win the Pulitzer Prize.

title: Iran Fears Threat From Afghans To its Oil Passage Route in Gulf

title: Ramps Pay A Brief Visit to City
description: A ramp at first glance might be mistaken for a green onion, a scallion or a leek. But ramps, which are bona fide, if renegade, members of the lily family, are a separate variety of onions that grow in the Appalachian Mountains. So highly prized are these mellow, tender bulbs, both for flavor and as an odoriferous spring tonic, that they inspire fullfledged festivals in many towns of West Virginia, most especially in Richwood, where the Feast of Ramson is held in early April. It is sponsored, as one might guess, by the National Ramp Association, which has headquarters in that town.

title: For the Elderly, Health Care at Home, First

It is now time for an infusion of imagination and new ideas to provide adequate, compassionate medical services to the elderly, at a price W3 can afford. I am more convinced than ever that the answer to such essential services lies in an effective home healthcare program.

description: WASHINGTON  Isolation is death in Alexander Vampilov's engrossing Duck Hunting.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: TOKYO, May 19 As head of Japan's Economic Planning Agency, Kiichi Miyazawa is the country's spokesman on domestic economic affairs. Last December he predictedagainst the advice of the great majority of Japanese Government economiststhat the economy would leap forward early this year.

title: 12 in the Senate Are Millionaires, Reports Under New Rules Show
description: WASHINGTON, May 19At least every fourth United States Senator may be a millionaire, but only a dozen can be placed in that category with certainty, according to reports made public by the Senate today.

title: Durables Orders Rose 0.4% in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) New factory orders for durable goods increaQed only 0.4 percent in April because of a decline in orders for defense equipment, the Commerce Departmnt said today.

title: Article 2  No Title
Businessman Jailed in Korea Case
description: WASHINGTON, May Ill (AP)Hancho C. Kim, a naturalized Ameriyan citizen, was sentenced today to six years in prison in the first criminal trial resulting from the Korean influencebuying scandal.

title: U.N. Official in Lebanon for Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 19A special United Nations envoy arrived here today to deal with, the rising crisis between United Nations peacekeeping forces and Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon.

title: G.M PUTS 5% CEILING ON EXECUTIVE RAISES
description: DETROIT, May 19  In a gesture of support for President Carter's efforts to curb inflation, the General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest industrial corporation, said today that a 5 percent ceiling had been placed on the combined increases in salary and bonus pay for its to executives this year.

title: Pirates 5, Expos 3
description: AT MONTREALDave Parker and Phil Garner hit tworun homers and Steve Brye added a solo homer, all in the fourth inning, to pace Don Robinson's fourth consecutive victory. Rudy May was thc victim of the longball eruption in. the fourth.

title: Albany Negotiators Fail to Agree On New York City Financial BillS
description: ALBANY, May 19State and New York City negotiators adjourned their fiscal discussions this evening without breaking the impasse on a bill to expand the borrowing power of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: JOB SEEKERS THRONG NEW PLANT IN BRONX
description: A crowd of 3,000 people looking for jobs stormed police barricades at a South Bronx building yesterday to get applications for 500 openings.

title: An EnergySaving Device Brews Trouble
description: WEBSTER, Minn., May 19With memories of last winter's brutal weather and soaring fuel bills still fresh in his mind and faced with the prospect of losing about $20,000 on his corn crop at current market prices, a Minnesota chemist turned farmer decided to dabble in a little moonshining of sorts.

title: C141'S DISPATCHED
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The White House announced today that 18 United States Air Force C141 transports were taking part in the French and Belgian airlift to Zaire as the Carter Administration sought to demonstrate a readiness to counter Soviet and Cuban military involvement in Africa.

title: Quebec in American Eyes
description: Premier Rend Levesque came to New York this week Dreaching his gospel or souvernintassociationsovereignty for Queoec, but in association with Canadaand attempting to dispel the fears that an independent Quebec would be bad for American business. He may well be right; his provincial administration has been Tar from radical in its fiscal measures. But there is a more concrete reason why Americans can look calmly on the matter: Quebec separatism appears to have passed its peak. The English Canadians have absorbed much of the Quebec message; they may not agree with it, but they are resigned to the French fact. In all likelihood, the province will reach an accommodation with Ottawa, avoiding the trauma of separation.

title: Dow Declines by 4.07 to 846.85: TakeoverRelated Issues Slip
description: The reverse side of the takeover movement showed itself yesterday when several companies either spurned or resolved possible corporate overtures and saw their stock prices drop in the process.

title: VIRGINIA WOMAN KILLED WHEN HER AUTO EXPLODES
description: GRUNDY, Va., May 19 (AP)An explosion with a force equivalent to at least 15 sticks of dynamite killed a woman who was sitting in her car today, a Federal investigator said.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Yank Bickering Revives
description: TORONTO, May 19Last season, while the New York Yankees were on their way to their second straight American League pennant and victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series, internal bickering was as much a part of things as base hits and putouts.

title: New Tour Recaptures Old Grandeur of Gramercy Park
description: New York is a city of familiar streets with unfamiliar histories. The idle walker will notice the faded little shops on East 20th Street, for instance, or a solitary mother playing with her child in the green confines of Gramercy Park.

title: Women's Wasting Lives
description: In 1918 I read the two books from which I have quoted above. More than any others, they formed my attitude toward the position of women. Not that I ever gave the subject much thought. The accident of female birth has never in a long life inhibited my freedom. I have followed my instincts and tried to use common sense in my behavior. In 1918, immediately after graduating from college, I took and passed a Civil Service examination for the position of research clerk in M.I.5.

title: Rutger Morse Smith Marries Mary Richie
description: Mary Evans Richie, a writer and novelist, was married yesterday to Rutger Morse Smith, president of H. J. Baker & Bros. Inc., a New Yorkbased international trading concern. The ceremony was performed by Judge Beatrice Schaneswitt of the State Supreme Court in her chambers.

title: Casino's Slot Machines Get First Feeding
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 19Silver dollars, most of them never to be seen again by their shortterm owners, began disappearing into the slot machines at the Resorts International HotelCasino here tonight, as gambling for real money opened in Atlantic City, on a trial basis.

title: 13 Firemen Hurt When Paint Drum Explodes in South Bronx Fire
description: Thirteen firemen were injured, three of them seriously, when a 55gallon paint drum exploded in their faces yesterday as they attempted to put out a fire in a walkin oven at a. metalprocessing Plant in the South Bronx.

title: COMPANY ROUNDUP
description: Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Investors announced yesterday that it had entered into separate fiveyear unsecured credit agreements amounting to $100 million with 20 banks.

title: Miss Costanza Trying to Keep White House Office
description: WASHINGTON May 19  Margaret Costanza, a Presidential assistant who ?? stripped of her major dutiez, is ?? to preserve the status be?? by occupying an office in the House.

title: DECLAN X. McMULLEN
description: Declan X. McMullen, who retired five years ago as educational consultant to Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the publisher, died Tuesday in Calvary Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 330 East 46th Street.

title: State Senate Study Urges Increases And LongTerm Pledges in Arts Aid
description: A panel of State Senators, in a study of the activities of the New York State Council on the Arts, has recommended an increase in the council's financial support to cultural institutions with large budgets and called for longterm aid commitments to the mostdistinguished cultural institutions.

title: Homosexual Seeking Ordination Lobbies Convention
description: SAN DIEGO, May I9William Silver, a New Yorker and an avowed homosexual whose request for ordination in the United Presbyterian Church has set off the most serious controversy in the denomination in recent times, spends long days here at the church's general assembly looking for support and for votes.

title: PERU PUTS OFF ELECTION IN FACE OF STRIKE THREAT
description: LIMA, Peru, May 19Peru's military rulers, facing the threat of a leftwing national strike, today postponed for two weeks the elections scheduled June 4 for a constitutional assembly.

title: Tigers Beat Red Sox for Sykes, 75, Increase Slender FirstPlace Lead
description: The Detroit Tigers, leading Boston by 20 percentage points in the battle for first place in the American League's Eastern Division, made the slim lead more secure by beating the Red Sox, 75, last night in Tiger Stadium before 48,817 fans.

title: Simons Leads Ohio Golf By Two Strokes on 69137
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 19Jim Simons, who is striving to live down his reputation as one of the slowest players on the PGA Tour, moved ahead of a field of much faster players today and took the lead in the second round of the third annual Memorial Tournament.

title: Black Leaders Seek Hiring Data On Minorities in Jersey Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 19Leaders of Atlantic City's black community, which makes up about half the population here, charged today that the legal rights of minorities were being ignored in the hiring for the gambling industry.

title: Kaunda Heads South, Hailing U.S. Policy on Africa
description: WASHINGTON, May 19  President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia flew to Atlanta today after urging for two days here that the United States keep pressing for majority rule in southern Africa.

title: Schlesinger Cites Price Pact on Gas
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 James R. Schlesinger, Secretary of Energy, said today that an agreement was reached with three key House members last night that should break the long Congressional deadlock over the portion of President Carter's energy package dealing with naturalcas nricing.

title: Cubs 6, Cardinals 2
description: AT CHICAGOGreg Gross hit two triples and Ivan DeJesus cracked his first home run of the season as Chicago sent St. Louis to its eighth straight defeat. Dave Roberts picked up his first victory, scattering six hits in his seveninning stint. John Denny (32) took the loss. The Cubs bunched a walk, Gross's first triple, a sacrifice fly, a single by Dave Kingman and a triple by Bobby Murcer for three runs in the first. DeJesus hit his homer in the seventh off Mark Litell.

title: Chrysler Files For Stock Issue
description: DETROIT, May 19 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had filed a registration statement for a controversial issue of sixmillion shares of preferred stock, each carrying a warrant entitling the purchaser to buy onehalf share of common stock.

title: The InvisibleAmericans in Norwegian Oil
description: STAVANGER, NorwayThe office of Mobil Exploration Norway sits right beside the quaintest part of Stavanger's harbor in a maroon and white building that, once houed a fish cannery.

title: Premiere of Sarmanto Jazz Mass
description: A rash of jazz masses appeared 15 or more years ago in which a common factor outside of the use of the qualifying word jazz, was a solemnity that tended to negate whatever relationship the music might have to jazz. This is not the case with Heikko Sarmanto's The New Hope Mass: which was commissioned by St. Perer's Church to celebrate the opening year of its new church on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. It was given its premiere on Thursday evening at St. Peter's, played by Mr. Sarmanto's jazz quintet and sung by Maija Hapouja, the Gregg Smilh Vocal Quartet, and the 60voice Low; Island Symphonic Choral AssociaCon, ccnducted by Mr. Smith.

title: Angels 7, Brewers 1
description: AT MILWAUKEEFrank Tanana became the major league's first sevengame winner, scattering nine hits in California's victory. Carney Lansford doubled home two runs in a fourrun, sixthinning burst.

title: American League Twins 5, Royals 3
description: AT KANSAS CITYBombo Rivera hit three successive singles and a homer to pace the Twins victory. Rivera, purchased by the Twins from the minor league team Denver during the offseason, cracked his homera 400footeroff Marty Pattin (11) in the eighth. Dan Ford tripled and scored on a sacrifice fly togive the Twins a 43 lead in the seventh. Roger Erickson evened his record at 33, and Mike Marshall picked up his second save with two innings of hitless relief,

title: Divorced Wife Wins Benefits
description: TRENTON, May 19 (AP)The beneficiary named on an insurance policy must be paid its value even though a divorced wife is listed instead of a current spouse, a state appeals court ruled yesterday. It awarded a $50,000 lifeinsurance policy to Ruth Shelly, who was divorced from William H. Sailer for eight years before his death in 1976. The ruling denied any benefits to Nancy .1. Sailer, who was married to Mr. Sailer when he died.

title: 3 Polish Musicians in Tribute
description: In addition to honoring the late Polish pianist, Thursday night's Witold Malcuzynski Memorial Concert at Carnegie Hall served as a showcase for duce talented young Polish musicians, all prizewinners in international cornpetitionsPiotr Janowski, violinist, Piotr Paleczny, pianist, and Jacek Kasprzyk, conductor. The program eluded music by Beethoven, Chopin, Strauss and Pendercki ,and the orchestra was the American Symphony.

title: I.B.M. Repurchase
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said that it had purchased a total of about 2.3 million of its own shares since the beginning of a stock repurchase program started last July. Under the repurchase program, I.B.M. was to buy 2.5 million of its shares, or an amount equal to $700 million, whichever was less.

title: Four Convicted in Abortion Sitin
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 19 (AP)A Roman Catholic priest and three students were convicted today of trespassing after a warning at a demonstration at an abortion clinic. City Judge Tennant Smallwood fined the Rev. Edward Markley $50 and the students $25 each and then suspended the fines for one year, pending no recurrences. They were arrested April 29 at the Birmingham Women's Medical Clinic where they staged a sitin to protest abortions.

title: 12 in the Senate Are Millionaires, Reports Under New Rules Show
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 At least every fourth United States Senator may be a millionaire, but only a dozen can be placed in that category with certainty, according to reports made public by the Senate today.

title: New Tokyo Airport Finally Opens With 13,000 Policemen on Hand
description: NARITA, Japan, Saturday, May 20Shortly before 10:30 A.M. this morning, a Shinto priest in a white kimono and wooden shoes entered a fourthfloor room in the north wing of the new airport terminal here. Surrounded by darksuited officials from the Transport Ministry, the Narita Airport Authority and Customs and Immigration, the priest waved a wand, chanted a prayer and ceremonially purified this $2.9 billion facility.

title: Winter Fur Fashion Preview: The Shapes of Things to Come
description: The first week of fur showings produced enough pelts to blanket the population of a small city  men, women and sometimes children. There are furs for snow, sleet and rain, and a lot of very decorative ones to make merry in, come the dark of night.

title: 10 Are Charged With Selling Parts Of Cars They Had Reported Stolen
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 19Ten men were arrested today and charged with conspiring to defraud automobile insurance companies by selling cars for parts while falsely reporting them stolen.

title: Consumer Notes
description: NEWARK, May 19The State Board of Public Utilities today approved an average 7 percent increase in rates for customers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the state's largest utility.

title: New London Police, ExMayor Cleared In HitRun Death
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 19The Police Department and a former New London Mayor were cleared today of any wrongdoing in a controversial hitandrun accident four yeas ago in which a 20yearold student was killed, but State's Attorney C. Robert Satti said cases like this never really close.

title: New Chairman for the T.V.A.
description: KNOXVILLE, May 19  Today was Simon David Freeman's first day as chairman of the board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority, a position that puts him at the throttle of an organization that employs 40,000 people and directly affects over seven million consumers scattered over 80,000 square miles.

title: Information on War Mostly SecondHand
description: For 20 minutes Thursday, Western correspondents based in Kinshasa, the Zairian capital, were allowed within five miles of insurgentheld Kolwezi in Shaba Province. It was the first and only close look at the battle situation since the fighting began a week ago.

title: NOBEL WINNERS PROTEST SOVIET DISSIDENT'S TRIAL
description: The Committee of Concerned Scientists said yesterday that it had sent a telegram signed by 15 Nobel laureates expressing our grave concern over the trial of, Yuri F. Orlov, the Russian physicist who was sentenced on Thursday to seven years in prison and five years in exile for antiSoviet agitation.

title: Board Split on Citizen Rate
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)Under Government ratesetting procedures, the Postal Service recommends rate changes to the Postal Rate Commission, an independent agency. The commission reviews those proposals and forwards its recommendations to the Postal Service Board of Governors for final approval.

title: Discoverer of Pap Test Is Honored
description: An oriental plane tree from the Greek island of Kos was dedicated to the memory of Dr. George N. Papanicolaou, discoverer of the Pap test for early cancer detection, in a courtyard ceremony at the Cornell University Medical College in Manhattan yesterday afternoon.

title: Paige to Try 800 and 1,500 In IC4A Meet
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 19 In a surprise move aimed at bolstering Villanuva.'s hopes for its first team title since 1971, Don Paige was entered in the 800 and 1,500meter runs for the IC4A outdoor track and field championships tomorrow and Sunday at Franklin Field.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDER  Ruth, beloved wife of Ira, devoted mother of Jonathan and Adele Schulman, cherished grandmother of Melissa and Jeremy. Loving sister of Louis Alter. Dear motherinlaw of Alan and Vivian. Services Sunday. 9:30 AM, at The Riverside, Bronx. 179 St. and Grand Concourse.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: G.S.A. FINDS AGENCIES STILL EAVESDROPPING
description: WASHINGTON. May 19 The General Services Administration has expressed concern about the continued ability of a wide raoge of Federal agencies to listen in on incoming and outgoing telephone calls despite Federal regulations imposed last year to curb the practice.

title: Tully Sets Vault Mark
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., May 19 (AP)Mike Tully broke the world polevault record in the Pacific8 Conference track and field championships at Oregon State University today.

title: Warrantlessness
description: J. Wallace LaPrade, the former agent in charge of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, recently held a news conference to complain about lack of rules governing warrantless coverage of individuals and organizations by Bureau agents. Mr. LaPrade asserted that the recent indictments of agents are an attempt to hold them responsible for activity that at the time appeared to be legal but was later determined by a new Administration to be unlawful.

title: More Than Words Can Ever Say
description: Soon we shall send Egypt, Israel and Saudi Arabia some dangerous warplanes.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the lost week

title: EXOFFICIAL OF U.S.I.A. AND STUDENT GUILTY OF SPYING FOR HANOI
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 19A Federal jury convicted a former official of the United States Information Agency and a Vietnamese graduate student today of being spies for Vietnam.

title: Primary Question: Candidates Names
description: TRENTON, May 19An overwhelming majority of New Jersey voters cannot name any of the candidates in either the Democratic or Republican primary contests for the United States Senate, according to a poll nicased today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: Hallberg, Sutton in Golf Final
description: PINEHURST, N.C., May 19 (UPI)The defending champion, Gary Hallberg, ousted Jim Gabrielson by 3 and I and Hal Sutton beat Walker Cup player, Vance Heafner, by 4 and 3 today to advance to tomorrow's 36hole final of the North and South amateur golf championship.

title: Of Mice and Men Is Set to Dance
description: The Atlanta Contemporary Dance Company bounced into town on Thursday for a debut season of four performances, at the Theater of the Riverde Church. The message was loud, dear and delivered with charming undorstatement: there's modern dance going on beyond the Hudson.

title: Fed Group Voted on May 5 To Keep 7% Funds Rate
description: The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee, in a special telephonic meeting, voted on May 5 to maintain the weekly average funds rate the shortterm interest rate from which most other interest rates are keyed upwardat about the prevailing 7 percent level.

title: HOUSE PASSES A BILL TO SAVE ALASKA LANDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed a  bill today that would preserve in a wild and protected status portions of. Alaska that are larger than all of Califo rnia.

title: Reds 4, Padres 3
description: AT CINCINNATIConsecutive home runs by Joe Morgan and George Foster with two out in the seventh inning lifted the Reds to victory. Dave Tomlin, who took over for Paul Moskau after the Padres went ahead, 32, in the seventh, picked up the victory, his second in three decisions.

title: CURARECASE FIGURE ACCUSED OF FRAMEUP
description: HACKENSACK, May 19In a heated exchange today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, the defense accused another doctor of framing Dr. Jascalevich in order to make a lot of money.

title: Books of The Times How to Live, What to Do
description: What a brave dream the idea of a Utopia is, yet how timid most Utopias have been, even in their very conceptions. All too often, they have a reductive approach to the good life, preferring to cure people of the idea of happiness rather than try to realize it. Utopian governments appear to have been very jealous, too, tending to replace human or sexual life with love of the state and regarding private propertyeven privacy itselfas a corrupting influence.

title: Article 1  No Title
Robert C. Van Tuyl Is Dead at 64; A Securities Leader for 2 Decades
description: Robert C. Van Tuyl, former vice chairman of Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. and an important figure in the securities industry for more than two decades, died last Monday in Naples, Fla. He was 64 years old.

title: Federal Agents Arrest 17 Aliens In Raid at a Jersey Plastic Plant
description: NEWARK, May 19 (AP)Seventeen illegal aliens have been arrested in a raid aL a Passaic plastic factory described as a sweatshop by Federal authorities.

title: Joan Harbeson Barnes Bride of Philip Pool Jr.
description: Joan Harbeson Barnes. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Ellis Barnes 2d of StLouis. was married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Anminziata in Ladue, Mo., to Philip Bemis Pool jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pool of New York and Nassau, the Bahamas. James R. Hartnett performed the ceremony.

title: The Preakness: What They Say
description: BALTIMORE, May 19 Summer, an almost total stranger, tiptoed into Maryland today just in time for the 103d annual festival of the Maryland Jockey Club, whose races, it was written many years ago, have always been distinguished by the fairness of decision, the large attendance of ladies and gentlemen from all parts of the country, and the fleetness of the thoroughbreds that contend for its liberal premiums. Centerpiece of the clambake is the Preakness Stakes, to be contested tomorrow by the only horse in the world that could win the triple crown this year, the two that were closest to him at the end of the Kentucky Derby, and four others that have a leg at each corner and nothing much besides.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: MicrofilmIng Corp. of America Moving Plant to North Carolina
description: The Microfilming Corporation of America announced yesterday that it would relocate its Glen Rock, N.J., plant to Sanford, N.C., later this year and that it had invited all of its 130 permanent emPlovees to move to the new site.

title: Yanks Trounce Blue Jays, 113; Mets Top Phils;McGraw Victim
description: Tug McGraw, once the toast of New York fans when he was toiling at Shea Stadium as a star bullpen tenant, last night gave home rooters in the crowd of 13,18! at Shea good cause to feel kindly toward him once again.

title: Bouton Starts Another Chapter
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., May 19 (AP) Jim Bouton, the former major league pitcher and bestselling author, made his second comeback in the Southern League tonight, and this time he was successful, scattering six hits to lead the Savannah Braves to a 53 victory over Nashville.

title: Red Brigades Meeting Place for Part of Rome Found
description: ROME, May 19The Italian police said today that they had discovered the place where members of the Red Brigades operating in the southern part of Rome had been holding meetings until recently.

title: Goldin Maps Contingency Plans to Meet 2 Payrolls
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin was preparing contingency plans yesterday to meet two payrolls without new loans from the city pension funds, ard he said that New York City could squeak through by not paying other bills coming due.

title: Bridge:
description: On some occasions, a defender can judge at an early stage what problem the declarer will have to face, and prepare his countermeasures.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONTelevision viewers often see a message in capital letters crawling across the bottom of the screen. It is probably made more compact and quicker to read by an invention that fits certain letters together.

title: Flexible Mortgage Gains Favor
description: With the help of a newly available graduated payment mortgage, James and Margaret Tessmer last week moved into a $35,000 splitlevel house in Deptford, N.J.

title: How Not to Equalize School Finance
description: The wide, sometimes shocking, disparities in spending by rich school districts and poor have attracted the attention of courts and legislatures in one state after another. Hence there should be wide interestbut little comfortin the firstyear results of New Jersey's efforts to support local schools through a courtimposed income tax: It has actually widened the dollar gap between wealthy districts and poor ones.

title: CBS Is Planning Special of the Leningrad Ice Show
description: There's an ice show from Leningrad. allRussian except for the two hosts, Sally Struthers of All in the Family and Harry Morgan, the top doc in M*A*S*H, headed for CBSTV sometime in the future.

title: A RESCUE OPERATION
description: PARIS, May 19France dropped 400 paratroopers into the embattled Zairian coppermining town of Kolwezi today to rescue foreigners trapped behind the lines of insurgents, and said that the bodies of 44 Europeans had been found. They apparently had been shot to death by the rebels.

title: 3 Share Lead on 69's at Fors gate
description: JAMESBURG, N.J., May 19Nancy Lopez was moving along at even par through 16 holes on the East Course at Forsgate Country Club. Ahead was the most difficult par3 hole on the women's tourand one of the most difficult firnslung holcsbefore sne could completo her first round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour stop here. She had never played these holes in anger before: She was an amateur when the tour made its first and second stops at Forsgate in 1976 and 1977,

title: Cook Industies Has Cash Left
description: E. W. Cook, chairman of Cook Industries, disclosed in a proxy statement that. he expected the ailing former grain merchandising company to have $35 million to $40 million in cash left over after all debts, shortterm loans, accounts payable and other obligations were met. He also said he might attempt to make the company private.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Spacecraft Is to Begin Trip to Venus Today
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 19Pioneer Venus 1, the first of two spacecraft that will explore the Earth's nearest planetary neighbor this year, was scheduled tonight for launching at 9:13 A.M. tomorrow.

title: About New York
description: When George Wynne decided to quit the priesthood eight years ago, it was not so bad as it might have been because he had entered the seminary after college, not as a teenager in the classic bloom of vocation that makes parents so proud. He has friends in that situation, who first delighted their parents with the calling, then crushed them by quitting as priests, and some of these men are still ostracized by their families.

title: Retiring Pilot Takes Friends on a Flight of Fancy
description: Some people are glad to get away from their work when they retire, but not Capt. Harry Stuart, He has enjoyed his job so much that he invited IOU friends, relatives and neighbors to come watch him work before he stops.

title: Treasury to Shape Urban Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Stung by criticism from the White House, the Treasury Department has agreed to take the lead in drafting and lobbying for legislation that would establish a national development bank, a key component of the Carter Administration's urban policy.

title: World Gold Prices
Notes on People
description: The Greek Government announced yesterday that Christina Onassis would grant more than $25 million to charities and cultural projects through the Alexander Onassis Foundation, created by her late father, Aristotle Onassis,

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: More Organizations Join Battle To Bar New Tower on Palisades
description: EDGEWATER, May 19A group of Cliffside Park residents are in the midst of a yearlong battle to halt plans by Centex Corporation of Dallas to build a third 31story structure in its Winston Towers complex at the top of the Palisades.

title: Fiscal Hurdles For New York
description: All the required elements to resolve the city's financial situation remain unsettled. Here, at a glance, is what needs to be clone:

title: Preakness: Who Will Set Pace?
description: BALTIMORE , May 19Pace makes the race, they say, and there was a growing suspicion here today that pace and jockey strategy could decide the outcome of tomorrow's Preakness Stakes.

title: Map Hobbyist Sharpens Images of Earth From Space
description: MADISON, N.J.John P. Snyder may not yet qualify as the Mercator of the space age, but, working at home with a pocket calculitor, he has solved a mapping problem that had baffled the professional mathematicians and cartographers for several years. He deNeloped a set of mathematical aquations by which images of Earth, taken by spacecraft, can be converted to accurate maps.

title: Based Near Belgian Border
description: BRUSSELS, May 19Defense ministers of Atlantic alliance countries agreed today to press for a final decision by their governments by autumn for the purchase of a $2 billion Airborne Warning and Control System involving the use of spacial planes.

title: Postal Unit Gives Final Approval To the 15Cent Rate for Letters
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (Reuters)The Postal Service Board of Governors voted today to raise the price of mailing a domestic letter to 15 cents effective May 29.

title: EDITOR OF VILLAGE VOICE TO KEEP JOB UNTIL JAN. 8
description: Marianne Partridge, who was dismissed last week as editor of The Village Voice, will remain in her position until Jan. 8, William J. Ryan, president and publisher of The Voice said Thursday.

title: COMMODITIES; Copper Futures Retreat; Zaire Impact Discounted
description: Copper futures on the New York Commodity Exchange moved down a little yesterday in a technical reaction after a week of strengthening prices.

title: London Silver Vaults Lure Bargain Hunters
description: LONDON, May 19  Robert and Eleanor Hughes of Greenport, L.I., headed for Chancery Lane, headquarters of London's legal fraternity, entered a shabby building and were welcomed by a sign saying: No Dogs or Photography Allowed.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Blue Cross Rise Urged in Jersey In Rate Revision
description: TRENTON. May 19A new hospital ratesetting system, scheduled to be sent to the floor of the Legislature Monday, would cost New Jersey's 4.3 million Blue Cross subscribers 10 percent more, or a total of $40 million to $60 million extra a year, while bills would be lowered for noninsured patients and commercial hospital insurance companies.

title: Teng Says That the Gang of Four Are Alive and Will Go on Eating
description: PEKING, May 18 (UPI) Deputy Prime Minister Tong Hsiaoping said today that the socalled Gang of Four, led by Mao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching, were still alive and will go on eating their meals.

title: Sindona Free Pending Appeal
description: Michele Sindona. he Italian financier wanted on fraud charges in Italy, was allowed to remain free on bail in New York yesterday to give his lawyers time to file a court petition to appeal a decision to extradite him.

title: Cash Prices
description: (Prices in N.Y. unless otherwise posted)

title: G.M. PUTS 5% CEILING ON EXECUTIVE RAISES
description: DETROIT, May 19  In a gesture of support for President Carter's efforts to curb inflation, the General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest industrial corporation, said today that a 5 percent ceiling had been placed on the combined increases in salary and bonus pay for its top executives this year.

title: C141'S DISPATCHED
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The White House announced today that 18 United States Air Force C141 transports were taking part in the French and Belgian airlift to Zaire as the Carter Administration sought to demonstrate a readiness to counter Soviet and Cuban military involvement in Africa.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 19 (AP) Willy Lindstrom's powerplay goal after 4 minutes 56 seconds of the first period was the first of five 4 minutes 56 seconds of the first period was the first of five Winnipeg goals in less than three minutes as the Jets routed the New England Whalers, 102, tonight. The triumph gave the Jets a 30 lead in the World Hockey Association playoff final.

title: Baroque Music Duo Plays Sonatas
description: Authentic instruments, good taste and awareness of style gave Jean Antrim and Jocelyn Chaparro three indispensable steps toward success in their concert of Baroque music at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night. Miss Antrim played a transverse wooden flute modeled after a 1670 instrument by Chevalier and Miss Chaparro's harpsichord was a splendid silverytoned affair with two manuals, designed after a 1620 RuckersBlanchet picturebook device.

title: A RESCUE OPERATION
description: PARIS, May I9France dropped 400 paratroopers into the embattled Zairian coppermining town of Kolwezi today to rescue foreigners trapped behind the lines of insurgents, and said that the bodies of 44 Europeans had been found. They apparently had been shot to death by the rebels.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bank Action on Theater

title: World News Briefs
description: The following dispatch was subject to censorship by the Rhodesian military authorities.

title: Political Foes on Cordial Terms
description: ROME, May 19In this ancientcapital, leaders of the two major parties, the Christian Democrats and the Communistsand of other political groups as wellhave long been on cordial terms.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, May 19 (UPI)  The strange case of a file clerk for the Federal Bureau of Investigation who sold F.B.I. documents to underworld figures has ended in fiveyear Federal prison terms for the clerk, Geraldine M. Rabinowitz, and her husband, Jeffrey. Bureau officials have said the case was only the second time in history that an F.B.I. employee had been charged with such an offense.

title: EXOFFICIAL OF U.S.I.A. AND STUDENT GUILTY OF SPYING FOR HANOI
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 19A Federal jury convicted a former official of the United States Information Agency and a Vietnamese graduate student today of being spies for Vietnam.

title: National League Giants 10, Dodgers 7
description: AT LOS ANGELESBill Madlock drove in four runs and Darrell Evans hit a pair of homers to carry the Giants to victory, their eighth in succession. The Gians, leading the Western Division, dropped the Dodgers into the third place in the standings before a sellout crowd of 52,388. Rick Monday hit a pair of threerun homers for the Dodgers. John Montefusco, with relief from Gary Lavelle, got the triumph to improve his record to 32.

title: ArguelloAlcala Bout Set
description: Alexis Arguello, World Boxing Council junior lightweight champion, will make his second title defense June 3 against Diego Alcala in San Juan, P.R., a spokesman for Don King Promotions said today. Arguello, from Panama, has won 54 of his career bouts, 43 by knockout, and lost three. Alcala is 3082.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: 3 CIVILIANS DIE IN CRASH OF HELICOPTER PROTOTYPE
description: A prototype Army. Black Hawk helicopter crashed into the Housatonic River in Shelton, Conn., yesterday, killing three civilians who were aboard it, according to the manufacturer, the Sikorsky Aircraft Division of the United Technologies Corporation.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Robert K. Poole, Wildlife Expert And Environmentalist in Africa
description: Robert K. Poole, director of African operations for the African Wildlife Leadership Foundation, died May 12 from injuries sustained in an automobile accident in Kenya. He was 45 years old and lived in Nairobi.

title: Dominicans Expect Vote Tally Soon
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Fleaullic, May 19The Government of President Jopquin Balaguer indicated today tha it would soon begin releasIng results of Tuesday's disputed national election. At the same time, the leadership of the opposition Dominican Revolutionary Party, which has said it won a landslide victory, expressed confidence that the crisis Would be resolved within 24 hours.

title: EARNINGS
description: Volkslwagenwerk A.G. increased its consolidated net profit in the first quarter by 24 percent, it announced yesterday from its headquarters in West Germany.

title: Israeli Army Imprisons 4 on Charges of Brutality to Religious Recruits
description: TEL AVIV, May 19Two Israeli Army lieutenants and two sergeants have been tried and imprisoned on charges that instructors at an armored training base subjected conscripts with special religious status to brutal treatment driving one to suicide.

title: Time Inc. Acquiring Box Maker
description: Time Inc., in its fifth major expansion move in the last few months, yesterday announced tentative plans to acquire the Inland Container Corporation in a cash and stock exchange valued at an estimated $281 million.

title: Realty News
description: The HeywardRobinson Company, an international engineering, consulting and general contracting company, is moving from 100 Church Street in Lower Manhattan to One World Trade Center.

title: 2 RUSSIANS ARRESTED BY F.B.I FOR SPYING
description: WASHINGTON. May 20Three Soviet citizens were caught in the act of picking up classified documents relating to the Navy's highly sensitive underwater Warfare projects today and seized as spies, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: SHOP TALK International Arrivals
description: GREENPORT THE stores of summer are awakening now, getting ready for the hordes of vacationists who return like swallows  on schedule  to their seasonal haunts. Shopkeepers are unfastening their shutters, sprucing up and stocking up.

title: Long Island/ This Week
description: AMAGANSE1T  Our Town, naivestyle watercolors by Margaret Lamb; 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Mondays, Thursdays through Saturdays; 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Sundays; through June 3; Gallery East Hampton, Main St. Recepthn today 2 to 5 P.M.

title: THE MARKETS A Few Cheers Were in Order
description: When the gong rang last Wednesday afternoon to signal the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, a few cheers certainly were in order. Stock prices stood at their highest level in eight months and trading volume in recent weeks had been the busiest in Big Board history. It was a continuation of the spectacular spring rally, fed by institutions and individuals. both at home and abroad.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: LETTERS OF E. B. WHITE, collected and edited by Dorothy Lobrano Guth. (Harper/Colophon, $6.95.) More than 600 pages of prose treasure, written by the New Yorker editor, essayist, author of Charlotte's Web and Stuart Little between 1908 (when he was 9 and living in Mount Vernon, N.Y.) to 1976 (when he'd retired to a Maine farm). A best seller in hardcover.

title: Anita H. Laudone Is Bride of Colin E. Harley
description: Anita Helene Laudone and Colin ?? Harley, lawyers with Davis Polk & Wardwell, were married yesterday afternoon in the Park Avenue Methodist Church by the Rev. Philip A. C. Clarke.

title: The G.O.P. and the Legislature
description: FOR years now, the major criticism leveled at the Republican Party by political scholars, writers and certain of its own members has been that the party is little more than a dwindling band of aginners, a party standing largely for negative things or for nothing at all.

title: A Moslem School Upsets Hunterdon
description: WEST AMWELL IT has long been the dream of Dr. Ahsan U. Zafar to create, on a secluded tract of farmland in this rural Hunterdon County township, a religious school and recreation center for children of an orthodox Moslem sect.

title: Savoring Ray Noble's Early Swing Music on Disks
description: When Ray Noble died on April 3, it was not, as such events are often described, the end of an era. Mr. Noble's era had ended more that 40 years earlier. But his death served as a reminder of the important, and largely overlooked, role that he played as arranger, conductor and composer in the transformation of pop music in the 30's. And it can encourage a rehearing of the records made between 1930 and 1934 that made his musical reputation, as opposed to his later and, unfortunately, more widely known reputation as a comedian on American radio. By a happy quirk of fatethe enthusiasm of a Noble fan who happens to have his own record company, Bill Borden, the head of MonmouthEvergreen Recordsvirtually all of Mr. Noble's English recordings are currently available on seven LP recordings.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY Outstanding, but Excessed
description: SCHOOL is a disagreeable place these days, and it isn't only the kids who are saying so. I hate to seem like a poor sport, but I'm not the only one grumbling. If I don't exactly speak for the masses, I do speak for many distraught teachers who expected to enjoy their work for as long as they wished and now find themselves excessed.

title: Picture Credits
ANTIQUES
description: ORANGE MODERN times have passed by the old center of Orange at Valley and Freeman Streets. The modern gasoline station at the corner seems an affront to the drowsy quality of the neighborhood. Things need a bit of paint here and there.

title: Words And Music
description: NED ROREM rides again. A new diary is at hand, actually a mixture of critical essays (on Benjamin Britten's Death in Venice, Nicolas Nabokov's Bagazh, Tennessee Williams's short stories, and so on) and shorter items in the manner of diary entries. It's a tired, dispirited book, one which suggests that Mr. Rorem is writing a diary because he's known for writing diaries, because it's somehow expected.

title: The Real Geraniums Are Spring's Charmers
description: While Gertrude Stein's edict that a rose is a rose is a rose may be true, the same doesn't hold for geraniums. The geraniums cher ished in my semishady rock garden are far different from the big, flamboyant geraniums that decorate untold numbers of cemeteries and brighten millions of windowboxes.

title: Elizabeth M. White Bride Of George Peper, Editor
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Marshall White, a medical illustrator to George Frederick Peper, executive editor of Golf magazine, took place yesterday in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. William A. Jarvi performed the ceremony.

title: The National Parks in City Pent
description: What do the Saugus Iron Works in Massachusetts, Ford's Theater in Washington. the former Federal prison on Alcatraz Island and the White House have in common? The answer is that they are managed, anomalously, by the National Park Service, created 106 years ago to protect wilderness.

title: Italy Is Searching For a Top Leader Of the Red Brigades
description: ROME, May 2pThe police were searching today for Mario Moretti, who is known to have been an active figure in Italian terrorist organizations for at least six sears and who is now believed to head of one of three groups of the Red Brigades operating in Rome.

title: Topics: Making Change
description: En route to passing the buckin this case authorizing a convenient new onedollar coinCongress has become ensnared in controversy. Feminists think the proposed coin should bear the image of Susan B. Anthony, the energetic advocate of women's suffrage. The Treasury Department, wary of timeconsuming competition from other worthy groups, urges the stylized image of MissLiberty. Count us firmly on both sides of the coin.

title: Health
description: The hearings by a New York State Assembly investigative committee last fall deviated startlingly from the routine. Asked to describe what they did in the operating room, the medicalsupply salesmen who

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Normal Ties With China
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Zbigniew BrzezinsKi, President Garter's national security ?? on his trip to ?? will be prooing China's attitude toward establishing formal diplomatic relations. In the United States there is confusion about the legal implications of normalization. Three misconceptions cloud analysis:

title: Josh Gibson: A. Symbol of Injustice, But Not a Martyr
description: To some, Josh Gibson's death contained an element of martyrdom. Ted Page and Jimmy Crutchfield, both sincere, genuine men who ate and played and slept with Josh believe he died of a broken heart. And nobody doubts them, for Josh's presumed disappointment over not making, the majors is a romantic, tragic notion that befits an athlete of such magnificence dying so young.

title: Marriage Announcement 6  No Title
description: Lisa Jane Pearson Is Wed

title: Arabs and Israelis Alike Share Illusions About U.S.
description: JERUSALEM  Yasir Arafat asked an interviewer questions about it. King Hussein said he watched with anxiety. President Anwar elSadat was confident about it. Israelis from Menachem Begin to the taxi driver talk about it all the time.

title: Sarah S. Osborne Engaged to Robert V. Edgar
description: Announcement had been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederik RL. Osborne of Auburn, N.Y., and Pointe an Pic, Quebec, of the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Sedgwick Osborne, to Robert V. Edgar, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Jr. of Geneva and Cedarhurst, L.I .

title: HOME CLINIC A Way to Beat Lightning to the Punch
description: WE ARE entering the time of year when the weather forecast frequently ends with the prediction local thunderstorms are likely. And thunderstorms usually mean lightning, that awesome display of atmospheric electricity that causes many fires and millions of dollars worth of property damage each year.

title: STAMPS
description: No one hearing the records of Jimmie Rodgers and the country music he endowed with such vitality and direction could doubt it was real American music, with strains at least as old as the nation itself. That is why the commemorative coming out this Wednesday for the singer and his music is an appropriate beginning for a new Performing Arts and Artists Series.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Bonnie Wolfman Wed

title: President Levine
description: THESE two sparkling first novels uphold the American ideal that life can be bizarre for anyone, regardless of race, creed or ecology.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 20 (AP) Wojtek Fibak of Poland ousted Buster Mottram of Britain, 63, 76, 64, and Guillermo Vilas of Argentina won by default from injured Manuel Orantes today for berths in the finals of the German open tennis tournament.

title: A SalesTax Debate With Quebec Is Isolating Trudeau
description: MONTREAL, May 20An increasingly intense battle over taxes between the federal Government and Quebec has isolated Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau as rarely before.

title: Guess Where Seaver's 41 Is?; Sports of The Times
description: Nearly a year after the deed was done, Tom Seaver's uniform is alive and well in Shea Stadiumlocked in the New York Mets office safe. The uniform has been stashed there by Joe McDonald, the general manager, to prevent souvenirhunters from snatching it. The safe combination is not right 41, but the irony is obvious.

title: Taralee Stack And Hans Roden To Wed July 8
description: Taralee Stack, a stockbroker with Folger Nclan Fleming Douglas Inc. in Washington, and Hans Olof Christian Roden, who is with the International Monetary Fund in Washington, plan to be married in the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., on July 8.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: T. Edward Hollander, Chancellor of the state's Department of Higher Education, was quoted on April 26 as saying that teachers should be knowledgeable about developmental, behavioral and abnormal psychology. Mr. Hollander is asking for new courses in an attempt to find a way to improve the current situation in our schools.

title: Lynn Forester Becomes Bride Of A. H. Platt
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday evening for the marriage of Lynn Forester, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Kenneth Forester of Oradell, N.J., to Alexander Hartley Platt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Adrian T. Platt of Madison, N.J.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Newfoundland: A World of Comfortable Englishness
description: After an allnight mystery voyage on a luxurious Swedishbuilt ocean liner through a wall of fog one arrives at a cluster of misty lights glowing feebly in the soft, closedin morning grayness of the shore of Newfoundland, at Port aux Basques. The fog lifts briefly to reveal a few modest frame houses perched here and there in the stony tundra.

title: Homosexual Bar Stirs Controversy For Provineetown
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., May 20The question of who has the right to determine the moral standards for a town is being threshed out in the courts after a decision by a Massachusetts agency to overrule Provincetown's decision to revoke the liquor license of a homosexual bar where seven men were arrested last fall and charged with committing unnatural sex acts on the premises.

title: Fiscal Hurdles For New York
description: All the required elements to resolve the city's financial situatinn remain unsettled. Here, at a glance, is what needs to be done:

title: Senate Passes Bill on Grazing Fees
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)The Senate passed legislation today to impose a oneyear moratorium on grazing fees charged by the Federal Guvernment on millions of acres of public lands. A HouseSenate conference committee mus now work out a compromise bill, Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus and Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland had proposed fee increases beginning this fall, but ranchers protested the proposals.

title: THEATER Pippin Replayed Minus the Frills
description: EAST WINDSOR THE musical Pippin was the darling of Broadway in 1972 and for several seasons after that. At the time, despite the many people who worked on it and a performance by Ben Vereen as the Leading Player that made him a star, what Pippin really seemed to be was a showcase for the dazzling talbnts of Bob Fosse as directorchoreographer. His dance numbers were breathtaking, his staging electric, and he had the good sense to stage the show without an intermission, preventing the audience from leaving out of weariness with the book.

title: Museum About Life in Diaspora Opens in Tel Aviv
description: TEL AVIV, May 20A museum tracing the history and life of Jews dispersed in many countries over the centuries opened this week at Tel Aviv University.

title: Florida Senate Approves Bill Allowing Manufacture of Laetrile
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 20 (AP)A bill that would allow the manufacture of laetrile, a controversial substance used in the treatment of cancer, has been approved by the Florida Senate.

title: U.S. Plane Deal Spurs a Drive by Israelis to Build Jet
description: The Senate vote clearing the way for the package sale of fighter planes to Israel and two Arab nations has spurred a campaign in Israel to proceed with a new homeproduced jet that would be equal to the F15.

title: Lonesome Cowboy Tells All
description: CHATHAM 'I WASN'T lonesome, and I wasn't a cowboy, John White, the former Lonesome Cowboy of radio fame, said with the dry humor for which he is noted.

title: GunLaw Deadline Extended
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)The Treasury Department, acknowledging the dispute provoked in some quarters by its proposed firearms regulations, said today that it was extending the deadline for comment on them. The department proposed requiring manufacturers to stamp coded serial numbers on each gun, to report all gun thefts to the Treasury and to submit quarterly reports on all sales.

title: Courville and Zahringer Reach Travis Golf Final
description: GARDEN CITY, L.L, May 20Jerry Courville of the Shorehaven (Conn.) Country Club became the favorite today to win the 68th Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament after two impressive triumphs. The 43yearold amateur golfer, the runnerup the last two yeart, defeated Peter Van Ingen of MeadoW Brook, 4 and 3, in the opening round. He won by the same margin in the quarterfinals from David Racaini of Wykagyl.

title: ART Imitation of Life
description: HARTFORD THE Tapestry Room at the Wadsworth Atheneum no longer houses tapestries, as its regular visitors know, but instead has American paintings of the 18th and 19th centuries. These are temporarily acting as a backdrop to six lifesize figures by Duane Hanson, an artist in Americana whose reputation should soon be rivaling Norman Rockwell's.

title: The Helpers and the Renegades
description: FOR the last decade or so, a little war has been raging in the professional classes between two groups that might be called, for want of any better terms, the helpers and the renegades. The struggle is over the privileged status of the institutions and professions that claim to act in the best interests of people who are socially subordinate and dependent. It involves the power and discretionary authority of mental hospitals, schools, prisons and parole boards, fostercare and welfare agencies, nursing homes and other social services and the rights of their patients, students, prisoners, charges and clients.

title: Again, Darkness at Noon
description: As the trial in Moscow of Yuri Orlov came to its grimly ordained end, our thoughts returned to the notorious Soviet trials of the 1930's. There are differences, but the underlying spirit is identical.

title: ART
description: MONTCLAIR MANY of us look back on the 1940's as not a particularly happy period in American history. At the outset of the decade, we were just shaking ourselves loose of the Depression, and that dispiriting upheaval was followed by one of the most cataclysmic events of all time: World War II.

title: Article 3  No Title
C1KLDREN'S BOOKS
description: I have to stipulate at the beginning that I am a pushover for James Marshall's cheerfully stolid drawings. When the Stupid family throws a costume party to celebrate Buster and Petunia's having flunked everything in school, Grandfather Stupid comes down the chimney dressed as the Easter Bunny, the cat and dog make the punch and father Stupid comes as Gen. George Washing Machine. What gossip columnist could describe the Stupids lovely home, adorned with such works of art as Mount Stupid, a masterful rendering of a flat green field, and helpful signs like, Please Don't Lick the Walls? I would much rather linger with the Stupids than deal seriously with the other four books reviewed here  and if I were a 6yearold, by gosh, I would.

title: Marriage Announcement 8  No Title
description: Alexandra Whitcraft Wed

title: Excitement Floats At Huguenot Park
description: SALVATORE TOCCI, in an oldfashioned straw skimmer and a redstriped blazer, looked dashing as he pedaled over the Twin Lakes in New Rochelle's Huguenot Park. I skated on this lake as a boy, even swam in it, although you weren't supposed to, Mr. Tocci, who is in his 70's, said with a wink. I'm glad they are doing something exciting here again.

title: An Offer SevenUp Couldn't Refuse
description: Philip Morris Inc. wants a crack at the softdrink industry so badly that it is willing to spend more than $500 million to buy its way in. That's an offer the SevenUp Company couldn't refuse. After two weeks of holding out while its stock was bid up, last week it agreed to sell.

title: Michael Weinberger Weds Miss Barmash
description: Marilyn Barmash. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Barmash of Hollis Hills. Queens, was married last night to Michael Weinberger. son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Weinberger of Manhattan.

title: Queue's Company
description: WE take the Jeep, of course with its fourwheeldrive, winch, and sidemounted pick, shovel, axe and crowbar. In their Bean Vagabond Packs, my wife and daughter carry the Stanley Vacuum Bottles, the Frontier Camp Ware and the food. The Folding Camp Table (seats four) is my responsibility, while my son is charged with the Smoke N Pit Barbecue.

title: Go by the Weather, Not the Calendar
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, now is the time to plant beans and corn in North Jersey gardens. But who can tell what the weather will be like?

title: Edward Crotty, Lawyer, Weds Daphna Krim
description: Daphna Danon Krim and Edward Crotty were married yesterday by Acting Supreme Court Justice Harold J. Rcth??x the New York home co the brick parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur 3. Krin??. Mr. Crotty is a son the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Crotty of Rochester. Mich.

title: PEOPLE
description: A Swiss appeals court ruled last week that Bernard Cornfeld must stand trial on charges of fraud, embezzlement and criminal mismanagement stemming from the collapse of I.O.S. Ltd., the mutual fund complex he founded. If convicted, he could be ?? to ?? for up to 10 years.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Ronald Smothers wrote with insight in his article [April 23] on a proposed Aquinas and lona College merger. Iona began its extension work at St. Thomas Aquinas College in 1972, and it was this successful beginning that has sparked our recent meetings.

title: Community Groups Look to Grass Roots At Annual Meeting
description: To Mayor Koch it was the largest annual partnership meeting in the citymeaning partnership between government and the governed.

title: Clinic in Chinatown Presses Drive for a New Facility
description: Wideeyed Mindy Pang approached a cluttered desk in the. Chinatown Health Clinic and proferred a crisp new $10 bill. Asked by an onlooker why she was doing so, the 8yearold scurried behind her grandmother and whispered, We're helping the Chinese.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY The Making of a Bed
description: WHY are you doing that? asks the neighbor's child as she watches me smooth sheets and fluff pillows. I have no quick answer.

title: Marriage Announcement 11  No Title
description: Weddings

title: This Movie Is The Easiest Thing I've Ever Done
description: The Wall Street law firm was in disarray. At one end of the blackandwhite tiled hall stood a group of secretaries, straining at an invisible line marked off by a young woman wearing a walkietalkie at her waist. At the other end stood a group of dispossessed lawyers, peering anxiously into their row of offices, And in one of those offices, the one with the O. Barrett nameplate, sat Ryan O'Neal, looking right at home interviewing three Lower East Side clients for a pro bono case.

title: New Landslides at Japanese Resort
description: NIIGATA, Japan, May 20 (Reuters)More than 1,000 soldiers and firemen ran for their lives today when new landslides thundered down a mountainside near here, where 13 persons have been buried by mudslides. The soldiers and firemen were searching for the bodies of eight persons still missing since Thursday's slides battered the ski resort of Myoko Kogen Machi rear here. A fifth body was found today.

title: 81 Big john Taylor Wins at Aqueduct
description: Just scoot as you leave the gate, said Doug Peterson, the trainer, to Jacinto Vasquez, the Jockey, as he saddled Big John Taylor before yesterday's 34th running of the Roseben Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Too Many Schools, Too Few Students Bring New Problems
description: WHITE PLAINS CLOSING a neighborhood school is one of the most painful events a community can experience, a school administrator in the county said recently, and yet we have had to face the fact that Westchester has too many schools and not enough students.

title: GARDENING
description: WHEN your house was new and your trees were small, your whole garden was sunny. Salvia and petunias would grow well most anywhere. Now that your trees are large, your garden is shady and no longer allows you to grow sunloving flowers. Or your garden may have always been shady, because your house was built in a wooded area and every attempt was made to save all the trees. After trying for years without success, you have finally given up trying to grow flowers that need sunlight.

title: INTERVIEW One Nurse's Victory Over Darkness
description: BRIDGEPORT AS a registered nurse at the Harborview Senior Citizens Health Clinic, Maureen Kearns takes the blood pressure, pulse and temperature of her patients, and counsels them on problems of health, nutrition and their families.

title: Plan in the Works To Protect Coastline
description: IN compliance with a Federal mandate to devise plans to protect and coordinate growth along its 32,000 miles of coastline, the state will soon unveil its program to create five coastalmanagement zones, one of which will cover Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Jordan: Desolate Wilderness and Wondrous Ruins in the Desert
description: The day I learned I would he going to Jordan as a writer with a filmmaking crew, my mind drew a blank. If someone had said Norway or Portugal or Malaysia, or even some place I had never visited, mental images would have snapped into focus, but Jordan was only a sea of sand in my mind.

title: The Amateur Chamber Musicians Network
description: A professor at the University of Oregon Medical School has to attend a convention in his specialty in Atlantic City. A dedicated musician, he takes along his cello. He also packs a mysterious magazinesize booklet, some 70 pages of fine Print.

title: Refugees in Kolwezi Recount Their Ordeal
description: KOLWEZI, Zaire, May 20 (AP)For the hundreds of Europeans leaving this embattled city today their evacuation marked the end of a week of constant terror at the hands of rebel invaders.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: This is to suggest an addendum to the excellent article [April 23] by Robert Tomasson on the troublesome traffic problems in Fairfield County.

title: Andretti Takes Prix Pole
description: ZOLDER,Belgium, May 20 (AP)Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., in a new JPSLotus 79. took the pole position today for tomorrow's Belgian Grand Prix, the sixth stop toward the world drivers championship.

title: Ballet Theater Steps Lively
description: The scene was decidedly domestic: a smiling mother holding her threemonthold baby boy in her lap, feeding him spoonfuls of baby food, while in the nearby kitchen the child's father warmed a bottle in a pan of water on the stove. Soft words spoken in Russian crossed the mother's lips as she urged the infant to eat. And when the bottle was brought to complete the meal, an aura of contentment fell on the family group.

title: Gambling Isn't All in Atlantic City
description: THE dealers in Atlantic City have had their finger joints oiled and the feltcovered tables are in place. Resorts International is booked solid. The New York City high rollers have boned up on their crap shooting and have begun reciting all possible combinations that total 21.

title: Questions/Answers
description: Our ivy did not winter well and shows a number of bronze leaves. We have been told an application of fertilizer will help to bring it back, but how can we apply it in the mass of leaves and stems.? P.M.H., Manhattan.

title: New York Municipal Hospitals Found Plagued by Nurse Shortage
description: A visiting committee has reported that New York City's municipal hospitals are plagued by a shortage of nursing personnel, and it asserted that the Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, for instance, lifethreatening shortages exist constantly in the intensivecare units, the neonatal unit and on almost all of the wards.

title: Experiment Finds Cash Grants Tend to Split Welfare Families
description: SEATTLE, May 20 (AP)Welfare cash grants tend to break up twoparent families, says Joe Corbett, the director of one of the most expensive social experiments ever undertaken in the country, who described the finding as completely contrary to our expectations.

title: World News Briefs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 20Leaders of Brazil's armed farces issued statements today supporting President Ernesto Geisel's plan to transfer power to a handpicked successor, Gen. Joo Baptista Figueiredo, next year.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203)3487767.

title: Allowances Raised For British Royalty
description: LONDON, May 20 (Reuters)Official allowances for Britain's royal family have been raised, according to figures published this week This year's total will be about $4.6 million.

title: When the Soundtrack Makes the Film
description: Movie soundtrack albums have been around for a long time. But they have traditionally been of music composed in the postTchaikovsky symphonic idiom, and most of them have been little more than aural reminders of the movies.

title: Park and the Opposition Shift Tactics In Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A year ago, government agents swept through the streets here arresting dozens of critics the Government of President Park Chung Hee. Lengthy interrogations, trials and imprisonments followed.

title: Condominiums  Promising State Market
description: CLLIFSIDE PARK THE word rolls easily over the tongue now. No stammering or halting and starting over. Condominium . To the especially au courant, it has even become condo.

title: New Critic Back Down South
description: WHEN Malcolm Cowley published a collection of William Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha works in 1946, almost all the novelist's books were out of print. Faulkner was chiefly a writer's writer, the subject of brilliant essays by Conrad Aiken and Robert Penn Warren, but he had been forced to supplement his income by doing movie scripts in Hollywood. Then success came in like a tide. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1950. His fame coincided with the postWorld War II boom in literary scholarship; and by now Faulkner has been overlaid by more articles, dissertations and books than almost any other American writer. But we still lack a firstrate book about him. Cleanth Brooks's is not that book, but it does two important things: it reaffirms the distinctive character of Southern culture both explicitly and by the implications of its critical method, and it gives the best account of the work Faulkner did in the 1920's as an intellectually gawky and emotionally moonstruck beginner.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Andrew Tobias, author of The Only Investment Guide You'll Ever Need, has a passion for things that pay off. He also advocates  it's another of the themes of his bestselling book  not investing recklessly or needlessly in things you don't have to, which applies to his 1974 Toyota: I've decided to take my own advice, he said the other day. Between the insurance, looking for a space to park it and the rest of the hassle of keeping a car in Manhattan, it doesn't pay. I think I've got a customeranother author.

title: HOME CLINIC A Way to Beat Lightning to the Punch
description: WE ARE entering the time of year when the weather forecast frequently ends with the prediction local thunderstorms are likely. And thunderstorms usually mean lightning, that awesome display of atmospheric electricity that causes many fires and millions of dollars worth of property damape each year.

title: Miami: Seen in Period of Cultural Growth
description: MIAMI No one is yet calling this holiday playgroundsometimes referred to as the had taste capital of the worlda mecca for the arts. But the fact that it will soon build its first publicly financed art gallery, part of a $21.9million cultural complex designed by the architect Philip Johnson, confirms the belief of Miami boosters that the area is entering a period of major cultural growth.

title: Supervisors Fare Best in Wage Study
description: HACKENSACK FOR the second year in a row, the position of supervisor in a mediumsized company was the must remunerative in the North Jersey area, according to the ninth annual wage and fringebenefit study conducted by the .Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Northern New Jersey.

title: Carter Sister's Plan To Visit ExJews On L.I. Is Assailed
description: A scheduled appearance next month on Long Island by Ruth Carter Stapleton before a small group of Jewish converts to Christianity has touched off protests by a number of Jewish and Christian leaders, some of whom have asked her to stay away

title: ALBANY GETS AROUND TO HANDLING OF DOGS
description: ALBANY, May 19In the midst of controversies over rent increases and crime, the Legislature finally got around this week to one of the most controversial issues of the legislative sessionthe care and handling of dogs.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Democrats Assess Assembly Role
description: THE No. 1 priority of Governor Byrne and the Assembly for the next two years is do whatever is necessary to encourage the creation of more jobs and stimulate business expansion in the private sector.

title: Silver Screen in the Sky
description: The film, as usual, is a sciencefiction one. We see only sciencefiction films up here. This month it is Bobby Deerfield, starring Al Pacino and Marthe Keller. Last month, it was Three Women, featuring Shelly Duvall and Sissy Spacek. Things are a little late getting up here, but we don't mind. We understand that they have to come a long way.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available

title: Marriage Announcement 7  No Title
description: Karolina Illigen Is Bride

title: DR. MARGARET KIELY, 84, EXQUEENS COLLEGE DEAN
description: Dr. Margaret Kiely, a former dean of the faculty of Queens College, died Thursday at her home in Bridgeport, Conn. She was 84 years old.

title: Atlantic City Passes Go But Will It Collect $200?
description: The First Casino Is Officially Set to Open This Week

title: Granite Challenges Glass on Facades
description: Brick and stone are making a comeback in the skyscraper architecture of the 1970's.

title: Commuters Take Aim at a ailroad
description: PASSENGERS on the old New York & Long Branch Railroad, now part of the Conrail system, have, without question, the highest frustration threshold among all New Jersey commuters, and so the recent militant stance taken by the line's riders, including their threats of lawsuits, must be taken seriously.

title: Health Maintenance Groups Take Growing Role as Resistance Eases
description: Prepaid physician and hospital care, under the awkward name of health maintenance organizations, seems to be overcoming public and professional resistance and is assuming an increasingly important role in the nation's health care delivery system.

title: Amy L.Hyman Engaged to Seth Allan Barad
description: The engagement of Amy Lynn Hyman to Seth Allan Barad has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Hyman of Dumont, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Barad of Belmont, Mass.

title: ProductLiability Bill Limits Basis for Suits
description: HARTFORD BACK around 1909, a New Britain company built a woodworking machine. In 1979, a New Jersey worker was injured while using it. The worker sued the manufacturer and collected.

title: Bicycle Riding:
description: SPRING brings out the Westchester bicyclists, pedaling forth in pursuit of freewheeling fun. But for all its fun, bicycling is becoming a runaway pacesetter in injuries and deaths.

title: The World
description: MOSCOW  Outside the small courthouse last week where dissident Yuri F.
