Orlov was being denied the right call defense witnesses, denied the opportunity to conduct full crossexaminations of prosecution witnesses, denied the chance to look at documents in evidence and laughed at by a hostile crowd of spectators bused In to pack the court, an American asked, almost to himself, Why do they even bother to have such a trial?

title: Hall of Fame Game Aug. 7 At Cooperstown Sold Out
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., May 20 (AP) The Hall of Fame game, scheduled for Aug. 7 between the New York Mets and the Detroit Tigers, has been sold out, the Cooperstown Baseball Committee has announced.

title: The Region; Atlantic City Getting Ready To Roll Them Bones Westport Gambles On Apartments Jackson High Must Integrate, but How? Jersey's New Worry  Mercury Poison Misusing $245,000 Is Not a Crime
description: In Summary

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about plans for the 1980 census reported incorrectly that Americans of Polish, Irish and Italian descent outnumbered those of Hispanic descent. In fact, Hispanic Americans constitute the nation's second largest ethnic group and are outnumbered only by blacks.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown. Thursday to Saturday, 8 P.M.; Sunday 2 P.M. $5.50, except Saturday, $6.50. Group discount available. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6. Reservations 6281169.

title: THE PROBLEM THAT CAN'T BE TRANQUILIZED
description: If you live on Manhattan's West Side, or if you ever get over there, you may well have crossed paths with Gerard Kerrigan, the parttime delivery man at the Eat Shoppe, a dinette on Broadway between 95th and 96th Streets. Kerrigan spends a good portion of each day out on the street, and he's hard to miss. He has round, unblinking owl eyes, and his upper lip hooks over his lower lip like a bird of prey's, although that's not exactly what one means when one says he's hard to miss. No, there's something off about Kerrigan. He seems drunk. High on something. Noticing his tattered duffel coat and halflaced sneakers, strangers sidestep him on Broadway and hurry on by.

title: DINING OUT The Idea Is Interesting
description: EVERY now and then a restaurant comes along with an interesting new dining concept. Take Johnson's Boarding House in Port Washington, for example. The name offers a clue to the familystyle, helpyourself service of soup, salad, vegetables, fruit and cheese. Where there is a choice, such as in the entrees, it is extremely limited  an approach that, in theory, should contribute to high quality, since the chef can concentrate on preparing a few things well. It doesn't quite work that way here.

title: Jockeys Agree: The Better Horse Won
description: BALTIMORE, May 20Old enemies already in only their second season at the races, Affirmed and Alydar roared down the homestretch of the Preakness today like a matched team of horses. And after a rousing duel that lasted threeeighths of a mile to the finish, every jockey in the race agreed on one thing: Both are exceptional colts, but Affirmed is that much better.

title: The Nation
description: In Summary

title: A Lobbyist Hoist by His Own Report
description: John lannone, an oilindustry lobbyist, knows his way around the Department of Energy. To prove it. he wrote a report to his superiors detailing how he had gotten advance notice of various actions by the department and had been able to modify some regulations for the benefit of the industry.

title: A Large Arab Community in Detroit Hails Jet Fighter Deal
description: DETROIT, May 20George Khoury and the Rev. John Badeen and All Ahmad Hossein are feeling a lot better about their country these days.

title: For New York's Dairy Farmers, 77 Was a Good Year Financially
description: ALBANY, May 18For the second year in a row, New York State dairy farmers produced more than $1 billion worth of milk last year, according to reports issued this week by the State Crop Reporting Service.

title: Douglas Reid Jr., Accountant, Marries Constance Curnen
description: Constance Avery Curnen, daughter of Dr. Edward C. Curnen Jr. of Leonia, N.J., a pediatrician, and the late Marion C. Curnen was married yesterday to Douglas Stewart Reid Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Reid of Framingham, Mass. The Rev. Paul Curran performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Changes in Beech Planes Ordered
description: WICHITA, Kan., May 20 (AP)The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered owners and operators to see that extensive changes are made in 840 twinengine planes built by Beech Aircraft Corporation from 1951 to 1977 to preven tinflight fires caused by leaking fuel or oil. The action came after five fatal accidents in which Beech Queen Airs and Twin Bonanzas had engine fires. The changes include replacement of all original fuel, oil and hydraulic lines and installation of a fire warning system.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND What the Fortune Cookie Doesn't Tell
description: THERE has been a spurt, perhaps even a boom, in Chinese restaurants on the Island. Only a few years ago Chinese restaurants were still the standard sort: egg drop or won ton soup (15 cents extra for won ton), the usual lists of A and B and the wrapup with ice cream, almond cookie or piece of pineapple on a toothpick and, with the check, fortune cookies. Then came the deluge: Polynesian variations on the Chinese restaurant, where everything came with a cherry or pineapple ring on top of it, and you washed it down with a Long Island version of a Singapore Sling or an Oahu winecooler, something like that.

title: At SchoolFinancing Debate's Heart: The Thorny Question of Equal Opportunity
description: AFTER you have brushed the foam off the beer, in the earthy analogy of Justice Alva P. Loiselle of State Supreme Court, the argument over how Connecticut should finance its public school education concerns only one item: money.

title: At Home: StarStruck
description: WE take the Jeep, of course with its fourwheeldrive, winch, and sidemounted pick, shovel, axe and crowbar. In their Bean Vagabond Packs, my wife and daughter carry the Stanley Vacuum Bottles, the Frontier Camp Ware and the food. The Folding Camp Table (seats four) is my responsibility, while my son is charged with the Smoke N Pit Barbecue.

title: Mary Gordon Sets Bridal on June 23
description: Mary A. Gordon and Donald M. Roberts, a senior vice president of Citibank, plan to be married June 23.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: The late Geoffrey Tillotson, with his wife, the scholar Kathleen Tillotson, was scheduled to contribute No. 11 (in two volumes) to Oxford's monumental History of English Literature.

title: Berna Gorenstein Is Married to Lee W. Huebner
description: Berna C. Gorenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Gorenstein of Highland Park, Ill., was married yesterday at her parents home to Lee W, Huebner, son of Mrs. Carl Huebner and the late Mr. Huebner of Sheboygan, Wis.

title: New Attacks Feared as Japan Starts Airport Service
description: TOKYO, Sunday, May 21Japanese officials were fearful of new guerrilla attacks at the new international airport at Narita near here but nonetheless pressed ahead with plans to receive the first cargo and passenger flights today.

title: SHOP TALK A Potpourri Of Handcrafts From Clay to Calico
description: NEARLY every item sold in the Yellow Brick Road, 93 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, is a handcraft. The owner, Michele Micarelli, likes to work with fabric, and pastelcolored trapuntostitched satin pillows in shell shapes are her own work, priced at $9 for the large size and $3.50 for the smaller 8inch size. The filling is polyester.

title: Spy Stories
description: When the Central Intelligence Agency's secrets began to tumble out in their melancholy profusion three years agu, veterans of the agency warned that it would not be easy to put the lid back on, more questions would be raised than answered, and the process of exposure would leave the practice of intelligence in demoralized disarray. At the time, such arguments were roughly dismissed as disingenuous, motivated less by honest concern for national security  fast replacing patriotism as the last refuge of scoundrels than by fear of embarrassment. But it turns out the Cassandras were absolutely right : the codebreaking computers may still be humming, the satellites clicking off their highresolution photos and the mighty river of paper working its way toward the National Security Council, but nothing else is the same. The intelligence community is divided and confused, just as predicted, and there is probably no better place to go for a glimpse of.the awful mess than the memoirs of William Colby, Director of the C.I.A. from 1973 to 1976.

title: Donna Lisa Jacobi Bride Of Michael Collins Miller
description: Donna Lisa Jacobi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Pierce Jacobi of High Point. N.C.. formerly of Wantarth, L.I.. was married at noon yesterday to Michael Collins Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Garnet Edward Miller of Asheboro, N.C.

title: The World
description: In Summary

title: WESTCHESTER REAL ESTATE
description: WESTCHESTER realtors are having their biggest sales boom in several yeas and they're getting the highest prices ever, an average of 13 percent more than last year.

title: Marriage Announcement 12  No Title
description: Diana Denson, Lecturer,

title: Akkadians Had A Word for It
description: CHICAGO AT the University of Chicago's Oriental Institute, scholarship is often esoteric, dealing with civilizations long deceased. But they all left their marks, which ingenious specialists are at work to master. To help others as well as themselves, the institute's linguists are laboring at a gaggle of dictionaries of ancient languages, and even one dictionary for a contemporary language, because it may illuminate extinct predecessors.

title: Allies Are Uneasy But Cliches Also Distort Realities
description: PARIS To the rest of the world, the President of the United States is not only the man who decides what America is going to do. He also has his finger on everybody else's fate. There is always a degree of suppressed irritation in allied countries when Americans choose a new President because people feel their future is also at stake without their having a choice in the decision.

title: Notes: Heading Out to the Country
description: Within a day's driving distance of the New York metropolitan area are old houses, both grand and small, gardens of formal design and roadsides of magnificent native American plant profu sion that should provide welcome respite for city dwellers warming up for summer vacations. And to compound the pleasure of shortdistance journeysthe double reward being the refreshment of change and ease of returning to one's own comfortable nestare the summer fairs and festivals that provide city residents a chance to poke around small towns and sample, if only briefly, a different sort of life.

title: British Journalists Union Seeks Disclosure of Printers Pay Scale
description: LONDON, May 20A group of disgruntled Fleet Street journalists says that some of the Linotype operators at their paper are not only making twice as much money as they are but also are making more than some of the top executives employing them.

title: CRIME
description: One of the more unusual series of procedurals has come from William Marshall. Yellowthread Street started the series about two years ago. The locale was  and still is  Hong Kong, where Chief Inspector Harry Feiffer and his men operate out of the Yellowthread Street division. The first book had many elements of farce in it; Mr. Marshall is amused by people and their antics. But as the series has progressed THIN AIR (Holt, Rinehart and Winston, $6.95) is the fourth and newest of the Yellowthread books  the action has become more serious and the plotting more in line with that of orthodox procedurals.

title: TV VIEW
description: In one of the publicity handouts for the new film on Dashiell Hammett's The Dain Curse, which CBS will broadcast in three installments tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday, James Coburn is described as precisely the worldweary, Cynical, dark romantic figure the novel calls for.

title: Red Sox Beat Tigers on Hobson's Hit in Ninth, 65
description: DETROIT, May 20 (AP)Butch Hobson snapped a 55 tie with a runscoring single in the ninth inning today to give the Boston Red Sox a 65 victory over the Detroit Tigers in a game that was delayed by rain for 1 hour 38 minutes.

title: Treasury Is Improving Cash Flow
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The Carter Administration announced today that it had initiated new procedures to regulate the flow of cash into and out of the Treasury. It projected a saying of $125 million a year as a result of the change.

title: Cornell, Johns Hopkins in Lacrosse Final
description: ITHACA, N.Y., May 20Cornell University used the same old winning formula, a balanced scoring attack and a tenacious defense, to defeat Navy, 137, in the semifinals today of the Lacrosse playoffs. The Big Red will play Johns Hopkins in the finals next Saturday at Rutgers.

title: Medicine Man Charged as Abettor
description: TAHLEQUAH, Okla., May 20 (UPI)William Lee Smith, an Indian medicine man, will be tried on charges of helping Gene Leroy Hart hide from the authorities who were trying to arrest him for the sex slayings of three Girl Scouts last summer. At a hearing yesterday, Larry Bowles of the Oklahoma State Bureau of Investigation, testified that Mr. Smith admitted aiding Mr. Hart. Mr. Bowles said Mr. Smith, 58 years old, told him of transporting Mr. Hart from his home near Vian to the house where Mr. Hart was captured April 6.

title: Rock Concert Planned for Giants Stadium
description: The first rock concert at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands has been scheduled for June 25 at 12:30 P.M. The performers will be the Beach Boys and the Steve Miller Band, and the event will be presented by John Scher's Monarch Entertainment Bureau and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which runs the Meadowlands complex.

title: Lee Stewart Weds Elizabeth A. Cotter
description: Elizabeth Ann Cotter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Cotter of Westport, Conn., and Lee Coddington Stewart, son of the Rev, and Mrs. George Lee Stewart of Medellin, Colombia, were married yesterday by the bridegroom's father in the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport.

title: Room at the Top on the Left
description: LEARNING that Simone Signoret's final philosophy examination at her lycee required her to Define the connections between passion and will, you immediately recall her roles in Casque d'Or and Room at the Top and Ship of Fools women whose commitment to nearly terminal emotions wasn't deterred by the sense of a deadline: The possibility of loss appeared to invigorate the will. Rapturous or rueful, her personae hardly need to make decisions: They follow what seems irreversible  a word that recurs throughout her autobiography, especially when she writes about meeting and marrying Yves Montand.

title: Recalling Havell, Audubon's Engraver
description: OSSINING EVERY town has its relic of some former great associationa house, perhaps, once lived in by an eminent person but now humbled and worn by time. In Ossining, it is the Havell House  still called that, although Robert Havell, the artist who built it in 1841 and became one of the town's famous residents, lived in it only until 1857. After a succession of owners, the property came into the possession of the present owners, and it has been theirs for more than 70 years.

title: Basic Skills Another View
description: IT has become fashionable in this enlightened age for everyone to put on rosecolored glasses and look back with fond memories to the good old days  to a time when arithmetic was arithmetic and reading was reading, and when everyone was supposed to write, spell and behave correctly.

title: Eviction of Westchester Woman And Sale of Belongings Upheld
description: The United States Supreme Court, dividing 5 to 3, has ruled against a Westchester County woman who contended that her constitutional right to due process was violated when she was evicted from her Mount Vernon, N.Y., home five years ago and faced with the forced sale of her belongings by a private storage company.

title: Doctors Assistants Get a No Vote
description: NEW JERSEY wisely remains the only state not to permit physicians assistants to practice. Perhaps the residents of New Jersey are questioning whether the 10,000 assistants practicing in the 49 other states have brought about any increase in the quality of health care or decreased the cost of that care to consumers in those states.

title: Ethical Culture Gala Marks 100th Y ear Of Midtown School
description: With yesterday officially declared Ethical Culture Schools Day by Mayor Koch, thousands of parents, alumni, students and friends turned out for a gala at the Fieldston School in the Riverdale section of the Bronx to celebrate the founding of the first of the three schools 100 years ago.

title: Gramercy Park Tours Today
description: Rain or shine, the National Park Serv ice will offer two walking tours of Gramercy Park today at 2 P.M. and 3:30 P.M. The tours, which are free, start at 28 East 20th Street.

title: Spacecraft Heading Toward Venus To Study Weather and Topography
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 20An American spacecraft embarked here today on a sevenmonth, 300millionmile voyage to orbit Venus and conduct the longest and most extensive survey thus far of the weather and topography of the Earth's nearest planetary neighbor.

title: Ideas &
description: The driver of the Land Rover had two children with smallpox in the back seat. He needed directions to the isolation camp near Merka, Somalia.

title: Carol Babcock Wed To Mark Hazzard
description: Carol Ann Babcock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Nash Babcock of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark Erickson Hazzard, son of Sandra Hazzard of Readfield, Mc., and Thomas Hazzard of Auausta. Me.

title: Nancy Fleming Plans A Wedding in August
description: The engagement of Nancy Connell Fleming to Timothy Bruce Brandi has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James T. Fleming Jr. of Waverly, Pa.. parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Bruce Brandi of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Point o'Woods, Fire Island.

title: Letters: Rebellion On Rails
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters of Congressional Delegates Being Published
description: WASHINGTONAs though it did not have trouble enough housing its 19 million volumes, the Library of Congress is increasing the burden by adding books of its own.

title: Yonkers Schools Chief Resigns
description: YONKERS, May 20 (AP)Joseph Robitaille has resigned as Yonkers School Superintendent to become head of the public school system in Albuquerque, N.M. The 55yearold Superintendent said today that he had asked the Yonkers Board of Education on Wednesday to relieve him of his duties in midJuly.

title: UNION COLLEGE PRESIDENT RESIGNS AFTER DISPUTES
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 20 (AP)Thomas N. Bonner has resigned as president of Union College after a series of disputes with some faculty and administration members that resulted in last winter's resignation of Ned Harkness as the college's hockey coach.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: Simons Leads by Shot On Birdie at Last Hole
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 20Jim Simons had to birdie the 18th hole today to maintain a thin lead in the third round of the third annual Memorial Tournament.

title: France's Forces Are Quietly Renewing Ties for NATO
description: BRUSSELS, May 20Cooperation in exercises and planning between the French Army, Navy and Air Force and NATO forces in Western Europe and the Mediterranean is increasingly intimate, according to highly placed officials at the alliance's headquarters here.

title: What's Doing in GUATEMALA CITY
description: MODERN HUB  The sprawling capital of Guatemala, with its broad avenues, clusters of highrise buildings and over a million inhabitants, sticks out like an incongruous urban thumb in a country noted for its Mayan and Spanish colonial past, its country scenery and Indians (more than half of the population) who cling to their customs, costumes, languages and lore. Most visitors tend to ignore the city, which, admittedly, offers little of these attractions. Still, it has its certain charm and serves as a convenient point of departure for dozens of interesting side trips. A few days in the capital before venturing out into the interior will also help the visitor to adjust to the altitude (5,000 feet), and the ifnottodaythentomorrow attitude of Guatemalans.

title: Canadiens Lead the League in the Front Office, Too
description: Don't be deceived by the Montreal Canadiens 40 defeat in the third game of the National Hockey League's championship series. The Canadiens still lead the Boston Bruins, 21, in the fourofsevengame series, still have lost but two games in this year's playoffs, still have dropped but five games in the last three years of playoffs and still are expected to subdue the Bruins for their third consecutive Stanley Cup.

title: INTERVIEW Bergen's Powerful Nonpolitician
description: AS head of the Bergen County Community Action Program, a federally financed antipoverty project, John P. Lyle administers 7,000 jobs and more than $60 million in Government grants. And he is widely regarded as one of the most powerful nonpolitical figures in the state.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ISABEL GAMBLE MacCAFFREY

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, aL Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and I26th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 2 P.M.) (Radio  WMCA, WGLI, 2 P.M.)

title: ExDutch Resistance Members And U.S. Veterans to Meet Again
description: Twentytwo World War II veterans in the New York City area have been conducting a manhunt of a friendly sort. They are searching for an estimated 250 United States Air Force flyers and Jews of Dutch origin living in the area who escaped or evaded the Nazis with the help of Dutch citizens.

title: Off on Her Own: Unaccompanied Adventures in Florence and Rome
description: I am an independent woman in my 50's, with fairtomiddling finances, health and looks, an experienced traveler who has made several trips to Europe. But I had traveled with my husband and now, as a widow of 10 years standing. I was contemplating two weeks in Italy by myself. I had to ask some hard questions: Would I be able to cope with the complications of another language, another currency? With strange men, perhaps inclined to lechery? And, most of all, with the lonely evenings? I was armed against these doubts by my lifelong dream of seeing Florence, my knowledge of Spanishwith a concomitant hope of being able to get along in Italianand by having learned to be happy in my own company.

title: Into Africa
description: The President of Zambia had a warning for the West last week: The risk or fullscale, worldwide war is too grave to beignored. At the time, Kenneth D. Kaunda, visiting in Washington, was talking specifically about Rhodesia (where dozens of blacks were killed when Government troops, supposedly seeking guerrillas, invaded a rural meeting) and South Africa.

title: Wendy Jean Cowen Wed to R. G. Hansen
description: Wendy Jean Cowen and Richard Gene Hansen were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Cowen of Larchmont, N.Y. The bridegroom is the son of Capt. Robert L. Hansen, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Hansen of Silver Spring, Md.

title: Sex and the Teen Ager (For Parents)
description: BY ADVISING their teenage children on birth control, are parents implicitly giving them permission to have sex and even applying pressure for them to do so? How do parents initiate such discussions with their children? What about morality  is the new pragmatic attitude toward sex on the part of teenagers undermining their feelings of responsibility for others?

title: Heinz Company Files Challenge To F.D.A. TomatoTesting Rules
description: PITTSBURGH, May 20 (Reuters)The H.J. Heinz Company has announced that it was filing a court challenge to Food and Drug Administration tomatotesting techniques and guidelines.

title: Beatrice Is Bolder
description: CHICAGO  A few months ago, a group of employees gave Wallace N. Rasmussen, chairman of the Beatrice Foods Company, a pair of nickelplated ice tongs.

title: The Class of 78  and 68
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 20Ten years ago, the college graduating class of 1968 was in revolt over the Vietnam war, stunned by the murder of Robert Kennedy just before graduation day, and shaking shaggy heads and even fists against the most venerable institutions of the nation.

title: Marriage Announcement 5  No Title
description: Lizanne Lucarelli Is Bride

title: Breath of Fresh Air for Everyone
description: WILLY developed a liking for spaghetti. Melissa learned how to set a table. And Wanda went to the beach for the first time.

title: CONNECTICUT REAL ESTATE
description: THE price of a singlefamily home throughout the state during the first three months of 1978 rose about 15 percent, according to a statistical survey just completed by the Connecticut Association of Realtors.

title: Monique Van Vooren Sings Her Own Songs
description: Monique Van Vooren does not lake her talents as a song writer too seriously.

title: Melissa McRoberts Sets July 29 Bridal To H. B. Freeman 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. William ?? ?? erts of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Jane McRoberts, to Harry Boit Freeman 3d of New York.

title: ISRAELIS PONDERING JETSALES RESPONSE
description: JERUSALEM, May 20Israeli politicians and foreign diplomats hire are keeping a wary eye on Prime Minister Menachem Begin and his Cabinet for any sign that they may be hardening their position against a renewal of the EgyptianIsraeli peace initiative.

title: New College Conferences: Group Teams by Brains, Not Brawn
description: There are two schools of thoughtno pun intendedon college athletics. One says the primary purpose of college is to educate young people; the other says colleges exist principally to entertain large crowds on Saturday afternoons in the fall, furnish athletes for professional sports and win national championships.

title: Dominican Opposition Thanks U.S. For Denouncing Vote Irregularity
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 20  Leaders of the Dominican Revolutionary Party today expressed strong appreciation for the denunciation by Washington of the apparent effort by the Dominican military to interrupt the election this week. They expressed the hope that the Carter Administration's action ushered in a new era in United StatesCaribbean relations.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Payoff time. Back in March 1977 Avon Books created a mighty stir along Publishers Row when paid a recordbreaking $1.9 million for the paperback rights to a novel by a littleknown, Australianborn nurse and parttime writer named Colleen McCullough. Neither the author nor her book, a family saga set in her native land, are little known any longer. Miss McCullough's smiling, round face has been seen on television screens and in bookstores from coast coast. The Thorn Birds is high on our hardcover Best Seller List this week for the 53d time.

title: A Holiday Refuge Retains the Japanese Love of Serenity and Design
description: About 70 miles southwest of Tokyo lies FujiHakoneIzu National Park, a highland resort to which Japanese families come to commune with art, nature, friends, the voices of the gods. In the foothills of Mount Fuji (12,388 feet), FujiHakoneIzu Park offers woodlands and flowers, lakes, rivers and streams, rushing waterfalls, yawning gorges and steaming hot springs.

title: On Tuesday, the First Auction of Gold Since 1975
description: Since March 1, as the inflation rate has climbed ever higher, gold prices have dropped from roughly $195 an ounce to $178.60 an ounce. It isn't supposed to work that way; gold is supposed to be a haven for people fleeing the ravages of inflation.

title: Jays Down Yanks, 108
description: TORONTO, May 20The Yankees went into today's game against the Toronto Blue Jays as the American League's leading team in fielding with a .985 average. But they uncharacteristically committed three errors that helped the Blue Jays score six runs in the sixth inning on the way to a 108 triumph over New York at Exhibition Stadium.

title: MaryEileen Lohr Is Married To Stephen Davoust in Jersey
description: MaryEileen Lohr and Stephen G. Davoust were married yesterday by the Rev. Carl Wolsin in Our Lady of Consolation Roman ,.:atholic Church in Wayne. N.J.

title: Spotlight on Ribicoff
description: WASHINGTON SENATOR Abraham A. Ribicoff, a meticulous man, currently seems to be violating one of his cardinal rules in handling major pieces of legislation in his role as a top committee chairman.

title: Magoon Set to Challenge Atlantic Crossing Mark
description: After a career in offshore powerboat facing in which titles were strung together like pearls, Bob Magoon found his hack against the wallactually eightfoot walls of waterlast summer. The walls stretched across the Atlantic Ocean and barred his assault on the transAtlantic powerboat speed record.

title: This Week in Sports
description: A. J. Foyt, the only fourtime winner of the Indianapolis 500, will try next Sunday for his fifth victory. Bobby Unser, Johnny Rutherford and Janet Guthrie are also expected in the field in America's most celebrated race. Today is the last day of Indianapolis qualifying. Races today include the Grand Prix of Belgium in Zolder, the MasonDixon 500 for stock cars at Dover Downs in Delaware and a TransAm contest in Seattle. A CanAm race will be held Saturday at Charlotte, N.C.

title: SPOTLIGHT The Queen of Fountain Pens
description: PARIS  This city is full of chic, svelte blondes in their mid40's, elegantly but conservatively dressed, with a new dog and a new house to fill their lives now that the children have left home, dabbling perhaps in real estate or antiques, independent enough to question the rightwing politics of their caste.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The State of the City's Tennis Courts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Researchers Find That 2 Drugs Will Lower Cholesterol Levels
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 20Scientists may soon be able to test the theory that lowering the level of serum cholesterol in the body will reduce the risk of fatal heart attacks, according to researchers at the University of California at San Francisco.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Former President Gerald Ford takes time out from playing golf to assess President Jimmy carter's performance: He's had no birdies, relatively few pars, a number of bogeys and a heckuva lot of double bogeys.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Crafts and Porcelain
description: THERE'S a new boutique in Wayne. It's at 67 Boonton Road, next door to the Tennis Bug, which is to tennis diehards what L.L. Bean is to hunters.

title: A War On Weeds Won
description: Thanks to health, energy, enthusiasm  and the assistance of black plastic  my father, now going on 82, tends a 3,000 square foot vegetable garden, planted with 40 different kinds of vegetables. His children and grandchildren eat like kings all year long!

title: LONG ISLAND REAL ESTATE The A. to the Home Buyer's Q.
description: FOR the Long Island buyer in search of a home, or for the owner who wants to upgrade and improve the house he already has, the experience can become a frustrating road of informationgathering.

title: CAMERA
description: There is no doubt that in the camera field simplicity sells. Kodak's easyloading 100size Instamatics have been the most popular cameras ever offered by that company, while their uncomplicated Handle instant camera passed the million mark in production half a year after its introduction in March 1977. As another indication of this, during the preChristmas 1977 period, the Polaroid nofrills OneStep instant camera was the nation's best seller, and that company manufactured 30,000 OneSteps a day to keep up with Santa's orders.

title: Wendy Congdon Wed to Alexander Hardy Stanton
description: Wendy Congdon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Congdon of Brooklyn Heights, was married there yesterday in the First Unitarian Church, to Alexander Hardy Stanton, son of Mrs. Jane Stanton of Brooklyn Heights and Robert F. Stanton of San Francisco. The Rev. Donald H. McKinney performed the ceremony.

title: Fiancee of Ron Rubenzer
description: The bridetobe, daughter also of the late Charles K. Denson, received a B.A. degree magna cum laude and an M.A. degree from Columbia. She is a granddaughter of Ruth Gilbert, Around Town editor of New York magazine.

title: 5 Are Killed as a Station Wagon And a Truck Collide in Vermont
description: FAYSTON. Vt., May 21 (AP)Five persons were killed today in a headon collision of a station wagon and a pickup truck.

title: FRENCH AND BELGIANS ROUT REBELS IN ZAIRE AND CONTROL KOLWEZI
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 20  French and Belgian paratroopers took control of the coppermining center of Kolwezi today routing Katangan rebels and gathering some 2,500 European residents for evacuation.

title: Sneva, in Record Speed, Wins 2d Indy Pole in Row
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 20Tom Sneva captured the pole for the Indianapolis 500 for the second year in a row today with a record speed. The fourtime winner. A.J. Foyt, met disaster.

title: Marriage Announcement 4  No Title
description: Yankees to Aid Research

title: Spain Expels a Soviet Engineer On Charges of Industrial Spying
description: MADRID, May 20 (AP)Spain expelled a Soviet engineer today on charges of industrial spying, according to officials.

title: Al Oerter, Retired Olympic DiscusThrowing Champion, Is Preparing at 41 for Another Fling at the Gold
description: He is the only man in history to win four gold medals in his event in four separate Olympic Games. Now 41 years old, Al Oerter, who frequently fought through pain to victory, is trying to prove that age is equally negotiable.

title: A Boston Bans a Bargain for the Opera
description: BOSTON  Dr. Laszlo Bonis, splendid in black tie and ruffled shirt, asked where the bar was.

title: Gail Peters Wed to K.G. Beitz
description: Gail Sandra Peters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leone J. Peters of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Kenneth George Beitz, son of Mr. and Airs. Richard Charles Beitz of Miami.

title: Louise Lasser Stars in TV Film by Louise Lasser
description: LOS ANGELESThe uncapped, 375tablet bottle of Exedrin in Louise Lasser's bathroom is half full. She takes three tablets, sipping the water to swallow them through a straw. That gesture is, in its eccentricity, a throwback to the lunatic world of Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman. And it is Mary Hartman who has given Louise Lasser a kingsized headadhe that may never go away.

title: INTERVIEW A Salute From His Parishioners
description: 'YOU know, said the Rev. Constantine Theodore, I didn't want anything at all. What he didn't want was any fuss over his impending retirement. But his flock had other ideas. So tonight, adjacent to St. John's Greek Orthodox Church in Blue Point, in the Community Cultural Center that was his first project when he came to the parish in 1959, the 65yearold Father Theodore will be honored at a testimonial dinner.

title: Montauk: Last Outpost Of a Military Era
description: MONTAUK WILLIAM KAISER has spent more than 25 years studying the history of aviation on the Island, and he knows that in 1919 a Navy C5 blimp, destined for Europe, took off from Rockaway and made a stop at Montauk Point, where there was blimp hangar. He also knows that the blimp never made it to Europe, but instead blew away accidentally during another stop in Newfoundland and was never seen again. The five crew members jumped off before the craft was lost.

title: Help for Trapped Women
description: WE'RE HERE to help all women, says Susan Smithline, director of the Northern WestchesterPutnam County Women's Center. We're not a women's lib group or attached to any political cause. Our job is to act as a referral agency and offer network of supportive services to all women.

title: Diane Susan Schmidt Bride Of Rev. Gregory Lee Hayes
description: Diane Susan Schmidt, who will receive a master's degree in Christian education this month from the Princeton Theological Seminary, was married yesterday morning to the Rev. Gregory Lee Hayes, a Methodist minister who next year expects to receive a Master of Theology degree from the seminary.

title: System of 22 Minibuses Proposed in Greenwich Gets Preliminary Vote
description: A proposal for a minibus system that has been under consideration in Greenwich, Conn., for four years took an uncertain step forward last week when the town's Board of Estimate and Taxation approved an appropriation of $160,000 for startup costs.

title: Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plan Rebate to Members in 2 States
description: CONCORD, N.H., May 20 (AP)Because Blue Cross and Blue Shield subscribers in New Hampshire and Vermont are not staying in the hospital as many days as they used to, the insurance plan has announced, it will return about $4 million to its members in those states.

title: Mary L., $6.80, Triumphs
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., May 20W. A. Wood's Mary L. made Monmouth Park's Regret Handicap her fourth consecutive victory as she outdueled six fillies and mares to take the $17,791 winner's purse today.

title: Another P.R. Solution?; IN THE NATION
description: As Richard Nixon was about to be buried In the rubble of Watergate, he thought he had merely a public relations problem that only required a public relations solution. Is that sad misjudgment, conceded in Mr. Nixon's new book, about to be repeated by President Carter?

title: Beauty
description: One of the world's richest and bestknown shipowners once gave as general advice for success the following: Live at a good address, be welldressed and always have a tan. Today's dermatologist would argue against that last bit of wisdom. Some dermatologists sincerely feel that all sunlight should be avoided whenever possible and that tans are nothing but bad. Others take a more middleoftheroad position. Sun, like food, should be taken in moderation, says Dr. Albert Lefkovits, a leading New York dermatologist. I recognize that patients de??ire some color and that a tan can be a great mental tonic, but I also must make patients aware that harm can result from overexposure to the sun.

title: Saudis See Threats From Inside And Outside
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Saudi defense officials, apparently afraid to utter a word that might jeopardize the Carter Administration's Middle East arms package, burrowed deep into their airconditioned offices here last Sunday and refused all questions. But when the Senate voted 5444 the next day not to bar the sales of warplanes to Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia it was clear their country had won a significant victory that means even more politically than militarily.

title: Hearings Consider Union Dispute
description: ALBANY, May 19Hearings opened here this week in an effort to resolve a bitter struggle between two rival factions of the A.F.L.C.I.O. over who will represent the state's professional, scientific and technical employees.

title: Dog Geneticists to Hold Jersey Seminar
description: Dr: Stephen W. J. Seager, the first scientist to successfully freeze and store canine semen, will lead an alldry seminar for dog breeders in New Jersey next month. In order to achieve a classroom atmosphere, reservations are limited to 60 for the event on June 24 at the Clam Broth House, Hoboken. The Palisades Kennel Club will be the host.

title: Dr. T. D. Mattison Weds Eve H. Rice, Author, Illustrator
description: The marriage of Eve Hart Rice, an author and illustrator of children's books, to Dr. Timothy David Mattison, a resident in dermatology at the New York University Medical Center, took place yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. Justice of the Peace Edward R. Peckerman Jr. of Washington Depot, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Stanwich Club.

title: SonicsBullets Matchup Unexpected, Intriguing; Cohesion and Defense The Schedule Factor A First for Kingdome
description: SEATTLE, May 20The opening game will be somewhat more important than usual when the Seattle SuperSonics and Washington Bullets begin their fourofsevengame series for the 32d National Basketball Association championship, at noon tomorrow Seattle time (3 P.M. in New York on Channel 2).

title: A Vietnam Perspective
description: Q. During your last official tour in Washington, Professor Rostow, you were National Security Adviser in the White House under President John. son. Perspectives on the world have changed enormously since that time, and I'm wondering about your own perspective. How do you now see our experience in Southeast Asia?

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Gradually our museums and galleries are coming to understand that an important part of the art of the 20th century was created not to be shown in museums and galleries but for the mass media. A few decades ago several types of newspaper and magazine photographs began to be shown in museumsfor example, the press photographs of Weegee and the public relations pictures of Farm Security Administration photographers. Soon afterward glamour portraits done by highclass photographers like Edward Steichen for glossy magazines like Vogue were recognized as art. in the past few years, fashion photographs have also gotten the nod. Now we are being treated to the Andy Warhol spectacle of purely commercial advertising photographs being exhibited in galleries as art.

title: New Yorkers Revel in Sun as Temperature Hits 90 Festival Gets Good Weather
description: Dazzling sunshine and balmy temperatures set the stage yesterday for sandals, shorts and sun dresses, and prompted at least one person to show up in Central Park in a twopiece bathing suit. Suddenly, it was summer.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Assembly Speaker, Christopher J. Jackman, Democrat of West New York, confesses that esoteric language sometimes leaves him at sea. As a result, he has revived his push of a stalled proposal to outlaw mumbojumbo in legal contracts in New Jersey.

title: Alan H. Ulan Is the Fiance Of Bonnie Gail Nitzberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Nitzberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonnie Gail Nitzberg, to Alan H. than of New York, son of Seymour Ulan of Long Beach, L.I., and Theresa Rubin, also o Long Beach. A July wedding planned.

title: Suzanne Langdon Wed To William E. Congdon
description: Suzanne Palmer Langdon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Palmer H. Langdon of Englewood, N.J., and William Edward Congdon, son of Mrs. Robert Lyons Congdon of Milford, Conn., and the late Mr. Congdon, were married yesterday by the Rev. William Reynolds who performed a nuptial mass in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Tokyo Airport Showdown Is Quite Japanese
description: A. Controversy for 13 Years, Embattled Narita Opened Yesterday

title: Rockland's Retiring Human Rights Head Critical of School Hiring
description: NE WCITY, N.Y., May 19Gains have been made against discrimination Rockland County in recent years, but a number of problems persist, including foot dragging by schools in hiring minority members, says Noel J. MacCarry, who has announced that he will retire July 1 as exec.itive director of the county's Human Rights Commission.

title: The Americanization of Beckenbauer: Cosmos' Star to Be Honored Today
description: In his first time at bat as a baseball player, Franz Beckenbauer singled sharply.

title: TV VIEW
description: This Tuesday's TV on Trial, which can be seen the Public Broadcasting Service (Channel 13 in New York) at 9 P.M., encompasses two separate issues, both of profound importance to television. Should television cameras be allowed in courtrooms? And what effect does TV content have on viewers? Produced by Don Fouser for Miami station WPBT, the twohour program contains highlights from the murder trial last September of 15yearold Ronney Zamora. WPBT's cameras entered the courtroom as part of a oneyear experimental pilot program, set up by the state of Florida, that permits television coverage without the consent either of the trial participants or of the judge. The station then broadcasts lengthy excerpts the same day.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY  The Name's the Same, but
description: THE immediate prospects for bigtime gambling in Atlantic City seem to be exciting the whole state these days. Well, most of the state, but not Caesar Crimi of South Orange, who isn't at all happy. As a matter of fact, he's perturbed.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TODAYNimrod Farm. Weston Road, Weston, Conn. Amateurowner and junior working hunters, open jumpers, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE Upbeat Business Leaders
description: Since the advent of spring, the economic skies have been clearing in the United States and abroad and are now showing signs of further brightness for the rest of the year. If the political climate were better, however, there would be an even stronger basis for optimism.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: There is something terribly wrong at the core Runaways and I'm going to have to try to putmy finger on what bothered me without being gratuitously offensive to some wellmeaning creative people and to a stageful of admirably energetic, if not remarkably talented, youngsters. Elizabeth Swados's patchwork quilt or sorrowing songs, StOmpeuillit tirades, and fragmentary confessions drawn from the lives of approximately 2,000 streetchildren she has interviewed and worked with has, of course, been decidedly successful at the Public Theater, where it opened in early March. Its move to Broadway, and a larger home at the Plymouth, must have seemed logical enough.

title: Gretchen Groat Is Bride of Brian Blake
description: Gretchen Groat, daughter of Robert Andrews Groat of Old Lyme, Conn., and the late Margaret Wade Groat, was married yesterday noon to Brian Poor Townsend Blake of New York, an assistant vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: Maryjo Tracy Wed To Brian J. Morris
description: Maryjo Tracy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Tracy of Crestwood, N.Y., was married there yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation to Brian J. Morris, son of Mrs. George Gately of West Palm, Fla., and the late George Morris, The Rev. Gerald Morris of Boynton Beach, Fla., a brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Japanese Urge U.S. To Allow Processing Of AFuel in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, May 20A group of Japanese utility executives have told United States officials they hope the Carter Administration will approve longterm Japanese plan to reprocess Americansupplied uranium in Britain and France.

title: SADAT REFERENDUM STIRS SOME CONCERN
description: CAIRO, May 20A nationwide referendum tomorrow aimed at giving President Anwar elSadat a mandate to eliminate his critics from political life has created a mood of anger and apprehension among many educated Egyptians who have generally supported his proclaimed policies of peace, democracy and economic opportunity.

title: Maryknoll Society Gives Sendoff To Clerical and Lay Missionaries
description: For the first time in the history of the NInyknoll Society, ordained and lay missionaries were honored at the same ceremony yesterday, before leaving for their costs overseas.

title: How Beckett 's Godot Rediscovered Theater
description: Next Thursday's production of Samuel Beckett's Waiting for Godot at the Brooklyn Academy promises to commend itself even to those who remember Bert Lahr's famous contribution to the original Broadway production in 1956 and believe that it could not be bettered. The directorWalter Asmus, of the Schiller Theater in Berlinis Beckett's own choice and the production as a whole is said to bear the author's stamp.

title: First the Rain and Now the Mud Slow Corn Planting
description: SUGAR GROVE, III., May 20Ted McCannon, a bearded young farmer, squatted in the soggy field beside his cattle barn and scratched through a sunbaked crust, bringing up a handful of rich, black soil and squeezing it into a mud ball.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deaths

title: CHESS
description: There is little doubt that, of all the kingside openings, the Ruy Lopez does the best job of maintaining opportunities for a complex middle game without taking undue risks.

title: SPORTS
description: HE IS is the only man in history to win four gold medals in his event in four separate Olympic Games. Now 41 years old, Al Oerter, who frequently fought through pain to victory, is trying to prove that age is equally negotiable.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayTriumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey 70mile T.S.D. rally; start at The Club House, Route 46 Westbound, Fairfield, N.J. Registration: noon; first car off 1:01 P.M.

title: 3 TERRORISTS KILLED IN ATTACK IN PARIS ON EL AL PASSENGERS
description: PARIS, May 20Three gunmen opened fire on passengers in the departure lounge of Orly Airport this afternoon and French security police killed the attackers.

title: Board of Education Wasted $16 Million, Audit by Levitt Says
description: New York State's Comptroller charged yesterday that mismanagement, poor bookkeeping and lack of stringent controls in the City Board of Education's Bureau cf Plant Operation had cost the taxpayers nealy S16 million in 1976.

title: Lyn Littlefield Wed To Claude Hoopes, A Real Estate Aide
description: Lyn Littlefield and Claude Brown Hoopes were married yesterday at the Grassy Hill Congregational Church in Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Edward S. Gleason, headmaster of the Noble and Greenough School in Dedham, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: Pop Master of American History
description: Ben Franklin taking his constitutional air bath ? Samuel Adams with his shirt unbuttoned? On Monday and Tuesday evenings, two halves of a new historical miniseries called The Bastard and studded with stars like Patricia Neal, Eleanor Parker and Donald Pleasence will be presented on WPIXTV. They will be the first of three fourhour syndicated Operation Prime Time programs. Television adaptations of Irwin Shaw's Evening in Byzantium and The Immigrants, by Howard Fast, will follow in July and November on more than 100 stations across the country.

title: Greek Orthodox Church on L.I. Staging a Testimonial for Priest
description: You know, said the Rev. Constantine Theodore, I didn't want anything at all. What he didn't want was any fuss over his impending retirement. But his flock had other ideas.

title: Headliners
description: It never hurts a working girl to marry the boss, but Elizabeth Halaby is giving the tradition a new twist. Next month, Miss Halaby, the daughter of Najeeb Halaby, former president of Pan American World Airways, will marry King Hussein. Miss Halaby, a graduate of Princeton University who became director of design and architecture for Royal Jordanian Airlines last year, met the king three months ago. A palace announcement last week said that the 43yearold monarch has renamed 26yearold Miss Halaby Nur elHussein  The Gleam of Hussein  in keeping with a Jordanian tradition that the King's wife have an Arabic name. Palace sources also indicated that a royal decree would be issued shortly, making Miss Halaby a princess rather than queen because she is not a citizen of Jordan. Miss Halaby, known as Lisa, will be the King's fourth wife. His first two marriages ended in divorce, and his third wife, Queen Alia, was killed in a helicopter crash in 1977.

title: Whitney de Roulet Married
description: Whitney de Roulet, daughter of Mrs. Vincent de Roulet of Manhasset, L.I, and the late Mr. de Roulet, former Ambassador to Jamaica, was married yesterday afternoon to Clark Lewis Bullock, son of Mrs. John Whittlela of Marcellus, N.Y., and Clarence Bullock of Beaver, Pa. The Rev. Frank N. Johnston of Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset performed the ceremony at the de Roulet home.

title: Diana L. Hibbard Married to David Allen Bitz
description: Diana Louise Hibbard, daughter of Dr. Walter R. Hibbard Jr. of Blacksburg, Va., and the late Charlotte Tracy Hibbard, was married yesterday afternoon to David Allen Bitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anton Bitz of Napoleon, N. D., and Brownsville, Tex.

title: Priscilla Lewis Weber Wed to William Pinches
description: Pricilla Lewis Weber, daughter of Col. Reginald Theodore Weber, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Weber of York Pa., was married yesterday to William Lionel Pinches of Felton, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Pinches of Lewiston Heights, N. Y. Canon George A. Kemp performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church in York.

title: Radio
description: 7:308, WABC: Message of Israel. Being Moral Without Believing in God.

title: Production, Housing, the Dollar: The Vital Signs Are Up
description: For the United States economy, April turned out not to be so cruel after all, according to the data pouring in last week. The dollar bucked up. Industrial production surged. Housing starts rose. Personal income too. And the stock market came alive.

title: POINTS OF VIEW Inflation's Toll on Capital Gains
description: Wage earners are acutely aware of the income tax bite in the paycheck. Few are aware, however, of the subtle effect inflation has on income tax rates. Thanks in part to inflation, our total income is higher and therefore is taxed at a higher rate, leaving our real spendable income relatively constant.

title: Without The Zim
description: WHAT do an Episcopalian girl from Queens, a Jewish girl from the Bronx, a Catholic girl from Philadelphia, and a pair of Jewish boys from Brooklyn and the Lower East Side have in common? Show business.

title: Fashion
description: When it comes to bikinis, the briefer the better. Even though onepiece maillots are back in the fashionable swim, there's nothing like a little bit of a bikini for women who love the sun. This summer, bikinis are as brief as they've ever been  but with a few added attractions. Electriccolored, stretchy suits are showing up with vivid trim. Fresh cotton bikinis have a touch of bright ruffles around the curves. And even that basic, the solid black bikini, is updated with passementerie ties across the hips. The shape of the bra is still the triangle, but this year the fabric can be adjusted to show more or less skin according to the whim of the bather. Bikini bottoms, held together with strings, ties, ribbons or elastic bands, cover just the essentials. Here, the pick of the briefest bikinis  for bodies that can stand up to therm??

title: Cauthen on Preakness: My Horse Beat Him Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, May 20Steve Cauthen, who doesn't walk on water but probably could ride on it, stood in the jammed and airless lounge of the press box while Pimlico's Sam Siciliano introduced the kid's kid brothers, 9yearold Kerry and Douglas, 15. Still wearing the flamingo and black silks that Affirmed had carried to a neck victory over Alydar in the eighth race between these two fine colts, Steve sipped a soft drink and surveyed the mob in front of him with a tranquil gaze.

title: On the Right Side of the Utility Pole
description: YORKTOWN ZIGZAGGING through northern Westchester is a boundary line that, though found on few maps, people on both sides are very much aware of. It is not readily visible except by close inspection of markers on utility poles.

title: Margaret Atwood: Poems and Poet
description: WE are all immigrants to this place even if we were born here: the country is too big for anyone to inhabit completely, and in parts unknown to us we move in fear, exiles and invaders. So Margaret Atwood has written of the Canadian sensibility. It is more than that. For this poet, the snow that settles overnight, silently, obscuring even the little that was known of the land itself is the flesh that has settled to her bones. The civilization she confronts is one that has tacked itself to a continent : an overlay of roads taped to the earth. The design it imposes is a kind of dottodot game.

title: RateCutting Hits Commercial Paper
description: Two developments last week bid fair to change the way Wall Street does business. There were reports that investment bankers might be headed for the same kind of rate cutting that has hit brokerage firms. And the Supreme Court ruled that the Securities and Exchange Commission could no longer issue 10day ban after 10day ban on trading in a company's stock.

title: POLITICS Crime as a Campaign Issue
description: CRIME is a subject that New York voters will hear much about this year. That's already evident from the warmup rhetoric of the two likely gubernatorial candidates, Governor Carey and Perry B. Duryea of Montauk, the Assembly minority leader. They are debating not only the death penalty  which the Governor opposes and Mr. Duryea favors but also less draconian anticrime programs that each is proposing.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Anglers Still Favor Earth worms
description: Since World War II, a seemingly endless spate of new fishing lures has included modifications of traditional plugs, jigs or spoons, plus others that emit presumably seductive sounds or are selfpropelled or selfilluminated, but the lowly earthworm has never lost. favor among many of the nation's anglers who now number about 60 million.

title: A Sportsman's Sketches
description: THE Big Red Machine is a primer in bad writing. It is cluttered with clichs, with awkward phrases and with quotes that no person, I am quite certain, ever uttered. It is hard to tell whether the fault is that of the author or of his colleague in the translation. But if the prose is poor, the organization is worse: The attempts at chronology are a bad joke (a scene from 1960 is followed by one from 1968 that is in turn followed by one from 1964, skipping back and forth for no conceivable purpose except confusion), and I will personally strike a gold medal for anyone who can determine why the nine chapters have been put in the order in which they so haphazardly appear. There are also errors in wording (the author talks of the Soviet basketball team being drilled in longrange offensive rebounding, a contradiction in terms) and errors of fact (the author says the Soviet hockey team won its fourth straight Olympic title in 1972, when in fact the streak was three, after an American victory at Squaw Valley in 1960).

title: Deaths
description: GREENEAnnette, wife of Emanuel Greene. We express our sincere condolences to the family on the sudden passing of Annette Greene.

title: Official Predicts Desegregation Will Have to Come by State Law
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)Most school desegregation in the next few years will be a result of state laws, not restrictive Federal statutes, David S. Tatel, director of the Office for Civil Rights in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, predicted at a meeting of state education officials.

title: WORLD CUP  OR WORLD WAR?; SOCCER
description: The year is 1969. In the hills of Central America soldiers march stealthily through the undergrowth. Troops armed for modern warfare by the Government of El Salvador are on a searchanddestroy mission. Reconnaissance planes fly overhead. Walkietalkies crackle in the mountain air. They seek the forces of the enemy, Honduras. Honduras? El Salvador? At war? Why?

title: Indians and Marines Fighting Planned Fuel Terminal
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 20Utility companies and state officials seeking a California coastal site for the unloading of imported liquefield natural gas have found themselves under attack from a tribe of angry Indians and the United States Marines.

title: Robin Donovan Sets Wedding in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Donovan of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Donovan to Joseph Timothy Harper of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Harper of Shorewood, Wis.

title: BRIDGE
description: A writer of bridge columns, attempting to follow the customs of his profession, is likely to be reminded of the Chile pine, a prickly tree of the genus Araucaria , by the deal shown in the column.

title: Architecture
description: The conventional image of a modern house at the beach consists of a structure with a lot of glass, quite possibly a roof tilting sharply at 45 degrees, and almost always an open deck. It is a formula that works well in the hands of a skilled architect, but can lead to pretentious mediocrity when it is attempted by an architect more interested in playing with geometric forms than in creating usable living space.

title: 3 KILLED AS LIGHT PLANE CRASHES IN MICHIGAN LAKE
description: LAPEER, Mich., May 20 (AP)A father, this son and another man were killed today when their light plane crashed into Lake Nepessing, five miles west of here, Lapeer County sheriff's deputies reported.

title: Mrs. Carner's 66 Gains Record and 2Shot Lead
description: JAMESBURG, N.J., May 20Forsgate Country Club's East course plays quite long for most women golfers. But JoAnne Carner made this difficult, bunker infested, 6,056yard course appear short today as she set a record of five under par with 33. 3366.

title: Princeton Rasing Its Tax on Grants
description: PRINCETON FOR many scientists at Princeton University, July 1 will be a day to look at the accounts for their research projects and swallow hard.

title: Elizabeth Bina Buckner Becomes Bride Of Leonard H. Orr, a Magazine Editor
description: Elizabeth Bina Buckner, daughter of Helen Watson Buckner of New York and Walker G. Buckner of Washington, Conn., was married yesterday to Leonard H. Orr of New York, a writer and managing editor of Business & Society Review, a quarterly magazine of opinion about corporate and public affairs.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

Elizabeth H. Bixby, Stephen F. Brophy To Marry June 17
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward W. Bixby of Media, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth H. Bixby, to Stephen Frederick Brophy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore ,Frederick Brophy of Greenwich, Conn.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Those who are setting out tomato, eggplant and pepper plants for the first time should be aware of a danger underground. The cutworm. This invisibile nuisance has no scruples. With a quick bite, it cuts off tender seedlings at ground level and the young plants fall like timber. In the morning, an unsuspecting gardener goes out to review his efforts and finds destruction.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: One of two valises containing $593,080 in bills split open while being shipped two months ago from Los Angeles to New York aboard a Trans World Airlines jet. When Heriberto Castro, a 33yearold Colombian national, and his wife, Fanny, showed up at Kennedy International Airport to claim the bags, the police were there with lots of questions.

title: Newspaper for Disabled, Shut for Lack of Money, Is Seeking Funds for Book
description: Achievement, one of the largest newspapers serving the physically disabled, which shut its doors in December 1977 for lack of funds, is seeking financing to publish in book form reprints of its best articles.

title: Bergdorf Goodman Robbed of $400,000
description: Thieves who apparently hid in Bergdorf Goodman before the Fifth Avenue store closed Friday night emerged hours later, broke into locked display cases and stole about $400,000 in jewelry and antiques, the police reported yesterday.

title: Peru Placed Under Martial Law As Regime Moves to Halt Rioting
description: LIMA, Peru, May 20  Peru was placed under martial law today as the military Government moved to halt a wave of looting and sabotage in which at least 12 persons have died this week.

title: Papers Tell Tragic Story of Man Who Invented FM
description: Some 200,000 papers tracing the anguished career of Edwin Howard Armstrong, inventor of FM radio, have been given a permanent place at Columbia University, affording historians of radio broadcasting an unusual new source of documentation.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: RECENTLY P.E.N. American Center sponsored a literary auction of manuscripts, first editions, letters and other memorabilia of authors and artists donated by its members. For those interested in the price, if not the value, of a literary reputation the results were instructive though hardly definitive.

title: SPORTS He Gets to First Base The Hard Way
description: TEANECK IT is not that Steve Dembowski wants to get beaned or hit by pitch. But somehow, some way, baseballs are attracted to Dembowski like a magnet.

title: Affirmed Outduels Alydar Again in the Preakness
description: BALTIMORE, May 20Affirmed beat Alydar again today, but their stretch duel in the 103d Preakness kept a track painter, a record crowd of 81,261 at Pimlico and a national television audience in suspence right to the end. The margin this time for Affirmed, a 12 favorite, was only a neck.

title: In Los Angeles, No Hurrahs Are Heard Despite Designation as Site of 84 Games
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20When Los Angeles was chosen almost 50 years ago by the International Olympic Committee to stage the 1932 Summer Olympics, the news was greeted here by parties and civic celebration.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Save Huntington's farms [April 16] and provide homes you can afford.

title: Miniature Poodle Best At Hempstead Show
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 20Despite the heat of the day and a final of overall superior quality, Ch. Tiopepi Amber Tanya, an apricot miniature poodle, came through in style today and won the Ladies Kennel Association of Long Island's 72d dog show on the Hofstra University campus. There were 1,600 does in competition.

title: THE WORLD'S OLDEST WORKS OF ART
description: For at least 25,000 years before the dawn of civilization, ragged bands of mammoth hunters and seed gatherers  the CroMagnon peoples of the ice age roamed the rolling valleys of Europe and the flat steppe of Asia, hurling spears at wild horses and wooly mammoths, and grubbing in the dirt for roots.

title: Pulling Up the Suburban Drawbridge
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  In suburban town meetings, where residents in decades past often debated the direction of town expansion and how to broaden the tax base to pay for it, an entirely different issue has become increasingly dominant in the 1970's: How to keep the town from expanding at all.

title: What Has Gone Wrong?
description: WASHINGTON  Not long ago, trilateralism was the fashion in foreign affairs. A Trilateral Commission linked a distinguished international band of politicians, bureaucrats, busi nessmen and professors in mutual discussion and study. And when Trilateral pupil Jimmy Carter became President and Trilateral headmaster Zbigniew Brzezinski became national security adviser, analysts at home and abroad looked eagerly through the Commission's voluminous reports for the guiding principals of a new foreign policy. The basic ideas they found were not so novel.

title: 54% IN POLL SEE INFLATION AS THE BIGGEST PROBLEM
description: Indicating a dramatic surge of concern, 54 percent of the American public now says that inflation is the most important problem facing the nation, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Marriage Announcement 10  No Title
description: Engagements

title: Newark Boys Chorus Tries a Higher Scale
description: NEWARK IN the music business, nothing attracts attention more than a commission  or two. The Newark Boys Chorus is currently putting the finishing touches on one, and another is waiting in the wings.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR;; Drilling Holes in Economic Lifeb??ts
description: Despite its sometimes too dismal prognostications and politically naive prescriptions, No Room in the Lifeboats (by Richard J. Barnet, April 16) was a provocative essay on political economy. But what developing countries need is less in the way of gigantic handouts and more by way of just remuneration for the sale of their limited resources.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: In Summary

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Because the literature for solo bas soon is limited in scope and interest, most concerts featuring the instrument are essentially chambermusic programs. But because the bassoon is the quintessential ensemble instrument, such a format provides just about all the information necessary about the player. Robert Cochran's debut Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall consisted of five works in which he proved himself an able bassoonist as well as musician able to submerge his talents into the larger whole.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on resolution to disapprove the President's proposal for the sale of aircraft and related defense articles to Egypt, Israel and Saudi Arabia, rejected, 54 to 44, May15.

title: Business Booms at Yonkers Defense Plant
description: YONKERS THE LORAL Corporation's electronic systems division, perched on a hill where Central Avenue meets the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, has some big problems and some little ones. And while it appears to be solving such major challenges as Western defense, the smaller ones, like local traffic, have seemed more intractable.

title: What to Do When the Loggers Want Your Trees
description: Logging? That was not what Dr.and Mrs. R. had in mind when they bought 100 acres of wooded land in the Litchfield Hills of Connecticut. They thought of the trees as an esthetic asset rather than a financial one. Then came the inquiry from a Massachusetts sawmill.

title: CONGRESSIYIEN UPSET OVER TEAMSTER FUND;
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Shakeups in the Central States, Southeast and SouthWest Areas Pension Fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have caused alarm on Capitol Hill and brought calls this week for closer Government scrutiny of the troubled $1.4 billion fund.

title: William Auer Weds Barbara Dederick
description: Barbara Preston Dederick, daughter of Dr. And Mrs. Gerald F. Dederick of HoHoKus, N. J., was married there yesterday to William Bernhard Auer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard M. Auer of Greenwich, Conn.. and Hobe Sound. Fla. The Rev. Haywood Levy performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Out on the Slopes Skiers Are Starting To Think Green
description: The grass ski season begins in this country next weekend, Memorial Weekend. If you have not heard of grass skiing it need not give you an inferiority complex. I did not know about it until I spent a long weekend at Bryce Resort near Basye, Va., last winter fur some skiing on manmade snow and learned about grass skiing, which is relatively new and worth a try.

title: Her Own Woman
description: A HUNDRED years from now, the current outpouring of feministinspired fiction will be of interest chiefly to social historians, who will wonder how we could have been so backward as to need so much instruction, and to our greatgrandchildren, who will find the books in the attic and wonder how we could have enjoyed reading 20 or 30 books a year all having the same plot. If one of these novels is still being read for pleasure and enlightenment, though, I think it will be Gail Godwin's The Odd Woman.

title: CARTER COMPLAINS ON ARMSAID CURBS
description: WASHINGTON. May 20  President Carter has complained that the ability of the United States to supply defensive weapons to African countries and others in a crisis was sharply limited by Coneressionally imposed resrtictions.

description: Sarah Skinner Is Affianced,

title: United Methodists Win $2 Million Settlement Against ExTreasurer
description: The New York annual conference of the United Methodist Church has won a $2 million settlement of its suit in State Supreme Court charging its former treasurer and the treasurer's accounting firm with fraud and a breach of fiduciary duty.

title: Mozambique Train Wreck Kills 8
description: LONDON, May 20 (Reuters)Eight people died and 49 were injured in Mozambique today when a passenger train and a freight train collided near Beira, the Maputo radio reported. The radio, monitored here, said rescue workers expected to find more bodies under the wreckage of the two trains.

title: Measured Against The Past, Carter Isn't Doing Badly
description: Years ago, in a lecture at Princeton, I sought to explain the President's troubles on Capitol Hill. Questions were hostile. Why, students wanted to know, can't he get anything done up there? They complained that it's all style, no substance. Above all, they criticized the lack of leadership. The date was Nov. 21, 1963.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The fullpage ad is dominated by an illustration that shows the head of a familiarlooking woman who wears large dark glasses and seems vaguely miffed. Cheek by jowl is the face of a darkskinned, grayhaired man, also familiarlooking, also in dark glasses, who seems to be comforting the woman, though one has the impression they might be on a private yacht the size of Crete. Below them we see a montage of smaller images that call to mind highlife in high placesa speedboat, an oceangoing yacht, beautiful women in evening dresses or bikinis, the ruins of a Greek temple on the top of a Greek hill and, in the lower lefthand corner, the White House with, standing in front of it, two beautiful people in beach gear.

title: Multinationals vs. the Trade Gap
description: An important solution to the dollar problem is being overlooked. The principal source of the international dollar crisis is the large and continuing United States balanceoftrade deficit, which last year soared to $27 billion. The Carter Administration has been resting its nopes on measures to reduce imports, such as the proposed energy conservation program, and to stimulate exports. But to close a $40 billion trade gap, suggested by 1978's first quarter figures, would require a reduction of almost 30 percent in imports, an increase of 33 percent in exports, or some combination of the two.

title: Missing Link in Hartford
description: A DIFFICULT session of the state legislature has just ended. I come away from it with gnawing doubts about the future strength of key elements of our system, concepts that I have always considered as solid as they are worthy. My faith is somewhat shaken in such genius ideas as a citizen legislature and the Madisonian theory that interest groups, each protecting their own turf, will keep our system in harmonious balance.

title: POLITICS Biebel's Neutrality Stand
description: HARTFORD ONE of the stories they tell about the late John Bailey is that when Connecticut Democrats were trying to pick their gubernatorial candidate in 1954, Mr. Bailey, the party's longtime state chairman, took a shoebox around the state and got party officials to drop in slips of paper naming their choice.

title: Singing Their Way From Moscow to Minsk
description: INSTEAD of just strolling down to the beach this summer, or joining in local amateur theatricals, 17yearold Donna Terenzio of West Hill High School in Stamford will be heading for singing engagements in Moscow and Minsk. She is one of more than 100 Connecticut highschool performers who are going to Eastern Europe at the end of June as part of a growing interest among local schools in international student endeavors.

title: Clashing Ideologies, Faiths and Outside Influences Put the SubSahara in Turmoil
description: NAIROBE  The belt of pour subSaharan states across the girth of Africa is one of the more crisisridden regions on earth. Wars extending into generations plague these middle latitudes, from the arid wastelands in the west, where Algerianbacked guerrillas are fighting Morocco and Mauritania over their partition of the former Spanish Sahara, to the mountain ranges of Ethiopia in the east, where the government is mounting a counteroffensive against Eritrean secessionists. Beyond the immediate subSahara region, the conflicts have significance for the rest of Africa including Angola, Rhodesia and Zaire, where last week French Foreign Legion and Belgium paratroopers were hurridly dispatched to rescue Europeans caught up in a bloody rebellion.

title: Walt Rostow: It Will Take Skill to Avoid a Boom
description: Walt W. Rostow, former adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, is a professor of economics and history at the University of Texas. His latest books, The World Economy: History and Prospects and Getting From Here to There  America's Future in the World Economy, were published last month.

description: TODAYLong Island K. C. Show, Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I.; 1,648 dogs; 9 A.M.7 P.M.

Buddenhagen of Akron, Ohio. The Rev. Richard Cosnotti performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

description: Ashort walk from the intersec tion of Franklin Avenue and Seventh Street in downtown Garden City lies a dormant, weedcovered 21acre construction site where the stately old Garden City Hotel once stood.
