description: Dividend Meetings

title: Sales Trend For Gasoline Takes Shift
description: The gasoline business is changing; with the start of the summer driving season just one week away, retailers are in turmoil, their market shares shifting at a pace unseen in a decade or more.

title: GOTBAUM BIDS CAREY PLAY FORCEFUL PART IN FINANCIAL TALKS
description: Victor Gotbaum, the union leader, yesterday called on Governor Carey to play a more forceful role in helping to achieve a fiscal package needed for continuing Federal help to New York City.

title: Ballet: Diana With Cynthia Gregory
description: CYNTHIA GREGORY is a marvel. Her body is a nearly perfect instrument for dancing. Her technique is prodigious; har stage presence, magisterial. She is a remark able dancer who deserves remarkable ballets.

title: Chickens Soar Downward in Flying Competition
description: RIO GRANDE, Ohio, May 21While Affirmed and Alydar battled for the win at the Preakness yesterday, the real competition on the American sports scene was among Chicken Kiev, Captain Cluck, Seattle Stew and a host of other barnyard favorites winging away for the gold medal of chickenhoodfirst place in the International Chicken Flying Meet.

title: De Gustibus On BrillatSavarin
description: The person who writes about food with more grace and style than anyone else is and has been for many years M.F.K. Fisher, whose works include such titles as Serve It Forth, Consider the Oyster and How to Cook a Wolf.

title: InflationWary Stepping Up Buying
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 22 (AP)More people today are buying cars, houses and appliances to beat future price increases than at any time in the last 25 years, the University of Michigan reported today.

title: Says He Shares Concern About Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON, May 22In a statement today that the White House helped to draft, Andrew Young, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, played down his differences with President Carter on Congressional restraints on aid to Zaire and other friendly African nations.

title: Equine Stars at Belmont
description: It could have been .an equine version of High Noon. There was Affirmed, the winner and new champion. ambling down the dusty street of Belmont's stable area, the bright sun directly overhead. He was heading fur Barn 47.

title: US. Studies Payments To Arabs
description: WASHINGTON; May 22A Department of Justice task force investigating illegal, foreign payments by American Corporations is, now concentrating on a series of aircraft transactions in the Arab emirates and Bahrain, according to Government and industry sources familiar with the invastigation.

title: Extra Funds for L.E.A.A. Sought
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)President Carter sent a supplemental appropriation request for the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration totaling $10 million to Congress today, the White House announced. The money is being requested to implement the community anticrime initiative that Mr. Carter announced earlier as part of his new national urban policy, the White House said.

title: Says He Shares Concern About Restrictions

title: Cabaret: Elly Stone Sings at Story Towne
description: ELLY STONE, who has been doing concerts much of the time in recent years since her longrun success in Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris, is taking a twoweek fling at cabaret, which suggests not only that cabaret is the ideal ?? for her style and repertory or songs, but also that Story Towne, 41 East 58th Street, where she appeared last weekend and to which she will return this week from Friday through Sunday, is potentially one of the best settings in town for cabaret.

title: Prescription Subsidies Win Senate Renewal
description: TRENTON, May 22 (UPI)The State Senate voted today to add $4 million to the pharmaceutical assistance program for the elderly, which is running out of money. Passed by a vote of 250 with no debate, the measure was then sent to the Assembly.

title: New Jazz: Oliver Lake
description: O LIVER LAKE, who was at Joseph Papp's Public Theater over the weekend, has been leading an exemplary quartet for several years now. Because of economic factors more than anything else, longla'sting groups with stable personnel are relatively rare in the new jazz, and this slows down the development of many players. Mr. Lake has employed Michael Gregory Jackson, guitarist, and Paul Maddox, drummer, for several years now, and his bassist, Leonard Jones, replaced Fred Hopkins more than a year ago. The stability has been healthy; the music has grown.

title: Frontiers of Science; Looking (Still) for Atlantis
description: In recent years, a tidal wave of speculations has linked a single volcanic eruption to such catastrophes, legendary or real, as the destruction of Atlantis, the fall of the Minoan civilization, the great flood, the plagues of Egypt and the drowning of Egyptians In pursuit of the biblical Hebrews.

title: Orchestra Of Queens
description: IF the Queens College Orchestral Society sounded far better than an average student group at its Alice Tully Hall concert Sunday night, that is because the orchestra, despite its name, is not comprised exclusively of Queens College undergraduates. The personnel also Includes many alumni as well as musicians from the surrounding area, all welded into one harmonious ensemble by its music director, Martin Canellakis.

title: Chase Realty Revamping Plan
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust will unveil a new reorganization plan to its 21 bank creditors today that is reported to be mostly cosmetic but that the trust hopes will buy it time to continue the painstakingly slow job of selling assets to pay off creditors.

title: CORRECTION

title: The Cathedral Singers
description: ANY musical event held within the vast, highvaulted surroundings of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine at 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue may legitimately be described as Music for a Great Space. In the case of the concert given there Sunday afternoon, with Richard Westenburg leading the Cathedral Singers and the Lancaster Brass, the title was especially appropriate. Mr. Westenburg conducted works specifically designed to take full advantage of the antiphonal and acoustical properties of this environment.

title: Albee Prepares Play In Woolf Mold
description: EDWARD ALBEE has just turned 20. Actually he recently celebrated his 50th birthday, but by his own calculation he began his life two decades ago when he wrote his first play. In any case, this is an advanced age for America's angriest young playwright, but one which finds hint at his busiest and most productive.

title: Western Electric Sued on Age Bias
description: The Labor Department sued ?? Western Electric Company yesterday charging that the corporation, ?? manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Compan violated Federal age discrimination laws at some of its North Carolina ?? cilities.

description: MEXICO CITY, May 22Henry A. Kissinger said today that the Soviet Union should be put on notice that events in Zaire were endangering the future of dtente.

title: Dissent Over Begin Peace Policy Strains Israel's New Moderate Party
description: JERUSALEM, May 22  The Democratic Movement for Change, Israel's new moderate political party, ,is troubled by internal quarreling and may be heading for a split over the question of remaining in Prime Minister Menachem Begin's rightofcenter coalition Government.

title: Koch Reassures Black Leaders
description: Mayor Koch has told black leaders angered at his administration that he is making siginifcant changes in his plans to restructure the city's antipoverty program, possibly including a continuation of community corporations.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WINNIPEG ,Manitoba. May 22 (AP)  Dave Kryskow triggered the attack as the Winnipeg Jets beat the New England Whalers, 53, tonight and won their second World Hockey Association championship in three years.

title: Five Are Reported Killed in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, May 22  Five people were reported killed today in clashes between demonstrators and the police on the first clay of a general strike called to protest Government price increases for food, fuel and transportation.

title: Archbishop Ignatius Pi of Shenyang
description: PEKING, May 22 (Reuters)The senior Roman Catholic prelate in China, Archbishop Ignatius Pi Shushih, died last Tuesday in Shenyang, Roman Catholic sources said today. He was 80 years old.

title: A Job for BridetoBe: Make Amman Lively
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 22People in and around the royal court hope that King Hussein's American bridetobe will bring fresh ideas and a new dimension to life in this capital, which many consider essentially boring.

title: New York's Overcrowded Prisons Prepare for Tougher Penal Laws
description: ALBANY, May 22New York State's prisons are severely overcrowded and the inmate population is continuing to grow, leaving officials struggling to figure out :flow they will handle the tougher laws and longer sentences being considered by Governor Carey and the Legislature.

title: Boys Choir Finding Fame Has It on Go
description: Some members of the highly regarded Newark Boys Chorus have become so sought fter tht it is increasingly difficult to get them all together for a concert, but all 34 will be on hand tomorrow night at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall for the premiere of a dramatic cantata by Gian Carlo Menotti. The Trial of the Gypsy.

title: 98% Endorse Sadat Political Curbs
description: CAIRO, May 22The voters of Egypt have overwhelmingly given President Anwar elSadat a mandate to carry out his proposals for curtailing political dissent and criticism in the press, the Minister of the Interior, Nabawi Ismail, announced today.

description: David R. Berkowitz, who was scheduled to be sentenced yesterday for the six Son of Sam murders, battled officers before e,rttering the courtroom, then walked in chanting, Stacy was a whore.

title: An Undercover Patient In an Ambulance Inquiry Leads to Theft Suspect
description: Because some patients taken by ambulance to Bellevue Hospital were arriving there with their pockets empty, the New York City Investigations Commissioner said yesterday, an undercover agent was assigned to play the role of an outoftown businessman taken ill at a midtown hotel. As a result, Commissioner Stanley N. Lupkin said, Rowland Howard, a 28yearold ambulance technician, was arrested on charges of grand larceny.

title: U.S. Agents Expect Indictment of 3 Chilean Officers in Letelier Case
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 22United States investigators expect to obtain within a month Federal grand jury indictments of three Chilean Army officers suspected of plotting the assassination of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader, in Washington.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Copper futures prices continued to rise yesterday after the fighting in Zaire's southern mining region, advancing another 1 cent a pound on the Comex in New York.

description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)The Glomar Explorer, which recovered parts of a sunken Soviet submarine, may be used to explore for oil and naturil, gas and condu?? drilling operations in 12,000 feet of wat??.

description: Nobody's paid much attention to serious coats in the last few years, but that's changing now. Things are lcioking up.

description: LOS ANGELES IT WAS natural enough for Mike Wallace to attend the CBSTV affiliates meeting in Los Angeles two weeks ago. He is, after all, one of the stars of that network's most popular weekly series, 60 Minutes, and stars are always welcome for the glamour they reflect on the proceedings.

description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Supreme Court left standing today a lower court's order requiring the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to supply local phone connections for a competing longdistance phone company.

description: David R. Berkowitz, who was scheduled to be sentenced yesterday for the six Son of Sam murders, battled officers before entering the courtroom, then walked in chanting, Stacy was a whore.

description: The American Express Company filed suit yesterday in Federal Court in New York against the United States Attorney General in connection with a Justice Department proceeding that could permit Citicorp to reacquire Carte Blanche, the travel and entertainment credit card operation, from the Avco Corporation.

title: Bruins No Cup of Tea To Montreal
description: MONTREAL, May 22  Today is Victoria Day in Canada, a holiday in celebration of Queen Victoria's birthdayan appropriate day for a Stanley Cup parade down St. Catharine's ,Street to City Hall, the usual route. Had the final series between the Montreal Canadiens and the Boston Bruins followed the pattern of the two previous finals. when Montreal swept Philadelphia and then the Bruins in four straight games, the 1978 clincher would have been last night and the parade would have been today.

title: Real Places
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. As the women sit, the light from the picture window hits the little straw basket on the coffee table and you can see the daisies in there are plastic, which would be Prufrocksad except they decorate a swatch of sponsors crowded thick as commercial minutes in the Super Bowl.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Supreme Court cleared the way today for a second trial of an unusual $8 million libel suit that had been touched off by a .San Francisco television documentary on the safety of nuclear power.

title: TV: The Bastard Winds Up Tonight
description: OPERATION PRIME TIME consists of a group of independent and networkaffiliated stations gathered together to finance programming of the highest quality for the evening schedule. Quality is obviously in the eye of the beholderor salesman. The group's first effort, unveiled a year ago. was Testimony of Two Men, a sixhour adaptation of Taylor Caldwell's sprawling, brawling novel. The new entry is The Bastard, the second and final two hours of which can be seen tonight at 8 on WPIXChannel 11.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MAY 23, 1978

title: Collision Kills 2 Pilots in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGE, May 22 (AP)  Two sin gleengine planes collided yesterday, killing both pilots as they scanned the spring, salmon run for fishermen below, the Federal authorities said. The planes collided near Augustine Island on Cook Inlet, 175 miles southwest of Anchorage. The names of the victims were not released.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AddressographMultigraph Corporation, Cleveland, has elected Arthur F. Kelly, chairman and chief executive officer of Western Airlines, to the beard.

title: Price Curb By A.T.&T. Is Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Robert S. Strauss, the President's chief counselor on inflation, hinted today that the American Telephone and. Telegraph Company would. announce that it was voluntarily adopting restraints on price and pay increases. The company said it would make an announcement tomorrow.

description: Business Records

title: Passman Leaves Hospital to Await Ruling on Ability to Stand Trial
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 22 (AP)  Former Representative Otto E. Passman. charged with accepting alleged Korean bribes and evading taxes, has returned home after nearly two months in a hospital. He is awaiting a court ruling due May 31 on whether he is too sick to stand trial.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC PROMENADE, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 8:30.

title: Atlantic City Prepares for Worst Ever  Traffic Expected at Casino's First Weekend
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 22Atlantic City officials said today that they had coped with holiday weekend crowds in the past and could again this weekend with the opening of the nation's first legal gambling casino outside Nevada, but both state and city police have gone to unusual lengths to prepare for the worst.

title: Ailey Dances Spill Over
description: DANCES came spilling out of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Saturday night at the City Center. Not content with a program of five pieces by such choreographers as Mr. Ailey, George Faison and Joyce Trisler, the company added a John Butler solo at the last minute. And buried in that cornucopia was Icarus, Lucas Hoving's retelling of the Greek myth, set to a score by Shinichi Matsushita, which was seen on Saturday for the first time this season.

title: Carter Seeks to Reassure T.V.A.
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 22President Carter came here today to reassure the nation's original nuclear community that he remained committed to the peaceful uses of nuclear power and to challenge the Tennessee Valley Authority to take an expanded role in developing sources of energy.

title: Panatta Ousts Gerulaitis In First Round in Rome
description: ROME, May 22 (Reuters)Adriano Panatta of Italy eliminated Vitas Gerulaitis, the defending champion, 76, 75, in a dramatic twohour match in the first round of the Italian open tennis championships today.

title: Rep. Kemp's Play Can Make Old No.15 Taxpayers' No. 1
description: WASHINGTON, May 22His halfclosed eyes glint slyly, and Jack Kemp cocks his arm just as he did in the old days when he was quarterbacking the Buffalo Bills. Then with evangelical fervor he tells a visitor: I've got the No. 1 offensive play in the country.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)Americans smoked 603 billion cigarettes in 1975 an increase of 9 billion over the previous year, the Government reported today. But it also said the tar and nicotine content was decreasing.

title: 10,000 Homeless After Indian Fire
description: NEW DELHI, May 22 (Reuters)More than 10,000 people lost their homes today when fire syept through a densely, populated area of Vijayawada, in the southeastern state of Andhra Pradesh, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Besieged Tokyo Airport Is Coping, But Passengers Are Bewildered
description: NARITA, Japan, May 22Westerners arriving on the first commercial flight into the $2.9 billion New Tokyo International Airport here appeared bewildered by the strong guard of riot policemen and by the signs of revolt.

title: Yuri Slonimsky, 76
description: Yuri Slonimsky, a Soviet ballet historian and critic whose writings were wellknown in Western ballet circles, died in Leningrad on April 23. He was 76 years old.

title: 12 Dignitaries Saluted by Yale At Graduation
description: NEW HAVEN, May 22  With three presidents of Yale in attendance, the university today awarded 2,887 degrees, including 12 honorary degrees, to its students and to outstanding citizens.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The United States dollar, aided somewhat by news over the weekend of a possible natural gaspricing agreement in Washington, posted gains yesterday in foreign exchange trading overseas but was mixed in New York, according to The Associated Press.

title: Hungary Nears Favored Status
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)The House of Representatives voted 209 to 173 today to grant full trade privileges to Hungary, which would become the fourth Communistgoverned state to win favorednation. status from the United States.

title: Zaire Exile Leader Dies in Brussels After an Accident With Loaded Pistol
description: BRUSSELS, May 22 (Reuters)Kanyonga Mobateli, leader of a Zairian exile group in Belgium, has died following an accident with a pistol a month ago.

title: Elephants Help City's Growth
description: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus gave away 149 bags of elephant manure yesterday at the foot of a Madison Square Garden truck ramp on 33d Street. A spokesman said the circus had 22 elephants.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury will sell $2.39 billion in twoyear notes today, and their yield is expected to be about 8 percent, the highest rate of return on such securities since September 1975.

title: MARGARET PHILLIPS, 68, A PAINTER AND EDUCATOR
description: Margaret McDonald Phillips, a painter and educator, died last Thursday night after a fall in her home at 3555 78th Street in Jackson Heights, Queens. She was 68 years old.

title: Woman Sued for $38 for Breaking Date
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 22It had to happen in this litigious nation.A San Francisco woman has been sued in Small Claims Court here by a San Jose area man for breaking a date.

title: A Job for BridetoBe: Make Amman Lively
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 22People in and around the royal court hope that King Hussein's American bridetobe will bring fresh ideas and a new dimension to life in this capital, which many consider essentially boring.

title: Bank Plan For City Stirs Doubts
description: TARPON SPRINGS, Fla., May 22Although the proposal to establish a free trade zone for banking in New York has a good chance of approval by the Legislature in Albany. Philip E. Coldwell, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, indicated today that the Fed took a cool view of such action.

title: CITY AND UNIONS FAIL TO REACH AGREEMENT ON A WAGE PACKAGE
description: Under pressure from Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal, negotiators for New York City and its unions I failed yesterday to put the finishing touches on a citywide agreement for 200,000 employees.

title: Gaming Stocks Aid Market
description: The prospective start of legalized gambling later this week in Atlantic City sent gaming stocks sharply higher yesterday as Wall Street's bestwinning group. Although some institutions prohibit gambling issues in their portfolios as a matter of policy, traders and other investors bought them avidly.

title: State 3d in Traffic Safety
description: The state improved in traffic safety from 46th in the country in 1975 to third in 1976, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: Tying Ft. Lee Rents to Price Index Discussed in Court
description: TRENTON, May 22  Lawyers for Fort Lce and for owners of highrise apartment buildings agreed today that tying rent increases to the Consumer Price Index or some other yardstick of inflation would be a fair method of initially adjust ing rents on an annual basis in the borough.

title: On Wall Street, Lunch Hour Is The Main Event
Obituary 1  No Title
description: ALEXANDER R. PIPER

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Ballet: IIlinka, Duell, Frohlich in Divertissements
description: THERE was some gorgeous dancing at the New York State Theater on Sunday night when the New York City Ballet presented the season's first performance of Bournonville Divertissements.

title: 2 F.B.I. CHIEFS KNEW OF ENTRIES, AIDE SAYS
description: WASHINGTON. May 22One of the three form.or Federal Bureau of Investigation officials charged with authorizing a series of illegal breakins told a grand jury that he had told his superiors as far back as 1973 that the breakins had taken place, according to documents filed in United States District Court here today.

title: FRANKLIN WATTS, FOUNDER OF BOOK PUBLISHER, AT 74
description: Franklin Watts, publisher of books for children and adults for more than 36 years, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 10 Waterside Plaza.

title: Yugoslavia Orders Plants From Japan
description: TOKYO, May 22 (Reuters)NisshoIwai Ltd. reported that it had received an order from Yugoslavia for a pyritesintering plant and a sulfuric acid factory worth roughly $13.2 million.

title: Belgians Fear French Intervention In Zaire Is to Expand Influence
description: BRUSSELS, May 22Belgian officials are convinced that France is using its military intervention in Shaba Province in Zaire as a pretext for expanding its influence in one of the richest mineral areas of Africa.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DIGGING IN One of the city's last tinsmitheries, situated in an atmospheric loft, will be visited tonight by Adventure on a Shoestring. The group will assemble at 6 o'clock on the southwest corner ,of 26th Street and Eighth Avenue. The tab is $3 and reservations are suggested at CO 52663.

title: Expos Top Pirates On a 5Hitter, 52
description: MONTREAL, May 22 (AP)  Steve Rogers, who hurled hitless ball for 713 innings, combined with Darold Knowles to pitch a fivehitter as the Montreal Expos posted a 52 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Nazi Plan To Hold Demonstration in Skokie
description: CHICAGO, May 22The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit ruled today that the heavily Jewish Chicago suburb of Skokie could not prohibit a demonstration by a Nazi group, which the village had contended would violate a village ordinance against rhetoric promoting racial hatred.

title: Pop: Singer From Israel
description: CHAVA ALBERSTEIN, an Israeli pop singer, was at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night, and her music was both eclectic and intensely nationalistic. Perhaps the nationalism should come as no surprise, but in an era when Malaysian pop singers are influenced by Nashville crooners and cabaret entertainment can be pretty much the same from Teheran to Tulsa it seems worthy of comment.

title: Addressograph Raises Net in 3d Fiscal Quarter
description: Increased profits from foreign operations and improved sales enabled the AddressographMultigraph Corporation to lift its net income in the third fiscal quarter to almost five times the total in the preceding year's quarter, the company said yesterday.

title: Harvard M.B.A.: A Golden Passport
description: BOSTON, May 22In a few days the world will be richer by 750 Masters of Business Administration from Harvard, a prospect that can be disappointing only to the 2,250 or so employers who tried hard to snag one this spring and failed.

title: Utah Power to Sell Shares
description: The Utah Power & Light Company will sell 2.2 million shares common stock today at a price of $17.90 a share. a price slightly above the $17.75 closing price yesterday on the New York Stock Exchance. The stock is being sold by an underwriting group managed by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Ribicoff, Focus of Jewish Anger for JetSale Vote, Argues It Reflected U.S. Interest
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  In all the contention over the Senate's approval of the controversial sale of jet fighters in the Middle East, it was Senator Abraham A Rihicoff who drew the most fire from critics in the Jewish community.

title: 2 F.B.I CHIEFS KNEW OF ENTRIES,AIDE SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, May 22One of the three former Federal Bureau of Investigation officials charged with authorizing a series of illegal breakins told a grand jury that he had told his superiors as far back as 1973 that the breakins had taken place, according to documents filed in United States District Court here today.

title: The U.N. Today
Casino Dealers Get Jersey Licenses, Paving Way for Opening Thursday
description: TRENTON, May 22The Casino Control Commission licensed 293 dealers and 30 pit bosses today, and Resorts International Inc. said it would open its gambling casino at Atlantic City on Thursday night, a day earlier than had been expected.

title: Article 2  No Title
BUSINESS Digest
description: A. T. & T. may announce voluntary wageprice restraints, Robert S. Strauss hinted. The President's chief inflation counselor said he had talked to John deButts, head of the telephone giant, and that some very positive steps were expected. [Page D1.] On another front, Douglas Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, said union leaders were willing to show restraint in their demands. [A16.]

title: Books of The Times
description: IT COULD HAVE BEEN a lot worse. Naturally, I started off deploring .44, Jimmy Breslin's and Dick Schaap's novel based on the Son of Sam killings. I deplored its very existence as another act in the exploitive press circus inspired by the terror last summer. I especially deplored the unctuously twofaced Author's Note, which reads: This is a novel. It is based on historical realities  the Son of Sam killings in New York City in 1976 and 1977  but it is not itself historically accurate It is not supposed to be. Many people were hurt by Son of Sam, directly and indirectly, and to avoid hurting those people further, and to protect those who shared their experiences and their thoughts with us, we have invented people, places, and dates, everything except the terror, The terror was real. This is a novel. It is not factual. We hope it is truthful.

title: Commuter Line Bus Strike Ends With Old Contract
description: NEWARK, May 22The Manhattan Transit Company agreed today to a oneyear extension of an expired union contract, ending a 52day strike that had directly affected 20,000 interstate commuters daily and thousands of others forced to ride crowded buses.

title: Emirates See Steady Oil Price
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 22 (UPI)The Oil Minister of the United Arab Emirates expects no oilprice increase at next month's Geneva meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. the Midale East Economic Survey said today.

title: Call by F.A.L.N. Follows 4 Explosions in 3 Cities
description: Incendiary devices touched off small fires at the New York metropolitan area's three major airports, and a pipe bomb exploded outside the Justice Department Building in Washington yesterday, but, the blasts caused no injuries and only slight damage.

title: Public Debate of Aides Obscures U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 The uncertainties over the American role in the Zaire airlift are part of the Administration's larger problems in determining a policy on how to deal with Africa, and in particular, with the Soviet and Cuban military roles,

title: If It's Tuesday, It Must Be...
description: THE second most frequently asked question about The New York Times in recent months has been, What's the Tuesday section going to be?

title: F.H.A. to Raise Mortgage Rates
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)Interest rates on Federal Housing Administration mortgage loans will he raised tomorrow to their highest level in two and a half years, the Government announced today.

title: Music: Winners of Composers' Contest
description: THE League of Composers and the United States section of the International Society for Contemporary Music recently held a national composers competition, the winners of which became entries in an international competition at the 1978 World Music Days in Helsinki, Finland. Friday and Saturday nights, the national winners were presented in concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Legislature Is Believed Likely to Extend Heart Law
description: ALBANY, May 22The Legislature appears likely to extend the heart law that lets policemen and firemen retire at threequarters pay if they develop a heart ailment during their employment, but the exact terms of the extension remain open to question.

title: Consumer Safety Panel Recalling Paint Removers as Shock Threat
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today that two brands of elactric paint removers that may pose a potential shock hazard were being recalled.

title: Hussein Flies Home After Talks With Saudi on Peace Stalemate
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 22 (AP)King Hussein returned to Jordan today after two days of private talks in Saudi Arabia with Crown Prince Fand. The talks were aimed at rebuilding Arab solidarity after the split caused by Egypt's peace overture to Israel last fall, informed sources said.

title: Mideast Gifts to U.S. Schools Pose Questions of Influence
description: Oil wealth from the Middle East is starting to flow onto college and university campuses throughout the country, bringing a bonanza of endowed chairs and new programs but stirring one of higher education's biggest controversies over the issue of outside influence.

title: Jens Nygaard Puts Accent on Strings
description: O RCHESTRAL Concert, the program said. More accurately, it was a string orchestra concert that Jens Nygaard conducted last night in Alice Tully Hall, though variety was provided by the soloistsviolin and harpsichord in Haydn's Double Concerto in F, trumpet and bassoon in Hindemith's equally double concerto.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Mideast Gifts to U. S. Schools Pose Questions of Influence
description: Oil wealth from the Middle. East is starting to flow onto college and university campuses throughout the country, bringing a bonanza of endowed chairs and new programs but stirring one of higher education's biggest controversies over the issue of outside influence.

title: Study of Puerto Rican Aid Urged
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights has urged the Carter Administration to create an interagency coordinating committee to review the impact of Federal programs on the Puerto Rican communities on the mainland and in Puerto Rico.

title: HONORED DETECTIVE PUT ON SUSPENSION
description: A 46yearold detective decorated for saving the life of a visiting statesman was suspended without pay by the New York City Police Department yesterday on charges that he sold confidential information to unauthorized outsiders,

title: Judge Limits Evidence on Curare At Death Trial of Dr. Jascalevich
description: HACKENSACK, May 22The .judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich ruled today that records of the doctor's purchases of curare during the time patients suddenly died at Riverdell Hospital were not admissible as evidence.

title: New York Countdown: the Crucial Veto
description: Another climax is at hand in New York City's Permanent Floating Financial Crisis. The city and its major unions are virtually finished writing a new wage contract. The pension funds and banks will soon make further investment in city bonds. And the State Legislature stands poised to create a new review board monitor the city's budget. All this is being accomplished in time to give Congress a chance to enact a longterm loan guarantee that would make possible, though not certain, a slow but steady retreat from the brink bankruptcy.

title: Barred Seniors Hold Private Graduation
description: MILWAUKEE, May 22 (AP)Twothirds of the senior class at Thomas More High School held a private graduation ceremony yesterday because they were barred from receiving diplomas at the regular commencement as punishment for skipping school.

title: Advertising
description: As it does periodically, Time Inc. yesterday announced a game of executive musical chairs, to he played June 1. Ralph P. Davidson, the 50yearold publisher of Time magazine, will move upstairs to share, without a standard corporate title, the duties of James R. Shepley, 60, president of the corporation. Mr. Davidson will be replaced by John A. Meyers, a Time veteran who has been puublisher of Sports Illustrated since 1972 and who will, in turn, be replaced by Kelso Sutton, 39.

title: Notes on People
description: ALTHOUGH booksellers around the nation have been reporting only lukewarm interest in RN: The Memoirs of Richard Nixon, about 50 persons invited to the former President's home to celebrate publication of the book were in a festive mood. Pat Nixon, recoverine from a bout of acute viral bronchitis, didn't join the festivities at La Casa Pacifica, the Nixon estate in San Clemente, Calif., but on hand were the Nixon daughters, Tricia Cox and Julie Eisenhower, Mrs. Eisenhower is expecting a baby, and Mr. Nixon compared writing his book to his daughter's forthcoming motherhood. A book is somewhat like a baby being born, he said.

title: Dance: Margaret Beals
description: THE SETTING of poetry to movement is an honorable enough if little practiced art. There is a delicate balance to be achieved before words and motion enhance and illuminate each other. Among current practitioners, Valerie Bettis and Jean Erdman have chosen for the most part to narrate dramatic poetry with dance.

title: 5 Islander Partners Form Overseer Unit Without Boe
description: A fiveman committee of partners has been formed to straighten out the tangled finances of the New York Islanders and it does not include Roy Boe, the team's president.

title: BELGIAN PARATROOPS FLY OUT OF KOLWEZI FRENCH UNIT REMAINS
description: KOLWEZI, Zaire, May 22Belgian paratroopers flew out of this battered coppermining town today, leaving under the control of French Foreign Legionnaires and Zairian Government troops.

title: Gunman Fails in Bank Holdup
description: DETROIT, May 22 (UPI)A gunman who said he was carrying a bomb held six people hostage in a bank for about 40 minutes today and then surrendered to the police. No one was injured and the bomb threat turned out to be a hoax. One shot was fired when the gunman and three accomplices entered the Manufacturers National Bank branch and announced a holdup. The three accomplices were arrested as soon as they ran out of the bank with the money.

title: Stage: Jesse James Poses
description: THE DEATH and Life of Jesse James is an elegant trap that catches nothing. Like a collection of advertisements for vodka or rum, it is a series of significant poses that possess everythingdecoration, wit, and a relentless haunted qualityexcept sigficance.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, MAY 22, 1978

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, MAY 24

title: Five Are Reported Killed in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, May 22Five people were reported killed today in clashes between demonstrators and the police on the first day of a general strike called to protest Government price increases for food, fuel and transportation.

title: SHCHARANSKY'S SITUATION WORSENS, MOTHER SAYS
description: MOSCOW, May 22The mother of Anatoly Shcharansky, a dissident who has been held for 14 months on charges of treason, expressed the fear today that the situation of her son had deteriorated since the political trials last week in Moscow and Tbilisi.

title: Chancellor Backs Modified Plan For Construction at York College
description: Bowing to what he called public policy considerations, the chancellor of the City University modified his position and endorsed yesterday a compromise $90 million to $100 million construction program for York College in Jamaica, Queens, and a curriculum built around business and healthcare programs.

title: House Panel Studies GrassRoots Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, May 22A Congressional subcommittee opened hearings today on the use of grassroots lobbying and heard assertions that many corporations may have improperly taken tax deductions for the costs of campaigns to influence the public on legislative matters.

title: HAIG SAYS HE'LL STAY AS NATO COMMANDER
description: BRUSSELS, May 19Gen. Alexander M. Haig said today that he had been asked by President Carter's Administration to remain in his post as supreme allied commander of Western forces and that he would do so.

title: Fierstein's Stud Moves to Players
description: HARVEY FIERSTEIN'S International Stud, which opened last night at the Players Theater after a run at La Mama, is not, as one might expect from the title, an example of theater of glitter. Instead, it is a small, sad love story about a female impersonator with scruples and standards.

title: CITY AND UNIONS FAIL TO REACH AGREEMENT ON A WAGE PACKAGE
description: Hopes for a quick settlement in New York City's labor negotiations were dashed last night when a top union leader emerged from bargaining talks and denounced city officials for making what he described as a regressive proposal that, he said, left the two sides further apart than they had been before.

title: Individuals Found Aided by Rate Rule
description: WASHINGTON, May 22It will come as no surprise to Wall Street, but 1977 was considerably less prosperous for the securities industry than the two preceding years, according to a statistical study issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: High Court Will Decide Fed Issue
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Reserve System can continue to keep secret for a month its key decisions on monetary policy.

title: Bridge:
description: The world's most successful charity bridge game has begun to behave like an amoeba. Two years ago the game between the United Jewish Appeal and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, which was played in Manhattan for many years under the direction of Tubby Stayman, raising vast sums, divided into two parts. And this year there are not only two sites but also two dates, allowing those who wish to play with an expert, or simply to mingle, to compete twice.

title: Two  Issues Resolved, One Remains. In Talks  on New York City Finances
description: ALBANY, May 22Two of the three key disputes standing in the way of bipartisan approval of New York City's financial legislation were reported to have. been resolved today and tonight by negotiators working at the Capitol here.

title: 18 Restaurants Cited for Violations Of Health Code by City Department
description: The New York City Department of Health listed 18 restaurants that had violated the Health Code, one that had corrected an earlier violation and five that had been closed for failing to correct earlier violations. The restaurants were listed as follows.

title: Twitching Tendons On Africa
description: Andrew Young has done it again. After a long silence, the United Nations Ambassador bobbed into the news with as much irreverence as ever. People are getting too excited about those Cubans in Africa, he said; and President Carter is not being prevented by Congressional restrictions from making some necessary response to them.

title: Cash Prices
description: ( Prices in N.Y. unless otherwise posted)

title: Presbyterians Reject the Ordination of Homosexuals
description: SAN DIEGO, May 22The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. tonight overwhelmingly adopted a report that disapproves the ordination of avowed, practicing homosexuals but strongly endorses civil and human rights for them.

title: Caputo Is Backed As Running Mate On Duryea Ticket
description: Representative Bruce Caputo of Yonkers has emerged as the frontrunner for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor, state G.O.P. aides said yesterday.

title: Rep. Kemp's Play Can Make Old No. 15 Taxpayers' No. 1
description: WASHINGTON, May 22His halfclosed eyes glint slyly. and Jack Kemp cocks his arm just as he did in the old days when he was quarterbacking the Buffalo Bills. Then with evangelical fervor he tells a visitor: I've got the No. 1 offensive play in the country.

title: Kentucky Seeks Easing Of Ban on Broodmares
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., May 22 (UPI)Kentucky veterinary officials said today they were increasingly optimistic about the continued control of equine venereal disease at two Kentcuky horsebreeding farms and were hoping for at least a partial easing of a Department of Agr culture ban On the shipping broodmares out of Kentucky.

title: JUDGESHIP NOMINEE QUERIED ON REMARKS
description: Martin Erdrnann once had unkind things to say about judgeshe called them whores and madamsand since he was nominated two weeks ago for a Criminal Court Judgeship by Mayor Koch, he has had a lot of explaining to do.

title: Public Debate of Aides Obscures U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The uncertainties over the American role in the Zaire airlift are part of the Administration's larger problems in determining a policy on how to deal with Africa, and in particular, with the Soviet and Cuban military roles.

title: 12 Dignitaries Saluted by Yale At Graduation
description: NEW HAVEN, May 22With three presidents of Yale in attendance, the university today awarded 2,887 degrees, including 12 honorary degrees, to its students and to outstanding citizens.

title: Iran Holds 15 in Bomb Blast
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 22 (Reuters)The police arrested 15 people after a time bomb exploded last night and damaged a ?? ?? kiosk the Moslem holy city of Qom. Newspapers said there were a few more arrests after a branch of the stateowned Melli Bank was set on fire in Qom, 95 miles south of here. Qom has been a center of continuing unrest this year.

title: Shero Says, I Quit'
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP)Fred Shero resigned today as coach of the Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League because he felt he had exhausted his ability to motivate the team he had led to two Stanley Cup championships during his sevenyear tenure.

title: Dealers and Pit Bosses Licensed, Opening the Way For Start of Atlantic City Casino Gambling Thursday
description: TRENTON, May 22The Casino ControlCommission licensed 293 dealers and 30 pit bosses today, and Resorts International Inc. said it would open its gambling, casino at Atlantic City Thursday night,?? day earlier than had been expected.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Andrus, 16 Months in Job, Still in Crossfire
description: WASHINGTON, May 22When Cecil D. Andrus was appointed Secretary of the Interior he announced that, as far as the nation's natural resources were concerned, the days of what he called Lhe Three R'srape, ruin and runwere

title: Gromyko Here for Arms Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22 (UPI)Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived here today for a United Nations summit session on disarmament. He urged deeds rather than words to stop the world from spending $400 billion a year on war machinery. Mr. Gromyko was the first major official to arrive for the fiveweek summit, the 10th special session of the General Assembly.

title: Business People
description: The way Najeeb Halaby tells it, he was interested in the Arab world long before other Americans of Arab origin discovered their heritage, which happened to occur just about the time oil prices went up. And, in fact, his company, Halaby International, appears to be well along the way to becoming an important factor in the Arab world, helping the rapidly expanding Middle East countries adapt to Western technology.

title: Agricultural CallIn Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)The Agricultural Council of America will conduct a telephone callin this week to sample public opinion on United States agriculture and what people should know about it. A panel of Agriculture Department officials and members of Congress will be on hand to help answer the calls from noon to 4 P.M. Wednesday. Council officials said that the tollfree number for the fourhour project is 8003688050.

title: The Forces That Favor Recession
description: An important segment of the financial community has apparently resigned itself to another recession later this year or next. These analysts see a recession as the only remedy for a disturbing inflation rate and they think a recession sooner will hurt less than a recession later, when the inflation rate might again be above 10 percent.

title: Norway and Volvo Joining In Oil and Auto Venture
description: LONDON, May 22Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, today announced a farreaching restructuring that will put the company in partnership with oilrich Norway and may lead to longterm cooperation on energy by Scandingvia's chief economic rivals.

title: 300 Arrested in Nuclear Protest at Submarine Base
description: Nearly 300 demonstrators were arrested yesterday in Bangor, Wash., after they climbed a sixfoot barbed wire fence and gathered on a grassy knoll inside the Trident nuclear submarine base. Meanwhile, one of 30 persons demonstrating in Groton, Conn., was arrested.

title: Strike at Ford Unit Ends
description: ROMEO, Mich., May 22 (UPI)Workers at the Ford Motor Company's only tractor plant in North America returned to work today, ending an 11day walkout touched off by a dispute over production standards. A spokesman at the plant said that full production shifts started reporting at midnight, and assembly line operations were back to normal for the first shift.

title: Ontario Plans U.S. Financing
description: Ontario is borrowing $200 million in the United States capital ?? today, bringing to more than $1.5 billion the volume of Canadien ?? done in the public market here so for this rear. The province's ?? which are rated tripleA by both Moody's and Strndard & Poor's. are priced to give investors a yield of 9 percent.

title: House Extends Veteran Eligibility
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)The House voted 388 to 0 today to extend to Sept. 30, 1980, a program offering trial Federal jobs for disabled veterans and Vietnam era veterans with fewer than 14 years of education and to restore eligibility to those who have lost it, The program is now due to expire June 30.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deatlis

title: Judge Limits Use Of Drug Records In Curare Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 22The judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich ruled today that records of the doctor's purchases of curare during the time patients suddenly died at Riverdell Hospital were not admissible as evidence.

title: Suspect Is Seized In Assault on Boy
description: A man was arrested in the South last night after he allegedly ??red a boy into an abandoned building in a neighborhood were there I.as been a recent string of sexual attacks against young boys.

title: Steel Output Declines 0.1%
description: Steel production for the week ended May 20 declined to 2.8 million tons, down 0.1 percent from the ?? million tons the week before, according to the Iron & Steel Institute.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Demonstration in Detroit
description: DETROIT, May 22 (UPI)A demonstration by 150 to 200 people outside a neoNazi bookstore en the city's Northwest Side last night grew into rock and bottle throwing. The police arrested 10 protesters and quelled the disturbance. A minor injury to an unidentified Nazi member was reported, a police spokesman said

title: Yanks Get Good Reports on Hunter, Guidry Ailments
description: The Yankees, who have endured more serious injuries to highpriced pitchers than probably any other team primarily because they own more highpriced pitchers than any other teamgained some degree of consolation yesterday from their latest medical reports.

title: Sports Leagues Battling Tax Proposal
description: Among President Carter's tax reform proposals now before the House Ways and Means Committee is one that would prevent a company from deducting the cost of tickets to sports events as a business expense. In the course of the months of argument over the proposals, sports promoters have been especially active in making known their view that removing the tax deduction would be catastrophic to their profits.

title: Job of Mayor's Cook Periled Over Interview
description: Mayor Koch's office threatened yesterday to discharge the cook at Gracie Mansion because she gave an interview to a newspaper reporter.. The threat was delivered by Mr. Koch's press secretary, Maureen R. Connelly, to the cook, Rozanne Gold, after the Mayor had seen Miss Gold walking with a New York Times reporter, Dena Kleiman, in Greenwich Village on Sunday.

title: Worst Ever Traffic Is Anticipated For Opening of Atlantic City Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 22  Atlantic City officials said today that they had coped with holiday weekend crowds in the past and could again this weekend with the opening of the nation's first legal gambling casino outside Nevada, but both state and city police have gone to unusual lengths to prepare for the worst.

title: Economic Scene
description: ON April 26, the Supreme Court struck down a Massachusetts law that had limited the First Amendment rights of a business corporation to those issues that materially affect its business, property or assets. By a 5to4 decision, the Court held in First National Bank Boston et al v. Bellotti that the appellantsnational banking associations and business corporationshad the right to spend corporate funds to publicize their views opposing a referendum to authorize the Massachusetts Legislature to enact a graduated personal income tax.

title: Great Performers Series To Present 52 Concerts
description: The Great Performers Series sponsored by Lincoln Center will present 39 solo artists and conductors and 11 ensembles in 52 concerts during the 197879 season. It is the largest number of events offered in the series since it was started 14 years ago.

title: Kaunda Says Political Solution Is Required in Zaire
description: Kenneth D. Kaunda, the President of Zambia, which borders Zaire, said at a news conference here yesterday that only a political solution to the conflict in Zaire would prevent another rebel in??.

title: Jazz: Thad JonesMel Lewis Band
description: THE Thad JonesMel Lewis big band has been a bastion of conservative values in contemporary jazz since its inception. Mr. Jones, a superb trumpeter with a penetrating sound and judiciously slippery sense of phrasing all his own, and Mr. Lewis. an experienced smallgroup and bigband drummer, have never concerned themselves very much with post1960 developments in the music, whether of the free form or electronic variety, Occasional soloists have brought in suggestions of contemporary ferment, but only in the context of the band's bright, traditionally oriented arrangements.

title: Washington Journal
description: She pronounces the name of the city with a hiss, as though she was taught by her Kentucky parents never to say it. They were pleased when she became a teacher, but after trying that for two years in Paducah, she moved here, against their wishes, a month after Spiro Agnew resigned, taking for herself a tidy apartment on Capitol Hill, a tedious job at the Commerce Department and a tenacious lover she does not like much more than she likes this city.

title: Giants Are Winning Race in the Bay Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 22The GiantDodger rivalry, baseball's most intense historically but stagnant the last six years while the Giants went into eclipse. is flourishing again.

title: Article 1  No Title
World Writers' Group Expels Chilean Affiliate As Tool of Government
description: The Chilean chapter of P.E.N. was expelled yesterday from membership in the Londonbased international writers organization, which said the chapter was a political arm of a totalitarian Government that intimidated and inhibited writers.

title: U.S. Policy on South Africa: Anti  Whi te Racism
description: PRETORIA, South AfricaAs a responsible member of the international community, South Africa finds itself in a unique situation, designed separately by the United States and the Soviet Union to yield a single result: propel South Africa, within its own inalienable territory, on a selfdestructive course.

title: Wickes Profit Up 33.3%
description: The Wickes Corporation disclosed yesterday a 33.3 percent rise in earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended April 29 to $4.4 million, or 41 cents a share. Sales of the retailer of lumber and other building supplies rose 29 percent to $402.6 million.

title: Music: Five Composers
description: WORKS by five winners of the 1977 League  ISCM National Composers Competition were featured at the group's final concert of the season Saturday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Perhaps it was a lean year, but most of the compositions seemed of fairly limited interest.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MAY 23, 1978

title: Redeeming the Welfare Pledge
description: President Carter fulfilled a campaign pledge last year when he submitted a sweeping welfare reform proposal to Congress. But key Democrats, like House Ways and Means Chairman Ullman and Senate Finance Chairman Long, balked at the nearly $20 billion price tag and for all practical purposes declared the controversial plan dead on arrival. Even as Representative Corman's special subcommittee labored conscientiously on the original proposal, welfare reform was quietly stricken from Washington's legislative priority list.

title: Wee...Cow'rin, Tim'rous Beastie
description: This is no time to be a mouse. Scarcely a day goes by without another newspaper report that some poor mouse has been pressganged into a laboratory and subjected to deadly experiments.

title: British Prime Minister Is Named First Winner of Humphrey Award
description: LONDON, May 22Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain has been named the first recipient of the Hubert H. Humphrey International Award, it was annnnunced today.

title: Japan's Auto Output Up
description: TOKYO, May 22 (UPI)Japan's automobile production in April totaled 757,277 units, up 7.7 percent from a year ago, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today. This brought JanuaryApril production to record of about 2.99 million units, up 11.8 percent over last year. April production included 490,440 passenger cars, up 9.4 percent from 1977, and 263,000 trucks, up 5.1 percent. The remaining 3,837 units were buses.

title: GIRL, 15, KILLED BY A SHOT WHILE CHATTING ON STREET
description: A 15yearold girl was killed at about 7 o'clock last night by a gunshot from an unknown source as she stood chatting with friends on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A special prosecutor appointed by District Attorney Denis E. Dillion of Nassau County has recommended that a grand jury be impaneled to consider whether criminal charges should he brought against six assistant district attorneys, dismissed by Mr. Dillon last March for the possession of marijuana.

title: WATERMAN AWARD GIVEN TO CALIFORNIA PHYSICIST
description: The National Science Foundation announced yesterday that its annual Alan T. Waterman Award has been presented to a 34yearold physicist, Richard A. Muller of the Berkeley Laboratory or the University of California.

title: 10 Now in House May Have Received Funds From Korea
description: WASHINGTON. May 22 (UPI)House investigators have information that indicates former Korean Ambassador Kim Dong Jo may have made payments to as many as 10 current members of Congress. Capitol Hill sources said today.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Death

title: Farm Land Sales Hearings Planned
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)A House subcommittee will hold hearings into the implications of increased foreign buying of United States farm land, Representative Richard Nolan, Democrat of Minnesota, said today. Mr. Nolan, who heads the Agriculture Committee's family farms and special studies subcommittee, said that he hoped to start the hearings in late June.

title: Vote on Homosexual Rights Bill Overshadows Other Oregon Races;
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 22The most interesting contest in tomorrow's Oregon primary is one in which nobody is running for office.

title: Cornell Aims at 3d Lacrosse Title in Row
description: Cornell has only one more barrier left between it and an unparalleled third national lacrosse championship in a row.

title: Bills Prohibiting Bank Redlining Gain in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 22  The Assembly tonight approved a package of bills that would prohibit bank redlining, the practice through which banks allegedly deny mortgages to homeowners in declining urban areas, and give the Superintendant of Banks the power to require that a certain portion of bank monies be allocated to decaying neighborhoods.

title: A Cup for Three Rangers
description: BOSTON, May 22At the time the New York Rangers thought they had pulled off the biggest Boston heist since the Brinks holdup. They had snatched Phil Esposito, who once had scored 76 goals in a season, and Carol Vadnais, a defenseman they had long coveted, from the Bruins in a trade for Brad Park, a defenseman who was not Bobby Orr, and Jean Ratelle, a center who was not even Jean Ratelle anymore. That was early in the 197576 season when both teams were wobbling on doublerunners. The Rangers are still on them. They're looking to unload Phil Esposito while they tolerate Carol Vadnais, await the two Swedish saviors (Anders Hedberg and Ulf Nilsson) in search for a new coach. But the Bruins have flourished since that trade and another deal that liberated Rick Middleton from the Ranger treadmill. With the fourofsevengame Stanley Cup final now tied at 22 as it returns to Montreal tomorrow night, the three Boston Rangers might even have their names engraved on the old silver mug.

title: Bruce Geller and Stephen Gentry, TV Executives, Die in Plane Crash
description: Bruce Geller, the television writer and producer who originated the Mission Impossible and Mannix television programs, and Stephen Gentry, a vice president of ABCTV, were killed Sunday in the crash of a twinengine plane in hills near Santa Barbara. Calif.

title: Women Gain Job Status, But Slowly, Study Says
description: Women are slowly moving up the corporate ladder into higherpowered, higherpaying jobs, but they still have a long way to go before they reach parity with their male counterparts, according to a study released yesterday by the Conference Board.

title: Article 3  No Title
Dr. Richstone Guilty Of Failing to Report Secretary's Death
description: Dr. Geoffrey Richstone, a New York internist and cardiologist who insured his secretary's life for $100,000 shortly before she died of amphetamine poisoning, was convicted yesterday of fsiling to report a death and of tampering with a witness.

title: H.E.W. Asks Delay of Hospitals Antitrust Exemption
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has asked the Justice Department to defer granting of an antitrust exemption to the nation's hospitals for their voluntary effort to hold down costs on the ground that the effort may have an adverse effect on health services.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WKCR. Christmas Oratio, Schutz; 12 Noels for Organ, DaquuL

title: U.A.W. CHIEF REPORTS FLEXIBILITY ON WAGES
description: Unions are willing to show restraint in their wage demands despite their leaders expressed resistance to formal guidebecause ?? to ??low inflation will mean wage an prIce controls, Douglas Fraser, mesident of the united Automobile workers said yesterday.

title: BELGIAN PARATROOPS FLY OUT OF KOLINEZI
description: KOLVVEZI, Zaire, May 22Belgian paratroopers flew out of this battered coppermining town today, leaving it under the control of French Foreign Legionnaires and Zairian Government troops.

title: Gala Begins Drive to Aid Women In Politics
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Art and politics and a balmy summer's eve mixed at a photographic preview in the home of Joan Mondale this evening to raise the profile and, perhaps, the coffers of the fouryearold Women's Campaign Fund.

title: Piano: Kazuko Hayami
description: KAZUKO HAYAMI, a young Japaneseborn pianist who has appeared in New York several times in recent years, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night. The centerpiece of her program was Schumann's Fantasia in C (Op. 17).

title: Keeping Pesticides Under Control
description: Agricultural and chemical interests are pushing hard to give the states major authority to determine which pesticides csn be used within their boundaries. They have persuaded the House of Representatives to approve a bill that would eliminate Federal supervision of state pesticide registrations, and the issue will he taken up shortly by a HouseSenate conference committee. It is the only major issue remaining unresolved in an otherwise commendable bill to streamline the cumbersome pesticide regulatory process that has resulted in a logjam of unreviewed products. The proposal to pass power to the states should be rejected; it would undermine the Federal effort to protect the public against harmful chemicals.

title: A Stiff Challenge
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., May 22 (AP)A young state senator in Kentucky's Sixth District is challenging a threeterm Congressman for the Democratic nomination to a seat in the House of Representatives in voting tomorrow. Representative John B. Breckinridge, 64 years old, is the only incumbent facing a stiff challengea contest with Tom Easterly, 38. Mary Louise Foust is unopposed in the Republican primary.

title: Ira Braus in Debut on Piano
description: IRA BRAUS, who made his official New York debut Saturday afternoon at Town Hall, is one of those pianists who sometimes makes up in spirit and general musicality what he lacks in really polished commanding technique. As a technician, Mr. Braus is simply not about to challenge the great pianists of the day. Complex passages expose him to an undue number of bloopers, and even when he's hitting the notes it isn't always with the control one would prefer.

title: Britain Offers Workers A Voice in Management
description: LONDON, May 23The Labor Government, retreating from radical prOposals made 16 months ago by a special committee, put forward its own longdelayed plan today to give British workers a voice in how their companies are run.

title: Texas Treatment
description: Although the authentic Texas barbecue can be duplicated only in a pit oven dug into the earth, or in one of the gigantic ovens used in the smokehouses, it can be approximated, outdoors, in the drumshaped smokebarbecue grill, the Cook n Cajun, available in the barbecue departments of all Abraham & Straus stores on Long Island and in New Jersey, as well as in the Brooklyn annex at Hoyt & Livingston Streets. The price is $50.00 for the single, $65.00 for the double, which is a better choice. Extra hickory chips are $1.29 for a box that holds about three pounds.

title: TV Security Lens In Atlantic City Can Pick Out Dot On Snake Eyes

title: The Absent Host
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23Every year the leaders of the nations gather here to deplore the spectacular rise in the worldwide expenditure on military weapons, but every year they increase their military budgets and contribute to the very thing they deplore.

title: Music: Black Symphony
description: WE can do jazz, and that's great. We can do spirituals; that's greater, maybe the greatest. We can also do the classics. all we A ant is a chance to prove it. Tha statement was made by the Rev Leon H. Sullivan in remarks during the debut concert of the National AfroAmerican Philharmonic Orchestra in the Philadelphia Academy of Music on Monday night. The ensemble was believed to be the first of its kinda fullsized symphony of qualified black instrumentalists playing in a major concert hall.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Supreme Court ruled that safety inspectors from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration could not make spot searches of facilities without a warrant. But the majority suggested alternate procedures that indicate the inspections program will not change much. [Page A1]. Eula Bingham, head of the agency, said that, if employers are not forthcoming, we will serve warrants automatically. [D1.]

title: Personal Health
description: IN the first century A.D., the Roman naturalist Pliny described Menstruating women as capable of turning milk and wine sour, ruining crops, killing bees, rusting iron and driving dogs mad. In Leviticus the menstruating woman is proclaimed unclean and anyone who touches her or anything she touches also becomes unclean. Accordingly, Orthodox Jewish women are not to engage in sexual intercourse during their menses, nor for seven days thereafter, nor until undergoing a cleansing ritual bath.

title: Deep in the Heart of Barbecue Country
description: SOME eaters specialize; others play the field. Purists with onetrack palates roam the world forever on the lookout for the ultimate in French haute cuisine or, perhaps in a pinch, for the more gussiedup specialties of Italy or China, by which is meant, of course, north Italy and north China and never, please God, the southern food of either.

title: DISARMAMENT TALKS GET STARTED AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23  The General Assembly opened a special fiveweek session on disarmament today as some diplomats privately voiced uncertainty about the commitment of the United States and the Soviet Union to the undertaking.

title: ALBANY WILL SUBMIT CONTROLBOARD BILL
description: ALBANY, May 23  After more than a week of almost steady negotiations, aides to the Republican and Democratic leaders of the Legislature agreed today to submit a bill to their members etemcding the use of the Emergency Financial Control Board for up to 30 yearscontingent upon the granting of longterm loan guarantees by the Federal Government.

4 ARE FOUND SLAIN AT OZONE PARK HOUSE
description: The dismembered bodies of a Queens woman and a neighborhood auto mechanic were found stuffed into garbage cans behind the woman's Ozone Park house late yesterday afternoon, and two Of the woman's three sons were found bludgeoned to death under their beds.

title: Dwindling Faith in the Press
description: The American press has changed dramatically in character and structure since the First Amendment was adopted, and public attitudes toward the press have changed along with it.

description: WASHINGTON, May 23  House energy conferees finally agreed 13 to natural gas bill today, voting 13 to 12 to support a plan that would lift price controls on new supplies in 1985.

description: Following aie the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday. May 15, to Sunday. May 21), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: A's Winkles Steps Down
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 23 (UPI) Bobby Winkles resigned today in the middle of his second year as manager of Oakland, with the surprising A's leading the American League's Western Division.

title: COMMODITIES Gold Sale Spurs Rise In Metals Futures
description: Prices of precious metals futures shot forward late yesterday after the results of the Government's auction of 300.000 ounces of gold bullion became widely known. Although the official prices were not made public yesterday, it was known that several Swiss banks had bid roughly $180 an ounce, slightly above the market level at the time of the auction.

title: AUBREY RAY FITCH, 94, WORLD WAR II ADMIRAL
description: NEW CASTLE, Me., May 23  Adm. Aubrey Ray Fitch, U.S.N., retired, died yesterday in his home here. He was 94 years old.

title: Court Bars Tree Removal
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI., May 23 (AP)  Acting in response to West Bay Shore residents, Charles Thom, a New York State Supreme Court justice, has signed an order prohibiting sewer workers from cutting down any more trees along the Montauk Highway pending a hearing next Monday. The trees were being removed as part of the Southwest Sewer District project covering the towns of Islip and Babylon.

title: Orioles Top Tigers, 20, On 2Hitter
description: Even though Detroit is a pennant contender this year and Baltimore is trying to stay out of the cellar, the Tigers still have trouble winning in Memorial Stadium, as last night's 20 loss to the Orioles showed again.

title: Notes on People
description: IRVING BERLIN, who celebrated his 90th birthday on May II, is scheduled to receive a belated gift June 4 in the Antoinette Perry Awards ceremonies at the Shubert Theater. He has been chosen to receive the Lawrence Langner Award for distinguished lifetime achievement in the American theater, the League of New York Theatres and Producers announced yesterday. The composer's citation will read,His songs are a proud and permanent expression of the buoyancy and optimism of our American heritage. Bob Hope is to be on hand to present the award, but a spokesman for the league said that because of Mr. Berlin's age, it was uncertain whether he would accept the honor in person.

title: Alexandra Buck Hursh Wed To Douglas Eugene Wilson
description: Alexandra Buck Hursh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Devers Hursh of Darien, Conn., was married in Tucson, Ariz., yesterday to Douglas Eugene Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Delbert Eugene Wilson of Rockford, Ill. The Rev. Robert Tominga performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of SS. Peter and Paul.

title: Real Estate
description: WHAT is a public amenity? Is it open space in plazas, and seating areas and street furniture? Or sculpture, fountains and plantings? Or enclosed pedestrian arcades, atriums or gallerias? or the retention of theaters and landmarks in new developments, or the contribution of funds for civic improvements? Or projects that mix offices, apartments and stores to enliven dead neighborhoods?

description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 23  Federal and state civilrights officials today denounced what they called the failure of the city's master plan to address the needs of blacks, Hispanics, other minority residents and senior citizens, particularly in housing.

description: Thurman Munson observed his selection as baseball father of the year by lashing three hits and driving in two runs last night, but several other Yankee fathers celebrated, too, in a 101 rout of the Cleveland Indians.

But three weeks ago, in a peculiar and backward step, the House voted to delete prisons.

(Page) Manning, a son Edward T., two grandchildren, brother Richard V. of West Bloomfield Michigan & a sister, Mrs. E. K. (Mary) Wilcox of Chatham New Jersey. The court said there was a need for development of a record before a decision could he made on using the 2.2acre Pit near Mio, designed to hold up to 1,500 animals contaminated with the chemical fire retardant CBB

description: New York 's Mitchell??ama housing developments, publiclyaided projects for moderateincome families, are in deep financial trouble. Costs have risen spectacularly; rents have been rising to cover them; tenants have been protesting; and the soundness of the government mortgages is imperiled. After months of study, Governor Carey has produced a rescue plan. Several state senators say it is too lavish. Several Assemblymen say it is too stingy. We think it 's just about right.

description: THE socalled feminist revolution has transformed the consciousness of American men more dramatically more decisivelyand perhaps more dangerouslythan the consciousness of women. This is Natalie Gittelson's conclusion after talking to men all over the country, and she is a very good listener indeed, whose only polemical thrusts are directed against in the mess in which both sexes have bedded down.
