title: Advertising Mennen Turns to Women
description: NEXT month the Mennen Company, maketers of men's and children's ??tries and treatment products, will begin a national advertising campaign for its first products for adult females.

title: Free Light Bulb Program in Detroit Switched Off
description: DETROIT, May 25You know, it's a good thing, somebody's going to come along and mess it up, Ray Potter, a sales trainee, said with the fine cynicism of modern man.

title: Oral Roberts Hospital Gets Construction GoAhead
description: TULSA, Okla., May 25A District Court judge refused today to halt construction of a controversial hospital that Oral Roberts, the evangelist and faith healer, has envisioned as the centerpiece of his $100 million City of Faith medical complex on the campus of Oral Roberts University here.

title: Korean Airline Will Get U.S. Jets Through Japan
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 25Korean Air Lines said today that, as part of a major expansion, it plPnned to lease $120 million in American airraft two Boeing 747's and a DC10from Japan.

title: Yankees, With Tidrow, Stop Indians, 93
description: For the second time in two games and the seventh time this season, the New York Yankees got a completegame pitching performance from its staff. And for the second game in a row, lusty hotting support made it easier to go the route.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Ballet: 2 New Dancers
description: AMERICAN ballet theater had two new dancers again in George Balanchine's Theme and Variations Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: By Skin Or By Sex
description: In the real world of the marketplace, are women socioeconomically disadvantaged just because they're women?

title: Strauss Warns Steel Industry
description: DALLAS, May 25 (UPI)Robert S. Strauss, the White House's inflation counselor, said today that threatened steel industry price rises would he opposed by the Administration because they would he inflationary.

title: Boxcars Ordered By Southern Pacific
description: The Southern Pacific Railroad chairman, Benjamin F. Biaggini, said yesterday that his company is placing orders for 5,000 new boxcars at a cost of $180 million for delivery in 1979. Mr. Biaggini said that the orders constitute a record new equipment program for the railroad.

title: Vance and Gromyko Resume Talks on Strategic Arms
description: Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance opened a new round of talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union yesterday in an effort to resolve at least some of the remaining major obstacles to a new accord limiting strategic arms. But President Carter warned that. Soviet actions could imperil Senate approval of such a pact.

title: Marshall Field Stand Defended by Arena
description: Angelo R. Arena, chairman and chief executive of Marshall Field & Company, yesterday defended the efforts of management in opposing a recent, unsuccessful takeover bid by Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.

title: DOWDY ATLANTIC CITY AWAITING A FACE LIFT
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 25This faded pleasure haven by the sea was braced today for the start of legalized casino gambling, an ambitious experiment that is supposed to revive a town that has been dying for decades and provide New Jersey with new revenues.

title: Angels 6, White Sox 0
description: ANAHEIM. Calif., May 25 (AP)Frank Tanana tossed a fourhitter to become the major leagues first eightgame winner and the California Angels remained in first place in the American I eague West with a 60 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

title: Notables Open Oral History Venture
description: An extraordinary gathering of scholarsand people who expect their lives to be of interest to scholarsyesterday celebrated the 30th anniversary of Columbia University's oral history project and the start of a cooperative venture between the project and the Dictionary of American Biography.

title: Business Resisting U.S. On JobBias Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Max 25The Carter Administration is waging a determined campaign to eliminate employment discrimination in companies doing business with the Federal Government, and the response from business is growing increasingly militant.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday inadvertently omitted the names of the radio stations in the New York area that are broadcasting the new series Mobil Showcase Presents the Best of BBC on Tuesdays at 9:05 P.M. The station are WQXR and WQXRFM.

title: Deaths
description: OLTARSHRose. Devoted mother of Rhoda Jaffe and Helen Spitzer, loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services Friday 1PM Boulevard Parkway Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: To the moderate surprise of Wall Street's money market economists, the Federal Reserve yesterday reported that the nation's basic money supplychecking account balances and curren; cydeclined slightly in the week ended May 21. As a result. they reasoned that the central hank would most likely not push shortterm interest rates any higher, at least until its policy meeting in mid June.

title: Deaths
description: KRULEWITCHMelvin L. The Officers of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign note with profound sorrow the passing of a distinguished Philanthropist and communal leader, who served on the Boards of both U.J.A. and Federation. He was long active in efforts to aid the needy and endangered in Israel, elsewhere overseas and here in New York and to provide for religious, morale and welfare needs of American Jews in the Armed Services and in their home communities. We offer heartfelt condolences to his wife, Helen and the other members of the bereaved family.

title: ExBroker Admits Manipulation
description: A former commodities broker pleaded guilty yesterday to having participated in a plan to create millions of dollars in fraudulent tax losses by manipulating the market for crudeoil futures.

title: In Lieu of Disarmament
description: The nonaligned countries whose clamor gave rise to the present special session on disarmament of the United Nations General Assembly could not have found much comfort in Vice President Mondale's speech Wednesday. Their broad coalition was united by two overriding objectives: eliminating nuclear weapons from the world's arsenals and indicting the two nuclear superpowers for spending so much more on arms than on aid for the world's poor. Disarmament  imply ing slashing reductions  was a term the Vice President rarely used; he preferred arms control instead. His rather standard menu of proposals held out little hope that the United States would deemphasize the role of nuclear weapons and none at all for an early drop in American defense spending that might free resources for development.

title: Zaire's Quest for Security
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 25The French forces are leaving Kolwezi, some Moroccans are arriving, and Zaire is again looking beyond its borders for help in staving off impeding collapse as its own army once more seems incapable of dealing with a small group of marauders.

title: E.P.A. Action Delays Water Plan Critical to Denver Area's Growth
description: DENVER, May 25One of the largest proposed water projects in the West, one that is critical to the nature of the Denver area's future growth, took what may be a fatal tumble today on its long road to Federal approval.

title: Events and Openings
description: PIROSMANI, 71 Russian fim with English subtit'es directed by Georgy Snengelaya, at the Cinema Studio, 66th Street and Broadway.

title: DR. DAVID PALMER
description: MOLINE, Ill., May 25 (AP)Dr. David Palmer, one of the nation's leading figures in chiropractic medicine, died last night at a Moline hospital, where he was admitted May 8. The cause of death was not announced. He was 72 years old.

title: COMMODITIES
description: CHICAGO, May 25 (AP)Copper fu tures leaped to their highest levels in a year, while a flood of speculative buying in agricultural commodity markets lifted dozens of contracts in that area to peak levels.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE business world was thrown into a quandary in recent days when three of its giantsthe General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Ccmpany and the American Telephone and Telegraph Ccanpany  suddenly acceded to a White House request to place a lid on executive salary increases this year. Just two weeks ago at the quarterly meeting of the Business Council in Hot Springs, Va., it was obvious that sentiment was running strongly against support for that aspect of the Administration's antiinflation game plan.

title: Auctions
description: THE 19th century financial barons and preWorld War II industrialists hung their Gobelins and Gothic tapestries from the ratters of their pseudo Norman and Tudorstyle American castles. But from the 1940's to the 1970's, tapestries were definitely out of style, and weavingwatchers attending auction sales were virtually idle.

title: Canadiens Win, 41, and Take 3d Straight Stanley Cup
description: BOSTON, May 25Neither the tenacious Boston Bruins, the cozy Boston Garden rink, 14,602 mostly hostile fans nor the coaching of Boston's Don Cherry could prevent the Montreal Canadiens tonight from capturing the Stanley Cup for the third consecutive time.

title: Stage: Macbeth At Long Wharf

title: Panatta, Borg, Miss Newberry Gain in Rome

title: Dance: Aileen Passloff Returns After Six Years
description: IT had been more than six years since Aileen Passloff performed in New York. Her program of new dances at the Theater of the Open Eye on Wednesday was worth the wait. This was a gracious and happy evening of dance, one that looked both to the past and future. Miss Passloff worked closely with the late James Waring and four solos were dedicated to the choreographer, teacher and friend. Set to piano music by Debussy, Beethoven, Bartok and Granados, these fragmentary dances evoked Mr. Waring's Ivr:cal exoticism. But they bore an unmistakable stamp of their own. Footsteps in !he Snow traces simple paths across the stage. In ...With the Moon and He Dreams of Small Battles, lightdesigned here by Robert Seder,as a mot vating agent and Miss Passloff responded and interacted with it almost as to a dance partner.

title: David Woods Merriman Weds Virginia Anderson
description: Virginia Anderson, daughter of Capt. Norman Oliver Anderson, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Anderson of Jacksonville, Fla., was married in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday to David Woods Merriman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Richmond Merriman of Providence and Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony.

description: BOSTON, May 25 (AP)Senator Edward W. Brooke has admitted making false statements in a sworn deposition regarding $49,000 in personal loans from a major liquor distributor, The Boston Globe reported today, reportedly in order to increase his liabilities.

description: DENVER, May 25One of the largest proposed water projects in the West, one that is critical to the nature of the Denver area's future growth, took what may be a fatal tumble today on its long road to Federal approval.

title: KOCH AND CITY UNIONS IN ACCORD ON CURBING CONTROL BOARD ROLE
description: ALBANY, May 25Mayor Koch and leaders of New York City's municipal unions reached an agreement early today to curtail the power of the Emergency Financial Control Board over laborcontract awards granted by arbitrators or impasse panels.. Their accord broke a bitter deadlock, and the Legislature immediately began moving to approve New York City's longawaited fiscal legislation by the end of this week.

title: Japanese Screenery
description: THERE is nothing in Western art quite comparable to the Japanese screen, which is at once a movable architectural component, serving a variety of practical functions, and an exalted form of pictorial art, admired for its purely esthetic qualities. In our culture, we tend to be supicious of efforts to combine these very different purposes. But traditionally, the Japanese have ordered these things differently, triumphantly uniting what the Western mind keeps separate, and we are given a marvelous opportunity to see some rare examples of this art in the exhibition called Genre Screens from the Suntory Museum of Art, which opened this week at the Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street (through July 9.)

title: Shero and Flyers To Discuss Status
description: Fred Shero, who announced his resignation last Monday as coach of the Philadelphia Flyers and is being sought by the New York Rangers, will meet with the Flyers president, Ed Snider, late next week.

title: Arafat and P.L.O. Aides Agree to Keep Guerrillas Out of Southern Lebanon
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, May 25 (AP)Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and his top aides have pledged to end the presence of armed guerrillas in southern Lebanon, to withdraw nonPalestinian volunteers from the area and to cooperate with United Nations peacekeeping forces.

title: Taste of Victory Eludes Park Again
description: BOSTON, May 25Brad Park leaned painfully aginst a wall in the Boston dressing room after the Bruins had lost the sixth and decisive game of the National Hockey League championship series to the Mcntreal Canadiens tonight. He was drinking soda out of a paper cup. Victory champagne has never been popped for him in 10 professional seasons.

title: ChristianJewish Unit Elects Head
description: Dr. David Hyatt, the president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, was recently elected president of the International Council of Christians and Jews at organization's 25th annual meeting in Vienna.

title: Chateau Lafite, at $18,000, Wins the Day
description: ATLANTA, May 25  A pair of promoters with opposing missions  one planning a benefit dinner for leukemiastricken children, the other hoping to publicize his nightclub near Detroit  bid a jeroboam of Chateau Lafite 1864 up to $18,000 today, making the bottle the single most expensive in the world.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday inadvertently omitted the names of the radio stations in the New York area that are broadcasting the new series Mobil Showcase Presents the Best of BBC on Tuesdays at 9:05 P.M. The stations are WQXR and WQXRFM.

title: Kennecott Changes Its Pricing System
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation informed customers yesterday that it would no longer set its prices based on the copper industry's producer price but would use the closing monthly prices for copper on the New York Commodity Exchange instead.

title: Pentagon Picks Canter Agency
description: The Department of Defense, which since the end of the draft has become one of the nation's leading advertisers, has for the first time retained the services of an outside management consulting company to (valuate its SICO million recruitment advertising function.

title: Colleagues Mourn a Scientist Who Saved Thousands
description: Jay Lehman had the incisive mind of a superb scientist, and many fellow scien tists are here to pay him tribute. But Jay Lehman had the heart of a physician. That's why he chose tropical medicine as his discipline.

title: Police End SickOut Campaign
description: WICHITA, Kan., May 25 (AP)A full complement of police officers returned to work today in this southeastern Kansas city after more than 140 officers failed to report yesterday in a campaign for higher pay. The campaign began early yesterday, when about 50 officers called in sick with various ailments. About 60 officers on the second shift said they were ill, and only four of 36 reported for the rollcall at midnight. Police officials contended that the sick calls resulted from an impasse in salary negotia tions.

title: Nazi Chief Sets Conditions to Cancel Stokie March
description: CHICAGO, May 25Frank Collin, the Nazi leader, has offered to cancel a controversial march through the predominantly Jewish suburb of Skokie, scheduled for June 25, if state and local officials kill legislation aimed at banning the march and if the Chicago Park District eliminates insurance requirements for the demonstration.

title: Israeli Court Halts a Settlement On Arab Land Pending an Appeal
description: JERUSALEM, May 25The Israeli Supreme Court today ordered a temporary suspension of work on a new Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, giving the court time to consider an appeal by a group of West Bank Arabs who contend that some of their land was illegally expropriated by the Israeli military.

title: Imperial Chemical Profits Down 9%
description: Imperial Chemical Industries. Britain's giant chemical producer, reported firstquarter net income of $116 million, or 21 cents a share, down 9 percent from $127 million, or 23 cents a share, for the 1977 quarter.

title: New Yorkers' House Poll Finds Many for Loan Bill
description: WASHINGTON May 25New York State Representatives, in a memberbymember canvass of the House, reported today that they had already found close to a majority in favor of or leaning toward approval of the $2 billion New York City loanassistance bill.

title: Pop: Billy Eckstine
description: AFTER 30 years as a popular ballad singer, and another decade before that singing with bands, Billy Eckstine has arrived at a very happy balance between experience and polish on one hand, and an easy disarming relationship with his listeners on the other. At the Playboy Club, 5 East 59th Street, where he is appearing through June 3, Mr. Eckstine makes a point of keeping things in balanceold songs and new songs, heavy songs and light songs, things he can do with absolute assurance and at least one thing that is so chancy that it can make a listener nervous.

title: Jazz From Japan
description: Japan, where American jazz musicians are received with a warmth and enthusiasm that is rarely matched in other parts of the world, will receive an American acknowledgement of its own jazz musicians. Barbara's, a club at Thompson and West Third Streets in Greenwich Village, will offer a threeweek Japanese Jazz Festival starting tonight and continuing on the two following Fridays and Saturdays.

title: Big Chicago Bank Lifts Prime to 8%
description: Chicago's largest commercial bank raised its lending rate to big, business benowers yesterday to 8 percent from 8 percent.

title: At Home, in Mohair, Fleece and Satin
description: When Catherine di Montezemolo was living in Italy, she rediscovered an oldfashioned idea: wrapping a woolly shawl around her shoulders when reading in bed. It's one of the charming touches incorporated into the sleepwear line she's just introduced.

title: Carter Plan for Inner City Jobs Is Found Giving Hope to Experts
description: Even as inflation commands a larger and larger share of public attention and concern, Labor Department officials and city administrators continue to worry about the highly Volatile problem of inner city unemployment. Government programs designed to crack that problem have continually bumped against two fundamental issues, according to manpower specialists. The first of those issues, evident since the advent of large Federal manpower programs in the 60's, is how to match the skills being provided by Government  financed training programs to jobs in the private economy. The second problem, of more recent vintage, is what happens to people employed under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act after their 12 or 18 months of subsidized employment expires.

title: News Voids Parts Of Guild Contract; Union Quits Talks
description: The Daily News formally terminated key provisions of its labor agreement with the Newspaper Guild yesterday afternoon, and the guild, which represents 1,400 editorial and commercial employees, promptly broke off contract negotiations and announced that its leaders would meet tonight to seek a strike deadline against the paper.

title: Hot and Cold
description: For the past 127 years, The New York Times's type has been hot, set like this paragraph, with each letter summoned to align itself beside the next until a whole line of words could be cast in molten lead. At the direction of a linotypist, the letters danced into place with the precision of the Rockettes, but to the discerning eye they were always individualists. Look closely and you can see one tilting left or right, or a wounded one with a nicked shoulder, or a drunken one refusing to toe the mark. This morning we say farewell on this page and the page opposite to these hot characters that so often seemed to have the printer's devil in them. Within a month they'll be gone from the rest of the paper as well.

title: U.S. Patents Chief Lauds Great Inventors
description: The whole history of our country has been affected by the great inventors, said Donald Banner; we live in an ambience in which these great minds have placed us. Mr. Banner can he excused his brief light of rhetoriche had just been approved by the Senate as the country's newest Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks. I've spent some 30 years of my life in this field, he said, w This is the culmination or my life's work.

title: Stricter Laws Sought As Debtors Continue To Be Harassed
description: Several months after he lost his job and stopped making payments on a color television set and a loan from a finance company, a 37yearold security guard and laborer came home one day to find a handwritten unsigned note pasted to the door of his Harlem apartment.

title: Man Held in Mother's Death
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 25 (Ap)Boris Pawlak, a 32yearold unemployed Washington Township man charged with beating his 51yearold mother to death, is being held in the Bergen County Jail here in lieu of $150,000 bail. Mr. Pawlak, who had been hospitalized for psychiatic problems at Bergen Pines Hospital, was arraigned yesterday in Bergen County Superior Court. The suspect was arrested shortly after midnight yesterday near the Hackensack Golf Club in Emerson, the police said.

description: BALTIMORE, May 25 (UPI)  Lee May lined a gamewinning home run in the eighth inning and Scott McGregor pitched his third straight complete gam etonight in a 21 victory by the Baltimore Orioles over the Detroit Tigers.

description: I learned to race on donkeys when I was a little boy, said Ruben A. Hernandcz, the 20yearold Puerto Rican jockey, yesterday after bringing home Len Rogozin's $6.40for$2 Doubt in Belmont Park's third race. All the kids back home were racing donkeys.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said that he would oppose any further legislative restrictions on his ability to provide economic and military assistance to friendly and nonaligned nations. He said that countries such as Zambia, Tanzania and even Mozambique might otherwise turn to the Soviet Union in crisis. The United States, Mr. Carter said, should be in a position to offer them a democratic friend rather than a totalitarian friend. [Page Al, Col. 6.]

title: In Ethiopia, Talk of Rift With Cuba
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 25The Cuban Ambassador and counselor in Ethiopia have not been seen in Addis Ababa for nearly two weeks, leading to speculation among Western diplomats that they have been asked to leave because of political activities.

title: Peters Valley Craftsmen Present an Open House
description: The Peters Valley craftsmen of Layton, N. J., whose ranks also include craftswomen, will open their studios to interested visitors this weekend through July 3. Textile, jewelry, wood and ceramic crafts, as well as blacksmithing, will be explained from 1 to 4 P.M. at the workshops of the 13 artisans. A gallery and store exhibition their handiwork will ba open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The studios, gallery and I store are open Tuesday through Sunday; closed Monday. Information: (201) 9485202.

description: WASHINGTON, May 25In the first three months of this year, the country's railroads had their heaviest cumulative losses ever for one quarter, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

title: Salomon to Enter PaperRate War
description: A ratecutting war in commercial paper is heating up. Salomon Brothers, it was learned yesterday, quietly let its customers know last week that it would be cutting rates on commercial paper as of July 1, following the lead of Goldman, Sachs & Company and undercutting many of the rates that firm had set.

title: Brando, Dean and Clift, the Young Mavericks
description: Nowadays, you can see them on the screen without actually seeing them on the screen. Montgomerry Clift plays a major part in Shampoo, even if it's Warren Beatty who does the hesiLating, the barely concealed calculating, and the indiscriminately seductive swaggering redolent of a deep sexual confusion. James Dean is a principal figure in Easy Rider, even if his nature is split between the stoical cool of Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper's anguish and frustration. Marlon Brando may have died in the first part of The Godfather, but he would be alive and well in The Godfather, Part II, in the performances of Robert De Niro and Al Pacino, even if the two younger actors weren't, respectively, imitating him, and playing his son. The Jack Nicholson of One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest reflects Clift in his careful watchfulness, Brando in his sensual mockery, and Dean in his nameless rage.

description: WASHINGTON, May 25President Carter's comments today that Congress has restricted his authority to assist foreign nations ceme in the aftermath of many curbs of Presidential aid powers over the last 5 years.

description: ATLANTA, May 25 (AP)Dave Eichelberger birdied five of his last six holes for a 10underpar 62the lowest round of the year on the pro golf tour and took a twoshot lead today in the first round of the $200,000 Atlanta Classic.

title: Rain Drenches Rutgers Commencement
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 25Rain fell on 9,000 graduates at Rutgers University's 212th commencement exercise this morning, transforming the traditional atmosphere of academic dignity and decorum into a scene of soggy confusion and chagrin.

title: Around the Nation
description: DALLAS, May 25The Dallas Independent School District has voted to appeal to the United States Supreme Court a ruling April 21 by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit that overturned the district's twoyearold desegregation plan.

description: The nation's retailers, faced with a steady rise in shoplifting, employee theft and robberies, are installing increasingly sophisticated and expensive surveillance systems.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 25  Zhigniew Brzezinski, the President's adviser on national security, looking fit after a fiveday tour of China, Japan and South Korea, left here today for Washington.

title: Schlitz Studies Personnel Cuts
description: The Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company announced it was considering reducing its work force because of declining beer sales.

title: Halpern Shot, a Week After His Boxing Comeback
description: Robert (Bobby) Halpern, a 45yearold exconvict and boxer who was knocked out in a comeback bout at Madison Square Garden last week, was shot and critically injured by two men in a Bronx store yesterday, according to the police.

title: For Memorial Day, The Cuts in Service Depend on Location
description: If you live and work in New Jersey or Connecticut, don't worry about when Memorial Day is. It's Monday, as it is in most of the United States.

title: At the Movies
description: CANNES, FRANCE FROM an attach case Alexander Salkind took a manila folder. From the folder he removed a photograph. Handing it to a visitor, he asked, with a certain dramatic inflection, Can you guess who this is? The photograph showed a darkhaired boy and a towering figure of a man. The boy is gazing up at him, smiling. The man is wearing a closefitting tunic with puffed sleeves and a lace collar. He has flaring white mustaches and a white gostee. His eyes, deepset and piercing above a highbridged nose, are focused somewhere far away.

title: Sale of Airbus Under Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Reuters)The International Trade Commission is conducting a preliminary investigation of the purchase by Eastern Air Lines of 23 Europeanmade A300 Airbuses, a commission spokesman said today, to determine whether unfair import practices were involved in the $778 million order.

title: Article 2 -- No Title

description: WASHINGTON, May 25  President Carter, overriding the objections of senior military officers and atomic energy officials, has decided to ask the Soviet Union for a temporary ban on almost all testing of nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: EARNINGS
description: Pressure on margins in the petroleum and agricultural chemicals businesses held down profits of Esmark Inc. in the second quarter and halfyear ended April 29, the company said yesterday. Earnings dipped by 3 and 4.4 percent, respectively.

title: Ousted Employee Is Charged in Fire That Killed 2 and Forced 400 to Flee
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., May 25A 19yearold stockboy dismissed from his job at a swmmingpool supply store yesterday was arrested today and charged with setting a predawn fire that destroyed the store, killed two volunteer firemen and drove 400 people from nearby homes amid clouds of toxic chlorine gas from storestocked chemicals.

title: Sikora Is a Surprise Out of Nowhere
description: LANDOVER, Md., may 25Illinois Wesleyan is far from a household name in coll.i,ge basketball, The Bloomington (Ill.) school is a member of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics and has a student population of 1.700, with 800 of it male. Schools like it rarely produce firstround draft picks for National Basketball Association teams. But once in a while, a Jack Sikma arrives.

title: Elinor Brickell Is Bride Of Stephen Richard Cohen
description: The marriage of Elinor Jane Brickell to Stephen Richard Cohen of New York and Bridgehampton, L. I., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Wohl, parents of the bride, in Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbis Bernard Mandelhaum and Melvin Keiffor performed the ceremony.

title: Beaths
description: KRULEWITCHMelvin L. The Officers of the United Jewish AppealFederation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign note with profound sorrow the passing of a distinguished philanthropist and communal leader, who served on the Boards of both U.J.A. and Federation. He was long active in efforts to aid the needy and endangered in Israel, elsewhere overseas and here in New York and to provide for religious, morale and welfare needs of American Jews in the Armed Services and in their home communities. We offer heartfelt condolences to his wife, Helen and the other members of the bereaved family.

title: Relationship Between Carter and Meany Reported Increasingly Cool
description: WASHINGTON. May 21  President Carter and President George Meany of the A.F.L.C.I.O., two powerful men who sometimes need each other, do not seem to have been hitting it off lately.

title: Old BMT Cars Running On the Nostalgia Line
description: Completely restored and repainted. the 67footlong standard BMT cars of 1915 are back on the track with a new namethe Nostalgia Train. And starting this weekend, the Transit Authority is offering trips Saturday and Sunday in these cars, once the pride of the BMT.

title: South Africa's Migrants Shuttle From Rural Poverty to Urban Squalor
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 25For most of the last 13 years, home for Phineas Kunene has been the Wolhuter Native Men's Hostel, dingy redbrick barracks in an area of garages and scrapiron merchants about a mile from this city's downtown skyscrapers.

title: Ousted Employee Charged. With Setting L.I Blaze That Killed 2 Firemen
description: BETHPAGE, L.I,, May 25A 19yearold stockboy dismissed from his job at a swimmingpool supply store yesterday was arrested today and charged with setting a predawn fire that destroyed the store, killed two volunteer firemen and drove 400 people from nearby homes amid clouds of toxic chlorine gas from storestocked chemicals.

title: Art: Morgan Offers FirstRate Fakes
description: IT is the function of the art museum to show us authentic works of art of superior esthetic quality. But from time to time it may also devolve upon a museum to show us something elseviz., inauthentic works of art of superior esthetic quality. This is what the Pierpont Morgan Library has now brought us in the remarkable exhibition of The Spanish Forger. It is a show that pays elaborate respect to an activity it is usually in the interest of museums and art historians to deplorethe wholesale production of persuasive artistic forgeries. And there can be no question that the socalled Spanish Forger earns our respect. He (they?) was certainly possessed of a certain genius..

title: Petrolane to Buy Two Denver Firms
description: Petrolane Inc., a distributor of liquefied petroleum gas, said it had agreed to acquire two Denver concerns, the Signal Drilling Company and Signal Oil Field Services Inc. for about 675.000 shares of Petrolane common stock worth about $23 million.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Art: Katzen's Monumental Sculptures
description: LIKE the architecture it often embellishes, monumental sculpture reflects the vision of its patrons more faithfully than do the other artsor perhaps the image is easier to see. Either way, the medium celebrates industrialism as effectively as it once enhanced religion and war. That it appears to do so with less gusto could be due to the conflict between the sculptor as autonomous creator and the sculptor looking to earn a living.

title: The Games People Will Play at Atlantic Citya Primer
description: ATLANTIC CITY Although there is as yet no Strip here, no cluster of spectacular Arabianmotif casinos, Atlantic City is, at least in terms of the games it will begin playing this weekend, Las Vegas East.

title: POLL SHOWS MORE IN U.S. OPPOSED TO NEUTRON BOMB
description: A major shift in American attitudes toward the production of the controversial neutron bomb has occurred within the last year, according to a. Harris poll released yesterday, United Press International repirted.

title: The U.N. Today
Business People
description: It was Lenin who first told Armand Hammer to get out of medicine and into business. Yesterday the current generation Of Soviet leaders endorsed their leader's judgment when they awarded Dr. Hammer The Order of Friendship Among Peoples in honor of his 80th birthday and of his longstanding efforts to promote SovietAmerican trade.

title: REGENTS REPLACING COMPETENCY TESTS
description: ALBANY, May 25The State Board of Regents voted today to take the first steps toward phasing in new minimumcompetency tests to replace the existing ones, which have been described by critics as ridiculously easy.

title: China Tour In Volley ball Is Spiked
description: DAYTON. Ohio, May 25 (AP)The United States men's volleyball team, accusing the Chinese of political shenanigans, canceled today its June tour of China.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen yesterday and weakened against. other foreign currencies in later trading in Europe and New York, The Associated Press reported.

title: The Pop Life
description: BUFFALO BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN'S triumphant return to live performing Tuesday night at Shea's Buffalo Theater broke a long silence. Unless one had followed the rock press closely, one might well have had no idea what had happened to him, so little was he in the news.

title: Bullets Beat Sonics, Even Series at 11
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 25  The Washington Bullets used a manypronged attack against the Seattle Supersonics tonight and came away with a 10698 victory before a capacity crowd of 19,035 at the Capital Centre.

title: Count Blinded by Village Robbers
description: A 35headold French count was blinded  possibly permanently  by caustic acid that was hurled at him by two robbers in Greenwich Village on Wednesday night, the police said.

title: Reaction on Eyeglass Ads Is Mixed
description: New York State officials, as well as optometrists and opticians themselves, yesterday expressed mixed opinions about the desirabilityand especially the local effectsof the Federal Trade Com mission's lifting the bans against the advertisement of eyeglass and contactlens prices.

title: For Children
description: SPINNING AND WEAVING DEMONSTRATION, at 12.:0 PM. on Friday, by Chris Oioenburg, daughter of the ??a??ner of Oldebrooke Soinnery in Lepanon, N. I., who will set up her s??inning wheel and loom, and demonstrale clothmaking curing the 18th century, at.. The Fraunces ?? Museum, 54 Pearl Street, Acmission, $1.50 Call 4251776,

title: Outbid Concern Gets City Contract
description: After five hours of public debate and behind  the  scenes maneuvering, the Board of Estimate yesterday awarded a $635,000 city contract for supplying lampposts to a Queens concern whose bid for the job was $2,800 higher than that of a Pennsylvania company.

title: Alabama Treasurer Is Convicted
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 25State Treasurer Melba Till Allen, a veteran Alabama politician who established an early reputation as a crusader against governmental corruption, was convicted late yesterday of using her office for personal gain.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, MAY 25, 1978

title: A BlueChip Tour of Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY AFTER a succession of fits and starts. gambling has finally arrived in Atlantic City and, even as this old resort town wonders whether its new games will become the cornerstone of an economic resurgence, the city has spruced up for its first betting weekend.

title: Broadway
description: IT is a season away, but everyone involved says it is marvelous, wonderful and a leadpipe cinch. It is Mother of Burlesque, or maybe The Mother of Burlesque. and perhaps by next season it will be called something else. Indisputably, however, it will star Carol Channing and she will wear pink tights. Miss Channing will play Lydia Thompson, who toured the country with her own troupe in the late 1800's, and who sometimes worked with a beef trust. Miss Channing will work with beef trust, too. The music and lyrics for all this are being written by Jerry Herman, while Michael Stewart and Mark Bramble are doing the book. James Nederlander is the producer.

title: Deaths
description: OLTARSHRose. Devoted mother of Rhoda Jaffe and Helen Spitzer, loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services Friday 1PM Souleyard Parkway Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said that he would oppose any further legislative restrictions on his ability to provide economic and military assistance to friendly and nonaligned nations. He said that countries such as Zambia, Tanzania and even Mozambique might otherwise turn to the Soviet Union in a crisis. The United States, Mr. Carter said, should be in a position to offer them a democratic friend rather than a totalitarian friend. [Page Al, Col. 6.]

title: Aides to Carter Say He Will Ask Full ATest Ban
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  President Carter, overriding the objections of senior military officers and atomic energy officials, has decided to ask the Soviet Union for a temporary ban on almost all testing of nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: Kirkland Foresees Defeat of Labor Bill Leading to Friction
description: HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 25The failure of Congress to pass the proposed labor revision act could cripple cooperation between organized labor and management on all fronts, Lane Kirkland, secretary treasurer and second ranking officer of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said last night

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Domestic and Foreign Affairs
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference yesterday afternoon in Chicago, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilitics of ABC News:

title: An Old Friend Finds Jimmy Hasn't Changed
description: ELMHURST, Ill., May 26 (AP)The Rev. James Wall says his old friend Jimmy Carter hasn't changed in the least since he became President. But Mr. Wall said he couldn't bring himself to call Mr. Carter Jimmy when the President was his house guest last night.

title: In Illinois, Carter Discards His Speech at 11 th Hour
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 26Reviving a technique that he used successfully in his campaign and in the early, most popular months of his Presidency, Jimmy Carter discarded a long prepared text today and for 30 minutes answered questions put to him by the Democrats and Republicans in the Illinois Legislature.

title: Brokers Take a Pounding As Their Clients Cheer
description: Two dozen gentlemen from Wall Street slipped into the locker room at the Felt Forum the other night, hung up their pinstriped and grey flannel suits and, as 4,000 clients, fellow money men and friends watched, proceeded to beat the daylights out of each other.

title: Rice Hits 16th Homer And Starts Comparisons
description: It's only the end of May, but in Boston fans are already starting to mention the name of Jim Rice in the same breath with Babe Ruth and Roger Maxis. Rice gave one more reason to start bringing up the comparisons last night by stroking his 16th home run of the season as the Red Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 63.in the fourth. Evans put the Red Sox up by 31 with a drive over the leftfield screen in the fifth.

title: Leslie Hogben Wed To Mark Hunacek
description: Leslie Hogben, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adrian Hogben of Iowa City and Ellsworth, Me., was married yesterday to Mark Hunacek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hunacek of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed in the Church Center for the United Nations by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg.

title: Aluminum Is Facing Threat
description: For two years, the aluminum industry has been able to raise prices and still hold most of its hardwon gains from such competitive materials as steel, glass and plastic. Today, however, it faces a potential market setback that could signal the beginning of a longrange growth problem for the industry.

title: Upsala College Given 271 Acres in Sussex
description: WANTAGE, May 26 (AP)  Upsala College announced today that it had been given 271 acres of farmland here valued at $1 million where it plans to build a satellite college to supplement its fouryear facility in East Orange.

title: Diplomats' Alien Servants Report Harsh Treatment
description: Sobrana Perfecta Quinones came to America expecting to earn $200 a month by working as a domestic in a foreign diplomat's home. That was more money than she thought she might ever have earned back home in Manila, and the promise of bringing along her 3yearold daughter and learning English also raised her hopes.

title: On Keeping the City the World's Financial Capital
description: A few years ago, a leading White House economist got a lot of laughs by suggesting that stockbrokers deserved some sympathy because of their poor economic condition. Comments like that are af ten surefire mirthmakers. Too bad. Especially for New York.

title: Sloane's Names New Chief
description: Herbert Raab has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the W. & J. Sloane subsidiary of the City Stores Company, effective July 1. Sloane's, based in New York, operates 45 furniture and homefurnishing stores in nine states and the District of Columbia.

title: Commodity Index
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 229.4 from 228.1 last week. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 216.9 on May 24, 1977.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, MAY 26, 1978

title: U.S. Says Soviet Snags Arms Talks By Demand on CruiseMissile Curb
description: WASHINGTON. May 26Administration officials said today that the Soviet Union had snagged the negotiations for an agreement to limit offensive nuclear weapons by demanding that the United States restrict the number of cruise missiles that could be placed aboard American bombers.

title: A Family That Alternates Suburb and Wilderness
description: CRANBURYFor most of the year Stuart and Gail Ashley lead lives much like those of their neighbors. Mr. Ashley is a consulting engineer in Somerville, and Mrs. Ashley is a a geology teacher at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. The children, Kim, 16 years old, and Todd, 12, go to school.

title: Is It More Difficult to Be a Man Today?
description: I hadn't thought of this as a hard Iife. Certainly, no man's life is as pleasant as it might be; satisfactions are sometimes fiercely fought and dearly won. But recently I've been made to reconsider.

title: Diamonds: No Frenzy, But Still No Normality
description: Back in March, Walter Hoving, chairman of Tiffany & Company, ran an advertisement warning diamond buyers that speculation was pushing up diamond prices.

title: EARNINGS
description: Higher sales and improved profit margins in the manufactured housing operations enabled Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. to report yesterday a 16.4 percent earnings gain for the fourth quarter and a 17 percent rise for the fiscal year ended April 30.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MAY 27, 1978

title: Yields Increase On U.S. Bills
description: Yields on sixmonth Treasury bills rose slightly yesterday, reaching their highest levels since December 1974. Threemonth bill rates were the highest since January.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Borg Gains Italy Semifinal
description: ROME, May 26 (AP)Topseeded Bjorn Borg, displaying impeccable tennis, routed eighthranked Harold Solomon of the United States, 62, 6I, today in the quarterfinals of the $210,000 Italian open tennis championships.

title: Neophonic Band and JazzRock
description: The New York Neophonic Orchestra is a 25piece band that has been playing regularly in New York for the last six years, although relatively few New Yorkers are aware of it. This is because its appearances have been almost exclusively in schools in the winter and in the parks in the summer. Last Wednesday and Thursday, the orchestra, which is described by its founder and director, Joel Kaye, as a concert rockjazz band with a rock  fusion rhythm section, played for the first time in a New York jazz room, Storytown, 41 East. 58th Street.

title: Bruhn Dances in Moor's Pavane
description: The American Ballet Theater gave its audience a surprise when The Moor's Pavane was added to Thursday night's program at the Metropolitan Opera House, replacing what most announcements had simply listed as Pas de Deux. Moreover, Jos Limn's choreographic retelling of Othello was performed by an allstar cast, with Erik Bruhn as Othello, Carla Fracci as Desdemona, Ivan Nagy as Iago and Sallie Wilson as Emilia.

title: Carter Takes Painful Road to Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 26It was not yet noon, but the Indiana sky was blazing when Pancho Carter limped into his garage on Gasoline Alley today already three hours behind.

title: Arlen Realty Is Expecting Major Loss
description: The Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, parent of the Korvettes department store chain, said yesterday that its writedowns would be about 5100 million for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Public Advocate Stanley C. Van Ness abarted yesterday that the Public Service Electric and Gas Company could have seved more than S70 million in construction costs at the Salem nuclearpower generating complex had effective management techniques been employed.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ASSEMBLY APPROVES CONTROL BOARD BILL FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: ALBANY, May 26The Assembly tonight approved New York City's emergency fiscal legislation.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (UPI)A panel of three Federal judges has struck down state laws allowing children to he committed to institutions for mental illness or retardation without representation by a lawyer or a proper hearing.

title: About New York
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 25Even before Dweet Menditto from Hackensack inaugurated the craps table this morning and began talking happily, then miserably, to the dice he rolled, there ?? jaded action in this town.

title: Brokers Take a Pounding As Their Clients Cheer
description: Two dozen gentlemen from Wall Street slipped into the locker room at the Felt Forum the other night, hung up their pinstriped and grey flannel suits and, as 4,000 clients, fellow money men and friends watched, proceeded to beat the daylights out of each other.

title: DR. R. GORDON GOULD
description: Dr. R. Gordon Gould, professor emeritus of medicine at the Stanford University School of Medicine and an expert on the metabolism of blood fats and proteins, died May 19 of cancer. He was 68 years old and lived in Palo Alto.

title: Council Angered by Albany Rebuff
description: Angry members of the City Council last night denounced the State Legislature for deciding not to request a homerule messageordinarily a formalityfrom the Council before enacting critical financial legislation affecting the city.

title: KOREAN EMBASSY DENIES CABLES SHOWED A PAY OFF
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)A South Korean Embassy spokesman today labeled as false any implication that a former ambassador cabled Seoul that he was distributing cash to American Congressmen.

title: CelebrityHunters, Plungers, $1 Bettors, Winners, Losers
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 26At the very moment that Governor Byrne was proclaiming the gambling casino open this morning, a young man in a leisure suit turned to a companion in the lounge bar.

title: Cannes Gets Down to Film Business
description: CANNES, France, May 24The chill, reluctant spring disappointed the usual tidal wave of beachcombers who frequent the shores near Cannes Film Festival. But the festival goers did look with favor on the new management's effort to restore a more earnest cinematic focus to the annual gathering in search of sun, fun and money in the name of international movies.

title: Northwest Rejects Pilots' Offer
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 26 (UPI)Northwest Airlines has rejected the latest contract proposal by its 1,550 striking pilots, and is was unlikely the two sides will return to the bargaining table in the near future. The Air Line Pilots Association responded by reinstating its lull list of 34 unresolved issues, which had been trimmed to seven. The rejection of the association's proposal yesterday left both sides doubtful that they could return to negotiations soon. The strike began April 29.

title: CONTROL BOARD BILL FOR NEW YORK CITY APPROVED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Saturday, May 27 The Legislature this morning approved New York City's emergency fiscal legislation, despite warnings from bank executives that they would withdraw from the city's $4.5 billion financing package unless additional safeguards are enacted to prevent the loss of powers by the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of cattle and meat futures closed mixed yesterday but mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. On the New York Commodity Exchange, copper futures prices finished unchanged from the day before. They had risen sharply on Thursday in the anticipated wake of weakened supplies resulting from the fighting in Zaire.

title: Teledyne Hits New High, But Most Stocks Lag
description: Teledyne, Wall Street's favorite conglomerate stock, continued to boom ahead to record levels yesterday, but for most of the market it was a day of sagging prices and volume.

title: Marie Wangeman Is Wed to William Sheppard
description: Marie Ellen Wangeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Wangeman of New York and Quaker Hill, Pawling, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to William Robert Sheppard, son of Group Capt. Don Ross Sheppard, Royal Australian Air Force, retired, and Mrs. Sheppard of Canberra, Australia. The Rev. Terence J. Finlay performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Abortions Rose 16% As Deaths Declined, U. S. Report Shows
description: ATLANTA, May 24 (AP)The number of legal abortions in the United States increased by 16 percent from 1975 to 1976, but the number of abortionrelated deaths of women continued to decline, the national Center for Disease Control said today.

title: SENATORS ASK PROOF THAT CUBA HAD ROLE IN INVASION OF ZAIRE
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The Senate Foreign Relations Committee asked the Administration today to produce evidence to back up President Carter's contention yesterday that Cuba had played a behindthescenes role in the recent invasion of Zaire by rebel forces based in Angola.

title: Patient Dumping By State Hospitals Charged by Pepper
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, said today that state hospitals were discharging thousands of mental patients, most of them elderly. into federally supported boarding homes that were inadequately equipped and often situated in slums. He called the practice a national scandal.

title: CONGRESS GIVEN SWAY OVER GUN PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The Treasury Department, faced with a possible loss of funds, pledged today that it would not put controversial firearms regulations into effect without specific approval from Congress. Some members of Congress out voiced suspicion that the Treasury appropriations request for fiscal 1978 contained hidden funds for the firearms proposals.

title: Astros Top Mets, 5 to 4, On Homers
description: HOUSTON, May 26The New York Mets took their act indoors tonight and, for a change, completed a game in nine innings. But their recmt magic finally eluded them when Jesus Alou and Jose Cruz hit a pair of home runs off Jerry Koosman in the Astrodome and powered the Houston Astros to a 54 victory.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Brooklyn carpenter who was paralyzed from the waist down in an accident at the World Trade Center received a $750,000 settlement of his $3 million negligence suit against contractors for the project.

title: Miss Mills Sets World 5,000 Mark
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 26Kathy Mills, a Penn State sophomore, bettered world records for three miles and 5,000 meters today, outrunning her nearest competitors by 180 yard in the Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women championships. Her time for the 5,000 was 15 minutes 35.52 seconds. Miss Mills, who won the National Collegiate crosscountry championship in November, shattered Jan Merrill's world best of 15:37.0. Miss Mills hit 15:03.9 at the threemile mark on the way to her other record.

title: Fashion in New York  It Was a Big Week for Hospitality
description: The Italians rediscovered America this week and virtually inundated it with charm, generosity and good will. Their motive was commercial, but it was glossed over with so many breakfasts, lunches and even a gala ball that everyone was overwhelmed.

title: Snepp Charge of Attempted Bribe In Vietnam Is Backed by U.S. File
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Frank W. Snepp 3d was essentially correct in his assertion that the United States tried to bribe Gen. Duong Van Minh to run for President of South Vietnam in 1971, according to a document made public today in connection with the Government's breach of contract suit against Mr. Sneoo.

title: M'LAUGHLIN IS DESIGNATED LIQUOR AGENCY CHAIRMAN
description: ALBANY, May 26  Governor Carey announced today that he planned to designate Edward J. McLaughlin as chairman of the State Liquor Authority over the objections of black and Puerto Rican legislators, who charged that the Governor had promised to appoint a black to the post.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONAn inventor with long experience in space and medial electronics will receive a patent next week for an improved method of cardiac stimulation, or pacemaker. Sheldon Thaler, a senior research associate for the ESB Technology Company in Yardley, Pa., believes his Visa pacemaker will exceed in importance any of his 20 previously patented inventions.

title: Expanded Spoleto Opens With Traviata
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., May 26 Verdi's La Traviata, last night at the Gaillard Municipal Auditorium. was the opening musical event of the 1978 Spoleto Festival. But the opening ceremony actually tnok place earlier in the day at the Cistern of the College of Charleston. Gov. James B. Edwards, Gian Carlo Menotti and Theodore Stern, president of the college, made speeches. Mario Laureti, the Mayor of Spoleto, spoke in Italian. Not to be outdone, Mayor Joseph P. Riley read a speech in Italian. Suddenly the Cistern was invaded by huge puppets, followed by members of the Phe Zulu Theater, who gave a ritual dance to drum accompaniment. Then Welcome Msomi, the leader of the South African company, addressed the audience in sonorous, impeccable Oxford English.

title: AirCargo Line to Build Newburgh Hub
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y. May 26Governor Carey and Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak today joined with the Federal Express Corporation of Memphis in announcing a plan to shift the aircargo line's eastern regional headquarters from Boston to Stewart Airport near here. The plan calls for building an aircargo hub with a potential for employing 400 to 600 people.

title: Company Earnings Reports
description: For periods en shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New YorkStock Exchange,(A) the AmericanStock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: New York Senate Approves Omnibus Anticrime Bill
description: ALBANY, May 26The Senate today unanimously approved the Republican omnibus anticrime bill, which embodies much of Governor Carey's anticrime package already passed by the Assembly but also includes the creation of a Justice Assistance Commission to monitor all aspects of New York City's criminaljustice system.

title: George Wallace Says Goodbye
description: The announced departure of Governor George Wallace of Alabama from electoral life sparks no elation: His retirement does not signal the disappearance of the resentments and fears that he came to represent. His career, which cost him so dearly, has left indelible memories  the upraised hand barring the schoolhouse door, the gibes at pointyheaded intellectuals.

title: Third Baby Travelling With Sect Dies of an Infection in Hospital
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 26 (AP) A third child who had been traveling with a religious sect has died in a hospital here after contracting a tropical disease known as infectious diarrhea.

title: Li. Man Pleads for Son Accused In Fire That Killed 2 Volunteers
description: MINEOLA, L.I., May 26I'm afraid he may commit suicide, Your Honor, George Cavagnaro said this morning as his 19yearold son was arraigned in Nassau County Court on murder and arson charges in the burning of a swimmingpool supply store and a cocktail lounge and the deaths of two volunteer firemen yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC PROMENADE, Avery Fisher Hatt, Lincoln center, 8:30.

title: Ghost Parking Lot Art Project In Connecticut to Be Dedicated
description: HAMDEN, Conn., May 26The aging Miracle Mile of this New Haven suburb has been revived in recent months by the burial of 20 cars in the parking lot of the Hamden Plaza Shopping Center on Dixwell Avenue.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: For the Dominicans The Election Is a Test of a Shaky Democracy
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 25The count in the disputed election dragged on this week, with indications that a final result will give victory to the Dominican Revolutionary Party, making Antonio Guzman, a wealthy 67yearold landowner, the next president.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, May 28

title: School Finance Issue Jeopardizes Ohio Governor's Reelection Drive
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 23If charisma alone could keep the doors of public schools in Ohio open, James Allen Rhodes, the nation's oldest Governor; would probably have little trouble this year in his bid for reelection.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
Lorser Feitelson, 80, Was Host Of Television Program on Art
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26 (AP)Lorser Feitelson, founder of the hard edge abstraction school of painting and who was host of a mid1950's television program, Feitelson on Art, died Wedneesday at the age of 80. He was born in Savannah, Ga., and came to Los Angeles in 1927. In the 1930's, he served as a supervisor of murals for art projects sponsored by the Federal Works Progress Administration.

title: Beaths
description: O'SHAUGHNESSYJohn F.: on May 25, 1978 of Seaford. Husband of the late Marie, devoted father of Mrs. Eileen Twomey, Patricia and John F. O'Shaughnessv, Jr. Dear brother of Mrs. Anna McGrath and Isabella O'Shaughnessv. Also survived by tour grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Reposing at the Charles G. Schmitt Funeral Home, 3863 Merrick Rd, Seaford. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 A.M. at St. William the Abbot R.C. Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: Federal Judge Seen as Satisfied With Desegregation in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26 (UPI)The Federal judge who ordered busing three years ago to provide a better racial balance in Louisville schools appears satisfied the program has resulted in a desegregated school system.

title: Miss Lopez Leader by Shot on 67
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 26Maybe Nancy Lopez will cool down some day so the other women on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour can catch her.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MAY 27, 1978

title: Biko Inquest to Remain Open
description: The Biko Inquest, the play about the investigation of the death of the South African black leader Stephen Biko, is to continue its run indefinitely, on a weektoweek basis, it was announced yesterday. The play, at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, was to have closed tomorrow, but demand for tickets has increased in the last few days.

title: It's G.I. Chow, and Haute Cuisine, Too
description: Suppose you were planning an elegant dinner party, and a number of caterers presented themselves and samples of their work to you for approval.

title: Notes on People
description: When he retires from the Army next week, Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, a critic a carter Admintstration policies, um not be granted disability benefits. In Washington, sources familiar with the case said yesterday that this had come as a surprise to many of General Singlaub's fellow officers, despite a tightening, in 1973, of practices that had for years allowed retiring generals and admirals with long service to collect generous disability benefits that could be translated into income tax deductions on retirement pay. General Singlaub has served for 35 years, but Army officials said he had been medically evaluated and determined ineligible for disability benefits that would have given him a substantial tax break on his $31,455 annual pension. The 56yearold General Singlaub first drew fire from the Administration for publicly criticizing the decision to withdraw ground troops from South Korea. More recently he was called to the Pentagon to explain his public criticism of President Carter's decision on the neutron warhead and of the Panama Canal treaties. Shortly afterward he announced his retirement.

title: Henderson, a Plugger, Sets Pace for Bullets
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 26The Washington Bullets are no different from most teams with an odd collection of nicknames for the players. Larry Wright is Bugeyes, Bob Dandridge Pick, Phil Walker, Gump, Greg Ballard Billiards or Pocket and Wes Unseld, Ton of Fun.

title: SENATORS ASK PROOF THAT CUBA HAD ROLE IN INVASION OF ZAIRE
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The Senate Foreign Relations Committee asked the Administration today to produce evidence to back up President Carter's contention yesterday that Cuba had played a behindthescenes role in the recent invasion of Zaire by rebel forces based in Angola.

title: Tamara Karsavina Is Dead at 93; Ballerina Was Star for Diaghilev
description: Tamara Karsavina, one of the greatest ballerinas of her geneilation, died in her sleep at the age of 93 yesterday in the London nursing home where she had lived for the past few years, Reuters reported from London.

title: 3 Troopers and 2 Fugitives Slain
description: CADDO, Okla., May 26 (UPI)Two es. caned prisoners described as thrill killers and three Oklahoma Highway Patrolmen were killed today in gunfights along the OklahonaTexas state line. A fourth officer was wounded.

title: Iraq Said to Execute 14 as Strain With Reds Grows
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26Amid signs of growing strain in Iraq's relations with the Soviet bloc, East European sources returning from Baghdad say that the Government of Iraq recently executed 14 Communists.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
Some Agreeable Surprises in Italy
description: The political consequences of the Moro kidnapping and murder have taken Italians and the world by surprise. Throughout the tragic affair, the Communists behaved in responsible fashion. On the very day of the kidnapping, March 16, they stopped arguing and voted Prime Minister Andreotti's new Government into office despite reservations about some Cabinet selections. In the ensuing weeks, they helped stiffen the Christian Democratic Cabinet against negotiations with the Red Brigades, whom they condemn for leftCommunist deviations as well as for terrorism. Most Italians agreed with this policy of nonnegotiation. Yet the country turned sharply away from the Communists last week in local elections that provided a rough sampling of Italian opinion, north and south. The Communist vote was markedly reduced while the Christian Democrats won their highest vote in two decades.

title: ROLAND KIRKBY
description: SEATTLE, May 26 (UPI)  Roland Kirkby, a former University of Washington football star, died yesterday of cancer at the age of 48. Mr. Kirkby was a member of the Husky varsity team from 1948 through 1950, and shared backfield honors with Hugh McElhenny, fullback, and Don Heinrich, quarterback. He set a school record against Kansas State in 1950 when he caught three touchdown passes.

title: SMALLER OIL SUPPLY SEEN BY SCHLESINGER
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger asserted today that the outlook for the supply of oil is bleaker than it appeared a year ago despite a slowdown in the growth of demand and the effects of improved conservation.

title: Jacqueline du Pr: Life in a New Key
description: LONDON  Seven years ago Jacqueline du Pr stopped playing the cello that had occupied her life since she was 4 years old. My hands no longer worked, she recalled, in a matteroffact manner. I simply couldn't feel the strings.

title: Mary L. Mahon Has Nuptials To Paul Guvet in St. Patrick's
description: In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, Mary Louise Mahon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis B. Mahon of Ocean City, N. J., was married to Paul Mark Guyet, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Guyet of Ramsey, N.J. Msgr. John Cassells performed the ceremony.

title: Your Money
description: WHEN the Telenet Corporation annoanced plans last week to sell 400,000 shares or common stock, it was one more sign of the speculative tone that is creeping back into the newissues market.

title: Willis Hatfield, Last Surviving Son Of Leader of the Legendary Feud
description: HUNTINGTON, W.Va., May 26 (UPI) Willis Hatfield of Olive Hill, the last surviving son of the legendary Anderson Devil Anse Hatfield of the HatfieldMcCoy feud, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 90 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday erroneously reported that the Western Electric Corporation had raised the monthly pensions of retired employees. The company should have been identified as the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

title: RICE TRADER INDICTED IN DEALING WITH PARK
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury charged today that the president of a New Jersey rice trading concern concealed his illegal use of Tongsun Park, the rice dealer, as his agent for Food for Peace sales to the South Korean Government.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The outlook for oil supplies is bleaker than a year ago, said James R. Schlesinger, the Energy Secretary, in a view contrasting with the prevailing attitude in the petroleum industry. He told a news conference that OPEC's production capacity would be somewhat lower than estimates made last year by the Central Intelligence Agency. [Page 1]

title: Husband Guilty in Rape of Wife In an Unusual Case in New Jersey
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., May 26 (UPI)A Medford Lakes, N. J., man has been convicted on charges of kidnapping and raping his estranged wife in a case that could prove to be a legal landmark in New Jersey.

title: Deaths
description: ABBOTTJoseph B. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph S. Abbott, associated with The Times from September, 1923 until retiring in 1956.

title: Carey Disputed on L.I. Pay Issue
description: MINEOLA, LI, May 26Governor Carey has criticized Nassau County for not having exhausted its rights to appeal an arbitrator's award that greatly increased police officers' salaries, but the head of the State Association of Counties asserted today that such an appeal would have been fruitless.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Airliner Bookings Soar With Supersaver Fares
description: LOS ANGELES, May 22I would never fly the other way again unless I was so fabulously wealthy I didn't care, Maureen Solomon., a film historian, said after her recent supersaver flight to New York and back to visit her family.

title: Herman's Plans 34th St. Store
description: Herman's World of Sporting Goods, a subsidiary of W. R. Grace & Company, is planning to open its largest Manhattan store in the vacated Franklin Simon store property at 33 West 34th Street in the Herald Square area in September, retailing sources reported yesterday.

title: Letter: On the BerkeyKodak Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Leone Sees Victory a Matter of More Recognition
description: Richard C. Leone has reduced his strategy in the race for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate to a pimple exerciseincrease his recognition among Democratic voters between now and June 6 and pick up the primary victory.

title: U.N. RALLY BY 2,000 BACKS DISARMAMENT
description: Praying in a dozen languages, 2,000 people of a multitude of faiths descended upon the United Nations yesterday, calling for world disarmament.

title: Georgia Battling I75 Frauds
description: ATLANTA, May 26Gov. George D. Busbee announced yesterday a crackdown on dishonest mechanics and service stations along Interstate 75 in an effort to prevent his state from reclaiming its once formidable reputation for tourist traps.

title: Woman Killed in Hijacking Attempt Found to Have Varied Background
description: ST. LOUIS,May 26To her neighbors in Richmond Heights, a St. Louis suburb, she was Barbara Ann Oswald, a pleasant 43yearold woman with five children who, to their surprise, was shot to death yesterday while trying to hijack a helicopter.

title: 262 DEAD ARE FOUND FROM ZAIRE FIGHTING
description: KOLWEZI, Zaire, May 26 (AP)Military and civilian search teams have recovered the bodies of 262 persons killed in the fighting for this coppermining city in southern Zaire, Red Cross officials said today.

title: COMPANY ROUNDUP
description: The board of Dymo Industries Inc. agreed unanimously yesterday that shareholders should accept the offer of $30 a share made by Esselte A.B. of Sweden to take over Dymo.

title: Gunfire in Crowded Bus Terminal On 8th Ave. Leaves 2 Dead, 2 Hurt
description: A barefoot man grabbed a Port Authority patrolman's revolver near the Greyhound ticket counter of the midtown bus terminal during the morning rush hour yesterday, killed the officer and, in a wild burst of gunfire that sent commuters scurrying for cover, seriously wounded two bystanders.

title: Gromyko Tells U.N. of Willingness To Negotiate Major New Arms Cut
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that as soon as a new SovietAmerican agreement to limit offensive nuclear arms is completed, his Government would be prepared to negotiate a substantial cut in the level of missiles and bombers.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar showed little change on overseas money markets today as traders awaited announcement of United States trade figures for April, according to The Associated Press. But once the disappointing figures were disclosed, the dollar fell in New York trading.

title: Nancy's Caddie Knows Who's Boss
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 26Almost every round, Nancy Lopez hits a shot that dazzles even her caddie. I'm impressed, Roscoe Jones will tell her with a smile. I'm very impressed. So is everybody else. Less than a year after turning pro, 21yearold Nancy Lopez has won four Ladies Professional Golf Association tournaments this year, two succession twice. She is the leading moneywinner with $81,448 and also the leading attractionyoung, pretty, pleasant, the most dominant young golfer since Jack Nicklaus arrived nearly $3 million ago. In the L.P.G.A. tournament that began at the Wykagyl Country Club today, Nancy Lopez was the golfer to watch with a fiveunderpar in the opening round. Watching her closer than anybody else was Roscoe Jones, her 26yearold caddie with bushy hair, a thin mustache, a mischievous smile and a sometimes demanding manner. Three weeks ago Nancy Lopez dismissed him for expecting me to hit a great shot every time. But she quickly rehired him. With two consecutive victories since their spat, all is calm now.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: VICTOR UNVANQUISHED Moonbeams, Every Day Is Ladies Day With Me and The Streets of New York are three songs that keep The Red Mill alive over the years. Starting tonight at 7:30, the Bel Canto Opera Company, in one of its delvings into operetta, will be presenting a limited engagement of the Victor Herbert musical at its resident showcase, 30 East 31st Street.

title: Pumping Metal for Public Uplift
description: Knowing nothing about gambling and being eager to cut a suave figure in Atlantic City, I went to Reno this week for instruction under a man named Ernie.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday erroneously reported that the Western Electric Corporation had raised the monthly pensions of retired employees. The company should have been identified as the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

title: SMALLER OIL SUPPLY SEEN BY SCHLESINGER
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger asserted today that the outlook for the supply of oil is bleaker than it appeared a year ago despite a slowdown in the growth of demand and the effects of improved conservation.

title: Debate in Washington: How to Meet Soviet Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Top officials of the Carter Administration in the last few weeks have been weighing the possible American responses to what they see as a striking pattern of Soviet aggressiveness in recent months from Afghanistan to Africa.

title: Juilliard Theater Offers Beggar's Opera
description: In a sense we have no business reviewing this. It is a student production. True, these are the thirdyear students at the Juilliard Theater Center, one of our leading theater schools, but more to the point, they are putting onwith the help of a talented orchestra from the music school  The Beggar's Opera.

title: Booksellers Open 78th Convention To Talk About Forthcoming Lists
description: ATLANTA, May 26The world of publishing has assembled here, for the 78th time since the American Booksellers Association was founded in 1900, for its annual showandtell about the books that will be read on the North American continent this summer and autumn.

title: Bruins Are Defeated but Unbowed
description: BOSTON, May 26While the Montreal Canadiens catapulted atop one another on the ice in celebration of their third consecutive Stanley Cup last night, a Boston Bruins' fan turned to a friend and said sharply, Well, we gave them a good fight this year anyway.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPICY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, May 26, 1978 Petition Filed By:

title: Guild Sets a June 6 Strike at News
description: The New York Newspaper Guild said last night that The Daily News would be struck at 2 P.M. on June 6 if a contract agreement had not been reached by then.

title: Artur Pavlovich Vader, at 58, President of Soviet Estonia
description: MOSCOW May 26 (AP)Artur Pavlovich Vader, President of the Soviet Baltic Republic of Estonia, died yesterday at age 58, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. It gave no details of his death.

title: Books of The Times
description: In 1657. Rembrandt was bankrupt and the Insolvency Office of Amsterdam made an inventory of all his possessions so that they could be auctioned to Pay off his debts. By consulting this inventory, which has survived, we are better able, Anthony Bailey says, to furnish not only Rembrandt's house, but also his temperament and his mind as well. For Rembrandt was a lover of things, of the actual. More clearly, perhaps, than any other painter in the world, he saw the relation between the particular and the universal, the thing and its place in the scheme of things.

title: Lure of California Fades for Business
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26Housing costs are too high ... Taxes are too high ... The transportation system is bad ... More and more of our young executives wont accept a transfer here.

title: It's Place Your Bets as East's First Casino Opens
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 26Legalized casino gambling began officially in Atlantic City today, with eager, but smallerthanexpected, crowds of bettors moving into the Resorts International hotel gaming mom and politicians predicting that golden clays were coming for this once prosperous, nowshabby resort town by the sea,

title: Colombo Is Eulogized as a Champion of Civil Rights
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr. was eulogized by his friends yesterday as a man of the people, a loving husband and father, a community activist who championed the rights of ItalianAmericans and as someone who, in 1971, was struck down by an assassin's bullets in the prime of life.

title: InflationProductivity Puzzle
description: Productivity helps keep inflation in check, or so economists say.

title: Aluminum Maker Fighting T.V.A.
description: The Consolidated Aluminum Corporation, the nation's fourth  largest aluminum producer, said yesterday that it had filed a complaint in a Federal court in Nashville seeking a preliminary and permanent injunction to bar the Tennessee Valley Authority from imposing a rate increase on July 2.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ATLANTA, May 26 (AP)Dave Eichelberger added a threeunderpar 69 to his opening round 62 and stretched his lead to three strokes today at the halfway mark of the $200,000 Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: Mobil Mixes Music and Its Views
Judge Tells Airlines Blind Can Have Canes
