description: BALTIMORE, May 26 (AP)  A Federal judge issued a temporary order today that barred United States airlines from seizing canes from blind passengers, as the Federal Aviation Administration had ordered them to do.

title: Johnson Makes Surprise Offer to GlobeUnion
description: Johnson Controls Inc. of Milwaukee made a surprise offer yesterday to merge with GlobeUnion Inc. although GlobeUnion's directors had recently accepted another merger offer from the Square D Company. Johnson makes temperature control systems for buildings and GlobeUnion is the last major independent manufacturer of batteries.

title: Portuguese Premier Defends His Optimism
description: LISBON, May 20In contrast with other European countries, we do not have social agitation, we have no terrorism, we have total tranquillity in the country, said Prime Minister Mario Soares, leaning his bulky form forward in his seat for emphasis. People say that I am too optimistic, that I see things through rosecolored glasses. But the truth is the truth.

title: Brooke Admits to False Statement, Under Oath, About a $49,000 Loan
description: BOSTON, May 26Senator Edward W. Brooke conceded today that he gave false information, under oath, about the source of a $49,000 personal loan in a deposition taken during his divorce proceedings last year.

title: Venezuelan Vote Set for Dec. 3
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 26 (Reuters)Venezuela's presidential and legislative elections will be held on Dec. 3, the electoral board ruled today. It. rejected suggestions by the governing Democratic Action Party that the two elections be held on separate dales.

title: Two Sued for Libel On Cancer Charges In Palisades Park
description: HACKENSACK. May 26Two women who contended that an abnormally h:gh number of cancer deaths had occurred in recent years in a neighborhood of Palisades Park near an industrial complex were sued today for libel by the Pfister Chemical Company, one of the plants in the complex.

title: A Threat to Private Colleges
description: Private colleges and universities are beset by harsh budget problems; now, the New York State Legislature is threatening to make them even harsher. Ten years ago, on the recommendation of a commission headed by the Ford Foundation's president, McGeorge Bundy, Albany enacted a generous program of direct aid to private colleges. Bundy aid, as it has come to be known, is allocated on the basis of the number of degrees granted, and in the current fiscal year its total came to $66.6 million. That amounts to an essential 6 percent of the institutions budgets.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: Byrne Pressing Legislature to Act On 20 Bills Stalled in Committees
description: TRENTON, May. 25Governor Byrne has begun pressing the Legislature in act on major bills stalled in committee, and, in a memorandum to Democratie leaders, he has suggested specific action on 20 measures.

title: World News Briefs
description: CAPE TOWN, May 26 (AP)  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia said today he would retire from politics once the transition to black majority rule in his country was complete.

title: ExBelgian Owner Helps Zaire on Mines
description: BRUSSELS, May 26Union Miniere, the big Belgian mining company that discovered the rich copper mines in the Shaba Province of Zaire, once epitomized Belgium's exploitation of its former African colony.

title: Most Banks Set 8% Prime; Stocks Off for 4th Day
description: The banking community across the country, with the notable exception of Citibank of New York, raised the prime lending rate yesterday to 8 percent from 8 percent.

title: Price Actions Mixed In Copper Industry
description: Major copper companies started yesterday to fall in line behind the higher price for electrolytic copper posted Thursday by the Kennecott Copper Corporation. But they did not adopt Kennecott's new pricing formula, and two of the industry's most important producers did not raise prices at all.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Racing Bill Set For Vote
description: ALBANY, May 26Assembly and Senate negotiators overcame their final political hurdles and reached agreement tonight on a bill intended to benefit New York's horseracing industry, despite the protests of a furious Offtrack Betting Corporation president. A formal vote is expected within a few weeks.

title: EGYPT CALLS HOME SADAT'S FOES ABROAD
description: CAIRO, May 26The Egyptian Government has ordered 30 journalists and writers who work abroad to come home to undergo investigation for writing or broadcasting reports considered critical of President Anwar elSadat and his policies.

title: Puerto Rican Day Parade to Honor Velez Despite Order Barring His Participation
description: The annual Puerto Rican Day Parade, scheduled for June 4, was dedicated yesterday to former City Councilman Ramon S. Velez, who has been barred by court erder from playing any official role in it.

title: Deaths
description: Abbott, Joseph

title: Head of Foreign Policy Magazine Named Ambassador to Denmark
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)Warren D. Manshel, the editor and publisher of Foreign Policy magazine and a former analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, was named by President Carter today as Ambassador to Denmark. He will replace John G. Dean, who has resigned.

title: Lure of California Fades for Business
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26Housing costs are too high ... Taxes are too high ... The transportation system is bad ... More and more of our young executives Won't accept a transfer here.

title: Gunfire in Crowded Bus Terminal On 8th Ave. Leaves 2 Dead, 2 Hurt
description: A barefoot man grabbed a Port Authority patrolman's revolver near the Greyhound ticket counter of the midtown bus terminal during the morning rush hour yesterday, killed the officer and, in a wild burst of gunfire, seriously wounded two bystanders.

title: Spencer Grand Slam Wins for Yanks, 43
description: It was Jim Spencer against John Mayberry last night in Yankee Stadium, and Spencer won the individual battle and the Yankees won the war, beating the Toronto Blue Jays by 43 before 19,985 fans.

title: Gromyko Tells U.N. of Willingness To Negotiate Major New Arms Cut
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y, May 26Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that as soon as a new SovietAmerican agreement to limit offensive nuclear arms is completed, his Government would be prepared to negotiate a substantial cut in the level of missiles and bombers.

title: Carter Announces Panel of 13 Will Study Coal Problem
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 26President Carter, fulfilling a promise he made three months ago, when the nation was in the midst of its longest coal strike, announced today that a 13member Cornmission on the Coal Industry would conduct a oneyear study of the embittered labormanagement relations in the mines.

title: Siberian Gas Accord
description: TOKYO, May 26 (Reuters)Japanese and United States businessmen and Soviet officials ended talks here today with an agreement to try to start deliveries of Siberian natural gas by 1985. a Japanese spokesman said. The fourday meeting discussed the proposed joint development. of reserves near the eastern Siberian town of Yakutsk.

title: Gifted Students in an Olympics of the Mind
description: GLASSBORO, May 24The State Department of Education and Glassboro State College have initialed an experimental education project to stimulate the creative capacities of New Jersey's gifted secondary school students.

title: Soviet Launches Cosmos 1012
description: MOSCOW, May 26 (UPI)The Soviet Union has launched Cosmos 1012, Tass, the official news agency, said today. The satellite is in an orbit that takes it 173.79 miles from the Earth's surface at maximum and 132.8 miles at minimum. It circles the earth every 89.2 minutes and tilts at an angle of 62.8 degrees.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Why the West Has Come to View Kolwezi as a Massacre of Whites
description: Why is the massacre at Kolwezi, in which more than twice as many blacks were killed as whites, being perceived around the world as a white bloodbath?

title: Brazil Spares Baby An $1,100 Exit Tax
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 26How soon after birth does one owe taxes? For Mauro Biscione, the answer was immediately, and the bill was $1,100 for an exit visa. Or so it was until the intervention this week of Brazil's central bank.

title: Broker Pleads Guilty on Taxes
description: Jules Nordlicht, a commodities floor broker. pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to a Federal charge of conspiracy to create $27 million in fraudulent tax losses through manipulation of the market for crude oil futures.

title: CopperMining Area Is Heart of Zaire's Economy
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 26It is difficult to imagine just how great a role Kolwezi, the heart of Zaire's mining industry, has played in the nation's economy and how dependent that economy has been on the 500 or 600 white metallurgists and engineers who have now gone.

title: Air Controllers Said to Slow Holiday Traffic
description: Airline carriers yesterday accused tower flight controllers of further snarling already congested holidayweekend air traffic by going by the book in dispute over the number of overseas cockpit training rides they are to be allowed.

title: A.M.C. Joins in Rise For Vehicle Prices
description: The American Motors Corporation, the smallest of the major car producers, announced yesterday that it would join other producers by Increasing the price of most of its passenger cars and all its utility vehicles, effective next Thursday.

title: Bridge:
description: In a unique ceremony about 10:30 o'clock tonight, Richard Goldberg, executive secretary of the American Contract Bridge League, will make a special presentation to Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, who lived in Brooklyn for the first half of his long and distinguished life.

title: Old Hand at Disarmament Tables Nurtures Hopes for U.N. Parley
description: He is an old man now, whitehaired, a little stooped and frail, peering through thick spectacles, but the gentle passion of his lifelong commitment to the notion that mankind should stop manufacturing the instruments of its own destruction is undimmed in Philip NoelBaker.

title: Diplomats' Alien Servants Report Harsh Treatment
description: Sobrana Perfecta Quinones came to America expecting to earn $200 a month by working as a domestic in a foreign diplomat's home. That was more money than she thought she might ever have earned back home in Manila, and the promise of bringing along her 3yearold daughter and learning English also raised her hopes.

title: Brooke Admits to False Statement, Under Oath, About a $49,000 Loan
description: BOSTON, May 26Senator Edward W. Brooke conceded today that he gave false information, under oath, about the source of a St 9,000 personal loan in a deposition taken during his divorce proceedings last year.

title: It's Place Your Bets as East's First Casino Opens
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 26Legalized casino gambling began officially in Atlantic City today, with eager, but smallerthanexpected, crowds of bettors moving into the Resorts International Hotel gaming room and politicians predicting that golden days were coming for this onceprosperous, nowshabby resort town by the sea.

title: Wherein a New Yorker Explains Her Intention to Leave
description: I am sorry, New York. I just didn't hear you. I apologize, Mayor Koch and. Abe Beame. You were certainly clear enough, but I didn't listen. I should have heard you John Lindsay and Robert Wagner, but sometimes I can be stupid.

title: Trade Deficit Widened In April
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The United States last month bought S2.9 billion more in foreign markets than it sold there, a slight increase from the $2.8 billion trade deficit in March and the fifthlargest monthly deficit on record, the Government reported today.

title: Mergers: Kennecott and Dymo
description: In the big proxy fight of the year, the Kennecott Copper Corporation has apparently survived a challenge from the CurtissWright Corporation. In a smaller but manyfaceted battle for Dymo Industries Inc., Esselte A.B. of Sweden last week raised its offer and in a matter of hours vanquished a West Coast competitor.

title: Benjamin Cohen, Bank Aide, Fiance of Lydia Jane Conway
description: Mrs. Winston Elting of San Miguel Allende, Mexico, formerly of Chicago, and John Conway of Appleton, Wis., have announced the engagement of their daugher, Lydia Jane Conway, to Benjamin H. Cohen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Cohen of Syosset, L.I. Plans have been made for an Octpber wedding in Chicago. their daugher, Lydia Jane Conway, to Benjamin H. Cohen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Cohen of Syosset, L.I. Plans have been made for an Octpber wedding in Chicago.

title: Sunday Observer
description: City life started me thinking about toes. Somebody had stepped on five of mine in a crowded place, and it occurred to me that for city people toes were a mistake. In fact, major parts of the human design are a mistake for city living.

title: Youth And the Vote
description: LIKE the Pied Piper of Hamelin, who lured the children out of town after their elders had refused to pay his fee, Bill Bradley has captured the imagination of youthful voters after the state Democratic establishment snubbed him.

title: SPORTS
description: THE Iroquois Indians who invented lacrosse called it baggataway. An organized game it wasn't. Neither the number of players nor the field of play was limited when two tribes convened for a baggataway bout. Each tribe chinned in a medicine man to serve as referee, whose person also marked the position of the goal. The goal might move a few feet or a few miles, depending upon the medicine man's concentration or his hankering for a stroll.

title: $20.3 Million in Federal Funds Earmarked for New York City Housing
description: New York State and city officials have decided that $20.3 million a year in newly authorized Federal rent subsidies will be used to spur 24 housing construction and rehabilitation projects across the city.

title: Leslie K. Sann Is Bride
description: Leslie Karen Sann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Sann of New York, and David Michael Kapov, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Kapov of Glenview, Ill., were married last night by Judge Jack Rosenberg of the Bronx Supreme Court at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Glastonbury May Lose U.S. Funds
description: GLASTONBURY THE strings attached to Federal block grants for municipalities may be used here for the first time in the history of the Department of Housing and Urban Development to yank the money back.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biographyinprogress of Wallace Stevens, I would like to hear from individuals who had contact with this poetbusinessman or with his family. Letters, reports, photos or other material will be most welcome. PETER A. BRAZEAU 135 Love Lane Manchester, Conn. 06040

title: Cities  The Key to Rebirth
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE has said that he will devote his second term to rebuilding New Jersey's cities. Citing the need for revitalization, however, is not accomplishing it. In this part of the nation, some cities, spurred by individual leadership, have turned themselves around.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Tricolore Falls Short Of Success

title: Dressing Children And Their Rooms
description: HUNTINGTON Achildren's store is not necessarily for children only, nor is it limited to parents and grandparents. A children's store can be a touchme experience or rememberwhen reminiscence  with a sprinkling of Oh, my, how things have changed! or What will they think of next? Whatever, wherever, can be a fun place to browse in.

title: Realty News
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies is expanding at Rockefeller Center.

title: Letters From Bess About Bess
description: IN 1900, the heroine of this novelinletters celebrates her 10th Christmas. I got everything I asked for, she writes to a friend, but I always do.

title: THEATER
description: ELMSFORD IF ONE thinks of the musical Shenandoah in terms of when it appeared  in January 1975, when America was very sick of war its success makes sense. If you think about the progress made in the musical theater, its success makes no sense. It is a Civil War soap opera reeking with noble characters who feel all the proper clich emotions, who speak poor dialogue and who sing thirdrate lyrics to a thirdrate score.

title: Cathy Clark Married to Christian McCarthy
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday, Cathy Patricia Clark, daughter of Mrs. Valdor E. Clark of Wallingford, Pa., and the late Mr. Clark, was married to Christian McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. McCarthy of Yonkers. The Rev. Gerard Di Senso performed the ceremony.

title: 557 Incidents of Suspected Arson In 10 Months Recorded in San Diego
description: SAN DIEGO, May 27A series of fires in landmarks, schools and shopping centers has focused the attention of San Diego residents on an outbreak of arson that has included 557 suspicious fires in the last In months.

title: Academic Robes With Thin Pockets
description: Ishall not walk in my peacock robes in the last academic procession to which my waning tenure entitles me. I have grown weary of the annual ritual presided over by politicians, administrators and important laymen who dutifully remind us that we are a faculty second to none, that our graduates are splendidly equipped to face the vicissitudes of practical life because of our superb teaching, and that the public is fully cognizant of the virtues that our graduating seniors have acquired from us.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: POWER MOWERS, edging machines, garden tractors and other powerdriven yard and garden tools can save a lot of work for the homeowner, but they also can lead to lots of frustration and fail to perform as expected if they are not serviced periodically and otherwise not maintained properly.

title: Rep. Fascell in Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI)Representative Dante Fascell, Democrat of Florida, chairman of a House International Relations subcommittee, has been admitted to Bethesda Naval Medical Center. for treatment of an undisclosed illness, the hospital officials said today. Mr. Fascell, 61 years old, was admitted to the hospital yesterday amid reports he was suffering dizzy spells.

title: LIGHT AUDIT SAYS CITY OVERPAID MILLIONS
description: New York City apparently overpaid millions of dollars for streetlighting maintenance and electricity costs because it failed to keep an accurate count of the number of lights for more than 40 years, according to a confidential Department of Investigation report.

title: Fund Raising Can Be a Real PartyPooper
description: WASHINGTON  Twice as many Americans say they are Democrats than admit to being Republicans, Elected officeholders divide in the same lopsided ratio. But John C. White, the Democratic National Chairman, said last week he had $169,179.05 on hand, plus debts of $2,300,997.52, and his Republican counterpart, Bill Brock, has $1,981,912.00 million cash on hand and another $1.2 million raised by April dinners but not vet finally entered on the books.

title: Janice Elizabeth Heisler Fiance of Kenneth Wile
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Heisler of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Elizabeth Heisler to Kenneth E. Wile, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Wile of Glencoe. Ill.

title: For One L.I. Author, 1978 Will See The Publication of 3 of His Novels
description: Lots of people grow up wanting to become novelists. Some of them do. But few have three navels come out in a single year.

title: Hungarians Feel Bit of Austerity After Big Gains
description: BUDAPESTThe imbalances of Hungary's 10yearold program of economic reforms, that became apparent to the planners years ago are beginning to be felt by ordinary citizens.

title: Rocky At Seventy
description: WASHINGTON  Nelson A. Rockefeller is celebrating, or anyway recognizing, his 70th birthday these days, not because he is 70 just yet (he won't be until July 8) but because, like the Queen in Britain, May is more convenient for his friends than July.

title: FIRE'S BITTER LEGACY IN A KENTUCKY TOWN
description: SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 27 When Chapter 84 of the Institute for Financial Education held its annual awards banquet a few days ago, there was a gentlemen's agreement that nothing would be said during the program about last year's banpet. But on Monday, when the residents of this tiny community conduct their an??ual Memorial Day paradeit will be all of five blocks Iongthe festivities are ?? end with brief remarks on what the business executives chose to ignore.

title: Battle Over Water Moves Into the Air
description: LONG BEACH AN 8foothigh whip antenna atop City Hall here is being used as the latest weapon in this city's battle with Long Beach Memorial Hospital over an unpaid $108.000 water bill.

title: Chicago Democrats Cheer Carter
description: CHICAGO, May 27President Carter finally met the Cook County Democrats on their own ground this week and they are hopeful that he was duly impressed.

title: Joan Joyce Makes Pitch For a Second Career
description: By day Joan Joyce is a 37yearold rookie on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, known for the length, if not the accuracy, of her drives. By night she's the star pitcher for the Connecticut Falcons, the twotime champions of the twoyearold Women's Professional Softball Association

title: A Soviet Bloc Tour by Car
description: To many vacationers an automobile trip of nearly 3,000 miles in Eastern Europe may sound outlandish, even forbidding. Well, it is not, at least, not so far as my husband, Clint, and I are concerned. Since 1965 we have traveled behind the Iron Curtain seven times, usually by car.

title: Deaths
description: FLASH ZEBROWSK IHelen. Mem ber Lady of the Holy Sepulchre, or May 25, 1978. Dear wife of the late Leo. Beloved mother of Vincent Flash. Devoted motherinlaw of Joan. Also survived by four grandsons, Vincent, Jr., William, Martin and Michael of Baldwin, L.I. Cherished sister of Reverend William Flashkowski and Genevieve. Reposing at Benson Funeral Service, Inc., 8312 Parsons Blvd. (at Grand Central Parkway), Jamaica, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10AM Queen of Peace RC Church, Main St. and 77th Rd., Kew Gardens Hills. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday 2.5 and 79PM. In lieu of flowers Masses preferred.

title: Events Today
description: Outdoor Art Exhibit: Noon to 6 P.M.; Upper West Sioe of Manhattan at 193d Street.

title: Diamond MeatTray Manufacturer Closing Upstate Plant in Wake of New York City Law on Packaging
description: OGDENSBURG, May 22 New York City consumers probably did not know they were eliminating the only biouegradable meat tray from their market when they lobbied for 100 percent visibility in meat packaging a decade ago.

title: Janet Abrams Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ira Lee Abrams of Hallandale, Fla., formerly of Lake Success, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Beth Abrams, to Philip Molofsky, Son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Sheldon Molofsky of Norfolk, Va.

title: Award Established For Architecture
description: The Hyatt Foundation at Chicago announced today that it will sponsor a $75,000 annual award for achievement in architecture. The award, to be called the International Architecture Prize, will be given for significant contributions to humanity and the environment through architecture.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Nicholas Secor, a 30yearold guitarist whose principal activities to date have apparently been centered in the Boston area, made his New York recital debut Monday night in Town Hall. A musician who seems very much involved with his instrument and its music, Mr. Secor demonstrated as much In the disarming running commentary that he inserted between the selections on his program.

title: Anne H. Steel, T. K. Armour Are Married
description: Anne Hollister Steel, daughter of Mrs. Edward Walter Wellman of Easton, Conn., and J. Thompson Steel of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy Keenan Armour, son of Mrs. Arthur Edward Larkin of Oak Brook, Ill., and Donald Armour of Santa Barbara. Calif.

title: Philip Glass Comes to Carnegie HallAt Last
description: Philip Glass and the members of the ensemble that plays his compositions were taking a break from a rehearsal for his Carnegie Hall concert Thursday. The musicians three saxophonists who double on flutes, three electric organists including Mr. Glass, and a sound engineerwere pacing around the loft, stretching, or talking in small groups about recent developments in SoHo's musical avantgarde, in the art world and in jazz. Mr. Glass, 41, has a craggily engaging face. He was wearing a checkered shirt, jeans, white socks and loafers, and was talking about Mozart.

title: Lacrosse Is Generating a Greta Interest on L.I.
description: The Iroquois Indians who invented lacrosse called it baggataway. An organized game it wasn't. Neither the number of players nor the field of play was limited when two tribes convened for a baggataway bout. Each tribe chipped in a medicine man to serve as referee, whose person also marked the position of the goal. The goal might move a few feet or a few miles, depending upon the medicine man's concentration or his hankering for a stroll.

title: Deaths
description: ABBOTTJoseph B. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the Passing of Joseph B. Abbott, associated with The Times from September, 1923 until retiring in 1956.

title: Paramus Buys a Golf Course to Save It
description: PARAMUS THE white paint on the old clubhouse of the Paramus Golf and Country Club is worn and peeling. Water leaks have yellowed parts of the ceiling of the circular front foyer, and the tile floor bears the scars of years of traffic from golfers spikes.

title: Molloy Debates Secularization
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE FOR the last few years a conflict has existed at Molloy College, the Island's only Roman Catholic college, about whether to drop its church affiliation. The dispute, involving both teachers and students at the 23yearold school founded by the Sisters of St. Dominic, involves questions of economics, religious philosophy and the law of the land.

title: Encounter: Today You Take Home Baby
description: During the year I spent at the American School of Classical Studies in Athens, a sudden attack of appendicitis put me in the hospital fora week of observation. My doctor rushed me to the hospital in the middle of the night, and I dimly remember that as I fell asleep he congratulated me on getting the last available bed in the women's ward.

title: Beneath the Surface Calm in Portugal, a Mood of Stagnation and Weariness of Politics
description: LISBON  Though Portuguese living standards have been declining steeply, the fourmonthold coalition Government of Socialists and conservatives has achieved a surface calm, beneath which the left is losing heart and momentum while the right has yet to score decisive gains.

title: County Jails: Are They Necessary?
description: EARLIER this year, the state's County Penal System Study Commission submitted its report to the Governor and the Legislature. The commission was charged with examining the condition of the county jails and making recommendations for their improvement.

title: This Week in Sports
description: America's richest and bestknown race, the Indianapolis 500, will be run today at the Indianapolif Motor Speedway. The favorites in the field of 33 drivers are Tom Sneva and Mario Andretti PenskeCosworths and A. J. Foyt in a CoyoteFoyt.

title: Deborah Kramer Wed to Gary Duerksen
description: The marriage of Deborah Louise Kramer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Yale Kramer of New York, to Gary Lynn Duerksen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward C. Duerksen of Denver, took place yesterday in the Bond Chapel on the University of Chicago campus. The Rev. Spencer Parsons, dean of the university's Rockefeller Chapel, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: His Cooking Benefits South River's Band
description: SOUTH RIVER BY his own admission, Theofil Kadela has always been a frustrated cook. For years, he cooked at home, where his wife, Hilda, said he did everything but clean up after himself.

title: Births
description: Davidson

title: Florida Congressman Arrested
description: DANIA, Fla., May 27 (AP)Representative J. Herbert Burke, a Republican member of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, was arrested on a charge of disorderly intoxication early today at a nightclub. Mr. Burke said he had followed two men there Friday night after he overheard them discussing a narcotics deal and the next thing I knew the Dania Police Department was there to get me. Mr. Burke was also charged with resisting arrest without violence. He was released on his signature. Mr. Burke is running for reelection.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: OCCASIONALLY, something will trigger a memory of childhood. It can be something as simple as Flash Gordon serials on television, your son collecting baseball cards and chewing bubble gum, a discarded skate key, a rusty twowheeler.

title: Rock Musicians Have Growing Pains, Too
description: Ray Davies of the Kinks and John Prine might seem a peculiar pairing. The former is the leader of a veteran British rock band that dates back 14 years, a group that grew out of bluesbased British rock but early on began mixing in bits of the British musichall/vaudeville tradition. Mr. Prine is a folksinger from Chicago whose music owes much to the country sounds of the South, as well as to the obvious example of Bob Dylan.

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD SPEAKING to a meeting of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Chicago earlier this month, Bill Brock, the former Tennessee Senator who is now the Republican national chairman, stressed that the Republicans were heavily involved in recruiting black candidates for Congress this year.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE summer of our lives is a place of the heart that knows no change of season and no passing of years. It is reached only by magic not easily summoned.

title: City Ballet Program Underlines The Infinite Variety of Balanchine
description: Thursday was a night for contrasts at the New York State Theater. The daycos ??eformed by the New York City Pallet spanned 35 years and in ??niarly happy hit of programming provided yet another occasion ??o wander at the variety of George Balanchine their choreographer.

title: GuitarMaking as a Labor of Love
description: FARMINGVILLE ANDREW TATAY guides the hands of his 13yearold son, James, as he teaches him how to join the neck of a guitar to the body. They fiddle with the piece until it has the proper feel because that certain kind of instinct is what Mr. Tatay says makes a craftsman different from a mechanic.

title: BRIDGE
description: The news that the laws of rubber bridge are due to be revised by the World Bridge Federation, which has appointed a committee for the purpose, has caused some cumblings of discontent among players of rubber bridge, who are a highly conservative group. They say that they are happy with things as they are, and that they do not want a bunch of tournament players legislating for them. But none of the complainants has gone so far as to offer to help with the work.

title: Sandra Waugh Fiancee Of Walter E. Winans Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goodrich Waugh of Southport, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Vail Waugh, to Walter Edward Winans Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Winans of Bedford Hills, N.Y. The wedding will take place June 10.

title: INVESTING
description: On Thursday banks and savings institutions will begin to sell sixmonth certificates that will carry interest rates linked to sixmonth Treasury bill rates. Does it make any sense to put your money into the new certificates?

title: Casino Is Gambling on Outdoing The Biggest House in Las Vegas
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 26When Resorts International breaks through the temporary north wall of its casino here in less than three weeks, its gambling room will be larger than the largest of the Las Vegas casinos, the MGM Grand Hotel.

title: Not Just Spinning Wheels
description: The bicycle is the most. efficient known means, animal or mechanical, of converting energy into transportation four times as efficient as a jet transport, five times as efficient as a man walking, ten limes as efficient as a gull flying. And the hike has tint basically changed since the invention of the derailleur gearchanger in 1899. Is the bike perfect? Not quite, according to Lawrence G. Brown, an engineer who has developed a bike drive based not on the chainwheel but on the rot at rig cam. Late last. year, men on Mr. Brown's hikes broke a number of American timetrial records, from 10 to 150 miles. That is not as impressive as it sounds, since marry of the records were very old. But it does prove the hike works. Next month, members of the American team for next summer's world championships in Germany will work out on the bikes to see if they like them, and the international governing federation will be asked if the hikes are legal. Mr. Brown claims his tests show his hike yields substantially more push on I he pavement for I he same poke on the pedal. If that is so many revolutions are in the making.

title: Finally, a Vote On Energy Plan
description: The Congressional conference cornmittee on energy, now seven painful months old, is nothing if not consistent. With every step forward come fresh reminders of how much more must still be done, a pattern that remained unbroken last week with one of the committee's bigger steps.

title: Hospitals Designed for the Dying
description: Calvary Hospital in the Bronx occupies a renovated structure originally designed in 1915 with double rooms and wards, awkward accommodations since half the patients die within a month after admission. Something new was needed.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TomorrowRacing at Lime Rock (Conn.) Park, near junction of Routes 7 and 112. Registration: 8 A.M.; practice 9; 15mile Vintage Sports Car Club of America race at noon; 100mile Champion Spark Plug lenge race 1 P.M.; 100mile Camel GT 2.5 Challenge race 2:45; 100mile Camel GT Challenge race 4:15. Information. (203)4352572.

title: Malry, Pianist, Makes a Debut On West Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 27E. Jerome Malry made his debut as a concert pianist here Thursday night at the Opera House in rehearsal for the Tchaikovsky International Competition, which begins June 8 in Moscow.

title: Baseball at a College Where Athletes Are Students First
description: The batting cage was pieced together with old shoe laces. A floodlight hung from the excess of the dimly lighted gymnasium.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Some books are not meant to be literature, but to change the consciousness of their readers  and in its own quiet way, I believe that Belonging will do just that. The story of a blind teenager who wants desperately to fit in, the material has the advantage of being autobiographical. The situations are genuine, the heartbreak real, and if the book is deficient in literary values it hardly seems to matter.

title: Miss Post, With 69138, Gains OneStroke Edge
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 27Sandra Post, who has been on the Ladies Professional Golf Association our for 11 years, and JoAnne Carner, who has eight years on the tour, did their best today to bring Nancy Lopez, the finest rookie in L.P.G.A. history, back to the pack. Miss Post even succeeded in taking the lead from Miss Lopez halfway through the $100,000 72hole tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club,

title: Gregorek Takes TwoMile Run in 8:50.7
description: John Gregorek raced the clock yesterday at the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships and won.

title: With a Lot of Help From His Friends
description: Once again, foreigners have salvaged Zaire's mineralladen Shaba province for the shaky Government of Mobutu Sese Seko. The fighting, which seemed largely over last week, also gave France, Belgium and, to a lesser extent, the United States, a chance to compete in showing decisiveness against rebel Zairians believed to he armed and trained by the Soviet Union and Cuba. But ihe cost of rescuing Shaba and Mr. Mobutu keeps rising.

title: NIXON BOOK DISPUTE ERUPTS AT MEETING
description: ATLANTA, May 27  The controversy over the right to publish and sell RN: The Memoirs of Richard Nixonas well as the right to tell potential readers not to buy the bookproduced a confrontation today at the annual meeting here of the American Booksellers Association.

title: ART
description: BREWSTER SUPERLATIVES are frequent and unfortunate hallmarks of art criticism. Works are all too often characterized as the best this, the most that or the greatest of anything, and such celebrations have done disservice to art, confounding rather than enlightening. They have, in effect, left us without a significant element or critical apparatus  attributes to describe those art objects that are indeed the most worthy.

title: Same Playwright, Next Play
INTERVIEW
description: IN THE 1955 movie Women's Prison, Ida Lupino played an authoritarian, stonefaced warden who dressed in a dull gray skirt, a mantailored white blouse and a black tie. She carried a nightstick and was feared by the inmates.

title: Elizabeth Burdge, Timothy J. Murphy To Marry July 29
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Burdge of Spring Lake, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Thompson Burdge to Timothy John Murphy so of Mrs. Richard J. Hughes of Princeton, N.J., and the late Capt. William M, Murphy, U.S.A.F.

title: Fighting School Vandalism With a Paintbrush
description: WHAT do you do in this age of rampant vandalism to create pride in the school environment? One solution is to have students paint murals on the school walls.

title: A Symbolic Triumph Over OSHA
description: Most businessmen fume when the OSHA inspector walks in unannounced to check the premises for safety infractions. Ferrol G. Barlow of Pocatello, Idaho, got so angry that he refused to let the Government man into his plumbing and electrical supply shop without a search warrant. The resulting case reached the Supreme Court and last week Mr. Barlow won a victory of sorts.

title: 4th Group Suspends Visit to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, May 27A delegation of 11 American cancer research scientists has indefinitely postponed a trip to the Soviet Union to protest the recent trial of a Soviet dissident. The decision will interrupt a program of scientific exchange that has been functioning for most of this decade.

title: Hearty Yankee Eating
description: With summer upon us, weekenders will be streaming out of the city heading for New England beaches, lakes and mountains and warmweather outdoor fun in the days ahead. And whatever their favorite relaxation may be, there is one delight they all can shareeating. Here is a sampling of some landmark New England restaurants where food is plentiful, good and in some cases cheapincluding a few headquarters of regional trenchermen, champion eaters whom the uninitiated can challenge at the buffet tables at one's own risk. All are open year round.

title: After 16 Years, Downtown Albany's Empire State Plaza Is Completed
description: ALBANYSixteen years after construction started, the modernistic Empire State Plaza, covering 98 acres of downtown Albany, is now complete.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: On April 11, commemorating the first anniversary of the date he submitted his energy plan to Congress and attempting to encourage Congress to take positive action on his legislative proposals, President Carter indicated that of all the major countries in the world, the United States is the only one without a national energy policy. This sentiment Is widely shared  in the United States and abroad  but it is nevertheless not true.

title: Who Is Raising the Children?
description: A Great Neck mother has reported the establishment of what she and her friends consider the ideal childcare center for the schoolage children of working mothers. She described a neighborhood center, staffed with certified teachers, where children in grades K to 6 could play from 12:30 P.M. until 6 P.M. Such a system of child care seems ideal. until closer examination reveals that its implications to both society and education are ominous.

title: Patricia Comstock Wed to W. L. Zeile
description: Patricia Mary Comstock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Comstock of Lvrgo, Fla., was married May 20 to William Laurence Zeile, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Walter Lewis Zeile of Basking Ridge, N.J. The ceremony took place in the Cathedral of the Assumption of Our Lady in Manzini, Swaziland.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: A Visit to a Cemetery in Northport Gives Fifth Graders Lesson on Early History
description: NORTHPORT, L.I.  Up a road near the Long Island Lighting Company generating plant, in a clearing that is so hidden by trees and bushes that one Would walk right past it unless he were aware of it, there is a site that a teacher has turned into an outdoor classroom where he can teach his fifth graders history, arithmetic, archeology, botany and art.

title: Brzezinski Gave Details to China On ArmsTalks With Soviet Union
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Zbigniew Brzezinski and his aides gave Chinese officials an unprecedented, detailed briefing on the status of SovietAmerican strategic arms talks and explained at length the contents of some secret White House memorandums on American security goals, Administration officials said today

title: P.L.0. Pledges to Halt Firing on Israel From Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27As Israeli troops prepare to complete their withdrawal from Lebanon by June 13, the Palestine Liberation Organization has pledged to freeze all shelling of Israel from Lebanese territory and it will try to curb guerrilla infiltration In the area, at least until the Israeli withdrawal, acccording to Zuheir Monsen, head of the P.L.O.'s military arm.

title: Before the Casinos, When Bingo Was It
description: RUTHERFORD NIGHTS at 9, the Erie train would rush in and drop off the newspapers. In the glare on the Rutherford platform, the fuzzy cord would be cut, the bundles broken, the papers apportioned.

title: The Majesty of It
description: EDINBURGH  Princess Margaret divorced: Do the state and nation of Britain quiver on their pedestal? No, but the British monarchy quivers a little. A flake of virtue, the preservative enamel that has encased the human bodies of the Royal family so effectively since Queen Victoria's time, has fallen to the ground.

title: Sports Editor's ailbox: Soft Landing I Electrified Basketball Rim
description: With all of the emphasis on the effect of the fiberglass pole on polevaulting records ('Can Technology Win the Game? April 2,1), little is ever said about the equally great impact of foamrubber landing mats. These landing pits came into being at about the same time as the fiberglass pole. L; Prior to that, the landing area was sawdust, and a vaulter had to land feet first or risk serious injury.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Gloomy forecasts, emanating from Washington as well as Wall Street, about prospects for higher consumer prices, higher interest rates and higher inflation rates combined last week to send the stock market decidedly lower.

title: CHESS
description: The Danish grandmaster Bent Larsen has always preferred the rapier to the bludgeon, yet no opponent can leave out of consideration those occasions when he is willing to involve himself in a knockdown, dragout brawl.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: VIVIEN LEIGH, by Anne Edwards. (Pocket, $2.50.) The troubled, in some ways tragic life of the English actress and beauty who will always be remembered as Scarlett O'Hara. Our reviewer praised Anne Edwards for the kind of agonized tenderness she extended her subject, but regretted the penny dreadfulness into which her style sometimes lapses. A best seller in hardcover.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Alison J. MacIntosh Is Engaged to Brian McMahon
description: The engagement of Alison Jane MacIntosh to Brian James McMahon has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David MacIntosh of Florham Park and Haven Beach, N.J., parents of the bridetobe. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. McMahon of Chatham, N.J., and Hillsboro Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for the fall.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  From the start, the investigation into the breakins by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has involved a good deal of fingerpointing and blameshifting. All the way up the line, agents and their supervisors have been saying that their superiors, with proper authority, had told them that bag jobs must be performed. The pattern held last week when the three men indicted on charges of authorizing those breakins suggested in pretrial motions that the persons actually responsible included people outside the reach of law: two former highlevel bureau officials who are dead and a former President who has been granted a pardon.

title: Notes: Corroborees, Kites, Country Fairs
description: Sumer is icumen in, ihude sing cuccu, quoth the poetand cuckoo indeed the season ahead promises to be, judging from the way country fairs are blossoming, boomerang festivals are booming and kiteflying contests are soaring throughout the United States.

title: A Long Weekend
description: It started as Decoration Day in the 1860's because it was the day that the graves of Civil War soldiers were decorated with flowers. It became Memorial Day in the 1880's, and as other wars and other generations followed, the 30th of May was established as a day of patriotic oratory and commemorative services.

title: Martha Patterson Gilmore Is Engaged to Mark Saylor
description: Mr. and Mrs. John V. Gilmore of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Patterson Gilmore, to Mark Julian Saylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Saylor of San Bernardino, Calif.

title: Rockets, Da
description: I FIRST encountered the name Zhores Medvedev in 1969, when an extraordinary book that he wrote  The Rise and Fall of T. D. Lysenko  arrived at The New Yorker for review. It had been circulating clandestinely in the Soviet Union in a samizdat version and had come into the possession of an American geneticist, I. Michael Lerner, who translated it and arranged for publication. The publication led to terrible difficulties for Mr. Medvedev in the Soviet Union. In 1973, while he was on a trip to Britain, his citizenship was revoked and he is now associated with the National Institute for Medical Research in London.

title: Aides Lobby to Keep 3 Programs Out of a Department of Education
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  President Carter's proposal to form a Department of Education is generating controversy, not over whether the Cabinetlevel agency should be created, but over whether three key programs should be excluded from the new department.

title: Topics
description: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former Prime Minister, is appealing his conviction for having ordered the murder of a political opponent. There are indications that the Pakistani Supreme Court will soon uphold the conviction  and the death sentence that accompanied it. And informed Pakistanis predict that General Mohammad Zia ulflaq, who heads the socalled martial law government that rook over from Mr. Bhutto, will have the sentence carried out within hours of the verdict.

title: Life With Father, Duke Ellington
description: THE problem with [Duke] Ellington, Ralph J. Gleason once wrote, was always that he was so much more than he seemed, so many things at once. This is true, although not everyone will view it as a problem. We shall not try, however, to consider all that he was, particularly the things that were seen and known by his large and admiring public: his charm, graciousness, wit, elegance, sophistication, dignity, and his position as perhaps the greatest composer of American music. These have been covered well enough in the wide Duke Ellington literature that exists  notably Stanley Dance's The World of Duke Ellington, Derek Jewell's Duke: A Portrait of Duke Ellington, Duke's own Music Is My Mistress, and the commentaries of Whitney Balliet, Albert Murray, Nat Hentoff, John Wilson and of Ralph Gleason.

title: Suspicious Yonkers Fire Injures 15 And Heavily Damages 4 Buildings
description: YONKERS, May 27 ( AP)A sus picious threealarm fire swept through four apartment buildings here last night, injuring 15 firefighters and driving 80 people from their homes.

title: ART
description: ROSLYN EVER since paper became widely used medium in the early Renaissance, artists have taken it for granted. It was simply means for them to express their visual ideas, an insignificant backdrop for significant pictorial event.

title: Briitsh Defuse World War II Bomb
description: COVENTRY, England, May 27 (Reuters)  British Army experts defused a 1,000pound German bomb today that had been buried on a schoolground since World War II. The bomb was found yesterday by workmen building an extension.

title: Bulldozing the Past
description: THE remains of one of New Jersey's earliest established colonies literally is disappearing from the face of the earth.

title: On Choosing a Companion
description: Choosing a travel companion is at least as precarious as choosing a marriage partner. The chances of success are perhaps even less. The initial stages of both journeys are filled with enthusiasms, indulgences and a fairly consistent closing of the eyes to that which may later become, if not unacceptable, at the very least unpalatable.

title: Buses That Bend Are Attracting Gazes and Praises
description: ALHAMBRA, Calif., May 22Not long ago, drivers on the San Bernardino Freeway here were startled by the sight of a oversized red bus cruising toward the Los Angeles suburbs bending like an accordion in the middle as it rounded curves.

title: Sonics Rely on Webster To Gain Playoff Edge
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 27For a look at tomorrow's third game of the National Basketball Association championship series between the Seattle SuperSonies at the Capital Centre, listen to Paul Silas:

title: Long Beach Threatens to Remove a Hospital's Antenna If It Fails to Pay Its $108,000 Water Bill
description: LONG BEACH, L.I.An eightfoothigh whip antenna atop City Hall here is being used as the latest weapon in this city's battle with Long Beach Memorial Hospital over an unpaid $108,000 water bill.

title: INTERVIEW
description: LOTS of people grow up wanting to become novelists. Some of them do. But few have three novels come out in a single year. One of those few is Robert De Maria. Spring, summer and fall of 1978 are seeing the publication Ly Harcourt BraceJove Books of three of his works of fiction.

title: James Clemente, Exporter, Marries Gail E. Turnbull
description: Gail Elizabeth Turnbull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hamilton Turnbull, was married yesterday to James Clemente, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Clemente. Both families are of Pelham, N.Y. The Rev. Donald R. Kocher performed the ceremony in the huguenot Memorial Church (Presbyterian) in Pelham

title: The Year
description: WHITE PLAINS YESTERDAY, in the city of Rye, the sound of drums ushered in the Memorial Day weekend. Marchers in Mount Kisco and Yonkers will be stepping off today. For those in Mount Vernon and Peekskill, it will be tomorrow. And on Tuesday it will be the turn of White Plains and New Rochelle, just to mention a few communities.

title: SENATE FINANCE UNIT TO CONSIDER DELUCA
description: ALBANY, May 27The Senate Fiance Committee will consider Governor Carey's controversial nomination of John R. DeLuca as director of the State Division of Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse following an unusual maneuver by the Senate Mental Hygiene Committee to push the nomination along.

title: PEOPLE
description: In 1975, Roy L. Ash said he wasn't going back to industry when he resigned as director of the Office of Management and Budget under President Gerald R. Ford. Referring to his twoyear stint with O.M.B., Mr. Ash said, Anything else is going to be anticlimactic.

title: Molly Ferbert Wed To Dr. M. A. Posner
description: Holly Jane Ferbert, daughter of Sarah J. Knaub of Lincolnshire, Ill., and Edward A. Ferbert of Short Hills, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Martin Allan Posner, a New York surgeon. Civil Court Judge Francis Pecora performed the ceremony at the Carlyle.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTIQUES
description: ATLANTIC CITY EVERYONE here next weekend will not be a gambler. There will be a major show and sale of antiques at Convention Hall, and on the Boardwalk it may be hard to tell the antiquers from the bettors.Irene Stella, who is running the show, reports that upward of 250 dealers of finequality antiques and collectibles will be displaying all categories, from the finest porcelains, art works, bronzes and jewelry to collections of dolls, antique advertising items and Americana. She estimates that $5 million in antiques will be offered for sale.

title: Rabbi Philip Bregman Fiance of Cathy Netter
description: Mrs. Ivan J. Netter of Eastchester, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Cathy Lyn Netter, to Rabbi Philip Lawrence Bregman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel E. Bregman of Toronto.

title: A Mother Of 10 Aids Her Peers
description: RUTHERFORD FOR the last three years, Kay Willis has been traveling around North Jersey, telling young mothers that they are doing an important job and that motherhood is a valid career.

title: Disclosures Bring Renewal of Efforts On Korea Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 27Leon Jaworski, the Special Counsel to the House ethics committee, managed to spark at least a temporary revival of the Korean investigation this week.

title: FOOD
description: FREEPORT YOU can buy fish in every town on the Island, but the most colorful market of all is in Freeport, where dockside places line Woodcleft Canal, the nautical mile. This is a busy commercial fish and boat area seasoned with authentic salt. You can combine serious shopping with an interesting outing.

title: FISHING
description: THE water may be cold, but the fishing is hot, and the outlook for the Island's anglers is bright. The blues are back. Patches of bluefish on their northward migration are on the move along the South Shore and around Montauk, with vast schools of 8to12pounders reported off southern New Jersey.

title: A Father Tests a Fifth Generation As Master Guitar Maker on L.I.
description: FARMINGVILLE, L.I.Andrew Tatay guides the hands of his 13yearold son, James, as he teaches him how to join the neck of a guitar to the body. They adjust the piece until it has the proper feel because that certain kind of instinct is what Mr. Tatay says makes a craftsman different from a mechanic.

title: NEW YORK CITY AGENCIES CITED FOR ENERGY WASTE
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin of New York City, an unannounced candidate for State Comptroller, has charged that more than $19 million is being wasted each year because energyconservation measures in city buildings were not being enforced.

title: Ozymandias
description: LEXINGTON, KY. On a winter afternoon as brown as the dingy sheep driven early to fold down the high street beyond the darkening garden, a gentleman banker from London, Horace Smith by name, is sitting in the long library of a pleasant house in the village of Marlow, a few miles up the Thames from Henley. He is writing a sonnet.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The interesting article To Thatch a Roof, Take Phragmites...  [April 23] needs one correction. As a professional restorationist on the Island for the last 25 years, I believe I should point out the error in the quoted statement that there's no record of thatched roofs being built here among the English settlers.

title: ,Crowds in Rest of Atlantic City Are Sparse, but Casino Is Packed
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 27Thousands of gamblersmany dedicated, some frustrated, a few remunerated  jammed themselves and their money into the Resorts International Hotel casino here today, as legalized gambling appeared to be taking a firm hold on the public's pocketbooks and wallets.

title: ANTIQUES
description: There are formidable temptations ahead for those with a tasteesoteric though it may befor medieval, Gothic and Renaissance works of art. The sort of European bronzes, ivories, enamels, wood carvings, glass and ceramics that survive were always rare. But since the 1930's, the scarcity of this material has brought to a near halt any major collecting by individuals or museums.

title: MUSIC
description: I MUST tell you, Patricia Brooks was saying, it's wonderful to be able to let go of the performing, to stop worrying about managers and press agents, to start leading a normal life after 24 years of a career. Suddenly it's all right that I'm getting older and it doesn't matter that my fingernails don't look so marvelous, and I can let go the false eyelashes, and I don't have to look absolutely ravishing when I step outside my house to go to the A&P. I adored my singing, but I love my teaching now just as much. In fact, in a very real way, I found a new kind of happiness.

title: ALINE FRUHAUF
description: WASHINGTON, May 27Aline Fruhauf, a caricaturist of personalities in art, music, literature and theater, died today in Bethesda, Md. She was 71 years old.

title: N.F.L. Offenses May Turn to 3 Backs
description: The increasing efficiency and use of the threefour defense (three linemen, four linebackers) will bring a response in the coming pro football season from offenses in the form of some plays utilizing three running backs rather than two.

title: MEMORIAL DAY
description: Tomorrow

title: On Your Mark, Get Set . . . Run
description: LIKE the legion of joggers who have taken to roads, tracks and parks, running clubs have proliferated in the state in recent years, and you don't have to be able to better five minutes  or even 10 minutes  in the milerun to qualify for membership. The only requisite for membership in most clubs is a desire to run for fun or on a competitive level. And one's times are not important.

title: How to Retire at 29 With $20 Million
description: THE world of narcotics has always taken a heavy toll of users, traffickers and crooked cops. But writers have not fared very well on the lethal stuff, either. Authors, many of whom should have known better, have overdosed on the astoldto tales excons and exnarks or have succumbed to the opiate of foundation grants and Federal studies. Donald Goddard, the author of Easy Money, has avoided all of the usual pitfalls. He has amplified what could have been yet another tedious astoldto tale of a failed cocaine courier into a fascinating book large enough to include the closest look so far at Frank Matthews, perhaps the most powerful narcotics wholesaler in the country in 1972.

title: Few Scars for ExHanoi POW's
description: LOS ANGELES, May 27Five years after they came home from North Vietnam, almost 300 former prisoners of war, many of them now beginning to show the paunch and gray hair of middle age, were reunited here this weekend for the first time.

title: FISHING
description: THE water may be cold, but the fishing is hot and the outlook for the New Jersey angler is bright.

title: DINING OUT
description: CAPO D'ACQUA is a beautiful addition to Southampton. Inside the spare Colonial gray clapboard building, which was originally intended to be an antiques shop, is an elegant dining room with a charming Mediterranean accent. You wouldn't mind a room or two like this down at the beach for yourself.

title: Questions Answers
description: The roots of three young trees: a birch, maple and poplar on our front lawn are suddenly appearing above ground. I have been told that covering them with topsoil would be harmful. What can we do? A.M.D., Fredonia, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth J. Bacon Fiancee of Lawyer
description: Robert Bacon of Woods Hole, Mass., who retired from the State Department as a Foreign Service officer, and Katharine Jay Bacon of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Jay Bacon, to Frank Luke McNamara Jr., an associate with the Boston law firm of Choate, Hall & Stewart.

title: Bad News for Banks
description: The nation's multinational banks got dose of bad news last week. One monetary official questioned the notion of a freetrade zone for New York City with tax advantages for banks and another announced plans for more concentrated regulation of the big banks.

title: New Idea for Old Pets:
description: CALVERTON THE founding director of the animal shelter and clinic here that have already attracted national attention has announced plans for another innovation in animal care a retirement home for dogs and cats.

title: Atlantic City Gladly Shows Its Openers
description: At last, the pleasure/pain principles of gambling could be legally practiced in Atlantic City. And business for the Memorial Day weekend seemed every bit as good as expected.

title: Eliza Bergman Bride Of Michael S. Condon, RestaurantConsultant
description: In the Palisades (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday Eliza Mary Jane Bergman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Bergman of New York, was married to Michael Stevens Condon, son of Anne Gerety and Richard Stevens Condon, both of New York. The Rev. Harriet Fay H. Elison performed the ceremony.

title: Tom Wolfe, Author, Weds Sheila Berger
description: Sheila Berger, art director of Harper's magazine, was married yesterday to Tom Wolfe, author and journalist, Justice Theodore R. Kupferman, Appellate Division, State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony at Mr. Wolfe's home in Manhattan.

title: Velasquez Wins Acorn On 92 Shot
description: Lou Rodinello who trains Darby Dan's Tempest Queen, plotted the strategy for the 3yearold daughter of Graustark carefully as he sent his filly out to compare in the $53,200 Acorn at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: DrugRehabilitation Center's Planned Move to Plainview Complex Drawing Community Opposition
description: In a small corner of the old Mitchel Field complex, which now serves primari y as the Nassau Community College campus, 63 young people live and work together with 18 staff members in an effort to help themselves resolve their chronic drug problems and return to society.

title: The Politics Of Politics
description: WHITE PLAINS ALTHOUGH the confrontation between County Executive Alfred B. DelBello and the Board of Legislators over the county solidwaste disposal plan grows out of some genuine differences over technological, environmental and financial issues, the engine driving the dispute is essentially political.

title: Jerome Weidman: Novel and Novelist.
description: UNTIL now, I had thought of Jerome Weidman as a kind of Dtrain John O'Hara with a rather overfamiliar message. It's no longer news that some of the wicked flourish because they started out as patsies in the Bronx. It was news when Mr. Weidman chronicled one such sweaty ascendancy in I Can Get It for You Wholesale back in 1937. I remember finding the very brutishness of that book masterful. And, though I haven't really followed Mr. Weidman's work in detail, it was my impression that he had often repeated himself, perhaps too often.

title: Misery's Company
description: Liberal middleclass writers on poverty, if they are being at all fictive, seem to imply an equation: their misery and our misery must have something to do with each other. They are poor, undisciplined, unruly, ungrateful, often criminal; we were unhappy children, neurotics, bad lovers, chain smokers: couldn't we please get together to do something about such a mess?

title: Future Events
description: Tickets t the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: Drug Program Shift Draws Protests
description: IN a small corner of the old Mitchel Field complex, which now serves primarily as the Nassau Community College campus, 63 young people live and work together with 18 staff members in an effort to help themselves resolve their chronic drug problems and return to society.

title: Thomas Mark Weds Melissa W. Sargent
description: Melissa Weir Sargent, daughter of Mrs. Webb Sargent of Madison, Conn., and J. Weir Sargent Jr. of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Erik Mark. son of Mr. and Mrs Arne E. Mark of Riverside, Conn. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Bradford Hastings.

title: Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard Begin New Fight for Representation
description: BOSTON, May 27 (AP)With threats of secession long since forgotten; legislators from Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard have begun what could be a long battle to restore their islands' representation at the Statehouse.

title: King Merritt, at 82, Was Known For Development of Mutual Funds
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., May 27 (AP)King Merritt, known for his development of mutual funds, died today of cancer. He was 82 years old.

title: Gail B. Phelps Fiancee Of Geoffrey L. Bradford
description: The engagement of Gail Bransford Phelps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Russell Phelps of Washington, to Geoffrey Laurence Bradford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis E. Bradford of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents. The wedding will take place on June 18.

title: The New East Wing
Design
description: Whether summer means sitting pretty in a palatial summer villa. or roughing it in a beach bungalow, there are a number of essentials that will make life easier for everyone. But it is essential that they be welldesigned. For example, the new multifunctional chairs that snap together in two seconds cost little but look like a million dollars and will add some welcome style to a shabby rented house. So what if the dining table is too big or too small and lists badly whenever a guest places an elbow on it? Inexpensive. but wellexecuted, flatware and dinnerware can dress up the table and give class to the most humble of dinners. And even though one may be glad to get away from television, music is always welcome  especially when there are a number of comfortably portable minimusic systems to choose from. with such features as tape players for cassettes no bigger than a credit card. One's summer accommodations may not be as luxurious as one had hoped  the fireplace may smoke and the hot water may be fitful  but a few wellchosen, welldesigned additions can make almost any house a home at least until fall.

title: TV MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME CLINIC
description: POWER MOWERS, edging machines, garden tractors and other powerdriven yard and garden tools can save a lot of work for the homeowner, but they also can lead to lots of frustration and fail to perform as expected if they are not serviced periodically and otherwise not maintained properly.

title: The Last Great ArtistBallerina
description: Tamara Karsavina and Anna Pavlova were the twin stars of the Russian ballet firmament that exploded in the West shortly before World War I and from which our part of the world still has not recovered. The roles Karsavina created for Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes are danced today on every continent, and it was in large part because of the artistry of Karsavina and her partner, Vaslav Nijnsky, that the Ballets Russes had their fabled impact in Paris in 1909 and in London in 1911.

title: BRIDGE
description: THE RECENT feats of a golfing Player (Gary), in recovering from an apparently hopeless situation to win a major tournament, have been emulated this month by a group of Westchester bridgeplayers.

title: Luminous Melancholy, Fantastical Wit
description: I DEAL readers probably ignore blurbs. But reading John Hollander's, it is hard to miss a mounting anxiety from book to book as to how, whether and when this extremely gifted and, after all, wellknown and wellesteemed poet will finally culminate. When will this figure of importance become an important maker (now, now, says the blurb), promulgate a major event, grow hauntingly inevitable and reveal the full scope and emergent power of a central poet.

title: Ellyn Sue Roth Fiancee Of Lawrence Mittman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Roth of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellyn Sue Roth, to Lawrence Mittman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mittman of New York. A fall wedding is planned.

title: TV VIEW
description: Certain schools of analysis maintain that television programming is only the secondary filler between commercials. The medium is in the business of delivering viewers to advertisers. thus making audience ratings the ultimate arbiters of survival. Like most seductive theories, this one is too neat to be completely true. It ignores. among other things, the longlived existence of lowrated news documentaries or the bulk of public television. But, allowing for reservations, only the incurably innocent would underestimate the power of the sponsor's message. It can obtrude, distract, badger, irritate, amuse, convince or alienate. And, often thoroughly researched and expensively produced. it's always there, several times an hour, shamelessly plucking on our behavioral chords.

title: How the Coaches Voted
description: Tom Landry, DallasShula, Grant, Allen.

title: CARTER AND GROMYKO REPORT SOME GAINS ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union concluded an extensive round of talks with President Carter and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today, with both, sides reporting limited gains toward a new agreement to limit strategic arms and sharp differences over Africa and human rights.

title: MORE FUNDS SENT ABROAD BY PALLOTTINE FATHERS
description: BALTIMORE, May 27 (AP)The Pallottine Fathers, who once operated one of the country's largest directmail charity operations, have substantially increased the amount of charity funds sent oversees, according to a new audit.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Letters: Perils for walkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Heavy Flooding in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 27 (AP)Widespread flooding has destroyed about 8,000 houses and driven thousands of people from their homes in Sylhet, a major teaproducing district in Bangladesh, officials reported today.

title: Elizabeth Keating Fiancee Of William Carter, Writer
description: Elizabeth Ann Keating and William John Carter, writer and television critic for The Baltimore Sun, plan to be married July 8.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON New StudentAid Plan Proposed
description: IN the academic year now coming to a close, 56,000 New Jerseyans attended college with the aid of the Federal Guaranteed Student Loan Program. This is a record high for New Jersey participation in the program, which Congress established in 1965.

title: Georgia's Golden Isles
description: When President Carter wants seriously to relax from the pressures of his Washington job, he flies to his native Georgia and goes fishing on one of its sea islands. Afloat on a freshwater pond and using a long cane pole, the President angles for bluegill, bream and shellcrackers, another member of the sunfish family, the fish he likes most to catch. Nothing, it is said, refreshes him more than such a trip. Certainly the setting is eminently restful, almost dreamily so.

title: Which Way to the Quagmire?
description: What, if anything, is the Carter Administration up to in Africa? Does even President Carter know? In view of the following record of events and statements, does anyone?

title: Panatta Wins in Rome as Fans Rattle Higueras
description: ROME, May 27 (UPI)  Adriano Panatta of Italy gained a spot today against Bjorn Borg in tomorrow's men's finals of the Italian tennis open with the help of 10,000 hooting and heckling fans who drove his semifinal opponent, Jose Higueras of Spain, off the court.

title: Controversy With China Discounted
description: Charges of political shenanigans against the Chinese in connection with a canceled volleyball tour were unjustified, officials of the National Committee on United StatesChina Relations said yesterday.

title: A First Novel For a Grandmother
description: SOUTH ORANGE IT was the type of overnight success story that one usually finds only in a movie theater: A first novel that was accepted by a large publishing house, a third printing only a week after its release and its selection by the Literary Guild (and alternate selection by the Jewish Book Club) for May.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MAY 28, 1978

title: HIGH ADVENTURE WITH A MASTER
description: It is 4 A.M. Claude Jaccoux's alarm watch has just gone off. I have been up for what seems like hours, prowling around the Rifugio Franco Monzino, high on the Italian side of Mont Blanc. (Poor Franco Monzinohe lies buried somewhere in these mountains; his family gave the money for the hut. Hut? It is more like a hotel. Last night we had clean sheets.) Having checked the weather every hour or so, I can tell Jaccoux that it looks good when he finally stirs himself. Years of climbing with Jaccoux have made it clear to me that there is no point in letting him know that his alarm has gone off. He is a professional guide and he will be ready when it is time to leave the refuge. We all have our nocturnal rhythms. In the mountains mine are rather feral, and I go about the business of getting ready.

title: GARDENING
description: EVERYONE loves a rose  except, perhaps, when impaled while pruning  but to love the flower is to accept its thorns as well. Not that everyone will choose to grow roses. They do require greater than average attention when compared with other garden flowers, so, if easy gardening is your goal, you'd better stick to marigolds and petunias. However, to the rose addict, a garden of roses coming into flower in June is a part of the substance of life itself.

title: R. 0. Schwab Fiance Of Jennifer P. Casey
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Paul Casey of Grosse PoIota, Mich, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Paul Casey, to Richard Oliver Schwab, son of Mrs. Oliver M. Gale and Nelson Schwab Jr., both of Cincinnati.

title: GARDENING
description: MAY is a marvelous month. Everything bursts into bloom and the memories of that long and arduous winter have faded. Almost.

title: 15Cent Postage Rate Takes Effect Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, May 27The price of mailing a domestic letter will increase from 13 cents to 15 cents at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

title: Flotation Devices
description: ALBANY  Not since 1975 had Governor Carey waded into New York City's fiscal problems in such a highly visible and highly risky way as he did last week.

title: Untying the President's Hands
description: The image of a President t tying to du good with one hand tied behind his back by Congress elicits sympathy. Jimmy Carter seized on that sympathy shrewdly last week as he noted the bloody events in Zaire and portrayed himself as hobbled in his desire to help independent African governments resist Soviet and Cuban pressure.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KANSAS CITY, Ma., May 27 (UPI)The Big Eight Conference, acting on recruiting violations by Kansas State, imposed today a fourpart penalty against the university, including the deprivation of 20 scholarships during the next three years.

title: Trailways Assails Operation of Depot After 2 Are Slain
description: A day after a Part Authority police officer and his assailant were slain and two bystanders were wounded in the midtown bus terminal, the president of the Trailways Bus System yesterday assailed conditions in the terminal, saying that the Port Authority has some hard questions to answer.

title: Kate Proctor Plans to Wed
description: Mrs. James Wilson Riley Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.. and William Ross Proctor Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathleen Patricia Proctor. to Wesley Robertson Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard W. Brooks of Greenwich.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Health. If you should happen by the Peachtree Street side of Atlanta's Hyatt Regency Hotel early any morning this weekend, you'll see an odd sight  a cluster of bookish types attending the American Booksellers Association convention, decked out in Tshirts and track shoes, getting ready to start on a fun run. It's part of a celebration Bantam Books is staging for a half dozen of its paperbacks about running. Three of these, the work of Dr. Kenneth H. Cooper, a Texas physician, have a total of 5,341,000 copies in print and are among the biggest sellers on the house's backlist.

title: THE PERPLEXING MR. PROXMIRE
description: With New York facing bankruptcy by hands of one of the greatest eccentrics midsummer, it is the city's destiny to have its fate in the in the entire history of the United States Senate.

title: Symphony Orchestras Turning to Pop Artists
description: Los ANGELES America's trim and proper symphony orchestraswhich have often been accused of refusing to acknowledge the 20th centuryhave recently and unexpectedly leapt light years beyond it. More than 80 major regional, metropolitan and oommunity orchestras will be performing John Williams's Star Wars Suite this yearcomplete with laser lights, fireworks and heavily ampiffled sound.

title: Gambling Spurs a Yacht Race
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE advent of casino gambling here will spur the introduction of a variety of events, all of which are expected to breathe new life into this longdowntrodden resort.

title: Gov. Blanton of Tennessee Says He Will Not Run for ReElection
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 27 (AP)Gov. Ray Blanton told a crowd of 2,000 Democratic supporters today that he would not run for reelection.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Fashion
description: Jeans. They're a phenomenon that goes on and on and on. They're blue, theyre red, they're white, they're skintight, they're baggy, they're faded, they're stiff, they're pleated, they're pocketed, they're zippered, they're cuffed, they're uncuffed, they're embroidered, they're plain, and they're in just about every closet in the Western world.

title: The Sleeping Beauty With Cynthia Gregory
description: So Tchaikovsky has done it again. All the glories of his miraculous score for The Sleeping Beauty swept through the Metropolitan Opera House Friday night and carried the ballerina in its title role to veritable heights of triumph.

title: Condominiums: An Adventure
description: SECAUCUS WELL, Phil Kieffer gets to fly his flags  America's, California's, New Jersey's and whatever other ones he chooses, including, probably, a newly ordered Secaucus banner  in front of his condominium in the Harmon Cove complex in this Hudson County town.

title: Weddings
description: CammarataZumoff

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: The Syrian Panels Can Still Be Seen

title: Dixie: A New Tune for the Unions
